origin: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak’st.
modern: I have half a mind to hit you before you speak again.

origin: Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, I’ll set thee in a shower of gold and hail Rich pearls upon thee.
modern: But if Antony is alive, healthy, friendly with Caesar, and not Caesar’s prisoner, I’ll shower you with gold and pearls.

origin: Madam, he’s well.
modern: Madam, he’s well.

origin: Well said.
modern: That’s well spoken.

origin: And friends with Caesar.
modern: And he’s friendly with Caesar.

origin: Th’ art an honest man.
modern: You are an honest man.

origin: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.
modern: Caesar and he are better friends than ever.

origin: Make thee a fortune from me.
modern: I’m going to make you a rich man.

origin: But yet, madam— I do not like “But yet.” It does allay The good precedence.
modern: But yet, madam— I don’t like the sound of “but yet.” It reverses all the good that came before it.

origin: Fie upon “But yet.” “But yet” is as a jailer to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor.
modern: Damn those words, “but yet!” “But yet” is like a jailer about to bring out some horrible criminal.

origin: Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together.
modern: Please, my friend, give me all the news, both good and bad, at the same time.

origin: He’s friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.
modern: You say he’s friendly with Caesar, healthy, and free.

origin: Free, madam, no.
modern: I didn’t say free, madam.

origin: I made no such report.
modern: No, I didn’t say that.

origin: He’s bound unto Octavia.
modern: He’s bound to Octavia.

origin: For what good turn?
modern: For what favor?

origin: For the best turn i’ th’ bed.
modern: For the favor of sleeping in her bed.

origin: I am pale, Charmian.
modern: I’m sick, Charmian.

origin: Madam, he’s married to Octavia.
modern: He’s married to Octavia, madam.

origin: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
modern: May you die of the worst disease!

origin: Good madam, patience.
modern: Good madam, be patient.

origin: What say you?
modern: What did you say to me?

origin: Hence, horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me!
modern: Get out, you horrible bastard, or I’ll gouge out your eyes.

origin: I’ll unhair thy head!
modern: I’ll scalp you.

origin: Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine, Smarting in ling’ring pickle!
modern: I’ll have you whipped with wire and soaked in brine like a pickle, making your pain linger.

origin: Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee And make thy fortunes proud.
modern: If you say it isn’t true, I’ll give you a province and make you rich.

origin: The blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage, And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.
modern: The blows I gave you already will make up for your upsetting me.

origin: He’s married, madam.
modern: He’s married, madam.

origin: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
modern: Rogue, you’ve lived too long!

origin: Nay then, I’ll run.
modern: No way, then, I’ll run.

origin: What mean you, madam?
modern: What’s the matter with you, madam?

origin: I have made no fault.
modern: I haven’t done anything to you.

origin: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.
modern: Good madam, restrain yourself.

origin: The man is innocent.
modern: The man hasn’t done anything wrong.

origin: Some innocents ’scape not the thunderbolt.
modern: Even innocents cannot always escape disaster.

origin: Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents.
modern: May Egypt drown in the Nile and all good creatures turn into poisonous snakes.

origin: Call the slave again.
modern: Call that servant back.

origin: Though I am mad, I will not bite him.
modern: Even though I’m mad, I won’t bite him.

origin: Call!
modern: Call him!

origin: He is afeard to come.
modern: He’s afraid to come in.

origin: I will not hurt him.
modern: I won’t hurt him.

origin: These hands do lack nobility that they strike A meaner than myself, since I myself Have given myself the cause.
modern: My hands are tainted if they hit an inferior, especially since I myself am the cause of my own distress.

origin: Come hither, sir.
modern: Come here, sir.

origin: Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news.
modern: It may be honest, but it’s never wise to bring bad news.

origin: Give to a gracious message An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.
modern: You can give good news in many ways, but let bad news interpret itself as you tell it.

origin: I have done my duty.
modern: I’ve only done my duty.

origin: Is he married?
modern: Is he married?

origin: The gods confound thee!
modern: May the gods destroy you!

origin: Dost thou hold there still?
modern: Do you maintain the same story?

origin: Should I lie, madam?
modern: Do you want me to lie, madam?

origin: Go, get thee hence.
modern: Go, get out!

origin: I crave your highness’ pardon.
modern: Even if you were as handsome as  I beg your highness’ pardon.

origin: He is married?
modern: Is he really married?

origin: Take no offense that I would not offend you.
modern: Please don’t be offended that I don’t want to offend you any more.

origin: To punish me for what you make me do Seems much unequal.
modern: It’s not fair to punish me for something you make me do.

origin: He’s married to Octavia.
modern: He’s married to Octavia.

origin: Oh, that his fault should make a knave of thee, That art not what th’ art sure of!
modern: It’s too bad that Antony’s fault should make you look like a jerk.

origin: Get thee hence.
modern: Go away.

origin: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me.
modern: The merchandise you bring from Rome is too expensive for me.

origin: Lie they upon thy hand And be undone by ’em!
modern: Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you.

origin: Good your highness, patience.
modern: Be patient, your highness.

origin: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.
modern: When I have praised Antony, I’ve disparaged Caesar.

origin: Many times, madam.
modern: Many times, madam.

origin: I am paid for ’t now.
modern: I’m being repaid for that now.

origin: Lead me from hence.
modern: Help me out of here.

origin: O Iras, Charmian!
modern: Oh, Iras, Charmian!

origin: Tis no matter.— Go to the fellow, good Alexas.
modern: It doesn’t matter.

origin: Bid him Report the feature of Octavia: her years, Her inclination.
modern: How old is she?

origin: Let him not leave out The color of her hair.
modern: Don’t let him leave out the color of her hair.

origin: Bring me word how tall she is.
modern: Bring me his answers quickly.

origin: Lead me to my chamber.
modern: Even though half of him is like a

origin: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, where’s the soothsayer that you praised so to th’ Queen?
modern: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost the most consummate Alexas, where’s the fortuneteller you recommended so highly to the Queen?

origin: Oh that I knew this husband, which, you say, must charge his horns with garlands!
modern: Oh, I only wish I knew the name of that husband you said he predicted will have a cheating wife!

origin: I make not, but foresee.
modern: I don’t make fortunes; I only see them.

origin: Pray, then, foresee me one.
modern: Then see a good one for me.

origin: No, you shall paint when you are old.
modern: No, he means you’ll use makeup when you’re old.

origin: Wrinkles forbid!
modern: May my wrinkles forbid that!

origin: Vex not his prescience.
modern: Don’t joke about his predictions.

origin: Be attentive.
modern: Pay attention.

origin: Hush!
modern: Quiet!

origin: You shall be more beloving than beloved.
modern: You will love more than you are loved.

origin: Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which, if thou hast considered, let us know If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.
modern: It’s proper that we speak first, which is why we sent our proposals ahead of us for your consideration.

origin: What was ’t That moved pale Cassius to conspire?
modern: Why did Cassius conspire against Caesar?

origin: Take your time.
modern: Take your time.

origin: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.
modern: Pompey, you cannot frighten us with your navy.

origin: We’ll speak with thee at sea.
modern: We’ll meet you at sea.

origin: At land, thou know’st How much we do o’ercount thee.
modern: Yes, on land you do outnumber me.

origin: At land indeed Thou dost o’ercount me of my father’s house, But since the cuckoo builds not for himself, Remain in ’t as thou mayst.
modern: Even more since you annexed my father’s house and lands.

origin: Be pleased to tell us— For this is from the present—how you take The offers we have sent you.
modern: But since,  To get back to the matter at hand, what do you think of our proposal?

origin: There’s the point.
modern: That’s the point.

origin: Which do not be entreated to, but weigh What it is worth embraced.
modern: Don’t let us talk you into anything, but consider carefully the value of our offers.

origin: You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia.
modern: You have offered me the lands of Sicily and Sardinia.

origin: And I must Rid all the sea of pirates, then, to send Measures of wheat to Rome.
modern: In return, I must clear the sea of pirates and send tributes of wheat to Rome.

origin: This ’greed upon To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted.
modern: If I agree to this, we may leave unharmed, with our shields undented.

origin: That’s our offer.
modern: That’s our offer.

origin: Know then I came before you here a man prepared To take this offer, but Mark Antony Put me to some impatience.
modern: You should know that when I came here I was prepared to accept your offer.

origin: Let me have your hand.
modern: Let me shake your hand.

origin: I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
modern: I didn’t think I would see you here.

origin: The beds i’ th’ East are soft, and thanks to you, That called me timelier than my purpose hither, For I have gained by ’t.
modern: The East is very seductive.

origin: Well, I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.
modern: Well, I cannot tell how my difficult life has weathered my face, but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage.

origin: Well met here.
modern: It’s good we had this meeting.

origin: I hope so, Lepidus.
modern: I hope it works out for the best, Lepidus.

origin: Thus we are agreed.
modern: So we are in agreement.

origin: That’s the next to do.
modern: That’s the next thing on the agenda.

origin: We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s Draw lots who shall begin.
modern: We’ll have celebration feasts for each other before we go our separate ways.

origin: That will I, Pompey.
modern: I’ll give the first one, Pompey.

origin: No, Antony, take the lot.
modern: No, Antony.

origin: But, first or last, Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have The fame.
modern: Whether your banquet is first or last, your Egyptian cooking will make it the best.

origin: I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.
modern: I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there.

origin: You have heard much.
modern: You’ve heard a lot.

origin: I have fair meanings, sir.
modern: I mean well, sir.

origin: And fair words to them.
modern: I’m sure you do.

origin: Then so much have I heard.
modern: I’ve heard a lot more.

origin: And I have heard Apollodorus carried—                                                                               What, I pray you?
modern: I heard that Apollodorus carried—   What did he carry, please?

origin: How far’st thou, soldier?
modern: How are you, soldier?

origin: Well, And well am like to do, for I perceive, Four feasts are toward.
modern: I’m well, and probably will be for a while, as I hear that four feasts are being prepared.

origin: Let me shake thy hand.
modern: Let me shake your hand.

origin: I never hated thee.
modern: I’ve never been your enemy.

origin: I have seen thee fight When I have envied thy behavior.
modern: I’ve seen you fight and envied your skill.

origin: Sir, I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did.
modern: Sir, I wouldn’t say I was your friend, but I’ve praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave.

origin: Enjoy thy plainness.
modern: Enjoy your frankness; it suits you.

origin: It nothing ill becomes thee.— Aboard my galley I invite you all.
modern: I invite you all aboard my ship.

origin: Will you lead, lords?
modern: After you, my lords?

origin: Show ’s the way, sir.
modern: Show us the way, sir.

origin: Come.
modern: Come with me.

origin: At sea, I think.
modern: I think it was at sea.

origin: We have, sir.
modern: That it was, sir.

origin: You have done well by water.
modern: You’ve done well at sea.

origin: And you by land.
modern: And you’ve done well on land.

origin: I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.
modern: I’ll flatter anyone who flatters me—though what I’ve accomplished on land cannot be denied.

origin: Nor what I have done by water.
modern: Neither can my accomplishments at sea.

origin: Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.
modern: Yes, for your own safety, you should deny one thing: you have been a great thief at sea.

origin: And you by land.
modern: As you were on land.

origin: There I deny my land service.
modern: That’s the one part of my service on land I do deny.

origin: But give me your hand, Menas.
modern: But let’s shake hands, Menas.

origin: If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.
modern: If our eyes were policemen, they might capture two thieves at once while we’re embracing.

origin: All men’s faces are true, whatsome’er their hands are.
modern: Men’s faces are truthful, whatever their hands do.

origin: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.
modern: But no beautiful woman has an honest face.

origin: No slander.
modern: That’s no lie.

origin: They steal hearts.
modern: They steal hearts.

origin: We came hither to fight with you.
modern: We came here to fight against you.

origin: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking.
modern: For my part, I’m sorry this battle turned into a drinking match.

origin: Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
modern: Today Pompey laughs away his fortune.

origin: If he do, sure he cannot weep ’t back again.
modern: If that’s true, he won’t get it back by crying.

origin: You’ve said, sir.
modern: That’s the truth, sir.

origin: We looked not for Mark Antony here.
modern: We didn’t expect Mark Antony to be here.

origin: Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?
modern: Is he married to Cleopatra?

origin: Caesar’s sister is called Octavia.
modern: Caesar’s sister is named Octavia.

origin: True, sir.
modern: That’s true, sir.

origin: She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.
modern: She was previously Caius Marcellus’ wife.

origin: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.
modern: But she is now Mark Antony’s wife.

origin: Pray ye, sir?
modern: Excuse me, sir?

origin: Tis true.
modern: It’s true.

origin: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.
modern: Then Caesar and he will always be united.

origin: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.
modern: If I were to make a prediction regarding this union, I wouldn’t say that.

origin: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.
modern: I think the marriage was made more for political reasons than for love.

origin: I think so too.
modern: I think so too.

origin: But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity.
modern: But you’ll see that the very thing that joins them will be the thing that separates them.

origin: Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
modern: Octavia has a pious, chaste, meek disposition.

origin: Who would not have his wife so?
modern: Doesn’t everyone want a wife like that?

origin: Not he that himself is not so, which is Mark Antony.
modern: Not someone who doesn’t share that disposition, meaning Mark Antony.

origin: He will to his Egyptian dish again.
modern: He’ll go back to his Egyptian dish.

origin: Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance.
modern: Then Octavia’s complaints will rouse Caesar, and as I said before, the thing that brought them together will part them.

origin: Antony will use his affection where it is.
modern: Antony will go where his passion is.

origin: He married but his occasion here.
modern: He only married out of political necessity.

origin: And thus it may be.
modern: Then that’s the way it may turn out.

origin: Come, sir, will you aboard?
modern: Come on, sir, will you come aboard?

origin: I have a health for you.
modern: I want to drink your health.

origin: I shall take it, sir.
modern: I’ll join you, sir.

origin: We have used our throats in Egypt.
modern: We did a lot of drinking in Egypt.

origin: Come, let’s away.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: Here they’ll be, man.
modern: Here’s where they’ll end up, on the floor.

origin: Some o’ their plants are ill-rooted already.
modern: Some of them are leaning already.

origin: Lepidus is high-colored.
modern: Lepidus is red in the face.

origin: They have made him drink alms-drink.
modern: They made him drink the leftover wine usually given to the poor.

origin: I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.
modern: I’d rather carry a reed that obviously can’t protect me than a sword I cannot lift.

origin: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile By certain scales i’ th’ Pyramid.
modern: This is how they do it, sir: they measure the depth of the Nile, according to certain marks made on the walls of the Pyramid.

origin: They know By th’ height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth Or foison follow.
modern: They know by those measurements if there will be famine or plenty.

origin: The higher Nilus swells The more it promises.
modern: The higher the Nile flows, the better the harvest.

origin: As it ebbs, the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain, And shortly comes to harvest.
modern: The harvest comes shortly after that.

origin: You’ve strange serpents there?
modern: Do you have unusual snakes there?

origin: Ay, Lepidus.
modern: Yes, Lepidus.

origin: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun.
modern: The Egyptian snake is born when the sun shines on the Nile mud, just like the crocodile.

origin: I am not so well as I should be, but I’ll ne’er out.
modern: I don’t feel so well, but I won’t stop.

origin: Not till you have slept.
modern: Not until you pass out.

origin: I fear me you’ll be in till then.
modern: I’m afraid you’ll keep going until then.

origin: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies’ pyramises are very goodly things.
modern: I’ve heard that the pyramids build by the Ptolemies are splendid.

origin: Without contradiction I have heard that.
modern: Without doubt I’ve heard that.

origin: What manner o’ thing is your crocodile?
modern: What does a crocodile look like?

origin: It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth.
modern: Sir, it’s shaped like itself and is as wide as it has width.

origin: It is just so high as it is, and moves with its own organs.
modern: It is only as high as it is and moves with its own legs.

origin: Of it own color too.
modern: Its own color.

origin: Tis a strange serpent.
modern: It’s a strange snake.

origin: Tis so.
modern: It is that.

origin: And the tears of it are wet.
modern: And its tears are wet.

origin: The matter?
modern: What is it?

origin: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.
modern: I’ve always had great respect for your destiny.

origin: Thou hast served me with much faith.
modern: You’ve served me faithfully.

origin: What’s else to say?—                                                          These quicksands, Lepidus, Keep off them, for you sink.
modern: What else can I say?

origin: What sayst thou?
modern: What are you saying?

origin: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world?
modern: Would you like to be king of the entire world?

origin: That’s twice.
modern: Now I’ve said it twice.

origin: How should that be?
modern: How could that happen?

origin: Nay, hear him.
modern: Just listen to him.

origin: Good now, some excellent fortune!
modern: Be kind now and tell me some excellent fortune.

origin: Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all.
modern: Tell me that I’ll marry three kings before noon and be widowed by all of them.

origin: Oh, excellent!
modern: Oh, excellent!

origin: Then belike my children shall have no names.
modern: Then my children will probably be illegitimate.

origin: Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?
modern: Tell me, please: how many boys and girls will I have?

origin: If every of your wishes had a womb, And fertile every wish, a million.
modern: If every time you wished for a child you could have had one, you would have a million children.

origin: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
modern: You seem to think no one outside of your bedroom knows what you wish.

origin: We’ll know all our fortunes.
modern: We’ll all want our fortune told.

origin: Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight, shall be—drunk to bed.
modern: My fortune—like that of many of us tonight—is to go drunk to bed.

origin: Hast thou drunk well?
modern: Are you drunk?

origin: No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
modern: No, Pompey, I haven’t had anything to drink.

origin: Show me which way.
modern: Tell me how.

origin: These three world-sharers, these competitors, Are in thy vessel.
modern: The three who share the known world are aboard your boat.

origin: All there is thine.
modern: Everything that belongs to them is yours.

origin: Ah, this thou shouldst have done And not have spoke on ’t!
modern: Oh, you should have done it without telling me!

origin: In me ’tis villainy, In thee ’t had been good service.
modern: For you to do it would be good service.

origin: Thou must know, ’Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor; Mine honor, it.
modern: You should know that to me, profit isn’t more important than honor, but the other way around.

origin: Repent that e’er thy tongue Hath so betrayed thine act.
modern: Regret that your mouth betrayed your actions.

origin: Being done unknown, I should have found it afterwards well done, But must condemn it now.
modern: But now I must condemn it.

origin: Desist, and drink.
modern: Give it up and go drink.

origin: This health to Lepidus!
modern: This toast is for Lepidus!

origin: Here’s to thee, Menas!
modern: Here’s to you, Menas.

origin: Enobarbus, welcome.
modern: I accept with thanks, Enobarbus.

origin: There’s a strong fellow, Menas.
modern: There goes a strong fellow, Menas.

origin: Why?
modern: Why do you say that?

origin: He bears The third part of the world, man.
modern: He carries a third of the world.

origin: Seest not?
modern: Can’t you see that?

origin: The third part, then, is drunk.
modern: Then a third of the world is drunk.

origin: Drink thou.
modern: Drink up.

origin: Come.
modern: All right, then.

origin: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
modern: This hasn’t reached the level of an Egyptian feast yet.

origin: It ripens towards it.
modern: It’s getting there.

origin: Strike the vessels, ho!
modern: Clink your cups together in a toast!

origin: Here’s to Caesar.
modern: Here’s to Caesar.

origin: I could well forbear ’t.
modern: I could do without another toast.

origin: Be a child o’ th’ time.
modern: Live in the moment.

origin: But I had rather fast from all four days Than drink so much in one.
modern: But I would rather abstain from everything for four days than drink so much in one.

origin: Let’s ha ’t, good soldier.
modern: Let’s have one, good soldier.

origin: Come, let’s all take hands Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense In soft and delicate Lethe.
modern: Come, let’s join our hands until the overpowering wine makes us soft and forgetful.

origin: All take hands.
modern: Everyone join hands.

origin: What needs more words?
modern: How can you top that?

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night, Pompey.

origin: And shall, sir.
modern: Yes, we will.

origin: Give ’s your hand.
modern: Let’s shake on it.

origin: We are friends.
modern: We’re friends!

origin: Come, down into the boat.
modern: Come, this way to the rowboat.

origin: Take heed you fall not.
modern: Be careful not to fall in.

origin: Menas, I’ll not on shore.
modern: Menas, I’m not going back on shore.

origin: No, to my cabin.
modern: No, come to my cabin.

origin: What!
modern: What do you say?

origin: There’s my cap.
modern: There’s my hat!

origin: Hoo!
modern: Hooray!

origin: Noble captain, come.
modern: Come on, noble captain.

origin: Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now Pleased fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death Make me revenger.
modern: Now I’ve paid you back, Parthia, and gotten revenge for Marcus Crassus’ death.

origin: For learn this, Silius: Better to leave undone than by our deed Acquire too high a fame when him we serve’s away.
modern: You must understand, Silius, that it’s better to leave something undone than achieve too much fame in your superior’s absence.

origin: Caesar and Antony have ever won More in their officer than person.
modern: Caesar and Antony have always achieved more by delegating authority to their officers than by leading their troops in person.

origin: Who does i’ th’ wars more than his captain can Becomes his captain’s captain; and ambition, The soldier’s virtue, rather makes choice of loss Than gain which darkens him.
modern: A man who achieves more in war than his captain does becomes his captain’s rival.

origin: I could do more to do Antonius good, But ’twould offend him, and in his offense Should my performance perish.
modern: I could do more to help Antony, but to do so would insult him.

origin: Thou hast, Ventidius, that Without the which a soldier and his sword Grants scarce distinction.
modern: A soldier is just a tool, like his sword, unless he has your qualities, Ventidius.

origin: Thou wilt write to Antony?
modern: Are you going to write Antony about this?

origin: I’ll humbly signify what in his name, That magical word of war, we have effected: How with his banners and his well-paid ranks The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o’ th’ field.
modern: I’ll write how, under his flag and with his well-paid troops, we have beaten the formerly unvanquished Parthia.

origin: Where is he now?
modern: Where’s Antony now?

origin: What, are the brothers parted?
modern: Did the brothers-in-law leave?

origin: They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
modern: They finished their business with Pompey, and Pompey has left.

origin: Octavia weeps To part from Rome.
modern: Octavia weeps at the thought of leaving Rome.

origin: Caesar is sad, and Lepidus, Since Pompey’s feast, as Menas says, is troubled With the greensickness.
modern: Caesar is in a sober mood.

origin: A very fine one.
modern: He’s a stylish man.

origin: Oh, how he loves Caesar!
modern: And how he loves Caesar!

origin: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!
modern: Yes, but how he adores Mark Antony!

origin: Caesar?
modern: Caesar?

origin: What’s Antony?
modern: Then what’s Antony?

origin: The god of Jupiter.
modern: A god of a god?

origin: Spake you of Caesar?
modern: Are you talking about Caesar?

origin: How, the nonpareil!
modern: He’s without equal!

origin: O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!
modern: Oh, Antony!

origin: Would you praise Caesar, say “Caesar.” Go no further.
modern: Oh, you  If you want to praise Caesar, just say his name—that’s all the praise that’s necessary.

origin: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
modern: He certainly flattered them both with extravagant compliments.

origin: But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony.
modern: He loves Caesar best, but he also loves Antony.

origin: Hoo!
modern: Oh!

origin: Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number—hoo!— His love to Antony.
modern: Hearts cannot think it, tongues cannot speak it, meas-urements cannot calculate it, scribes cannot write it, bards cannot sing it, and poets cannot make verses about it.

origin: Both he loves.
modern: He loves them both.

origin: They are his shards, and he
modern: They are his dung, and he their beetle.

origin: So, This is to horse.
modern: So, there’s the signal to ride.

origin: Adieu, noble Agrippa.
modern: Good-bye, noble Agrippa.

origin: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.
modern: Good luck, worthy soldier, and good-bye.

origin: No further, sir.
modern: You can’t go any further with us, sir.

origin: For better might we Have loved without this mean, if on both parts This be not cherished.
modern: If you and I don’t value her equally, it would be better for us to work out our differences without her.

origin: Make me not offended In your distrust.
modern: Don’t insult me with your distrust.

origin: I have said.
modern: I mean what I say.

origin: You shall not find, Though you be therein curious, the least cause For what you seem to fear.
modern: You won’t find any cause for anxiety, even if you look for one.

origin: So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
modern: So, may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support.

origin: We will here part.
modern: We’ll leave you here.

origin: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
modern: Good-bye, my dearest sister, good-bye.

origin: The elements be kind to thee and make Thy spirits all of comfort!
modern: I hope you have good weather to set your mind at ease.

origin: Fare thee well.
modern: Farewell.

origin: My noble brother!
modern: My noble brother!

origin: The April’s in her eyes; it is love’s spring, And these the showers to bring it on.
modern: Her eyes are like April: full of showers.

origin: What, Octavia?
modern: What is it, Octavia?

origin: I’ll tell you in your ear.
modern: I’ll tell you privately.

origin: Look, here I have you.
modern: See, now I have you.

origin: Thus I let you go And give you to the gods.
modern: And thus I let you go and give you to the gods.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Good-bye.

origin: Be happy.
modern: Be happy.

origin: Farewell, farewell.
modern: Farewell, farewell.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: E’en as the o’erflowing Nilus presageth famine.
modern: Like the  Oh stop it, you lusty bed-hopper.

origin: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.
modern: You can’t see the future.

origin: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear.—Prithee, tell her but a workaday fortune.
modern: Well, if a moist palm isn’t a clear sign of promiscuity, then I can’t scratch my own ear.

origin: Your fortunes are alike.
modern: Your fortunes are the same.

origin: But how, but how?
modern: But how?

origin: Give me particulars.
modern: Give me details.

origin: I have said.
modern: I’ve said what I have to say.

origin: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?
modern: Isn’t my fortune just a little better than hers?

origin: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?
modern: Well, if you could have just an inch of better fortune than me, where would you like the improvement?

origin: Not in my husband’s nose.
modern: Not in my husband’s nose.

origin: Our worser thoughts heavens mend.
modern: May heaven save us from indecent thoughts!

origin: Alexas!
modern: Alexas!

origin: For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded.
modern: If it’s sad to see a handsome man with a cheating wife, it’s a tragedy to see an ugly thug with a wife who’s faithful.

origin: Therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum, and fortune him accordingly.
modern: Therefore, dear Isis, do the right thing and give him the fortune he deserves.

origin: Where is the fellow?
modern: Where is that messenger?

origin: Half afeard to come.
modern: He’s afraid to come in.

origin: Go to, go to.—Come hither, sir.
modern: Oh, come on.—Come here, sir.

origin: Good majesty, Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you But when you are well pleased.
modern: Gracious Queen, even Herod of Judea wouldn’t dare look at you unless you were in a good mood.

origin: That Herod’s head I’ll have!
modern: I’ll have Herod’s head chopped off!

origin: Most gracious majesty!
modern: Most formidable Queen!

origin: Didst thou behold Octavia?
modern: Did you see Octavia?

origin: Ay, dread Queen.
modern: Yes, revered Queen.

origin: Where?
modern: Where?

origin: Madam, in Rome.
modern: In Rome, Madam.

origin: I looked her in the face, and saw her led Between her brother and Mark Antony.
modern: I saw her face as she walked with her brother and Mark Antony.

origin: Is she as tall as me?
modern: Is she as tall as I am?

origin: She is not, madam.
modern: She is not, madam.

origin: Didst hear her speak?
modern: Did you hear her speak?

origin: Is she shrill-tongued or low?
modern: Is her voice pitched high or low?

origin: Madam, I heard her speak.
modern: Madam, I heard her speak.

origin: She is low-voiced.
modern: She has a low-pitched voice.

origin: That’s not so good.
modern: That’s not in her favor.

origin: He cannot like her long.
modern: He can’t like her very long.

origin: Like her?
modern: Like her?

origin: O Isis, ’tis impossible.
modern: Oh, Isis, that’s impossible.

origin: I think so, Charmian.
modern: You’re right, Charmian.

origin: She creeps.
modern: She creeps along.

origin: She shows a body rather than a life, A statue than a breather.
modern: She has a body, not a life.

origin: Is this certain?
modern: Is this true?

origin: Or I have no observance.
modern: If not, then I have no powers of observation.

origin: Three in Egypt Cannot make better note.
modern: There aren’t three people in all of Egypt who could do better.

origin: There’s nothing in her yet.
modern: She doesn’t have anything going for her so far.

origin: The fellow has good judgment.
modern: This messenger is wise.

origin: Excellent.
modern: Very wise.

origin: Charmian, hark.
modern: Do you hear that, Charmian?

origin: And I do think she’s thirty.
modern: And I think she’s at least thirty.

origin: Bear’st thou her face in mind?
modern: Do you remember her face?

origin: Is ’t long or round?
modern: Was it long or round?

origin: Round, even to faultiness.
modern: Round enough to be unattractive.

origin: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
modern: Usually that means a person is foolish.

origin: Her hair, what color?
modern: What color is her hair?

origin: Brown, madam, and her forehead As low as she would wish it.
modern: Brown, madam, and she wouldn’t want her forehead to be any lower.

origin: Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
modern: You mustn’t hold my earlier outburst against me.

origin: I will employ thee back again; I find thee Most fit for business.
modern: I’ll hire you again to go back to Rome.

origin: Go make thee ready; Our letters are prepared.
modern: My letters are ready to go.

origin: A proper man.
modern: He’s an admirable man.

origin: Indeed, he is so.
modern: He certainly is.

origin: I repent me much That so I harried him.
modern: I’m very sorry I was so hard on him.

origin: Nothing, madam.
modern: Not a bit, madam.

origin: All may be well enough.
modern: Everything may still be all right.

origin: I warrant you, madam.
modern: I assure you it is, madam.

origin: O my good lord, Believe not all, or, if you must believe, Stomach not all.
modern: Oh, dear husband, don’t believe everything you hear—or if you must believe it, don’t let it all make you angry.

origin: A more unhappy lady, If this division chance, ne’er stood between, Praying for both parts.
modern: No lady could be more miserable than I if you two disagree.

origin: Gentle Octavia, Let your best love draw to that point which seeks Best to preserve it.
modern: Gentle Octavia, support the one that supports you.

origin: The meantime, lady, I’ll raise the preparation of a war Shall stain your brother.
modern: In the meantime, I’ll raise an army that will surpass his.

origin: The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak, Your reconciler!
modern: May the god of power make me, the weakest of the weak, your mediator.

origin: When it appears to you where this begins, Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them.
modern: When you find out who started this disagreement, turn your anger upon them.

origin: Provide your going; Choose your own company and command what cost Your heart has mind to.
modern: Order supplies for your trip and choose your traveling companions.

origin: How now, friend Eros!
modern: How goes it, friend Eros?

origin: There’s strange news come, sir.
modern: Some startling news has just arrived, sir.

origin: What, man?
modern: What news, man?

origin: Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.
modern: Caesar and Lepidus declared war against Pompey.

origin: This is old.
modern: That’s old news.

origin: What is the success?
modern: Who’s winning?

origin: So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
modern: So the weak third of the triumvirate is imprisoned until death frees him.

origin: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more, And throw between them all the food thou hast, They’ll grind the one the other.
modern: And even if you throw everything you possess to the two of them, they’ll battle each other to the death to have it all.

origin: Where’s Antony?
modern: Where’s Antony?

origin: More, Domitius: My lord desires you presently.
modern: Another thing, Domitius: Antony wants to see you now.

origin: My news I might have told hereafter.
modern: I should have waited to tell you my news.

origin: Twill be naught, But let it be.
modern: But never mind.

origin: Bring me to Antony.
modern: Take me to Antony.

origin: Come, sir.
modern: Come with me, sir.

origin: Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more In Alexandria.
modern: In Alexandria he condemned Rome, and that’s not all.

origin: Here’s the manner of ’t: I’ th’ marketplace, on a tribunal silvered, Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold Were publicly enthroned.
modern: This is what happened: he and Cleopatra sat on chairs of gold on a silver-covered stage in the marketplace.

origin: This in the public eye?
modern: He did this in public?

origin: She In th’ habiliments of the goddess Isis That day appeared, and oft before gave audience, As ’tis reported, so.
modern: He gave Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia to Ptolemy.

origin: Let Rome be thus informed.
modern: Let’s send this news to Rome.

origin: Who, queasy with his insolence already, Will their good thoughts call from him.
modern: The Roman people are fed up with his arrogance already.

origin: The people knows it, and have now received His accusations.
modern: The people have heard it already, and they’ve been told of his accusations.

origin: Who does he accuse?
modern: Who does he accuse?

origin: Caesar, and that, having in Sicily Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him His part o’ th’ isle.
modern: He accuses me of withholding his share of Sextus Pompeius’ possessions, which we seized in Sicily.

origin: Then does he say he lent me Some shipping, unrestored.
modern: Then he says I didn’t return some ships he loaned me.

origin: Sir, this should be answered.
modern: Sir, these accusations should be answered.

origin: Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
modern: It has been done already, and the messenger is on his way.

origin: I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel, That he his high authority abused And did deserve his change.
modern: I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position.

origin: He’ll never yield to that.
modern: He’ll never agree to that.

origin: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.
modern: Then we won’t agree to his demands.

origin: Hail, Caesar, and my lord!
modern: Greetings, Caesar, my lord!

origin: Hail, most dear Caesar!
modern: Greetings, dearest Caesar!

origin: That ever I should call thee castaway!
modern: Oh, to think you’ve been rejected!

origin: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.
modern: You’ve never thought of me like that, and you have no reason to.

origin: Why have you stol’n upon us thus?
modern: Then why did you travel so quietly?

origin: You come not Like Caesar’s sister.
modern: You didn’t arrive like Caesar’s sister.

origin: The wife of Antony Should have an army for an usher and The neighs of horse to tell of her approach Long ere she did appear.
modern: Antony’s wife should have an army to escort her, with neighing horses to announce her arrival long before she appears.

origin: Nay, the dust Should have ascended to the roof of heaven, Raised by your populous troops.
modern: The dust from your attending troops should have risen to heaven.

origin: We should have met you By sea and land, supplying every stage With an augmented greeting.
modern: I would have met you by sea and again by land.

origin: My lord, Mark Antony, Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged His pardon for return.
modern: Mark Antony heard that you were preparing to wage war on him.

origin: Which soon he granted, Being an obstruct ’tween his lust and him.
modern: Which he quickly allowed, given that you’re an obstacle to his lust.

origin: Amen.
modern: Amen.

origin: Hush!
modern: Quiet!

origin: Here comes Antony.
modern: Here comes Antony.

origin: Saw you my lord?
modern: Have you seen my lord?

origin: No, lady.
modern: No, lady.

origin: Was he not here?
modern: Wasn’t he here?

origin: No, madam.
modern: No, madam.

origin: He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him.—Enobarbus!
modern: He was in a good mood, and then suddenly he started thinking of Rome.

origin: Madam?
modern: Madam?

origin: Here at your service.
modern: Here, at your service.

origin: My lord approaches.
modern: Here comes my lord.

origin: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.
modern: Your wife, Fulvia, mustered her army first.

origin: Against my brother Lucius?
modern: Against my brother Lucius?

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Do not say so, my lord.
modern: Don’t say that, my lord.

origin: Where is he now?
modern: Where do you think he is now?

origin: My lord, in Athens.

origin: No, my most wrongèd sister.
modern: No, he’s not.

origin: Cleopatra Hath nodded him to her.
modern: Cleopatra summoned him.

origin: He hath given his empire Up to a whore; who now are levying The kings o’ th’ earth for war.
modern: He’s given his empire to a whore, and now they’re gathering kings to wage a war.

origin: He hath assembled Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus, Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont; Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia, With a more larger list of scepters.
modern: He’s recruited Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; the King of Pont; Herod, of Judea; Mithridates, King of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, the kings of Mede and Lycaonia, and many more.

origin: Ay me, most wretched, That have my heart parted betwixt two friends That does afflict each other!
modern: I’m divided between two friends who are determined to kill each other.

origin: Welcome hither.
modern: You’re welcome here.

origin: Your letters did withhold our breaking forth Till we perceived both how you were wrong led And we in negligent danger.
modern: I didn’t write about breaking the alliance with Antony until I saw you were being misled and realized how dangerous it would be to keep postponing preparations.

origin: Cheer your heart.
modern: Cheer yourself.

origin: Best of comfort, And ever welcome to us.
modern: You will always be welcome to me.

origin: Welcome, lady.
modern: Welcome, lady.

origin: Welcome, dear madam.
modern: Welcome, dear madam.

origin: Each heart in Rome does love and pity you.
modern: Every heart in Rome loves and pities you.

origin: Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large In his abominations, turns you off And gives his potent regiment to a trull That noises it against us.
modern: Only the adulterous and abominable Antony abandons you, giving his power to a whore who turns that power against us.

origin: Most certain.
modern: It’s undeniable.

origin: Sister, welcome.
modern: You are welcome here, sister.

origin: Pray you Be ever known to patience.
modern: I beg you to continue to be patient.

origin: My dear’st sister!
modern: My dearest sister!

origin: But why, why, why?
modern: But why, why, why?

origin: Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars And sayst it is not fit.
modern: You opposed my taking part in the war.

origin: Is ’t not denounced against us?
modern: Isn’t this war against me?

origin: Why should not we Be there in person?
modern: Why shouldn’t I be there in person?

origin: What is ’t you say?
modern: What do you mean?

origin: Sink Rome!
modern: Let Rome fall!

origin: And their tongues rot That speak against us!
modern: May the tongues of our critics rot!

origin: A charge we bear i’ th’ war, And as the president of my kingdom will Appear there for a man.
modern: I have responsibilities in this war, and as the absolute ruler of my kingdom I will carry out my duties as if I were a man.

origin: Speak not against it.
modern: Don’t argue against it.

origin: I will not stay behind.
modern: I won’t stay behind.

origin: Nay, I have done.
modern: No, I’ve had my say.

origin: Here comes the Emperor.
modern: Here comes the Emperor.

origin: Is it not strange, Canidius, That from Tarentum and Brundusium He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea And take in Toryne?—You have heard on ’t, sweet?
modern: Isn’t it strange, Canidius, that he could cross the Ionian Sea so quickly from Tarentum and Brundusium and take Toryne?—Have you heard about this, sweet?

origin: Celerity is never more admired Than by the negligent.
modern: No one admires speed more than the lazy.

origin: By sea, what else?
modern: What else?

origin: Why will My lord do so?
modern: Why do you want to do that, my lord?

origin: For that he dares us to ’t.
modern: Because he’s daring us to do it.

origin: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
modern: So you’ve dared him to single combat.

origin: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia, Where Caesar fought with Pompey.
modern: Yes, and you dared Caesar to fight the battle at Pharsalia, where he fought against Pompey.

origin: But these offers, Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off, And so should you.
modern: But Caesar ignores offers that don’t give him an advantage, and so should you.

origin: In Caesar’s fleet Are those that often have ’gainst Pompey fought.
modern: His ships are maneuverable.

origin: Their ships are yare, yours, heavy.
modern: Yours are slow and awkward.

origin: No disgrace Shall fall you for refusing him at sea, Being prepared for land.
modern: Refusing to fight him at sea won’t disgrace you.

origin: I’ll fight at sea.
modern: I’ll fight at sea.

origin: But if we fail, We then can do ’t at land.
modern: Even if we fail at that, we can still fight him on land.

origin: Thy business?
modern: What’s your business?

origin: The news is true, my lord.
modern: The news is true, my lord.

origin: He is descried.
modern: He has captured Toryne.

origin: Canidius, Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land, And our twelve thousand horse.
modern: Canidius, take our nineteen

origin: How now, worthy soldier?
modern: What’s the news, brave soldier?

origin: O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea!
modern: Oh, don’t fight by sea, noble Emperor!

origin: Trust not to rotten planks.
modern: Don’t trust rotten planks.

origin: Do you misdoubt This sword and these my wounds?
modern: Don’t you trust my sword and these wounds?

origin: Let th’ Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking.
modern: Let the Egyptians and Phoenicians go swimming.

origin: We Have used to conquer standing on the earth And fighting foot to foot.
modern: We are used to winning by standing on the earth and fighting toe to toe.

origin: Well, well, away.
modern: Well, well, let’s go.

origin: By Hercules, I think I am i’ th’ right.
modern: By Hercules, I think I’m right.

origin: Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows Not in the power on ’t.
modern: Soldier, you are.

origin: So our leader’s led, And we are women’s men.
modern: Our leader is being led.

origin: You keep by land The legions and the horse whole, do you not?
modern: On land you keep the legions and cavalry together, don’t you?

origin: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea; But we keep whole by land.
modern: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius will go by sea, but we’ll keep the bulk on land.

origin: This speed of Caesar’s Carries beyond belief.
modern: Caesar’s speed defies belief.

origin: While he was yet in Rome His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all spies.
modern: While he was still in Rome, he deployed his forces in so many different disguises that all our spies were fooled.

origin: Who’s his lieutenant, hear you?
modern: Who’s his lieutenant, do you know?

origin: They say, one Taurus.
modern: A man named Taurus, they say.

origin: Well I know the man.
modern: I know the man well.

origin: The Emperor calls Canidius.
modern: The Emperor is calling for Canidius.

origin: With news the time’s with labor, and throws forth Each minute some.
modern: The present time is like a woman in labor, each minute giving birth to some piece of news.

origin: Taurus!
modern: Taurus!

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: Strike not by land; keep whole.
modern: Don’t attack by land.

origin: Provoke not battle Till we have done at sea.
modern: Don’t provoke them to battle until we have finished at sea.

origin: Our fortune lies Upon this jump.
modern: Our fate depends on this chance.

origin: Set we our squadrons on yond side o’ th’ hill, In eye of Caesar’s battle, from which place We may the number of the ships behold And so proceed accordingly.
modern: Assemble our squadrons on the other side of the hill, in sight of Caesar’s navy.

origin: I can behold no longer.
modern: I can’t watch any more.

origin: Gods and goddesses, All the whole synod of them!
modern: The Egyptian flagship, the  Gods and goddesses—the whole congregation of them!

origin: What’s thy passion?
modern: What’s wrong with you?

origin: The greater cantle of the world is lost With very ignorance.
modern: We have lost a major portion of the world through utter foolishness.

origin: We have kissed away Kingdoms and provinces.
modern: We have kissed away entire kingdoms and provinces.

origin: How appears the fight?
modern: How goes the battle?

origin: Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt— Whom leprosy o’ertake!—i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight, When vantage like a pair of twins appeared Both as the same, or rather ours the elder, The breeze upon her, like a cow in June, Hoists sails and flies.
modern: Right in the middle of the fight, just when the battle could have gone either way—actually we had a slight advantage—that immoral Egyptian nag—May she die of leprosy!—suddenly became frightened, and turned her ships around and fled.

origin: That I beheld.
modern: I saw that.

origin: Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view.
modern: The sight made me so sick I couldn’t watch any more.

origin: Well, what worst?
modern: Well, give me the worst news.

origin: The nature of bad news infects the teller.
modern: The bearer of bad news is often blamed for it.

origin: When it concerns the fool or coward.
modern: Only if the hearer is a fool or a coward.

origin: On.
modern: Go on.

origin: Things that are past are done, with me.
modern: As far as I’m concerned, what’s past is done.

origin: Tis thus: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death, I hear him as he flattered.
modern: It’s like this: as long as a person tells me the truth, even though it means my death, I will listen as though he praised me.

origin: O my lord!
modern: Oh, my lord!

origin: Speak to me home.
modern: Speak plainly.

origin: Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome.
modern: Call Cleopatra what the Romans call her.

origin: Oh, then we bring forth weeds When our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us Is as our earing.
modern: It’s easy to err when left to our own devices, but criticism helps us to see our faults and correct them.

origin: Fare thee well awhile.
modern: Good-bye for a while.

origin: I never saw an action of such shame.
modern: I never saw such a shameful act.

origin: Experience, manhood, honor, ne’er before Did violate so itself.
modern: Terrible.

origin: Alack, alack!
modern: Terrible.

origin: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath And sinks most lamentably.
modern: The battle on the sea is almost lost.

origin: Had our general Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
modern: If our general had been his old self, we would have won.

origin: Oh, he has given example for our flight Most grossly by his own!
modern: Oh, with his sordid desertion, he sets the example for our own.

origin: Ay, are you thereabouts?
modern: Are you considering desertion, as well?

origin: Why then, good night indeed.
modern: Then everything must really be finished.

origin: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.
modern: They fled toward Peloponnesus.

origin: To Caesar will I render My legions and my horse.
modern: I’ll yield my legions and cavalry to Caesar.

origin: Hark.
modern: Listen.

origin: Friends, come hither.
modern: Friends, come here.

origin: I am so lated in the world that I Have lost my way forever.
modern: I’m completely lost.

origin: I have a ship Laden with gold.
modern: I have a ship full of treasure.

origin: Fly And make your peace with Caesar.
modern: Escape and make peace with Caesar.

origin: Fly?
modern: Flee?

origin: Not we.
modern: Not us.

origin: I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards To run and show their shoulders.
modern: I’ve told cowards to turn their backs on me and run.

origin: Friends, begone.
modern: Friends, go.

origin: I have myself resolved upon a course Which has no need of you.
modern: I’ve decided on a plan that doesn’t require your assistance.

origin: Begone.
modern: Leave.

origin: Oh, I followed that I blush to look upon!
modern: Oh, I followed something I’m ashamed to look at now!

origin: My very hairs do mutiny, for the white Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them For fear and doting.
modern: Even my hair revolts.

origin: Friends, begone.
modern: Friends, go.

origin: You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you.
modern: I’ll give you letters of introduction to some friends of mine who will help you.

origin: Pray you, look not sad, Nor make replies of loathness.
modern: Please, don’t be sad, and don’t tell me how reluctant you are.

origin: Take the hint Which my despair proclaims.
modern: Take your cues from my own despair.

origin: Let that be left Which leaves itself.
modern: Abandon the person that has abandoned himself.

origin: To the seaside straightway!
modern: Go to the harbor immediately!

origin: I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
modern: I’ll give you the title to that ship and its treasure.

origin: Leave me, I pray, a little.
modern: Just give me a moment, please—only a moment.

origin: Pray you now, Nay, do so, for indeed I have lost command.
modern: I’ve relinquished my authority, so please—I’ll see you all before long.

origin: Why, what else?
modern: What else?

origin: Let me sit down.
modern: Let me sit down.

origin: Oh, fie, fie, fie!
modern: Oh, damn, damn, damn!

origin: Madam!
modern: Madam!

origin: Madam, O good Empress!
modern: Madam, oh, good Empress!

origin: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.
modern: The Queen is here, my lord.

origin: Go to him, madam, speak to him.
modern: Go to him, madam, speak to him.

origin: He is unqualitied with very shame.
modern: He’s not himself because he feels so ashamed.

origin: Well then, sustain me.
modern: Well, then, help me.

origin: Most noble sir, arise.
modern: Most noble sir, stand up.

origin: The Queen approaches.
modern: The Queen is coming.

origin: Her head’s declined, and death will seize her but Your comfort makes the rescue.
modern: She’s weak and will die unless you comfort her.

origin: I have offended reputation, A most unnoble swerving.
modern: I’ve destroyed my reputation, a most shameful error.

origin: Sir, the Queen.
modern: Sir, here’s the Queen.

origin: Oh, whither hast thou led me, Egypt?
modern: Oh, where have you led me, Egypt?

origin: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails!
modern: Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my panic!

origin: I little thought You would have followed.
modern: I didn’t think you would follow me.

origin: Egypt, thou knew’st too well My heart was to thy rudder tied by th’ strings, And thou shouldst tow me after.
modern: Queen, you knew very well that my heart was tied to your ship and that you would pull me along with you.

origin: O’er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me.
modern: You knew that my spirit was completely under your control and that I would ignore the gods’ orders in favor of yours.

origin: Oh, my pardon!
modern: Oh, forgive me!

origin: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes.
modern: Now I will have to send my humble proposal of peace to that young man.

origin: You did know How much you were my conqueror, and that My sword, made weak by my affection, would Obey it on all cause.
modern: You knew that my sword, weakened by my love for you, would obey that love no matter what.

origin: Fall not a tear, I say.
modern: Don’t shed even one tear.

origin: One of them rates All that is won and lost.
modern: One of your tears is worth everything that was won and lost.

origin: Give me a kiss.
modern: Give me a kiss.

origin: Even this repays me.— We sent our schoolmaster.
modern: This repays me.

origin: Let him appear that’s come from Antony.
modern: Let the envoy from Antony come in.

origin: Know you him?
modern: Do you know him?

origin: Approach and speak.
modern: Come forward and speak.

origin: Such as I am, I come from Antony.
modern: Humble as I am, I represent Antony.

origin: I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea.
modern: Until recently, I was as unimportant to his affairs as the morning dew is to the wide ocean.

origin: Be ’t so.
modern: So be it.

origin: Declare thine office.
modern: Say what you’re here for.

origin: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and Requires to live in Egypt; which not granted, He lessens his requests, and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth A private man in Athens.
modern: If that is not granted, he reduces his requests and asks only that he be allowed to live as a private man in Athens.

origin: This for him.
modern: That’s all he asks for himself.

origin: Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness, Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs, Now hazarded to thy grace.
modern: Cleopatra recognizes your greatness and accepts your authority.

origin: For Antony, I have no ears to his request.
modern: As for Antony, I’m not interested in his requests.

origin: The Queen Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend Or take his life there.
modern: I’ll give the Queen a hearing and grant her requests if she either throws her dishonored friend out of Egypt or kills him.

origin: This if she perform, She shall not sue unheard.
modern: Then I’ll listen to her.

origin: So to them both.
modern: Give my answer to them both.

origin: Fortune pursue thee!
modern: May good luck follow you!

origin: Bring him through the bands.
modern: Take him safely through the lines.

origin: Caesar, I go.
modern: I go, Caesar.

origin: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think’st his very action speaks In every power that moves.
modern: Observe how Antony takes his defeat and how his attitude influences his actions.

origin: Caesar, I shall.
modern: I will, Caesar.

origin: What shall we do, Enobarbus?
modern: What are we going to do, Enobarbus?

origin: Think and die.
modern: Think about our situation, then die.

origin: Is Antony or we in fault for this?
modern: Who is to blame for this: Antony or I?

origin: Antony only, that would make his will Lord of his reason.
modern: Only Antony was at fault.

origin: Why should he follow?
modern: Why should he have followed you?

origin: The itch of his affection should not then Have nicked his captainship at such a point When half to half the world opposed, he being The merèd question.
modern: With half the world opposing the other half, it wasn’t the time for Antony, the pivotal player, to let love distract him.

origin: Twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags And leave his navy gazing.
modern: To race after your departing ships, leaving his navy to watch, was a shame as great as the resulting loss.

origin: Prithee, peace.
modern: Please, let’s not talk about it.

origin: Is that his answer?
modern: Is that his answer?

origin: Ay, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she Will yield us up?
modern: The Queen will be treated fairly if she gives me up?

origin: He says so.
modern: That’s what he says.

origin: Let her know ’t.—   And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.
modern: Tell her.

origin: That head, my lord?
modern: Your head, my lord?

origin: A messenger from Caesar.
modern: A messenger has arrived from Caesar.

origin: What, no more ceremony?
modern: With no more ceremony than that?

origin: See, my women, Against the blown rose may they stop their nose, That kneeled unto the buds.—Admit him, sir.
modern: See, ladies, how they scorn me now.

origin: At your noble pleasure.
modern: I’ll be at your service.

origin: He stays upon your will.
modern: He’s waiting outside.

origin: What are you?
modern: What’s your message?

origin: Fulvia thy wife is dead.
modern: Your wife, Fulvia, is dead.

origin: Where died she?
modern: Where did she die?

origin: In Sicyon.
modern: In Sicyon.

origin: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.
modern: In this letter you’ll find details of her illness and other, more serious matters that concern you.

origin: Forbear me.
modern: Leave me.

origin: Caesar’s will?
modern: What does Caesar want?

origin: Hear it apart.
modern: It is for your ears only.

origin: None but friends.
modern: There are only friends here.

origin: Say boldly.
modern: Speak confidently.

origin: So haply are they friends to Antony.
modern: So they are possibly Antony’s friends.

origin: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has, Or needs not us.
modern: Sir, he should have as many as Caesar has.

origin: If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend.
modern: If Caesar chose, Antony would jump at the chance to be his friend.

origin: For us, you know Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.
modern: As for us, you know we are Antony’s, and he is Caesar’s.

origin: So.— Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats Not to consider in what case thou stand’st, Further than he is Caesar.
modern: Just remember that he is Caesar.

origin: He knows that you embrace not Antony As you did love, but as you feared him.
modern: He knows that you didn’t embrace Antony because you loved him, but because you feared him.

origin: Oh!
modern: Oh!

origin: He is a god and knows What is most right.
modern: He is like a god and knows the truth.

origin: Mine honor was not yielded, But conquered merely.
modern: My honor wasn’t given; it was only dominated.

origin: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him?
modern: Shall I tell Caesar what you request from him?

origin: For he partly begs To be desired to give.
modern: He almost begs for the opportunity to help you.

origin: It much would please him That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon.
modern: It would please him very much if you would rely on his wealth and success to support you.

origin: But it would warm his spirits To hear from me you had left Antony And put yourself under his shroud, The universal landlord.
modern: But he would feel even better if I could tell him that you had left Antony and put yourself under his protection.

origin: What’s your name?
modern: What’s your name?

origin: My name is Thidias.
modern: My name is Thidias.

origin: Most kind messenger, Say to great Caesar this in deputation: I kiss his conqu’ring hand.
modern: Most kind messenger, tell great Caesar that through his deputy I kiss his conquering hand.

origin: Tell him I am prompt To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.
modern: Tell him I am ready to lay my crown at his feet and kneel before him.

origin: Favors?
modern: Promising favors?

origin: By Jove that thunders!
modern: By Jove that thunders!

origin: What art thou, fellow?
modern: Who are you, slave?

origin: You will be whipped.
modern: You will be whipped.

origin: Take hence this jack and whip him.
modern: Take away this lout and whip him.

origin: Moon and stars!
modern: By the moon and stars!

origin: Whip him.
modern: Whip him!

origin: Were ’t twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here—what’s her name Since she was Cleopatra?
modern: If I saw twenty of the greatest powers that pay tribute to Caesar taking such liberties with her hand—what’s her name now?

origin: Whip him, fellows, Till like a boy, you see him cringe his face And whine aloud for mercy.
modern: Whip him, fellows, until he screws up his face like a baby and cries aloud for mercy!

origin: Take him hence.
modern: Take him away.

origin: This jack of Caesar’s shall Bear us an errand to him.
modern: Caesar’s knave will bring him a message for us.

origin: Good my lord— You have been a boggler ever.
modern: My good lord— You’ve always been a liar.

origin: But when we in our viciousness grow hard— Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut To our confusion.
modern: But when our vices become habits—Oh, the sadness of it!—the wise gods blind us, shade our better judgment, make us love our mistakes, and laugh as we strut to our ruin.

origin: Oh, is ’t come to this?
modern: Oh, has it come to this?

origin: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar’s trencher.
modern: You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar’s plate when I met you.

origin: Nay, you were a fragment Of Gneius Pompey’s, besides what hotter hours, Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have Luxuriously picked out.
modern: No, you were one of Gneius Pompey’s leftovers—not to mention your other, more depraved affairs, which have somehow managed to avoid becoming the subject of vulgar gossip.

origin: For I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.
modern: For I’m sure that although you may know what temperance is, you’ve never experienced it firsthand.

origin: Wherefore is this?
modern: Why are you doing this?

origin: Soundly, my lord.
modern: Soundly, my lord.

origin: Cried he?
modern: Did he cry?

origin: And begged he pardon?
modern: Did he beg my pardon?

origin: He did ask favor.
modern: He did ask for mercy.

origin: Have you done yet?
modern: Are you done yet?

origin: Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed, And it portends alone the fall of Antony.
modern: You, my earthly moon, are now eclipsed, and that alone foretells my ruin.

origin: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points?
modern: In order to flatter Caesar, would you flirt with the servant who laces up his pants?

origin: Not know me yet?
modern: Don’t you know me still?

origin: Coldhearted toward me?
modern: Has your heart cooled toward me?

origin: Ah, dear, if I be so, From my cold heart let heaven engender hail, And poison it in the source, and the first stone Drop in my neck.
modern: Ah, dear, if that is true, let heaven make poisonous hail grow from my heart, and let the first hailstone drop down my throat.

origin: As it determines, so Dissolve my life!
modern: As it dissolves, so shall my life.

origin: The next Caesarion smite, Till by degrees the memory of my womb, Together with my brave Egyptians all, By the discandying of this pelleted storm Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey!
modern: The next hailstone should hit Caesarion, until one by one all my children, and every one of my brave Egyptians, are killed by the dissolving of this pellet storm and lie unburied, covered by gnats and flies.

origin: I am satisfied.
modern: I am satisfied.

origin: Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where I will oppose his fate.
modern: I will fight him there.

origin: Our force by land Hath nobly held.
modern: Our land forces have bravely stood firm.

origin: Our severed navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threat’ning most sealike.
modern: Our tattered navy has reassembled and set sail, as formidable as the sea itself.

origin: Where hast thou been, my heart?
modern: Where have you been, my bravery?

origin: Dost thou hear, lady?
modern: Do you hear what I say, lady?

origin: If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
modern: If I come back from the battlefield again to kiss those lips, I’ll be covered in blood.

origin: I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
modern: My sword and I will earn our place in history.

origin: There’s hope in ’t yet.
modern: We still have hope.

origin: That’s my brave lord!
modern: That’s my brave lord!

origin: I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed, And fight maliciously.
modern: I’ll fight brutally.

origin: For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me.
modern: But now I’ll grit my teeth and kill anyone who tries to stop me.

origin: Come, Let’s have one other gaudy night.
modern: Come, let’s have one more extravagant night.

origin: Call to me All my sad captains.
modern: Invite all my sad captains.

origin: Let’s mock the midnight bell.
modern: Let’s drink through midnight.

origin: It is my birthday.
modern: It’s my birthday.

origin: I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
modern: I had planned to celebrate it quietly, but since my lord is once more himself, I will be Cleopatra again.

origin: We will yet do well.
modern: We’ll win yet.

origin: Do so.
modern: Do so.

origin: We’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force The wine peep through their scars.—Come on, my Queen, There’s sap in ’t yet.
modern: I’ll speak to them, and then tonight I’ll get them all so drunk that the wine seeps out of their old war wounds.

origin: Now he’ll outstare the lightning.
modern: Now he’ll work himself up to a fury.

origin: When valor preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with.
modern: When courage consumes reason, it destroys its only weapon.

origin: I will seek Some way to leave him.
modern: I’ll look for some way to leave his service.

origin: He calls me “boy” and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt.
modern: He calls me “boy” and scolds me as if he had the power to whip me out of Egypt.

origin: Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die, meantime Laugh at his challenge.
modern: Let the old ruffian discover that I have many other ways to die, and in the meantime, we’ll laugh at his challenge.

origin: Give him no breath, but now Make boot of his distraction.
modern: Don’t give him time to catch his breath.

origin: Never anger Made good guard for itself.
modern: Anger does not protect the angry well.

origin: Let our best heads Know that tomorrow the last of many battles We mean to fight.
modern: Tell our top commanders that I want tomorrow’s battle to be the last we fight.

origin: Within our files there are, Of those that served Mark Antony but late, Enough to fetch him in.
modern: Our army has recently acquired many of Mark Antony’s former soldiers—enough to capture him.

origin: See it done And feast the army.
modern: See that it is done, and prepare a feast for the soldiers.

origin: We have store to do ’t, And they have earned the waste.
modern: We have enough supplies for it, and they’ve earned it.

origin: Poor Antony!
modern: Poor Antony!

origin: What’s your pleasure, sir?
modern: What would you like, sir?

origin: I must with haste from hence.
modern: I have to leave right away.

origin: Why, then, we kill all our women.
modern: That will kill our lovers.

origin: We see how mortal an unkindness is to them.
modern: We know how much they suffer if we are unkind to them.

origin: If they suffer our departure, death’s the word.
modern: If we leave, it will feel like nothing less than death to them.

origin: I must be gone.
modern: I must be gone.

origin: Under a compelling occasion, let women die.
modern: If it’s that important, then let the women die.

origin: It were pity to cast them away for nothing, though between them and a great cause they should be esteemed nothing.
modern: It would be a pity to throw them away for nothing, but if it’s a matter of choosing between them and a great cause, then they’re worthless.

origin: Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly.
modern: If Cleopatra hears even a breath of this, she’ll die immediately.

origin: I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment.
modern: I’ve seen her claim to be dying twenty times before, and for far less reason.

origin: I do think there is mettle in death, which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.
modern: I think there must be something invigorating about death, since she dies with such enthusiasm.

origin: She is cunning past man’s thought.
modern: She’s more cunning than anyone can imagine.

origin: We cannot call her winds and waters sighs and tears.
modern: Her sighs and tears are like great winds and floods.

origin: He will not fight with me, Domitius?
modern: He won’t fight with me, Domitius?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Why should he not?
modern: Why won’t he?

origin: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.
modern: He thinks that since his fortune is twenty times better than yours, it would be like pitting twenty men against one.

origin: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land I’ll fight.
modern: Tomorrow, soldier, I’ll fight by sea and land.

origin: Or I will live Or bathe my dying honor in the blood Shall make it live again.
modern: By the end I will either live, or else I’ll restore my honor by shedding my blood.

origin: Woo’t thou fight well?
modern: Will you fight well?

origin: I’ll strike and cry, “Take all.”                                                           Well said.
modern: When I strike, I’ll cry, “All or nothing!” Well put.

origin: Come on!
modern: Come on.

origin: Call forth my household servants.
modern: Call out my household servants.

origin: Let’s tonight Be bounteous at our meal.
modern: Tonight let’s have plenty to eat.

origin: You have served me well, And kings have been your fellows.
modern: You have all served me well, and kings are your peers.

origin: The gods forbid!
modern: The gods forbid!

origin: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
modern: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.

origin: Scant not my cups, and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too, And suffered my command.
modern: Keep my cups full and treat me as you did when my empire was one of your fellow servants, obeying my commands.

origin: Look, they weep, And I, an ass, am onion-eyed.
modern: Look—they’re crying.

origin: Ho, ho, ho!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
modern: May the evil one take me if I meant it like that!

origin: Grace grow where those drops fall!
modern: Those tears will bring blessings to you.

origin: My hearty friends, You take me in too dolorous a sense, For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you To burn this night with torches.
modern: You interpret my words in a melancholy sense, my hearty friends.

origin: Know, my hearts, I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you Where rather I’ll expect victorious life Than death and honor.
modern: You should know, my friends, that I have good hopes for tomorrow, and that I will lead you as if I expect victory rather than an honorable death.

origin: Brother, good night.
modern: Good night, brother.

origin: Tomorrow is the day.
modern: Tomorrow is the day.

origin: Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?
modern: Have you heard about anything unusual happening in the city?

origin: Nothing.
modern: No.

origin: What news?
modern: What was it?

origin: Belike ’tis but a rumor.
modern: It was probably just a rumor.

origin: Good night to you.
modern: Good night.

origin: Well, sir, good night.
modern: Well sir, good night.

origin: Soldiers, have careful watch.
modern: Soldiers, watch carefully.

origin: And you.
modern: You too.

origin: Here we.
modern: This is our station.

origin: And if tomorrow Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope Our landmen will stand up.
modern: And if our navy wins tomorrow, no doubt our army will do their part.

origin: Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.
modern: It’s an outstanding army and highly motivated.

origin: Peace!
modern: Quiet!

origin: What noise?
modern: What’s that sound?

origin: Hark!
modern: Listen!

origin: Music i’ th’ air.
modern: There’s music coming out of thin air.

origin: Under the earth.
modern: From under the earth.

origin: It signs well, does it not?
modern: It’s a lucky sign, isn’t it?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Peace, I say!
modern: Quiet, I say.

origin: What should this mean?
modern: What does this mean?

origin: How now, masters?
modern: Hello there, good sirs.

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Is ’t not strange?
modern: Isn’t it strange?

origin: Do you hear, masters?
modern: Do you hear that, men?

origin: Do you hear?
modern: Do you?
