origin: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter; Let’s see how it will give off.
modern: Let’s follow the music as far as we can without leaving our station and see if it stops.

origin: Content.
modern: Good idea.

origin: Tis strange.
modern: It’s very strange.

origin: Sleep a little.
modern: Get a little sleep.

origin: Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
modern: Come on, good fellow, help me into that armor you’re carrying.

origin: If fortune be not ours today, it is Because we brave her.
modern: If luck deserts us today, it’s because we defy it.

origin: Come.
modern: Come on.

origin: Nay, I’ll help too.
modern: No, I’ll help too.

origin: What’s this for?
modern: What’s this part for?

origin: Ah, let be, let be!
modern: Ah, leave it alone.

origin: Thou art The armorer of my heart.
modern: You armor my heart.

origin: False, false.
modern: No!

origin: This, this.
modern: No!

origin: Sooth, la, I’ll help.
modern: Really, I’ll help.

origin: Thus it must be.
modern: It must go like this.

origin: Well, well, We shall thrive now.—Seest thou, my good fellow?
modern: We’ve got it now.—Do you see this, my good fellow?

origin: Go put on thy defenses.
modern: Go and put on your own armor.

origin: Briefly, sir.
modern: In a minute, sir.

origin: Is not this buckled well?
modern: Didn’t I buckle this well?

origin: Rarely, rarely.
modern: Excellently, excellently.

origin: Dispatch.—O love, That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew’st The royal occupation!
modern: Hurry.—Oh, love, if you could only watch the battle today and see how expert I am at my craft.

origin: Good morrow to thee.
modern: Good morning to you.

origin: Welcome.
modern: Welcome.

origin: Thou look’st like him that knows a warlike charge.
modern: You look like a person who knows the business of war.

origin: To business that we love we rise betimes And go to ’t with delight.
modern: When we love our job we get up early and go to it joyfully.

origin: A thousand, sir, Early though ’t be, have on their riveted trim And at the port expect you.
modern: Even though it’s early, there are already a thousand armored soldiers waiting for you at the harbor.

origin: The morn is fair.
modern: The weather is fair.

origin: Good morrow, General.
modern: Good morning, General.

origin: Good morrow, General.
modern: Good morning, General.

origin: Tis well blown, lads.
modern: That was a fine fanfare, boys.

origin: This morning, like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note, begins betimes.
modern: Like a young man who wants to amount to something, this morning begins early.

origin: Fare thee well, dame.
modern: Farewell, lady.

origin: Whate’er becomes of me, This is a soldier’s kiss.
modern: Whatever happens to me, this is a soldier’s kiss.

origin: I’ll leave thee Now like a man of steel.
modern: I’ll leave you without revealing any emotion, like a man of steel.

origin: Lead me.
modern: Lead the way.

origin: He goes forth gallantly.
modern: He goes forth to war bravely.

origin: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!
modern: May the gods bless Antony today!

origin: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed To make me fight at land!
modern: I wish you and your scarred self had convinced me to wage our last battle on land.

origin: Hadst thou done so, The kings that have revolted, and the soldier That has this morning left thee, would have still Followed thy heels.
modern: If you had, the kings that have revolted and the soldier that deserted this morning would still be behind you.

origin: Who’s gone this morning?
modern: Who deserted this morning?

origin: Who?
modern: You don’t know?

origin: One ever near thee.
modern: Someone who was always near you.

origin: Sir, He is with Caesar.
modern: Sir, he’s with Caesar.

origin: Sir, his chests and treasure He has not with him.
modern: Sir, he left his belongings and treasure.

origin: Is he gone?
modern: He’s gone?

origin: Most certain.
modern: It’s certain.

origin: Go, Eros, send his treasure after.
modern: Eros, send his treasure to him.

origin: Do it.
modern: Do it now.

origin: Detain no jot, I charge thee.
modern: Don’t keep anything back, I insist.

origin: Write to him— I will subscribe—gentle adieus and greetings.
modern: Write to him from me—I’ll sign it—sending greetings and gentle good-byes.

origin: Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master.
modern: Say that I hope he never has cause to look for a new master.

origin: Oh, my fortunes have Corrupted honest men!
modern: Oh, my bad luck has forced honest men to become traitors.

origin: Dispatch.—Enobarbus!
modern: Hurry.

origin: Fulvia is dead.
modern: Fulvia is dead.

origin: Sir?
modern: Pardon me?

origin: Fulvia is dead.
modern: Fulvia is dead.

origin: Fulvia?
modern: Fulvia?

origin: Dead.
modern: Dead.

origin: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice.
modern: Then you should offer the gods a sacrifice to show your thanks.

origin: If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented.
modern: If Fulvia were the last woman on earth, there would be a reason to grieve.

origin: This grief is crowned with consolation.
modern: But in this way, grief and comfort appear together.

origin: Your old smock brings forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.
modern: The only kind of tears you should shed in this case are the kind you might get from holding an onion to your nose.

origin: The business she hath broached in the state Cannot endure my absence.
modern: I must go and continue the business Fulvia started.

origin: And the business you have broached here cannot be without you, especially that of Cleopatra’s, which wholly depends on your abode.
modern: The business you began here needs you as well—especially the business with Cleopatra, which only you can attend to.

origin: No more light answers.
modern: Enough of this frivolous talk.

origin: Let our officers Have notice what we purpose.
modern: Give our officers notice of our intentions.

origin: I shall break The cause of our expedience to the Queen And get her leave to part.
modern: I’ll tell the Queen the reason for our quick departure and get her permission to leave.

origin: For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home.
modern: Fulvia’s death and the pressing concerns related to it are not the only reasons I am eager to go; friends in Rome have also sent many letters advising my return.

origin: Much is breeding  Which, like the courser’s hair, hath yet but life, And not a serpent’s poison.
modern: The empire may be in danger if he’s not restrained before he reaches his full potential.

origin: Say our pleasure, To such whose place is under us, requires Our quick remove from hence.
modern: There are many troubles brewing now that have yet to become full-fledged threats.

origin: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
modern: Agrippa, go start the battle.

origin: Our will is Antony be took alive.
modern: We want Antony taken alive.

origin: Make it so known.
modern: Make sure everyone knows that.

origin: Caesar, I shall.
modern: I will, Caesar.

origin: The time of universal peace is near.
modern: An era of universal peace is about to start.

origin: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the vant, That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself.
modern: That way Antony will feel like he’s fighting his own men.

origin: For this pains Caesar hath hanged him.
modern: Caesar hanged him for this service.

origin: Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment but No honorable trust.
modern: Canidius and the others that left Antony are given hospitality here but no positions of trust.

origin: I have done ill, Of which I do accuse myself so sorely That I will joy no more.
modern: I’ve done a bad thing, for which I will blame myself so much that I’ll never be happy again.

origin: Enobarbus, Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with His bounty overplus.
modern: Enobarbus, Antony has sent you all your treasure, with generous gifts besides.

origin: The messenger Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules.
modern: The messenger arrived on my watch and is unloading his mules at your tent.

origin: I give it you.
modern: It’s yours.

origin: Mock not, Enobarbus.
modern: Don’t joke about this, Enobarbus.

origin: I tell you true.
modern: I’m telling you the truth.

origin: Best you safed the bringer Out of the host.
modern: You’d better bring the messenger safely through the lines so he can return.

origin: I must attend mine office, Or would have done ’t myself.
modern: I’d do it myself, but I can’t leave my post.

origin: Your Emperor Continues still a Jove.
modern: Your Emperor is still a king among gods.

origin: I am alone the villain of the earth, And feel I am so most.
modern: I am the worst person alive, and I know it the best.

origin: O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold!
modern: Oh, Antony, you extravagantly generous man, how would you have rewarded me for serving you faithfully when you reward my badness with all of this gold!

origin: This blows my heart.
modern: My heart feels like it’s about to explode.

origin: If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do ’t, I feel.
modern: If grief doesn’t kill me, I’ll find a quicker way to kill myself—even though I think grief will do the job just as well.

origin: I fight against thee?
modern: I, fight against you, Antony?

origin: No, I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die.
modern: No, I’ll go find some ditch to die in.

origin: The foul’st best fits My latter part of life.
modern: The foulest fate would be most appropriate for me now in this latest phase of my life.

origin: Retire!
modern: Retreat!

origin: We have engaged ourselves too far.
modern: We’ve advanced too far.

origin: Caesar himself has work, and our oppression Exceeds what we expected.
modern: Caesar himself is in trouble and there are more adversaries than we expected.

origin: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
modern: Oh, my brave Emperor, this is what I call a fight!

origin: Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.
modern: If we’d fought like this before, we’d have driven them home with bandaged heads.

origin: Thou bleed’st apace.
modern: You’re bleeding a lot.

origin: I had a wound here that was like a “T,” But now ’tis made an “H.”                                                        They do retire.
modern: I had a scar here that looked like a “T”; now it’s an “H.” They’re retreating.

origin: We’ll beat ’em into bench-holes.
modern: We’ll chase ’em into their latrines.

origin: I have yet Room for six scotches more.
modern: I still have room for six more wounds.

origin: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves For a fair victory.
modern: They’re retreating, sir, and our superiority indicates a clear victory.

origin: Let us score their backs And snatch ’em up, as we take hares, behind!
modern: Let’s slash their backs and grab ’em like we do rabbits, from behind.

origin: Tis sport to maul a runner.
modern: It’s fair game to mark a coward.

origin: I will reward thee Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold For thy good valor.
modern: I’ll reward you once for your cheerfulness and ten times for your courage.

origin: Come thee on.
modern: Come on.

origin: I’ll halt after.
modern: I’ll limp after you.

origin: We have beat him to his camp.
modern: We’ve driven him all the way back to his camp.

origin: Run one before And let the Queen know of our gests.
modern: One of you run to the Queen with the news.

origin: Tomorrow, Before the sun shall see ’s, we’ll spill the blood That has today escaped.
modern: Before sunrise tomorrow, we’ll kill anyone who escaped today.

origin: Lord of lords!
modern: You are all    Lord of lords!

origin: O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from The world’s great snare uncaught?
modern: Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world?

origin: Mine nightingale, We have beat them to their beds.
modern: My songbird, we have beaten them to their beds.

origin: What, girl, though gray Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we A brain that nourishes our nerves and can Get goal for goal of youth.
modern: What do you think, girl!

origin: Behold this man.
modern: Look at this man.

origin: He hath fought today As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroyed in such a shape.
modern: Today he fought as though he were a god who hated mankind.

origin: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phoebus’ car.
modern: He deserves it, even if it were covered with jewels like holy

origin: If we be not relieved within this hour, We must return to th’ court of guard.
modern: If we aren’t relieved in an hour, we have to return to our barracks.

origin: O bear me witness, night— What man is this?
modern: Oh, listen to me, night— Who is this?

origin: Stand close and list him.
modern: Stay hidden and listen.

origin: Be witness to me, O thou blessèd moon, When men revolted shall upon record Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did Before thy face repent.
modern: Be my witness, oh you blessed moon.

origin: Enobarbus?
modern: That’s Enobarbus?

origin: Peace!
modern: Quiet!

origin: Hark further.
modern: Keep listening.

origin: Throw my heart Against the flint and hardness of my fault, Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder And finish all foul thoughts.
modern: My heart, which dried out with grief, will surely break apart into a powder, and that will be the end of my disgusting mind.

origin: O Antony!
modern: Oh, Antony!

origin: Let’s speak to him.
modern: Let’s speak to him.

origin: Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.
modern: Let’s listen to him.

origin: Let’s do so.
modern: Good idea.

origin: But he sleeps.
modern: But he’s sleeping.

origin: Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his Was never yet for sleep.
modern: No one ever gave a prayer like that before going to sleep.

origin: Go we to him.
modern: Let’s go to him.

origin: Awake, sir, awake.
modern: Wake up, sir, wake up.

origin: Speak to us.
modern: Speak to us.

origin: Hear you, sir?
modern: Do you hear us, sir?

origin: The hand of death hath raught him.
modern: The hand of death has taken him.

origin: Let us bear him  To th’ court of guard.
modern: Let’s carry him to the barracks.

origin: He is of note.
modern: He’s an important person.

origin: Our hour  Is fully out.
modern: Our hour is up.

origin: Come on, then.
modern: Come on, then.

origin: He may recover yet.
modern: He may recover yet.

origin: I shall do ’t.
modern: I will.

origin: Their preparation is today by sea.
modern: They’ve switched their operation to the sea today.

origin: We please them not by land.
modern: We didn’t please them on land.

origin: For both, my lord.
modern: We’re ready for both, my lord.

origin: I would they’d fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air, We’d fight there too.
modern: I wish they’d fight in fire or in the air.

origin: But this it is: our foot Upon the hills adjoining to the city Shall stay with us.
modern: But here’s the plan: our army will stay with us on the hills by the city.

origin: To the vales, And hold our best advantage.
modern: Let’s take up the best positions we can in the valleys.

origin: Yet they are not joined.
modern: They still haven’t joined the battle.

origin: Where yond pine does stand I shall discover all.
modern: I’ll be able to see better from that pine tree over there.

origin: I’ll bring thee word Straight how ’tis like to go.
modern: I’ll let you know right away how it’s going.

origin: Swallows have built In Cleopatra’s sails their nests.
modern: Swallows have built nests in Cleopatra’s sails.

origin: All is lost!
modern: All is lost!

origin: This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.
modern: This treacherous Egyptian has betrayed me.

origin: Triple-turned whore!
modern: Three-time traitor and whore!

origin: Bid them all fly, For when I am revenged upon my charm, I have done all.
modern: Tell the army to flee.

origin: Bid them all fly.
modern: Order them to escape.

origin: Begone!
modern: Go!

origin: O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.
modern: Oh, sun, I will never see another one of your sunrises.

origin: Fortune and Antony part here.
modern: Luck and Antony separate here and now.

origin: Even here Do we shake hands.
modern: Here we’ll shake hands good-bye.

origin: All come to this?
modern: Is it all come to this?

origin: Betrayed I am.
modern: I’ve been stripped of everything, betrayed.

origin: Oh, this false soul of Egypt!
modern: Oh, that devious Egyptian spirit!

origin: Ah, thou spell!
modern: Ah, you sorceress!

origin: Avaunt!
modern: Be gone!

origin: Why is my lord enraged against his love?
modern: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

origin: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving, And blemish Caesar’s triumph.
modern: Get out of my sight, or I’ll give you what you deserve and spoil Caesar’s victory.

origin: Let him take thee And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
modern: Let him hoist you up in front of the shouting crowds!

origin: Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot Of all thy sex.
modern: Follow his chariot, like the greatest disgrace to your whole gender.

origin: Most monsterlike be shown For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let Patient Octavia plow thy visage up With her preparèd nails!
modern: Then let Octavia dig up your face with her nails.

origin: She dies for ’t.—Eros, ho!
modern: She’ll die for it.—Eros, ho!

origin: Help me, my women!
modern: Help me, ladies!

origin: To th’ monument!
modern: Go to your tomb!

origin: There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
modern: Lock yourself in and send him word that you’re dead.

origin: The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off.
modern: When a great person departs, it causes more pain than when the soul leaves the body.

origin: Say that the last I spoke was “Antony,” And word it, prithee, piteously.
modern: Say the last word I spoke was “Antony,” and please word it pathetically.

origin: Hence, Mardian, And bring me how he takes my death.
modern: Go, Mardian, and let me know how he reacts to my death.

origin: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?
modern: Eros, can you still see me?

origin: Ay, noble lord.
modern: Yes, noble lord.

origin: Thou hast seen these signs.
modern: You’ve seen these illusions.

origin: Ay, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: That which is now a horse, even with a thought The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct As water is in water.
modern: What looks like a horse is quick as thought disfigured by the wind, made as difficult to distinguish as water poured into water.

origin: It does, my lord.
modern: That’s true, my lord.

origin: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body.
modern: Eros, my young friend, your captain is now just like that cloud.

origin: Here I am Antony, Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
modern: Here and now I seem like Antony, but I can’t keep myself in this form, my boy.

origin: Nay, weep not, gentle Eros.
modern: No, don’t cry, kind Eros.

origin: Oh, thy vile lady!
modern: Oh, your contemptible lady!

origin: She has robbed me of my sword.
modern: She has disarmed me.

origin: Hence, saucy eunuch!
modern: Get out, insolent eunuch!

origin: Peace!
modern: Silence!

origin: She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.
modern: She has betrayed me and shall die.

origin: Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged.
modern: A person can only pay with their life once, and she has paid in full.

origin: What thou wouldst do Is done unto thy hand.
modern: What you wanted is yours.

origin: The last she spake Was “Antony, most noble Antony!” Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony.
modern: Most noble Antony!” Then, as she was speaking your name, a strangled groan split her words.

origin: It was divided Between her heart and lips.
modern: Antony” was divided between her heart and lips.

origin: She rendered life, Thy name so buried in her.
modern: She gave up her life with your name still within her.

origin: Dead, then?
modern: Is she dead, then?

origin: Dead.
modern: Dead.

origin: Unarm, Eros.
modern: Remove your armor, Eros.

origin: Go.
modern: Off!

origin: Off, pluck off!
modern: Take off my armor.

origin: O, cleave, my sides!
modern: Oh, chest, obey me!

origin: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.
modern: Heart, for once be stronger than all the rest of the body combined.

origin: Crack thy frail case!—Apace, Eros, apace.
modern: Faster, Eros, faster.

origin: No more a soldier.
modern: I won’t be a soldier anymore.

origin: Bruisèd pieces, go.
modern: Battered armor, be off.

origin: You have been nobly borne.
modern: You were worn with honor.

origin: I will o’ertake thee, Cleopatra, and Weep for my pardon.
modern: I will catch up with you, Cleopatra, and weep for your forgiveness.

origin: Since the torch is out, Lie down and stray no farther.
modern: Since the light of my life has gone out, I’ll stop here.

origin: Now all labor Mars what it does.
modern: Now any effort ruins what it attempts.

origin: Yea, very force entangles Itself with strength.
modern: Yes, even power gets in its own way.

origin: Seal then, and all is done.— Eros!—I come, my Queen.—Eros!—Stay for me.
modern: End it, then, and everything is over.—Eros!—I’m coming, my Queen!—Eros!—Wait for me.

origin: Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand, And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
modern: In the place where souls recline on beds of flowers we’ll walk hand in hand and amaze the other ghosts with our spirited demeanor.

origin: Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops, And all the haunt be ours.—Come, Eros, Eros!
modern: Eros!

origin: What would my lord?
modern: What can I do for my lord?

origin: Since Cleopatra died I have lived in such dishonor that the gods Detest my baseness.
modern: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonor that the gods despise my disgrace.

origin: Do ’t.
modern: Do it.

origin: The time is come.
modern: This is that time.

origin: Thou strik’st not me, ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.
modern: You won’t be striking me down, but defeating Caesar.

origin: Put color in thy cheek.
modern: Call up your courage.

origin: The gods withhold me!
modern: The gods forbid!

origin: Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts, Though enemy, lost aim and could not?
modern: Can I do what all the Parthian arrows, though shot by enemies, could not?

origin: Eros, Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down His corrigible neck, his face subdued To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded His baseness that ensued?
modern: Eros, would you like to look through a window in Rome and watch your master marching in Caesar’s victory parade, his arms crossed and tied, his head bowed in submission, his face red from shame, while the chariot of triumphant Caesar precedes him, putting the final stamp to his humiliation?

origin: I would not see ’t.
modern: I would not.

origin: Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn Most useful for thy country.
modern: Draw your trustworthy sword, which you have used in such service to your country.

origin: O sir, pardon me!
modern: Oh, sir, pardon me!

origin: When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then To do this when I bade thee?
modern: When I freed you from slavery, didn’t you swear to do this when I asked you?

origin: Do it at once, Or thy precedent services are all But accidents unpurposed.
modern: Do it immediately, or all your previous services to me were accidental, without purpose.

origin: Draw and come.
modern: Take out your sword and come on.

origin: Turn from me then that noble countenance Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.
modern: Then turn your noble face away from me, that face that the whole world adores.

origin: Lo thee!
modern: Look!

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: I did not see him since.
modern: I haven’t seen him recently.

origin: What should I do I do not?
modern: What should I do that I’m not doing?

origin: In each thing give him way.
modern: Always give him his way.

origin: Cross him in nothing.
modern: Never contradict him.

origin: Tempt him not so too far.
modern: Don’t push him too far.

origin: I wish, forbear.
modern: I wish you’d be patient.

origin: In time we hate that which we often fear.
modern: We come to hate that which controls us.

origin: But here comes Antony.
modern: But here comes Antony.

origin: I am sick and sullen.
modern: I am sick and sullen.

origin: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose— Help me away, dear Charmian!
modern: I’m sorry to have to say this— Help me away from here, dear Charmian!

origin: I shall fall.
modern: I shall faint.

origin: My sword is drawn.
modern: I have drawn my sword.

origin: My dear master, My captain, and my emperor, let me say, Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.
modern: My dear master, my captain, my sovereign, let me say before I strike this fatal blow: farewell.

origin: Tis said, man, and farewell.
modern: You’ve said it, friend, and farewell to you.

origin: Farewell, great chief.
modern: Good-bye, great commander.

origin: Shall I strike now?
modern: Should I do it now?

origin: Now, Eros.
modern: Now, Eros.

origin: Why, there then!
modern: Well, then, there!

origin: Thus I do escape the sorrow Of Antony’s death.
modern: With this I avoid the grief of Antony’s death.

origin: My Queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record.
modern: My Queen and Eros have by their brave examples beaten me to the history books.

origin: To do thus I learned of thee.
modern: I learned to do this from you.

origin: How!
modern: What!

origin: Not dead?
modern: I’m not dead?

origin: Oh, dispatch me!
modern: Oh, kill me!

origin: What’s the noise?
modern: What’s the trouble?

origin: I have done my work ill, friends.
modern: I’ve botched the job, friends.

origin: Oh, make an end Of what I have begun!
modern: Oh, finish what I’ve begun.

origin: The star is fall’n.
modern: Our guiding light is out.

origin: And time is at his period.
modern: And time itself is ended.

origin: Alas, and woe!
modern: Sadness and despair!

origin: Let him that loves me strike me dead.
modern: Whoever’s a real friend should strike me dead.

origin: Not I.
modern: Not me.

origin: Nor I.
modern: Me neither.

origin: Nor anyone.
modern: None of us.

origin: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
modern: Your death and destiny advise your followers to escape.

origin: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings, Shall enter me with him.
modern: I only need to show your sword to Caesar and tell him about your death to get into his good favor.

origin: Where’s Antony?
modern: Where’s Antony?

origin: There, Diomed, there.
modern: There, Diomedes, there.

origin: Lives he?
modern: Is he still alive?

origin: Wilt thou not answer, man?
modern: Why don’t you answer me, man?

origin: Art thou there, Diomed?
modern: Is that you, Diomedes?

origin: Draw thy sword and give me Sufficing strokes for death.
modern: Draw your sword and give me enough blows to kill me.

origin: Most absolute lord, My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.
modern: Most powerful lord, my mistress Cleopatra sent me to you.

origin: When did she send thee?
modern: When did she send you?

origin: Now, my lord.
modern: Just now, my lord.

origin: Where is she?
modern: Where is she?

origin: Locked in her monument.
modern: Locked in her tomb.

origin: She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass.
modern: She had a premonition of what has actually happened.

origin: For when she saw— Which never shall be found—you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.
modern: Afraid that your anger would not subside, she sent you word she was dead.

origin: Too late, good Diomed.
modern: Too late, good Diomedes.

origin: Call my guard, I prithee.
modern: Call my guard, please.

origin: What ho, the Emperor’s guard!
modern: Hey out there!

origin: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.
modern: Carry me, good friends, to where Cleopatra is.

origin: Tis the last service that I shall command you.
modern: It’s the last command I shall ever give you.

origin: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear All your true followers out.
modern: We’re very sorry, sir, that you may not live to wear us out with your commands.

origin: Most heavy day!
modern: It’s a very sad day.

origin: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows.
modern: No, my friends, don’t please fate by giving it your sorrow as well.

origin: Bid that welcome Which comes to punish us, and we punish it, Seeming to bear it lightly.
modern: If we welcome our punishment, we punish it right back by seeming to take it lightly.

origin: Take me up.
modern: Pick me up.

origin: I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.
modern: I have often led you, now you must carry me, my good friends—and take my thanks for everything.

origin: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.
modern: Oh, Charmian, I will never leave this tomb!

origin: Be comforted, dear madam.
modern: Be calm, dear lady.

origin: No, I will not.
modern: No, I won’t.

origin: All strange and terrible events are welcome, But comforts we despise.
modern: Strange and terrible events are all welcome, but I despise comforts.

origin: Our size of sorrow, Proportioned to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it.
modern: The size of my sorrow must be as great as its source.

origin: How now?
modern: What’s the news!

origin: Is he dead?
modern: Is he dead?

origin: His death’s upon him, but not dead.
modern: He is close to death, but not dead yet.

origin: O Antony, Antony, Antony!
modern: Oh, Antony, Antony, Antony!

origin: Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!
modern: Help, Charmian, help, Iras, help!

origin: Peace!
modern: Be calm!

origin: Not Caesar’s valor hath o’erthrown Antony, But Antony’s hath triumphed on itself.
modern: It was not Caesar’s bravery that conquered Antony but Antony’s that has triumphed over himself.

origin: So it should be, that none but Antony Should conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!
modern: That’s the way it should be—only Antony should conquer Antony.

origin: Nay, but this dotage of our general’s O’erflows the measure.
modern: No, our general’s infatuation is out of control.

origin: Those his goodly eyes, That o’er the files and musters of the war Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn The office and devotion of their view Upon a tawny front.
modern: His eyes used to glow with pride when he reviewed his troops.

origin: His captain’s heart, Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gypsy’s lust.
modern: His heart used to burst the buckles on his breastplate in great fights, but now he’s lost all temperance and dedicates his heart to satisfying the lust of an Egyptian whore.

origin: Look where they come.
modern: Look at them.

origin: Take but good note, and you shall see in him The triple pillar of the world transformed Into a strumpet’s fool.
modern: Take a good look, and you’ll see that one of the three men who rule the world has turned into a whore’s jester.

origin: Behold and see.
modern: Look and see.

origin: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.
modern: If what you feel is really love, tell me how much.

origin: There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.
modern: It would be a pretty stingy love if it could be counted and calculated.

origin: I’ll set a bourn how far to be beloved.
modern: I want to measure the extent of your love, to see how far it stretches.

origin: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
modern: Then you would have to go beyond heaven, beyond earth.

origin: News, my good lord, from Rome.
modern: I have news from Rome, my good lord.

origin: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
modern: I am dying, Cleopatra, dying.

origin: Only I here importune death awhile, until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips.
modern: I just beg death to wait awhile, until I place the last of our many thousands of kisses on your lips.

origin: I dare not, dear, Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not, Lest I be taken.
modern: I don’t dare come down—forgive me, my lord—I don’t dare, for fear of capture.

origin: Not th’ imperious show Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall Be brooched with me.
modern: I will never be exhibited as lucky Caesar’s prize.

origin: If knife, drugs, serpents, have Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
modern: If knives, poison, or snakes have edge, effect, or venom, I am safe from that fate.

origin: Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor Demuring upon me.
modern: Your wife Octavia, with her self-effacing eyes and self-righteous assumptions, won’t get any praise from patronizing me.

origin: Assist, good friends.
modern: Help us, good friends.

origin: Oh, quick, or I am gone.
modern: Oh, quick, before I’m gone.

origin: Here’s sport indeed!
modern: Such exercise!

origin: How heavy weighs my lord!
modern: My lord is so heavy!

origin: Had I great Juno’s power, The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up And set thee by Jove’s side.
modern: If I had the goddess Juno’s power, I would make the strong-winged messenger, Mercury, pick you up and seat you beside Jove.

origin: And welcome, welcome!
modern: And welcome, welcome!

origin: Die when thou hast lived.
modern: Die where you have lived, in my arms.

origin: Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.
modern: If my lips had the power to give life, I would wear them out like this.

origin: A heavy sight!
modern: What a sad sight!

origin: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
modern: I am dying, Cleopatra, dying.

origin: Give me some wine and let me speak a little.
modern: Give me some wine and let me say a few words.

origin: My resolution and my hands I’ll trust, None about Caesar.
modern: I’ll trust my determination and my hands, but none of Caesar’s men.

origin: Now my spirit is going.
modern: Now I feel my soul leaving.

origin: I can no more.
modern: I can’t speak any more.

origin: Noblest of men, woo’t die?
modern: Most noble man, will you die?

origin: Hast thou no care of me?
modern: Don’t you care about me?

origin: Shall I abide In this dull world, which in thy absence is No better than a sty?
modern: Shall I stay in this dreary world, which is no better than a pigsty without you?

origin: My lord!
modern: My lord!

origin: Oh, withered is the garland of the war.
modern: Oh, the glory of war has faded.

origin: The soldier’s pole is fall’n!
modern: The flags have fallen.

origin: Young boys and girls Are level now with men.
modern: Young boys and girls are equal to men.

origin: The odds is gone, And there is nothing left remarkable Beneath the visiting moon.
modern: There is nothing distinctive, nothing remarkable left in the world.

origin: She’s dead too, our sovereign.
modern: Our Queen is dead too.

origin: Lady!
modern: Lady!

origin: Madam!
modern: Madam!

origin: O madam, madam, madam!
modern: Oh, madam, madam, madam!

origin: Royal Egypt, Empress!
modern: Royal Egypt, Empress!

origin: Peace, peace, Iras.
modern: Quiet, quiet, Iras.

origin: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares.
modern: Now I am no more than a woman, ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores.

origin: All’s but naught.
modern: Now all is for nothing.

origin: How do you, women?
modern: How are you, my ladies?

origin: What, what, good cheer!
modern: Cheer up!

origin: Why, how now, Charmian?
modern: How are you, Charmian?

origin: My noble girls!
modern: My gallant girls!

origin: Good sirs, take heart.
modern: Good noble ladies, be brave.

origin: We’ll bury him, and then, what’s brave, what’s noble, Let’s do ’t after the high Roman fashion And make death proud to take us.
modern: We’ll bury him, and then we’ll commit acts as brave and fine as any Romans, and make death proud to take us.

origin: Come, away.
modern: Come on, you can go.

origin: This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
modern: The container of that great soul is now cold.

origin: Ah, women, women!
modern: Ah, ladies, ladies!

origin: Come.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: We have no friend But resolution, and the briefest end.
modern: We have no friends but determination and the quickest death.

origin: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.
modern: Tell him to surrender.

origin: Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks The pauses that he makes.
modern: His position is hopeless.

origin: Caesar, I shall.
modern: Right away, Caesar.

origin: Wherefore is that?
modern: What are you doing with a sword?

origin: And what art thou that dar’st Appear thus to us?
modern: Who do you think you are coming in here armed?

origin: I am called Dercetus.
modern: My name is Decretus.

origin: Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy Best to be served.
modern: I served Mark Antony, who was the commander most worthy of my services.

origin: Whilst he stood up and spoke, He was my master, and I wore my life To spend upon his haters.
modern: While he was alive, I lived only to serve him and oppose his enemies.

origin: If thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.
modern: If not, you can kill me.

origin: What is ’t thou say’st?
modern: What are you saying?

origin: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
modern: Caesar, I’m telling you that Antony is dead.

origin: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack.
modern: When such a great man dies there should be a thunderclap.

origin: The round world Should have shook lions into civil streets And citizens to their dens.
modern: The fractured world, in its confusion, should send lions into the city streets and humans into the wilderness to live in lions’ dens.

origin: The death of Antony Is not a single doom.
modern: This isn’t the death of one man.

origin: In the name lay A moiety of the world.
modern: It’s the death of half the world.

origin: Now, my dearest Queen— Pray you, stand farther from me.
modern: Now, my dearest Queen— Please, stand farther away from me.

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: I know by that same eye there’s some good news.
modern: I can see in your eyes there’s been some good news.

origin: What, says the married woman you may go?
modern: What, does your wife say you can come home?

origin: Would she had never given you leave to come!
modern: I wish she’d never let you come.

origin: Let her not say ’tis I that keep you here.
modern: Don’t let her say I kept you.

origin: I have no power upon you.
modern: I have no power over you.

origin: Hers you are.
modern: You belong to her.

origin: The gods best know—                                              Oh never was there queen So mightily betrayed!
modern: The gods know— Oh, never has a queen been so betrayed as I have been.

origin: Yet at the first I saw the treasons planted.
modern: I knew from the first it would be this way.

origin: Cleopatra— Why should I think you can be mine, and true— Though you in swearing shake the thronèd gods— Who have been false to Fulvia?
modern: Cleopatra— How could I have ever thought that you would be faithful and true, even though your vows of love shook the heavens themselves—you, who were unfaithful to Fulvia?

origin: Riotous madness, To be entangled with those mouth-made vows Which break themselves in swearing!
modern: It was wild insanity to believe promises made by the mouth and not the heart.

origin: When you sued staying, Then was the time for words.
modern: When you begged to stay, that was the time for words.

origin: No going then!
modern: You didn’t want to go then!

origin: Eternity was in our lips and eyes, Bliss in our brows’ bent, none our parts so poor But was a race of heaven.
modern: You saw eternity in my lips and eyes, and happiness in the arch of my eyebrows.

origin: They are so still, Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world, Art turned the greatest liar.
modern: My features are still that beautiful—or else you, the greatest soldier in the world, have become the greatest liar by overpraising them.

origin: This is his sword.
modern: This is his sword.

origin: I robbed his wound of it.
modern: I pulled it from his wound.

origin: Behold it stained With his most noble blood.
modern: Look—his noble blood is still on it.

origin: Look you, sad friends, The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings.
modern: Listen, sad friends, though the gods may rebuke me, this news would make kings cry.

origin: His taints and honors Waged equal with him.
modern: His faults were equally matched by his virtues.

origin: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us Some faults to make us men.
modern: But gods, you give us faults so we’ll be human.

origin: Caesar is touched.
modern: Caesar is upset.

origin: I must perforce Have shown to thee such a declining day, Or look on thine.
modern: Either I had to ruin you, or you would have ruined me.

origin: Hear me, good friends—
modern: Let me tell you, friends—

origin: But I will tell you at some meeter season.
modern: I’ll tell you at a better time.

origin: The business of this man looks out of him.
modern: This man looks like his business is urgent.

origin: We’ll hear him what he says.
modern: Let’s hear what he has to say.

origin: Bid her have good heart.
modern: Tell her to put her mind at rest.

origin: She soon shall know of us, by some of ours, How honorable and how kindly we Determine for her, for Caesar cannot live To be ungentle.
modern: She’ll find out soon enough by one of our messengers how respectfully and kindly we plan to treat her.

origin: So the gods preserve thee!
modern: May the gods bless you.

origin: Come hither, Proculeius.
modern: Come here, Proculeius.

origin: Go and say We purpose her no shame.
modern: Tell her we mean her no disrespect.

origin: Go, And with your speediest bring us what she says And how you find of her.
modern: Go, and hurry back to bring us her reply and news of her state of mind.

origin: Caesar, I shall.
modern: I will, Caesar.

origin: Gallus, go you along.
modern: Gallus, you go with him.

origin: Where’s Dolabella, To second Proculeius?
modern: Where’s Dolabella?

origin: Dolabella!
modern: Dolabella!

origin: Let him alone, for I remember now How he’s employed.
modern: I remember he’s already occupied.

origin: He shall in time be ready.
modern: He’ll be done in time.

origin: Go with me and see What I can show in this.
modern: Come and see the proof.

origin: Tis paltry to be Caesar.
modern: It’s pathetic to be Caesar.

origin: Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave, A minister of her will.
modern: He can’t be Fortune; he’s only Fortune’s errand boy.

origin: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt, And bids thee study on what fair demands Thou mean’st to have him grant thee.
modern: Caesar greets the Queen of Egypt and asks that you consider what you will ask from him.

origin: What’s thy name?
modern: What’s your name?

origin: My name is Proculeius.
modern: My name is Proculeius.

origin: Antony Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but I do not greatly care to be deceived, That have no use for trusting.
modern: But I don’t worry about being deceived because I don’t need to trust.

origin: If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom.
modern: If your master wants a queen to beg from him, you should tell him that a queen will beg for no less than a kingdom.

origin: If he please To give me conquered Egypt for my son, He gives me so much of mine own as I Will kneel to him with thanks.
modern: If he will grant me conquered Egypt, so that I may give it to my son, I will kneel to him with thanks.

origin: Be of good cheer.
modern: Be content.

origin: You’re fall’n into a princely hand.
modern: You’re in the charge of an honorable man.

origin: Fear nothing.
modern: Don’t be afraid.

origin: Let me report to him Your sweet dependency, and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness Where he for grace is kneeled to.
modern: If I can tell him that you have submitted to him sweetly, he’ll request your assistance in finding ways in which he can support you.

origin: Pray you, tell him I am his fortune’s vassal, and I send him The greatness he has got.
modern: Please tell him I have surrendered to his fortune.

origin: I hourly learn A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly Look him i’ th’ face.
modern: I’m learning every hour how to be subservient.

origin: This I’ll report, dear lady.
modern: I’ll tell him all of this, dear lady.

origin: You see how easily she may be surprised.
modern: Be at ease.

origin: Royal Queen!
modern: Your majesty!

origin: O Cleopatra!
modern: Oh, Cleopatra!

origin: Hold, worthy lady, hold!
modern: Stop, brave lady, stop!

origin: Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this Relieved but not betrayed.
modern: We have not betrayed you.

origin: What, of death too, That rids our dogs of languish?
modern: What, am I being denied death, as well?

origin: Cleopatra, Do not abuse my master’s bounty by Th’ undoing of yourself.
modern: Don’t insult my master’s generosity by killing yourself.

origin: Let the world see His nobleness well acted, which your death Will never let come forth.
modern: Your death would prevent that.

origin: Where art thou, Death?
modern: Where are you, Death?

origin: Come hither, come!
modern: Come here.

origin: Come, come and take a queen Worth many babes and beggars!
modern: Come, and you can have a queen.

origin: Oh, temperance, lady!
modern: Oh, control yourself, lady!

origin: This mortal house I’ll ruin, Do Caesar what he can.
modern: Let Caesar do whatever he wants.

origin: Know, sir, that I Will not wait pinioned at your master’s court, Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia.
modern: You’d better understand that I won’t wait till I’m chained up in your master’s court, and I won’t let myself be scolded even once by dull Octavia.

origin: Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome?
modern: Shall I let them exhibit me to the shouting mobs of Rome?

origin: Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me.
modern: I’d rather die in a ditch in Egypt, and make it my gentle grave.

origin: Rather on Nilus’ mud Lay me stark naked and let the waterflies Blow me into abhorring.
modern: I’d rather lie in the Nile mud with flies laying their eggs in me, making me disgusting.

origin: Rather make My country’s high pyramides my gibbet And hang me up in chains!
modern: I’d rather be hung in chains from one of our pyramids!

origin: You do extend These thoughts of horror further than you shall Find cause in Caesar.
modern: You’ll see that Caesar is giving you no reason to do so.

origin: Proculeius, What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows, And he hath sent for thee.
modern: Proculeius, Caesar has heard about what you’ve done here and has sent for you.

origin: For the Queen, I’ll take her to my guard.
modern: I’ll take the Queen into my custody.

origin: So, Dolabella, It shall content me best.
modern: So be it, Dolabella.

origin: Be gentle to her.
modern: Be kind to her.

origin: Most noble Empress, you have heard of me?
modern: Have you heard of me, most noble Empress?

origin: I cannot tell.
modern: I don’t remember.

origin: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams.
modern: You must be the one who laughs when boys or women tell you their dreams.

origin: Is ’t not your trick?
modern: Isn’t that your habit?

origin: I understand not, madam.
modern: I don’t know what you mean, madam.

origin: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
modern: I dreamed about an emperor called Antony.

origin: Oh, such another sleep, that I might see But such another man!
modern: Oh, I wish I could sleep again, so I could have another dream like that!

origin: His reared arm Crested the world.
modern: When he raised his arm in command, the world trembled.

origin: For his bounty, There was no winter in ’t, an autumn ’twas That grew the more by reaping.
modern: There was no end to his generosity.

origin: In his livery Walked crowns and crownets.
modern: Kings and noblemen served him.

origin: Realms and islands were As plates dropped from his pocket.
modern: Kingdoms and provinces dropped from his pockets like loose change.

origin: Cleopatra— Think you there was or might be such a man As this I dreamt of?
modern: Cleopatra— Do you think there ever was, or could there ever be, a man such as the one I dreamed about?

origin: Gentle madam, no.
modern: No, gentle madam.

origin: You lie up to the hearing of the gods.
modern: The gods can hear you lying!

origin: Nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t’ imagine An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy, Condemning shadows quite.
modern: Antony would easily outshine all imaginary beings.

origin: Hear me, good madam.
modern: Listen to me, madam.

origin: Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it As answering to the weight.
modern: You are a remarkable person and your loss is equally remarkable.

origin: Would I might never O’ertake pursued success, but I do feel, By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites My very heart at root.
modern: I hope I never achieve success if I don’t feel some of your heartbroken grief right now.

origin: I thank you, sir.
modern: Thank you, sir.

origin: Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
modern: Do you know what Caesar intends to do with me?

origin: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.
modern: I’m reluctant to tell you what I wish you knew.

origin: Arise, you shall not kneel.
modern: You need not kneel to me.

origin: I pray you, rise.
modern: Please rise, Queen.

origin: Sir, the gods Will have it thus.
modern: The gods have ordained it to be like this, sir.

origin: Take to you no hard thoughts.
modern: Don’t think I blame you.

origin: I’ll take my leave.
modern: I’ll leave you now.

origin: And may, through all the world!
modern: You may do whatever you want in the world.

origin: Tis yours, and we, Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall Hang in what place you please.
modern: It’s yours, and you may hang us, your trophies of war, anywhere you like.

origin: Here, my good lord.
modern: Here, my good lord.

origin: How now, lady?
modern: What do you mean, lady?

origin: I would I had thy inches.
modern: I wish I were as big and strong as you.

origin: Thou shouldst know There were a heart in Egypt.
modern: Listen to me, Queen.

origin: Hear me, Queen: The strong necessity of time commands Our services awhile, but my full heart Remains in use with you.
modern: There is an emergency I must take care of, but my whole heart will remain here with you.

origin: Our Italy Shines o’er with civil swords.
modern: My Italy is full of civil war.

origin: Sextus Pompeius Makes his approaches to the port of Rome.
modern: Sextus Pompeius is sailing toward the port of Rome.

origin: My more particular, And that which most with you should safe my going, Is Fulvia’s death.
modern: But my personal motivation—and that which should move you most to sanction my departure—is that Fulvia is dead.

origin: Can Fulvia die?
modern: Is it possible Fulvia is dead?

origin: She’s dead, my Queen.
modern: She’s dead, my Queen.

origin: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.
modern: You shall advise me in everything having to do with Cleopatra.

origin: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels I am possessed of.
modern: This is the inventory of the money, silverware, dishes, and jewels that are still in my possession.

origin: Tis exactly valued, Not petty things admitted.
modern: Not even trivial things were left out.

origin: Where’s Seleucus?
modern: Where’s Seleucus?

origin: Here, madam.
modern: Here, madam.

origin: This is my treasurer.
modern: This is my treasurer.

origin: Let him speak, my lord, Upon his peril, that I have reserved To myself nothing.
modern: My lord, he will swear on his life that I haven’t kept a thing.—Tell the truth, Seleucus.

origin: Madam, I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not.
modern: Madam, I’d rather sew my lips shut than tell a lie when my life depends upon it.

origin: What have I kept back?
modern: What did I keep for myself?

origin: Enough to purchase what you have made known.
modern: Enough to buy everything you have declared.

origin: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra.
modern: No, don’t be ashamed, Cleopatra.

origin: See, Caesar!
modern: Look around you, Caesar.

origin: Oh, behold How pomp is followed!
modern: Oh, just see what happens after the pageantry is over!

origin: The ingratitude of this Seleucus does Even make me wild.
modern: Seleucus’ ingratitude makes me wild.

origin: Thou shalt Go back, I warrant thee!
modern: I’ll give you a good reason to cringe, I promise you.

origin: But I’ll catch thine eyes, Though they had wings.
modern: I’ll scratch out your eyes, even if they could fly.

origin: Oh, rarely base!
modern: Oh, that was unbelievably low!

origin: Cleopatra, Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest.
modern: Cleopatra, our conquest won’t include either the things you kept back or the ones you listed.

origin: Still be ’t yours.
modern: It’s all still yours.

origin: Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe Caesar’s no merchant, to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold.
modern: Do whatever you like with it.

origin: Therefore be cheered.
modern: So cheer up.

origin: No, dear Queen, For we intend so to dispose you as Yourself shall give us counsel.
modern: No, dear Queen.

origin: Feed and sleep.
modern: Eat and sleep.

origin: Our care and pity is so much upon you That we remain your friend.
modern: I have so much care and pity for you that you could call me friend.

origin: And so, adieu.
modern: And so, good-bye.

origin: My master, and my lord!
modern: My master and my lord!

origin: Not so.
modern: Not true.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Good-bye.

origin: But, hark thee, Charmian.
modern: But listen, Charmian.

origin: Finish, good lady.
modern: It’s time to end it, good lady.

origin: Madam, I will.
modern: I will, madam.

origin: Where’s the Queen?
modern: Where’s the Queen?

origin: Behold, sir.
modern: Look, sir.

origin: Dolabella!
modern: Dolabella.

origin: Make your best use of this.
modern: Make the best use of this information you can.

origin: I have performed Your pleasure and my promise.
modern: I have done your bidding and fulfilled my promise.

origin: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.
modern: Dolabella, I will always be in debt to you.

origin: I your servant.
modern: And I your servant.

origin: Adieu, good Queen.
modern: Good-bye, good Queen.

origin: I must attend on Caesar.
modern: I must go attend Caesar.

origin: Farewell, and thanks.
modern: Farewell, and thanks.

origin: Now, Iras, what think’st thou?
modern: Now, Iras, what do you think?

origin: Thou an Egyptian puppet shalt be shown In Rome, as well as I.
modern: You will be exhibited in Rome along with me, like Egyptian puppets.

origin: Mechanic slaves With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall Uplift us to the view.
modern: Crude slaves with greasy aprons, rulers, and hammers shall lift us up so everyone can see.

origin: The gods forbid!
modern: The gods forbid!

origin: Nay, ’tis most certain, Iras.
modern: No, it’s certain, Iras.

origin: Oh, the good gods!
modern: Insolent  Oh, the good gods!

origin: Nay, that’s certain.
modern: No, that’s the truth.

origin: I’ll never see ’t!
modern: I’ll never see it.

origin: For I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes.
modern: I know my nails are stronger than my eyes; I’ll scratch them out.

origin: Why, that’s the way To fool their preparation and to conquer Their most absurd intents.
modern: Why, that’s just the way to frustrate their plans and defeat their absurd intentions.

origin: Now, Charmian!
modern: Now, Charmian!

origin: Show me, my women, like a queen.
modern: Women, dress me like a queen.

origin: Go fetch My best attires.
modern: Go get my best clothes.

origin: Wherefore’s this noise?
modern: What’s that noise?

origin: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.
modern: There’s a farmer here who won’t leave without seeing your Highness.

origin: He brings you figs.
modern: He has brought you figs.

origin: Let him come in.
modern: Let him come in.

origin: What poor an instrument May do a noble deed!
modern: What a poor instrument, that can do such a noble deed!

origin: He brings me liberty.
modern: He brings me freedom.

origin: My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me.
modern: There’s nothing of the weak woman left in me.

origin: Now from head to foot I am marble-constant.
modern: Now from head to foot I’m as firm as marble.

origin: Now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine.
modern: Now the inconstant moon has nothing to do with me.

origin: This is the man.
modern: This is the man.

origin: Avoid, and leave him.
modern: Leave us.

origin: Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there, That kills and pains not?
modern: Do you have in there the pretty snake of the Nile that kills without pain?

origin: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal.
modern: I certainly do have him, but I wouldn’t advise you to touch him.

origin: Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.
modern: People who die of it seldom or never recover.

origin: Remember’st thou any that have died on ’t?
modern: Do you remember anyone who died of it?

origin: Very many, men and women too.
modern: Many people, men and women alike.

origin: Truly, she makes a very good report o’ th’ worm.
modern: Indeed, she gives a very good testimony of the snake’s power.

origin: But he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do.
modern: But if you believe everything they say, you won’t be saved by half of what they do.

origin: But this is most falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.
modern: But this is a sure thing: the snake’s an odd snake.

origin: I wish you all joy of the worm.
modern: I hope you are pleased with the snake.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.
modern: You must know that the snake will act according to his nature.

origin: Ay, ay.
modern: Yes, yes.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people, for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.
modern: There isn’t any kindness in the snake.

origin: Very good.
modern: Good.

origin: Will it eat me?
modern: Will it eat me?

origin: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman.
modern: Don’t think I’m so dumb that I don’t know that the devil himself won’t eat a woman.

origin: Well, get thee gone.
modern: Well, you can go now.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: Give me my robe.
modern: Give me my robe.

origin: Put on my crown.
modern: Put on my crown.

origin: I have Immortal longings in me.
modern: I long to be immortal.

origin: Yare, yare, good Iras, quick.
modern: Quickly, quickly, good Iras, quickly.

origin: Methinks I hear Antony call.
modern: I think I hear Antony call me.

origin: I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act.
modern: I see him revive himself to praise my noble act.

origin: I hear him mock The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men To excuse their after wrath.—Husband, I come!
modern: I hear him mock Caesar’s luck, which the gods give to men in order to balance out their subsequent wrath.

origin: Now to that name my courage prove my title!
modern: Now let my courage prove my title as wife.

origin: I am fire and air, my other elements I give to baser life.—So, have you done?
modern: So, are you done?

origin: Come then and take the last warmth of my lips.
modern: Come then, kiss me and take the last bit of warmth from my lips.

origin: Farewell, kind Charmian.
modern: Good-bye, kind Charmian.

origin: Iras, long farewell.
modern: Iras, I won’t see you again for a long time.

origin: Have I the aspic in my lips?
modern: Do I have the asp’s poison on my lips?

origin: Dost fall?
modern: Did you fall?

origin: If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch, Which hurts, and is desired.
modern: If you can leave your body so easily, then the touch of death is like a lover’s pinch, which hurts but is desired.

origin: Dost thou lie still?
modern: Do you lie still?

origin: If thus thou vanishest, thou tell’st the world It is not worth leave-taking.
modern: If you leave like that, you tell the world that it’s not worthy of a good-bye.

origin: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say The gods themselves do weep!
modern: Clouds, dissolve into rain, so that I could say the gods themselves are weeping!

origin: Come, thou mortal wretch, With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate Of life at once untie.
modern: Separate me from life with your sharp teeth.

origin: Poor venomous fool Be angry and dispatch.
modern: Poor poisonous fool, be angry and bite.

origin: Oh, couldst thou speak, That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass Unpolicied!
modern: Oh, if you could speak, I might hear you call Caesar an ass who’s been outsmarted!

origin: O eastern star!
modern: Oh, eastern star!

origin: Peace, peace!
modern: Quiet, quiet!

origin: Dost thou not see my baby at my breast, That sucks the nurse asleep?
modern: Don’t you see my baby suckling at my breast so that its nurse will fall asleep?

origin: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too.
modern: The poison is as sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle—Oh, Antony!—No, I’ll take you too.

origin: What should I stay— In this wild world?
modern: Why should I stay— In this vile world?

origin: So, fare thee well.
modern: So, good-bye.

origin: Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession lies A lass unparalleled.
modern: Now, Death, you can boast that you have an incomparable girl in your possession.

origin: Downy windows, close,
modern: Close, soft eyes.

origin: And golden Phoebus never be beheld Of eyes again so royal!
modern: The sun will never be seen by such royal eyes again.

origin: Your crown’s awry.
modern: Your crown is crooked.

origin: I’ll mend it and then play— Where’s the Queen?
modern: I’ll straighten it, then play— Where’s the Queen?

origin: Speak softly.
modern: Speak softly.

origin: Wake her not.
modern: Don’t wake her.

origin: Caesar hath sent—                                        Too slow a messenger.
modern: Caesar has sent— Too slow a messenger.

origin: Oh, come apace, dispatch!
modern: Oh, come quickly!

origin: I partly feel thee.
modern: I almost feel you.

origin: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar.
modern: There’s Dolabella, who was sent from Caesar.

origin: Call him.
modern: Call him.

origin: What work is here, Charmian?
modern: What kind of work is this, Charmian?

origin: Is this well done?
modern: Is this well done?

origin: It is well done and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings.
modern: It is well done, and appropriate for a princess who has descended from so many royal kings.

origin: Ah, soldier!
modern: Ah, soldier!

origin: How goes it here?
modern: What’s going on in here?

origin: All dead.
modern: They’re all dead.

origin: Caesar, thy thoughts Touch their effects in this.
modern: Caesar, you thought this would happen.

origin: Thyself art coming To see performed the dreaded act which thou So sought’st to hinder.
modern: You’re coming here yourself to see the dreaded act you had tried to stop.

origin: O most false love!
modern: Oh, unfaithful lover!

origin: Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill With sorrowful water?
modern: Stop arguing and listen to my plans.

origin: Now I see, I see, In Fulvia’s death how mine received shall be.
modern: Whether I go ahead with them or not is completely up to you.

origin: By the fire That quickens Nilus’ slime, I go from hence Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war As thou affects.
modern: I swear by the sun that when I leave here, it will be as your faithful servant.

origin: Cut my lace, Charmian, come!
modern: Cut my corset laces, Charmian, so I can breathe.

origin: But let it be.
modern: Hurry!

origin: I am quickly ill, and well, So Antony loves.
modern: Just as Antony loves.

origin: My precious Queen, forbear, And give true evidence to his love which stands An honorable trial.
modern: Control yourself, my precious Queen, and concede that my love is true.

origin: So Fulvia told me.
modern: That’s what Fulvia told me.

origin: I prithee, turn aside and weep for her.
modern: I beg you, turn away and cry for her.

origin: Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears Belong to Egypt.
modern: Then say good-bye to me and tell me those tears were for my benefit.

origin: O sir, you are too sure an augurer.
modern: Oh, sir, you are too good at predicting the future.

origin: That you did fear is done.
modern: What you were afraid of has happened.

origin: The manner of their deaths?
modern: How did they die?

origin: I do not see them bleed.
modern: I don’t see any blood.

origin: Who was last with them?
modern: Who was with them last?

origin: A simple countryman that brought her figs.
modern: A simple country farmer who brought her figs.

origin: This was his basket.
modern: This was the basket.

origin: Poisoned, then.
modern: They were poisoned, then.

origin: Oh, Caesar, This Charmian lived but now.
modern: Oh, Caesar, this Charmian lived until a moment ago.

origin: She stood and spake.
modern: She stood and spoke.

origin: I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress.
modern: I found her adjusting the crown on her dead mistress.

origin: Tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropped.
modern: She stood trembling, then suddenly dropped dead.

origin: Oh, noble weakness!
modern: Oh, noble weakness!

origin: Here on her breast There is a vent of blood, and something blown.
modern: Here on her breast there’s a little bloody mark.

origin: The like is on her arm.
modern: There’s a similar mark on her arm.

origin: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves Have slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile.
modern: This is an asp’s trail, and these fig leaves have slime on them, just like the kind that asps deposit on the caves by the Nile.

origin: Take up her bed And bear her women from the monument.
modern: Pick up her bed and carry her ladies out of the tomb.

origin: She shall be buried by her Antony.
modern: She shall be buried next to her Antony.

origin: No grave upon the earth shall clip in it A pair so famous.
modern: No other grave on earth shall hold a pair this famous.

origin: Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral, And then to Rome.
modern: Our army shall somberly attend this funeral and then depart for Rome.

origin: Come, Dolabella, see High order in this great solemnity.
modern: Come, Dolabella.

origin: You’ll heat my blood.
modern: You’ll make me angry.

origin: No more.
modern: No more of this.

origin: You can do better yet, but this is meetly.
modern: I know you can do better than that, but it’ll do for now.

origin: Now, by my sword—                                              And target.
modern: I swear by my sword— Swear by your shield, too!

origin: I’ll leave you, lady.
modern: I’ll leave you, lady.

origin: Courteous lord, one word.
modern: Polite sir, let me say one thing.

origin: Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it.
modern: Sir, you and I must part company—no, that’s not it.

origin: Tis sweating labor To bear such idleness so near the heart As Cleopatra this.
modern: It’s difficult to have such immaturity so close to my heart, but bear with me.

origin: But, sir, forgive me, Since my becomings kill me when they do not Eye well to you.
modern: Even the traits that become me most kill me when you don’t approve of them.

origin: Your honor calls you hence.
modern: Your honor is the reason you are leaving.

origin: Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly, And all the gods go with you!
modern: May the gods be with you.

origin: Upon your sword Sit laurel victory, and smooth success Be strewed before your feet.
modern: May your sword be victorious and everything you do succeed.

origin: Let us go.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: Come.
modern: Come with me.

origin: Our separation so abides and flies That thou, residing here, goes yet with me, And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
modern: Our imminent separation so occupies our thoughts that even though you stay here, you come with me, and even though I leave here, I stay with you.

origin: You are too indulgent.
modern: You’re too forgiving.

origin: Say this becomes him— As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things cannot blemish—yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness.
modern: Even if we said that this behavior suits him—though only a man with a perfect character could avoid being disgraced by such antics—there’s no excuse for the extra work we’ve had to take on while he’s been off amusing himself.

origin: If he filled His vacancy with his voluptuousness, Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones Call on him for ’t.
modern: If he’s been spending his leisure time in lustful pursuits, then he’ll be punished with venereal diseases, and that’s his business.

origin: Here’s more news.
modern: Here’s more news.

origin: Pompey is strong at sea, And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar.
modern: Pompey has a strong navy.

origin: I should have known no less.
modern: I should have known it.

origin: It hath been taught us from the primal state That he which is was wished until he were, And the ebbed man, ne’er loved till ne’er worth love, Comes deared by being lacked.
modern: It’s been this way ever since the first government was organized.

origin: Caesar, I bring thee word Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound With keels of every kind.
modern: Caesar, I have news about Menecrates and Menas, notorious pirates who prowl the sea in a variety of ships.

origin: Many hot inroads They make in Italy—the borders maritime Lack blood to think on ’t—and flush youth revolt.
modern: They’ve made many raids upon Italy—and the naval patrols go pale at even the thought of resisting them.

origin: Antony, Leave thy lascivious wassails.
modern: Antony, it’s time to stop your wild hedonism.

origin: When thou once Wast beaten from Modena, where thou slew’st Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel Did famine follow, whom thou fought’st against, Though daintily brought up, with patience more Than savages could suffer.
modern: And even though you were brought up as a gentleman, you patiently tolerated more hardships than savages could withstand.

origin: Thou didst drink The stale of horses and the gilded puddle Which beasts would cough at.
modern: You drank horses’ urine and water from scum-covered puddles that even animals would refuse.

origin: Tis pity of him.
modern: It’s too bad.

origin: Let his shames quickly Drive him to Rome.
modern: Let’s hope his sense of shame will send him back to Rome quickly.

origin: Tis time we twain Did show ourselves i’ th’ field, and to that end Assemble we immediate council.
modern: It’s time that we brought our armies into the field.

origin: Pompey Thrives in our idleness.
modern: Pompey is making the most of our absence.

origin: Tomorrow, Caesar, I shall be furnished to inform you rightly Both what by sea and land I can be able To front this present time.
modern: Tomorrow, Caesar, I’ll be able to tell you what land and sea forces I can raise for this war.

origin: Till which encounter It is my business too.
modern: I’ll be getting my own figures together in the meantime.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Good-bye.

origin: Farewell, my lord.
modern: Good-bye, my lord.

origin: Charmian!
modern: Charmian!

origin: Madam?
modern: Madam?

origin: That I might sleep out this great gap of time My Antony is away.
modern: So I can sleep away the time while my Antony is gone.

origin: You think of him too much.
modern: You think about him too much.

origin: Oh, ’tis treason!
modern: That’s treason!

origin: Madam, I trust, not so.
modern: I hope not, Madam.

origin: What’s your highness’ pleasure?
modern: What can I do for your highness?

origin: Not now to hear thee sing.
modern: I don’t want to hear you sing.

origin: I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has.
modern: I’m not interested in anything a eunuch can do.

origin: Tis well for thee That, being unseminared, thy freer thoughts May not fly forth of Egypt.
modern: It’s a good thing for you that, being castrated, you can better concentrate on my needs.

origin: Hast thou affections?
modern: Do you have desires?

origin: Yes, gracious madam.
modern: Yes, dear madam.

origin: Indeed?
modern: Indeed?

origin: Not in deed, madam, for I can do nothing But what indeed is honest to be done.
modern: Well, not in deed, madam, since I can’t do anything unchaste.

origin: Stands he or sits he?
modern: Is he standing or sitting?

origin: Or does he walk?
modern: Or is he walking?

origin: Or is he on his horse?
modern: Or is he on his horse?

origin: O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!
modern: Oh, how fortunate that horse is to have Antony on him.

origin: He’s speaking now, Or murmuring “Where’s my serpent of old Nile?” For so he calls me.
modern: He’s speaking now, or perhaps he’s whispering, “Where’s my serpent of the Nile?” For that’s his pet name for me.

origin: Now I feed myself With most delicious poison.
modern: I’m killing myself with this provocative speculation . . .

origin: Think on me, That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black And wrinkled deep in time.
modern: Are you thinking about me?

origin: Nay, hear them, Antony.
modern: No, listen to it, Antony.

origin: Perform ’t, or else we damn thee.”                                                                     How, my love?
modern: Perhaps  What, my love?

origin: Perchance?
modern: Maybe?

origin: Nay, and most like.
modern: No, most likely.

origin: You must not stay here longer.
modern: You can’t stay here any longer.

origin: Call in the messengers.
modern: Call in the messengers and we’ll find out.

origin: As I am Egypt’s queen, Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine Is Caesar’s homager.
modern: As surely as I am the queen of Egypt, Antony, you’re blushing, which means you’re Caesar’s servant.

origin: The messengers!
modern: Call the messengers!

origin: Sovereign of Egypt, hail!
modern: Queen of Egypt, greetings!

origin: How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
modern: You are nothing like Mark Antony!

origin: Yet, coming from him, that great med’cine hath With his tinct gilded thee.
modern: But since you come from him, you’re saturated with his healing spirit.

origin: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
modern: How does it go with my magnificent Mark Antony?

origin: Last thing he did, dear Queen, He kissed—the last of many doubled kisses— This orient pearl.
modern: The last thing he did before sending me off, dear Queen, was to kiss—the last of many such kisses—this Indian pearl for you.

origin: Mine ear must pluck it thence.
modern: My ear must pull it out.

origin: Good friend,” quoth he, “Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends This treasure of an oyster, at whose foot, To mend the petty present, I will piece Her opulent throne with kingdoms.
modern: Good friend,” he said, “say that the faithful Roman sends an oyster’s treasure to the great Queen of Egypt, and that he plans to enhance this meager gift by adding new kingdoms to her empire.

origin: All the East, Say thou, shall call her mistress.” So he nodded, And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed, Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke Was beastly dumbed by him.
modern: Tell her that the entire East shall call her Queen.” Then he nodded and solemnly mounted an armored warhorse, which neighed so loudly it effectively silenced anything I might have said in reply.

origin: What was he, sad or merry?
modern: Was he sad or happy?

origin: Like to the time o’ th’ year between the extremes Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.
modern: He was like that time of year halfway between the extremes of hot and cold: he was neither sad nor happy.

origin: Note him, Note him, good Charmian, ’tis the man, but note him.
modern: Just notice.

origin: He was not sad, for he would shine on those That make their looks by his.
modern: He wasn’t sad, because he knows that his disposition affects others.

origin: He was not merry, Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay In Egypt with his joy, but between both.
modern: He was somewhere in the middle, between them . . .

origin: O heavenly mingle!
modern: Oh, heavenly mixture!

origin: Be’st thou sad or merry, The violence of either thee becomes, So does it no man else.—Mett’st thou my posts?
modern: Whether you are sad or merry, the intensity of either suits you like no one else . . .

origin: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.
modern: Yes, madam, twenty different messengers.

origin: Why do you send so thick?
modern: Why did you send so many?

origin: Who’s born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.
modern: Whoever is born on a day I forget to send a message to Antony will die a beggar.

origin: Ink and paper, Charmian.
modern: Bring ink and paper, Charmian.

origin: Welcome, my good Alexas.
modern: Welcome, my good Alexas.

origin: Did I, Charmian, Ever love Caesar so?
modern: Charmian, did I ever love Caesar as much as this?

origin: Oh, that brave Caesar!
modern: Oh, that splendid Caesar!

origin: Be choked with such another emphasis!
modern: May you choke on any other sentiments like that!

origin: Say, “the brave Antony.”                                                 The valiant Caesar!
modern: Say, “That splendid Antony.” The courageous Caesar!

origin: By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth If thou with Caesar paragon again My man of men.
modern: By Isis, I’ll give you bloody teeth if you ever compare Caesar with Antony, my best man among men.

origin: By your most gracious pardon, I sing but after you.
modern: Pardon me, but I’m just repeating what you yourself have said.

origin: My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then.
modern: That was when I was young and inexperienced and didn’t know what passion was.

origin: We, ignorant of ourselves, Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers Deny us for our good, so find we profit By losing of our prayers.
modern: In that case, the wise gods deny our prayers for our own good.

origin: I shall do well.
modern: I’ll do well.

origin: The people love me, and the sea is mine.
