modern: The people are on my side, and I’m in charge of the sea.

origin: My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to th’ full.
modern: My forces are growing, and everything I know tells me it’s all coming together.

origin: Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors.
modern: Mark Antony is at dinner in Egypt and won’t be going outside to make war.

origin: Caesar gets money where He loses hearts.
modern: Caesar loses supporters wherever he raises money.

origin: Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flattered, but he neither loves, Nor either cares for him.
modern: Lepidus flatters both of them, as they flatter him, but he doesn’t love them, and they don’t love him.

origin: Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field.
modern: Caesar and Lepidus are organizing their military operation.

origin: A mighty strength they carry.
modern: They have a massive army.

origin: Where have you this?
modern: Where did you hear this?

origin: Tis false.
modern: It’s not true.

origin: From Silvius, sir.
modern: From Silvius, sir.

origin: He dreams.
modern: He’s dreaming.

origin: I know they are in Rome together Looking for Antony.
modern: I know they’re in Rome together, hoping for Antony to return.

origin: But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!
modern: Lecherous Cleopatra, may all the charms of love soften those withered lips!

origin: Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both.
modern: Join your witchcraft with your beauty, and let Antony’s lust combine with both.

origin: Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts, Keep his brain fuming.
modern: Keep this libertine occupied with endless debauchery.

origin: This is most certain that I shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected.
modern: This news is absolutely true: Mark Antony is expected to arrive in Rome at any hour now.

origin: Since he went from Egypt ’tis A space for farther travel.
modern: In the time since he left Egypt, he could have traveled an even longer distance.

origin: His soldiership Is twice the other twain.
modern: His military ability is double that of the other two.

origin: But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.
modern: We must form a better opinion of ourselves if our uprising can pull the insatiable Antony’s attention away from that Egyptian widow.

origin: I cannot hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.
modern: I don’t expect Caesar and Antony will have a very friendly reunion.

origin: I know not, Menas, How lesser enmities may give way to greater.
modern: Menas, I don’t understand how minor quarrels can be superseded by greater ones.

origin: Be ’t as our gods will have ’t.
modern: It will be as the gods see fit.

origin: It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
modern: In any case, our survival depends on putting together the strongest force possible.

origin: Come, Menas.
modern: Let’s go, Menas.

origin: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.
modern: Good Enobarbus, you would be doing a very good thing if you advised your captain to speak calmly and quietly.

origin: I shall entreat him To answer like himself.
modern: I will advise him to speak as he usually does.

origin: By Jupiter, Were I the wearer of Antonio’s beard, I would not shave ’t today.
modern: By Jupiter, if I were Antony, I wouldn’t shave my beard today.

origin: Tis not a time for private stomaching.
modern: This is not the time for dwelling on personal grievances.

origin: But small to greater matters must give way.
modern: But major issues must come before minor ones.

origin: Not if the small come first.
modern: Not if the minor ones come up first.

origin: Here comes the noble Antony.
modern: Here comes the noble Antony.

origin: And yonder, Caesar.
modern: And there comes Caesar.

origin: Tis spoken well.
modern: You’re right.

origin: Were we before our armies, and to fight, I should do thus.
modern: If we were in front of our armies, about to fight, I would do this.

origin: Welcome to Rome.
modern: Welcome to Rome.

origin: Thank you.
modern: Thank you.

origin: Sit.
modern: Have a seat.

origin: Sit, sir.
modern: After you.

origin: Nay, then.
modern: No, after you.

origin: I must be laughed at If or for nothing or a little, I Should say myself offended, and with you Chiefly i’ th’ world; more laughed at, that I should Once name you derogately, when to sound your name It not concerned me.
modern: I should be ridiculed if I were offended so easily—and laughed at even more for speaking of you disrespectfully, when I had no reason to speak of you at all.

origin: My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was ’t to you?
modern: Caesar, what did my stay in Egypt have to do with you?

origin: No more than my residing here at Rome Might be to you in Egypt.
modern: No more than my staying here in Rome might mean to you in Egypt.

origin: Yet if you there Did practice on my state, your being in Egypt Might be my question.
modern: But if you conspired against my position while you were there, I might be interested in the reason for your stay in Egypt.

origin: How intend you, “practiced”?
modern: How do you mean, “conspired”?

origin: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent By what did here befall me.
modern: You can judge for yourself what I mean.

origin: Your wife and brother Made wars upon me, and their contestation Was theme for you.
modern: Your wife and brother led troops against me, claiming to be fighting in your name.

origin: You were the word of war.
modern: They said they were acting for you.

origin: You do mistake your business.
modern: You’re mistaken.

origin: My brother never Did urge me in his act.
modern: My brother didn’t use my name to justify his rebellion.

origin: Did he not rather Discredit my authority with yours, And make the wars alike against my stomach, Having alike your cause?
modern: He rejected my authority as much as yours.

origin: Of this my letters Before did satisfy you.
modern: I’ve already sent the proof in my letters.

origin: If you’ll patch a quarrel, As matter whole you have to make it with, It must not be with this.
modern: If you want to pick a fight, you’ll have to find a more substantial excuse.

origin: You praise yourself By laying defects of judgment to me, but You patched up your excuses.
modern: You defend yourself by blaming my judgment, but you’re just making up feeble excuses.

origin: Not so, not so.
modern: Not true, not true.

origin: I know you could not lack, I am certain on ’t, Very necessity of this thought, that I, Your partner in the cause ’gainst which he fought, Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars Which fronted mine own peace.
modern: You know I would never approve a war against my own cause.

origin: As for my wife, I would you had her spirit in such another.
modern: As for my wife, if only you had such a wife.

origin: The third o’ th’ world is yours, which with a snaffle You may pace easy, but not such a wife.
modern: It’s easier to rule a third of the world than a wife like that.

origin: For that you must But say I could not help it.
modern: But you can’t blame me for her offenses.

origin: I wrote to you When rioting in Alexandria.
modern: I sent you a letter while you were carousing in Alexandria.

origin: Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want Of what I was i’ th’ morning.
modern: I was not myself, as a result of the wine.

origin: But next day I told him of myself, which was as much As to have asked him pardon.
modern: The next day I explained all this to him, which was as good as begging his pardon.

origin: Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife.
modern: Let’s not fight over this fellow.

origin: Hear the ambassadors.
modern: Meet with the ambassadors.

origin: No messenger but thine, and all alone Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and note The qualities of people.
modern: Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and observe the people.

origin: You have broken The article of your oath, which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with.
modern: You will never be able to say the same about me.

origin: Soft, Caesar.
modern: Go on, Caesar.

origin: No, Lepidus, let him speak.
modern: What part of the agreement did I break?

origin: The honor is sacred which he talks on now, Supposing that I lacked it.—But, on, Caesar.
modern: You agreed to send me troops and weapons when I needed them.

origin: The article of my oath?
modern: You refused me both.

origin: To lend me arms and aid when I required them, The which you both denied.
modern: I overlooked your request, but I did not deny it.

origin: Neglected, rather, And then when poisoned hours had bound me up From mine own knowledge.
modern: Your request came at a time when the poisonous effects of reveling caused me to be unaware of my own actions.

origin: Tis noble spoken.
modern: Spoken like a gentleman.

origin: If it might please you to enforce no further The griefs between ye, to forget them quite Were to remember that the present need Speaks to atone you.
modern: If it’s okay with you, you should not press your grievances any further, but realize that the current situation should be enough to reconcile you.

origin: Worthily spoken, Maecenas.
modern: Well put, Maecenas.

origin: Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.
modern: Or you can pretend to settle your differences until this matter with Pompey is finished.

origin: You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.
modern: You can argue as much as you like when there’s nothing else to do.

origin: Thou art a soldier only.
modern: You are only a soldier.

origin: Therefore speak no more.
modern: Don’t speak any further.

origin: Go to, then.
modern: As you please.

origin: Give me leave, Caesar.
modern: May I speak, Caesar.

origin: Speak, Agrippa.
modern: What is it, Agrippa?

origin: Thou hast a sister by the mother’s side, Admired Octavia.
modern: You have a beautiful half-sister, Octavia.

origin: Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.
modern: Great Mark Antony is a widower now.

origin: Say not so, Agrippa.
modern: You’d better not make that suggestion, Agrippa.

origin: If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof Were well deserved of rashness.
modern: If Cleopatra heard you, you would be well punished for your audacity.

origin: I am not married, Caesar.
modern: It’s true I’m not married, Caesar.

origin: Let me hear Agrippa further speak.
modern: Let me hear what Agrippa has to say.

origin: By this marriage, All little jealousies, which now seem great, And all great fears, which now import their dangers, Would then be nothing.
modern: With this marriage, all the petty jealousies that now seem huge, and all the great fears that are dangerous in themselves, would disappear.

origin: Her love to both Would each to other and all loves to both Draw after her.
modern: Since she would love both of you, you two would be joined in that love.

origin: Will Caesar speak?
modern: What do you say, Caesar?

origin: The power of Caesar, and His power unto Octavia.
modern: He has both my power and my influence over Octavia.

origin: May I never To this good purpose, that so fairly shows, Dream of impediment!
modern: I wouldn’t dream of opposing such an obviously promising idea.

origin: There’s my hand.
modern: Here’s my hand.

origin: A sister I bequeath you whom no brother Did ever love so dearly.
modern: I give you a sister whom I love more than a brother ever loved any sister.

origin: Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts, and never Fly off our loves again!
modern: She will be the bond that joins our kingdoms and our hearts.

origin: Happily, amen!
modern: I’m happy to say “amen” to that!

origin: I did not think to draw my sword ’gainst Pompey, For he hath laid strange courtesies and great Of late upon me.
modern: I didn’t think I would ever fight Pompey.

origin: Time calls upon ’s.
modern: There isn’t much time.

origin: Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.
modern: Either we go after Pompey or he’ll come after us.

origin: Where lies he?
modern: Where is he now?

origin: What is his strength by land?
modern: Near  How large is his land army?

origin: Great and increasing.
modern: Large and increasing.

origin: But by sea he is an absolute master.
modern: But his navy rules the sea.

origin: So is the fame.
modern: That’s what I hear.

origin: Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.
modern: Come with us, Lepidus.

origin: Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.
modern: Noble Antony, even illness couldn’t keep me away.

origin: Good Enobarbus!
modern: Good Enobarbus!

origin: We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested.
modern: We can be happy that things have been resolved so agreeably.

origin: You stayed well by ’t in Egypt.
modern: And I see you survived your time in Egypt.

origin: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and but twelve persons there!
modern: We heard that once you were served eight wild boars roasted whole for breakfast—for only twelve people!

origin: Is this true?
modern: Is that true?

origin: This was but as a fly by an eagle.
modern: That was nothing.

origin: We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.
modern: There were many even more memorable feasts.

origin: She’s a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.
modern: She’s a remarkable lady, if the rumors are to be believed.

origin: I will tell you.
modern: I’ll tell you.

origin: The poop was beaten gold, Purple the sails, and so perfumèd that The winds were lovesick with them.
modern: The sails were dyed purple, and they were perfumed so heavily that they made the air seem dizzy with love.

origin: The oars were silver, Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made The water which they beat to follow faster, As amorous of their strokes.
modern: The oars were made of silver, and the oarsmen rowed in time to flute music.

origin: On each side her Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids, With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool, And what they undid did.
modern: Pretty, Cupid-like boys stood on either side of her, smiling and cooling her with multicolored fans, which seemed to fan the flames in her cheeks even as they cooled them, undoing what they did.

origin: Oh, rare for Antony!
modern: How excellent for Antony!

origin: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, Invited her to supper.
modern: When she landed at the port, Antony sent an invitation for her to come to supper.

origin: She replied It should be better he became her guest, Which she entreated.
modern: She replied by saying that it would be better for him to be her guest instead.

origin: Royal wench!
modern: Royal seductress!

origin: Now Antony must leave her utterly.
modern: Now Antony has to leave her completely.

origin: Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale Her infinite variety.
modern: Age won’t wither her, and her charms are so varied that she never grows boring.

origin: Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies, for vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.
modern: Even her worst faults are charming, and holy priests bless her even when she acts the slut.

origin: Let us go.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest Whilst you abide here.
modern: Good Enobarbus, consider yourself my guest as long as you’re here.

origin: Humbly, sir, I thank you.
modern: I humbly thank you.

origin: All which time Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers To them for you.
modern: And I will spend our time apart on my knees, praying for you.

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night.

origin: If you can, your reason?
modern: Tell me why, if you can.

origin: But yet hie you to Egypt again.
modern: But you had better get back to Egypt again.

origin: Say to me whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar’s or mine?
modern: Tell me who shall have the better luck, Caesar or me?

origin: Caesar’s.
modern: Caesar.

origin: Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.
modern: So you’d better not stay with him, Antony.

origin: Thy dæmon—that thy spirit which keeps thee—is Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable Where Caesar’s is not.
modern: Your guardian angel is noble, courageous, significant, and unmatched when Caesar’s not around.

origin: But near him thy angel Becomes afeard, as being o’erpowered.
modern: But when you are with him, your angel is weakened and easily frightened.

origin: Therefore Make space enough between you.
modern: That’s why there must be space between you.

origin: Rest you happy!
modern: Have a good night!

origin: Speak this no more.
modern: Don’t speak of this again.

origin: To none but thee, no more but when to thee.
modern: To none but you, only to you.

origin: If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose, and of that natural luck He beats thee ’gainst the odds.
modern: With his natural luck, he will beat you even against the odds.

origin: Thy luster thickens When he shines by.
modern: Your light dulls when he is near.

origin: I will to Egypt.
modern: Leave now.

origin: And though I make this marriage for my peace, I’ th’ East my pleasure lies.
modern: Tell Ventidius I want to speak with him.

origin: O come, Ventidius.
modern: Come here, Ventidius.

origin: You must to Parthia.
modern: You must go to Parthia.

origin: Your commission’s ready.
modern: Your authorization is ready.

origin: Follow me and receive ’t.
modern: Come with me and I’ll get it for you.

origin: Trouble yourselves no further.
modern: Don’t spend any more time here.

origin: Pray you, hasten Your generals after.
modern: Go tell your generals to hurry their preparations.

origin: Sir, Mark Antony Will e’en but kiss Octavia, and we’ll follow.
modern: Sir, we’ll follow as soon as Mark Antony kisses Octavia good-bye.

origin: Till I shall see you in your soldiers’ dress, Which will become you both, farewell.
modern: Good-bye then, until the time I see you dressed in your battle gear, which will suit you both very well.

origin: Your way is shorter.
modern: You’re taking a shorter route.

origin: My purposes do draw me much about.
modern: My plans take me a roundabout way.

origin: You’ll win two days upon me.
modern: You’ll get there two days before me.

origin: Sir, good success.
modern: Good luck, sir.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: Give me some music.
modern: Play me some music.

origin: Music, moody food Of us that trade in love.
modern: Music feeds the melancholy moods of us lovers.

origin: The music, ho!
modern: Musicians, come in!

origin: Let it alone.
modern: Never mind.

origin: Let’s to billiards.
modern: Let’s play billiards.

origin: Come, Charmian.
modern: Play with me, Charmian.

origin: My arm is sore.
modern: My arm is sore.

origin: As well as I can, madam.
modern: I’ll do my best, madam.

origin: I’ll none now.
modern: I don’t want to play now.

origin: Give me mine angle.
modern: Give me my fishing rod.

origin: We’ll to th’ river.
modern: We’ll go to the river.

origin: There, My music playing far off, I will betray Tawny-finned fishes.
modern: With my music playing in the background, I’ll lure fish.

origin: Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.
modern: Cram your good news into my ears.

origin: Madam, madam— Antonio’s dead!
modern: Madam, madam— Antony’s dead!

origin: If thou say so, villain, Thou kill’st thy mistress.
modern: If you say that, you bastard, you’ll kill your Queen.

origin: But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings Have lipped, and trembled kissing.
modern: Kings have trembled to kiss this hand.

origin: First, madam, he is well.
modern: Let me say first, madam, that he is well.

origin: Why, there’s more gold.
modern: Well then, here’s more money for you.

origin: But, sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well.
modern: But you know, sirrah, we customarily say that the dead are well.

origin: Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.
modern: If that’s what you mean, I’ll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words.

origin: Good madam, hear me.
modern: Good madam, let me speak.

origin: Well, go to, I will.
modern: All right, I will.

origin: But there’s no goodness in thy face—if Antony Be free and healthful, so tart a favor To trumpet such good tidings!
modern: But you don’t look as if you bring good news.

origin: If that you were the good Sir Rowland’s son, As you have whispered faithfully you were, And as mine eye doth his effigies witness Most truly limned and living in your face, Be truly welcome hither.
modern: If you really are Sir Rowland’s son, as you’ve just whispered to me—and I can absolutely see the likeness in your face— you are truly welcome here.

origin: I am the duke That loved your father.
modern: I am the duke who loved your father.

origin: The residue of your fortune Go to my cave and tell me.—Good old man, Thou art right welcome as thy master is.
modern: Come to my cave and tell me the rest of your story.—Good old man, you are as welcome here as your master is.

origin: Support him by the arm.
modern: Give him your arm.

origin: Give me your hand, And let me all your fortunes understand.
modern: Give me your hand, and explain your situation to me.

origin: Not see him since?
modern: You haven’t seen him since?

origin: Sir, sir, that cannot be.
modern: Sir, sir, that can’t be true.

origin: But were I not the better part made mercy, I should not seek an absent argument Of my revenge, thou present.
modern: If I weren’t a merciful man, I’d forget about your missing brother and punish you in his place.

origin: But look to it: Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is.
modern: But do this: find your brother, wherever he is.

origin: Bring him, dead or living, Within this twelvemonth or turn thou no more To seek a living in our territory.
modern: Bring him here dead or alive within the next year, or get out off my land.

origin: Thy lands and all things that thou dost call thine Worth seizure, do we seize into our hands Till thou canst quit thee by thy brother’s mouth Of what we think against thee.
modern: I’m seizing your lands and all that you possess until your brother gives testimony that absolves you of any guilt.

origin: Oh, that your Highness knew my heart in this: I never loved my brother in my life.
modern: I wish your Highness knew my true feelings in this matter: I have never in my life loved my brother.

origin: More villain thou.—Well, push him out of doors And let my officers of such a nature Make an extent upon his house and lands.
modern: That makes you an even bigger villain.—Well, throw him out, and have my officers seize his house and lands.

origin: Do this expediently, and turn him going.
modern: Do this immediately, and send him packing.

origin: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love.
modern: Hang there on this tree, you lines of poetry, and bear witness to my love.

origin: And how like you this shepherd’s life, Master Touchstone?
modern: And you,  And how are you liking the shepherd’s life, Master Touchstone?

origin: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd’s life, it is naught.
modern: Well, in and of itself, it is a good life, but given that it’s a shepherd’s life, it’s worthless.

origin: In respect that it is solitary, I like it very well; but in respect that it is private, it is a very vile life.
modern: In the fact that it’s solitary, I enjoy it very much; but in the sense that it’s private, it’s terrible.

origin: Now in respect it is in the fields, it pleaseth me well; but in respect it is not in the court, it is tedious.
modern: Now, I’m very pleased with it being outdoors, but in its not being at the court, it is boring.

origin: Hast any philosophy in thee, shepherd?
modern: Are you any kind of philosopher yourself, shepherd?

origin: Such a one is a natural philosopher.
modern: You’re a natural-born philosopher!

origin: Wast ever in court, shepherd?
modern: Were you ever at court, shepherd?

origin: No, truly.
modern: Honestly, no.

origin: Then thou art damned.
modern: Then you are damned.

origin: Nay, I hope.
modern: I hope not.

origin: Your reason.
modern: Explain.

origin: Why, if thou never wast at court, thou never saw’st good manners; if thou never saw’st good manners, then thy manners must be wicked, and wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation.
modern: Well, if you were never at court, you were never exposed to good manners; if you never witnessed good manners, your manners must be wicked; wickedness is a sin, and committing sins leads to damnation.

origin: Thou art in a parlous state, shepherd.
modern: You are in a perilous state, shepherd.

origin: Not a whit, Touchstone.
modern: Not at all, Touchstone.

origin: Those that are good manners at the court are as ridiculous in the country as the behavior of the country is most mockable at the court.
modern: The good manners of the court look as silly in the country as country behavior is laughable at the court.

origin: You told me you salute not at the court but you kiss your hands.
modern: You told me that you don’t salute at the court but kiss hands.

origin: That courtesy would be uncleanly if courtiers were shepherds.
modern: Now, if courtiers were shepherds, that kind of courtesy would be unclean.

origin: Instance, briefly.
modern: Give a quick example.

origin: Come, instance.
modern: Come, explain.

origin: Why, we are still handling our ewes, and their fells, you know, are greasy.
modern: Why, because we’re always handling our ewes, and their fleece, as you know, is greasy.

origin: Why, do not your courtier’s hands sweat?
modern: What, don’t courtiers' hands sweat?

origin: And is not the grease of a mutton as wholesome as the sweat of a man?
modern: And isn’t a sheep’s grease as wholesome as a man’s sweat?

origin: A better instance, I say.
modern: That’s a poor example.

origin: Come.
modern: A better example—come on.

origin: Besides, our hands are hard.
modern: Besides, our hands are hard and calloused.

origin: Your lips will feel them the sooner.
modern: Then your lips will feel them more quickly.

origin: Come.
modern: Come on.

origin: Most shallow man.
modern: You worthless man!

origin: Thou worms' meat in respect of a good piece of flesh, indeed.
modern: You are about as much of a thinker as worm’s meat is a nice steak.

origin: Learn of the wise and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the very uncleanly flux of a cat.
modern: Learn from the wise, and comprehend: the courtier’s perfume is made from cat discharge—much more disgusting than tar.

origin: Mend the instance, shepherd.
modern: Fix your example, shepherd.

origin: You have too courtly a wit for me.
modern: Your wit is too courtly for me.

origin: I’ll rest.
modern: I’ll rest now.

origin: Good morrow to your Worship.
modern: Good morning, sir.

origin: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke’s daughter, be banished with her father?
modern: Can you tell me whether Rosalind, Duke Senior’s daughter, has also been banished?

origin: Where will the old duke live?
modern: Where will the old duke live?

origin: Wilt thou rest damned?
modern: You’re going to rest while you’re still damned?

origin: God help thee, shallow man.
modern: God help you, foolish man.

origin: God make incision in thee; thou art raw.
modern: Pray God does some surgery on you: you need to be fixed.

origin: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram, out of all reasonable match.
modern: That’s another sin arising from your ignorance: you bring ewes and rams together and make your living by their copulation.

origin: Here comes young Master Ganymede, my new mistress’s brother.
modern: Here comes young Mr. Ganymede, my new mistress’s brother.

origin: No jewel is like Rosalind.
modern: There is no jewel like Rosalind.

origin: Her worth being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Rosalind.
modern: Her worth is carried on the wind And it blows throughout the world, carrying the name of Rosalind.

origin: All the pictures fairest lined Are but black to Rosalind.
modern: All the most beautiful paintings Are black when compared to Rosalind.

origin: Let no fair be kept in mind But the fair of Rosalind.
modern: Don’t think of any beauty But the beauty of Rosalind.

origin: I’ll rhyme you so eight years together, dinners and suppers and sleeping hours excepted.
modern: I could rhyme like that for eight years in a row, excepting meal times and sleeping hours.

origin: It is the right butter-women’s rank to market.
modern: That awful, plodding rhyme sounded like a row of dairy women stomping off to market.

origin: Out, fool.
modern: Oh, stop, fool.

origin: For a taste: If a hart do lack a hind, Let him seek out Rosalind.
modern: Let me try: If there’s a buck who needs a doe Tell him Rosalind will do.

origin: If the cat will after kind, So, be sure, will Rosalind.
modern: A cat in heat will look for a mate, And Rosalind certainly will too.

origin: Winter garments must be lined, So must slender Rosalind.
modern: Winter garments need to be filled with something, And so does skinny Rosalind.

origin: They that reap must sheaf and bind, Then to cart with Rosalind.
modern: After you harvest, you have to sheaf and bind So throw ripe Rosalind on the harvest cart.

origin: Sweetest nut hath sourest rind; Such a nut is Rosalind.
modern: The sweetest nut has the sourest rind And Rosalind is that kind of nut.

origin: He that sweetest rose will find Must find love’s prick, and Rosalind.
modern: The man who finds the sweetest rose Will be pricked by it, and by Rosalind.

origin: This is the very false gallop of verses.
modern: This is exactly the false way that verses gallop along.

origin: Why do you infect yourself with them?
modern: Why bother with them?

origin: Peace, you dull fool.
modern: Quiet, you stupid fool.

origin: I found them on a tree.
modern: I found them on a tree.

origin: Truly, the tree yields bad fruit.
modern: Well, the tree bears rotten fruit.

origin: You have said, but whether wisely or no, let the forest judge.
modern: All right, you’ve had your say, but we’ll let the forest judge whether or not you spoke wisely.

origin: Peace.
modern: Quiet!

origin: But upon the fairest boughs, Or at every sentence end, Will I “Rosalinda” write, Teaching all that read to know The quintessence of every sprite Heaven would in little show.
modern: But on the prettiest branches Or at the end of every sentence  I’ll write “Rosalinda,” Teaching everyone who can read that the essence of every spirit Is contained in this one woman.

origin: Therefore heaven nature charged That one body should be filled With all graces wide-enlarged.
modern: Heaven commanded Nature To fill her one body With all the graces that women contain.

origin: Nature presently distilled Helen’s cheek, but not her heart, Cleopatra’s majesty, Atalanta’s better part, Sad Lucretia’s modesty.
modern: Nature took Helen’s  Cleopatra’s majesty, The best of Atalanta, And unhappy Lucretia’s modesty.

origin: Thus Rosalind of many parts By heavenly synod was devised, Of many faces, eyes, and hearts To have the touches dearest prized.
modern: So, by heaven’s decree, Rosalind Was composed Of different faces, eyes, and hearts, so that she might have the most prized touches of all.

origin: Heaven would that she these gifts should have And I to live and die her slave.
modern: Heaven wanted Rosalind to have these gifts And me to live and die as her slave.

origin: Didst thou hear these verses?
modern: Were you listening to these verses?

origin: Oh, yes, I heard them all, and more too, for some of them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.
modern: Oh yes, I heard them all, and more, too.

origin: Ay, but the feet were lame and could not bear themselves without the verse, and therefore stood lamely in the verse.
modern: Some of those lines had more feet than the  That’s not a problem: the feet can bear Sure, but these feet were

origin: But didst thou hear without wondering how thy name should be hanged and carved upon these trees?
modern: But did you listen to all that poetry without even wondering about what your name is doing on all these trees?

origin: Is it a man?
modern: Was it a man?

origin: And a chain, that you once wore, about his neck.
modern: And he had a chain that once belonged to you hanging around his neck.

origin: Change you color?
modern: Are you blushing?

origin: I prithee, who?
modern: Please, who?

origin: O Lord, Lord, it is a hard matter for friends to meet, but mountains may be removed with earthquakes and so encounter.
modern: It’s difficult to bring two friends together, but even mountains can be moved together by earthquakes.

origin: Nay, but who is it?
modern: No, who are you talking about?

origin: Is it possible?
modern: Is it possible?

origin: Nay, I prithee now, with most petitionary vehemence, tell me who it is.
modern: No, I’m begging you now, tell me who it is.

origin: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!
modern: Oh, this is wonderful, wonderful—just wonderful wonderful!

origin: Good my complexion, dost thou think though I am caparisoned like a man, I have a doublet and hose in my disposition?
modern: Good grief, do you think that just because I’m dressed like a man, I have a man’s patience?

origin: One inch of delay more is a South Sea of discovery.
modern: Every second you delay is as long and dull as a journey to South Seas.

origin: I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace.
modern: I’m begging you, tell me who it is quickly, and speak fast.

origin: I would thou couldst stammer, that thou might’st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at once, or none at all.
modern: I wish you could just stammer this hidden man out of your mouth like wine out of a narrow-necked bottle: either too much at once or none at all.

origin: I prithee take the cork out of thy mouth, that I may drink thy tidings.
modern: I’m begging you, take the cork out of your mouth so I can drink the news.

origin: So you may put a man in your belly.
modern: So you want to put a man in your belly.

origin: Is he of God’s making?
modern: Did God make him?

origin: What manner of man?
modern: I mean, what sort of man is he?

origin: Is his head worth a hat or his chin worth a beard?
modern: Is he enough of a man to wear a hat and grow a beard ?

origin: Nay, he hath but a little beard.
modern: No, he has only a little beard.

origin: Why, God will send more, if the man will be thankful.
modern: Well, eventually God will send him some more hair, if he thanks Him.

origin: Let me stay the growth of his beard, if thou delay me not the knowledge of his chin.
modern: I’ll wait till his beard grows in, if you’ll just hurry up and tell me what chin that beard is on.

origin: It is young Orlando, that tripped up the wrestler’s heels and your heart both in an instant.
modern: It’s Orlando, who triumphed over both the wrestler and you in the same instant.

origin: Nay, but the devil take mocking.
modern: Damn you for mocking me.

origin: I' faith, coz, ’tis he.
modern: Really, cousin, it’s him.

origin: Orlando?
modern: Orlando?

origin: Orlando.
modern: Orlando.

origin: What did he when thou saw’st him?
modern: What did he do when you saw him?

origin: What said he?
modern: What did he say?

origin: How looked he?
modern: How did he look?

origin: Wherein went he?
modern: Where did he go?

origin: What makes him here?
modern: What brings him here?

origin: Did he ask for me?
modern: Did he ask about me?

origin: Where remains he?
modern: Where is he staying?

origin: How parted he with thee?
modern: How did he say good-bye?

origin: And when shalt thou see him again?
modern: And when will you see him again?

origin: Answer me in one word.
modern: Answer me in a word.

origin: But doth he know that I am in this forest and in man’s apparel?
modern: You’d better get me  But does he know that I’m here in the forest and dressed in men’s clothing?

origin: Looks he as freshly as he did the day he wrestled?
modern: Does he look as bright and handsome as the day we saw him wrestling?

origin: But take a taste of my finding him, and relish it with good observance.
modern: But taste my story, and relish it by paying attention.

origin: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.
modern: I found Orlando under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

origin: It may well be called Jove’s tree when it drops forth such fruit.
modern: That tree could be called God’s tree, since it drops such wonderful fruit.

origin: Give me audience, good madam.
modern: Let me talk, good lady.

origin: Proceed.
modern: Go on.

origin: There lay he, stretched along like a wounded knight.
modern: He lay there, stretched out like a wounded knight.

origin: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes the ground.
modern: Though that must have been a pitiful sight, the ground looked beautiful.

origin: Cry “holla” to thy tongue, I prithee.
modern: Cry, “whoa!” to your tongue, please.

origin: It curvets unseasonably.
modern: It’s leaping about like a frisky horse.

origin: He was furnished like a hunter.
modern: He was dressed like a hunter.

origin: Oh, ominous!
modern: Oh, that’s ominous!

origin: He comes to kill my heart.
modern: He has come to kill my heart.

origin: I would sing my song without a burden.
modern: I’d like to sing my song solo.

origin: Thou bring’st me out of tune.
modern: You’re making me go off-key.

origin: Do you not know I am a woman?
modern: Don’t you know that I’m a woman?

origin: When I think, I must speak.
modern: Whatever I think, I have to say.

origin: Sweet, say on.
modern: Sweetheart, go on.

origin: You bring me out.
modern: Quiet!

origin: Soft, comes he not here?
modern: Isn’t that him heading this way?

origin: Tis he.
modern: That’s him.

origin: I thank you for your company, but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone.
modern: Thanks for your company but, really, I would have preferred being alone.

origin: And so had I, but yet, for fashion sake, I thank you too for your society.
modern: Me too, but still, for the sake of good manners, I’ll say thanks for your company.

origin: God be wi' you.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Let’s meet as little as we can.
modern: Let’s meet as little as we can.

origin: I do desire we may be better strangers.
modern: I also hope that we can be better strangers.

origin: I pray you mar no more trees with writing love songs in their barks.
modern: Please don’t ruin any more trees by carving love poems on their barks.

origin: I pray you mar no more of my verses with reading them ill- favoredly.
modern: Please don’t ruin any more of my poems by reading them so badly.

origin: Rosalind is your love’s name?
modern: Your love’s name is Rosalind?

origin: Yes, just.
modern: Yes, that’s it.

origin: I do not like her name.
modern: I don’t like her name.

origin: What stature is she of?
modern: How tall is she?

origin: Just as high as my heart.
modern: Just as tall as my heart.

origin: You are full of pretty answers.
modern: You’re sure full of smooth answers.

origin: The worst fault you have is to be in love.
modern: Your worst fault is being in love.

origin: Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.
modern: Well, it’s a fault I wouldn’t trade for your best virtue.

origin: I am weary of you.
modern: I’m tired of you.

origin: There I shall see mine own figure.
modern: There I’ll see only myself.

origin: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.
modern: Which is either a fool or a nothing.

origin: I’ll tarry no longer with you.
modern: I’m not going to waste any more time with you.

origin: Farewell, good Signior Love.
modern: Goodbye, good Mr. Love.

origin: I am glad of your departure.
modern: I’m glad to see you go.

origin: Adieu, good Monsieur Melancholy.
modern: Adieu, good Mr. Depression.

origin: Very well.
modern: Very well.

origin: What would you?
modern: What do you want?

origin: You should ask me what time o' day.
modern: You should ask me what time of day it is, instead.

origin: There’s no clock in the forest.
modern: There’s no clock here in the forest.

origin: Then there is no true lover in the forest, else sighing every minute and groaning every hour would detect the lazy foot of time as well as a clock.
modern: Then there must be no lovers in the forest, either, because they’re as good as a clock, marking the lazy foot of time with a sigh every minute and a groan every hour.

origin: Marry, do I, sir, and I came to acquaint you with a matter.
modern: Indeed I do, sir, and I’ve come to let you in on a certain problem.

origin: I am given, sir, secretly to understand that your younger brother Orlando hath a disposition to come in disguised against me to try a fall.
modern: I’ve been informed by certain sources I can’t disclose that your younger brother Orlando plans to fight me in disguise.

origin: Tomorrow, sir, I wrestle for my credit, and he that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well.
modern: Tomorrow, sir, I’m fighting for my reputation, and any man who gets away without a broken bone or two is an exceptional wrestler indeed.

origin: Your brother is but young and tender, and, for your love I would be loath to foil him, as I must for my own honor if he come in.
modern: Your brother is young and inexperienced, and because of my affection for you, I’d hate to crush him—though I’d have to, if he challenged me.

origin: Therefore, out of my love to you, I came hither to acquaint you withal, that either you might stay him from his intendment or brook such disgrace well as he shall run into, in that it is a thing of his own search and altogether against my will.
modern: I’m telling you all this out of affection for you, so you can either keep him from carrying out his plans or prepare to accept his disgrace, which will be his own fault, not mine.

origin: Charles, I thank thee for thy love to me, which thou shalt find I will most kindly requite.
modern: Charles, I thank you for your loyalty to me, and you’ll see that I’ll reward you.

origin: I had myself notice of my brother’s purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it; but he is resolute.
modern: I’d heard about my brother’s plan and have been subtly trying to change his mind, but he’s determined.

origin: I’ll tell thee, Charles: it is the stubbornest young fellow of France, full of ambition, an envious emulator of every man’s good parts, a secret and villainous contriver against me his natural brother.
modern: I tell you, Charles, he’s the stubbornest young fellow in France: overly ambitious, jealous of other people’s good qualities, and a traitor against me, his own blood brother.

origin: Therefore use thy discretion.
modern: So use your discretion.

origin: I had as lief thou didst break his neck as his finger.
modern: I’d be just as happy if you broke his neck as his finger.

origin: I speak but brotherly of him, but should I anatomize him to thee as he is, I must blush and weep, and thou must look pale and wonder.
modern: But if I really laid him bare, I’d have to weep and hang my head, and you would not believe me, his behavior is so shocking.

origin: And why not the swift foot of time?
modern: Why didn’t you say “the swift steps” of time instead of the “lazy foot”?

origin: Had not that been as proper?
modern: Wouldn’t that have been just as appropriate?

origin: By no means, sir.
modern: No, not at all, sir.

origin: Time travels in diverse paces with diverse persons.
modern: Time travels at different speeds for different people.

origin: I’ll tell you who time ambles withal, who time trots withal, who time gallops withal, and who he stands still withal.
modern: I can tell you who time strolls for, who it trots for, who it gallops for, and who it stops cold for.

origin: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
modern: Okay, who does it trot for?

origin: Who ambles time withal?
modern: Who does time amble for?

origin: These time ambles withal.
modern: Time ambles for both men.

origin: Who doth he gallop withal?
modern: Who does it gallop for?

origin: Who stays it still withal?
modern: Who does it stand still for?

origin: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between term and term, and then they perceive not how time moves.
modern: For lawyers on vacation, because they sleep their holidays away, with no sense of how time moves.

origin: Where dwell you, pretty youth?
modern: Where do you live, pretty young man?

origin: Are you native of this place?
modern: Were you born here?

origin: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.
modern: Just like the rabbit, who lives where she is born.

origin: Your accent is something finer than you could purchase in so removed a dwelling.
modern: Your speech is more refined than I would expect in such a remote place as this.

origin: I have been told so of many.
modern: Many people have told me so.

origin: But indeed an old religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was in his youth an inland man, one that knew courtship too well, for there he fell in love.
modern: Actually, an old religious uncle of mine taught me how to speak, and he was brought up in the city.

origin: I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.
modern: Thank God I’m not a woman and afflicted with all the giddiness that troubles that entire sex.

origin: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he laid to the charge of women?
modern: What were the primary evils he claimed women were guilty of?

origin: There were none principal.
modern: There were no primary ones.

origin: I prithee, recount some of them.
modern: Please, tell me some of them.

origin: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that are sick.
modern: No, I won’t give my medicine away to anyone but the sick.

origin: There is a man haunts the forest that abuses our young plants with carving “Rosalind” on their barks, hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of Rosalind.
modern: There’s a man haunting this forest who abuses the trees by carving “Rosalind” on their barks.

origin: I am he that is so love-shaked.
modern: Well, I’m the man you’re speaking of.

origin: I pray you tell me your remedy.
modern: Please, tell me your cure.

origin: There is none of my uncle’s marks upon you.
modern: But you don’t have any of the symptoms my uncle told me about.

origin: He taught me how to know a man in love, in which cage of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.
modern: He taught me how to recognize a man in love, and you’re not a prisoner of love, I’m sure.

origin: What were his marks?
modern: What did he say the symptoms were?

origin: A lean cheek, which you have not; a blue eye and sunken, which you have not; an unquestionable spirit, which you have not; a beard neglected, which you have not—but I pardon you for that, for simply your having in beard is a younger brother’s revenue.
modern: A thin face, which you don’t have; a sleepless, sunken eye, which you don’t have; an irritable temper, which you don’t have; a neglected beard, which you don’t have—but that might not be so telling, since you don’t have much beard anyway.

origin: Then your hose should be ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe untied, and everything about you demonstrating a careless desolation.
modern: Your stockings should be falling down around your ankles, your hat flying off your head, your sleeves unbuttoned, your shoes untied, and everything about you demonstrating carelessness and misery.

origin: But you are no such man.
modern: But you’re no such man.

origin: You are rather point-device in your accouterments, as loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.
modern: You’re so neat and well put-together that you look like you love yourself more than anyone else.

origin: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.
modern: Young boy, I wish I could make you believe that I’m in love.

origin: Me believe it?
modern: Make me believe it?

origin: But, in good sooth, are you he that hangs the verses on the trees wherein Rosalind is so admired?
modern: But really, are you the one who’s been hanging on the trees those poems that speak so admiringly of Rosalind?

origin: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.
modern: I swear to you by Rosalind’s own pretty hand that I am that unfortunate man.

origin: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?
modern: Are you really as in love as your poems declare?

origin: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.
modern: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much I love her.

origin: Love is merely a madness and, I tell you, deserves as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do, and the reason why they are not so punished and cured is that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers are in love, too.
modern: The only reason they don’t get punished and cured is that the disease is so commonplace that the nuthouse nurses are usually suffering from it, too.

origin: Yet I profess curing it by counsel.
modern: But I promise it can be cured with some guidance.

origin: Did you ever cure any so?
modern: Have you ever cured anyone this way before?

origin: Yes, one, and in this manner.
modern: Yes, one, and this is how I did it.

origin: I would not be cured, youth.
modern: I don’t want to be cured, boy.

origin: I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and come every day to my cote and woo me.
modern: I could cure you, if you just called me Rosalind and came by my cottage every day to woo me.

origin: Now, by the faith of my love, I will.
modern: By my faith in love, I will, then.

origin: Tell me where it is.
modern: Tell me where you live.

origin: Go with me to it, and I’ll show it you; and by the way you shall tell me where in the forest you live.
modern: Come with me, I’ll show you, and along the way, you can tell me where you live.

origin: Will you go?
modern: Will you come?

origin: With all my heart, good youth.
modern: Wholeheartedly, good young man.

origin: Nay, you must call me Rosalind.—Come, sister, will you go?
modern: No, you have to call me Rosalind.—Sister, you’re coming?

origin: Come apace, good Audrey.
modern: Come on, sweet Audrey.

origin: I will fetch up your goats, Audrey.
modern: I’ll get your goats, Audrey.

origin: Doth my simple feature content you?
modern: Do my simple features please you?

origin: Your features, Lord warrant us!
modern: Your features, God help us!

origin: What features?
modern: What features?

origin: Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
modern: Really, Audrey, I wish you were more poetical.

origin: I do not know what “poetical” is.
modern: I don’t know what “poetical” means.

origin: Is it honest in deed and word?
modern: Is it “chaste in word and action”?

origin: Is it a true thing?
modern: Does it mean being truthful?

origin: No, truly, for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.
modern: Not really, for the truest poetry is often the most artificial.

origin: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?
modern: But you still wish the gods had made me poetical?

origin: I do, truly, for thou swear’st to me thou art honest.
modern: I do, in fact.

origin: Now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst feign.
modern: Right now you swear to me that you are a virgin; if you were a poet, I might have some hope you were lying.

origin: Would you not have me honest?
modern: What, you don’t want me to be chaste?

origin: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favored, for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.
modern: Not really, unless you were ugly.

origin: Well, I am not fair, and therefore I pray the gods make me honest.
modern: Well, I’m not beautiful, so I hope that I can at least be chaste.

origin: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.
modern: I’m not a slut—I keep myself clean—but I thank God I am ugly.

origin: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness; sluttishness may come hereafter.
modern: Well, praise the Lord you’re ugly.

origin: But what though?
modern: Well, God bless this marriage!

origin: Courage.
modern: Amen.

origin: Well, that is the dowry of his wife; ’tis none of his own getting.
modern: Well, that’s what the wife brings to the marriage.

origin: Horns?
modern: Horns?

origin: Even so.
modern: Well, there they are.

origin: Poor men alone?
modern: Only for poor men?

origin: No, no.
modern: No, no.

origin: The noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal.
modern: The nobleman’s are as huge as the underfed villager’s.

origin: Is the single man therefore blessed?
modern: Is the single man lucky, then?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: As a walled town is more worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a married man more honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor.
modern: Just as a town protected by a wall around it is worth more than a low-lying village, a married man’s horned forehead is more honorable than a bachelor’s bare forehead.

origin: Here comes Sir Oliver.—Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met.
modern: Here comes Sir Oliver.

origin: Will you dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel?
modern: Will you marry us here, under this tree, or should we follow you to your chapel?

origin: Is there none here to give the woman?
modern: Is there anyone to give the bride away?

origin: I will not take her on gift of any man.
modern: I don’t want to take another man’s second-hand goods.

origin: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.
modern: No, someone has to give her away or the marriage isn’t legal.

origin: How do you, sir?
modern: How are you, sir?

origin: You are very well met.
modern: We’re glad to see you.

origin: God 'ild you for your last company.
modern: God bless you for being here.

origin: I am very glad to see you.
modern: I’m very glad to see you.

origin: Even a toy in hand here, sir.
modern: This is just a trifling matter here, sir.

origin: Nay, pray be covered.
modern: No, no, put your hat back on.

origin: Will you be married, motley?
modern: Do you want to get married, fool?

origin: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.
modern: Just as the ox has his yoke, the horse its bridle, the falcon a tether, a man has his desires—to keep in check.

origin: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush like a beggar?
modern: And, being a man of your breeding, you’re going to be married under some shrubs like a beggar?

origin: Get you to church, and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is.
modern: Get yourself to a church and have a proper priest, who can tell you what marriage is all about, marry you.

origin: Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.
modern: Then one of you will warp and pull away—and there goes your marriage.

origin: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.
modern: Come with me and let me advise you.

origin: Come, sweet Audrey.
modern: Come, sweet Audrey.

origin: We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.—Farewell, good Master Oliver, not               'Tis no matter.
modern: We have to be married properly.

origin: Ne'er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling.
modern: None of these deranged rascals can shake me from my profession.

origin: Never talk to me.
modern: Don’t talk to me.

origin: I will weep.
modern: I’m going to cry.

origin: Do, I prithee, but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.
modern: Go ahead if you want, but remember that crying doesn’t suit a man.

origin: But have I not cause to weep?
modern: But don’t I have good reason to cry?

origin: As good cause as one would desire.
modern: As good a reason as any.

origin: Therefore weep.
modern: So go ahead and cry.

origin: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.
modern: His kiss is as holy as bread blessed by a priest.

origin: I am heartily glad I came hither to you.
modern: I’m very glad I came to see you.

origin: If he come tomorrow, I’ll give him his payment.
modern: If he shows up tomorrow, I’ll give him what’s coming to him.

origin: If ever he go alone again, I’ll never wrestle for prize more.
modern: If he can manage to walk after our fight, I’ll never wrestle for money again.

origin: Farewell, good Charles.
modern: Farewell, my lord.

origin: But it shall not be so long; this wrestler shall clear all.
modern: But not for long; Charles will take care of everything.

origin: You have heard him swear downright he was.
modern: But you heard him swear up and down that he was.

origin: He attends here in the forest on the duke your father.
modern: He’s staying in the forest with your father now.

origin: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with him.
modern: I met my father in the woods yesterday and had a long conversation with him.

origin: So he laughed and let me go.
modern: He laughed at that and let me go.

origin: But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando?
modern: He writes brave poems, speaks brave words, makes brave promises, and then breaks them just as bravely.

origin: Oh, that’s a brave man.
modern: He’s like a cowardly

origin: Who comes here?
modern: Who’s coming here?

origin: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired After the shepherd that complained of love, Who you saw sitting by me on the turf, Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess That was his mistress.
modern: Mistress and master, you’ve often asked about that lovelorn shepherd you once saw me sitting with, the one who complained about the disdainful shepherdess he was in love with.

origin: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
modern: Yes, what about him?

origin: Sweet Phoebe, do not scorn me.
modern: Sweet Phoebe, do not scorn me.

origin: Do not, Phoebe.
modern: Do not, Phoebe.

origin: Say that you love me not, but say not so In bitterness.
modern: Go ahead and say you don’t love me, but not so bitterly.

origin: Now counterfeit to swoon, why, now fall down; Or if thou canst not, Oh, for shame, for shame, Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers.
modern: Faint, fall down—if you don’t, then you’re lying about my eyes being murderers.

origin: Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee.
modern: Come on, show me the wound that my eyes have caused.

origin: But now mine eyes, Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not.
modern: But my eyes, which I’ve darted at you, haven’t even left a mark.

origin: Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes That can do hurt.
modern: Now I am sure that eyes can’t hurt a person.

origin: O dear Phoebe, If ever—as that ever may be near— You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy, Then shall you know the wounds invisible That love’s keen arrows make.
modern: Oh, darling Phoebe, if you ever fall in love with some fresh face, then you’ll know about the invisible wounds that love’s sharp arrows can make.

origin: But till that time Come not thou near me.
modern: Well, until that time, don’t come near me.

origin: And when that time comes, Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not, As till that time I shall not pity thee.
modern: And when that time comes, then you can mock me, but please don’t pity me, because I won’t pity you.

origin: But, mistress, know yourself.
modern: But mistress, know yourself.

origin: Down on your knees And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man’s love, For I must tell you friendly in your ear, Sell when you can; you are not for all markets.
modern: Get down on your knees and thank heaven for sending you such a good man.

origin: Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer.
modern: Ask this man’s forgiveness, love him, and accept his offer.

origin: So take her to thee, shepherd.
modern: So take her, shepherd, and God bless you.

origin: Besides, I like you not.
modern: Besides, I don’t like you.

origin: Will you go, sister?—Shepherd, ply her hard.
modern: Come on, sister.

origin: Come, sister.—Shepherdess, look on him better, And be not proud.
modern: And don’t be proud.

origin: Though all the world could see, None could be so abused in sight as he.
modern: The whole world could look at you, and no one would be as blind as he is, thinking you’re beautiful.

origin: Sweet Phoebe, pity me.
modern: Sweet Phoebe, have pity on me.

origin: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
modern: Well, I’m sorry for you, gentle Silvius.

origin: If you do sorrow at my grief in love, By giving love your sorrow and my grief Were both extermined.
modern: Then both my grief and your sorrow will be cured.

origin: Thou hast my love.
modern: You have my friendship.

origin: Is not that neighborly?
modern: Isn’t that enough?

origin: I would have you.
modern: I want you.

origin: Why, that were covetousness.
modern: Well, that’s just greedy.

origin: But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.
modern: But don’t expect any more than that.

origin: Know’st thou the youth that spoke to me erewhile?
modern: Do you know the boy who was just speaking to me?

origin: Not very well, but I have met him oft, And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds That the old carlot once was master of.
modern: Not very well, but I’ve met him several times.

origin: Think not I love him, though I ask for him.
modern: Don’t think I’m in love with him just because I’m asking about him.

origin: Tis but a peevish boy—yet he talks well— But what care I for words?
modern: But what do I care about words?

origin: Yet words do well When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
modern: And yet, words are a good thing when the man speaking them is pleasant to listen to.

origin: It is a pretty youth—not very pretty— But sure he’s proud—and yet his pride becomes him.
modern: He’s awfully proud, but his pride suits him.

origin: He’ll make a proper man.
modern: He’ll grow up to be a proper man.

origin: He is not very tall—yet for his years he’s tall.
modern: He’s not very tall, but he’s tall enough for his age.

origin: His leg is but so-so—and yet ’tis well.
modern: His legs aren’t great, but they’re alright.

origin: There was a pretty redness in his lip, A little riper and more lusty red Than that mixed in his cheek: ’twas just the difference Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
modern: His lips were nice and red, a little more lively and passionate than the red that was in his cheeks—one was pure red and the other more pink.

origin: For what had he to do to chide at me?
modern: What right did he have to scold me like that?

origin: He said mine eyes were black and my hair black And, now I am remembered, scorned at me.
modern: He said my eyes and my hair were black and, now that I think of it, he scorned me.

origin: I marvel why I answered not again.
modern: I’m surprised I didn’t bite back.

origin: But that’s all one: omittance is no quittance.
modern: But no matter—I’ll get back at him soon enough.

origin: I’ll write to him a very taunting letter, And thou shalt bear it.
modern: I’ll write him a taunting letter, and you can deliver it.

origin: Wilt thou, Silvius?
modern: Will you do that for me, Silvius?

origin: Phoebe, with all my heart.
modern: With all my heart, Phoebe.

origin: I will be bitter with him and passing short.
modern: I’ll be bitter toward him, and curt.

origin: Go with me, Silvius.
modern: Come with me, Silvius.

origin: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with thee.
modern: Please, pretty young man, I’d like to get to know you better.

origin: They say you are a melancholy fellow.
modern: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

origin: I am so.
modern: I am.

origin: I do love it better than laughing.
modern: I like it better than laughing.

origin: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.
modern: People who are either too serious or too silly are awful.

origin: Why, ’tis good to be sad and say nothing.
modern: Well, I think it’s good to be serious and keep quiet.

origin: Why then, ’tis good to be a post.
modern: In that case it’s good to be a post.

origin: I have neither the scholar’s melancholy, which is emulation; nor the musician’s, which is fantastical; nor the courtier’s, which is proud; nor the soldier’s, which is ambitious; nor the lawyer’s, which is politic; nor the lady’s, which is nice; nor the lover’s, which is all these, but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness.
modern: I don’t have the proud melancholy of a courtier or the ambitious melancholy of a soldier or the calculated melancholy of a lawyer.

origin: A traveler.
modern: You’re a traveler.

origin: By my faith, you have great reason to be sad.
modern: Well then, you have good reason to be sad.

origin: I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men’s.
modern: I’m afraid you’ve sold your own land to see other men’s.

origin: Then to have seen much and to have nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.
modern: To have seen much but own nothing is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

origin: Yes, I have gained my experience.
modern: Not true.

origin: And your experience makes you sad.
modern: And your experience makes you sad.

origin: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.
modern: I’d rather have a jester to make me happy than experience to make me sad—and to travel for all that trouble, no less!

origin: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind.
modern: Good day and happiness to you, darling Rosalind.

origin: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.
modern: My beautiful Rosalind, I’m only an hour late.

origin: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
modern: Please, Rosalind, my sweet cousin—be happy.

origin: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of, and would you yet I were merrier?
modern: Dear Celia—I already look much happier than I feel, but you want me to look even happier?

origin: Unless you could teach me to forget a banished father, you must not learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure.
modern: Unless you can also teach me how to forget my banished father, you shouldn’t try to teach me how to be happy.

origin: Herein I see thou lov’st me not with the full weight that I love thee.
modern: Well, by this I can see that you don’t love me as much as I love you.

origin: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours.
modern: If  Well, I’ll just forget the difficulties of my situation, in order to focus on the happiness of yours.

origin: By mine honor I will, and when I break that oath, let me turn monster.
modern: I swear I will, and if I ever break my promise let me turn into a monster.

origin: Therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.
modern: So please, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be happy.

origin: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports.
modern: From now on I will, cousin, and I’ll think of all kinds of games for us.

origin: Let me see—what think you of falling in love?
modern: Let me see—what do you think about falling in love?

origin: Break an hour’s promise in love?
modern: You’d break a date with your beloved by a whole hour?

origin: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.
modern: Forgive me, darling Rosalind.

origin: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight.
modern: No, if you’re ever late like this again, I’ll refuse to see you.

origin: I had as lief be wooed of a snail.
modern: I’d rather be wooed by a snail.

origin: Of a snail?
modern: A snail?

origin: Besides, he brings his destiny with him.
modern: Besides, he brings his fate with him.

origin: What’s that?
modern: What fate is that?

origin: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for.
modern: Why, his cuckold’s horns, of course—the kind you men are always blaming on your wives.

origin: But he comes armed in his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.
modern: See, the snail already has its horns, which prevents nasty rumors from spreading about his wife’s infidelity.

origin: Virtue is no hornmaker, and my Rosalind is virtuous.
modern: A virtuous woman won’t give her husband horns, and my Rosalind is definitely virtuous.

origin: And I am your Rosalind.
modern: And I am your Rosalind.

origin: Rosalind of a better leer than you.
modern: Come on, woo me, woo me.

origin: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday humor, and like enough to consent.
modern: I’m in a good mood now and likely to give you what you want.

origin: What would you say to me now, an I were your very, very Rosalind?
modern: What would you say to me now if I really were your precious little Rosalind?

origin: I would kiss before I spoke.
modern: I’d kiss you before I spoke.

origin: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were graveled for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss.
modern: No, it would be better to speak first and kiss only after you’ve run out of things to say.

origin: Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking—God warn us—matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.
modern: When good orators finish talking, they spit; when lovers do (God help us if they ever do), they kiss.

origin: How if the kiss be denied?
modern: What if she won’t kiss me?

origin: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
modern: Who could be out of things to say if he were with the girl he loves?

origin: Marry, that should you if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.
modern: Indeed, you would be out if I were your mistress—if my chastity is worth as much as my wit.

origin: Am not I your Rosalind?
modern: Aren’t I your Rosalind?

origin: I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking of her.
modern: I like to pretend you are, because then it’s almost like actually talking to her.

origin: No, faith, die by attorney.
modern: No, you won’t die yourself, but only by proxy.

origin: The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love cause.
modern: This world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time not one man has ever actually died from love.

origin: Then love me, Rosalind.
modern: Then love me, Rosalind.

origin: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.
modern: Okay, I will—on Fridays and Saturdays, and the rest.

origin: And wilt thou have me?
modern: And will you have me?

origin: Ay, and twenty such.
modern: Sure, and twenty others just like you.

origin: What sayest thou?
modern: What’s that?

origin: Are you not good?
modern: Well, aren’t you a good man?

origin: I hope so.
modern: I hope so.

origin: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?— Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us.—Give me your hand, Orlando.—What do you say, sister?
modern: And can a person ever have too much of a good thing?—Come on, sister, you can be the priest and marry us.—Give me your hand, Orlando.—What do you say, sister?

origin: Pray thee, marry us.
modern: Please, marry us.

origin: I will.
modern: I do.

origin: Ay, but when?
modern: Okay, but when?

origin: Why, now, as fast as she can marry us.
modern: Right now; as fast as she can say the vows.

origin: Then you must say “I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.” I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.
modern: Then you have to say, “I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife.” I take you, Rosalind, to be my lawfully wedded wife.

origin: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband.
modern: Maybe I should ask you what right you have to take me, but I’ll take you, Orlando, to be my husband.

origin: So do all thoughts.
modern: So do all thoughts.

origin: They are winged.
modern: They have wings.

origin: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possessed her.
modern: Now tell me how long you intend to keep her.

origin: Forever and a day.
modern: Forever and a day.

origin: Say “a day” without the “ever.” No, no, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed. Maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives.
modern: No, Orlando, men are like April when they’re wooing a girl—young, and passionate—but like December once they’re married and their passions have cooled.

origin: I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock- pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more newfangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey.
modern: I’ll be more jealous of you than a wild rooster over his hen; more noisy than a parrot chattering about the rain; more fond of new things than an ape; more giddy about getting what I want than a monkey.

origin: I will weep for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you are disposed to be merry.
modern: I’ll cry at nothing, and I’ll always do it when you’re in a good mood.

origin: I will laugh like a hyena, and that when thou art inclined to sleep.
modern: And when you want to go to sleep, I’ll be up laughing like a hyena.

origin: But will my Rosalind do so?
modern: But will my Rosalind do this, too?

origin: Oh, but she is wise.
modern: But she is wise.

origin: Or else she could not have the wit to do this.
modern: Right.

origin: The wiser, the waywarder.
modern: The wiser the woman, the wilder.

origin: Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out at the casement.
modern: If you close the doors on a woman’s wit, it’ll fly out the window.

origin: Shut that, and ’twill out at the keyhole.
modern: If you shut the windows, it will pour out the keyhole.

origin: Stop that, ’twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.
modern: If you stop up the keyhole, it will escape from the chimney along with the smoke.

origin: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say “Wit, whither wilt?”  Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your wife’s wit going to your neighbor’s bed.
modern: A man with a wife like that might ask, “Hey, wandering wit, where are you off to?” Nah, better save the questions for when you find her in your neighbor’s bed.

origin: You shall never take her without her answer unless you take her without her tongue.
modern: You’ll never find her without an answer unless you find her without a tongue.

origin: Oh, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool.
modern: A woman who doesn’t know how to make her own indiscretions look like her husband’s fault is hardly a woman.

origin: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.
modern: Rosalind, I have to leave you for two hours.

origin: I must attend the duke at dinner.
modern: I must join the duke for lunch.

origin: By two o'clock I will be with thee again.
modern: I’ll be back here with you by two o'clock.

origin: Ay, go your ways, go your ways.
modern: Oh, go, leave me.

origin: I knew what you would prove.
modern: I knew you’d turn out this way.

origin: My friends told me as much, and I thought no less.
modern: My friends told me as much, and I knew it, too.

origin: Tis but one cast away, and so, come, death.
modern: So, take me, death!

origin: Two o'clock is your hour?
modern: You’ll be back at two o'clock?

origin: Ay, sweet Rosalind.
modern: Yes, sweet Rosalind.

origin: Therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.
modern: So beware of my contempt, and keep your promise.

origin: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind.
modern: I’ll keep my promise just as if you really were Rosalind.

origin: So, adieu.
modern: So, goodbye.

origin: Well, time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let time try.
modern: Well, time is the old judge that tries your kind of criminal.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate.
modern: You have absolutely abused our sex in this love talk of yours.

origin: We must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
modern: We should rip off your man’s clothing and show the world the woman who has represented her own kind so badly.

origin: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love.
modern: Oh cousin, cousin, cousin, my sweet little cousin, I wish you knew how deep in love I am.

origin: Or rather bottomless, that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.
modern: Or it’s bottomless, at least: pour affection in one end, and it runs out the other.

origin: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceived of spleen, and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses everyone’s eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love.
modern: Cupid—that blind bastard son of Venus, conceived from a thought and anger, born from insanity, that blind, naughty boy who makes everyone else go blind just because he can’t see himself—let Cupid judge how deep my love runs.

origin: I’ll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando.
modern: I’m telling you, Aliena, I can’t stand being apart from Orlando.

origin: I’ll go find a shadow and sigh till he come.
modern: I’m going to find some shade and sigh until he returns.

origin: And I’ll sleep.
modern: And I’m going to sleep.

origin: Which is he that killed the deer?
modern: Which one of you killed the deer?

origin: Yes, sir.
modern: Yes, sir.

origin: Sing it.
modern: Then sing it.

origin: Tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise enough.
modern: It doesn’t matter if it’s in tune so long as it’s loud enough.

origin: How say you now?
modern: What do you say now?

origin: Is it not past two o'clock?
modern: Isn’t it past two o'clock?

origin: And here much Orlando.
modern: And I see a lot of Orlando here.

origin: Look who comes here.
modern: Look who’s coming.

origin: No, I protest, I know not the contents.
modern: No, I swear, I don’t even know what’s in it.

origin: Phoebe did write it.
modern: Phoebe wrote it.

origin: What shall be our sport, then?
modern: Well, then, what should we do for fun instead?

origin: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.
modern: Let’s go find that hussy, Fortune, and and mock her till she starts distributing her gifts more equally.

origin: No?
modern: Oh, really?
