origin: When Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by Fortune fall into the fire?
modern: Well, when Nature makes a person beautiful, can’t Fortune make her fall into a fire, thereby making her ugly after all?

origin: Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?
modern: And even though Nature has given us the wit to have this argument, hasn’t Fortune sent this fool here to stop us?

origin: Come, come, you are a fool, And turned into the extremity of love.
modern: Come on, you’re a fool, and driven to extreme measures by love.

origin: I say she never did invent this letter.
modern: The point is that she didn’t write this letter.

origin: This is a man’s invention, and his hand.
modern: These are a man’s words, and his handwriting.

origin: Sure it is hers.
modern: I’m telling you, it’s hers.

origin: Why, she defies me Like Turk to Christian.
modern: Why, she challenges me like a Muslim would challenge a Christian.

origin: Women’s gentle brain Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention, Such Ethiop words, blacker in their effect Than in their countenance.
modern: No, a woman’s gentle brain could never have come up with such crude expressions and even harsher meanings.

origin: Will you hear the letter?
modern: Do you want to hear what she says?

origin: So please you, for I never heard it yet, Yet heard too much of Phoebe’s cruelty.
modern: If you want to read it, as I haven’t heard it yet, though I’ve heard too much of Phoebe’s cruelty.

origin: She Phoebes me.
modern: She’s Phoebe-ing me.

origin: Mark how the tyrant writes.
modern: Listen to what the tyrant says.

origin: That a maiden’s heart hath burned?
modern: You call that ranting?

origin: Call you this railing?
modern: You call this sneering?

origin: Why, thy godhead laid apart, Warr’st thou with a woman’s heart?
modern: Why do you pity him?

origin: Not to be endured.
modern: Follow them straight to the cottage.

origin: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.
modern: Since you asked, I suppose it’s not bragging to say that we are.

origin: Orlando doth commend him to you both, And to that youth he calls his Rosalind He sends this bloody napkin.
modern: Orlando sends his regards to you both, and he sends this bloody handkerchief to the boy he calls “his Rosalind.” Is that you?

origin: Are you he?
modern: It is.

origin: Some of my shame, if you will know of me What man I am, and how, and why, and where This handkercher was stained.
modern: It’s about who I am, and how, why, and where this handkerchief was stained.

origin: I pray you, tell it.
modern: Please, tell us.

origin: He threw his eye aside— And mark what object did present itself: Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age And high top bald with dry antiquity, A wretched, ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, Lay sleeping on his back.
modern: He looked to the side, and pay attention to what he saw then: under an oak tree—whose lower branches were mossy with age and top branches ancient and brittle—he saw a wretched beggar, with overgrown hair and beard, asleep on his back.

origin: This seen, Orlando did approach the man And found it was his brother, his elder brother.
modern: He discovered that the man was his older brother.

origin: Oh, I have heard him speak of that same brother, And he did render him the most unnatural That lived amongst men.
modern: Oh, I’ve heard him talk about that brother, and he described him as the most inhumane man alive.

origin: But to Orlando: did he leave him there, Food to the sucked and hungry lioness?
modern: He turned away twice and almost left him there.

origin: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so, But kindness, nobler ever than revenge, And nature, stronger than his just occasion, Made him give battle to the lioness, Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling, From miserable slumber I awaked.
modern: But his kindness was nobler than even his desire for revenge, his natural goodness was stronger than his need to give his brother what he deserved.

origin: Are you his brother?
modern: Are you his brother?

origin: Was ’t you he rescued?
modern: Was it you that he rescued?

origin: Was ’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
modern: Was it you that was always plotting to kill him?

origin: Twas I, but ’tis not I. I do not shame To tell you what I was, since my conversion So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.
modern: That was me, but it’s not me— I’m not ashamed to tell you what I once was, since I’m so happy to have since converted.

origin: But for the bloody napkin?
modern: But what about the bloody handkerchief?

origin: By and by.
modern: I’ll get there.

origin: Brief, I recovered him, bound up his wound, And after some small space, being strong at heart,
modern: After a brief time—as he is a strong, brave man—

origin: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.
modern: Many people faint when they see blood.

origin: There is more in it.—Cousin Ganymede.
modern: There’s more to it than that.—Ganymede!

origin: Look, he recovers.
modern: Look, he’s recovering.

origin: I would I were at home.
modern: I want to go home.

origin: We’ll lead you thither.
modern: We’ll take you there.

origin: I pray you, will you take him by the arm?
modern: Please, will you take his arm?

origin: Be of good cheer, youth.
modern: Buck up, boy!

origin: You a man?
modern: You’re a man?

origin: You lack a man’s heart.
modern: You don’t have a man’s courage.

origin: I do so, I confess it.
modern: It’s true, I confess.

origin: Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well-counterfeited.
modern: Oh, sir, someone would think I was a good fake.

origin: I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited.
modern: Please tell your brother what a convincing show I put on.

origin: Heigh-ho.
modern: Whoo-hoo!

origin: This was not counterfeit.
modern: That was no show.

origin: There is too great testimony in your complexion that it was a passion of earnest.
modern: Your cheeks are too flushed for me to believe that was a fake faint.

origin: Counterfeit, I assure you.
modern: Fake, I’m telling you.

origin: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.
modern: Well, then, be brave and pretend to be a man.

origin: So I do.
modern: That’s what I’m doing.

origin: But i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.
modern: But honestly, I should have been a woman.

origin: Come, you look paler and paler.
modern: Come on, you keep getting paler.

origin: That will I, for I must bear answer back How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.
modern: I’ll do that, because I have to tell my brother how you forgave him, Rosalind.

origin: I shall devise something.
modern: I’ll think of something.

origin: But I pray you commend my counterfeiting to him.
modern: But please, tell him how well I faked a faint.

origin: Will you go?
modern: Will you come with us?

origin: We shall find a time, Audrey.
modern: We’ll get married at some point, Audrey.

origin: Patience, gentle Audrey.
modern: Be patient.

origin: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old gentleman’s saying.
modern: Really, the priest was good enough, no matter what that old guy said.

origin: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext.
modern: No, he was wicked and vile.

origin: But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you.
modern: But Audrey, there’s a boy in the forest who claims you’re his girl.

origin: Here comes the man you mean.
modern: Here comes the man himself.

origin: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown.
modern: It warms my heart to encounter such a country bumpkin.

origin: How old are you, friend?
modern: How old are you, friend?

origin: Five-and-twenty, sir.
modern: Twenty-five, sir.

origin: A ripe age.
modern: A mature age.

origin: Is thy name William?
modern: Is your name William?

origin: William, sir.
modern: Yes, it’s William, sir.

origin: A fair name.
modern: A good name.

origin: Wast born i' th' forest here?
modern: Were you born here in the forest?

origin: Ay, sir, I thank God.
modern: Yes sir, thank God.

origin: Thank God.” A good answer.
modern: Thank God”—that’s a good answer.

origin: Art rich?
modern: Are you rich?

origin: Faith, sir, so-so.
modern: Well, so-so.

origin: So-so” is good, very good, very excellent good.
modern: So-so” is good, very good, an excellent answer.

origin: And yet it is not: it is but so-so.
modern: And then again, it’s not so good, but only so-so.

origin: Art thou wise?
modern: Are you wise?

origin: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.
modern: Yes sir, I’m fairly witty.

origin: Why, thou sayst well.
modern: Well, that’s a fine answer.

origin: Give me your hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: Art thou learned?
modern: Are you educated?

origin: No, sir.
modern: No, sir.

origin: Then learn this of me: to have is to have.
modern: Then learn this from me: if you have something, you have it.

origin: For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other.
modern: Everyone knows that when you pour a drink out of a cup and into a glass, the cup becomes empty.

origin: He, sir, that must marry this woman.
modern: Why, the he that will marry this woman.

origin: Therefore, you clown, abandon—which is, in the vulgar, “leave”—the society—which in the boorish is “company”—of this female—which in the common is “woman”; which together is, abandon the society of this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into death, thy liberty into bondage.
modern: Or, rather, I’ll kill you, or I’ll do away with you, or I’ll turn your life into death and your freedom into captivity.

origin: I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel.
modern: I’ll poison you, or beat you with a club, or stab you with a sword.

origin: I will bandy with thee in faction.
modern: I’ll bandy you about and overwhelm you with my cleverness.

origin: I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways.
modern: I will, in other words, kill you in three hundred and fifty ways.

origin: Therefore tremble and depart.
modern: Therefore, tremble with fear and leave.

origin: Do, good William.
modern: Do what he says, William.

origin: God rest you merry, sir.
modern: Farewell, sir.

origin: Our master and mistress seeks you.
modern: Our master and mistress are looking for you.

origin: Come away, away.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey.—I attend, I attend.
modern: Hurry up, Audrey, hurry.—I’m coming, I’m coming.

origin: Mistress, you must come away to your father.
modern: Mistress, you have to go see your father.

origin: Were you made the messenger?
modern: Did they make you the messenger?

origin: Of a certain knight that swore by his honor they were good pancakes, and swore by his honor the mustard was naught.
modern: From a certain knight who swore on his honor that the pancakes he was eating were good, and that the mustard on top of them—he swore on his honor—was bad.

origin: Now, I’ll stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.
modern: Now, I’ll swear to the opposite—that the pancakes were rotten, and the mustard was fine—but even so, the knight wasn’t lying.

origin: How prove you that in the great heap of your knowledge?
modern: And how, out of your great heap of knowledge, will you manage to prove that?

origin: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.
modern: Yes, please; unleash your wisdom.

origin: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.
modern: Watch me: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.

origin: By our beards (if we had them), thou art.
modern: By our beards (if we had them), you are a knave.

origin: By my knavery (if I had it), then I were.
modern: And I swear by my wickedness (if I had any) that I am a knave.

origin: Is ’t possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her?
modern: Is it really possible that you could like her right after meeting her?

origin: It shall be to your good, for my father’s house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland’s will I estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.
modern: It will be to your advantage, because I’ll leave our father’s house and all his property to you, while I live and die a shepherd here in the forest.

origin: You have my consent.
modern: You have my consent.

origin: Let your wedding be tomorrow.
modern: You can be married tomorrow if you want.

origin: Thither will I invite the duke and all’s contented followers.
modern: I’ll invite the duke and all of his followers.

origin: Go you and prepare Aliena, for look you, here comes my Rosalind.
modern: Go get Aliena ready—because, look, here comes my Rosalind.

origin: And you, fair sister.
modern: And hello to you, fair sister.

origin: O my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf.
modern: Oh, darling Orlando, it’s so hard to see you wearing your heart in a sling.

origin: It is my arm.
modern: Actually, it’s my arm.

origin: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.
modern: I thought your heart had been wounded by a lion’s claws.

origin: They are in the very wrath of love, and they will together.
modern: They’re in the heat of passion; they simply have to be together.

origin: Clubs cannot part them.
modern: You couldn’t beat the two of them apart.

origin: They shall be married tomorrow, and I will bid the duke to the nuptial.
modern: They’ll be married tomorrow, and I’ll invite the duke to the ceremony.

origin: But Oh, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man’s eyes.
modern: But, oh, it makes me bitter to look at happiness through another man’s eyes.

origin: By so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.
modern: Tomorrow I’ll be at the depths of my misery thinking about the happiness my brother has achieved, in having what he wished for.

origin: Why, then, tomorrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?
modern: Well then, can’t I act as Rosalind for you tomorrow?

origin: I can live no longer by thinking.
modern: I can’t live by pretending anymore.

origin: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.
modern: I won’t exhaust you anymore with idle chitchat.

origin: I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are.
modern: You should know that I think you’re a smart man.

origin: Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things.
modern: Believe me, then, that I have special powers.

origin: I have, since I was three year old, conversed with a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable.
modern: Since I was three years old, I’ve been in contact with a powerful but virtuous magician—no black magic here.

origin: If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her.
modern: If you love Rosalind as much as you say you do, you will marry her when your brother marries Aliena.

origin: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.
modern: I know where she is and, if you don’t mind, I will set her before you tomorrow, whole and unharmed.

origin: Speak’st thou in sober meanings?
modern: Are you serious?

origin: By my life I do, which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician.
modern: I swear on my life, which I take pretty seriously, even if I am a magician.

origin: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.
modern: Look, here comes someone who loves me, along with someone who loves her.

origin: I care not if I have.
modern: I don’t care.

origin: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd.
modern: A faithful shepherd worships you.

origin: Good shepherd, tell this youth what ’tis to love.
modern: Silvius, tell this youth what it means to be in love.

origin: It is to be all made of sighs and tears, And so am I for Phoebe.
modern: It means being full of sighs and tears, like I am for Phoebe.

origin: And I for Ganymede.
modern: And like I am for Ganymede.

origin: And I for Rosalind.
modern: And like I am for Rosalind.

origin: And I for no woman.
modern: And like I am for no woman.

origin: It is to be all made of faith and service, And so am I for Phoebe.
modern: It means being faithful and ready to serve, just like I am for Phoebe.

origin: And I for Ganymede.
modern: And like I am for Ganymede.

origin: And I for Rosalind.
modern: And like I am for Rosalind.

origin: And I for no woman.
modern: And like I am for no woman.

origin: It is to be all made of fantasy, All made of passion and all made of wishes, All adoration, duty, and observance, All humbleness, all patience and impatience, All purity, all trial, all observance, And so am I for Phoebe.
modern: It means being filled with fantasy; with passion and wishes; with adoration, loyalty, and devotion.

origin: And so am I for Rosalind.
modern: And I for Rosalind.

origin: And so am I for no woman.
modern: And I for no woman.

origin: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
modern: Since you know all this is true, why do you blame me for loving you?

origin: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
modern: And why do you blame me for loving you?

origin: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
modern: And why do you blame me for loving you?

origin: Why do you speak, too, “Why blame you me to love you?”?
modern: Who are you talking to?

origin: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.
modern: I’m saying it to the girl who isn’t here and doesn’t hear me.

origin: Pray you, no more of this.
modern: All right, stop this.

origin: Tis like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon.
modern: You sound like a pack of wolves howling at the moon.

origin: I’ll not fail, if I live.
modern: As long as I’m alive, I’ll be here.

origin: Nor I.
modern: Me too.

origin: Nor I.
modern: Me too.

origin: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey.
modern: Tomorrow is the happy day, Audrey.

origin: Tomorrow will we be married.
modern: We’ll be married tomorrow.

origin: I do desire it with all my heart, and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world.
modern: I hope it doesn’t make me unchaste that I really want to be a married woman.

origin: Here comes two of the banished duke’s pages.
modern: Here come two of Duke Senior’s pages.

origin: Well met, honest gentleman.
modern: Good afternoon, good gentleman.

origin: By my troth, well met.
modern: It really is good to see you.

origin: Come, sit, sit, and a song.
modern: Come, sit, sit, and sing me a song.

origin: We are for you.
modern: Sounds good to us.

origin: Sit i' th' middle.
modern: Sit between us.

origin: Shall we clap into ’t roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?
modern: Should we just get down to it?

origin: I' faith, i' faith, and both in a tune like two gypsies on a horse.
modern: Yes, yes, and let’s sing in unison, like two gypsies riding on a single horse.

origin: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untunable.
modern: Really, young men, though it wasn’t a very hard song to get right, the music was still all out of tune.

origin: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy Can do all this that he hath promisèd?
modern: Orlando, do you really believe that this boy can do everything he’s promised?

origin: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.
modern: Yes, even if I had whole kingdoms to give along with her.

origin: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.
modern: I will, even if I were king of all kingdoms.

origin: That will I, should I die the hour after.
modern: Yes, even if I die an hour later.

origin: But if you do refuse to marry me, You’ll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?
modern: But if you decide not to marry me, you’ll marry this faithful shepherd instead?

origin: So is the bargain.
modern: That’s the deal.

origin: Though to have her and death were both one thing.
modern: Even if marrying her meant I died.

origin: I have promised to make all this matter even.
modern: I’ve promised to make everything right.

origin: Keep your word, Phoebe, that you’ll marry me Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd.
modern: Phoebe, keep your promise to marry me, and to marry this shepherd if you choose to refuse me.

origin: Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her If she refuse me.
modern: Silvius, keep your promise to marry Phoebe if she refuses me.

origin: And from hence I go To make these doubts all even.
modern: I’ll leave now, to set all these things right.

origin: I do remember in this shepherd boy Some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.
modern: This shepherd boy reminds me quite vividly of my daughter.

origin: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
modern: My lord, when I first saw him I thought he was your daughter’s brother.

origin: But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born And hath been tutored in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle, Whom he reports to be a great magician Obscurèd in the circle of this forest.
modern: But, my lord, this boy was born in the forest and has been schooled not in the usual subjects but only in magic.

origin: Good my lord, bid him welcome.
modern: My lord, welcome this man.

origin: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.
modern: This is the jester I have met so many times in the forest.

origin: He hath been a courtier, he swears.
modern: He swears he used to be a courtier.

origin: If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation.
modern: If anyone doubts this, let him put me on trial.

origin: I have undone three tailors.
modern: I have bankrupted three tailors.

origin: I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.
modern: I have quarreled four times, and almost got in a fight.

origin: And how was that ta'en up?
modern: And how was that one settled?

origin: Faith, we met and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause.
modern: Well, we almost fought and then realized that we had reached the seventh cause.

origin: How “seventh cause”?—Good my lord, like this fellow.
modern: What do you mean, the seventh cause?

origin: I like him very well.
modern: I like him very well.

origin: Prithee, who is ’t that thou mean’st?
modern: Tell me, who is this knight?

origin: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.
modern: A man old Frederick, your father, loves.

origin: My father’s love is enough to honor him.
modern: If he has my father’s love, then that’s enough honor for me.

origin: Enough.
modern: Enough of this.

origin: Speak no more of him; you’ll be whipped for taxation one of these days.
modern: No more talk about my father; you’ll be whipped for slander one of these days.

origin: The more pity that fools may not speak wisely what wise men do foolishly.
modern: It’s a pity that fools aren’t allowed to speak wisely about the foolish things that wise men do.

origin: With his mouth full of news.
modern: Honestly, you’re speaking the truth—ever since the fools were  With his mouth full of news.

origin: Which he will put on us as pigeons feed their young.
modern: Which he’ll shove down our throats the way pigeons feed their young.

origin: Then shall we be news-crammed.
modern: Then we’ll be stuffed with news.

origin: All the better.
modern: Well that’s good.

origin: We shall be the more marketable.—Bonjour, Monsieur Le Beau.
modern: If we’re  Hello, Monsieur Le Beau.

origin: What’s the news?
modern: What’s the news?

origin: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.
modern: Fair princess, you’ve missed some good sport.

origin: Sport?
modern: Sport?

origin: Of what color?
modern: Of what

origin: God 'ild you, sir.
modern: God bless you, sir.

origin: A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favored thing, sir, but mine own.
modern: This poor virgin isn’t much to look at, sir, but she’s mine.

origin: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.
modern: Really, he’s very witty, and full of wise sayings.

origin: But for the seventh cause.
modern: But back to that argument you mentioned.

origin: How did you find the quarrel on the seventh cause?
modern: What’s the “seventh cause”?

origin: Upon a lie seven times removed.—Bear your body more seeming, Audrey.—As thus, sir: I did dislike the cut of a certain courtier’s beard.
modern: I didn’t like the way a particular courtier had cut his beard.

origin: He sent me word if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it was.
modern: He sent me word that, whether I liked it or not, he liked it fine.

origin: This is called “the countercheck quarrelsome,” and so to “the lie circumstantial” and “the lie direct.”  And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
modern: They call this “the argumentative countercheck.” And so on through “the circumstantial lie” and “the direct lie.” And how many times did you say his beard wasn’t cut well?

origin: He’s as good at anything and yet a fool.
modern: He’s as smart as they come, but just a jester.

origin: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit.
modern: He uses his clownishness to disguise his deadly wit.

origin: Then is there mirth in heaven When earthly things, made even, Atone together.
modern: There is laughter in heaven When earthly affairs are put right And people unite.

origin: Good duke, receive thy daughter.
modern: Good duke, come receive your daughter.

origin: Hymen from heaven brought her, Yea, brought her hither, That thou mightst join her hand with his Whose heart within his bosom is.
modern: Hymen brought her from heaven Yes, brought her here.

origin: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.
modern: If my eyes don’t deceive me, you are my daughter.

origin: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.
modern: If my eyes don’t deceive me, you are my Rosalind.

origin: If sight and shape be true, Why then, my love adieu.
modern: If my eyes aren’t deceiving me, goodbye, love.

origin: Peace, ho!
modern: Quiet!

origin: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me, Even daughter, welcome in no less degree.
modern: My niece, you are welcome here as if you were my own daughter.

origin: Let me have audience for a word or two.
modern: Let me have your attention for a moment.

origin: I am the second son of old Sir Rowland, That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
modern: I’m Sir Rowland’s middle son, and I bring you news.

origin: Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day Men of great worth resorted to this forest, Addressed a mighty power, which were on foot In his own conduct, purposely to take His brother here and put him to the sword.
modern: When Duke Frederick heard that great, worthy men were coming to this forest every day, he raised a large army to invade this land and fight his brother.

origin: This to be true I do engage my life.
modern: I swear on my life that I’m speaking the truth.

origin: Sir, by your patience: if I heard you rightly, The duke hath put on a religious life And thrown into neglect the pompous court.
modern: Do you mean to say that the duke has abandoned the glamorous court to live as a monk?

origin: He hath.
modern: Yes, he has.

origin: To him will I.
modern: I will go find him.

origin: Out of these convertites There is much matter to be heard and learned.
modern: There is much to be learned from these converts.

origin: Stay, Jaques, stay.
modern: Stay, Jaques, stay here for a bit.

origin: To see no pastime I.
modern: No, this fun is not for me.

origin: What you would have I’ll stay to know at your abandoned cave.
modern: I’ll wait for you in your cave, where you can tell me what you need from me.

origin: Proceed, proceed.
modern: Let’s proceed.

origin: We’ll so begin these rites As we do trust they’ll end, in true delights.
modern: We’ll begin the ceremony the way we hope it will end—with delight.

origin: If it be true that good wine needs no bush, ’tis true that a good play needs no epilogue.
modern: If it’s true that you don’t need

origin: What color, madam?
modern: What color, madam?

origin: How shall I answer you?
modern: I don’t understand—how should I answer that?

origin: As wit and fortune will.
modern: However your wit and luck allow.

origin: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.
modern: Tell us about this wrestling.

origin: Well, the beginning that is dead and buried.
modern: Well, we’ve missed the beginning; it’s dead and buried.

origin: There comes an old man and his three sons— I could match this beginning with an old tale.
modern: There comes an old man with his three sons— It sounds like the beginning of an old folktale.

origin: Three proper young men of excellent growth and presence.
modern: Three proper young men, all good looking and with great presence—

origin: With bills on their necks: “Be it known unto all men by these presents.”  The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the duke’s wrestler, which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him.
modern: Right, and they wore proclamations around their necks, saying, “Be it known to all men by these  The eldest of the three brothers wrestled with Charles, the duke’s wrestler.

origin: So he served the second, and so the third.
modern: Charles did the same to the second brother, and the third.

origin: Yonder they lie, the poor old man their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping.
modern: They’re lying over there, and the poor old man, their father, weeps so piteously over them that the whole audience has joined him in grieving.

origin: Alas!
modern: Oh, dear!

origin: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have lost?
modern: But tell me, monsieur—what sport are the ladies missing?

origin: Why, this that I speak of.
modern: Why, the one I just told you about.

origin: Or I, I promise thee.
modern: Me too, I swear.

origin: But is there any else longs to see this broken music in his sides?
modern: Doesn’t anyone else want to see this, and hear breath wheezing out from broken ribs?

origin: Shall we see this wrestling, cousin?
modern: Shall we go watch this wrestling, cousin?

origin: Yonder sure they are coming.
modern: Yes, I see them coming.

origin: Let us now stay and see it.
modern: Let’s stay and watch.

origin: Come on.
modern: Come on.

origin: Since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.
modern: Since the youth won’t be reasoned with, he’ll have to suffer for his stubbornness.

origin: Is yonder the man?
modern: Is that the man?

origin: Even he, madam.
modern: That’s him, madam.

origin: Alas, he is too young.
modern: Alas, he is too young.

origin: Yet he looks successfully.
modern: Yet he seems capable.

origin: How now, daughter and cousin?
modern: What’s up, daughter and niece?

origin: Are you crept hither to see the wrestling?
modern: Have you snuck over here to watch the wrestling?

origin: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.
modern: Yes, my lord, if you give us permission.

origin: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you, there is such odds in the man.
modern: You won’t enjoy it much, I can tell you, the odds are so against this young man.

origin: In pity of the challenger’s youth, I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated.
modern: Because he’s so young, I’ve tried to discourage him, but he won’t listen.

origin: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.
modern: Call him over here, good Monsieur Le Beau.

origin: Yonder comes my master, your brother.
modern: I remember, Adam, that’s  Here comes my master, your brother.

origin: Go apart, Adam, and thou shalt hear how he will shake me up.
modern: Go hide, Adam, and you’ll hear how he abuses me.

origin: Monsieur the challenger, the Princess calls for you.
modern: Mister Challenger, the princess wants to speak to you.

origin: I attend them with all respect and duty.
modern: I’ll wait on them with all respect and duty.

origin: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler?
modern: Young man, have you challenged Charles the Wrestler?

origin: No, fair princess.
modern: No, lovely princess.

origin: He is the general challenger.
modern: He is the general challenger.

origin: I come but in as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.
modern: I have only come in—like the others have—to try to fight him with the strength of my youth.

origin: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years.
modern: Young gentleman, you are too bold for your age.

origin: You have seen cruel proof of this man’s strength.
modern: You have seen the cruel proof of this man’s strength.

origin: If you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal enterprise.
modern: If you took a good look at yourself, or if you thought about this more carefully, your fear would teach you to act more cautiously.

origin: We pray you for your own sake to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.
modern: We beg you, for your own sake, to respect your safety and give up.

origin: Do, young sir.
modern: Please, young sir.

origin: But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial, wherein, if I be foiled, there is but one shamed that was never gracious; if killed, but one dead that was willing to be so.
modern: If I’m killed, it will only be the death of a man who was willing to be dead.

origin: I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing.
modern: I won’t wrong any of my friends, because I don’t have any to mourn for me, and I won’t have wronged the world, because I don’t have anything in the world.

origin: Only in the world I fill up a place which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.
modern: In this world, I’m only taking up space.

origin: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.
modern: I wish I could give you the little strength that I have.

origin: And mine, to eke out hers.
modern: Mine too, to join hers.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Good luck.

origin: Pray heaven I be deceived in you.
modern: I hope to God I’m wrong about your chances.

origin: Your heart’s desires be with you.
modern: I hope you get what you desire!

origin: You shall try but one fall.
modern: You get only one round.

origin: No, I warrant your Grace you shall not entreat him to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first.
modern: No, I’m sure your Grace won’t be able to persuade him to try a second round, even though you couldn’t dissuade him from trying the first.

origin: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the leg.
modern: You should mock me    I wish I were invisible, so I could grab that strong fellow by the leg.

origin: O excellent young man!
modern: Oh, what an excellent young man!

origin: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who should down.
modern: If I could shoot lightning bolts from my eyes, I can tell you who’d be on the ground.

origin: No more, no more.
modern: No more, no more.

origin: How dost thou, Charles?
modern: How are you doing, Charles?

origin: He cannot speak, my lord.
modern: He can’t speak, my lord.

origin: Bear him away.
modern: Carry him away.

origin: What is thy name, young man?
modern: What is your name, young man?

origin: Orlando, my liege, the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.
modern: Orlando, my lord, the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

origin: I would thou hadst been son to some man else.
modern: I wish you were someone else’s son.

origin: The world esteemed thy father honorable, But I did find him still mine enemy.
modern: The whole world thought your father was an honorable man, but he was always my enemy.

origin: I would thou hadst told me of another father.
modern: I wish you had told me you had a different father.

origin: Were I my father, coz, would I do this?
modern: If I were my father, cousin, would I do this?

origin: I am more proud to be Sir Rowland’s son, His youngest son, and would not change that calling To be adopted heir to Frederick.
modern: I’m proud to be Sir Rowland’s son—his youngest son—and I would never change that, not even to be Frederick’s adopted heir.

origin: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul, And all the world was of my father’s mind.
modern: My father loved Sir Rowland as much as he loved his own soul, and the rest of the world shared my father’s opinion.

origin: Had I before known this young man his son, I should have given him tears unto entreaties Ere he should thus have ventured.
modern: If I had known this young man was his son, I would have tried harder to convince him not to fight.

origin: Gentle cousin, Let us go thank him and encourage him.
modern: Gentle cousin, let’s go thank him and encourage him.

origin: Shall we go, coz?
modern: Yes.

origin: Ay.—Fare you well, fair gentleman.
modern: Good luck, fair gentleman.

origin: He calls us back.
modern: He’s calling us back.

origin: Will you go, coz?
modern: My  Will you come on, cousin?

origin: Have with you.
modern: I’m coming.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Farewell.

origin: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue?
modern: What is this passion that ties up my tongue?

origin: I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference.
modern: I can’t speak to her, even though she asked me to.

origin: Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
modern: Either Charles or some prettier thing has mastered you.

origin: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place.
modern: Good sir, as a friend, I advise you to leave this place.

origin: Albeit you have deserved High commendation, true applause, and love, Yet such is now the duke’s condition That he misconsters all that you have done.
modern: Although you deserve praise, applause, and love, right now the duke misconstrues everything you’ve done.

origin: The duke is humorous.
modern: The duke is temperamental.

origin: But I can tell you that of late this duke Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece, Grounded upon no other argument But that the people praise her for her virtues And pity her for her good father’s sake; And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady Will suddenly break forth.
modern: But I will tell you that lately the duke has been displeased with his niece, and for no other reason than that people praise her virtues and pity her for her father’s sake.

origin: Sir, fare you well.
modern: Goodbye, sir.

origin: Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.
modern: Later, in a better world than this, I’d love to get to know you.

origin: I rest much bounden to you.
modern: I’m indebted to you.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Thus must I from the smoke into the smother, From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother.
modern: Out of the frying pan and into the fire—from a tyrant duke to a tyrant brother!

origin: But heavenly Rosalind!
modern: But, oh, heavenly Rosalind!

origin: Why, Rosalind!
modern: What’s going on, Rosalind?

origin: Not one to throw at a dog.
modern: I don’t even have one to throw at a dog.

origin: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs.
modern: No, your words are too precious to be wasted on dogs.

origin: Throw some of them at me.
modern: Throw some of your words at me.

origin: Then there were two cousins laid up, when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any.
modern: Then there would be two cousins lying sick in bed: one hurt by reasons and the other gone crazy without any.

origin: But is all this for your father?
modern: Is all of this about your father?

origin: No, some of it is for my child’s father.
modern: No, some of it is about my child’s father.

origin: If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.
modern: If we walk on the well-worn paths, they won’t get caught in our petticoats.

origin: Hem them away.
modern: Cough them up.

origin: I would try, if I could cry “hem” and have him.
modern: I’d try it, if I could cry “hem” and have him.

origin: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.
modern: Come on, take control of your feelings.

origin: Oh, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself.
modern: But they’re siding with a better wrestler than myself.

origin: Oh, a good wish upon you.
modern: Oh, that’s a good wish!

origin: The duke my father loved his father dearly.
modern: You’ll fight with him eventually, and  The duke, my father, loved his father very much.

origin: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly?
modern: Does that necessarily mean you should love his son?

origin: By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly.
modern: By that kind of logic, I should hate Orlando, since my father hates his father.

origin: Yet I hate not Orlando.
modern: But I don’t hate Orlando.

origin: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.
modern: No, please don’t hate him—for my sake.

origin: Why should I not?
modern: Why shouldn’t I?

origin: Doth he not deserve well?
modern: Doesn’t he deserve it?

origin: Let me love him for that, and do you love him because I do.
modern: Let me love him because he deserves it, and you can love him because I do.

origin: Look, here comes the duke.
modern: Look, here comes the duke.

origin: With his eyes full of anger.
modern: He looks angry.

origin: Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste, And get you from our court.
modern: Madam, hurry as fast as you can get out of my court.

origin: Me, uncle?
modern: Me, uncle?

origin: You, cousin.
modern: You, niece.

origin: Within these ten days if that thou beest found So near our public court as twenty miles, Thou diest for it.
modern: In ten days time, if you’re found within twenty miles of the court, you’ll die for it.

origin: I do beseech your Grace, Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me.
modern: Please, your Grace, tell me what crime I have committed.

origin: If with myself I hold intelligence Or have acquaintance with mine own desires, If that I do not dream or be not frantic— As I do trust I am not—then, dear uncle, Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your Highness.
modern: If I know my own thoughts and desires, and I’m not dreaming or crazy—which I’m sure I’m not—then, dear uncle, I’ve never had so much as a half-formed thought that would have offended you.

origin: Thus do all traitors.
modern: All traitors protest like this.

origin: If their purgation did consist in words, They are as innocent as grace itself.
modern: If they could purge their guilt simply by saying that they were innocent, they’d all be as innocent as God Himself.

origin: Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.
modern: I don’t trust you.

origin: Thou art thy father’s daughter.
modern: You are your father’s daughter.

origin: There’s enough.
modern: That’s enough.

origin: So was I when your Highness took his dukedom.
modern: I was his daughter when your Highness took my father’s dukedom.

origin: So was I when your Highness banished him.
modern: I was his daughter when you banished him.

origin: My father was no traitor.
modern: My father wasn’t a traitor.

origin: Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much To think my poverty is treacherous.
modern: So, please, my lord, don’t assume that I’m treacherous just because I’m poor, with no titles to my name.

origin: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
modern: Dear master, listen to me.

origin: Ay, Celia, we stayed her for your sake.
modern: Yes, Celia, we kept her here for your sake.

origin: I was too young that time to value her, But now I know her.
modern: I was too young at the time to appreciate her value, but now I know her.

origin: If she be a traitor, Why so am I.
modern: If she’s a traitor, why then, so am I.

origin: Thou art a fool.
modern: You’re a fool.

origin: She robs thee of thy name, And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous When she is gone.
modern: You will seem even brighter and more virtuous when she’s out of the picture.

origin: Then open not thy lips.
modern: So be quiet.

origin: Firm and irrevocable is my doom Which I have passed upon her.
modern: The sentence I’ve passed down on her is firm and unshakeable.

origin: She is banished.
modern: She is banished.

origin: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege.
modern: Then lay that sentence on me too, my lord.

origin: I cannot live out of her company.
modern: I cannot live without her.

origin: You are a fool.—You, niece, provide yourself.
modern: You are a fool.—You, niece, prepare to leave.

origin: If you outstay the time, upon mine honor And in the greatness of my word, you die.
modern: On my honor and by my word, if you outstay the ten days, you will die.

origin: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go?
modern: Oh, my poor Rosalind, where will you go?

origin: Wilt thou change fathers?
modern: Do you want to exchange fathers?

origin: I will give thee mine.
modern: I’ll give you mine.

origin: I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.
modern: I insist, don’t be more distressed than I am.

origin: I have more cause.
modern: I have more reason to be distressed.

origin: Now, sir, what make you here?
modern: Hey, you!

origin: Nothing.
modern: What are you  Nothing.

origin: I am not taught to make anything.
modern: I’ve never been taught how to make anything.

origin: What mar you then, sir?
modern: Well, then, what are you messing up?

origin: Marry, sir, be better employed, and be naught awhile.
modern: I’m helping  Indeed, sir, find something better to do and get lost for a while.

origin: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?
modern: Should I tend your pigs and eat husks with them?

origin: Know you where you are, sir?
modern: When did I  Do you know where you are, sir?

origin: O sir, very well: here in your orchard.
modern: Yes, sir, very well—I’m here in your orchard.

origin: Know you before whom, sir?
modern: Do you know whom you’re talking to?

origin: Ay, better than him I am before knows me.
modern: Yes, better than you know me.

origin: I know you are my eldest brother, and in the gentle condition of blood you should so know me.
modern: I know you’re my oldest brother, and deserve more respect.

origin: I have as much of my father in me as you, albeit, I confess, your coming before me is nearer to his reverence.
modern: I have as much of our father in me as you do, though I admit you’re closer to him and matter more because you’re older.

origin: Thou hast not, cousin.
modern: No you haven’t, cousin.

origin: Prithee, be cheerful.
modern: Please, be cheerful.

origin: Know’st thou not the duke Hath banished me, his daughter?
modern: Don’t you realize the duke has also banished me, his daughter?

origin: That he hath not.
modern: No, he hasn’t.

origin: No, hath not?
modern: Oh, he hasn’t?

origin: Rosalind lacks then the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one.
modern: Well, then, you don’t have the affection that would teach you that you and I are one.

origin: Shall we be sundered?
modern: Will we be separated?

origin: Shall we part, sweet girl?
modern: Should we part, sweet girl?

origin: For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale, Say what thou canst, I’ll go along with thee.
modern: I swear by the heavens, which have grown pale in sympathy with us, I’m going with you, whatever you say.

origin: Why, whither shall we go?
modern: But where will we go?

origin: To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden.
modern: To the Forest of Arden, to find your father.

origin: Alas, what danger will it be to us, Maids as we are, to travel forth so far?
modern: But what danger we’ll put ourselves in, two young, innocent women traveling so far!

origin: Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
modern: Fresh beauty attracts thugs and thieves even more than money.

origin: I’ll put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face.
modern: I’ll put on some poor and ragged clothes and smudge my face with dirt.

origin: Were it not better, Because that I am more than common tall, That I did suit me all points like a man?
modern: Wouldn’t it be better—since I’m unusually tall for a woman—to dress myself like a man?

origin: A gallant curtal-axe upon my thigh, A boar-spear in my hand, and in my heart Lie there what hidden woman’s fear there will, We’ll have a swashing and a martial outside— As many other mannish cowards have That do outface it with their semblances.
modern: I’ll wear a big sword in my belt, carry a boar-spear in my hand, and hide all my womanish fear in my heart.

origin: What shall I call thee when thou art a man?
modern: What should I call you when you’re a man?

origin: I’ll have no worse a name than Jove’s own page, And therefore look you call me Ganymede.
modern: I’ll take no lesser name than that of  Something that refers to my current state.

origin: But what will you be called?
modern: Instead of Celia, call me Aliena.

origin: Would he not be a comfort to our travel?
modern: Wouldn’t he be a comfort to us in our travels?

origin: Leave me alone to woo him.
modern: Let’s go gather our jewels and money.

origin: Let’s away And get our jewels and our wealth together, Devise the fittest time and safest way To hide us from pursuit that will be made After my flight.
modern: We’ll figure out the best time and safest route to avoid being found out by my father’s guards, whom he’ll send out as soon as he discovers I’ve gone.

origin: Now go we in content To liberty, and not to banishment.
modern: Now, we go contentedly to freedom—not banishment.

origin: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?
modern: Now, my companions and brothers in exile, hasn’t experience made this simple life sweeter than a life of glittery pomp and circumstance?

origin: Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court?
modern: Aren’t these woods less perilous than the court, with all its jealousies and intrigues?

origin: These are counselors That feelingly persuade me what I am.” Sweet are the uses of adversity, Which, like the toad, ugly and venomous, Wears yet a precious jewel in his head.
modern: I smile and think, “Thank goodness the wind doesn’t flatter me: it’s like a councilor who makes me feel what I’m really made of.” Adversity can have its benefits—like the ugly, poisonous  I wouldn’t change my situation for anything.

origin: And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
modern: You’re lucky, my lord, to be able to see the peace and sweetness even in what bad luck has brought you.

origin: I would not change it.
modern: Come, shall we hunt some deer for dinner?

origin: Happy is your Grace, That can translate the stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
modern: It bothers me, though, that these poor spotted innocents, who, after all, are this deserted city’s native citizens, should be gouged with arrows.

origin: Come, shall we go and kill us venison?
modern: Indeed, my lord, the gloomy Jaques grieves over these deaths.

origin: And indeed, my lord, The wretched animal heaved forth such groans That their discharge did stretch his leathern coat Almost to bursting, and the big round tears Coursed one another down his innocent nose In piteous chase.
modern: Big, round tears ran piteously down the animal’s innocent nose.

origin: And did you leave him in this contemplation?
modern: And did you leave him like this?

origin: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer.
modern: We did, my lord, weeping and carrying on about the sobbing deer.

origin: Show me the place.
modern: Take me to him.

origin: I love to cope him in these sullen fits, For then he’s full of matter.
modern: I love to argue with him when he’s having one of these fits, because then he always has a lot to say.

origin: I’ll bring you to him straight.
modern: I’ll bring you to him right away.

origin: Can it be possible that no man saw them?
modern: Can it be possible that no one saw them leave?

origin: It cannot be.
modern: It cannot be.

origin: Some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this.
modern: Some villains in my court must have known about this and let it happen.

origin: I cannot hear of any that did see her.
modern: I can’t find anyone who saw her leave.

origin: The ladies, her attendants of her chamber Saw her abed, and in the morning early They found the bed untreasured of their mistress.
modern: Her ladies-in-waiting saw her go to bed, and early this morning the bed was empty.

origin: My lord, the roinish clown, at whom so oft Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
modern: My lord, that dirty clown whom you laughed at so often is also missing.

origin: Send to his brother.
modern: Send a message to his brother.

origin: Fetch that gallant hither.
modern: Bring that swinger Orlando here.

origin: If he be absent, bring his brother to me.
modern: If he’s not around, bring his brother Oliver to me.

origin: I’ll make him find him.
modern: I’ll make Oliver find him.

origin: Do this suddenly, And let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways.
modern: Do this immediately, and don’t stop searching and interrogating until you’ve brought home these foolish runaways.

origin: Who’s there?
modern: Who’s there?

origin: Why, what make you here?
modern: What are you doing here?

origin: Why are you virtuous?
modern: Why are you so strong and good?

origin: Why do people love you?
modern: Why do people love you?

origin: And wherefore are you gentle, strong, and valiant?
modern: And why are you noble, strong, and brave?

origin: Why would you be so fond to overcome The bonny prizer of the humorous duke?
modern: Why would you be so foolish as to beat the moody duke’s favorite champion?

origin: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
modern: Your praise has beaten you home.

origin: Know you not, master, to some kind of men Their graces serve them but as enemies?
modern: Don’t you know, master, that some men’s best qualities do them in?

origin: Oh, what a world is this when what is comely Envenoms him that bears it!
modern: Oh, what a world this is, when even what is beautiful in a man poisons him!

origin: Why, what’s the matter?
modern: Why, what’s the matter?

origin: Within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives.
modern: In this house lives a man who despises all that is good in you.

origin: Your brother—no, no brother—yet the son— Yet not the son, I will not call him son— Of him I was about to call his father Hath heard your praises, and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie, And you within it.
modern: Oliver, your brother—no, not your brother; and yet he’s the son—but no, I won’t call him the son—of that great man I was about to call his father, has heard about how well you did in the wrestling match, and tonight he’s planning on burning your house down, with you in it.

origin: If he fail of that, He will have other means to cut you off.
modern: And if he fails at that, he will find other ways to kill you.

origin: I overheard him and his practices.
modern: I overheard him and his plans.

origin: This is no place, this house is but a butchery.
modern: This is no place for you; this home is now a slaughterhouse.

origin: Abhor it, fear it, do not enter it.
modern: Hate it, fear it, do not come inside.

origin: Why, whither, Adam, wouldst thou have me go?
modern: Then where would you have me go, Adam?

origin: No matter whither, so you come not here.
modern: It doesn’t matter where, so long as it’s not here.

origin: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food, Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce A thievish living on the common road?
modern: What, would you have me beg for my food?

origin: Yet this I will not do, do how I can.
modern: This is all that’s left for me to do, but I won’t do it.

origin: I rather will subject me to the malice Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
modern: I’d rather give myself up to the hatred of a violent brother who refuses to recognize that we are brothers.

origin: But do not so.
modern: But don’t do that.

origin: Let me be your servant.
modern: Let me be your servant.

origin: Though I look old, yet I am strong and lusty, For in my youth I never did apply Hot and rebellious liquors in my blood Nor did not with unbashful forehead woo The means of weakness and debility.
modern: I know I may be old, but I’m strong and healthy, because in my youth I never drank nor lived recklessly.

origin: Therefore my age is as a lusty winter, Frosty but kindly.
modern: Therefore, my old age is like a blustery winter: cold, but kindly.

origin: Let me go with you.
modern: Let me go with you.

origin: I’ll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.
modern: I’ll do everything a younger man could do for you.

origin: O good old man, how well in thee appears The constant service of the antique world, When service sweat for duty, not for meed.
modern: Oh, good old man, you’re a great example of that old work ethic, where people worked because it was their duty, not just for the money.

origin: But come thy ways.
modern: Come along, though.

origin: We’ll go along together, And ere we have thy youthful wages spent, We’ll light upon some settled low content.
modern: We’ll go together, and before we’ve spent all the savings of your youth, we’ll find a way to make a living.

origin: Master, go on, and I will follow thee To the last gasp, with truth and loyalty.
modern: Go on, master, and I will follow you—with truth and loyalty to my last breath.

origin: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here livèd I, but now live here no more.
modern: From the time I was seventeen, over sixty years ago, I have lived in this house, but now I will live here no more.

origin: At seventeen years, many their fortunes seek, But at fourscore, it is too late a week.
modern: Many men seek their fortune at seventeen; at eighty, it’s a bit late.

origin: Yet fortune cannot recompense me better Than to die well, and not my master’s debtor.
modern: But fortune could not reward me better than to let me die well, without owing my master anything.

origin: O Jupiter, how weary are my spirits!
modern: Oh Lord, my spirits are tired!

origin: I care not for my spirits, if my legs were not weary.
modern: I wouldn’t care about my spirits, if my legs weren’t tired.

origin: I cannot go no further.
modern: I can’t go any further.

origin: For my part, I had rather bear with you than bear you.
modern: I’d rather bear with you than  Well, this is the Forest of Arden.

origin: Ay, now am I in Arden, the more fool I.
modern: Yes, now I’m in Arden, and that makes me the bigger fool.

origin: Ay, be so, good Touchstone.
modern: Yes, be content, good Touchstone.

origin: Look you who comes here, a young man and an old in solemn talk.
modern: Look who’s coming: a young man and an old man, having a serious talk.

origin: Wilt thou lay hands on me, villain?
modern: What, you dare put your hands on me, villain?

origin: I am no villain.
modern: I’m no villain.

origin: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so.
modern: If you weren’t my brother, I’d leave this hand of mine on your neck until I’d pulled out your tongue for talking like this.

origin: Thou hast railed on thyself.
modern: You’ve only insulted yourself.

origin: Sweet masters, be patient.
modern: Gentlemen, calm down.

origin: For your father’s remembrance, be at accord.
modern: For the sake of your father’s memory, make peace.

origin: Let me go, I say.
modern: Let me go, I say.

origin: I will not till I please.
modern: I won’t until I’m ready.

origin: You shall hear me.
modern: You will listen to me.

origin: My father charged you in his will to give me good education.
modern: My father instructed you in his will to give me a good education.

origin: You have trained me like a peasant, obscuring and hiding from me all gentlemanlike qualities.
modern: But you’ve raised me as a peasant, hiding from me what I needed to become a gentleman.

origin: The spirit of my father grows strong in me, and I will no longer endure it.
modern: My father’s spirit is growing in me, and I won’t take this any longer.

origin: And what wilt thou do—beg when that is spent?
modern: And what are you going to do after you’ve spent your money?

origin: Well, sir, get you in.
modern: Well, sir, go inside.

origin: I will not long be troubled with you.
modern: I’m not going to be bothered by you for long.

origin: You shall have some part of your will.
modern: You’ll get some of what you want.

origin: I pray you leave me.
modern: Now please leave me alone.

origin: That is the way to make her scorn you still.
modern: What you’re doing is the way to make her scorn you continually.

origin: O Corin, that thou knew’st how I do love her!
modern: Oh, Corin, I wish you could understand how much I love her!

origin: I partly guess, for I have loved ere now.
modern: I’m sure I can guess.

origin: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess, Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.
modern: No Corin, since you’re old, you cannot guess—even if you were as dedicated a lover in your youth as there ever was, sighing and mooning all night long.

origin: But if thy love were ever like to mine— As sure I think did never man love so— How many actions most ridiculous Hast thou been drawn to by thy fantasy?
modern: If your love was anything like mine—and I’m sure that no man has loved as I love now—exactly how many ridiculous actions did your fantasizing lead you to?

origin: Into a thousand that I have forgotten.
modern: Oh, a thousand of them, all of which I’ve forgotten.

origin: Oh, thou didst then ne'er love so heartily.
modern: Oh, then you never loved as wholeheartedly as me.

origin: If thou rememb’rest not the slightest folly That ever love did make thee run into, Thou hast not loved.
modern: If you can’t remember the stupidest little thing love made you do, you haven’t loved.

origin: Or if thou hast not sat as I do now, Wearying thy hearer in thy mistress’s praise, Thou hast not loved.
modern: Or if you haven’t sat as I do now, boring your listener with all your lover’s virtues, then you haven’t loved.

origin: Or if thou hast not broke from company Abruptly, as my passion now makes me, Thou hast not loved.
modern: Or if you haven’t broken away from human company, as my feelings now lead me to do, you haven’t loved.

origin: O Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!
modern: O Phoebe, Phoebe, Phoebe!

origin: Alas, poor shepherd, searching of thy wound, I have by hard adventure found mine own.
modern: Oh, poor shepherd!

origin: And I mine.
modern: Me too.

origin: I remember when I was in love I broke my sword upon a stone and bid him take that for coming a- night to Jane Smile.
modern: I remember when I was in love, I broke my sword on a stone, and told him to take that for coming at night to see Jane Smile.

origin: And I remember the kissing of her batler, and the cow’s dugs that her pretty chopped hands had milked.
modern: I remember kissing her washing stick and the cow’s udders that her pretty, chapped hands had milked.

origin: And I remember the wooing of a peascod instead of her, from whom I took two cods and, giving her them again, said with weeping tears, “Wear these for my sake.” We that are true lovers run into strange capers.
modern: I remember wooing a pea plant in her name, and then taking two pea pods and begging her to wear them “for my sake.” Those of us who are really in love will do the strangest things.

origin: But as all is mortal in nature, so is all nature in love mortal in folly.
modern: But everything that lives is mortal, including the foolishness of love.

origin: Thou speak’st wiser than thou art ware of.
modern: You speak more wisely than you know.

origin: Nay, I shall ne'er be ware of mine own wit till I break my shins against it.
modern: Nah, I’ll never be aware of my own wit, until I break my shins on it.

origin: Jove, Jove, this shepherd’s passion Is much upon my fashion.
modern: By God!

origin: And mine, but it grows something stale with me.
modern: And like mine, but I’m getting a little tired of it.

origin: I pray you, one of you question yond man, if he for gold will give us any food.
modern: Please, one of you go ask that man over there if we can buy some food off him.

origin: Peace, fool.
modern: Shut up, fool.

origin: He’s not thy kinsman.
modern: He’s not your relative.

origin: Who calls?
modern: Who’s calling?

origin: Your betters, sir.
modern: Your superiors.

origin: I prithee, shepherd, if that love or gold Can in this desert place buy entertainment, Bring us where we may rest ourselves and feed.
modern: Please sir, if love or money can buy anything in this empty place, tell us where we can rest and feed ourselves.

origin: Fair sir, I pity her And wish, for her sake more than for mine own, My fortunes were more able to relieve her.
modern: Dear sir, I pity the lady and wish—more for her sake than my own—that I was more able to help her.

origin: But I am shepherd to another man And do not shear the fleeces that I graze.
modern: But I’m a hired hand: I don’t profit from the flocks I tend.

origin: Besides, his cote, his flocks, and bounds of feed Are now on sale, and at our sheepcote now, By reason of his absence, there is nothing That you will feed on.
modern: Besides, his cottage, his flocks, and his grazing rights are on sale now, and since he’s not there, there’s nothing to eat at our house.

origin: What is he that shall buy his flock and pasture?
modern: Who wants to buy the flock and the pasture?

origin: That young swain that you saw here but erewhile, That little cares for buying anything.
modern: That young man who was just here.

origin: I pray thee, if it stand with honesty, Buy thou the cottage, pasture, and the flock, And thou shalt have to pay for it of us.
modern: Please, if you can do it without taking advantage of the young man, buy the cottage, pasture, and flock for us, and we’ll pay you for it.

origin: And we will mend thy wages.
modern: And we will raise your wages.

origin: Assuredly the thing is to be sold.
modern: The thing is definitely going to be sold.

origin: Go with me.
modern: Come with me.

origin: If you like upon report The soil, the profit, and this kind of life, I will your very faithful feeder be And buy it with your gold right suddenly.
modern: If you like what you see of the land, the profit that’s possible, and this rustic life, I’ll be your faithful servant, and buy the place with your gold right away.

origin: More, more, I prithee, more.
modern: More, more, please, more.

origin: It will make you melancholy, Monsieur Jaques.
modern: It’s only going to make you sad, Monsieur Jaques.

origin: I thank it.
modern: I’m glad about that.

origin: More, I prithee, more.
modern: More, please, more.

origin: I can suck melancholy out of a song as a weasel sucks eggs.
modern: I can suck sadness out of a song the way a weasel sucks eggs.

origin: More, I prithee, more.
modern: More, please, more.

origin: My voice is ragged.
modern: My voice is ragged.

origin: I know I cannot please you.
modern: I know I won’t please you.

origin: Come, more, another stanzo.
modern: Come on, another stanza—is that what you call 'em, “stanzas”?

origin: Nay, I care not for their names.
modern: Nah, I don’t care what their

origin: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I’ll thank you.
modern: Well then, if I’ve ever thanked a man, I’ll thank you now.

origin: But that they call “compliment” is like th' encounter of two dog- apes.
modern: But two men complimenting each other is like two baboons getting together.

origin: Well, I’ll end the song.—Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree.—He hath been all this day to look you.
modern: The duke will drink under this tree.—He’s been looking for you all day, you know.

origin: And I have been all this day to avoid him.
modern: And I’ve been avoiding him all day.

origin: He is too disputable for my company.
modern: He’s too argumentative for me.

origin: I think of as many matters as he, but I give heaven thanks and make no boast of them.
modern: I think of as many things as he does, but I just thank heaven and don’t show off about it.

origin: Come, warble, come.
modern: Come, warble for me.

origin: I’ll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
modern: I wrote a verse to this tune, though it’s not very imaginative.

origin: Dear master, I can go no further.
modern: Dear master, I can’t go any farther.

origin: Oh, I die for food.
modern: Oh, I’m dying of hunger.

origin: Here lie I down and measure out my grave.
modern: I’ll lie down here and measure out my grave.

origin: Farewell, kind master.
modern: Farewell, kind master.

origin: Why, how now, Adam?
modern: Hey, what’s this, Adam?

origin: No greater heart in thee?
modern: No braver than this?

origin: Live a little, comfort a little, cheer thyself a little.
modern: Live a little, be comforted a little, cheer up a little.

origin: If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.
modern: If I can find any animal in this wild forest, I’ll either be food for it or bring it as food for you.

origin: Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.
modern: You’re not as close to death as you think you are.

origin: I will here be with thee presently, and if I bring thee not something to eat, I will give thee leave to die.
modern: I’ll be back soon, and if I haven’t brought you anything to eat, I will give you permission to die.

origin: But if thou diest before I come, thou art a mocker of my labor.
modern: But if you die before I return, you’ll have made a mockery of my efforts.

origin: Well said.
modern: There we go!

origin: Thou look’st cheerly, and I’ll be with thee quickly.
modern: You look happier already, and I’ll be back quickly.

origin: Yet thou liest in the bleak air.
modern: But you’re lying out in the cold.

origin: Cheerly, good Adam.
modern: Cheer up, good Adam.

origin: I think he be transformed into a beast, For I can nowhere find him like a man.
modern: I think he must have turned into an animal, because I can’t find him anywhere looking like a man.

origin: My lord, he is but even now gone hence.
modern: My lord, he just left here.

origin: Here was he merry, hearing of a song.
modern: He was happy here, listening to a song.

origin: If he, compact of jars, grow musical, We shall have shortly discord in the spheres.
modern: If that man, who’s made up of conflicts, becomes musical, then there must be something wrong with the universe.

origin: Go seek him.
modern: Go find him.

origin: Tell him I would speak with him.
modern: Tell him I want to speak with him.

origin: He saves my labor by his own approach.
modern: He saved me the trouble: here he comes.

origin: Why, how now, monsieur?
modern: Well, what’s going on, mister?

origin: What a life is this That your poor friends must woo your company?
modern: What kind of life do you lead that your poor friends must beg for your company?

origin: What, you look merrily.
modern: What, you look amused.

origin: And then he drew a dial from his poke And, looking on it with lackluster eye, Says very wisely, “It is ten o'clock.
modern: Then he pulled a watch from his bag and, looking at it solemnly, said, “It’s ten o'clock.

origin: Thus we may see,” quoth he, “how the world wags.
modern: This way, we can see how the world moves.

origin: Tis but an hour ago since it was nine, And after one hour more ’twill be eleven.
modern: Only an hour ago it was nine, and in another hour it will be eleven.

origin: O noble fool!
modern: Oh, noble fool!

origin: A worthy fool!
modern: A worthy fool!

origin: Motley’s the only wear.
modern: Motley is the only thing to wear.

origin: What fool is this?
modern: Who is this fool?

origin: Oh, that I were a fool!
modern: A worthy fool!

origin: God be with my old master.
modern: God bless my old master.

origin: He would not have spoke such a word.
modern: He would never have spoken to me like this.

origin: Is it even so?
modern: Is that how it’s going to be?

origin: Begin you to grow upon me?
modern: Are you starting to challenge me?

origin: I will physic your rankness and yet give no thousand crowns neither.—Holla, Dennis!
modern: I’ll cure you of your insolence, and I’m not going to give you a thousand crowns, either!—Hey, Dennis!

origin: Calls your Worship?
modern: Did you call for me, your Worship?

origin: Was not Charles, the duke’s wrestler, here to speak with me?
modern: Wasn’t Charles, the duke’s wrestler, here to speak with me?

origin: So please you, he is here at the door and importunes access to you.
modern: Yes, sir, he’s here at the door right now and asks to see you.

origin: Call him in.
modern: Call him in.

origin: Twill be a good way, and tomorrow the wrestling is.
modern: I have a good plan.

origin: I must have liberty Withal, as large a charter as the wind, To blow on whom I please, for so fools have.
modern: Like the wind, I must have the freedom to blast anyone I please, as fools do.

origin: And they that are most gallèd with my folly, They most must laugh.
modern: And whoever is most irritated by my foolishness has to laugh the hardest.

origin: And why, sir, must they so?
modern: Why, sir, must he?

origin: The “why” is plain as way to parish church: He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob.
modern: Well, it’s as plain as the beaten path to a parish church.

origin: Invest me in my motley.
modern: Dress me up in motley.

origin: Give me leave To speak my mind, and I will through and through Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world, If they will patiently receive my medicine.
modern: Let me speak my mind, and I’ll rid the world of its sickness—if it will only tolerate my medicine.

origin: Fie on thee!
modern: To hell with you!

origin: I can tell what thou wouldst do.
modern: I know what you’d do.

origin: What, for a counter, would I do but good?
modern: What would I do besides good?

origin: Most mischievous foul sin in chiding sin, For thou thyself hast been a libertine, As sensual as the brutish sting itself, And all th' embossèd sores and headed evils That thou with license of free foot hast caught Wouldst thou disgorge into the general world.
modern: You would be committing a wicked sin by chiding other people for sinning, because you yourself have been a terrible sinner, as carnal in your appetites as lust itself, and all the swollen pustules of sin that you acquired in your freedom you now want to burst and shoot back into the world at large.

origin: Who can come in and say that I mean her, When such a one as she such is her neighbor?
modern: Who can say I mean just her when all her neighbors are exactly like her?

origin: Forbear, and eat no more.
modern: And when some lowlife protests that  Stop, and eat no more.

origin: Why, I have eat none yet.
modern: But I haven’t eaten anything yet.

origin: Nor shalt not till necessity be served.
modern: And you won’t until the needy eat.

origin: Of what kind should this cock come of?
modern: What kind of fighting cock is this?

origin: Art thou thus boldened, man, by thy distress Or else a rude despiser of good manners, That in civility thou seem’st so empty?
modern: Are you acting so boldly from hardship or because you despise good manners?

origin: You touched my vein at first.
modern: You were right the first time.

origin: But forbear, I say.
modern: But stop, I say.

origin: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.
modern: If you won’t listen to reason, I’ll have to die.

origin: What would you have?
modern: What would you like?

origin: Your gentleness shall force More than your force move us to gentleness.
modern: Gentlemanly manners have more sway around here than force does.

origin: I almost die for food, and let me have it.
modern: I’m dying for food, so let me have some.

origin: Sit down and feed, and welcome to our table.
modern: Sit down and eat, and welcome to our table.

origin: Speak you so gently?
modern: Do you really speak like such a gentleman?

origin: Pardon me, I pray you.
modern: I beg your pardon.

origin: I thought that all things had been savage here, And therefore put I on the countenance Of stern commandment.
modern: I thought everything out here was wild, which is why I acted so stern and commanding.

origin: True is it that we have seen better days And have with holy bell been knolled to church, And sat at good men’s feasts and wiped our eyes Of drops that sacred pity hath engendered.
modern: We have in fact seen better days and been summoned to church by the ringing of the holy bell and sat at good men’s feasts and cried tears of pity—therefore, sit down and take whatever will satisfy your needs.

origin: Then but forbear your food a little while Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn And give it food.
modern: Then please, put off your eating for a little while I, like a mother doe, find my fawn and bring it food.

origin: There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love.
modern: There is a poor old man who, purely out of love, has limped after me for miles.

origin: I thank you; and be blessed for your good comfort.
modern: Thank you, and God bless you for your hospitality.

origin: Thou seest we are not all alone unhappy.
modern: You see, we’re not alone in our unhappiness.

origin: All the world’s a stage, And all the men and women merely players.
modern: The whole world is a stage, and all the men and women merely actors.

origin: They have their exits and their entrances, And one man in his time plays many parts, His acts being seven ages.
modern: They have their exits and their entrances, and in his lifetime a man will play many parts, his life separated into seven acts.

origin: At first the infant, Mewling and puking in the nurse’s arms.
modern: In the first act he is an infant, whimpering and puking in his nurse’s arms.

origin: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.
modern: Then he’s the whining schoolboy, with a book bag and a bright, young face, creeping like a snail unwillingly to school.

origin: And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.
modern: He’s full of wise sayings and up-to-the-minute anecdotes: that’s the way he plays his part.

origin: Welcome.
modern: Welcome.

origin: Set down your venerable burden, And let him feed.
modern: Set the honorable old man down and let him eat.

origin: I thank you most for him.
modern: I thank you very much on his behalf.

origin: Welcome.
modern: Welcome.

origin: Fall to.
modern: Eat.
