origin: Saving your merry humor, here’s the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three-odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman.
modern: The total due is about three ducats more than I owe this gentleman.

origin: I pray you, see him presently discharged, For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.
modern: Please, pay him immediately.

origin: I am not furnished with the present money.
modern: I don’t have the cash right now.

origin: Besides, I have some business in the town.
modern: Besides, I have some business to take care of in town.

origin: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself.
modern: So you’ll bring the necklace to her yourself?

origin: Well, sir, I will.
modern: All right, sir, I will.

origin: Have you the chain about you?
modern: Do you have it with you?

origin: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain.
modern: Listen, please, give me the necklace.

origin: Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, And I, to blame, have held him here too long.
modern: The wind is right and it’s high tide, and I’ve delayed him a long time already.

origin: Good Lord!
modern: Good Lord!

origin: You use this dalliance to excuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine.
modern: You’re using this as an excuse for not showing up at the Porcupine like you promised.

origin: I should have chid you for not bringing it, But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.
modern: I should have reprimanded you then for not bringing it, but you started fighting with me first.

origin: The hour steals on.
modern: It’s getting late.

origin: I pray you, sir, dispatch.
modern: Please, sir, hurry up.

origin: You hear how he importunes me.
modern: Antipholus, you hear how the man pleads with me.

origin: The chain!
modern: Give me the necklace!

origin: Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.
modern: Give it to my wife, and get your money.

origin: Come, come.
modern: Come, come.

origin: You know I gave it you even now.
modern: You know I gave it to you just now.

origin: Either send the chain, or send me by some token.
modern: Send the necklace to her, or send me with a token that will authorize her to pay me.

origin: Fie, now you run this humor out of breath.
modern: Damn it, this isn’t funny.

origin: Come, where’s the chain?
modern: Where’s the necklace?

origin: I pray you, let me see it.
modern: Let me see it.

origin: I answer you?
modern: Pay you?

origin: What should I answer you?
modern: What should I pay you?

origin: The money that you owe me for the chain.
modern: The money you owe me for the necklace.

origin: I owe you none till I receive the chain.
modern: I owe you nothing until I receive the necklace.

origin: You know I gave it you half an hour since.
modern: You know that I gave it to you a half hour ago.

origin: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it.
modern: You wrong me even more, sir, by denying it.

origin: Consider how it stands upon my credit.
modern: Consider how poorly this reflects on me.

origin: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.
modern: I will.

origin: I do,  This touches me in reputation.
modern: This harms my reputation.

origin: Consent to pay thee that I never had?— Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar’st.
modern: Pay for something I never got?

origin: Here is thy fee.
modern: Go ahead, you fool.

origin: Arrest him, officer.
modern: Arrest me if you dare.

origin: I would not spare my brother in this case If he should scorn me so apparently.
modern: I would have my own brother arrested if he treated me so terribly.

origin: I do arrest you, sir.
modern: You’re under arrest, sir.

origin: You hear the suit.
modern: You hear the charges.

origin: I do obey thee till I give thee bail.
modern: I’ll obey you until I can make bail.

origin: But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer.
modern: But Angelo, you’ll pay for this, even if it costs all the precious metals in your jewelry shop.

origin: Sir, sir, I will have law in Ephesus, To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.
modern: Sir, the laws of Ephesus will be on my side, and you’ll be embarrassed.

origin: Nay, forward, old man.
modern: No, keep going, old man; don’t stop like that.

origin: Do not break off so, For we may pity though not pardon thee.
modern: For we may take pity on you, even if we can’t pardon you.

origin: O, had the gods done so, I had not now Worthily termed them merciless to us.
modern: Had the gods taken pity on us, I wouldn’t be here calling them merciless.

origin: Thus have you heard me severed from my bliss; That by misfortunes was my life prolonged To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.
modern: It’s been my bad luck to remain alive long enough to be able to tell the sad stories of my own misfortunes.

origin: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for, Do me the favour to dilate at full What hath befall'n of them and thee till now.
modern: And for the sake of those you grieve for, do me a favor: tell me the full story of what has happened to you and them, up to this point.

origin: Our fraughtage, sir, I have conveyed aboard, and I have bought The oil, the balsamum and aqua vitae.
modern: I’ve left our luggage on the ship, and I bought the oil, balm, and liquor you wanted.

origin: Why, thou peevish sheep, What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?
modern: You annoying idiot, what Epidamnum ship is waiting for me?

origin: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.
modern: A ship you sent me to find, to book passage out of here.

origin: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope And told thee to what purpose and what end.
modern: You drunken slave, I sent you for a rope, and I told you what to do with it.

origin: You sent me for a rope’s end as soon.
modern: Yeah, right—you sent me to get whipped.

origin: You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.
modern: You sent me to the port to find a ship.

origin: I will debate this matter at more leisure And teach your ears to list me with more heed.
modern: I’ll debate this with you later, and then I’ll teach you to listen more carefully.

origin: To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight.
modern: Go to Adriana, you scoundrel, and quickly.

origin: Give her this key, and tell her in the desk That’s cover’d o'er with Turkish tapestry There is a purse of ducats.
modern: Give her this key, and tell her that there’s money in the desk that’s covered with a Turkish tapestry.

origin: Let her send it.
modern: Have her send it to me.

origin: Tell her I am arrested in the street, And that shall bail me.
modern: Tell her that I’ve been arrested and the money will be my bail.

origin: Hie thee, slave.
modern: Hurry, you slave!

origin: Begone.— On, officer, to prison till it come.
modern: Go!

origin: To Adriana.
modern: To Adriana?

origin: That is where we dined, Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband.
modern: Where that “sweetheart” said I was her husband!

origin: She is too big, I hope, for me to compass.
modern: She’s too much for me to handle.

origin: Thither I must, although against my will, For servants must their masters' minds fulfill.
modern: But I must go there, against my will: servants must fulfill their masters' wishes.

origin: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so?
modern: Oh, Luciana, did he tempt you like that?

origin: Looked he or red or pale, or sad or merrily?
modern: Sad or happy?

origin: First he denied you had in him no right.
modern: First, he said you had no right to him.

origin: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
modern: He meant he did nothing right for me—which is true, unfortunately.

origin: Then swore he that he was a stranger here.
modern: Then he swore he was a stranger here.

origin: Then pleaded I for you.
modern: And that’s true—he  Then I pleaded for you.

origin: And what said he?
modern: And what did he say?

origin: That love i begged for you he begged of me.
modern: That he felt for me the love that I begged him to feel for you.

origin: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?
modern: How did he try to persuade you to love him?

origin: Have patience, I beseech.
modern: Have some patience, please.

origin: Who would be jealous, then, of such a one?
modern: Then why be jealous of a person like that?

origin: No evil lost is wailed when it is gone.
modern: When an evil thing has been lost, no one cries.

origin: Ah, but I think him better than I say, And yet would herein others' eyes were worse.
modern: Oh, but I think of him more highly than I say I do—and I wish he looked worse in other women’s eyes.

origin: My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.
modern: My heart adores him, even though my tongue curses him.

origin: How hast thou lost thy breath?
modern: How did you lose your breath?

origin: By running fast.
modern: By running fast.

origin: Where is thy master, Dromio?
modern: Where’s your master, Dromio?

origin: Is he well?
modern: Is he all right?

origin: No, he’s in Tartar limbo, worse than hell.
modern: No, he’s in a place worse than hell.

origin: The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands; A hound that runs counter and yet draws dryfoot well, One that before the judgment carries poor souls to hell.
modern: A backbiting friend, one who grabs people, who patrols the streets and passageways.

origin: Why, man, what is the matter?
modern: Speak, man, what’s the matter?

origin: Tell me at whose suit.
modern: Tell me, who had him arrested?

origin: I know not at whose suit he is arrested well, But he’s in a suit of buff which ’rested him; that can I tell.
modern: I don’t know who had him arrested, but the man that arrested him was in a suit of leather.

origin: Go fetch it, sister.
modern: Get it, sister.

origin: This I wonder at, That he, unknown to me, should be in debt.
modern: How could he be in debt without me knowing it?

origin: Do you not hear it ring?
modern: Don’t you hear it ring?

origin: What, the chain?
modern: What, the necklace?

origin: No, no, the bell.
modern: No, no, the bell.

origin: Tis time that I were gone.
modern: It’s time for me to go.

origin: It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.
modern: It was two o'clock when I left him, and now it’s one.

origin: That did I never hear.
modern: I’ve never heard of that.

origin: Excellent well.
modern: Of course.

origin: You are a fishmonger.
modern: You sell fish.

origin: Not I, my lord.
modern: No, not me, sir.

origin: Then I would you were so honest a man.
modern: In that case I wish you were as good a man as a fish seller.

origin: Honest, my lord?
modern: Good, sir?

origin: Ay, sir.
modern: Yes, sir.

origin: To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.
modern: Only one man in ten thousand is good in this world.

origin: That’s very true, my lord.
modern: That’s definitely true, my lord.

origin: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion— Have you a daughter?
modern: Since if the sun breeds maggots on a dead dog, kissing the corpse—by the way, do you have a daughter?

origin: I have, my lord.
modern: I do indeed, my lord.

origin: Let her not walk i' th' sun.
modern: Then by all means never let her walk in public.

origin: Conception is a blessing, but, as your daughter may conceive—Friend, look to ’t.
modern: Procreation is a good thing, but if your daughter gets pregnant … look out, friend.

origin: Words, words, words.
modern: A lot of words.

origin: What is the matter, my lord?
modern: And what is the subject?

origin: Between who?
modern: Between whom?

origin: I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.
modern: I mean, what do the words say?

origin: Slanders, sir.
modern: Oh, just lies, sir.

origin: Into my grave.
modern: Into my grave.

origin: Indeed, that is out of the air.
modern: Well, that’s certainly out of this world, all right.

origin: You cannot, sir, take from me any thing that I will more willingly part withal—except my life, except my life, except my life.
modern: You can’t take anything from me that I care less about—except my life, except my life, except my life.

origin: Fare you well, my lord.
modern: Good-bye, my lord.

origin: You go to seek the Lord Hamlet.
modern: You’re looking for Lord Hamlet.

origin: There he is.
modern: He’s right over there.

origin: God save you, sir!
modern: Thank you, sir.

origin: My honored lord!
modern: My lord!

origin: My most dear lord!
modern: My dear sir!

origin: My excellent good friends!
modern: Ah, my good old friends!

origin: How dost thou, Guildenstern?
modern: How are you, Guildenstern?

origin: Ah, Rosencrantz!
modern: And Rosencrantz!

origin: Good lads, how do you both?
modern: Boys, how are you both doing?

origin: Happy, in that we are not overhappy.
modern: Happy that we’re not too happy, lucky in being not too lucky.

origin: On Fortune’s cap we are not the very button.
modern: But you’re not down and out, either, are you?

origin: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favors?
modern: So you’re around Lady Luck’s waist?

origin: Faith, her privates we.
modern: Yes, we’re the privates in her army.

origin: What news?
modern: Anyway, what’s up?

origin: But your news is not true.
modern: But you’re wrong.

origin: Let me question more in particular.
modern: Let me ask you a particular question.

origin: What have you, my good friends, deserved at the hands of fortune that she sends you to prison hither?
modern: What crimes have you committed to be sent here to this prison?

origin: Prison, my lord?
modern: Prison, my lord?

origin: Denmark’s a prison.
modern: Denmark’s a prison.

origin: Then is the world one.
modern: Then I guess the whole world is one.

origin: A goodly one, in which there are many confines, wards, and dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst.
modern: Yes, quite a large one, with many cells and dungeons, Denmark being one of the worst.

origin: We think not so, my lord.
modern: We don’t think so, my lord.

origin: Why, then, ’tis none to you, for there is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
modern: Well, then it isn’t one to you, since nothing is really good or bad in itself—it’s all what a person thinks about it.

origin: To me it is a prison.
modern: And to me, Denmark is a prison.

origin: Why then, your ambition makes it one.
modern: That must be because you’re so ambitious.

origin: Tis too narrow for your mind.
modern: It’s too small for your large mind.

origin: Which dreams indeed are ambition, for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
modern: Dreams are a sign of ambition, since ambition is nothing more than the shadow of a dream.

origin: A dream itself is but a shadow.
modern: But a dream itself is just a shadow.

origin: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow’s shadow.
modern: In fact, I consider ambition to be so light and airy that it’s only the shadow of a shadow.

origin: Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretched heroes the beggars' shadows.
modern: Then I guess beggars are the ones with bodies, while ambitious kings and heroes are just the shadows of beggars.

origin: Shall we to th' court?
modern: Should we go inside?

origin: Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I thank you, and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny.
modern: Well, then, I thank you, though I’m such a beggar that even my thanks are not worth much.

origin: Is it your own inclining?
modern: Or was it just your whim, on your own initiative?

origin: What should we say, my lord?
modern: What should we say, my lord?

origin: You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color.
modern: You were sent for.

origin: I know the good king and queen have sent for you.
modern: I know the king and queen sent for you.

origin: To what end, my lord?
modern: Why would they do that, my lord?

origin: That you must teach me.
modern: That’s what I want you to tell me.

origin: My lord, we were sent for.
modern: My lord, we were sent for.

origin: What might be toward, that this sweaty haste Doth make the night joint laborer with the day?
modern: Is something about to happen that warrants working this night and day?

origin: Who is ’t that can inform me?
modern: Who can explain this to me?

origin: That can I.
modern: I can.

origin: I will tell you why.
modern: Or at least I can describe the rumors.

origin: Why did you laugh then, when I said “man delights not me”?
modern: So why did you laugh when I said that men don’t interest me?

origin: He that plays the king shall be welcome.
modern: The one who plays the part of the king will be particularly welcome.

origin: The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target, the lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous man shall end his part in peace, the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o' th' sear, and the lady shall say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt for ’t.
modern: The adventurous knight will wave around his sword and shield, the lover will be rewarded for his sighs, the crazy character can rant all he wants, the clown will make everybody laugh, and the lady character can say whatever’s on her mind, or I’ll stop the play.

origin: What players are they?
modern: Which troupe is it?

origin: Even those you were wont to take delight in, the tragedians of the city.
modern: The tragic actors from the city, the ones you used to enjoy so much.

origin: How chances it they travel?
modern: What are they doing on the road?

origin: Their residence, both in reputation and profit, was better both ways.
modern: They made more money and got more attention in the city.

origin: I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.
modern: But things have changed there, and it’s easier for them on the road now.

origin: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the city?
modern: Are they as popular as they used to be when I lived in the city?

origin: Are they so followed?
modern: Do they attract big audiences?

origin: No, indeed are they not.
modern: No, not like before.

origin: How comes it?
modern: Why?

origin: Do they grow rusty?
modern: Are they getting rusty?

origin: Nay, their endeavor keeps in the wonted pace.
modern: No, they’re busy and as excellent as ever.

origin: But there is, sir, an eyrie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top of question and are most tyrannically clapped for ’t.
modern: The problem is that they have to compete with a group of children who yell out their lines and receive outrageous applause for it.

origin: These are now the fashion, and so berattle the common stages—so they call them—that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.
modern: These child actors are now in fashion, and they’ve so overtaken the public theaters that society types hardly come at all, they’re so afraid of being mocked by the playwrights who write for the boys.

origin: What, are they children?
modern: What, you mean kid actors?

origin: Who maintains 'em?
modern: Who takes care of them?

origin: How are they escoted?
modern: Who pays their way?

origin: Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing?

modern: Who would choose to grunt and sweat through an exhausting life, unless they were afraid of something dreadful after death, the undiscovered country from which no visitor returns, which we wonder about without getting any answers from and which makes us stick to the evils we know rather than rush off to seek the ones we don’t?

origin: Oh, treble woe Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head, Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense Deprived thee of!
modern: Oh, damn three times, damn ten times the evil man whose wicked deed deprived you of your ingenious mind.

origin: Hold off the earth awhile Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
modern: Hold off burying her until I’ve caught her in my arms once more.

origin: Hold off thy hand.
modern: That’s no way to pray.

origin: Pluck them asunder.
modern: Pull them apart.

origin: O my son, what theme?
modern: Oh, my son, what issue is that?

origin: I loved Ophelia.
modern: I loved Ophelia.

origin: Forty thousand brothers Could not with all their quantity of love Make up my sum.
modern: Forty thousand brothers, if you added all their love together, couldn’t match mine.

origin: What wilt thou do for her?
modern: What are you going to do for her?

origin: O, he is mad, Laertes.
modern: Oh, he’s crazy, Laertes!

origin: For love of God, forbear him.
modern: For the love of God, be patient with him.

origin: Swounds, show me what thou'lt do.
modern: Damn it, show me what you’re going to do for her.

origin: Woo’t weep?
modern: Will you cry?

origin: Woo’t fight?
modern: Fight?

origin: Woo’t fast?
modern: Stop eating?

origin: Woo’t tear thyself?
modern: Cut yourself?

origin: I’ll do ’t.
modern: I’ll do all that.

origin: And if thou prate of mountains let them throw Millions of acres on us, till our ground, Singeing his pate against the burning zone, Make Ossa like a wart!
modern: And if you rattle on about mountains, then let them throw millions of acres over us.

origin: This is mere madness.
modern: This is pure insanity.

origin: And thus a while the fit will work on him.
modern: He’ll be like this for a little while.

origin: Anon, as patient as the female dove When that her golden couplets are disclosed, His silence will sit drooping.
modern: Then he’ll be as calm and quiet as a dove waiting for her eggs to hatch.

origin: I loved you ever.
modern: I always loved you.

origin: But it is no matter.
modern: But it doesn’t matter.

origin: I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him.
modern: Please, Horatio, go with him.

origin: Who’s there?
modern: Who’s there?

origin: Long live the king!
modern: No, who are  Long live the king!

origin: Barnardo?
modern: Is that Barnardo?

origin: He.
modern: Yes, it’s me.

origin: You come most carefully upon your hour.
modern: You’ve come right on time.

origin: Tis now struck twelve.
modern: The clock’s just striking twelve.

origin: Get thee to bed, Francisco.
modern: Go home to bed, Francisco.

origin: For this relief much thanks.
modern: Thanks for letting me go.

origin: Tis bitter cold, And I am sick at heart.
modern: It’s bitterly cold out, and I’m depressed.

origin: Have you had quiet guard?
modern: Has it been a quiet night?

origin: Not a mouse stirring.
modern: I haven’t even heard a mouse squeak.

origin: Well, good night.
modern: Well, good night.

origin: If you do meet Horatio and Marcellus, The rivals of my watch, bid them make haste.
modern: If you happen to see Horatio and Marcellus, who are supposed to stand guard with me tonight, tell them to hurry.

origin: I think I hear them.—Stand, ho!
modern: I think I hear them.

origin: So much for this, sir.
modern: That’s enough about that.

origin: Now shall you see the other.
modern: Now I’ll tell you the other story about my journey.

origin: You do remember all the circumstance?
modern: Do you remember the circumstances?

origin: Remember it, my lord?
modern: How could I forget, my lord!

origin: Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting That would not let me sleep.
modern: There was a kind of war in my brain that wouldn’t let me sleep.

origin: Methought I lay Worse than the mutines in the bilboes.
modern: It was worse than being a captive in chains.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is it possible?

origin: I beseech you.
modern: Yes, please tell me.

origin: Wilt thou know Th' effect of what I wrote?
modern: Do you want to know what I wrote?

origin: Ay, good my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: I had my father’s signet in my purse, Which was the model of that Danish seal.
modern: I had my father’s signet ring in my pocket, with the royal seal of Denmark on it.

origin: Folded the writ up in form of th' other, Subscribed it, gave ’t th' impression, placed it safely, The changeling never known.
modern: I folded up the new document, signed it, sealed it, and put it safely back so that no one noticed any difference.

origin: Now, the next day Was our sea fight, and what to this was sequent Thou know’st already.
modern: The next day we had our fight at sea, and you know what happened after that.

origin: So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to ’t.
modern: So Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are in for it.

origin: Why, man, they did make love to this employment.
modern: Man, they were asking for it.

origin: They are not near my conscience.
modern: I don’t feel guilty about them at all.

origin: Their defeat Does by their own insinuation grow.
modern: They got what they deserved.

origin: Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes Between the pass and fell incensèd points Of mighty opposites.
modern: It’s always dangerous when little people get caught in the crossfire of mighty opponents.

origin: Why, what a king is this!
modern: What a king Claudius is!

origin: is ’t not perfect conscience To quit him with this arm?
modern: Isn’t it completely moral to kill him now with this sword—and an easy conscience?

origin: And is ’t not to be damned To let this canker of our nature come In further evil?
modern: And wouldn’t I be damned if I let this monster live to do more harm?

origin: It must be shortly known to him from England What is the issue of the business there.
modern: He’ll find out soon what happened in England.

origin: It will be short.
modern: Soon enough.

origin: The interim’s mine.
modern: But I have the meantime.

origin: I’ll court his favors.
modern: I’ll be nice to him.

origin: But sure the bravery of his grief did put me Into a towering passion.
modern: It was just that the showiness of his grief sent me into a fury.

origin: Peace.—Who comes here?
modern: Hang on a minute—who are you?

origin: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
modern: Welcome back to Denmark, my lord.

origin: I humbly thank you, sir.
modern: Thank you kindly, sir.

origin: Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from His Majesty.
modern: My lord, if you have a free moment, I have a message from His Majesty.

origin: I thank your lordship.
modern: No thank you, my lord.

origin: It is very hot.
modern: It’s very hot.

origin: It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.
modern: It is rather cold, indeed, my lord.

origin: But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my complexion.
modern: And yet I feel it’s very hot and humid, which is bad for my complexion.

origin: Exceedingly, my lord.
modern: Yes indeed it is, sir.

origin: It is very sultry—as ’twere—I cannot tell how.
modern: Very humid, I can’t tell you how humid it is.

origin: My lord, his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head.
modern: My lord, His Majesty wanted me to tell you that he’s placed a large bet on you.

origin: Sir, this is the matter—  I beseech you, remember— Nay, good my lord, for mine ease, in good faith.
modern: This is what it’s all about— Please, I beg you— No, my lord, I’m comfortable like this, thank you.

origin: Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you, though I know to divide him inventorially would dizzy th' arithmetic of memory, and yet but yaw neither, in respect of his quick sail.
modern: Sir, your description of him doesn’t detract from his good qualities, though I know that trying to list them all would make your head spin, and even so you wouldn’t be able to keep up with him.

origin: A truant disposition, good my lord.
modern: I felt like skipping school, sir.

origin: I would not hear your enemy say so, Nor shall you do mine ear that violence, To make it truster of your own report Against yourself.
modern: I wouldn’t allow your enemies to say that, and I won’t believe it from you.

origin: I know you are no truant.
modern: I know you’d never skip school.

origin: But what is your affair in Elsinore?
modern: What are you doing here in Elsinore?

origin: We’ll teach you to drink deep ere you depart.
modern: I’ll teach you to drink hard by the time you leave.

origin: My lord, I came to see your father’s funeral.
modern: Sir, we came to see your father’s funeral.

origin: I pray thee, do not mock me, fellow student.
modern: Please, don’t make fun of me.

origin: I think it was to see my mother’s wedding.
modern: I think you came to see my mother’s wedding instead.

origin: Indeed, my lord, it followed hard upon.
modern: Well, sir, it’s true it came soon after.

origin: The funeral baked meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables.
modern: The leftovers from the funeral dinner made a convenient wedding banquet.

origin: Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio.
modern: Oh, I’d rather have met my fiercest enemy in heaven, Horatio, than have lived through that terrible day!

origin: My father—methinks I see my father.
modern: My father—I think I see my father.

origin: Where, my lord?
modern: Where, sir?

origin: In my mind’s eye, Horatio.
modern: In my imagination, Horatio.

origin: I saw him once.
modern: I saw him once.

origin: He was a goodly king.
modern: He was an admirable king.

origin: He was a man.
modern: He was a great human being.

origin: Take him for all in all.
modern: He was perfect in everything.

origin: I shall not look upon his like again.
modern: I’ll never see the likes of him again.

origin: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.
modern: You speak absolutely correctly, sir.

origin: The concernancy, sir?
modern: And what’s the point, sir?

origin: Why do we wrap the gentleman in our more rawer breath?
modern: Why are we talking about him like this?

origin: Sir?
modern: Sorry, sir?

origin: I know you are not ignorant— I would you did, sir.
modern: I know you know something— Thanks for the compliment, I’m happy you know that.

origin: Yet in faith, if you did, it would not much approve me.
modern: But in fact it doesn’t say much.

origin: Well, sir?
modern: I’m sorry, you were saying?

origin: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is—
modern: I know you know something about how excellent Laertes is—

origin: I dare not confess that lest I should compare with him in excellence, but to know a man well were to know himself.
modern: I can’t admit that, since you’d have to compare his excellence to mine.

origin: I mean, sir, for his weapon.
modern: Excellent in fencing, I mean, sir.

origin: Rapier and dagger.
modern: The rapier and the dagger.

origin: That’s two of his weapons.
modern: Those are only two of his weapons.

origin: But well.
modern: But, go on.

origin: The king, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary horses, against the which he has impawned, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards with their assigns—as girdle, hangers, and so.
modern: The king has bet six Barbary horses, and he has prepared six French rapiers and daggers with all their accessories.

origin: Three of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.
modern: Three of the carriages are very imaginatively designed, and they match the fencing accessories.

origin: What call you the carriages?
modern: What do you mean by “carriages”?

origin: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.
modern: The carriages, sir, are the hangers—where the swords hang.

origin: The phrase would be more germane to the matter if we could carry cannon by our sides.
modern: Carriage” makes it sound like it’s pulling around a cannon.

origin: I would it might be hangers till then.
modern: I prefer to call it a “hanger.” But anyway.

origin: But, on: six Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages—that’s the French bet against the Danish.
modern: Six Barbary horses, six French swords with accessories, and three imaginatively designed carriages—sounds like a French bet against the Danish.

origin: Why is this “impawned,” as you call it?
modern: Why has all this been put on the table?

origin: The king, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits.
modern: The king, sir, has bet that in a dozen rounds between you and Laertes, he won’t beat you by more than three hits.

origin: How if I answer “No”?
modern: But what if my answer’s no?

origin: If it please His Majesty, ’tis the breathing time of day with me.
modern: It’s my exercise time.

origin: I commend my duty to your lordship.
modern: My services are at your command.

origin: Yours, yours.
modern: Thank you.

origin: He does well to commend it himself.
modern: It’s a good thing he’s here to recommend himself.

origin: There are no tongues else for ’s turn.
modern: No one else would.

origin: He did comply, sir, with his dug before he sucked it.
modern: He used to praise his mother’s nipple before he sucked it.

origin: He sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time.
modern: The king wishes to know if you want to play against him right away, or wait awhile.

origin: I am constant to my purpose.
modern: I’ll do whatever the king wants.

origin: They follow the king’s pleasure.
modern: If he’s ready now, so am I.

origin: If his fitness speaks, mine is ready, now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.
modern: Otherwise, I’ll do it anytime, as long as I’m able.

origin: The king and queen and all are coming down.
modern: The king and queen are coming down with everyone else.

origin: In happy time.
modern: Right on cue.

origin: The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to Laertes before you fall to play.
modern: The queen wants you to chat with Laertes—politely—before you begin your match.

origin: She well instructs me.
modern: She’s full of good advice.

origin: You will lose this wager, my lord.
modern: You’re going to lose this bet, my lord.

origin: I do not think so.
modern: I don’t think so.

origin: Since he went into France, I have been in continual practice.
modern: I’ve been practicing fencing constantly since he went off to France.

origin: I shall win at the odds.
modern: With the handicap they’ve given me, I think I’ll win.

origin: But thou wouldst not think how ill all’s here about my heart.
modern: But I have a sinking feeling anyway.

origin: But it is no matter.
modern: Oh well.

origin: I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.
modern: I’ll say you’re not feeling well.

origin: Not a whit.
modern: You’ll do no such thing.

origin: We defy augury.
modern: I thumb my nose at superstitions.

origin: If it be not to come, it will be now.
modern: What’s important is to be prepared.

origin: Since no man of aught he leaves knows, what is ’t to leave betimes?
modern: Since nobody knows anything about what he leaves behind, then what does it mean to leave early?

origin: Let be.
modern: Let it be.

origin: Come, Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me.
modern: Come shake hands with Laertes, Hamlet.

origin: But in my terms of honor I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement Till by some elder masters, of known honor, I have a voice and precedent of peace To keep my name ungored.
modern: I will accept no apology until experts in matters of honor show me how to make peace with you without staining my own reputation in doing so.

origin: Come, one for me.
modern: Yes, hand me one too.

origin: I’ll be your foil, Laertes.
modern: I’m going to make you look sharp, Laertes.

origin: You mock me, sir.
modern: You’re making fun of me.

origin: No, by this hand.
modern: No, I swear I’m not.

origin: Very well, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord, quite well.

origin: Your grace hath laid the odds o' th' weaker side.
modern: You’ve bet on the weaker fencer.

origin: I have seen you both.
modern: I’ve seen both of you fence.

origin: But since he is better we have therefore odds.
modern: But since Laertes is better, we’ve given him a handicap.

origin: Ay, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
modern: Put the goblets of wine on that table.

origin: If Hamlet give the first or second hit Or quit in answer of the third exchange, Let all the battlements their ordnance fire!
modern: If Hamlet makes the first or second hit, or gets back at Laertes by making the third hit, then let my soldiers give him a military salute.

origin: The king shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath, And in the cup an union shall he throw Richer than that which four successive kings In Denmark’s crown have worn.
modern: I’ll drink to Hamlet’s health, and into his goblet I’ll drop a pearl even more costly than those in the crowns of the last four Danish kings.

origin: Give me the cups.
modern: Give me the goblets.

origin: Come on, sir.
modern: Come on, sir.

origin: Come, my lord.
modern: Come on, my lord.

origin: One.
modern: That was one hit.

origin: No.
modern: No, it wasn’t.

origin: Judgment?
modern: Referee!

origin: A hit, a very palpable hit.
modern: It was obviously a hit.

origin: Well, again.
modern: Well, let’s go on.

origin: Stay, give me drink.—Hamlet, this pearl is thine.
modern: Give me a goblet.—Hamlet, this pearl’s yours.

origin: Here’s to thy health.
modern: Here’s to your health.

origin: Give him the cup.
modern: Give him the goblet.

origin: Set it by a while.
modern: Set it down awhile.

origin: Come.
modern: Let’s play.

origin: Another hit.
modern: Another hit.

origin: What say you?
modern: What do you say?

origin: A touch, a touch, I do confess ’t.
modern: You got me, I admit it.

origin: Our son shall win.
modern: My son will win.

origin: He’s fat, and scant of breath.— Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows.
modern: He’s flabby and out of breath.—Here, Hamlet, take my handkerchief and wipe your forehead.

origin: The queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.
modern: The queen drinks to your good luck and happiness, Hamlet.

origin: Good madam.
modern: Thank you, madam.

origin: Gertrude, do not drink.
modern: Gertrude, don’t drink that.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: Excuse me.

origin: I pray you, pardon me.
modern: I’ll drink it if I like.

origin: I dare not drink yet, madam.
modern: I’d better not drink now.

origin: By and by.
modern: I’ll drink later.

origin: Come, let me wipe thy face.
modern: Come on, let me wipe your face.

origin: I do not think ’t.
modern: I doubt it.

origin: Come, for the third, Laertes.
modern: Get ready for the third hit, Laertes.

origin: You do but dally.
modern: You’re just playing around.

origin: I pray you, pass with your best violence.
modern: Come on, give me your best shot.

origin: I am afeard you make a wanton of me.
modern: I sense you’re treating me like a child.

origin: Say you so?
modern: You think so?

origin: Come on.
modern: Come on.

origin: Have at you now!
modern: Take this!

origin: Part them!
modern: Separate them.

origin: They are incensed.
modern: They’re overdoing it.

origin: Nay, come, again.
modern: No, come on, one more time.

origin: Look to the queen there, ho!
modern: Take care of the queen!

origin: They bleed on both sides.—How is it, my lord?
modern: Both fencers are bleeding—how do you feel, my lord?

origin: How is ’t, Laertes?
modern: How do you feel, Laertes?

origin: Why, as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric.
modern: Like a mouse caught in my own trap, Osric.

origin: How does the queen?
modern: How’s the queen?

origin: She swoons to see them bleed.
modern: She fainted at the sight of them bleeding.

origin: The drink, the drink!
modern: The drink, the drink!

origin: I am poisoned.
modern: I’ve been poisoned.

origin: O villainy!
modern: Oh, what evil!

origin: Ho, let the door be locked.
modern: Lock the door.

origin: Treachery!
modern: We’ve been betrayed!

origin: Seek it out.
modern: Find out who did it!

origin: It is here, Hamlet.
modern: I’m the one, Hamlet.

origin: Hamlet, thou art slain.
modern: Hamlet, you’re dead.

origin: No medicine in the world can do thee good.
modern: No medicine in the world can cure you.

origin: In thee there is not half an hour of life.
modern: You don’t have more than half an hour to live.

origin: The treacherous instrument is in thy hand, Unbated and envenomed.
modern: The treacherous weapon is right in your hand, sharp and dipped in poison.

origin: The foul practice Hath turned itself on me.
modern: The foul plan backfired on me.

origin: Lo, here I lie, Never to rise again.
modern: Here I lie and will never get up again.

origin: Thy mother’s poisoned.
modern: Your mother’s been poisoned.

origin: I can no more.
modern: I can’t speak anymore.

origin: The king, the king’s to blame.
modern: The king, the king’s to blame.

origin: The point envenomed too!—Then, venom, to thy work.
modern: Then get to work, poison!

origin: My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
modern: Sir, I think I saw him last night.

origin: Saw who?
modern: Saw who?

origin: The king my father?!
modern: The king my father?!

origin: Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear, till I may deliver, Upon the witness of these gentlemen, This marvel to you.
modern: Just listen carefully while I tell you the amazing thing I saw, with these gentlemen as witnesses.

origin: For God’s love, let me hear.
modern: For God’s sake, let me hear it.

origin: Two nights together had these gentlemen, Marcellus and Barnardo, on their watch, In the dead waste and middle of the night, Been thus encountered: a figure like your father, Armed at point exactly, cap-à-pie, Appears before them and with solemn march Goes slow and stately by them.
modern: After midnight, for two nights running, these two guards, Marcellus and Barnardo, saw a figure that looked very much like your father, in full armor from head to toe.

origin: Thrice he walked By their oppressed and fear-surprisèd eyes Within his truncheon’s length, whilst they, distilled Almost to jelly with the act of fear, Stand dumb and speak not to him.
modern: It just appeared before them and marched past them with slow dignity three times, a staff’s distance from their amazed eyes, while they turned, quaking with fear and too shocked to speak.

origin: I knew your father.
modern: I knew your father.

origin: But where was this?
modern: But where did this happen?

origin: Treason!
modern: Treason!

origin: Treason!
modern: Treason!

origin: O, yet defend me, friends.
modern: Protect me, my friends.

origin: I am but hurt.
modern: I’ve only been hurt, not killed.

origin: Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damnèd Dane, Drink off this potion.
modern: Here, you goddamn incest-breeding Danish murderer, drink this.

origin: Is thy union here?
modern: Is your little pearl in there?

origin: Follow my mother.
modern: Follow my mother.

origin: He is justly served.
modern: He got what he deserved.

origin: It is a poison tempered by himself.
modern: He mixed that poison himself.

origin: Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
modern: Please forgive me as I forgive you, Hamlet.

origin: Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee, Nor thine on me.
modern: You’re not responsible for my death and my father’s, and I’m not responsible for yours.

origin: Heaven make thee free of it.
modern: God will free you from blame.

origin: Thou livest.
modern: You’re alive.

origin: Never believe it.
modern: Not for a second.

origin: I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
modern: I’m more like an ancient Roman than a corrupt modern Dane.

origin: Here’s yet some liquor left.
modern: Some of this liquor’s still left in the goblet.

origin: As thou'rt a man, Give me the cup.
modern: Please, give me that goblet, if you love me.

origin: Let go!
modern: Let go of it!

origin: By heaven, I’ll have ’t.
modern: I’ll get it from you, I swear.

origin: O God, Horatio, what a wounded name, Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me!
modern: Oh God, Horatio, what a damaged reputation I’m leaving behind me, as no one knows the truth.

origin: If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart Absent thee from felicity a while, And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain To tell my story.
modern: If you ever loved me, then please postpone the sweet relief of death awhile, and stay in this harsh world long enough to tell my story.

origin: What warlike noise is this?
modern: What are these warlike noises?

origin: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland, To th' ambassadors of England gives This warlike volley.
modern: Young Fortinbras, returning in triumph from Poland, is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors.

origin: O, I die, Horatio.
modern: Oh, I’m dying, Horatio!

origin: The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit.
modern: This strong poison’s overpowering me.

origin: I cannot live to hear the news from England.
modern: I will not live to hear the news from England.

origin: But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras.
modern: But I bet Fortinbras will win the election to the Danish crown.

origin: He has my dying voice.
modern: He’s got my vote as I die.

origin: O, O, O, O.
modern: Oh, oh, oh, oh.

origin: Where is this sight?
modern: What do I see here?

origin: What is it ye would see?
modern: What would you like to see?

origin: This quarry cries on havoc.
modern: These corpses suggest mayhem.

origin: O proud death, What feast is toward in thine eternal cell, That thou so many princes at a shot So bloodily hast struck?
modern: Oh, proud Death, what banquet are you preparing that you’ve needed to knock off so many princes at one stroke?

origin: The sight is dismal, And our affairs from England come too late.
modern: This is a horrible sight.

origin: The ears are senseless that should give us hearing, To tell him his commandment is fulfilled, That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
modern: We meant to tell the king that his orders have been carried out, and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.

origin: Had it th' ability of life to thank you.
modern: Who will thank us now?

origin: For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
modern: As for me, I welcome my good luck with sadness.

origin: Let four captains Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage, For he was likely, had he been put on, To have proved most royally.
modern: Let four captains carry Hamlet like a soldier onto the stage.

origin: And, for his passage, The soldiers' music and the rites of war Speak loudly for him.
modern: Military music and military rites will speak for his heroic qualities.

origin: Take up the bodies.
modern: Pick up the corpses.

origin: My lord, upon the platform where we watch.
modern: On the platform where we stand guard, sir.

origin: Did you not speak to it?
modern: Didn’t you talk to it?

origin: My lord, I did, But answer made it none.
modern: I did, sir, but it didn’t answer me.

origin: Tis very strange.
modern: That’s very strange.

origin: I pray you all, If you have hitherto concealed this sight, Let it be tenable in your silence still.

origin: Farewell.

origin: Do you doubt that?

origin: No more.

origin: Then weigh what loss your honor may sustain If with too credent ear you list his songs, Or lose your heart, or your chaste treasure open To his unmastered importunity.

origin: Fear it, Ophelia.

modern: If I weren’t forbidden to tell you the secrets of

modern: Let’s go back to court together, but

origin: Take you, as ’twere, some distant knowledge of him, As thus: “I know his father and his friends, And, in part, him.” Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
modern: Do you get what I’m saying, Reynaldo?

origin: Ay, very well, my lord.
modern: Yes, very well, sir.

origin: And in part him, but,” you may say, “not well.

origin: Addicted so and so.—” And there put on him What forgeries you please.

origin: But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips

origin: Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, Quarreling, drabbing—you may go so far.
modern: That’s right, or drinking, swearing, fist-fighting, visiting prostitutes—that kind of thing.

origin: My lord, that would dishonor him!
modern: But that would ruin his reputation!

origin: Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.
modern: Oh no, not if you say it right.

origin: But, my good lord— Wherefore should you do this?
modern: But, sir— Why should you do this, you want to know?

origin: Ay, my lord.
modern: Yes, sir.

origin: I would know that.

origin: Very good, my lord.

origin: By the mass, I was about to say something.

origin: Where did I leave?
modern: What was I saying?

origin: I saw him yesterday”—or “t' other day,” Or then, or then, with such or such—“and, as you say, There was he gaming, there o'ertook in’s rouse, There falling out at tennis,” or, perchance, “I saw him enter such a house of sale”—   Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth.
modern: I just saw him yesterday,” or “the other day,” or whenever it is, you know, “and there he was gambling,” or “there he was, totally wasted, or fighting with somebody about a tennis match, or going into a house of ill repute”—that means a whorehouse, you know—or whatever.

origin: You have me, have you not?
modern: You get my point, don’t you?

origin: My lord, I have.
modern: Yes, I do, sir.

origin: God be wi' you.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Have a safe trip.

origin: Good my lord.
modern: Thank you, sir.

origin: I shall, my lord.

origin: And let him ply his music.

origin: Well, my lord.

origin: Farewell.

origin: With what, i' th' name of God?
modern: From what, in God’s name?

origin: Mad for thy love?
modern: Is he crazy with love for you?

origin: What said he?
modern: What did he say?

origin: Long stayed he so.
modern: He stayed like that a long time.

origin: At last, a little shaking of mine arm And thrice his head thus waving up and down, He raised a sigh so piteous and profound As it did seem to shatter all his bulk And end his being.
modern: Finally, after shaking my arm a little, and jerking his head up and down three times, he sighed like it was his last breath.

origin: Come, go with me.
modern: Come with me.

origin: I will go seek the king.
modern: I’ll go tell the king about this.

origin: This is the very ecstasy of love, Whose violent property fordoes itself And leads the will to desperate undertakings As oft as any passion under heaven That does afflict our natures.
modern: Love is such a violent emotion that it makes people self-destruct, as much as any strong emotion.

origin: I am sorry.
modern: I’m so sorry.

origin: That hath made him mad.
modern: That’s what made him crazy.

origin: I am sorry that with better heed and judgment I had not quoted him.
modern: I regret not observing him more closely before I told you to do that.

origin: I feared he did but trifle And meant to wreck thee.
modern: I thought he was just toying with you and meant to ruin your reputation.

origin: But beshrew my jealousy!
modern: Damn my suspicious thoughts!

origin: By heaven, it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.
modern: It’s as common for us old people to assume we know more than we do as for young people to be too wild and crazy.

origin: Come, go we to the king.
modern: Come on, let’s go see the king.

origin: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
modern: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.

origin: Moreover that we much did long to see you, The need we have to use you did provoke Our hasty sending.
modern: I’ve wanted to see you for a long time now, but I sent for you so hastily because I need your help right away.

origin: Something have you heard Of Hamlet’s “transformation”—so call it Since nor th' exterior nor the inward man Resembles that it was.
modern: You’ve probably heard about the “change” that’s come over Hamlet—that’s the only word for it, since inside and out he’s different from what he was before.

origin: What it should be, More than his father’s death, that thus hath put him So much from th' understanding of himself, I cannot dream of.
modern: I can’t imagine what’s made him so unlike himself, other than his father’s death.

origin: Both your majesties Might, by the sovereign power you have of us, Put your dread pleasures more into command Than to entreaty.
modern: Both you and the king might have ordered us to execute your command, instead of asking us so politely.

origin: But we both obey And here give up ourselves, in the full bent, To lay our service freely at your feet To be commanded.
modern: But we’ll obey.

origin: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.
modern: Thanks, Rosencrantz and worthy Guildenstern.

origin: Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.
modern: Thanks, Guildenstern and worthy Rosencrantz.

origin: And I beseech you instantly to visit My too much changèd son.
modern: I beg you to pay a visit right away to my son, who’s changed too much.

origin: Go, some of you, And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.
modern: Servants, take these gentlemen to see Hamlet.

origin: Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful to him!
modern: I hope to God we can make him happy and do him some good!

origin: Ay, amen!
modern: Amen to that!

origin: Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully returned.
modern: The ambassadors are back from Norway, sir.

origin: Thou still hast been the father of good news.
modern: Once again you bring good news.

origin: Have I, my lord?
modern: Do I, sir?

origin: I assure my good liege, I hold my duty as I hold my soul, Both to my God and to my gracious king.
modern: I assure your majesty I’m only doing my duty both to my God and my good king.

origin: It is offended.
modern: It looks like you’ve offended it.

origin: See, it stalks away.
modern: Look, it’s going away.

origin: Stay!
modern: Stay!

origin: I charge thee, speak!
modern: I order you, speak!

origin: How now, Horatio?
modern: What’s going on, Horatio?

origin: You tremble and look pale.
modern: You’re pale and trembling.

origin: Is not this something more than fantasy?
modern: You agree now that we’re not imagining this, don’t you?

origin: What think you on ’t?
modern: What do you think about it?

origin: Before my God, I might not this believe Without the sensible and true avouch Of mine own eyes.
modern: I swear to God, if I hadn’t seen this with my own eyes I’d never believe it.

origin: Is it not like the king?
modern: Doesn’t it look like the king?

origin: As thou art to thyself.
modern: Yes, as much as you look like yourself.

origin: Such was the very armour he had on When he the ambitious Norway combated.
modern: The king was wearing exactly this armor when he fought the king of Norway.

origin: So frowned he once when, in an angry parle, He smote the sledded Polacks on the ice.
modern: And the ghost frowned just like the king did once when he attacked the Poles, traveling on the ice in sleds.

origin: Tis strange.
modern: It’s weird.

origin: And I do think—or else this brain of mine Hunts not the trail of policy so sure As it hath used to do—that I have found The very cause of Hamlet’s lunacy.
modern: And I believe—unless this brain of mine is not so politically cunning as it used to be—that I’ve found out why Hamlet’s gone crazy.

origin: Oh, speak of that.
modern: Tell me!

origin: That do I long to hear.
modern: I want very much to find out.

origin: Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.
modern: All right, but first let the ambassadors speak.

origin: My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
modern: Then you can hear my news, as dessert.

origin: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
modern: Then be so kind as to show them in.

origin: He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found The head and source of all your son’s distemper.
modern: Gertrude, he says he’s found out the reason for your son’s insanity.

origin: I doubt it is no other but the main: His father’s death and our o'erhasty marriage.
modern: I doubt it’s anything but the obvious reason: his father’s dying and our quick marriage.

origin: Well, we shall sift him.—Welcome, my good friends!
modern: Welcome, my good friends.

origin: Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?
modern: Tell me, Voltemand, what’s the news from the king of Norway?

origin: Whereat grieved— That so his sickness, age, and impotence Was falsely borne in hand—sends out arrests On Fortinbras, which he, in brief, obeys, Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine Makes vow before his uncle never more To give th' assay of arms against your majesty.
modern: He was very upset that Fortinbras had taken advantage of his being old and sick to deceive him, and he ordered Fortinbras’s arrest.

origin: Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,
modern: Fortinbras swore never to threaten Denmark again.

origin: Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee And his commission to employ those soldiers, So levied as before, against the Polack, With an entreaty, herein further shown, That it might please you to give quiet pass Through your dominions for this enterprise, On such regards of safety and allowance As therein are set down.
modern: The old king was so overjoyed by this promise that he gave young Fortinbras an annual income of three thousand  I like this news, and when I have time I’ll read this and think about how to reply.

origin: Meantime we thank you for your well-took labor.
modern: Meanwhile, thank you for your efforts.

origin: Go to your rest.
modern: Go relax now.

origin: At night we’ll feast together.
modern: Tonight we’ll have dinner.

origin: Most welcome home!
modern: Welcome back!

origin: This business is well ended.
modern: Well, that turned out well in the end.

modern: Sir and madam, to make grand speeches about what majesty is, what service is, or why day is day, night is night, and time is time is just a waste of a lot of day, night, and time.

origin: Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes, I will be brief: your noble son is mad.
modern: Your son is crazy.

origin: Mad call I it, for, to define true madness, What is ’t but to be nothing else but mad?
modern: Crazy” I’m calling it, since how can you say what craziness is except to say that it’s craziness?

origin: But let that go.
modern: But that’s another story.

origin: Thus it remains, and the remainder thus.
modern: Think about it.

origin: I have a daughter—have while she is mine— Who in her duty and obedience, mark, Hath given me this.
modern: I have a daughter (I have her until she gets married) who’s given me this letter, considering it her duty.

origin: Good madam, stay a while.
modern: Madam, please be patient.

origin: I will be faithful.
modern: I’ll read it to you.

origin: O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers.

modern: I can’t put my feelings into verse, but please believe I love you best, oh, best of all.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Believe it.

origin: Hamlet.” This in obedience hath my daughter shown me, And more above, hath his solicitings, As they fell out by time, by means, and place, All given to mine ear.
modern: Hamlet.” Dutifully and obediently my daughter showed me this letter, and more like it.

origin: But how hath she received his love?
modern: And how did she react to all this?

modern: Sir, what is your opinion of me?

modern: I know you are loyal and honorable.

origin: I would fain prove so.
modern: I would like to prove to you that I am.

origin: What might you think?
modern: No, I had to do something.

origin: No, I went round to work, And my young mistress thus I did bespeak: “Lord Hamlet is a prince out of thy star.
modern: And so I said to my daughter: “Lord Hamlet is a prince, he’s out of your league.

origin: It may be, very like.
modern: It may be, it certainly may be.

modern: Has there ever been a time—I’d really like to know—when I’ve definitely said something was true, and it turned out not to be true?

origin: Not that I know.
modern: Not that I know of.

origin: How may we try it further?
modern: What can we do to find out if it’s true?

modern: Well, you know he sometimes walks here in the lobby for four hours at a time.

origin: So he does indeed.
modern: Yes, he does.

origin: At such a time I’ll loose my daughter to him.
modern: When he’s there next time, I’ll send my daughter to see him.

modern: Please go away, both of you.

origin: I’ll board him presently.
modern: I’ll speak to him now.

origin: O, give me leave.
modern: Oh, please let me.

origin: How does my good Lord Hamlet?
modern: How are you, Hamlet?

origin: Well, God-'a'-mercy.
modern: Fine, thank you.

origin: Do you know me, my lord?
modern: Do you know who I am?

origin: The town is beseeched, and the trumpet call us to the breach, and we talk and, be Chrish, do nothing, ’tis shame for us all.
modern: The town is besieged, and the trumpet calls us to the gap, and we talk and do nothing, by Christ.

origin: So God sa' me, ’tis shame to stand still.
modern: It’s a disgrace to us all.

origin: By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber, ay’ll de gud service, or I’ll lig i' th' grund for it, ay, or go to death.
modern: I swear by the mass, before I close my eyes to go to sleep, I’ll put in some good fighting, or I’ll lie in the ground dead.

origin: Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—  Of my nation?
modern: Captain Macmorris, I think, see—correct me if I’m wrong—there are not many of your nation— My nation?

origin: What ish my nation?
modern: What is my nation?

origin: Ish a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal.
modern: It’s a villain and a bastard and a coward and a rascal.

origin: What ish my nation?
modern: What is my nation?

origin: Who talks of my nation?
modern: Who talks of my nation?

origin: Look you, if you take the matter otherwise than is meant, Captain Macmorris, peradventure I shall think you do not use me with that affability as, in discretion, you ought to use me, look you, being as good a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of war and in the derivation of my birth and in other particularities.
modern: Captain Macmorris, if you take my words in some way other than how they were meant, see, I’ll have to think you’re not treating me with the good will you ought to, see, since I am as good a man as yourself, both in the practice of war and in my country of origin and in other respects.

origin: I do not know you so good a man as myself.
modern: I do not know that you are as good a man as myself.

origin: So Chrish save me, I will cut off your head.
modern: So, by Christ, I’ll cut off your head.

origin: Gentlemen both, you will mistake each other.
modern: Now, now, both of you gentlemen!

origin: Ah, that’s a foul fault.
modern: Yes, and that’s a serious failing.

origin: The town sounds a parley.
modern: The town is asking for a pause in the fighting for negotiation.

origin: Captain Macmorris, when there is more better opportunity to be required, look you, I will be so bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war, and there is an end.
modern: Captain Macmorris, when we have more leisure, see, I will be so bold as to show you I know about the practice of warfare, and that’s that.

origin: How yet resolves the governor of the town?
modern: What has the governor of the town decided?

origin: This is the latest parle we will admit.
modern: This is the final discussion I will grant.

origin: Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves Or, like to men proud of destruction, Defy us to our worst.
modern: So submit to my mercy or, like men who revel in their own destruction, challenge me to do my worst.

origin: For, as I am a soldier, A name that in my thoughts becomes me best, If I begin the batt'ry once again, I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur Till in her ashes she lie burièd.
modern: For, as I am a soldier, the name I think suits me best, once I begin my attack on Harfleur again, I will not leave the half-conquered town until she lies buried in her own ashes.

origin: The gates of mercy shall be all shut up, And the fleshed soldier, rough and hard of heart, In liberty of bloody hand, shall range With conscience wide as hell, mowing like grass Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants.
modern: The gates of mercy will be closed by then, and harsh and hard-hearted soldiers, who have tasted blood, will have free reign to commit whatever violence they want, mowing down your lovely young virgins and budding infants.

origin: What rein can hold licentious wickedness When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
modern: What power can rein in promiscuous evil once it’s gotten rolling?

origin: We may as bootless spend our vain command Upon th' enragèd soldiers in their spoil As send precepts to the Leviathan To come ashore.
modern: We might as well send orders to the whale to come ashore as try to restore order in soldiers carried away with their looting.

origin: What say you?
modern: What do you say?

origin: Will you yield and this avoid Or, guilty in defense, be thus destroyed?
modern: Will you surrender and avoid all this or be called to account for the destruction of this town?

origin: Our expectation hath this day an end.
modern: Today our hopes are at an end.

origin: The Dauphin, whom of succors we entreated, Returns us that his powers are yet not ready To raise so great a siege.
modern: The Dauphin, whom we asked for reinforcements, sends back the answer that he’s not yet in a position to raise so great an army.

origin: Therefore, great King, We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.
modern: Therefore, great king, we surrender our town and lives to your kind mercy.

origin: Open your gates.
modern: Open your gates.

origin: Come, uncle Exeter, Go you and enter Harfleur.
modern: Come, uncle Exeter, enter Harfleur.

origin: There remain And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French.
modern: Stay there and fortify it well against the French.

origin: Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest; Tomorrow for the march are we addressed.
modern: Tonight in Harfleur we will be your guest; tomorrow we’ll march on.

origin: It must be so, for miracles are ceased, And therefore we must needs admit the means How things are perfected.
modern: No, I’ll recite it for you right now: “de hand, de fangres, de nails—” “De nails,” madame.

origin: Doth his Majesty Incline to it or no?
modern: Ugh!

origin: D'elbow.”      “D'elbow,”    “De nick,”  “De nick.”  “De chin.” “De sin.”
modern: That’s enough for one lesson.

origin: Tis certain he hath passed the river Somme.
modern: He’s certainly crossed the river Somme.

origin: An if he be not fought withal, my lord, Let us not live in France.
modern: And if he advances unopposed, my lord, let us abandon France.

origin: Let us quit all And give our vineyards to a barbarous people.
modern: Let us leave everything and give our vineyards to the barbarous nation.

origin: Normans, but bastard Normans, Norman bastards!
modern: God alive!

origin: Unfought withal, but I will sell my dukedom To buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm In that nook-shotten isle of Albion.
modern: If they march along unopposed, I will sell my dukedom for a sodden, filthy farm in that craggy isle of Albion.

origin: Is not their climate foggy, raw, and dull, On whom, as in despite, the sun looks pale, Killing their fruit with frowns?
modern: Doesn’t the sun shine palely down on them, as though in contempt, killing their fruit with frowns?

origin: And shall our quick blood, spirited with wine, Seem frosty?
modern: And shall our lively blood, quickened by wine, be so frosty?

origin: Where is Montjoy the herald?
modern: Where is Montjoy, the herald?

origin: Speed him hence.
modern: Send him on his way quickly.

origin: Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.
modern: Tell him to greet the king of England with our sharp defiance.

origin: Up, princes, and, with spirit of honor edged More sharper than your swords, hie to the field: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; You dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, and of Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jacques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Faulconbridge, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois; High dukes, great princes, barons, lords, and knights, For your great seats now quit you of great shames.
modern: Rise, princes, and, with a spirit of honor more sharply edged than your swords, rush to the battlefield: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; you dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jaques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Fauconberg, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois.

origin: Bar Harry England, that sweeps through our land With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur.
modern: Stop Harry of England, who is now sweeping through our land with banners drenched in the French blood he spilled at Harfleur.

origin: Therefore, Lord Constable, haste on Montjoy And let him say to England that we send To know what willing ransom he will give.
modern: Have Montjoy hurry, then, Lord Constable, and have him ask the king of England what he is willing to pay us to get out of the war.

origin: Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.
modern: Prince Dauphin, you’ll stay with me in Rouen.

origin: Not so, I do beseech your Majesty.
modern: No, please, I beg your Majesty.

origin: Be patient, for you shall remain with us.
modern: Be patient, because you’re staying with me.

origin: Now forth, Lord Constable and princes all, And quickly bring us word of England’s fall.
modern: Go now, Lord Constable and all you princes, and quickly bring us news of England’s defeat.

origin: Is the duke of Exeter safe?
modern: Is the duke of Exeter safe?

origin: He is called Aunchient Pistol.
modern: He is called Ensign Pistol.

origin: I know him not.
modern: I don’t know him.

origin: Here is the man.
modern: Here he is.

origin: Captain, I thee beseech to do me favors.
modern: Captain, I have a favor to beg of you.

origin: The duke of Exeter doth love thee well.
modern: You’re on very good terms with the duke of Exeter.

origin: Ay, I praise God, and I have merited some love at his hands.
modern: Yes, God be praised, I have managed to earn his favor.

origin: Fortune is an excellent moral.
modern: She provides an excellent moral.

origin: A damnèd death!
modern: I’m glad to hear it.

origin: Aunchient Pistol, I do partly understand your meaning.
modern: Discipline must be kept.

origin: Die and be damned, and  It is well.
modern: Then die and be damned!

origin: Why, this is an arrant counterfeit rascal.
modern: Why, that man is a total fraud and rascal.

origin: I’ll assure you, he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you shall see in a summer’s day.
modern: What he just said to me—it’s alright.

origin: trick up with new-tuned oaths; and what a beard of the general’s cut and a horrid suit of the camp will do among foaming bottles and ale-washed wits is wonderful to be thought on.
modern: And what a beard trimmed like the general’s or a rough uniform will do among foaming mugs and brains washed with ale, you wouldn’t believe.

origin: But you must learn to know such slanders of the age, or else you may be marvelously mistook.
modern: But you must learn to recognize such liars, or you will be greatly taken advantage of.

origin: If I find a hole in his coat, I will tell him my mind.
modern: If I find an opportunity, I will give him a piece of my mind.

origin: How now, Fluellen, cam’st thou from the bridge?
modern: Tell me, Fluellen: did you just come from the bridge?

origin: Ay, so please your Majesty.
modern: Yes, your Majesty.

origin: The duke of Exeter has very gallantly maintained the pridge.
modern: The duke of Exeter has held the bridge very gallantly.

origin: The French is gone off, look you, and there is gallant and most prave passages.
modern: The French have retreated, see, and there were great acts of courage.

origin: Marry, th' athversary was have possession of the pridge, but he is enforced to retire, and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge.
modern: Indeed, the enemy nearly took the bridge, but he was forced to retreat, and the duke of Exeter holds the bridge.

origin: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a prave man.
modern: I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a brave man.

origin: What men have you lost, Fluellen?
modern: What men have you lost, Fluellen?

origin: The perdition of th' athversary hath been very great, reasonable great.
modern: The enemy’s losses have been very great, pretty substantial.

origin: Marry, for my part, I think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man.
modern: To tell the truth, though, I think the duke hasn’t lost a single man, except for one who will probably be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph—I don’t know if your Majesty knows the man.

origin: We would have all such offenders so cut off, and we give express charge that in our marches through the country there be nothing compelled from the villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful language; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the gentler gamester is the soonest winner.
modern: I want all such offenders to be dealt with that way, and I give precise orders that in our progress through the country there shall be nothing seized from the villages, nothing taken that is not paid for, none of the French harassed or abused in disrespectful language.

origin: You know me by my habit.
modern: You know from my clothing who I am.

origin: Well then, I know thee.
modern: Well then, I know who you are.

origin: What shall I know of thee?
modern: What do you have to tell me?

origin: My master’s mind.
modern: My master’s decision.

origin: Unfold it.
modern: Go ahead.

origin: Thus says my king: “Say thou to Harry of England, though we seemed dead, we did but sleep.
modern: My king says this: “Tell Harry of England: though we appeared dead, we were only asleep.

origin: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness.
modern: Strategy makes a better soldier than haste.

origin: Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full ripe.
modern: Tell him we could have driven him back at Harfleur but thought it unwise to burst a pustule before it had fully ripened.

origin: Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial.
modern: Now the time is right for us to speak, and we do so with imperial authority.

origin: With good acceptance of his Majesty— Save that there was not time enough to hear, As I perceived his Grace would fain have done, The severals and unhidden passages Of his true titles to some certain dukedoms, And generally to the crown and seat of France, Derived from Edward, his great-grandfather.
modern: Favorably, except that there wasn’t enough time for his Grace to hear, as I sensed he would have liked to, the details about how he is rightfully entitled to certain dukedoms in France, and to the throne of France in general, through clear lines of descent originating with his great-grandfather, Edward III.

origin: What was th' impediment that broke this off?
modern: What kept you from telling him this?

origin: The French ambassador upon that instant Craved audience.
modern: The French ambassador arrived at that moment and asked to see the king.

origin: And the hour, I think, is come To give him hearing.
modern: And, in fact, I think they’re meeting together right now.

origin: Is it four o'clock?
modern: Is it four o'clock?

origin: It is.
modern: It is.

origin: Then go we in to know his embassy, Which I could with a ready guess declare Before the Frenchman speak a word of it.
modern: Then let’s go in and hear what he has to say—though I think I can guess before the Frenchman has uttered a word.

origin: Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we have lost, the disgrace we have digested, which, in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under.
modern: have lost, and the indignity we have endured, for which he is too insignificant to sufficiently pay us back.

origin: For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for th' effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person, kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction.
modern: His coffers are too poor to atone for our losses, his entire kingdom too small to account for the amount of blood we’ve shed, and the sight of him kneeling at our feet an empty satisfaction compared to the indignity we have put up with.

origin: To this, add defiance, and tell him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his followers, whose condemnation is pronounced.” So far my king and master; so much my office.
modern: Add defiance to all this and, by way of conclusion, tell him that he has betrayed the men who follow him, whose death sentence has been pronounced.” My king and master’s message delivered, my task is done.

origin: What is thy name?
modern: What is your name?

origin: I know thy quality.
modern: I know your position.

origin: Montjoy.
modern: Montjoy.

origin: Thou dost thy office fairly.
modern: You do your job well.

origin: Turn thee back, And tell thy king I do not seek him now But could be willing to march on to Calais Without impeachment, for, to say the sooth, Though ’tis no wisdom to confess so much Unto an enemy of craft and vantage, My people are with sickness much enfeebled, My numbers lessened, and those few I have Almost no better than so many French, Who when they were in health, I tell thee, herald, I thought upon one pair of English legs Did march three Frenchmen.
modern: Go back and tell your king I do not seek an encounter with him now but would be willing to march on to Calais without interference, for—to be honest, though it’s probably unwise to confess this to a powerful enemy who has the advantage—my men are considerably weakened by illness, my numbers reduced, and those few men I have almost no better than so many Frenchmen, though when they were in good form, I tell you, herald, I thought three Frenchmen walked on every pair of English legs.

origin: Yet, forgive me, God, That I do brag thus.
modern: But God forgive me for bragging.

origin: Go therefore, tell thy master: here I am.
modern: Anyway, go tell your master I am here.

origin: I shall deliver so.
modern: I’ll deliver the message.

origin: Thanks to your Highness.
modern: I thank your Highness.

origin: I hope they will not come upon us now.
modern: I hope they don’t attack us now.

origin: We are in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.
modern: We’re in God’s hands, brother, not in theirs.

origin: March to the bridge.
modern: March to the bridge.

origin: It now draws toward night.
modern: Night is approaching.

origin: Tut, I have the best armor of the world.
modern: I have the best armor in the world.

origin: Would it were day!
modern: I wish it were day!

origin: You have an excellent armor, but let my horse have his due.
modern: You have wonderful armor, but give my horse his due.

origin: It is the best horse of Europe.
modern: It is the best horse in Europe.

origin: Will it never be morning?
modern: Will it never be morning?

origin: My lord of Orléans, and my Lord High Constable, you talk of horse and armor?
modern: My lord of Orléans, and my lord high Constable, are you talking about horses and armor?

origin: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.
modern: You are as well provided in both respects as any prince in the world.

origin: What a long night is this!
modern: What a long night this is!
