origin: I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.
modern: I will not trade my horse for any that walks on four legs.

origin: He bounds from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui a les narines de feu.
modern: He leaps from the ground as if his insides were light as hairs.

origin: The earth sings when he touches it.
modern: The earth sings when he touches it.

origin: The basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.
modern: The lowest part of his hoof is more musical than Pan’s pipe.

origin: He’s of the color of the nutmeg.
modern: He’s the color of nutmeg.

origin: And of the heat of the ginger.
modern: And hot as ginger.

origin: It is a beast for Perseus.
modern: He is an animal worthy of Perseus.

origin: He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you may call beasts.
modern: He is indeed worthy of the name “horse,” and you can call all the rest beasts.

origin: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.
modern: Indeed, my lord, he is a perfectly wonderful horse.

origin: It is the prince of palfreys.
modern: He is the prince of horses.

origin: His neigh is like the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance enforces homage.
modern: His neigh is like a monarch’s command.

origin: No more, cousin.
modern: Enough, cousin.

origin: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my palfrey.
modern: No, the man who cannot extol the virtues of my horse from dawn to dusk is not particularly clever.

origin: It is a theme as fluent as the sea.
modern: It’s a subject as worthy of endless discussion as the changing sea.

origin: Turn the sands into eloquent tongues, and my horse is argument for them all.
modern: If each grain of sand had a tongue to eulogize, my horse would be a topic for them all.

origin: Tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a sovereign’s sovereign to ride on, and for the world, familiar to us and unknown, to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at him.
modern: He is a subject for a king to contemplate, and for a king’s king to ride on, and for the world at large—both friend and stranger—to stop whatever they are doing and marvel at.

origin: I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of nature—”  I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s mistress.
modern: I once wrote a sonnet in his praise which began, “Wonder of nature—” I have heard a sonnet to one’s mistress that began like that.

origin: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my courser, for my horse is my mistress.
modern: Then the writer imitated the one I composed to my steed, for my horse is my mistress.

origin: Your mistress bears well.
modern: Your mistress is a good mount.

origin: So perhaps did yours.
modern: So, perhaps, did yours.

origin: Mine was not bridled.
modern: Mine wasn’t wearing a bridle.

origin: Oh, then belike she was old and gentle, and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off and in your straight strossers.
modern: Oh, then I guess she was old and gentle, and you rode barelegged, like an Irish yokel.

origin: You have good judgment in horsemanship.
modern: You’re a good judge of horsemanship.

origin: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs.
modern: Take a tip from me, then.

origin: I had rather have my horse to my mistress.
modern: I’d rather have my horse than a mistress.

origin: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.
modern: I’d prefer to keep my mistress rather than some lame horse.

origin: I tell thee, Constable, my mistress wears his own hair.
modern: I’ll tell you this, Constable, my mistress has his own hair.

origin: I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to my mistress.
modern: I could make the same boast even if I had a pig as my mistress.

origin: Le chien est retourné à son propre vomissement, et la truie lavée au bourbier.” Thou mak’st use of anything.
modern: The dog returns to its own vomit, and the newly washed sow to its mud puddle.” You’d take anything for a mistress.

origin: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.
modern: At least I don’t have a horse for my mistress—or a saying so beside the point.

origin: My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?
modern: My Lord Constable, are those stars or suns I saw on the armor in your tent tonight?

origin: Stars, my lord.
modern: Stars, my lord.

origin: Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.
modern: I hope some will fall off tomorrow.

origin: And yet my sky shall not want.
modern: And yet I’ll still have plenty.

origin: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and ’twere more honor some were away.
modern: No doubt, for you wear too many in the first place, and it might be more seemly to make do with fewer.

origin: Ev'n as your horse bears your praises—who would trot as well were some of your brags dismounted.
modern: Yes, like your horse, who, staggering under your boasts, would trot more easily if some of them dismounted.

origin: Would I were able to load him with his desert!
modern: I only wish I could load him up with all the praise he deserves!

origin: Will it never be day?
modern: Oh, will it never be day?

origin: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of my way.
modern: I’d say the same thing, but I’m afraid I’d be faced out of my way.

origin: Tis midnight.
modern: It’s midnight.

origin: I’ll go arm myself.
modern: I’ll go put my armor on.

origin: The Dauphin longs for morning.
modern: The Dauphin really wants it to be morning.

origin: He longs to eat the English.
modern: He wants to eat the English.

origin: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.
modern: Swear by her foot, so she can stamp out the oath.

origin: He is simply the most active gentleman of France.
modern: He’s definitely the most active gentleman of France.

origin: Doing is activity, and he will still be doing.
modern: Performing is activity, and he is always doing that.

origin: He never did harm that I heard of.
modern: He never did harm that I heard of.

origin: Nor will do none tomorrow.
modern: And he’s not going to do any tomorrow.

origin: He will keep that good name still.
modern: That part of his reputation will stand.

origin: I know him to be valiant.
modern: I know him to be valiant.

origin: I was told that by one that knows him better than you.
modern: I was told that by one who knows him better than you.

origin: What’s he?
modern: Who was that?

origin: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.
modern: Why, he told me so himself, and he said he didn’t care who knew it.

origin: He needs not.
modern: He doesn’t have to care.

origin: It is no hidden virtue in him.
modern: His virtue is not hidden.

origin: Tis a hooded valor, and when it appears, it will bate.
modern: His courage is hidden, and when it is revealed, it will shrink.

origin: Ill will never said well.
modern: Ill will never prompted anything well said.

origin: Have at the very eye of that proverb with “A pox of the devil.”  You are the better at proverbs, by how much “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”  You have shot over.
modern: I’ll go straight for that proverb with “To hell with the devil.” You are better at proverbs than I am by as much as “A fool shoots quickly and overshoots his mark.” You have overshot.

origin: Tis not the first time you were overshot.
modern: I’ve outshot you, and not for the first time.

origin: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
modern: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

origin: Who hath measured the ground?
modern: Who measured the ground?

origin: The Lord Grandpré.
modern: The Lord Grandpré.

origin: Alas, poor Harry of England!
modern: Poor Harry of England!

origin: He longs not for the dawning as we do.
modern: He doesn’t long for the dawn as we do.

origin: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of England to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge.
modern: What a miserable and obstinate fellow this king of England is, to blunder with his fat-headed followers so far beyond his capacity.

origin: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.
modern: If the English had any sense, they would run away.

origin: That they lack, for if their heads had any intellectual armor, they could never wear such heavy head-pieces.
modern: If there were anything inside their heads, they could never wear such heavy helmets.

origin: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.
modern: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.

origin: Their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.
modern: Their hounds are unequaled in courage.

origin: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads crushed like rotten apples.
modern: Foolish dogs, blindly running straight toward a Russian bear only to have their heads crushed like rotten apples.

origin: You may as well say, that’s a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.
modern: You might just as well say, “That’s a valiant flea that dares to eat its breakfast on the lip of a lion.” Yes, exactly.

origin: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their wives.
modern: And the men resemble their English hounds in their loud, showy ferocity, too, leaving their brains behind with their wives.

origin: And then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.
modern: Give them hefty meals of beef and iron and steel, and they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

origin: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.
modern: Yes, but these English are seriously short of beef.

origin: Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight.
modern: Then tomorrow we’ll find that they feel only like eating, not like fighting.

origin: Now is it time to arm.
modern: It’s time to put our armor on.

origin: Come, shall we about it?
modern: Shall we get started?

origin: It is now two o'clock.
modern: It’s two o'clock now.

origin: But, let me see, by ten We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.
modern: But let me see, by ten we shall each have captured a hundred Englishmen.

origin: Now entertain conjecture of a time When creeping murmur and the poring dark Fills the wide vessel of the universe.
modern: Now summon up the image of stealthy murmurs and engulfing darkness filling the wide vessel of the universe.

origin: Oh, now, who will behold The royal captain of this ruined band
modern: He bids them good morning with a modest smile and calls

origin: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?
modern: Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?

origin: Not here in presence.
modern: He’s not here.

origin: Send for him, good uncle.
modern: Send for him, dear uncle.

origin: Shall we call in th' ambassador, my liege?
modern: Shall we call in the ambassador, my liege?

origin: Not yet, my cousin.
modern: Not yet, cousin.

origin: We would be resolved, Before we hear him, of some things of weight That task our thoughts concerning us and France.
modern: Before I hear him, I want to decide some important issues that are on my mind concerning my throne and France.

origin: God and his angels guard your sacred throne And make you long become it.
modern: May God and his angels guard your sacred throne and grant that you dignify it for a long time.

origin: Sure we thank you.
modern: Thank you, I’m sure.

origin: My learnèd lord, we pray you to proceed And justly and religiously unfold Why the law Salic that they have in France Or should or should not bar us in our claim.
modern: My learned lord, kindly explain to us the legal and religious grounds for why this French Salic law either should or shouldn’t bar me in my claim.

origin: And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord, That you should fashion, wrest, or bow your reading, Or nicely charge your understanding soul With opening titles miscreate, whose right Suits not in native colors with the truth; For God doth know how many now in health Shall drop their blood in approbation
modern: For God knows how many healthy men will shed their blood in support of whatever you persuade me to do.

origin: Let him cry, “Praise and glory on his head!” For forth he goes and visits all his host, Bids them good morrow with a modest smile, And calls them brothers, friends, and countrymen.
modern: them brothers, friends, and countrymen.

origin: Upon his royal face there is no note How dread an army hath enrounded him, Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color Unto the weary and all-watchèd night, But freshly looks and overbears attaint With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty, That every wretch, pining and pale before, Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks.
modern: There is no indication of the mighty army that surrounds them in his expression, nor has the long, sleepless night robbed his face of an ounce of color.

origin: Gloucester, ’tis true that we are in great danger.
modern: Gloucester, it’s true that we are in great danger.

origin: The greater therefore should our courage be.
modern: But our courage should only be the greater for that.

origin: Good morrow, brother Bedford.
modern: Good morning, brother Bedford.

origin: God almighty, There is some soul of goodness in things evil, Would men observingly distill it out.
modern: God Almighty, there must be some essential goodness even in evil, if men would only look for it.

origin: For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers, Which is both healthful and good husbandry.
modern: In our case, our bad neighbors over their make us early risers, a healthy and sensible thing to be.

origin: Besides, they are our outward consciences And preachers to us all, admonishing That we should dress us fairly for our end.
modern: Besides, they act as outward consciences and preachers to us all, a visible reminder that we should prepare ourselves for death.

origin: Thus may we gather honey from the weed And make a moral of the devil himself.
modern: Think like that, and you’ll manage to get honey out of a common weed and find a moral lesson in the devil himself.

origin: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.
modern: Good morning, old Sir Thomas Erpingham!

origin: A good soft pillow for that good white head Were better than a churlish turf of France.
modern: A nice, soft pillow would be a more suitable place to lay that good white head than France’s hard, cold ground.

origin: So the spirit is eased.
modern: It eases the spirit.

origin: And when the mind is quickened, out of doubt, The organs, though defunct and dead before, Break up their drowsy grave and newly move, With casted slough and fresh legerity.
modern: And when the mind is engaged, the rest of the body, dead and dull before, wakes up and comes to life with a new nimbleness and sensitivity, like a snake shedding its dead skin.

origin: Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas.
modern: Lend me your cloak, Sir Thomas.

origin: We shall, my liege.
modern: We shall, my liege.

origin: Shall I attend your Grace?
modern: Shall I accompany your Grace?

origin: No, my good knight.
modern: No, my good knight.

origin: Go with my brothers to my lords of England.
modern: Go with my brothers to my English peers.

origin: I and my bosom must debate awhile, And then I would no other company.
modern: I need to be alone with my thoughts for a while and don’t want any company.

origin: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!
modern: The Lord in heaven bless you, noble Harry!

origin: A friend.
modern: A friend.

origin: Discuss unto me: art thou officer or art thou base, common, and popular?
modern: Or are you low, vulgar, and of the common people?

origin: I am a gentleman of a company.
modern: I am a gentleman of a company.

origin: Trail’st thou the puissant pike?
modern: Do you carry a pike?

origin: Even so.
modern: Exactly.

origin: What are you?
modern: What about you?

origin: As good a gentleman as the emperor.
modern: I’m as good a gentleman as the emperor.

origin: Then you are a better than the king.
modern: Then you’re a better man than the king.

origin: The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold, A lad of life, an imp of fame, Of parents good, of fist most valiant.
modern: The king’s a dear boy with a heart of gold, he’s a lively lad, a wag, born of fine parents, good with his fists.

origin: I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heartstring I love the lovely bully.
modern: I kiss his dirty shoe, and from the bottom of my heart I love the lovely boy.

origin: What is thy name?
modern: What is your name?

origin: Harry le Roy.
modern: Harry le Roy.

origin: Le Roy?
modern: Le Roy?

origin: A Cornish name.
modern: That’s a Cornish name.

origin: Art thou of Cornish crew?
modern: Are you with a Cornish company?

origin: No, I am a Welshman.
modern: No, I am a Welshman.

origin: Know’st thou Fluellen?
modern: Do you know Fluellen?

origin: Yes.
modern: Yes.

origin: Tell him I’ll knock his leek about his pate Upon Saint Davy’s day.
modern: Tell him I’ll take the leek out of his hat on Saint Davy’s Day and slap his head with it.

origin: Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day, lest he knock that about yours.
modern: You’d better not wear your dagger in your cap that day, or he might slap your head with it.

origin: Art thou his friend?
modern: Are you his friend?

origin: And his kinsman too.
modern: Yes, and his relative, too.

origin: The  I thank you.
modern: Thank you.

origin: God be with you.
modern: God be with you.

origin: My name is Pistol called.
modern: My name is Pistol.

origin: It sorts well with your fierceness.
modern: The name suits your fierceness.

origin: Captain Fluellen.
modern: Captain Fluellen!

origin: It is the greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept.
modern: It never ceases to amaze me the way people ignore the correct, traditional principles and rules of war.

origin: If you would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great, you shall find, I warrant you, that there is no tiddle toddle nor pibble babble in Pompey’s camp.
modern: If you would take the trouble to study the tactics of Pompey the Great, I can tell you that you would find no tittle-tattle or pibble-pabble in Pompey’s camp.

origin: I warrant you, you shall find the ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise.
modern: I tell you, you would find the rituals of war and, I promise you, its ceremonies and its solicitudes and its forms and its gravity and its discipline all to be quite counter to all this noise.

origin: Why, the enemy is loud.
modern: But the enemy is loud.

origin: You hear him all night.
modern: You can hear them all night long.

origin: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also, look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, in your own conscience, now?
modern: And if the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating idiot, does that mean, you think, that we should also be an ass and a fool and a prating idiot?

origin: I will speak lower.
modern: Think about it.

origin: I pray you and beseech you that you will.
modern: I will lower my voice.

origin: Though it appear a little out of fashion, There is much care and valor in this Welshman.
modern: Though he seems a little old-fashioned, there is much care and courage in this Welshman.

origin: Brother John Bates, is not that the morning which breaks yonder?
modern: Brother John Bates, isn’t that dawn breaking over there?

origin: We see yonder the beginning of the day, but I think we shall never see the end of it.—Who goes there?
modern: That’s the beginning of the day we see, but I don’t think we’ll see the end of it.—Who goes there?

origin: A friend.
modern: A friend.

origin: Under what captain serve you?
modern: What captain do you serve?

origin: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.
modern: Sir Thomas Erpingham.

origin: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman.
modern: A veteran commander and a very kind gentleman.

origin: I pray you, what thinks he of our estate?
modern: Tell me, what does he think of our situation?

origin: Even as men wracked upon a sand, that look to be washed off the next tide.
modern: We’re men beached on the sand, hoping to be washed out by the next tide.

origin: He hath not told his thought to the king?
modern: He hasn’t told this to the king, has he?

origin: The violet smells to him as it doth to me.
modern: The violet smells to him the same as it does to me.

origin: His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing.
modern: And though his feelings may be pitched higher than ours, when they plummet, they plummet that much farther.

origin: Therefore, when he sees reason of fears as we do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish as ours are.
modern: Therefore, when he has reason to fear, as we do, his fears are without question of the same order.

origin: Yet, in reason, no man should possess him with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing it, should dishearten his army.
modern: Still, it stands to reason that he mustn’t betray his fear, as it might dishearten his army.

origin: He may show what outward courage he will, but I believe, as cold a night as ’tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.
modern: He can act as brave as he wants, but I believe on a cold night like this he wishes he were neck-deep in the Thames, and I wish he were, too, and I with him, whatever the danger, so long as we were far away from here.

origin: By my troth, I will speak my conscience of the king.
modern: I’ll tell you truly what I think about the king in my heart.

origin: I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is.
modern: I don’t think he wants to be anywhere but where he is.

origin: I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here alone, howsoever you speak this to feel other men’s minds.
modern: Oh, I’m sure you don’t dislike him so much as to wish he were here alone, even though you say this to find out how the rest of us feel.

origin: Methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the king’s company, his cause being just and his quarrel honorable.
modern: I don’t think there’s anywhere I’d rather die than in the king’s company, as his cause is just and honorable.

origin: That’s more than we know.
modern: That’s more than we know.

origin: If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us.
modern: If his cause is wrong, our obedience to the king clears us of responsibility for it.

origin: But if the cause be not good, the king himself hath a heavy reckoning to make, when all those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a battle, shall join together at the latter day, and cry all, “We died at such a place,” some swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some upon their wives left poor behind them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their children rawly left.
modern: But if the cause is not just, the king himself will have a lot to answer for, when all those legs and arms and heads chopped off in battle shall join together on Judgment Day crying, “We died at such and such a place.” Some will be swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some for the wives that are destitute without them, some about the debts they owed, some for their children left unprovided for.

origin: I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle, for how can they charitably dispose of anything, when blood is their argument?
modern: I think few die well who die in battle.

origin: The king is not bound to answer the particular endings of his soldiers, the father of his son, nor the master of his servant, for they purpose not their death, when they purpose their services.
modern: The father and the master and the king didn’t order their subordinates' deaths when they ordered their services.

origin: Besides, there is no king, be his cause never so spotless, if it come to the arbitrament of swords, can try it out with all unspotted soldiers.
modern: Besides, there’s no king, however pure his cause, who, if it comes to a trial by combat, can rely on using completely blameless soldiers.

origin: Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.
modern: Even if these men have escaped the law and punishment at home, they cannot escape God.

origin: Where they feared the death, they have borne life away; and where they would be safe, they perish.
modern: When they feared death, they escaped with their lives; and now where they imagine they’re safe, they perish.

origin: Then, if they die unprovided, no more is the king guilty of their damnation than he was before guilty of those impieties for the which they are now visited.
modern: So, if they die unprepared, the king is no more guilty of their damnation than he was guilty of the earlier crimes they’re finally being punished for.

origin: Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own.
modern: Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own.

origin: Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man in his bed: wash every mote out of his conscience.
modern: Therefore, every soldier should do as any man who is sick in his bed would do: clear his conscience of any stain.

origin: And, dying so, death is to him advantage; or not dying, the time was blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained.
modern: Then if he dies, his death serves him.

origin: Tis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill upon his own head.
modern: It’s clear, every man must take responsibility for the manner of his own death.

origin: The king is not to answer it.
modern: The king is not responsible for it.

origin: I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet I determine to fight lustily for him.
modern: I don’t expect him to answer for me, and yet I’m determined to fight vigorously for him.

origin: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
modern: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.

origin: If I live to see it, I will never trust his word after.
modern: If I live to see it, I’ll never trust his word again.

origin: You pay him then.
modern: Yeah, right, go get him.

origin: That’s a perilous shot out of an elder gun, that a poor and private displeasure can do against a monarch.
modern: That’s a lame threat from a toy gun, a poor individual’s private displeasure with a monarch.

origin: You may as well go about to turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a peacock’s feather.
modern: You may as well try to turn the sun to ice by fanning its face with a peacock feather.

origin: You’ll “never trust his word after.” Come, ’tis a foolish saying.
modern: You’ll “never trust his word again.” Come on, that was a stupid thing to say.

origin: Your reproof is something too round.
modern: Your scolding is somewhat overblown.

origin: I should be angry with you if the time were convenient.
modern: I’d be angry with you if the occasion allowed.

origin: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.
modern: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.

origin: I embrace it.
modern: I’m game.

origin: How shall I know thee again?
modern: How will I recognize you in the future?

origin: Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear it in my bonnet.
modern: Give me some trinket of yours, and I will wear it in my hat.

origin: Then, if ever thou dar’st acknowledge it, I will make it my quarrel.
modern: Then, if you dare to acknowledge it, I’ll take up my quarrel with you.

origin: There.
modern: Here.

origin: This will I also wear in my cap.
modern: I’ll also wear this in my cap.

origin: If ever thou come to me and say, after tomorrow, “This is my glove,” by this hand I will take thee a box on the ear.
modern: If you come to me after tomorrow and say, “That’s my glove,” I swear by this hand, I will take it and give you a box on the ear.

origin: If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.
modern: If I ever see it, I will challenge you.

origin: Thou dar’st as well be hanged.
modern: You may as well undertake to be hanged.

origin: Well, I will do it, though I take thee in the king’s company.
modern: I’ll do it even if I find you in the company of the king himself.

origin: Keep thy word.
modern: Keep your word.

origin: Fare thee well.
modern: Farewell.

origin: Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to one they will beat us, for they bear them on their shoulders.
modern: Indeed, the French can bet twenty French crowns to one that they’ll beat us, they have such an army.

origin: But it is no English treason to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper.
modern: But it’s no treason for an Englishman to cut off a French crown—a head, I mean—and tomorrow the king himself will do some snipping.

origin: Of what your reverence shall incite us to.
modern: to wage war.

origin: Therefore take heed how you impawn our person, How you awake our sleeping sword of war.
modern: I charge you, in the name of God, be careful what you say.

origin: Under this conjuration, speak, my lord, For we will hear, note, and believe in heart That what you speak is in your conscience washed As pure as sin with baptism.
modern: With this in mind, speak, my lord.

origin: Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers That owe yourselves, your lives, and services To this imperial throne.
modern: Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and all you peers who owe your lives and duty to this imperial throne.

origin: Upon the king!
modern: Upon the king!

origin: Let us our lives, our souls, our debts, our careful wives, our children, and our sins lay on the king!
modern: Let’s lay everything upon the king: our lives, our souls, our debts, our anxious wives, our children, and our sins.” I must bear responsibility for all of it.

origin: We must bear all.
modern: What a painful condition responsibility is.

origin: O hard condition, Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath Of every fool, whose sense no more can feel But his own wringing.
modern: It goes along with being born to greatness, but it makes you get badmouthed by every fool who only has his own suffering to care about.

origin: What infinite heart’s ease Must kings neglect that private men enjoy?
modern: What infinite peace do king’s give up that private men enjoy?

origin: And what have kings that privates have not too, Save ceremony, save general ceremony?
modern: What do kings have that private men do not, besides the pomp of their position?

origin: And what art thou, thou idol ceremony?
modern: And what is this useless ceremony of kings?

origin: What kind of god art thou, that suffer’st more Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?
modern: What kind of god is ceremony, which suffers more than its worshippers do?

origin: What are thy comings in?
modern: What income, what profit does it bring in?

origin: O ceremony, show me but thy worth!
modern: Oh, ceremony, only show me your value!

origin: What is thy soul of adoration?
modern: Why are you adored?

origin: Art thou aught else but place, degree, and form, Creating awe and fear in other men, Wherein thou art less happy, being feared, Than they in fearing?
modern: You’re less happy, being feared, than they are in fearing you.

origin: What drink’st thou oft, instead of homage sweet, But poisoned flattery?
modern: What do you get to drink, instead of sweet obedience, but poisonous flattery?

origin: Oh, be sick, great greatness, And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!
modern: Try being sick, great greatness, and see if ceremony can cure you!

origin: Think’st thou the fiery fever will go out With titles blown from adulation?
modern: Do you think fiery fever can be put out by the windy puff of titles?

origin: Will it give place to flexure and low bending?
modern: Will it be chased away by bowing and scraping?

origin: Canst thou, when thou command’st the beggar’s knee, Command the health of it?
modern: You can command a beggar to bow on bended knee, but can you take possession of his health?

origin: No, thou proud dream, That play’st so subtly with a king’s repose.
modern: No, vain illusion, so intricately bound up with a king’s rest.

origin: And, but for ceremony, such a wretch, Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep, Had the forehand and vantage of a king.
modern: dusk and all night long sleeps in peace.

origin: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence, Seek through your camp to find you.
modern: My lord, your noble subjects are looking for you all over the camp.

origin: Good old knight, Collect them all together at my tent.
modern: Good old knight, gather them all together at my tent.

origin: I’ll be before thee.
modern: I’ll meet you there.

origin: I shall do’t, my lord.
modern: Consider it done, my lord.

origin: O God of battles, steel my soldiers' hearts.
modern: Oh God of battles, bolster my soldiers' courage.

origin: Possess them not with fear.
modern: Don’t let them know fear.

origin: Take from them now The sense of reck'ning ere th' opposèd numbers Pluck their hearts from them.
modern: Rob them of the ability to count before the numbers against them overwhelm their courage.

origin: Not today, O Lord, Oh, not today, think not upon the fault My father made in compassing the crown.
modern: And just for today, Oh, Lord, just today don’t think of the crime my father committed in seizing the crown!

origin: I Richard’s body have interrèd anew, And on it have bestowed more contrite tears Than from it issued forcèd drops of blood.
modern: I’ve transferred Richard’s body to a new grave and on it poured more tears of remorse than it has shed drops of blood.

origin: Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay, Who twice a day their withered hands hold up Toward heaven to pardon blood.
modern: I’ve hired five hundred almsmen to hold up their withered hands to heaven, praying for my pardon twice a day throughout the year.

origin: And I have built Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests Sing still for Richard’s soul.
modern: And I’ve built two chapels where solemn priests sing continually for Richard’s soul.

origin: More will I do— Though all that I can do is nothing worth, Since that my penitence comes after all, Imploring pardon.
modern: I will do more, though nothing I can do is any good since this remorse comes after the crime, asking for pardon.

origin: My liege.
modern: My liege.

origin: My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Ay, I know thy errand.
modern: My brother Gloucester’s voice?

origin: I will go with thee.
modern: I’ll go with you.

origin: The day, my friends, and all things stay for me.
modern: The day, my friends, and everything await me.

origin: The sun doth gild our armor.
modern: The sun glints off our armor.

origin: Up, my lords.
modern: Awake, my lords!

origin: Now, my Lord Constable?
modern: Is it time, my Lord Constable?

origin: Hark how our steeds for present service neigh.
modern: Listen to our horses neighing, longing to be working.

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?
modern: What, you want them to weep our horses' blood?

origin: How shall we then behold their natural tears?
modern: Then how will we see their own natural tears?

origin: The English are embattled, you French peers.
modern: The English are in the field, French lords.

origin: To horse, you gallant princes, straight to horse.
modern: To our horses, you gallant princes.

origin: What’s to say?
modern: What’s there to say?

origin: Then let the trumpets sound The tucket sonance and the note to mount, For our approach shall so much dare the field That England shall couch down in fear and yield.
modern: Our advance will so dazzle the enemy that England will cower in fear and surrender.

origin: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?
modern: What are you waiting for, lords of France?

origin: Yond island carrions, desperate of their bones, Ill-favoredly become the morning field.
modern: Those island-bred skeletons, terrified for their bones, are an offensive sight on the morning field.

origin: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps.
modern: The horsemen stand frozen like candlesticks, torches in their hands.

origin: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.
modern: Meanwhile, their  They’ve said their prayers, and now they wait for death.

origin: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits, And give their fasting horses provender, And after fight with them?
modern: Shall we go send them food and fresh clothing and feed their starving horses before we fight them?

origin: On, to the field!
modern: To the field!

origin: I will the banner from a trumpet take And use it for my haste.
modern: I’ll take the banner from a trumpeter and use that.

origin: Come, come away.
modern: Come, let’s be off!

origin: The sun is high, and we outwear the day.
modern: The sun is up and we’re wasting the day!

origin: Where is the king?
modern: Where is the king?

origin: The king himself is rode to view their battle.
modern: The king rode out alone to view their troops.

origin: Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.
modern: They have fully sixty thousand fighting men.

origin: There’s five to one.
modern: That’s five to one.

origin: Besides, they all are fresh.
modern: Besides, they’re fresh.

origin: God’s arm strike with us!
modern: May God’s arm strike on our side!

origin: Tis a fearful odds.
modern: These are frightening odds.

origin: God be wi' you, princes all.
modern: God be with all of you, princes.

origin: I’ll to my charge.
modern: I’ll go and join my men.

origin: Farewell, good Salisbury, and good luck go with thee.
modern: Farewell, good Salisbury; and may good luck go with you.

origin: Farewell, kind lord.
modern: Farewell, kind lord.

origin: Fight valiantly today.
modern: Fight valiantly today.

origin: And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it, For thou art framed of the firm truth of valor.
modern: But then I do you wrong to say as much, since you are the very embodiment of bravery.

origin: He is as full of valor as of kindness, Princely in both.
modern: He is as full of courage as of kindness, princely in both.

origin: Oh, that we now had here But one ten thousand of those men in England That do no work today.
modern: Oh, if only we had with us here ten thousand of those men back home in England who aren’t working today.

origin: What’s he that wishes so?
modern: Who wishes that?

origin: My cousin Westmoreland?
modern: My cousin Westmoreland?

origin: No, my fair cousin.
modern: No, my dear cousin.

origin: If we are marked to die, we are enough To do our country loss; and if to live, The fewer men, the greater share of honor.
modern: If we are slated to die, the fewer, the better for our country, and if we’re slated to live, the fewer men, the greater the share of honor for each of us.

origin: God’s will, I pray thee wish not one man more.
modern: In God’s name, I beg you not to wish for one more man.

origin: By Jove, I am not covetous for gold Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost; It yearns me not if men my garments wear; Such outward things dwell not in my desires.
modern: By God, I am not selfish when it comes to money: I don’t care who eats at my expense.

origin: But if it be a sin to covet honor, I am the most offending soul alive.
modern: But if it is a sin to be selfish about honor, I am the most guilty soul alive.

origin: No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England.
modern: No, my cousin, don’t wish that even one man who is now in England were here instead.

origin: God’s peace, I would not lose so great an honor As one man more, methinks, would share from me, For the best hope I have.
modern: By God, I wouldn’t lose as much honor as a single man more would cost me, I think—not even if it meant giving up my best hope for victory.

origin: Oh, do not wish one more!
modern: Oh, do not wish one more!

origin: His passport shall be made, And crowns for convoy put into his purse.
modern: He will be given safe conduct and money for his passage home.

origin: We would not die in that man’s company That fears his fellowship to die with us.
modern: We would not want to die in the company of a man who fears to die with us.

origin: He that shall see this day, and live old age, Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors And say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.” Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars, And say, “These wounds I had on Crispin’s day.”
modern: He who survives this day and lives to see old age shall yearly entertain his neighbors on the eve, saying, “Tomorrow is

origin: All things are ready if our minds be so.
modern: We’re ready if our minds are ready.

origin: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
modern: Let any man perish who isn’t ready now!

origin: Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?
modern: You don’t wish we had more help from England anymore, cousin?

origin: God be with you all.
modern: God be with you all.

origin: Tucket Once more I come to know of thee, King Harry, If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound, Before thy most assurèd overthrow.
modern: Once more I come to ask you, King Harry, if you’re ready to negotiate your ransom before your certain defeat.

origin: For certainly thou art so near the gulf Thou needs must be englutted.
modern: For assuredly, you are so near the abyss that you’re bound to be swallowed up.

origin: Besides, in mercy, The constable desires thee thou wilt mind Thy followers of repentance, that their souls May make a peaceful and a sweet retire From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies Must lie and fester.
modern: Moreover, out of mercy, the Constable urges you to remind your men to make their peace with God and repent, so that their souls may depart sweetly and peacefully from these fields where, poor wretches, their bodies will likely fall and fester.

origin: Who hath sent thee now?
modern: Who sent you this time?

origin: The constable of France.
modern: The Constable of France.

origin: I pray thee, bear my former answer back.
modern: Be good enough to take back the same answer I gave before.

origin: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.
modern: Tell them to capture me, then sell my bones.

origin: The man that once did sell the lion’s skin While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.
modern: The man that once sold the skin of a lion while the beast still lived died hunting him.

origin: A many of our bodies shall no doubt Find native graves, upon the which, I trust, Shall witness live in brass of this day’s work.
modern: And on their graves, I trust, the story of this day’s work will be written in brass.

origin: And those that leave their valiant bones in France, Dying like men though buried in your dunghills, They shall be famed; for there the sun shall greet them And draw their honors reeking up to heaven, Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime,
modern: And those who leave their valiant bones in France, dying like men though buried in your dunghills—they’ll be remembered, too.

origin: Besides, their writers say, King Pepin, which deposèd Childeric, Did, as heir general, being descended Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair, Make claim and title to the crown of France.
modern: Besides, according to the French historians, King Pepin, who deposed Childeric, based his own claim to the crown of France on his descent from Blithild, the daughter of King Clothair.

origin: Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great, To find his title with some shows of truth, Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught, Conveyed himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare, Daughter to Charlemagne, who was the son To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son Of Charles the Great.
modern: Another case: Hugh Capet, who usurped the crown from Charles the duke of Lorraine—sole male heir in a direct line from Charles the Great—passed himself off as heir to Lady Lingare, daughter of Charlemagne, who was the son of Lewis the Emperor (who was the son of Charles the Great), in order to give his claim to the throne more validity (though, in fact, the claim was completely false and worthless).

origin: Also King Lewis the Tenth, Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, Could not keep quiet in his conscience, Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine, By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France.
modern: Another case: King Lewis the Tenth, who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, could not rest easy as king until he was assured that Queen Isabel, his grandmother, was a direct descendent of the Lady Ermengare, daughter of the aforementioned Charles duke of Lorraine, by which marriage the line of Charles the Great was reunited with the throne of France.

origin: So that, as clear as is the summer’s sun, King Pepin’s title and Hugh Capet’s claim, King Lewis his satisfaction, all appear To hold in right and title of the female.
modern: Thus, it should be clear as day that King Pepin’s title, Hugh Capet’s claim, and the resolution of King Lewis’s doubts all plainly derive from the female.

origin: Let me speak proudly: tell the constable We are but warriors for the working day; Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched With rainy marching in the painful field.
modern: Let me speak proudly: tell the Constable we’re only workaday soldiers.

origin: There’s not a piece of feather in our host— Good argument, I hope, we will not fly— And time hath worn us into slovenry.
modern: There’s not a strand of feather left in our whole army—a good sign, I hope, that we won’t fly away like birds—and time on the field has made us slovenly.

origin: If they do this, As, if God please, they shall, my ransom then Will soon be levied.
modern: If they do this, as they will, God willing, my ransom will soon be raised.

origin: Herald, save thou thy labor.
modern: Herald, spare yourself.

origin: Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald.
modern: Don’t come again to ask for my ransom, good messenger.

origin: They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints, Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them, Shall yield them little.
modern: I swear the only ransom will be these bones of mine.

origin: Tell the constable.
modern: Tell the constable that.

origin: I shall, King Harry.
modern: I shall, King Harry.

origin: And so fare thee well.
modern: And so farewell.

origin: Thou never shalt hear herald anymore.
modern: You’ll never hear from the herald again.

origin: I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom.
modern: I’m afraid you’ll come to me again for ransom.

origin: My lord, most humbly on my knee I beg The leading of the vaward.
modern: My lord, most humbly on bended knee I beg you to grant me the leading of the vanguard.

origin: Take it, brave York.
modern: Take it, brave York.

origin: Now, soldiers, march away, And how Thou pleasest, God, dispose the day.
modern: Now, soldiers, advance.

origin: Yield, cur.
modern: Surrender, dog!

origin: He says his name is Master Fer.
modern: Is that a lot of      He says his name is Master Fer.

origin: Master Fer.
modern: Master Fer!

origin: What are his words?
modern: What does he say?

origin: He prays you to save his life.
modern: He begs you to spare his life.

origin: He is a gentleman of a good house, and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns.
modern: He is a gentleman of a good family, and for his ransom, he will give you two hundred crowns.

origin: Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns will take.
modern: Tell him my fury will abate, and I’ll take the crowns.

origin: Expound unto me, boy.
modern: Explain, boy.

origin: He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks, and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one, as he thinks, the most brave, valorous, and thrice- worthy seigneur of England.
modern: He thanks you on his knees many times and considers himself fortunate to have fallen into the hands of one, as he thinks, who is the bravest, most valorous, and thrice-worthy gentleman of England.

origin: As I suck blood, I will some mercy show.
modern: As I get to leech him, I will show some mercy.

origin: Follow me.
modern: Follow me.

origin: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart.
modern: I never heard so loud a voice issue from such an empty heart.

origin: I must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our camp.
modern: I have to stay with the servants, who are with our camp’s luggage.

origin: The French might have a good prey of us if he knew of it, for there is none to guard it but boys.
modern: We’re sitting ducks for the French, if they only knew it, for there is no one guarding it but boys.

origin: Reproach and everlasting shame Sits mocking in our plumes.
modern: Regret and everlasting shame sit on our helmets, mocking us.

origin: Do not run away.
modern: Do not run away.

origin: Why, all our ranks are broke.
modern: Our men have all broken ranks.

origin: O perdurable shame!
modern: O, everlasting shame!

origin: Let’s stab ourselves.
modern: Let’s fall on our swords.

origin: Be these the wretches that we played at dice for?
modern: Are these the wretches that we threw dice for?

origin: Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?
modern: Is this the king we offered to ransom?

origin: Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame!
modern: Shame, eternal shame, and nothing but shame!

origin: Let us die.
modern: Let us die honorably.

origin: And he that will not follow Bourbon now, Let him go hence, and with his cap in hand Like a base pander hold the chamber door, Whilst by a slave, no gentler than my dog, His fairest daughter is contaminate.
modern: He who will not follow me now, let him depart and stand in the doorway like a pimp, cap in hand, while some slave, no nobler than my dog, violates his daughter.

origin: Disorder, that hath spoiled us, friend us now.
modern: Maybe we can benefit from the same chaos that has defeated us.

origin: Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.
modern: Let’s go offer up our lives

origin: We are enough yet living in the field To smother up the English in our throngs, If any order might be thought upon.
modern: There are enough of us still alive in the field to overcome the English with our numbers if we could just restore some kind of order.

origin: The devil take order now!
modern: The hell with order!

origin: I’ll to the throng.
modern: I’m going back into battle.

origin: Let life be short, else shame will be too long.
modern: Let life be short so that shame won’t last too long.

origin: Yet keep the French the field.
modern: The French are still fighting.

origin: The duke of York commends him to your Majesty.
modern: The duke of York sends your Majesty his respects.

origin: Lives he, good uncle?
modern: Is he still alive, good uncle?

origin: Thrice within this hour I saw him down, thrice up again and fighting.
modern: Three times in an hour I saw him down, and three times up again and fighting.

origin: From helmet to the spur, all blood he was.
modern: He was covered with blood from his helmet to his spurs.

origin: In which array, brave soldier, doth he lie, Larding the plain, and by his bloody side, Yoke-fellow to his honor-owing wounds, The noble earl of Suffolk also lies.
modern: By his side lies the noble earl of Suffolk, York’s comrade and equal in brave wounds.

origin: Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over, Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes That bloodily did yawn upon his face.
modern: Suffolk died first, and York, cut to pieces, came to him where he lay in his blood and took him by the face, kissing his gashes.

origin: And cries aloud, “Tarry, my cousin Suffolk.
modern: He cried out, “Wait for me, dear cousin.

origin: My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.
modern: My soul will keep yours company on the way to heaven.

origin: Tarry, sweet soul, for mine; then fly abreast, As in this glorious and well-foughten field We kept together in our chivalry.” Upon these words I came and cheered him up.
modern: Wait for mine, sweet soul.

origin: The French have reinforced their scattered men.
modern: The French have reinforced their scattered men.

origin: Then every soldier kill his prisoners.
modern: Then every soldier must kill his prisoners.

origin: Give the word through.
modern: Spread the word.

origin: So do the kings of France unto this day, Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law To bar your Highness claiming from the female And rather choose to hide them in a net Than amply to imbar their crooked titles Usurped from you and your progenitors.
modern: To this day, the kings of France follow this unspoken rule, even though they point to this Salic law to bar your Highness from inheriting it through the female line.

origin: May I with right and conscience make this claim?
modern: Can I justifiably and in good conscience make this claim?

origin: The sin upon my head, dread sovereign, For in the Book of Numbers is it writ: “When the man dies, let the inheritance Descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord, Stand for your own, unwind your bloody flag, Look back into your mighty ancestors.
modern: For it is written in the book of Numbers: “When the man dies, let the inheritance descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord, claim what is yours.

origin: Go, my dread lord, to your great-grandsire’s tomb, From whom you claim.
modern: Go to the tomb of your great-grandfather, from whom your own title to the crown derives.

origin: Invoke his warlike spirit And your great-uncle’s, Edward the Black Prince, Who on the French ground played a tragedy, Making defeat on the full power of France Whiles his most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion’s whelp Forage in blood of French nobility.
modern: Invoke his warlike spirit and that of Edward the Black Prince, your great-uncle, who fought a tragic battle on French soil, routing the French army in full force while his mighty father stood by on a hilltop, smiling to see his son steeped in the blood of French noblemen.

origin: O noble English, that could entertain With half their forces the full pride of France And let another half stand laughing by, All out of work and cold for action!
modern: O noble English, who could take on the entire French army with only half their forces, leaving the other half to stand by, idle and laughing.

origin: Awake remembrance of these valiant dead And with your puissant arm renew their feats.
modern: Awaken the memory of those valiant ancestors and with your own powerful arm make their deeds live again.

origin: You are their heir, you sit upon their throne, The blood and courage that renownèd them Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege Is in the very May-morn of his youth, Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.
modern: You are their heir and sit on their throne, and the blood and courage that glorified them run in your veins.

origin: Kill the poys and the luggage!
modern: To kill the boys with the luggage!

origin: Tis expressly against the law of arms.
modern: It’s expressly against the rules of combat.

origin: Tis as arrant a piece of knavery, mark you now, as can be offert, in your conscience now, is it not?
modern: It’s as complete a work of villainy as any that could be thought up.

origin: Tis certain there’s not a boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter.
modern: There’s certainly not a boy left alive, and it was done by the cowardly rascals who were running from the battle.

origin: Besides, they have burned and carried away all that was in the king’s tent, wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner’s throat.
modern: On top of this, they’ve either burned or carried away everything that was in the king’s tent.

origin: Oh, ’tis a gallant king!
modern: Oh, he’s a gallant king!

origin: Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain Gower.
modern: Yes, he was born at Monmouth, Captain Gower.

origin: Why, I pray you, is not “pig” great?
modern: And is “pig” not the same as “great,” may I ask?

origin: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.
modern: The pig or the mighty or the huge or the magnanimous—they all mean the same thing, with some variation.

origin: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
modern: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.

origin: His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.
modern: His father was Philip of Macedon, as I remember.

origin: I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn.
modern: I think that Macedon is indeed where Alexander was born.

origin: I tell you, Captain, if you look in the maps of the 'orld, I warrant you shall find, in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations, look you, is both alike.
modern: I tell you, Captain, if you look at a map of the world, I’ll bet you will find, comparing Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations, see, are very similar.

origin: There is a river in Macedon, and there is also, moreover, a river at Monmouth.
modern: There is a river in Macedon, and there is likewise a river in Monmouth.

origin: It is called Wye at Monmouth, but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river.
modern: The river in Monmouth is called Wye, but the name of the other river has gone out of my head.

origin: But ’tis all one; ’tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both.
modern: Nevertheless, it’s all one—the two rivers are as alike as my fingers are to my fingers, and there are salmon in both.

origin: If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in all things.
modern: If you look closely at Alexander’s life, Harry of Monmouth’s stands up fairly well by comparison—for there are analogies in everything.

origin: Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and also being a little intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, look you, kill his best friend, Cleitus.
modern: Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his angers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and also being a little the worse for drink, killed his best friend Cleitus in a drunken rage, see.

origin: It is not well done, mark you now, to take the tales out of my mouth ere it is made and finished.
modern: It is not courteous, you know, to assume you know my meaning before I’ve finished talking.

origin: I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it.
modern: I’m speaking purely in analogies and comparisons.

origin: Sir John Falstaff.
modern: Sir John Falstaff.

origin: That is he.
modern: That’s the one.

origin: I’ll tell you, there is good men porn at Monmouth.
modern: I tell you, there are good men born at Monmouth.

origin: Here comes his Majesty.
modern: Here comes his Majesty.

origin: I was not angry since I came to France Until this instant.
modern: I was not angry since I came to France until this instant.

origin: Take a trumpet, herald.
modern: Take a trumpet, herald.

origin: Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill.
modern: Ride out to the horsemen on that hill.

origin: If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field.
modern: If they seek battle with us, have them come down or else clear the field.

origin: They do offend our sight.
modern: The sight of them is offensive.

origin: If they’ll do neither, we will come to them And make them skirr away as swift as stones Enforcèd from the old Assyrian slings.
modern: If they’ll do neither, we’ll come to them and make them fly like stones shot from powerful slings.

origin: Go and tell them so.
modern: Go and tell them this.

origin: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.
modern: Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

origin: His eyes are humbler than they used to be.
modern: He looks humbler than he used to.

origin: Know’st thou not That I have fined these bones of mine for ransom?
modern: Don’t you know that I have offered these bones of mine for ransom?

origin: Com’st thou again for ransom?
modern: Are you coming again for ransom?

origin: No, great king.
modern: No, great king.

origin: I come to thee for charitable license, That we may wander o'er this bloody field To book our dead and then to bury them; To sort our nobles from our common men, For many of our princes—woe the while!— Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood.
modern: I come to ask you out of charity to let us wander over this bloody field to record the numbers of our dead and bury them, separating our nobles from the common men, for many of our princes—alas!—lie drowned and soaked in the blood of mercenary soldiers.

origin: So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs In blood of princes, and the wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage Yerk out their armèd heels at their dead masters, Killing them twice.
modern: Likewise, our common men lie drenched in the blood of princes, and their wounded steeds, ankle-deep in gore, struggle and, raging wildly, stamp on their dead masters with their hooves, killing them a second time.

origin: Oh, give us leave, great king, To view the field in safety and dispose Of their dead bodies.
modern: Oh, give us permission, great king, to search the field in safety and dispose of our dead bodies.

origin: The day is yours.
modern: You won it.

origin: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!
modern: God, not our strength, be praised!

origin: What is this castle called that stands hard by?
modern: What is the name of the castle that stands over there?

origin: They call it Agincourt.
modern: Agincourt.

origin: Then call we this the field of Agincourt, Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.
modern: Then we’ll call this the Battle of Agincourt, fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.

origin: Your grandfather of famous memory, an’t please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in France.
modern: If I may say so, your Majesty, your famous grandfather and your great-uncle Edward, the Black Prince of Wales—or so I’ve read in the history books—fought a very brave battle here in France.

origin: They did, Fluellen.
modern: They did, Fluellen.

origin: Your Majesty says very true.
modern: Your Majesty is quite right.

origin: If your Majesties is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, your Majesty know, to this hour is an honorable badge of the service.
modern: If your Majesties recall it, the Welsh fought very valiantly in a garden where there were leeks growing, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps which, your Majesty knows, is to this day a badge of honorable military service.

origin: And I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy’s day.
modern: I do believe your Majesty takes no shame in wearing the leek on Saint Davy’s Day.

origin: I wear it for a memorable honor, For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.
modern: I wear it with pride, for I am Welsh you know, good countryman.

origin: Thanks, good my countryman.
modern: Thanks, my good countryman.

origin: By Jeshu, I am your Majesty’s countryman, I care not who know it.
modern: By Jesus, I am your Majesty’s countryman, and I don’t care who knows it.

origin: I will confess it to all the 'orld.
modern: I will confess it to all the world.

origin: I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty, praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.
modern: I needn’t be ashamed of your Majesty, God be praised, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.

origin: God keep me so.—Our heralds go with him.
modern: God keep me so.—Heralds, go with him.

origin: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead On both our parts.
modern: Bring me an exact report of the number of dead on both sides.

origin: Soldier, you must come to the king.
modern: Soldier, you must come to the king.

origin: Soldier, why wear’st thou that glove in thy cap?
modern: Soldier, why are you wearing that glove in your cap?

origin: An’t please your Majesty, ’tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.
modern: If it pleases your Majesty, it is the token of a man I must fight with, if he’s still alive.

origin: An Englishman?
modern: An Englishman?

origin: He is a craven and a villain else, an ’t please your Majesty, in my conscience.
modern: If I may say so, your Majesty, as I see it he would be a coward and a villain not to.

origin: It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort, quite from the answer of his degree.
modern: It may be that his antagonist is a gentleman of very high degree, quite outside of his own sphere.

origin: Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is, as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself, it is necessary, look your Grace, that he keep his vow and his oath.
modern: Even if he were as important a man as the devil—as Lucifer or Beelzebub himself—he’s required, see, your Grace, to keep his vow.

origin: If he be perjured, see you now, his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jack Sauce as ever his black shoe trod upon God’s ground and His earth, in my conscience, la.
modern: If he backs down, he’ll become as notorious a villain and as saucy a Jack as ever walked on God’s earth, in my opinion.

origin: Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meet’st the fellow.
modern: Then keep your vow, fellow, when you meet the man.

origin: So I will, my liege, as I live.
modern: So I will, my liege.

origin: Who serv’st thou under?
modern: Whom do you serve under?

origin: Under Captain Gower, my liege.
modern: Under Captain Gower, my liege.

origin: Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars.
modern: Gower is a good captain, and is well versed and well read in the wars.

origin: Call him hither to me, soldier.
modern: Have him come to me here, soldier.

origin: I will, my liege.
modern: I will, my liege.

origin: Here, Fluellen, wear thou this favor for me and stick it in thy cap.
modern: Here, Fluellen, stick this in your cap.

origin: Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects.
modern: Your Grace does me as great an honor as could be wished by any of his subjects.

origin: Know’st thou Gower?
modern: Do you know Captain Gower?

origin: He is my dear friend, an please you.
modern: He is my dear friend, your Majesty.

origin: Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.
modern: Go find him, please, and bring him to my tent.

origin: I will fetch him.
modern: I’ll fetch him.

origin: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.
modern: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, follow Fluellen at a close distance.

origin: The glove which I have given him for a favor May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear.
modern: The glove which I have given him to wear may possibly win him a box on the ear.

origin: I by bargain should Wear it myself.
modern: According to an agreement, I should wear it myself.

origin: Follow, and see there be no harm between them.
modern: Follow and see to it that nothing serious happens between them.

origin: Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.
modern: You come with me, uncle of Exeter.

origin: I warrant it is to knight you, Captain.
modern: I’m sure it is to knight you, Captain.

origin: God’s will and His pleasure, Captain, I beseech you now, come apace to the king.
modern: As it is God’s will and pleasure, Captain, I entreat you to come quickly to the king.

origin: Sir, know you this glove?
modern: Sir, do you recognize this glove?

origin: Know the glove!
modern: Know the glove!

origin: I know the glove is a glove.
modern: I know the glove is a glove.

origin: I know this, and thus I challenge it.
modern: Well, I recognize this one  Good God!

origin: Sblood, an arrant traitor as any ’s in the universal world, or in France, or in England!
modern: As absolute a traitor as any in the whole entire world—or even France or England!

origin: Do you think I’ll be forsworn?
modern: Do you think I’d break my oath?

origin: Stand away, Captain Gower.
modern: Stand aside, Captain Gower.

origin: I will give treason his payment into plows, I warrant you.
modern: I’ll reward treason with blows, I promise you.

origin: I am no traitor.
modern: I’m not a traitor.

origin: He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.
modern: Arrest him: he’s a friend of the duke of Alençon’s.

origin: My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
modern: My Lord of Warwick, a most corrupt treason—God be praised for it!—has been discovered, as plain as any you’d hope to see on a summer’s day.

origin: Here is his Majesty.
modern: Here is his Majesty.

origin: My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that, look your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alençon.
modern: My liege, this man is a villain and a traitor, who—see, your Grace—has struck the glove which your Majesty took from Alençon’s helmet.

origin: My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow of it.
modern: My liege, this was my glove.

origin: I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.
modern: I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.

origin: Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty’s manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is.
modern: Your Majesty, see here—if it won’t offend your Grace—what a complete, rascally, beggarly, lousy rat this is.

origin: I hope your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness, and will avouchment that this is the glove of Alençon that your Majesty is give me, in your conscience now.
modern: I hope your Majesty will, in all good conscience, bear me out and vouch for the fact that this is the glove of Alençon and that your Majesty gave it to me.

origin: Twas I indeed thou promised’st to strike, And thou hast given me most bitter terms.
modern: It was I, in fact, whom you promised to strike.

origin: They know your Grace hath cause and means and might; So hath your Highness.
modern: And so you do.

origin: Never king of England Had nobles richer, and more loyal subjects, Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England And lie pavilioned in the fields of France.
modern: Their bodies may remain here in England, but their hearts are encamped on the fields of France already.

origin: Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear liege, With blood and sword and fire to win your right, In aid whereof we of the spiritualty Will raise your Highness such a mighty sum As never did the clergy at one time Bring in to any of your ancestors.
modern: Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear king, to win back what’s rightfully yours with blood and sword and fire.

origin: We do not mean the coursing snatchers only, But fear the main intendment of the Scot, Who hath been still a giddy neighbor to us.
modern: What we have to worry about is a full-scale invasion from Scotland—always an unreliable neighbor.

origin: An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.
modern: If it pleases your Majesty, let his neck pay the price, if there is any martial law in the world.

origin: How canst thou make me satisfaction?
modern: How can you square things with me?

origin: It was ourself thou didst abuse.
modern: You abused me to my face.

origin: Your Majesty came not like yourself.
modern: Your Majesty didn’t present yourself as the king.

origin: You appeared to me but as a common man.
modern: You represented yourself as just a common man.

origin: And what your Highness suffered under that shape, I beseech you take it for your own fault and not mine, for, had you been as I took you for, I made no offense.
modern: Anything your Highness suffered in that disguise, I beg you to see it as your own fault and not mine, because if you’d been what I took you for, there would have been no offense.

origin: Therefore, I beseech your Highness pardon me.
modern: Therefore, I beg your Highness, pardon me.

origin: I will none of your money.
modern: I’ll have none of your money.

origin: It is with a good will.
modern: It’s meant in good will.

origin: I can tell you it will serve you to mend your shoes.
modern: I tell you, you can use it to get your shoes fixed.

origin: Come, wherefore should you be so pashful?
modern: Come, why be so hesitant?

origin: Your shoes is not so good.
modern: Your shoes are in pretty bad shape.

origin: Tis a good silling, I warrant you, or I will change it.
modern: It’s a good shilling, I promise you.

origin: Now, herald, are the dead numbered?
modern: Now, herald, have the dead been counted?

origin: Here is the number of the slaughtered French.
modern: Here is the count of the slaughtered French.

origin: What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?
modern: What prisoners of rank have been taken, uncle?

origin: This note doth tell me of ten thousand French That in the field lie slain.
modern: This paper tells me of ten thousand Frenchmen who lie dead on the battlefield.

origin: Of princes in this number And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead One hundred twenty-six.
modern: Among them are one hundred twenty-six princes and standard-bearing nobles.

origin: Added to these, Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen, Eight thousand and four hundred, of the which, Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights.
modern: Add to these eight thousand four hundred knights, squires, and brave gentlemen, five hundred of whom were given the title of knight only yesterday.

origin: So that in these ten thousand they have lost, There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.
modern: Among the ten thousand the French have lost only sixteen hundred are mercenaries.

origin: The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, And gentlemen of blood and quality.
modern: The rest of the dead are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, and gentlemen of birth and rank.

origin: Of lusty earls: Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.
modern: Of brave earls, Grandpré and Roussi, Fauconberg and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.

origin: Where is the number of our English dead?
modern: Where is the number of our English dead?

origin: When, without stratagem, But in plain shock and even play of battle, Was ever known so great and little loss On one part and on th' other?
modern: When was there ever before so great a loss on one side and so little on the other, in the ordinary and equal clash of battle?

origin: Take it, God, For it is none but thine.
modern: Take credit, God, for it is no one’s doing but yours.

origin: Tis wonderful.
modern: It’s unbelievable.

origin: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement: That God fought for us.
modern: Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement—that God fought for us.

origin: Yes, my conscience, He did us great good.
modern: Yes, I truly think He did great good.

origin: Do we all holy rites.
modern: We’ll perform all the holy rites.

origin: Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story That I may prompt them; and of such as have, I humbly pray them to admit th' excuse Of time, of numbers, and due course of things, Which cannot in their huge and proper life Be here presented.
modern: As for those who have, I beg you to excuse the gaps in time, and the many people and things that cannot be represented here in all their magnitude and proper form.

origin: So let him land, And solemnly see him set on to London.
modern: Let’s have him land and solemnly proceed to London.

origin: So swift a pace hath thought that even now You may imagine him upon Blackheath, Where that his lords desire him to have borne His bruisèd helmet and his bended sword Before him through the city.
modern: Thoughts work so quickly that even now you can imagine him on Blackheath, where his lords suggest that he should carry his battle-scarred sword and helmet on a procession through the city.

origin: He forbids it, Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride, Giving full trophy, signal, and ostent Quite from himself, to God.
modern: He refuses, as he is free of vanity and self-serving pride and ascribes all the glory and responsibility for victory to God.

origin: But now behold, In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought, How London doth pour out her citizens.
modern: Now in the factory of thought, create the image of all London pouring forth into the streets.

origin: The Mayor and all his brethren in best sort, Like to the senators of th' antique Rome, With the plebeians swarming at their heels, Go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in— As, by a lower but loving likelihood,
modern: Picture the mayor and all his brother citizens dressed in their best as they go forth like senators of ancient Rome to welcome home their conquering Caesar.

origin: Then brook abridgment, and your eyes advance After your thoughts, straight back again to France.
modern: Skip over all the particularities between then and Harry’s return to France.

origin: Saint Davy’s day is past.
modern: Saint Davy’s Day has passed.

origin: There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in all things.
modern: There are reasons and causes why and how in everything.

origin: It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him, but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires.
modern: We were somewhere where I couldn’t pick a fight with him, but I’ve decided to wear it in my cap until I see him again, whereupon I’ll give him a little piece of my mind.

origin: Why, here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.
modern: And here he comes, puffing himself up like a turkey.

origin: Ha, art thou bedlam?
modern: Are you mad?

origin: Hence.
modern: Away!

origin: I am qualmish at the smell of leek.
modern: The smell of leek turns my stomach.

origin: I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek.
modern: I wonder if you’d be so good, you lousy, rotten villain, to grant my wish and my request and gratify me, see, by eating this leek.

origin: Because, look you, you do not love it, nor your affections and your appetites and your digestions does not agree with it, I would desire you to eat it.
