origin: Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar.
modern: I took your hands in friendship, but, indeed, I was distracted when I looked down at Caesar.

origin: Friends am I with you all and love you all Upon this hope: that you shall give me reasons Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.
modern: I am friends with you all and love you all, on one condition—that you prove to me that Caesar was dangerous.

origin: Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.
modern: Our reasons are so well considered that even if you, Antony, were Caesar’s son, you would be satisfied with them.

origin: You shall, Mark Antony.
modern: You may, Mark Antony.

origin: Brutus, a word with you.
modern: Brutus, may I have a word with you?

origin: It shall advantage more than do us wrong.
modern: It’ll help us more than hurt us.

origin: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body.
modern: Mark Antony, take Caesar’s body.

origin: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us, But speak all good you can devise of Caesar, And say you do ’t by our permission.
modern: You will not blame us in your funeral speech, but will say all the good you want to about Caesar and that you do it by our permission.

origin: And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.
modern: And you’ll speak on the same platform as I do, after I’m done.

origin: Be it so.
modern: So be it.

origin: I do desire no more.
modern: I don’t want anything more.

origin: Prepare the body then, and follow us.
modern: Prepare the body, then, and follow us.

origin: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever livèd in the tide of times.
modern: You are what’s left of the noblest man that ever lived.

origin: Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
modern: Pity the hand that shed this valuable blood.

origin: Over thy wounds now do I prophesy— Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue— A curse shall light upon the limbs of men.
modern: Over your wounds—which, like speechless mouths, open their red lips, as though to beg me to speak—I predict that a curse will fall upon the bodies of men.

origin: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy.
modern: Fierce civil war will paralyze all of Italy.

origin: I do, Mark Antony.
modern: I do, Mark Antony.

origin: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.
modern: Caesar wrote for him to come to Rome.

origin: He did receive his letters and is coming.
modern: He received Caesar’s letters, and he is coming.

origin: Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes, Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, Began to water.
modern: Grief seems to be contagious, for my eyes, seeing the tears in yours, began to fill.

origin: Is thy master coming?
modern: Is your master coming?

origin: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.
modern: He rests tonight within twenty-one miles of Rome.

origin: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced.
modern: Report back to him fast and tell him what has happened.

origin: Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse Into the marketplace.
modern: Don’t go back until I’ve carried the corpse into the marketplace.

origin: Lend me your hand.
modern: Help me here.

origin: We will be satisfied!
modern: We want answers.

origin: Let us be satisfied!
modern: Give us answers.

origin: Then follow me and give me audience, friends.
modern: Then follow me and listen to my speech, friends.

origin: Cassius, go you into the other street And part the numbers.
modern: Cassius, go to the next street and divide the crowd.

origin: Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here.
modern: Let those who will hear me speak stay.

origin: Those that will follow Cassius, go with him, And public reasons shall be renderèd Of Caesar’s death.
modern: Lead those away who will follow you, and we’ll explain publicly the reasons for Caesar’s death.

origin: I will hear Brutus speak.
modern: I’ll listen to Brutus.

origin: I will hear Cassius and compare their reasons When severally we hear them renderèd.
modern: I’ll listen to Cassius, and we will compare their reasons.

origin: The noble Brutus is ascended.
modern: Noble Brutus has mounted the platform.

origin: Be patient till the last.
modern: Be patient until I finish.

origin: Romans, countrymen, and lovers!
modern: Romans, countrymen, and friends!

origin: Hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear.
modern: Listen to my reasons and be silent so you can hear.

origin: Believe me for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor that you may believe.
modern: Believe me on my honor and keep my honor in mind, so you may believe me.

origin: Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge.
modern: Be wise when you criticize me and keep your minds alert so you can judge me fairly.

origin: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his.
modern: If there’s anyone in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, I say to him that my love for Caesar was no less than his.

origin: If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.
modern: If, then, that friend demands to know why I rose up against Caesar, this is my answer: it’s not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more.

origin: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men?
modern: Would you rather that Caesar were living and we would all go to our graves as slaves, or that Caesar were dead and we all lived as free men?

origin: As Caesar loved me, I weep for him.
modern: I weep for Caesar in that he was good to me.

origin: As he was fortunate, I rejoice at it.
modern: I rejoice in his good fortune.

origin: As he was valiant, I honor him.
modern: I honor him for being brave.

origin: But, as he was ambitious, I slew him.
modern: But his ambition—for that, I killed him.

origin: There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition.
modern: There are tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his bravery, and death for his ambition.

origin: Who is here so base that would be a bondman?
modern: Who here is so low that he wants to be a slave?

origin: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
modern: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended.

origin: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman?
modern: Who here is so barbarous that he doesn’t want to be a Roman?

origin: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
modern: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I’ve offended.

origin: Who is here so vile that will not love his country?
modern: Who here is so vile that he doesn’t love his country?

origin: If any, speak—for him have I offended.
modern: If there are any, speak, for it is he whom I have offended.

origin: I pause for a reply.
modern: I will pause for a reply.

origin: None, Brutus, none.
modern: No one, Brutus, no one.

origin: Then none have I offended.
modern: Then I have offended no one.

origin: I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus.
modern: I’ve done no more to Caesar than you will do to me.

origin: The question of his death is enrolled in the Capitol.
modern: The reasons for his death are recorded in the Capitol.

origin: His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
modern: His glory has not been diminished where he earned it, nor have those offenses for which he was killed been exaggerated.

origin: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying—a place in the commonwealth—as which of you shall not?
modern: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no part in the killing, will benefit from his death—receiving a share in the commonwealth, as you all will.

origin: Live, Brutus!
modern: Live, Brutus!

origin: Live, live!
modern: Live, live!

origin: Bring him with triumph home unto his house!
modern: Let’s carry him in triumph to his house!

origin: I am not gamesome.
modern: I don’t like sports.

origin: I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.
modern: I’m not competitive like Antony.

origin: Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires.
modern: But don’t let me keep you from going, Cassius.

origin: I’ll leave you.
modern: I’ll go my own way.

origin: Cassius, Be not deceived.
modern: Cassius, don’t take it badly.

origin: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?
modern: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

origin: Let him be Caesar!
modern: Let him become Caesar!

origin: Caesar’s better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus!
modern: Caesar’s better qualities exist in Brutus, and we will crown him.

origin: We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.
modern: We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and celebration!

origin: My countrymen—     Peace, silence!
modern: My countrymen— Silence!

origin: Brutus speaks.
modern: Brutus speaks.

origin: Peace, ho!
modern: Quiet there!

origin: Good countrymen, let me depart alone.
modern: Good countrymen, let me leave alone.

origin: I do entreat you, not a man depart, Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.
modern: I ask that none of you leave, except myself, until Antony has finished.

origin: Let him go up into the public chair.
modern: Let him mount the pulpit.

origin: We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up.
modern: We’ll listen to him.

origin: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.
modern: For Brutus’s sake, I am indebted to you.

origin: What does he say of Brutus?
modern: What does he say about Brutus?

origin: He says for Brutus' sake He finds himself beholding to us all.
modern: He says that for Brutus’s sake he finds himself indebted to us all.

origin: Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.
modern: He’d better not speak badly of Brutus here.

origin: This Caesar was a tyrant.
modern: Caesar was a tyrant.

origin: Nay, that’s certain.
modern: That’s for sure.

origin: We are blest that Rome is rid of him.
modern: We’re lucky that Rome is rid of him.

origin: Peace!
modern: Quiet!

origin: Let us hear what Antony can say.
modern: Let’s hear what Antony has to say.

origin: You gentle Romans—     Peace, ho!
modern: You gentle Romans— Quiet there!

origin: Let us hear him.
modern: Let us hear him.

origin: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears.
modern: Friends, Romans, countrymen, give me your attention.

origin: I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
modern: I have come here to bury Caesar, not to praise him.

origin: The evil that men do lives after them; The good is oft interrèd with their bones.
modern: The evil that men do is remembered after their deaths, but the good is often buried with them.

origin: So let it be with Caesar.
modern: It might as well be the same with Caesar.

origin: The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious.
modern: The noble Brutus told you that Caesar was ambitious.

origin: If it were so, it was a grievous fault, And grievously hath Caesar answered it.
modern: If that’s true, it’s a serious fault, and Caesar has paid seriously for it.

origin: Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest— For Brutus is an honorable man; So are they all, all honorable men— Come I to speak in Caesar’s funeral.
modern: With the permission of Brutus and the others—for Brutus is an honorable man; they are all honorable men—I have come here to speak at Caesar’s funeral.

origin: He was my friend, faithful and just to me.
modern: He was my friend, he was faithful and just to me.

origin: But Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honorable man.
modern: But Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man.

origin: He hath brought many captives home to Rome Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill.
modern: He brought many captives home to Rome whose ransoms brought wealth to the city.

origin: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?
modern: Is this the work of an ambitious man?

origin: When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept.
modern: When the poor cried, Caesar cried too.

origin: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff.
modern: Ambition shouldn’t be so soft.

origin: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honorable man.
modern: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, and Brutus is an honorable man.

origin: You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse.
modern: You all saw that on the Lupercal feast day I offered him a king’s crown three times, and he refused it three times.

origin: Was this ambition?
modern: Was this ambition?

origin: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know.
modern: I am not here to disprove what Brutus has said, but to say what  I think there’s a lot of sense in what he says.

origin: If thou consider rightly of the matter, Caesar has had great wrong.
modern: If you think about it correctly, Caesar has suffered a great wrong.

origin: Has he, masters?
modern: Has he, sirs?

origin: He would not take the crown.
modern: Caesar wouldn’t take the crown.

origin: Therefore ’tis certain he was not ambitious.
modern: Therefore it’s certain that he wasn’t ambitious.

origin: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
modern: If it turns out he wasn’t, certain people are going to get it.

origin: Poor soul!
modern: Poor man!

origin: His eyes are red as fire with weeping.
modern: Antony’s eyes are fiery red from crying.

origin: There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.
modern: There isn’t a nobler man than Antony in all of Rome.

origin: But yesterday the word of Caesar might Have stood against the world.
modern: Only yesterday the word of Caesar might have stood against the world.

origin: Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence.
modern: Now he lies there worth nothing, and no one is so humble as to show him respect.

origin: O masters, if I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong— Who, you all know, are honorable men.
modern: Oh, sirs, if I stirred your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I would offend Brutus and Cassius, who, you all know, are honorable men.

origin: I will not do them wrong.
modern: I will not do them wrong.

origin: I rather choose To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, Than I will wrong such honorable men.
modern: I would rather wrong the dead, and wrong myself and you, than wrong such honorable men.

origin: But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar.
modern: But here’s a paper with Caesar’s seal on it.

origin: Let but the commons hear this testament— Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read— And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood, Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue.
modern: If you could only hear this testament—which, excuse me, I don’t intend to read aloud—you would kiss dead Caesar’s wounds and dip your handkerchiefs in his sacred blood, and beg for a lock of hair to remember him by.

origin: We’ll hear the will.
modern: We want to hear the will.

origin: Read it, Mark Antony!
modern: Read it, Mark Antony.

origin: The will, the will!
modern: The will, the will!

origin: We will hear Caesar’s will.
modern: We want to hear Caesar’s will.

origin: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.
modern: It isn’t proper for you to know how much Caesar loved you.

origin: You are not wood, you are not stones, but men.
modern: You aren’t wood, you aren’t stones—you’re men.

origin: And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar, It will inflame you, it will make you mad.
modern: And, being men, the contents of Caesar’s will would enrage you.

origin: Read the will.
modern: Read the will.

origin: We’ll hear it, Antony.
modern: We want to hear it, Antony.

origin: You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will.
modern: You have to read us the will, Caesar’s will.

origin: Will you be patient?
modern: Will you be patient?

origin: Will you stay awhile?
modern: Will you wait awhile?

origin: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it.
modern: I’ve said too much in telling you of it.

origin: I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.
modern: I’m afraid that I wrong the honorable men whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.

origin: They were traitors!
modern: They were traitors.

origin: The testament!
modern: The testament!

origin: They were villains, murderers.
modern: They were villains, murderers.

origin: The will!
modern: The will!

origin: Read the will!
modern: Read the will!

origin: You will compel me, then, to read the will?
modern: You force me to read the will, then?

origin: Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar, And let me show you him that made the will.
modern: Then make a circle around Caesar’s corpse, and let me show you the man who made this will.

origin: Shall I descend?
modern: Shall I come down?

origin: And will you give me leave?
modern: Will you let me?

origin: Come down.
modern: Come down.

origin: Descend.
modern: Descend.

origin: You shall have leave.
modern: We’ll let you.

origin: Stand from the hearse.
modern: Stand away from the hearse.

origin: Stand from the body.
modern: Stand away from the body.

origin: Room for Antony, most noble Antony!
modern: Make room for Antony, most noble Antony!

origin: Nay, press not so upon me.
modern: No, don’t press up against me.

origin: Stand far off.
modern: Stand further away.

origin: Stand back.
modern: Stand back.

origin: Room!
modern: Give him room.

origin: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
modern: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.

origin: You all do know this mantle.
modern: You all know this cloak.

origin: I remember The first time ever Caesar put it on.
modern: I remember the first time Caesar ever put it on.

origin: Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent, That day he overcame the Nervii.
modern: It was the day he overcame the Nervii warriors.

origin: Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through.
modern: Look, here’s where Cassius’s dagger pierced it.

origin: See what a rent the envious Casca made.
modern: See the wound that Casca made.

origin: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.
modern: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel.

origin: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
modern: The gods know how dearly Caesar loved him!

origin: This was the most unkindest cut of all.
modern: This was the most unkind cut of all.

origin: Then burst his mighty heart, And, in his mantle muffling up his face, Even at the base of Pompey’s statue, Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.
modern: And at the base of Pompey’s statue, with his cloak covering his face, which was dripping with blood the whole time, great Caesar fell.

origin: O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!
modern: Oh, what a fall it was, my countrymen!

origin: Then I, and you, and all of us fell down, Whilst bloody treason flourished over us.
modern: Then you and I and all of us fell down, while bloody treason triumphed.

origin: Oh, now you weep, and, I perceive, you feel The dint of pity.
modern: Oh, now you weep, and I sense that you feel pity.

origin: These are gracious drops.
modern: These are gracious tears.

origin: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold Our Caesar’s vesture wounded?
modern: But if it overwhelms you to look at Caesar’s wounded cloak, how will you feel, kind men, now?

origin: Look you here, Here is himself, marred, as you see, with traitors.
modern: Look at this, here is the man—scarred, as you can see, by traitors.

origin: O piteous spectacle!
modern: Oh, what a sad sight!

origin: O noble Caesar!
modern: Oh, noble Caesar!

origin: O woeful day!
modern: Oh, sad day!

origin: O traitors, villains!
modern: Oh, traitors, villains!

origin: O most bloody sight!
modern: Oh, most bloody sight!

origin: About!
modern: Revenge!

origin: Seek!
modern: Seek!

origin: Burn!
modern: Burn!

origin: Fire!
modern: Set fire!

origin: Kill!
modern: Kill!

origin: Slay!
modern: Slay!

origin: Stay, countrymen.
modern: Wait, countrymen.

origin: Peace there!
modern: Quiet there!

origin: Hear the noble Antony.
modern: Listen to the noble Antony.

origin: They that have done this deed are honorable.
modern: Those who have done this deed are honorable.

origin: What private griefs they have, alas, I know not, That made them do it.
modern: I don’t know what private grudges they had that made them do it.

origin: They are wise and honorable, And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.
modern: They’re wise and honorable, and will no doubt give you reasons for it.

origin: I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
modern: I haven’t come to steal your loyalty, friends.

origin: For I have neither wit nor words nor worth, Action nor utterance nor the power of speech, To stir men’s blood.
modern: I have neither cleverness nor rhetorical skill nor the authority nor gesture nor eloquence nor the power of speech to stir men up.

origin: I only speak right on.
modern: I just speak directly.

origin: But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
modern: But if I were Brutus and Brutus were me, then I’d stir you up, and install in each of Caesar’s wounds the kind of voice that could convince even stones to rise up and mutiny.

origin: We’ll mutiny.
modern: We’ll mutiny.

origin: We’ll burn the house of Brutus.
modern: We’ll burn Brutus’s house.

origin: Away, then!
modern: Let’s go, then!

origin: Come, seek the conspirators.
modern: Come, find the conspirators!

origin: Yet hear me, countrymen.
modern: Wait, and listen to me, countrymen.

origin: Yet hear me speak.
modern: Quiet!

origin: Peace, ho!
modern: Wait!

origin: Hear Antony.
modern: Listen to Antony.

origin: Most noble Antony!
modern: Most noble Antony!

origin: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what.
modern: Why, friends, you don’t even know what you’re doing yet.

origin: Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
modern: What has Caesar done to deserve your love?

origin: Alas, you know not.
modern: Alas, you don’t know.

origin: I must tell you then.
modern: I must tell you then.

origin: You have forgot the will I told you of.
modern: You’ve forgotten the will I told you about.

origin: Most true.
modern: Yes!

origin: The will!
modern: The will!

origin: Let’s stay and hear the will.
modern: Let’s stay and hear the will!

origin: Most noble Caesar!
modern: Most noble Caesar!

origin: We’ll revenge his death.
modern: We’ll revenge his death.

origin: O royal Caesar!
modern: Oh, royal Caesar!

origin: Hear me with patience.
modern: Listen to me patiently.

origin: Peace, ho!
modern: Quiet, there!

origin: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks, His private arbors and new-planted orchards, On this side Tiber.
modern: Also, he’s left you all his walkways—in his private gardens and newly planted orchards—on this side of the Tiber River.

origin: He hath left them you And to your heirs forever—common pleasures, To walk abroad and recreate yourselves.
modern: He’s left them to you and to your heirs forever—public pleasures in which you will be able to stroll and relax.

origin: Here was a Caesar!
modern: Here was a Caesar!

origin: When comes such another?
modern: When will there be another like him?

origin: We’ll burn his body in the holy place, And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
modern: We’ll burn his body in the holy place and use the brands to set the traitors' houses on fire.

origin: Take up the body.
modern: Take up the body.

origin: Go fetch fire.
modern: We’ll start a fire.

origin: Now let it work.
modern: Now, let it work.

origin: How now, fellow?
modern: What’s up, my man?

origin: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.
modern: Sir, Octavius has already arrived in Rome.

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.
modern: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.

origin: And thither will I straight to visit him.
modern: I will go straight to visit him.

origin: He comes upon a wish.
modern: I ask for him, and he comes.

origin: Fortune is merry, And in this mood will give us anything.
modern: Fortune is happy today and, in this mood, will give us anything we want.

origin: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.
modern: I heard Octavius say that Brutus and Cassius have ridden like madmen through the gates of Rome.

origin: Belike they had some notice of the people How I had moved them.
modern: They probably received warning about how much I stirred up the people.

origin: Bring me to Octavius.
modern: Take me to Octavius.

origin: Tis just.
modern: That’s true.

origin: And it is very much lamented, Brutus, That you have no such mirrors as will turn Your hidden worthiness into your eye That you might see your shadow.
modern: And it’s too bad, Brutus, that you don’t have any mirrors that could display your hidden excellence to yourself.

origin: I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome, Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus And groaning underneath this age’s yoke, Have wished that noble Brutus had his eyes.
modern: I’ve heard many of the noblest Romans—next to immortal Caesar—speaking of you, complaining of the tyranny of today’s government, and wishing that your eyes were working better.

origin: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me?
modern: What dangers are you trying to lead me into, Cassius, that you want me to look inside myself for something that’s not there?

origin: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear.
modern: I’ll tell you, good Brutus.

origin: And since you know you cannot see yourself So well as by reflection, I, your glass, Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of.
modern: And since you know you can see yourself best by reflection, I’ll be your mirror and show you, without exaggeration, things inside you that you can’t see.

origin: And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus.
modern: And don’t be suspicious of me, noble Brutus.

origin: Were I a common laugher, or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester, if you know That I do fawn on men and hug them hard And, after, scandal them, or if you know That I profess myself in banqueting To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.
modern: If I were your average fool, or if I made my feelings for you worthless by making the same promises of friendship to everybody, or if you’d seen me first flattering men, hugging them tightly, and later slandering them behind their backs, or if you hear that I drunkenly declare friendship at banquets with all the rabble, only then, of course, go ahead and assume I’m dangerous.

origin: What means this shouting?
modern: Why are they shouting?

origin: I do fear, the people Choose Caesar for their king.
modern: I’m afraid the people have made Caesar their king.

origin: Ay, do you fear it?
modern: Really, are you afraid of that?

origin: Then must I think you would not have it so.
modern: Then I have to assume you don’t want him to be king.

origin: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unlucky charge my fantasy.
modern: I dreamed last night that I feasted with Caesar, and unlucky signs overwhelmed my imagination.

origin: I have no will to wander forth of doors, Yet something leads me forth.
modern: I have no desire to go outside, yet something leads me there.

origin: What is your name?
modern: What’s your name?

origin: Whither are you going?
modern: Where are you going?

origin: Where do you dwell?
modern: Where do you live?

origin: Are you a married man or a bachelor?
modern: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

origin: Answer every man directly.
modern: Answer all of us, now.

origin: Ay, and briefly.
modern: Yes, and be brief.

origin: Ay, and wisely.
modern: Yes, and be wise.

origin: What is my name?
modern: What’s my name?

origin: Whither am I going?
modern: Where am I going?

origin: Where do I dwell?
modern: Where do I live?

origin: Am I a married man or a bachelor?
modern: Am I a married man or a bachelor?

origin: Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.
modern: Then, to answer every man briefly, wisely, and truthfully—wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

origin: That’s as much as to say they are fools that marry.
modern: You imply that married men are fools.

origin: You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear.
modern: You’ll get a blow from me for that, I think.

origin: Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.
modern: Right this instant, I’m going to Caesar’s funeral.

origin: As a friend or an enemy?
modern: As a friend or an enemy?

origin: As a friend.
modern: As a friend.

origin: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.
modern: Getting right to the point, I live near the Capitol.

origin: Your name, sir, truly.
modern: Tell us your name, sir, truthfully.

origin: Truly, my name is Cinna.
modern: Truthfully, my name is Cinna.

origin: Tear him to pieces.
modern: Tear him to pieces.

origin: He’s a conspirator.
modern: He’s a conspirator.

origin: I am not Cinna the conspirator.
modern: I’m not Cinna the conspirator.

origin: It is no matter.
modern: It doesn’t matter.

origin: His name’s Cinna.
modern: His name’s Cinna.

origin: Pluck but his name out of his heart and turn him going.
modern: Pull only his name out of his heart and let him go.

origin: Tear him, tear him!
modern: Tear him apart, tear him up!

origin: Come, brands, ho, firebrands.
modern: Come, firebrands, over here!

origin: To Brutus', to Cassius', burn all.
modern: To Brutus’s, to Cassius’s, let’s burn them all.

origin: Some to Decius' house and some to Casca’s.
modern: Some of you go to Decius’s house and some to Casca’s.

origin: Some to Ligarius'.
modern: Some to Ligarius’s.

origin: Away, go!
modern: Go!

origin: These many, then, shall die.
modern: These ones, then, will be assassinated.

origin: Their names are pricked.
modern: Their names are marked.

origin: I do consent—    Prick him down, Antony.
modern: I agree— Put a mark next to his name too, Antony.

origin: Upon condition Publius shall not live, Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.
modern: On the condition that your sister’s son, Publius, also must die, Mark Antony.

origin: He shall not live.
modern: He will die.

origin: Look, with a spot I damn him.
modern: See—I’ve sealed his fate with this mark next to his name.

origin: But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house.
modern: But, Lepidus, go to Caesar’s house.

origin: Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies.
modern: Bring his will here, and we’ll figure out a way to reduce his bequests to the people.

origin: What, shall I find you here?
modern: Will you be here when I return?

origin: Or here, or at the Capitol.
modern: Either here or at the Capitol.

origin: This is a slight, unmeritable man, Meet to be sent on errands.
modern: He’s an unremarkable man, fit only to be sent on errands.

origin: Is it fit, The threefold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?
modern: Does it really make sense, once we divide the world into three parts, that he should be one of the three rulers?

origin: Octavius, I have seen more days than you.
modern: Octavius, I’m older than you are.

origin: And though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way.
modern: And although we’re giving these honors to this man so that he shares some of the blame for what we’re doing, he’ll carry these honors like a jackass carries gold—groaning and sweating under the load, either led or pushed, as we direct him.

origin: And having brought our treasure where we will, Then take we down his load and turn him off, Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears And graze in commons.
modern: Once he’s carried our treasure where we want it, we’ll free him of the load and turn him loose like a jackass, to shake his ears and graze in the public pastures.

origin: You may do your will, But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.
modern: You can do what you want, but he’s an experienced and honorable soldier.

origin: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that I do appoint him store of provender.
modern: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that reason I give him all the hay he wants.

origin: Stand, ho!
modern: Stop.

origin: Give the word, ho, and stand.
modern: Pass on the command to halt!

origin: What now, Lucillius?
modern: What’s happening now, Lucillius?

origin: Is Cassius near?
modern: Is Cassius nearby?

origin: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.
modern: He’s nearby, and Pindarus has come to salute you on behalf of his master.

origin: But if he be at hand I shall be satisfied.
modern: If he’s nearby, I want an explanation.

origin: He is not doubted.—A word, Lucillius.
modern: Can I have a word with you, Lucillius?

origin: But not with such familiar instances Nor with such free and friendly conference As he hath used of old.
modern: He received me with courtesy and sufficient respect, but not with affection, nor with as much open and friendly conversation as he once greeted me.

origin: Thou hast described A hot friend cooling.
modern: You’ve described a warm friend who’s cooling off.

origin: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.
modern: Plain and simple loyalty doesn’t make anyone act phony.

origin: But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle.
modern: But insincere men, like horses who are too lively at the start of a race, make a big show of their spirit.

origin: But when they should endure the bloody spur, They fall their crests and, like deceitful jades, Sink in the trial.
modern: But when push comes to shove, they droop like those horses that are all show and slow to a crawl.

origin: Comes his army on?
modern: Is his army approaching?

origin: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered.
modern: They plan to spend the night in Sardis.

origin: The greater part, the horse in general, Are come with Cassius.
modern: The larger part, the main body of cavalry, are coming with Cassius.

origin: Hark!
modern: Look!

origin: He is arrived.
modern: He’s arrived.

origin: March gently on to meet him.
modern: March to meet him at a dignified pace.

origin: Stand, ho!
modern: Halt.

origin: Stand, ho!
modern: Halt!

origin: Speak the word along.
modern: Pass the order along.

origin: Stand!
modern: Halt!

origin: Stand!
modern: Halt!

origin: Stand!
modern: Halt!

origin: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.
modern: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

origin: Judge me, you gods!
modern: Let the gods judge me!

origin: Wrong I mine enemies?
modern: Do I mistreat even my enemies?

origin: And when you do them—     Cassius, be content.
modern: And when you do— Cassius, calm down.

origin: Before the eyes of both our armies here, Which should perceive nothing but love from us, Let us not wrangle.
modern: Let’s not argue here in front of both our armies, which ought to see nothing but love between us.

origin: Bid them move away.
modern: Order them to move back.

origin: Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs, And I will give you audience.
modern: Then, in my tent, you can elaborate on your complaints, and I’ll listen.

origin: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.
modern: Pindarus, order our commanders to lead their charges a little ways away from this ground.

origin: Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.
modern: Have Lucius and Titinius guard the door.

origin: That you have wronged me doth appear in this: You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians, Wherein my letters, praying on his side Because I knew the man, were slighted off.
modern: My evidence that you have wronged me is that you condemned and disgraced Lucius Pella for taking bribes here from the Sardinians, and you ignored my letters, where I argued that he was innocent; I know the man.

origin: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.
modern: You wronged yourself to write on behalf of such a man.

origin: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment.
modern: In a time like this, it doesn’t make sense to criticize every offense.

origin: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself Are much condemned to have an itching palm, To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers.
modern: I’ll tell you, Cassius, you yourself have been called greedy and been accused of giving your positions to undeserving men in exchange for gold.

origin: I “an itching palm”!
modern: Me, “greedy”!

origin: You know that you are Brutus that speak this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.
modern: You know, if you were anyone other than Brutus, that speech would be your last.

origin: The name of Cassius honors this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
modern: The name of Cassius gives credit to these corrupt actions, and so they go unpunished.

origin: Chastisement!
modern: Unpunished!

origin: Remember March, the ides of March remember.
modern: Remember March, March 15th.

origin: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
modern: Didn’t great Caesar bleed for the sake of justice?

origin: What villain touched his body, that did stab, And not for justice?
modern: Who among us stabbed him for any cause but justice?

origin: What, shall one of us That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes, And sell the mighty space of our large honors For so much trash as may be graspèd thus?
modern: Should we now dirty our fingers with lowly bribes and sell the mighty offices that we hold for whatever money we can get our hands on?

origin: I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman.
modern: I’d rather be a dog and howl at the moon than be that kind of Roman.

origin: Brutus, bait not me.
modern: Brutus, do not provoke me.

origin: I’ll not endure it.
modern: I will not take it.

origin: You forget yourself To hedge me in.
modern: You’re forgetting yourself when you back me into a corner.

origin: I am a soldier, I, Older in practice, abler than yourself To make conditions.
modern: I’m a soldier, more experienced than you, and better able to give orders.

origin: Go to.
modern: Get lost!

origin: You are not, Cassius.
modern: You are not, Cassius.

origin: I am.
modern: I am.

origin: I say you are not.
modern: I say you’re not.

origin: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself.
modern: Don’t provoke me any further or I’ll forget to restrain myself.

origin: Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.
modern: If you care about your health, you won’t push me any further.

origin: Away, slight man!
modern: Leave, you little man.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is this possible?

origin: Hear me, for I will speak.
modern: Listen to me, for I have something to tell you.

origin: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?
modern: Does a madman scare me when he stares at me?

origin: But wherefore do you hold me here so long?
modern: But why do you keep me here so long?

origin: What is it that you would impart to me?
modern: What do you want to tell me?

origin: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, As well as I do know your outward favor.
modern: I know this quality in you, Brutus—it’s as familiar to me as your face.

origin: Well, honor is the subject of my story.
modern: Indeed, honor is what I want to talk to you about.

origin: I cannot tell what you and other men Think of this life, but, for my single self, I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself.
modern: I don’t know what you and other men think of this life, but as for me, I’d rather not live at all than live to worship a man as ordinary as myself.

origin: I was born free as Caesar.
modern: I was born as free as Caesar.

origin: So were you.
modern: So were you.

origin: We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter’s cold as well as he.
modern: We both have eaten as well, and we can both endure the cold winter as well as he.

origin: For once upon a raw and gusty day, The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores, Caesar said to me, “Darest thou, Cassius, now Leap in with me into this angry flood And swim to yonder point?” Upon the word, Accoutred as I was, I plungèd in And bade him follow.
modern: Once, on a cold and windy day, when the river Tiber was crashing against its banks, Caesar said to me, “Cassius, I dare you to jump into this rough water with me and swim to that point there.” As soon as he spoke, though I was fully dressed, I plunged in and called for him to follow.

origin: So indeed he did.
modern: And he did.

origin: But ere we could arrive the point proposed, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I sink!” I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor, Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber Did I the tired Caesar.
modern: But before we reached the end point, Caesar cried, “Help me, Cassius, or I will sink!” And just as Aeneas, the hero who founded Rome, emerged from the fires of Troy with his elderly father Anchises on his shoulder, so I emerged from the Tiber carrying the tired Caesar.

origin: All this”?
modern: All this”?

origin: Ay, more.
modern: Yes, and more.

origin: Fret till your proud heart break.
modern: Go ahead—rage till your proud heart breaks.

origin: Go show your slaves how choleric you are And make your bondmen tremble.
modern: Show your slaves how mad you are, and make your servants tremble.

origin: Is it come to this?
modern: Has it come to this?

origin: You say you are a better soldier.
modern: You say you’re a better soldier.

origin: Let it appear so.
modern: Show it!

origin: Make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well.
modern: Make your boasts come true, and I’ll be thrilled.

origin: For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.
modern: I’m always happy to hear about brave men.

origin: You wrong me every way.
modern: You wrong me in every way.

origin: You wrong me, Brutus.
modern: You wrong me, Brutus.

origin: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
modern: When Caesar was alive, even he wouldn’t dare anger me like this.

origin: Peace, peace!
modern: Oh, be quiet.

origin: You durst not so have tempted him.
modern: You wouldn’t have dared to tempt him so.

origin: I durst not!
modern: I wouldn’t have dared!

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: For your life you durst not.
modern: You wouldn’t have dared, out of fear for your life.

origin: Do not presume too much upon my love.
modern: Don’t take my love for granted.

origin: I may do that I shall be sorry for.
modern: I might do something I’ll be sorry for.

origin: You have done that you should be sorry for.
modern: You’ve already done something you should be sorry for.

origin: There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, For I am armed so strong in honesty That they pass by me as the idle wind, Which I respect not.
modern: Your threats don’t scare me, Cassius, because I’m so secure in my honesty and integrity that they pass me by like a weak breeze.

origin: I did send To you for gold to pay my legions, Which you denied me.
modern: I asked you for gold to pay my soldiers, and you wouldn’t give it to me.

origin: Was that done like Cassius?
modern: Was that the Caius Cassius that I knew?

origin: Should I have answered Caius Cassius so?
modern: And would I have ever done that to you?

origin: I denied you not.
modern: I didn’t refuse you.

origin: You did.
modern: You did.

origin: I did not.
modern: I didn’t.

origin: He was but a fool that brought My answer back.
modern: The man who brought my answer to you was a fool.

origin: Brutus hath rived my heart.
modern: You have broken my heart.

origin: A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
modern: A friend should put up with his friend’s weaknesses, but you exaggerate mine.

origin: I do not, till you practice them on me.
modern: I don’t until you practice them on me.

origin: You love me not.
modern: You don’t love me.

origin: I do not like your faults.
modern: I don’t like your faults.

origin: A friendly eye could never see such faults.
modern: A friend would never see those faults.

origin: A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear As huge as high Olympus.
modern: No, a flatterer wouldn’t, even if the faults were as huge as Mount Olympus.

origin: Oh, I could weep My spirit from mine eyes.
modern: Oh, I could weep my soul right out of myself!

origin: Sheathe your dagger.
modern: There’s my dagger  Put away your dagger.

origin: Be angry when you will, it shall have scope.
modern: Be angry whenever you like, it’s all right with me.

origin: Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor.
modern: Do whatever you want, and I’ll say your insults are just a bad mood.

origin: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.
modern: When I said that, I was angry too.

origin: Do you confess so much?
modern: You admit it, then?

origin: Give me your hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: And my heart too.
modern: And my heart too.

origin: O Brutus!
modern: Oh, Brutus!

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: Have not you love enough to bear with me, When that rash humor which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?
modern: Do you have enough love for me to be patient when my bad temper, which I inherited from my mother, makes me forget how I should behave?

origin: Yes, Cassius.
modern: Yes, Cassius.

origin: And from henceforth When you are over-earnest with your Brutus, He’ll think your mother chides and leave you so.
modern: And from now on, when you get hot with me, I’ll assume it’s your mother speaking and leave it at that.

origin: How now?
modern: What’s this!

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: For shame, you generals!
modern: You should be ashamed, generals!

origin: What do you mean?
modern: What do you think you’re doing?

origin: Love, and be friends as two such men should be.
modern: Love each other and be friends, like two such men should be.

origin: For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.
modern: Listen to me, because I’m older than you, surely.

origin: Bear with him, Brutus.
modern: Be patient with him, Brutus.

origin: Tis his fashion.
modern: That’s just how he is.

origin: I’ll know his humor when he knows his time.
modern: I’ll humor him when he learns how to behave.

origin: What should the wars do with these jigging fools?
modern: What should we do with all these rhyming fools that follow us from post to post?

origin: Companion, hence!
modern: Get out of here, my friend.

origin: Away, away, be gone.
modern: Away, away, be gone.

origin: Lucillius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.
modern: Lucillius and Titinius, order the commanders to have the men camp for the night.

origin: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you, Immediately to us.
modern: And return to us immediately, bringing Messala with you.

origin: I did not think you could have been so angry.
modern: I didn’t think you could even be so angry.

origin: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.
modern: Oh Cassius, I’m tired out by many sorrows.

origin: Portia is dead.
modern: Portia is dead.

origin: Ha, Portia?
modern: Portia!

origin: She is dead.
modern: She is dead.

origin: O insupportable and touching loss!
modern: What an irreplaceable and grievous loss!

origin: Upon what sickness?
modern: What sickness did she die of?

origin: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong—for with her death That tidings came—with this she fell distract And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.
modern: She was worried about my absence, and about the fact that young Octavius and Mark Antony have grown so strong—which I found out at the same time as the news of her death.

origin: And died so?
modern: And that’s how she died?

origin: Even so.
modern: Yes, like that.

origin: O ye immortal gods!
modern: Oh, immortal gods!

origin: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.
modern: My heart is thirsty for that noble promise.

origin: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup.
modern: Fill my cup, Lucius, until the wine overflows it.

origin: I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
modern: I cannot drink too much of Brutus’s love.

origin: Now sit we close about this taper here And call in question our necessities.
modern: Now let’s sit closely around this candle and discuss our needs.

origin: Portia, art thou gone?
modern: Portia, are you really gone?

origin: No more, I pray you.
modern: No more about that, please.

origin: Messala, I have here receivèd letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
modern: Messala, I have received these letters explaining that young Octavius and Mark Antony are rushing toward Philippi and bearing down upon us with a mighty power.

origin: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.
modern: I have received letters that say the same.

origin: With what addition?
modern: And anything else?

origin: That by proscription and bills of outlawry, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators.
modern: That with a series of legal writs, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus have put a hundred senators to death.

origin: Therein our letters do not well agree.
modern: On that point, our letters don’t agree.

origin: Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.
modern: My letters say only seventy senators were killed, one being Cicero.

origin: Cicero one?
modern: Cicero too?

origin: Cicero is dead, And by that order of proscription.
modern: Cicero is dead, by their decree.

origin: No, Messala.
modern: No, Messala.

origin: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
modern: And you haven’t heard any news about her in your letters?

origin: Nothing, Messala.
modern: Nothing, Messala.

origin: That methinks is strange.
modern: I think that’s strange.

origin: Why ask you?
modern: Why do you ask?

origin: Hear you aught of her in yours?
modern: Have you heard something of her in your letters?

origin: No, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

origin: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.
modern: Now, as you’re a Roman, tell me the truth.

origin: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell.
modern: Then you must take the truth I have to tell like a Roman.

origin: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
modern: It’s certain that she is dead, and she died in a strange way.

origin: Why, farewell, Portia.
modern: Well, good-bye, Portia.

origin: We must die, Messala.
modern: We all must die, Messala.

origin: With meditating that she must die once, I have the patience to endure it now.
modern: Having already thought about the fact that she would have to die sometime, I can endure her death now.

origin: Even so great men great losses should endure.
modern: That’s the way great men ought to endure great losses.

origin: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.
modern: I’ve practiced Stoicism with as much devotion as you, but I still couldn’t bear this news like you do.

origin: Well, to our work alive.
modern: Well, let’s move on to our work with the living.

origin: What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently?
modern: What do you think of marching to Philippi immediately?

origin: I do not think it good.
modern: I don’t think it’s a good idea.

origin: Your reason?
modern: Why not?

origin: This it is: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us.
modern: Here’s why: it’d be better for the enemy to come after us.

origin: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.
modern: That way, he’ll waste his provisions and tire out his soldiers, weakening his own capacities, while we, lying still, are rested, energetic, and nimble.

origin: The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged, From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back.
modern: If we meet him at Philippi, these people will be at our backs.

origin: Hear me, good brother— Under your pardon.
modern: Listen to me, good brother.

origin: You must note beside, That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe.
modern: Our regiments are full to the brim; our cause is ready.

origin: The enemy increaseth every day.
modern: The enemy gets larger each day.

origin: We, at the height, are ready to decline.
modern: We, now at our largest, can only decrease.

origin: On such a full sea are we now afloat, And we must take the current when it serves Or lose our ventures.
modern: It’s on such a high tide that we’re now floating, and we must take the current when it is offered, or lose our campaign.

origin: Then, with your will, go on.
modern: If that’s what you want, all right.

origin: We’ll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.
modern: We’ll go forward with you and meet them at Philippi.

origin: The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity, Which we will niggard with a little rest.
modern: It’s now late at night, and actions must accommodate bodily needs, which we’ll satisfy with only a short rest.

origin: There is no more to say?
modern: That’s all there is to say.

origin: No more.
modern: There’s nothing else.

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night.

origin: Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.
modern: We’ll rise and leave early tomorrow.

origin: Lucius!
modern: Lucius!

origin: Never come such division ’tween our souls.
modern: Let’s pray that we never come into conflict like that again.

origin: Let it not, Brutus.
modern: Let’s not, Brutus.

origin: Is now become a god, and Cassius is A wretched creature and must bend his body If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.
modern: And this is the man who has now become a god, and I’m a wretched creature who must bow down if Caesar so much as carelessly nods my way.

origin: He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him, I did mark How he did shake.
modern: In Spain, Caesar had a fever, and it made him shake.

origin: Tis true, this god did shake!
modern: It’s true, this so-called “god”—he shook.

origin: His coward lips did from their color fly, And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world Did lose his luster.
modern: His cowardly lips turned white, and the same eye whose gaze terrifies the world lost its gleam.

origin: I did hear him groan, Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans Mark him and write his speeches in their books— “Alas,” it cried, “give me some drink, Titinius,” As a sick girl.
modern: I heard him groan—yes, I did—and the same tongue that ordered the Romans to obey him and transcribe his speeches in their books cried, “Give me some water, Titinius,” like a sick girl.

origin: Ye gods, it doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone.
modern: It astounds me that such a weak man could beat the whole world and carry the trophy of victory alone.

origin: Another general shout!
modern: More shouting!

origin: I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heaped on Caesar.
modern: I think this applause is for some new honors awarded to Caesar.

origin: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus, and we petty men Walk under his huge legs and peep about To find ourselves dishonorable graves.
modern: Why, Caesar straddles the narrow world like a giant, and we petty men walk under his huge legs and look forward only to dying dishonorably, as slaves.

origin: Men at some time are masters of their fates.
modern: Men can be masters of their fate.

origin: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars But in ourselves, that we are underlings.
modern: It is not destiny’s fault, but our own faults, that we’re slaves.

origin: Brutus and Caesar—what should be in that “Caesar”?
modern: Brutus” and “Caesar.” What’s so special about “Caesar”?

origin: Why should that name be sounded more than yours?
modern: Why should that name be proclaimed more than yours?

origin: Write them together, yours is as fair a name.
modern: Write them together—yours is just as good a name.

origin: Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well.
modern: Pronounce them—it is just as nice to say.

origin: Everything is well.
modern: Everything’s fine.

origin: Good night, my lord.
modern: Good night, my lord.

origin: Good night, good brother.
modern: Good night, good brother.

origin: Good night, Lord Brutus.
modern: Good night, Lord Brutus.

origin: Farewell, everyone.
modern: Farewell, everyone.

origin: Give me the gown.
modern: Give me the gown.

origin: Where is thy instrument?
modern: Where’s your lute?

origin: Here in the tent.
modern: Here in the tent.

origin: What, thou speak’st drowsily?
modern: What, are you sleepy?

origin: Call Claudio and some other of my men.
modern: Call Claudio and some of my other men.

origin: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
modern: I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

origin: Varrus and Claudio!
modern: Varrus and Claudio!

origin: Calls my lord?
modern: Did you call, my lord?

origin: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep.
modern: Sirs, I ask you to sleep in my tent.

origin: It may be I shall raise you by and by On business to my brother Cassius.
modern: I might wake you up in a while to send you on an errand to my brother Cassius.

origin: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.
modern: If you like, we’ll stand by and wait to do whatever you need.

origin: Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so.
modern: Look, Lucius, here’s the book I was searching for.

origin: I put it in the pocket of my gown.
modern: I put it in the pocket of my nightgown.

origin: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.
modern: I was sure that you hadn’t given it to me.

origin: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile, And touch thy instrument a strain or two?
modern: Can you stay awake a bit longer and play a few tunes on your lute?

origin: Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.
modern: Yes, my lord, if you would like.

origin: It does, my boy.
modern: I would, my boy.

origin: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
modern: I ask too much of you, but you’re always willing.

origin: It is my duty, sir.
modern: It’s my duty, sir.

origin: I should not urge thy duty past thy might.
modern: I shouldn’t make you do more than you’re able.

origin: I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
modern: I know that young men look forward to their rest.

origin: I have slept, my lord, already.
modern: I’ve already slept, my lord.

origin: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again.
modern: That was good planning, and you’ll sleep some more.

origin: I will not hold thee long.
modern: I won’t keep you very long.

origin: If I do live, I will be good to thee.
modern: If I live through this, I’ll be good to you.

origin: This is a sleepy tune.
modern: This is a sleepy tune.

origin: O murderous slumber, Layst thou thy leaden mace upon my boy That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night.
modern: Gentle boy, good night.

origin: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee.
modern: I won’t trouble you so much as to wake you.

origin: And, good boy, good night.
modern: Good night, good boy.

origin: Let me see, let me see.
modern: Let me see, let me see.

origin: Is not the leaf turned down Where I left reading?
modern: Didn’t I turn down the page where I left off reading?

origin: Here it is, I think.
modern: Here it is, I think.

origin: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition.
modern: I think it’s my bad eyesight that’s making me see this horrible vision.

origin: It comes upon me.—Art thou any thing?
modern: It’s coming toward me.

origin: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
modern: Are you a god, an angel, or a devil, that you make my blood turn cold and my hair stand up?

origin: Speak to me what thou art.
modern: Tell me what you are.

origin: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.
modern: I’m your evil spirit, Brutus.

origin: Why comest thou?
modern: Why do you come here?

origin: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.
modern: To tell you that you’ll see me at Philippi.

origin: Well, then I shall see thee again?
modern: Then I’ll see you again?

origin: Ay, at Philippi.
modern: Yes, at Philippi.

origin: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.
modern: Alright, then I’ll see you at Philippi.

origin: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.
modern: Evil spirit, I want to talk some more.

origin: Claudio!
modern: Claudio!

origin: The strings, my lord, are false.
modern: Claudio!

origin: He thinks he still is at his instrument.
modern: He thinks he’s still playing his instrument.

origin: Lucius, awake.
modern: Lucius, wake up!

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?
modern: Were you dreaming, Lucius?

origin: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
modern: My lord, I don’t think I cried out.

origin: Yes, that thou didst.
modern: Yes, you did.

origin: Didst thou see any thing?
modern: Did you see anything?

origin: Nothing, my lord.
modern: Nothing, my lord.

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?
modern: Why did you cry out in your sleep?

origin: Did we, my lord?
modern: Did we, my lord?

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Saw you anything?
modern: Did you see anything?

origin: No, my lord, I saw nothing.
modern: No, my lord, I didn’t see anything.

origin: Nor I, my lord.
modern: Me neither, my lord.

origin: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius.
modern: Go to my brother Cassius.

origin: Bid him set on his powers betimes before, And we will follow.
modern: Order him to advance his forces first thing, and we’ll follow.

origin: It shall be done, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd.
modern: Now, Antony, our prayers have been answered.

origin: You said the enemy would not come down But keep the hills and upper regions.
modern: You said the enemy wouldn’t come down but keep to the hills and upper regions.

origin: It proves not so.
modern: It seems not.

origin: Their battles are at hand.
modern: Their forces are nearby.

origin: They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.
modern: They intend to challenge us here at Philippi, responding to our challenge before we’ve even challenged him.

origin: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know Wherefore they do it.
modern: I know how they think, and I understand why they’re doing this.

origin: They could be content To visit other places, and come down With fearful bravery, thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage.
modern: They really wish they were somewhere else, but they want to descend on us, looking fierce so we’ll think they’re brave.

origin: But ’tis not so.
modern: But they aren’t.

origin: Prepare you, generals.
modern: Prepare yourselves, generals.

origin: The enemy comes on in gallant show.
modern: The enemy approaches with great display.

origin: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.
modern: They show their bloody heralds of battle, and something must be done immediately.

origin: Octavius, lead your battle softly on, Upon the left hand of the even field.
modern: Octavius, lead your forces slowly out to the left side of the level field.

origin: Upon the right hand I.
modern: I’ll go to the right side.

origin: Keep thou the left.
modern: You stay on the left.

origin: Why do you cross me in this exigent?
modern: Why are you defying me in this urgent matter?

origin: They stand and would have parley.
modern: They want to talk.

origin: Stand fast, Titinius.
modern: Stay here, Titinius.

origin: We must out and talk.
modern: We have to go out and talk to them.

origin: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
modern: Mark Antony, should we give the signal to attack?

origin: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.
modern: No, Octavius Caesar, we’ll respond to their charge.

origin: Make forth.
modern: Go forward.

origin: The generals would have some words.
modern: The generals want to speak with us.

origin: Words before blows.
modern: Words before fighting.

origin: Is it so, countrymen?
modern: Is that how it is, countrymen?

origin: Not that we love words better, as you do.
modern: Not that we love words more than fighting, like you do.

origin: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.
modern: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

origin: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.
modern: Brutus, you give a nice speech along with your evil strokes.

origin: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees And leave them honeyless.
modern: But your words are as sweet as honey—you’ve stolen from the bees and left them with nothing.

origin: Not stingless too?
modern: I took their stings too, wouldn’t you say?

origin: Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar.
modern: Villains, you didn’t do even that much when your vile daggers struck each other as they hacked up Caesar’s sides.

origin: Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself.
modern: Now, Brutus, you have only yourself to thank.

origin: When think you that the sword goes up again?
modern: Come, come, let’s remember why we’re here.

origin: Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds Be well avenged, or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.
modern: If arguing makes us sweat, the real trial will turn that water to blood.

origin: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands Unless thou bring’st them with thee.
modern: Caesar, you’re not going to be killed by a traitor—unless you kill yourself..

origin: So I hope.
modern: I hope you’re right.

origin: I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.
modern: I wasn’t born to die on your sword.

origin: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.
modern: If you were the noblest of your family, young man, you couldn’t die more honorably.

origin: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor, Joined with a masker and a reveler!
modern: An annoying schoolboy, unworthy of such an honor, joined by a masquerader and a partier!

origin: Old Cassius still.
modern: Still the same old Cassius!

origin: If you dare fight today, come to the field.
modern: If you dare to fight today, come to the field.

origin: If not, when you have stomachs.
modern: If not, come when you have the courage.

origin: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark!
modern: Now let the wind blow, waves swell, and ships sink!

origin: The storm is up and all is on the hazard.
modern: The storm has begun and everything is at stake.

origin: Messala!
modern: Messala!

origin: Messala, This is my birthday, as this very day Was Cassius born.
modern: Messala, today is my birthday—I was born on this very day.

origin: Give me thy hand, Messala.
modern: Give me your hand, Messala.

origin: Be thou my witness that against my will, As Pompey was, am I compelled to set Upon one battle all our liberties.
modern: You’ll be my witness that I’ve been forced, as Pompey was, to wager all of our freedoms on one battle.

origin: You know that I held Epicurus strong And his opinion.
modern: You know that I used to believe in Epicurus and his disregard for omens.

origin: Now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage.
modern: I’ve changed my mind now and partly believe in omens.

origin: Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched, Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands, Who to Philippi here consorted us.
modern: Traveling from Sardis, two mighty eagles fell on our front flag and perched there, eating from the hands of the soldiers who’d accompanied us to Philippi.

origin: This morning are they fled away and gone, And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us As we were sickly prey.
modern: This morning, they’ve flown away and in their place are ravens, crows, and kites, flying over our heads and looking down on us, as though we were sickly prey.

origin: Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.
modern: Their shadows are like a deadly canopy, under which our army lies, ready to die.

origin: Believe not so.
modern: Don’t believe in this.

origin: I but believe it partly, For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly.
modern: I only partly believe it, for I’m enthusiastic and resolved to meet all dangers without wavering.

origin: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
modern: Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly with us today so that we, who want peace, can live on to old age!

origin: But since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let’s reason with the worst that may befall.
modern: But since the affairs of men are always uncertain, let’s think about the worst that may happen.

origin: If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together.
modern: If we lose this battle, this is the last time we’ll speak to each other.

origin: What are you then determinèd to do?
modern: If we lose, what do you plan to do?

origin: Brutus” will start a spirit as soon as “Caesar.” Now in the names of all the gods at once, Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed That he is grown so great?
modern: Cast spells with them, and “Brutus” will call up a ghost as well as “Caesar.” Now, in the name of all the gods, I ask you what food does Caesar eat that has made him grow so great?

origin: Age, thou art shamed!
modern: Our era should be ashamed!

origin: Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!
modern: Rome has lost the ability to raise noble men!

origin: When went there by an age, since the great flood, But it was famed with more than with one man?
modern: When was there ever an age, since the beginning of time, that didn’t feature more than one famous man?

origin: When could they say till now, that talked of Rome, That her wide walks encompassed but one man?
modern: Until now, no one could say that only one man mattered in all of vast Rome.

origin: Now is it Rome indeed, and room enough, When there is in it but one only man.
modern: Now, though, in all of Rome, there’s room for only one man.

origin: Oh, you and I have heard our fathers say, There was a Brutus once that would have brooked Th' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome As easily as a king.
modern: You and I have heard our fathers talk of another Brutus—your ancestor—who would’ve let the devil himself reign in his Roman Republic before he let a king rule.

origin: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous.
modern: I have no doubt that you love me.

origin: What you would work me to, I have some aim.
modern: I’m beginning to understand what you want me to do.

origin: How I have thought of this and of these times I shall recount hereafter.
modern: What I think about this, and about what’s happening here in Rome, I’ll tell you later.

origin: For this present, I would not, so with love I might entreat you, Be any further moved.
modern: For now, don’t try to persuade me anymore—I ask you as a friend.

origin: What you have said I will consider, what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things.
modern: I’ll think over what you’ve said, I’ll listen patiently to whatever else you have to say, and I’ll find a good time for us to discuss further such weighty matters.

origin: Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us.
modern: Until then, my noble friend, think about this: I’d rather be a poor villager than call myself a citizen of Rome under the hard conditions that this time is likely to put us through.

origin: I am glad that my weak words Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.
modern: I’m glad that my weak words have provoked even this small show of protest from you.

origin: Then if we lose this battle You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?
modern: Then if we lose this battle, you’ll be willing to be led in chains through the streets of Rome?

origin: No, Cassius, no.
modern: No, Cassius, no.

origin: Think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome.
modern: Don’t imagine that I’ll ever allow myself to return to Rome in chains.

origin: He bears too great a mind.
modern: My mind is too great for that.

origin: Therefore our everlasting farewell take.
modern: Therefore, accept my everlasting farewell.

origin: Forever and forever farewell, Cassius.
modern: Forever and forever, farewell, Cassius!

origin: If we do meet again, why, we shall smile.
modern: If we meet again, then we’ll smile.

origin: If not, why then this parting was well made.
modern: If not, then this parting was well done.

origin: Forever and forever farewell, Brutus.
modern: Forever and forever, farewell, Brutus!

origin: If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed.
modern: If we meet again, then we’ll smile indeed.

origin: If not, ’tis true this parting was well made.
modern: If not, it’s true, this parting was well done.

origin: Why then, lead on.
modern: Well, lead on.

origin: Oh, that a man might know The end of this day’s business ere it come!
modern: Oh, I wish I could know what will happen today before it happens!

origin: But it sufficeth that the day will end, And then the end is known.—Come, ho!
modern: But it’s enough to know that the day will end, and then the end will be known.

origin: Away!
modern: Let’s go!

origin: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side.
modern: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these dispatches to our forces on the other side.

origin: Let them set on at once, for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow.
modern: They should advance immediately, because I sense Octavius’s side is a bit fainthearted right now, and a sudden push would overthrow him.

origin: Ride, ride, Messala.
modern: Ride, ride, Messala.

origin: Myself have to mine own turned enemy.
modern: I’ve become an enemy to my own soldiers!

origin: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly.
modern: Oh, Cassius, Brutus gave the orders too soon.

origin: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off.
modern: Retreat further, my lord, retreat further.

origin: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.
modern: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord.

origin: Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.
modern: Therefore you must run, noble Cassius.

origin: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?
modern: Are those my tents on fire?

origin: They are, my lord.
modern: They are, my lord.

origin: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.
modern: Titinius, if you love me, get on your horse and spur him on until he’s brought you to those troops and back again, so that I can find out whether those troops are friends or enemies.

origin: I will be here again, even with a thought.
modern: I’ll be back quicker than you can think a thought.

origin: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill.
modern: Go, Pindarus, climb a little higher on this hill.

origin: My sight was ever thick.
modern: My eyesight has always been bad.

origin: Regard Titinius, And tell me what thou notest about the field.
modern: Watch Titinius and tell me what you see in the field.

origin: This day I breathed first.
modern: Today was the day I breathed my first breath.

origin: Time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end.
modern: Time has come round, and I’ll end where I began.

origin: My life is run his compass.
modern: My life has run its circle.

origin: What news?
modern: What news?

origin: And, hark!
modern: And listen!

origin: They shout for joy.
modern: They shout for joy.

origin: Come down, behold no more.
modern: Come down, look no more.

origin: Oh, coward that I am, to live so long To see my best friend ta'en before my face!
modern: Oh, I’m such a coward for living long enough to see my best friend taken before my eyes!

origin: Come hither, sirrah.
modern: Come here, boy.

origin: Come now, keep thine oath.
modern: Come now, keep your oath.

origin: Caesar, thou art revenged, Even with the sword that killed thee.
modern: Caesar, you are revenged with the very same sword that killed you.

origin: So I am free.
modern: So I’m free.

origin: Yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will.
modern: But I didn’t want to be free like this.

origin: O Cassius, Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.
modern: Oh, Cassius, I’ll run far from this country to where no Romans can find me.

origin: It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, As Cassius' legions are by Antony.
modern: The armies have merely changed places, Titinius, because Octavius has been overthrown by noble Brutus’s forces at the very moment that Antony overthrew Cassius’s legions.

origin: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.
modern: This news will comfort Cassius.

origin: Where did you leave him?
modern: Where did you leave him?

origin: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman on this hill.
modern: On this hill and in despair, with his slave Pindarus.

origin: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?
modern: Isn’t that him on the ground?

origin: He lies not like the living.
modern: He doesn’t seem to be alive.

origin: O my heart!
modern: Oh, my heart!

origin: Is not that he?
modern: Isn’t that him?

origin: What, Pindarus!
modern: Pindarus!

origin: Where art thou, Pindarus?
modern: Where are you, Pindarus?

origin: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears.
modern: Look for him, Titinius, while I go to meet the noble Brutus and force him to hear this news.

origin: I may say “thrusting” it, For piercing steel and darts envenomèd Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.
