modern: I say “force” because Brutus would rather I stuck sharp blades and poisoned arrows in his ears than fill them with this.

origin: Hie you, Messala, And I will seek for Pindarus the while.
modern: Hurry, Messala, and I’ll look for Pindarus in the meantime.

origin: Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?
modern: Why did you send me out, brave Cassius?

origin: Did I not meet thy friends?
modern: Didn’t I meet up with your allies?

origin: And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory And bid me give it thee?
modern: And didn’t they place the wreath of victory on my brow and order me to give it to you?

origin: Didst thou not hear their shouts?
modern: Didn’t you hear their shouts?

origin: Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything!
modern: Alas, you misunderstood everything!

origin: But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow.
modern: But let me place this wreath on your head.

origin: Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I Will do his bidding.
modern: Your Brutus ordered me to give it to you, and I’ll do what he says.

origin: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
modern: Where is his body, Messala?

origin: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.
modern: Over there, where Titinius mourns it.

origin: Titinius' face is upward.
modern: Titinius is lying face-up.

origin: He is slain.
modern: He’s been killed.

origin: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!
modern: Oh, Julius Caesar, you are still powerful.

origin: Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords In our own proper entrails.
modern: Your ghost walks the earth and turns our swords toward our own stomachs.

origin: Are yet two Romans living such as these?
modern: Could you have found two Romans as good as these two?

origin: The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!
modern: Good-bye to you, the last of all the Romans.

origin: I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.
modern: I will find the time to cry for you, Cassius, I’ll find the time.

origin: Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body.
modern: Come, then, and send his body to Thasos.

origin: Let us to the field.
modern: Let’s proceed to the field.

origin: Labio and Flavio, set our battles on.
modern: Labio and Flavio, push our armies onward.

origin: Tis three o'clock, and, Romans, yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight.
modern: It is three o'clock, and, Romans, before night, we will try our luck in a second battle.

origin: What bastard doth not?
modern: Who is so low that he wouldn’t?

origin: Who will go with me?
modern: Who will advance with me?

origin: I will proclaim my name about the field.
modern: I will proclaim my name around the field.

origin: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
modern: I am the son of Marcus Cato!

origin: A foe to tyrants, and my country’s friend.
modern: An enemy to tyrants and a friend to my country.

origin: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!
modern: I am the son of Marcus Cato!

origin: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I!
modern: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus.

origin: Brutus, my country’s friend.
modern: Brutus, my country’s friend.

origin: Know me for Brutus!
modern: Know that I am Brutus!

origin: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?
modern: Oh, young and noble Cato, have you been slain?

origin: Only I yield to die.
modern: I’d rather die.

origin: There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight.
modern: Here is some money for you to kill me immediately.

origin: Kill Brutus, and be honored in his death.
modern: Kill Brutus and be honored by the killing.

origin: We must not.
modern: We must not.

origin: A noble prisoner!
modern: He is a noble prisoner!

origin: Room, ho!
modern: Make room!

origin: Tell Antony Brutus is ta'en.
modern: Tell Antony that Brutus has been taken.

origin: I’ll tell the news.
modern: I’ll tell him the news.

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: Safe, Antony.
modern: He’s safe, Antony.

origin: I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus.
modern: I can assure you that no enemy will ever take the noble Brutus alive.

origin: The gods defend him from so great a shame!
modern: The gods protect him from so great a shame!

origin: The games are done and Caesar is returning.
modern: The games are done and Caesar is returning.

origin: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve, And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you What hath proceeded worthy note today.
modern: As they pass by, grab Casca by the sleeve, and he’ll tell you if anything important happened today—in his usual sour way.

origin: I will do so.
modern: I’ll do so.

origin: But, look you, Cassius, The angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow, And all the rest look like a chidden train.
modern: But look, Cassius, Caesar looks angry and everyone else looks as if they’ve been scolded.

origin: Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol Being crossed in conference by some senators.
modern: Calphurnia’s face is pale, and Cicero’s eyes are as red and fiery as they get when senators are arguing with him at the Capitol.

origin: Casca will tell us what the matter is.
modern: Casca will tell us what’s the matter.

origin: Antonio.
modern: Antonio!

origin: Caesar.
modern: Caesar?

origin: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
modern: Come, last of my friends, rest on this rock.

origin: Statilius showed the torchlight but, my lord, He came not back.
modern: Statilius waved the torchlight at us, but he hasn’t come back.

origin: He is or ta'en or slain.
modern: He’s been captured or killed.

origin: Sit thee down, Clitus.
modern: Sit down, Clitus.

origin: Hark thee, Clitus.
modern: Listen, Clitus.

origin: What, I, my lord?
modern: Who, me, my lord?

origin: No, not for all the world.
modern: No, not for all the world.

origin: Peace then!
modern: Silence, then!

origin: No words.
modern: Don’t give it away.

origin: I’ll rather kill myself.
modern: I’d rather kill myself.

origin: Hark thee, Dardanius.
modern: Listen, Dardanius.

origin: Shall I do such a deed?
modern: Would I dare do something like that?

origin: O Dardanius!
modern: Oh Dardanius!

origin: O Clitus!
modern: Oh Clitus!

origin: Come hither, good Volumnius.
modern: Come here, good Volumnius.

origin: List a word.
modern: Listen a minute.

origin: What says my lord?
modern: What is it, my lord?

origin: At Sardis once, And this last night here in Philippi fields.
modern: Once at Sardis and once last night, here in Philippi fields.

origin: I know my hour is come.
modern: I know that my hour has come.

origin: Not so, my lord.
modern: No, it hasn’t, my lord.

origin: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.
modern: No, I’m sure it has, Volumnius.

origin: Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.
modern: You see how the world goes, Volumnius.

origin: Our enemies have beat us to the pit.
modern: Our enemies have driven us to the edge of the grave.

origin: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us.
modern: It’s nobler to leap in ourselves than dawdle until they push us.

origin: Good Volumnius, Thou know’st that we two went to school together.
modern: Good Volumnius, you know that we went to school together.

origin: Even for that our love of old, I prithee, Hold thou my sword hilts, whilst I run on it.
modern: For the sake of our old friendship, I ask you, hold my sword handle while I run on it.

origin: That’s not an office for a friend, my lord.
modern: That’s not a job for a friend, my lord.

origin: Fly, fly, my lord.
modern: Run, run, my lord.

origin: There is no tarrying here.
modern: We can’t wait here.

origin: Farewell to you.—And you.—And you, Volumnius.
modern: Farewell to you, and you, and you, Volumnius.

origin: Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep.
modern: Strato, you’ve slept this whole time.

origin: I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto.
modern: I’ll have glory in this losing day—more than Octavius and Mark Antony will gain by their foul conquest.

origin: So fare you well at once, for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life’s history.
modern: So farewell, all, for my tongue has almost finished with its life.

origin: Night hangs upon mine eyes.
modern: I can’t see ahead of me.

origin: My bones would rest, That have but labored to attain this hour.
modern: My bones want to rest after helping me up to this hour.

origin: Fly, my lord, fly.
modern: Run, my lord, run.

origin: Hence.
modern: Go on!

origin: I will follow.
modern: I’ll follow.

origin: I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord.
modern: I beg you, Strato, stay by me.

origin: Thou art a fellow of a good respect.
modern: You’re a man with a good reputation.

origin: Thy life hath had some smatch of honor in it.
modern: Your life has had honor in it.

origin: Hold then my sword and turn away thy face While I do run upon it.
modern: Then, hold my sword and turn your face away while I run on it.

origin: Wilt thou, Strato?
modern: Will you, Strato?

origin: Give me your hand first.
modern: Give me your hand, first.

origin: Farewell, good Strato.
modern: Farewell, good Strato.

origin: What man is that?
modern: What man is that?

origin: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala.
modern: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala.

origin: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.
modern: I’ll take all who served Brutus into my service.

origin: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
modern: You, will you join with me?

origin: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.
modern: Yes, if Messala recommends me to you.

origin: Do so, good Messala.
modern: Do so, good Messala.

origin: How died my master, Strato?
modern: How did my master die, Strato?

origin: I held the sword and he did run on it.
modern: I held the sword and he ran on it.

origin: Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.
modern: Then take this man into your service, Octavius, for he did the final service to my master.

origin: This was the noblest Roman of them all.
modern: This was the noblest Roman of them all.

origin: All the conspirators save only he Did that they did in envy of great Caesar.
modern: All the rest of the conspirators acted out of jealousy of great Caesar.

origin: He only in a general honest thought And common good to all, made one of them.
modern: Only he acted from honesty and for the general good.

origin: His life was gentle, and the elements So mixed in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, “This was a man.” According to his virtue let us use him, With all respect and rites of burial.
modern: His life was gentle, and the elements mixed so well in him that Nature might stand up and say to all the world, “This was a man.” Let’s treat him according to his virtue, with all the respect and rituals of burial.

origin: Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie Most like a soldier, ordered honorably.
modern: His body will lie in my tent tonight, with the honorable observance that suits a soldier.

origin: So call the field to rest, and let’s away To part the glories of this happy day.
modern: So order the armies to rest, and let’s go home to share the glories of this happy day.

origin: Ay, Casca.
modern: Yes, Casca.

origin: Tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad.
modern: Tell us what happened today that put Caesar in such a serious mood.

origin: Why, you were with him, were you not?
modern: But you were with him, weren’t you?

origin: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.
modern: If I were, I wouldn’t need to ask you what happened.

origin: Why, there was a crown offered him; and, being offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.
modern: A crown was offered to him, and he pushed it away with the back of his hand, like this—and then the people started shouting.

origin: What was the second noise for?
modern: What was the second noise for?

origin: Why, for that too.
modern: The same thing.

origin: They shouted thrice.
modern: They shouted three times.

origin: What was the last cry for?
modern: What was the last cry for?

origin: Why, for that too.
modern: For the same thing.

origin: Was the crown offered him thrice?
modern: The crown was offered to him three times?

origin: Ay, marry, was ’t, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other, and at every putting-by mine honest neighbors shouted.
modern: Yes, indeed, it was, and he pushed it away three times, each time more gently than the last; and at each refusal my countrymen shouted.

origin: Who offered him the crown?
modern: Who offered him the crown?

origin: Why, Antony.
modern: Antony.

origin: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.
modern: Tell us how it happened, noble Casca.

origin: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it.
modern: I can’t explain it.

origin: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither, ’twas one of these coronets) and, as I told you, he put it by once—but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it.
modern: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown—though it wasn’t a real crown, just a small circlet—and, as I told you, he refused it once—though in my opinion he would’ve liked to have it.

origin: Then he offered it to him again, then he put it by again—but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it.
modern: Then Antony offered it to him again, and he refused it again (though, in my opinion, he was reluctant to take his hand off it).

origin: And then he offered it the third time.
modern: Then Antony offered it the third time.

origin: And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
modern: As for myself, I didn’t dare laugh, for fear of opening my lips and inhaling the stinking air.

origin: But soft, I pray you.
modern: But wait a minute, please.

origin: What, did Caesar swoon?
modern: Did you say Caesar fainted?

origin: He fell down in the marketplace, and foamed at mouth, and was speechless.
modern: He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at the mouth and was speechless.

origin: Tis very like.
modern: That’s very likely.

origin: He hath the falling sickness.
modern: He has epilepsy, a disease where you fall down.

origin: No, Caesar hath it not.
modern: No, Caesar doesn’t have epilepsy.

origin: But you and I And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.
modern: You and I, and honest Casca, we have epilepsy—we’ve fallen.

origin: I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fell down.
modern: I don’t know what you mean by that, but I’m sure Caesar fell down.

origin: What said he when he came unto himself?
modern: What did he say when he regained consciousness?

origin: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut.
modern: Indeed, before he fell down, when he realized the commoners were glad he refused the crown, he pulled open his robe and offered them his throat to cut.

origin: An I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues.
modern: If I’d been a common laborer and hadn’t taken him up on his offer, to hell with me.

origin: And so he fell.
modern: And so he fainted.

origin: When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their worships to think it was his infirmity.
modern: When he regained consciousness again, he said that if he’d done or said anything wrong, he wanted them to know that it was all because of his sickness.

origin: Three or four wenches where I stood cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts.
modern: Three or four women near me cried, “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts.

origin: If Caesar had stabbed their mothers they would have done no less.
modern: But never mind them—if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would’ve forgiven him.

origin: And after that he came thus sad away?
modern: And after that he came back here looking so serious?

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Hence!
modern: Get out of here!

origin: Home, you idle creatures get you home!
modern: Go home, you lazy men.

origin: Is this a holiday?
modern: What, is today a holiday?

origin: Why, sir, a carpenter.
modern: I’m a carpenter, sir.

origin: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
modern: Where are your leather apron and your ruler?

origin: What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
modern: What are you doing, wearing your best clothes?

origin: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.
modern: And you, sir, what’s  Well, compared to a fine workman, you might call me a mere cobbler.

origin: But what trade art thou?
modern: But what’s your trade?

origin: Answer me directly.
modern: Answer me straightforwardly.

origin: A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
modern: It is a trade, sir, that I practice with a clear conscience.

origin: What trade, thou knave?
modern: What trade, boy?

origin: Thou naughty knave, what trade?
modern: You insolent rascal, what trade?

origin: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me.
modern: Sir, please, don’t be angry.

origin: Yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.
modern: But if your soles are worn out, I can mend you.

origin: What mean’st thou by that?
modern: What do you mean by that?

origin: Mend” me, thou saucy fellow?
modern: Mend” me, you impertinent fellow?

origin: Did Cicero say anything?
modern: Did Cicero say anything?

origin: Ay, he spoke Greek.
modern: Yes, he said something in Greek.

origin: To what effect?
modern: What did he say?

origin: Nay, an I tell you that, I’ll ne'er look you i' th' face again.
modern: If I told you I understood Greek, I’d be lying.

origin: But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads.
modern: But those who understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads.

origin: But, for mine own part, it was Greek to me.
modern: As for myself, it was Greek to me.

origin: I could tell you more news too.
modern: I have more news too.

origin: Murellus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs off Caesar’s images, are put to silence.
modern: Murellus and Flavius have been punished for pulling scarves off statues of Caesar.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: There you go.

origin: There was more foolery yet, if I could remember it.
modern: There was even more foolishness, if I could only remember it.

origin: Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?
modern: Will you have dinner with me tonight, Casca?

origin: No, I am promised forth.
modern: No, I have a commitment.

origin: Will you dine with me tomorrow?
modern: Will you dine with me tomorrow?

origin: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner worth the eating.
modern: Yes, if I’m still alive, and you’re still sane, and your dinner is worth eating.

origin: Good.
modern: Good.

origin: I will expect you.
modern: I’ll expect you.

origin: Do so.
modern: Do so.

origin: Farewell both.
modern: Farewell to you both.

origin: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
modern: What a stupid man he’s become!

origin: He was quick mettle when he went to school.
modern: He was so sharp when he was in school.

origin: So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise, However he puts on this tardy form.
modern: He’s still sharp when it comes to carrying out a bold or noble enterprise, though he puts on this show of stupidity.

origin: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite.
modern: He speaks roughly, but what he says is smart, and his roughness makes other people enjoy listening to him.

origin: And so it is.
modern: You’re right, that’s how it is.

origin: For this time I will leave you.
modern: I’ll leave you for now.

origin: Tomorrow, if you please to speak with me, I will come home to you.
modern: If you’d like to talk tomorrow, I’ll come to your home.

origin: Or, if you will, Come home to me, and I will wait for you.
modern: Or, if you don’t mind, come to my home, and I’ll wait for you.

origin: I will do so.
modern: I’ll do so.

origin: Till then, think of the world.
modern: Until then, think about the well-being of Rome.

origin: Well, Brutus, thou art noble.
modern: Well, Brutus, you’re noble.

origin: Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus.
modern: Caesar resents me, but he loves Brutus.

origin: If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius, He should not humor me.
modern: If I were Brutus now and Brutus were me, I wouldn’t have let him influence me.

origin: I will this night, In several hands, in at his windows throw, As if they came from several citizens, Writings all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely Caesar’s ambition shall be glancèd at.
modern: Tonight I’ll throw through his window a few letters in different handwriting—as if they came from several citizens—all testifying to the great respect Romans have for Brutus, and all alluding to Caesar’s unseemly ambition.

origin: Brought you Caesar home?
modern: Did you accompany Caesar home?

origin: O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threatening clouds, But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
modern: Cicero, I’ve seen storms in which the angry winds split old oak trees, and I’ve seen the ocean swell, rage, and foam, as if it wanted to reach the storm clouds, but never before tonight, never until now, have I experienced a storm that drops fire.

origin: Either there is a civil strife in heaven, Or else the world, too saucy with the gods, Incenses them to send destruction.
modern: Either there are wars in heaven, or else the world, too insolent toward the gods, provokes them to send destruction.

origin: Besides—I ha' not since put up my sword— Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glared upon me and went surly by, Without annoying me.
modern: Also—I’ve kept my sword unsheathed since I saw this—in front of the Capitol I met a lion who looked at me and strutted by without bothering to attack me.

origin: And there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women, Transformèd with their fear, who swore they saw Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.
modern: And there were a hundred spooked women huddled together in fear who swore they saw men on fire walk up and down the streets.

origin: And yesterday the bird of night did sit Even at noon-day upon the marketplace, Hooting and shrieking.
modern: And yesterday the night owl sat hooting and shrieking in the marketplace at noon.

origin: When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say, “These are their reasons.
modern: When all these extraordinary things happen at once, we shouldn’t say, “These happenings can be explained rationally.

origin: They are natural.” For I believe they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon.
modern: They’re natural enough.” I think these things are omens of things to come in our country.

origin: Indeed, it is a strange-disposèd time.
modern: Indeed, it’s a strange time.

origin: But men may construe things after their fashion, Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
modern: But men tend to interpret things however suits them and totally miss the actual meaning of the things themselves.

origin: Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?
modern: Is Caesar visiting the Capitol tomorrow?

origin: He doth, for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.
modern: He is, because he told Antonius to tell you he’d be there tomorrow.

origin: Good night then, Casca.
modern: Good night then, Casca.

origin: This disturbèd sky Is not to walk in.
modern: This bad weather isn’t good to walk around in.

origin: A Roman.
modern: A Roman.

origin: Casca, by your voice.
modern: It’s Casca—I know your voice.

origin: Your ear is good.
modern: Your ear is good.

origin: Cassius, what night is this!
modern: Cassius, what a night this is!

origin: A very pleasing night to honest men.
modern: It’s a very pleasing night to honest men.

origin: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?
modern: Who ever saw the heavens threaten like this?

origin: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
modern: Those who have known how bad things are here on earth.

origin: For my part, I have walked about the streets, Submitting me unto the perilous night, And, thus unbracèd, Casca, as you see, Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone.
modern: I have walked around the streets, exposing myself to the perilous night, unbuttoned like this, as you see, Casca, baring my chest to the thunderbolt.

origin: And when the cross blue lightning seemed to open The breast of heaven, I did present myself Even in the aim and very flash of it.
modern: When the forked blue lightning seemed to break open the sky, I put myself right where I thought it would hit.

origin: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?
modern: But why did you tempt the heavens like that?

origin: It is the part of men to fear and tremble When the most mighty gods by tokens send Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.
modern: Mankind’s role is to fear and tremble when the almighty gods send warning signals.

origin: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want, Or else you use not.
modern: You’re acting stupid, Casca, and you lack the quick wits that a Roman should have—or else you don’t use them.

origin: You look pale, and gaze, And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder To see the strange impatience of the heavens.
modern: You go pale, you stare, and you act in awe of the strange disturbance in the heavens.

origin: A man no mightier than thyself or me In personal action, yet prodigious grown, And fearful as these strange eruptions are.
modern: A man no mightier than you or I in ability, yet grown as huge and frightening as tonight’s strange happenings.

origin: Let it be who it is.
modern: Let it be who it is.

origin: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.
modern: Our tolerance for slavery and oppression shows us to be weak, like women.

origin: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king, And he shall wear his crown by sea and land In every place save here in Italy.
modern: Indeed, they say that the senators plan to establish Caesar as a king tomorrow, and he’ll wear his crown at sea and on land everywhere except here in Italy.

origin: I know where I will wear this dagger then.
modern: I know where I’ll wear this dagger, then.

origin: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius.
modern: I’ll kill myself to save myself from slavery.

origin: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong.
modern: In suicide, gods make the weak strong.

origin: Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat.
modern: In suicide, gods allow tyrants to be defeated.

origin: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron Can be retentive to the strength of spirit.
modern: No stony tower, no brass walls, no airless dungeon, no iron chains can contain a strong mind.

origin: But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself.
modern: But if a man becomes weary of these obstacles, he can always kill himself.

origin: If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure.
modern: Let everyone beware: I can shake off the tyranny that now oppresses me whenever I choose.

origin: So can I.
modern: So can I.

origin: So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.
modern: In fact, every imprisoned man holds in his own hand the tool to free himself.

origin: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
modern: How can Caesar be a tyrant then?

origin: Poor man!
modern: Poor man!

origin: I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep.
modern: I know he wouldn’t be a wolf if the Romans didn’t act like sheep.

origin: He were no lion were not Romans hinds.
modern: He couldn’t be a lion if the Romans weren’t such easy prey.

origin: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws.
modern: People who want to start a big fire quickly start with little twigs.

origin: But, O grief, Where hast thou led me?
modern: But, oh no!

origin: Then I know My answer must be made.
modern: What have I said in my grief?

origin: You speak to Casca, and to such a man That is no fleering telltale.
modern: Say no more.

origin: Hold, my hand.
modern: Shake my hand.

origin: Be factious for redress of all these griefs, And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest.
modern: If you’re joining together to right these wrongs, I’ll go as far as any one of you.

origin: There’s a bargain made.
modern: That’s a deal.

origin: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence.
modern: Now let me tell you, Casca, I have already convinced some of the noblest Romans to join me in an honorable but dangerous mission.

origin: And I do know by this they stay for me In Pompey’s porch.
modern: And I know that by now they’re waiting for me on the porch outside Pompey’s theater.

origin: Tis Cinna.
modern: It’s Cinna.

origin: I do know him by his gait.
modern: I recognize his walk.

origin: To find out you.
modern: To find you.

origin: Who’s that?
modern: Who’s that?

origin: Metellus Cimber?
modern: Metellus Cimber?

origin: No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts.
modern: No, it’s Casca, someone who’s going to work with us.

origin: Am I not stayed for, Cinna?
modern: Aren’t the others waiting for me, Cinna?

origin: I am glad on ’t.
modern: I’m glad Casca is with us.

origin: What a fearful night is this!
modern: What a fearful night this is!

origin: There’s two or three of us have seen strange sights.
modern: Two or three of us have seen strange things.

origin: Am I not stayed for?
modern: Are the others waiting?

origin: Tell me.
modern: Tell me.

origin: Yes, you are.
modern: Yes, they are.

origin: O Cassius, if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party— Be you content.
modern: Oh, Cassius, if you could only convince Brutus to join us— Don’t worry.

origin: Good Cinna, take this paper, And look you lay it in the praetor’s chair Where Brutus may but find it.
modern: Good Cinna, take this paper and be sure to lay it in the judge’s chair where Brutus sits, so he’ll find it.

origin: All this done, Repair to Pompey’s porch, where you shall find us.
modern: When you’ve finished all this, return to the porch of Pompey’s theater, where you’ll find us.

origin: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
modern: Are Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

origin: All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone To seek you at your house.
modern: Everyone’s there except Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone to look for you at your house.

origin: Well, I will hie, And so bestow these papers as you bade me.
modern: Well, I’ll hurry and put these papers where you told me.

origin: That done, repair to Pompey’s theatre.
modern: When you’ve finished, go back to Pompey’s theater.

origin: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house.
modern: Come on, Casca, you and I will go see Brutus at his house before sunrise.

origin: Him and his worth and our great need of him You have right well conceited.
modern: Yes, you’re absolutely right about how worthy Brutus is and how much we need him.

origin: Let us go, For it is after midnight, and ere day We will awake him and be sure of him.
modern: Let’s go, because it’s already after midnight, and we want him on our side before daylight.

origin: Awake, I say!
modern: Wake up, I say!

origin: What, Lucius!
modern: Lucius!

origin: Called you, my lord?
modern: Did you call me, my lord?

origin: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius.
modern: Put a candle in my study, Lucius.

origin: When it is lighted, come and call me here.
modern: Call me when it’s lit.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: It must be by his death, and for my part I know no personal cause to spurn at him But for the general.
modern: I have no personal reason to strike at him—only the best interest of the people.

origin: He would be crowned.
modern: He wants to be crowned.

origin: How that might change his nature, there’s the question.
modern: The question is, how would being king change him?

origin: It is the bright day that brings forth the adder And that craves wary walking.
modern: Evil can come from good, just as poisonous snakes tend to come out into the open on bright sunny days—which means we have to walk carefully.

origin: Crown him that, And then I grant we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with.
modern: If we crown him, I have to admit we’d be giving him the power to do damage.

origin: Why, sir, cobble you.
modern: Cobble you, sir.

origin: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?
modern: You’re a cobbler, are you?

origin: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl.
modern: Sir, I make my living using an awl.

origin: I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes.
modern: I’m a surgeon to old shoes.

origin: When they are in great danger, I recover them.
modern: When they’re endangered, I save them.

origin: As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.
modern: The noblest men who ever walked on leather have walked on my handiwork.

origin: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
modern: But why aren’t you in your shop today?

origin: Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
modern: Why are you leading these men through the streets?

origin: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to get myself into more work.
modern: Well, to wear out their shoes and get myself more work.

origin: Wherefore rejoice?
modern: Why would you celebrate it?

origin: What conquest brings he home?
modern: What victory does he bring home?

origin: What tributaries follow him to Rome To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?
modern: What foreign lands has he conquered and captive foreigners chained to his chariot wheels?

origin: Th' abuse of greatness is when it disjoins Remorse from power.
modern: Rulers abuse their power when they separate it from compassion.

origin: So Caesar may.
modern: Caesar might act like that.

origin: Then, lest he may, prevent.
modern: Therefore, in case he does, we must hold him back.

origin: And since the quarrel Will bear no color for the thing he is, Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented, Would run to these and these extremities.
modern: And since our quarrel is with his future behavior, not what he does now, I must frame the argument like this: if his position is furthered, his character will fulfill these predictions.

origin: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.
modern: The candle is burning in your study, sir.

origin: Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus sealed up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed.
modern: While I was looking for a flint to light it, I found this paper on the window, sealed up like this, and I’m sure it wasn’t there when I went to bed.

origin: Get you to bed again.
modern: Go back to bed.

origin: It is not day.
modern: It isn’t daybreak yet.

origin: Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?
modern: Is tomorrow the 15th of March, boy?

origin: I know not, sir.
modern: I don’t know, sir.

origin: Look in the calendar and bring me word.
modern: Check the calendar and come tell me.

origin: I will, sir.
modern: I will, sir.

origin: Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.
modern: Sir, fifteen days of March have gone by.

origin: Tis good.
modern: Good.

origin: Go to the gate.
modern: Go to the gate.

origin: Somebody knocks.
modern: Somebody’s knocking.

origin: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, I have not slept.
modern: I haven’t slept since Cassius first began to turn me against Caesar.

origin: Is he alone?
modern: Is he alone?

origin: Do you know them?
modern: Do you know them?

origin: Let 'em enter.
modern: Let them in.

origin: O conspiracy, Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night When evils are most free?
modern: Oh, conspiracy, are you ashamed to show your face even at night, when evil things are most free?

origin: O, then by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage?
modern: If so, when it’s day, where are you going to find a cave dark enough to hide your monstrous face?

origin: Hide it in smiles and affability.
modern: Instead, hide your true face behind smiles and friendliness.

origin: I think we are too bold upon your rest.
modern: I’m afraid we’re intruding too boldly on your sleep time.

origin: Good morrow, Brutus.
modern: Good morning, Brutus.

origin: Do we trouble you?
modern: Are we bothering you?

origin: I have been up this hour, awake all night.
modern: I’ve been up all night.

origin: Know I these men that come along with you?
modern: Do I know these men who are with you?

origin: This is Trebonius.
modern: This is Trebonius.

origin: He is welcome hither.
modern: He’s welcome here.

origin: This, Decius Brutus.
modern: This is Decius Brutus.

origin: He is welcome too.
modern: He’s welcome too.

origin: This, Casca.
modern: This is Casca.

origin: This, Cinna.
modern: This is Cinna.

origin: And this, Metellus Cimber.
modern: And this is Metellus Cimber.

origin: They are all welcome.
modern: They’re all welcome.

origin: What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?
modern: What worries have kept you awake tonight?

origin: Shall I entreat a word?
modern: Can I have a word with you?

origin: Here lies the east.
modern: Here’s the east.

origin: Doth not the day break here?
modern: Won’t the dawn come from here?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: You shall confess that you are both deceived.
modern: You’re both wrong.

origin: And let us swear our resolution.
modern: And let us swear to our resolution.

origin: No, not an oath.
modern: No, let’s not swear an oath.

origin: So let high-sighted tyranny range on Till each man drop by lottery.
modern: Then we can let this ambitious tyrant continue unchallenged until each of us is killed at his whim.

origin: But if these— As I am sure they do—bear fire enough To kindle cowards and to steel with valor The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress?
modern: But if we have reasons that are strong enough to ignite cowards into action and to make weak women brave—and I think we do—then, countrymen, what else could we possibly need to spur us to action?

origin: What other bond Than secret Romans that have spoke the word And will not palter?
modern: What bond do we need other than that of discreet Romans who have said what they’re going to do and won’t back down?

origin: And what other oath Than honesty to honesty engaged, That this shall be, or we will fall for it?
modern: And what oath do we need other than that we honest men have told each other that this will happen or we will die trying?

origin: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs.
modern: Swearing is for priests, cowards, overly cautious men, feeble old people, and those long-suffering weaklings who welcome abuse.

origin: Unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt.
modern: Only men whom you wouldn’t trust anyway would swear oaths, and for the worst reasons.

origin: But do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath, when every drop of blood That every Roman bears—and nobly bears— Is guilty of a several bastardy If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath passed from him.
modern: Don’t spoil the justness and virtue of our endeavor nor weaken our own irrepressible spirits by thinking that we need a binding oath, when the blood that every noble Roman contains within him would be proven bastard’s blood if he broke the smallest part of any promise he had made.

origin: But what of Cicero?
modern: But what about Cicero?

origin: Shall we sound him?
modern: Should we see what he thinks?

origin: I think he will stand very strong with us.
modern: I think he will stand strong with us.

origin: Let us not leave him out.
modern: Let’s not leave him out.

origin: No, by no means.
modern: No, by no means.

origin: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion And buy men’s voices to commend our deeds.
modern: Yes, we should get his support, for his mature presence will make others think well of us and speak out in support of our actions.

origin: It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands.
modern: They’ll assume that Cicero, with his sound judgment, ordered the actions.

origin: O, name him not.
modern: No, don’t even mention him.

origin: Let us not break with him, For he will never follow anything That other men begin.
modern: He’ll never follow anything that other men have started.

origin: Then leave him out.
modern: Then leave him out.

origin: Indeed he is not fit.
modern: Indeed, he’s not right for this.

origin: Decius, well urged.
modern: Good point, Decius.

origin: I think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar.
modern: I don’t think it would be wise to let Mark Antony, whom Caesar is so fond of, outlive Caesar.

origin: We shall find of him A shrewd contriver.
modern: We’d find that he was a dangerous plotter.

origin: And, you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.
modern: And as you know, his connections, if he put them to good use, might be enough to hurt us all.

origin: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards, For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.
modern: Our action will seem too bloody if we cut off Caesar’s head and then hack at his arms and legs too, Caius Cassius—because Mark Antony is merely one of Caesar’s arms.

origin: Let us be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius.
modern: Let’s be sacrificers but not butchers, Caius.

origin: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood.
modern: We’re all against what Caesar stands for, and there’s no blood in that.

origin: Oh, that we then could come by Caesar’s spirit And not dismember Caesar!
modern: Oh, how I wish we could oppose Caesar’s spirit—his overblown ambition—and not hack up Caesar himself!

origin: But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it.
modern: But, unfortunately, Caesar has to bleed if we’re going to stop him.

origin: And, gentle friends, Let’s kill him boldly but not wrathfully.
modern: Noble friends, let’s kill him boldly but not with anger.

origin: Let’s carve him as a dish fit for the gods, Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds.
modern: Let’s carve him up like a dish fit for the gods, not chop him up like a carcass fit for dogs.

origin: And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, Stir up their servants to an act of rage And after seem to chide 'em.
modern: Let’s be angry only long enough to do the deed, and then let’s act like we’re disgusted by what we had to do.

origin: This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious, Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be called purgers, not murderers.
modern: This will make our actions seem practical and not vengeful.

origin: If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar.
modern: If he loves Caesar, then he can only hurt himself—by grieving and dying for Caesar.

origin: And that were much he should, for he is given To sports, to wildness and much company.
modern: And I’d be surprised if he even did that, for he prefers sports, fun, and friends.

origin: There is no fear in him.
modern: There’s nothing to fear in him.

origin: Peace!
modern: Quiet!

origin: Count the clock.
modern: Count how many times the clock chimes.

origin: The clock hath stricken three.
modern: The clock struck three.

origin: Tis time to part.
modern: It’s time to leave.

origin: It may be, these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.
modern: It might happen that these strange signs, the unusual terror of this night, and the urgings of his fortune-tellers will keep him away from the Capitol today.

origin: Never fear that.
modern: Don’t worry about that.

origin: If he be so resolved, I can o'ersway him.
modern: If he’s reluctant, I can convince him.

origin: For he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.
modern: He loves to hear me tell him how men can be snared by flatterers, just like unicorns can be captured in trees, elephants in holes, and lions with nets.

origin: But when I tell him he hates flatterers, He says he does, being then most flatterèd.
modern: When I tell him he hates flatterers, he agrees, just at the moment when I’m flattering him the most.

origin: Let me work.
modern: Let me work on him.

origin: For I can give his humor the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.
modern: I can put him in the right mood, and I’ll bring him to the Capitol.

origin: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
modern: No, we’ll all go there to bring him.

origin: By the eighth hour.
modern: By eight o'clock.

origin: Is that the uttermost?
modern: Is that the latest we can do it?

origin: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.
modern: Caius Ligarius doesn’t like Caesar, who berated him for speaking well of Pompey.

origin: I wonder none of you have thought of him.
modern: I wonder that none of you thought about getting his support.

origin: Now, good Metellus, go along by him.
modern: Good Metellus, go to him now.

origin: He loves me well, and I have given him reasons.
modern: He likes me, and I’ve given him good reason to.

origin: Send him but hither and I’ll fashion him.
modern: Just send him here, and I’ll persuade him.

origin: The morning comes upon ’s.
modern: The morning is approaching.

origin: We’ll leave you, Brutus.
modern: We’ll leave, Brutus.

origin: And, friends, disperse yourselves.
modern: Friends, go your separate ways.

origin: But all remember What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.
modern: But all of you, remember what you’ve said and prove yourselves true Romans.

origin: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily.
modern: Good gentlemen, look like you’re rested and happy.

origin: And so good morrow to you every one.
modern: And so, good morning to all of you.

origin: Boy!
modern: Boy!

origin: Lucius!—Fast asleep?
modern: Lucius!

origin: It is no matter.
modern: Fast asleep?

origin: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber.
modern: Well, enjoy the sweetness of deep sleep.

origin: Therefore thou sleep’st so sound.
modern: That’s why you sleep so soundly.

origin: Brutus, my lord.
modern: Brutus, my lord.

origin: Portia, what mean you?
modern: Portia, what are you doing awake?

origin: It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw, cold morning.
modern: It isn’t good for your health to expose your weak body to the raw, cold morning.

origin: Nor for yours neither.
modern: It’s not good for your health, either.

origin: Y' have ungently, Brutus, Stole from my bed.
modern: You rudely snuck out of bed.

origin: And yesternight, at supper, You suddenly arose and walked about, Musing and sighing, with your arms across, And when I asked you what the matter was, You stared upon me with ungentle looks.
modern: And last night at dinner, you got up abruptly and paced back and forth with your arms crossed, brooding and sighing, and when I asked you what was the matter, you gave me a dirty look.

origin: I urged you further, then you scratched your head And too impatiently stamped with your foot.
modern: I asked you again, and you scratched your head and stamped your foot impatiently.

origin: Yet I insisted; yet you answered not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you.
modern: I still insisted on knowing what the matter was, but you wouldn’t answer me, instead giving me an angry wave of your hand and telling me to leave you alone.

origin: Dear my lord, Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.
modern: My dear lord, tell me what’s bothering you.

origin: And do you now strew flowers in his way That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood?
modern: And now you toss flowers in the path of Caesar, who comes in triumph over Pompey’s defeated sons?

origin: Be gone!
modern: Go home!

origin: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees, Pray to the gods to intermit the plague That needs must light on this ingratitude.
modern: Run to your houses, fall on your knees, and pray to the gods to spare you the pain that you deserve for such ingratitude.

origin: Go, go, good countrymen, and for this fault, Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
modern: Go, go, good countrymen, and to make up for having done wrong, gather up all the poor men like yourselves, lead them to the Tiber, and weep into the river until it overflows its banks.

origin: Go you down that way towards the Capitol.
modern: You go down toward the Capitol, and I’ll go this way.

origin: This way will I. Disrobe the images If you do find them decked with ceremonies.
modern: Undress the statues if they’re decorated in honor of Caesar.

origin: May we do so?
modern: Can we do that?

origin: I’ll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets.
modern: I’ll walk around and force the commoners off the streets.

origin: So do you too, where you perceive them thick.
modern: You do the same, wherever the crowds are thick.

origin: These growing feathers plucked from Caesar’s wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness.
modern: If we take away Caesar’s support, he’ll have to come back down to earth; otherwise, he’ll fly too high and keep the rest of us in a state of fear and obedience.

origin: I am not well in health, and that is all.
modern: I’m not feeling well—that’s all.

origin: Brutus is wise, and were he not in health, He would embrace the means to come by it.
modern: You’re smart, though, and if you were sick, you’d take what you needed to get better.

origin: Why, so I do.
modern: I’m doing so.

origin: Good Portia, go to bed.
modern: Good Portia, go to bed.

origin: Is Brutus sick?
modern: Are you sick?

origin: And is it physical To walk unbracèd and suck up the humors Of the dank morning?
modern: And is it healthy to walk uncovered and breathe in the dampness of the morning?

origin: What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed, To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air To add unto his sickness?
modern: You’re sick, yet you sneak out of your warm bed and let the humid and disease-infested air make you sicker?

origin: Kneel not, gentle Portia.
modern: Don’t kneel, noble Portia.

origin: You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.
modern: You’re my true and honorable wife, as dear to me as the blood that runs through my sad heart.

origin: If this were true, then should I know this secret.
modern: If that were true, then I’d know your secret.

origin: I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife.
modern: I admit I’m only a woman, but nevertheless I’m the woman Lord Brutus took for his wife.

origin: I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter.
modern: I admit I’m only a woman, but I’m still a woman from a noble family—I’m Cato’s daughter.

origin: Think you I am no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so husbanded?
modern: Do you really think I’m no stronger than the rest of my sex, with such a father and such a husband?

origin: Tell me your counsels.
modern: Tell me your secrets.

origin: I will not disclose 'em.
modern: I won’t betray them.

origin: I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh.
modern: I’ve proved my trustworthiness by giving myself a voluntary wound here in my thigh.

origin: Can I bear that with patience, And not my husband’s secrets?
modern: If I can bear that pain, then I can bear my husband’s secrets.

origin: O ye gods, Render me worthy of this noble wife!
modern: Oh, gods, make me worthy of this noble wife!

origin: Hark, hark!
modern: Listen!

origin: One knocks.
modern: Someone knocks.

origin: Leave me with haste.
modern: Leave me quickly.

origin: Lucius, who’s that knocking?
modern: Lucius, who’s that knocking?

origin: He is a sick man that would speak with you.
modern: Here’s a sick man who wants to speak with you.

origin: Would you were not sick!
modern: How I wish you felt better!

origin: I am not sick if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.
modern: I’m not sick if you’ve prepared some honorable exploit for me.

origin: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.
modern: Indeed, I would have such an exploit for you, Ligarius, if you were healthy enough to hear it.

origin: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.
modern: A deed that will make sick men healthy.

origin: But are not some whole that we must make sick?
modern: But aren’t there some healthy men whom we have to make sick?

origin: That must we also.
modern: That too.

origin: What it is, my Caius, I shall unfold to thee as we are going To whom it must be done.
modern: My dear Caius, I’ll explain the task at hand to you as we walk toward the man we must do it to.

origin: Follow me, then.
modern: Follow me, then.

origin: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight.
modern: Neither the sky nor the earth have been quiet tonight.

origin: Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out, “Help, ho!
modern: Calphurnia cried out three times in her sleep, “Help, someone!

origin: They murder Caesar!”—Who’s within?
modern: They’re murdering Caesar!” Who’s there?

origin: My lord.
modern: My lord?

origin: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice And bring me their opinions of success.
modern: Go tell the priests to perform a sacrifice immediately, and bring me their interpretation of the results.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: What mean you, Caesar?
modern: What are you doing, Caesar?

origin: Think you to walk forth?
modern: Are you planning to go out?

origin: You shall not stir out of your house today.
modern: You’re not leaving the house today.

origin: Caesar shall forth.
modern: I will go out.

origin: The things that threatened me Ne'er looked but on my back.
modern: The things that threaten me have only seen my back.

origin: When they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanishèd.
modern: When they see the face of Caesar, they will vanish.

origin: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me.
modern: Caesar, I never believed in omens, but now they frighten me.

origin: There is one within, Besides the things that we have heard and seen, Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
modern: A servant told me the night-watchmen saw horrid sights too, but different ones from what we heard and saw.

origin: A lioness hath whelpèd in the streets, And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead.
modern: A lioness gave birth in the streets, and graves cracked open and thrust out their dead.

origin: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.
modern: Fierce, fiery warriors fought in the clouds in the usual formations of war—ranks and squadrons—until the clouds drizzled blood onto the Capitol.

origin: O Caesar!
modern: Oh, Caesar!

origin: These things are beyond all use, And I do fear them.
modern: These things are beyond anything we’ve seen before, and I’m afraid.

origin: What can be avoided Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?
modern: How can we avoid what the gods want to happen?

origin: Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
modern: But I will go out, for these bad omens apply to the world in general as much as they do to me.

origin: When beggars die there are no comets seen.
modern: When beggars die there are no comets in the sky.

origin: The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.
modern: The heavens only announce the deaths of princes.

origin: Cowards die many times before their deaths.
modern: Cowards die many times before their deaths.

origin: The valiant never taste of death but once.
modern: The brave experience death only once.

origin: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come.
modern: Of all the strange things I’ve ever heard, it seems most strange to me that men fear death, given that death, which can’t be avoided, will come whenever it wants.

origin: What say the augurers?
modern: What do the priests say?

origin: They would not have you to stir forth today.
modern: They don’t want you to go out today.

origin: Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.
modern: They pulled out the guts of the sacrificed animal and couldn’t find its heart.

origin: The gods do this in shame of cowardice.
modern: The gods do this to test my bravery.

origin: Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear.
modern: They’re saying I’d be an animal without a heart if I stayed home today out of fear.

origin: No, Caesar shall not.
modern: So, I won’t.

origin: We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible.
modern: We’re two lions born on the same day in the same litter, and I’m the older and more terrible.

origin: And Caesar shall go forth.
modern: I will go out.

origin: Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.
modern: Alas, my lord, your confidence is getting the better of your wisdom.

origin: Do not go forth today.
modern: Don’t go out today.

origin: Call it my fear That keeps you in the house, and not your own.
modern: Say that it’s my fear that keeps you inside and not your own.

origin: We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, And he shall say you are not well today.
modern: We’ll send Mark Antony to the senate house, and he’ll say that you’re sick today.

origin: Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And for thy humor I will stay at home.
modern: Mark Antony will say I’m not well, and to please you I’ll stay at home.

origin: Here’s Decius Brutus.
modern: Here’s Decius Brutus.

origin: He shall tell them so.
modern: He’ll tell them so.

origin: Caesar, all hail!
modern: Hail, Caesar!

origin: Good morrow, worthy Caesar.
modern: Good morning, worthy Caesar.

origin: I come to fetch you to the senate house.
modern: I’ve come to take you to the senate house.

origin: And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the senators And tell them that I will not come today.
modern: And you’ve come at a good time, so you can convey my greetings to the senators and tell them I won’t come today.

origin: Shall Caesar send a lie?
modern: Would I send a lie?

origin: Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?
modern: Have I accomplished so much in battle, but now I’m afraid to tell some old men the truth?

origin: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.
modern: Decius, go tell them that Caesar won’t come.

origin: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
modern: Most mighty Caesar, give me some reason, so I won’t be laughed at when I tell them so.

origin: The cause is in my will.
modern: The reason is that it’s what I want.

origin: I will not come.
modern: I’m not coming.

origin: That is enough to satisfy the senate.
modern: That’s enough for the senate.

origin: But for your private satisfaction, Because I love you, I will let you know.
modern: But for your private satisfaction, because I love you, I’ll tell you.

origin: Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.
modern: Calphurnia, my wife, is keeping me at home.

origin: And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begged that I will stay at home today.
modern: She takes these signs for warnings and predictions of terrible evils to come, and, on her knee, she begged me to stay home today.

origin: This dream is all amiss interpreted.
modern: This dream has been interpreted all wrong.

origin: It was a vision fair and fortunate.
modern: It was a good and lucky vision.

origin: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance.
modern: Your statue spouting blood through many holes, in which many smiling Romans bathed, means that you’ll provide great Rome with sustaining blood, and that great men will strive to get some token of approval from your holy blood.

origin: This by Calphurnia’s dream is signified.
modern: This is what Calphurnia’s dream means.

origin: And this way have you well expounded it.
modern: You’ve offered an excellent interpretation.

origin: I have, when you have heard what I can say.
modern: I will have when you hear the rest of what I have to say.

origin: And know it now: the senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
modern: The senate has decided to give mighty Caesar a crown today.

origin: If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change.
modern: If you send them word that you won’t come, they might change their minds.

origin: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia!
modern: How foolish your fears seem now, Calphurnia!

origin: I am ashamèd I did yield to them.
modern: I’m ashamed that I yielded to them.

origin: Give me my robe, for I will go.
modern: Give me my robe, because I’m going.

origin: And look, where Publius is come to fetch me.
modern: And look, here’s Publius, come to fetch me.

origin: Good morrow, Caesar.
modern: Good morning, Caesar.

origin: Welcome, Publius.
modern: Welcome, Publius.

origin: Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius, Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean.
modern: Caius Ligarius, I was never your enemy so much as the sickness that’s made you so thin.

origin: What is ’t o'clock?
modern: What time is it?

origin: Caesar, ’tis strucken eight.
modern: Caesar, the clock has struck eight.

origin: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.
modern: I thank you all for your trouble and courtesy.

origin: So to most noble Caesar.
modern: And to you, most noble Caesar.

origin: I am to blame to be thus waited for.
modern: I’m to blame for making you wait for me.

origin: Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius, I have an hour’s talk in store for you.
modern: Trebonius!

origin: Remember that you call on me today.
modern: Remember to see me today.

origin: Be near me, that I may remember you.
modern: Stay near me so I’ll remember.

origin: Caesar, I will.
modern: Caesar, I will.

origin: Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me.
modern: Good friends, go in and have some wine with me.

origin: And we, like friends, will straightway go together.
modern: And we’ll leave together, like friends.

origin: Calphurnia!
modern: Calphurnia!

origin: Peace, ho!
modern: Quiet!

origin: Caesar speaks.
modern: Caesar’s talking.

origin: Calphurnia!
modern: Calphurnia!

origin: Here, my lord.
modern: I’m here, my lord.

origin: Caesar, my lord.
modern: Yes, Caesar?

origin: I shall remember.
modern: I’ll remember.

origin: When Caesar says, “do this,” it is performed.
modern: When Caesar says “do this,” it is done.

origin: Set on, and leave no ceremony out.
modern: Continue, then, and don’t forget to perform all of the rituals.

origin: Caesar!
modern: Caesar!

origin: Caesar, beware of Brutus.
modern: Caesar, beware of Brutus.

origin: Take heed of Cassius.
modern: Watch Cassius.

origin: Come not near Casca.
modern: Don’t go near Casca.

origin: Have an eye to Cinna.
modern: Keep an eye on Cinna.

origin: Trust not Trebonius.
modern: Don’t trust Trebonius.

origin: Mark well Metellus Cimber.
modern: Pay attention to Metellus Cimber.

origin: Decius Brutus loves thee not.
modern: Decius Brutus doesn’t love you.

origin: Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.
modern: You’ve wronged Caius Ligarius.

origin: There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar.
modern: These men all have one intention, and it’s directed against Caesar.

origin: If thou beest not immortal, look about you.
modern: If you aren’t immortal, watch those around you.

origin: Security gives way to conspiracy.
modern: A sense of security opens the door to conspiracy.

origin: The mighty gods defend thee!
modern: I pray that the mighty gods defend you!

origin: Thy lover,      Artemidorus” Here will I stand till Caesar pass along, And as a suitor will I give him this.
modern: Your friend,      Artemidorus.” I’ll stand here until Caesar passes by, and I’ll give him this as though it’s a petition.

origin: If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.
modern: If you read this, Caesar, you might live.

origin: If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.
modern: If not, the Fates are on the side of the traitors.

origin: I prithee, boy, run to the senate house.
modern: Boy, I beg you to run to the senate house.

origin: Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.
modern: Don’t stay to answer me—get going.

origin: I would have had thee there and here again Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.
modern: I want you there and back again before I can even tell you what you should do there.

origin: Madam, what should I do?
modern: Madam, what should I do?

origin: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?
modern: Run to the Capitol and nothing else?

origin: And so return to you, and nothing else?
modern: And then return to you and nothing else?

origin: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth.
modern: Yes, return and tell me if your master looks well, because he was sick when he left.

origin: And take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.
modern: And pay attention to what Caesar does and which men are close to him.

origin: Hark, boy!
modern: Listen, boy!

origin: What noise is that?
modern: What’s that noise?

origin: I hear none, madam.
modern: I don’t hear anything, madam.

origin: Prithee, listen well.
modern: I beg you, listen well.

origin: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
modern: Truly, madam, I don’t hear anything.

origin: Come hither, fellow.
modern: Come here, you.

origin: Which way hast thou been?
modern: Where are you coming from?

origin: At mine own house, good lady.
modern: My own house, good lady.

origin: What is ’t o'clock?
modern: What time is it?

origin: About the ninth hour, lady.
modern: Around nine o'clock, madam.

origin: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?
modern: Has Caesar gone to the Capital yet?

origin: Madam, not yet.
modern: Madam, not yet.

origin: I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol.
modern: I’m going to stand so I can see him pass on the way to the Capitol.

origin: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?
modern: You have some plea for Caesar, don’t you?

origin: That I have, lady.
modern: Yes, I do, lady.

origin: If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself.
modern: If it pleases Caesar to be so good to himself as to hear me, I’ll try to get him to do what’s good for him.

origin: Why, know’st thou any harm’s intended towards him?
modern: Why, do you know of any harm intended toward him?

origin: None that I know will be; much that I fear may chance.
modern: Nothing that I know for sure, but a lot that I’m afraid might happen.

origin: Good morrow to you.
modern: Good morning to you.

origin: Here the street is narrow.
modern: The street is narrow here.

origin: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of senators, of praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.
modern: The crowd that follows Caesar at his heels—senators, justices, common petitioners—will suffocate a feeble man almost to death.

origin: I’ll get me to a place more void, and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.
modern: I’ll move to a more open place and there speak to great Caesar as he walks past.

origin: I must go in.
modern: I must go in.

origin: Ay, Caesar, but not gone.
modern: Yes, Caesar, but it’s not gone yet.

origin: O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit That touches Caesar nearer.
modern: Oh, Caesar, read mine first, for my petition affects you more directly.

origin: Read it, great Caesar.
modern: Read it, great Caesar.

origin: What touches us ourself shall be last served.
modern: Whatever pertains to myself I will deal with last.

origin: Delay not, Caesar.
modern: Don’t delay, Caesar.

origin: Read it instantly.
modern: Read it instantly.

origin: What, is the fellow mad?
modern: What, is the man insane?

origin: Weapons, arms?
modern: You have weapons?

origin: What’s the matter here?
modern: What’s going on here?

origin: Keep peace, upon your lives.
modern: Stop it, I order you.

origin: He dies that strikes again.
modern: The next person to strike again dies.

origin: What is the matter?
modern: What’s going on here?

origin: The messengers from our sister and the king.
modern: These are the messengers from my sister and the king.

origin: What is your difference?
modern: What are you fighting about?

origin: Speak.
modern: Tell me.

origin: I am scarce in breath, my lord.
modern: I’m out of breath, sir.

origin: A tailor made thee.
modern: A tailor made you.

origin: Thou art a strange fellow.
modern: That’s an odd thing to say.

origin: A tailor make a man?
modern: How can a tailor make a person?

origin: Ay, a tailor, sir.
modern: Definitely a tailor, sir.

origin: A stone-cutter or painter could not have made him so ill though they had been but two years o' th' trade.
modern: A sculptor or a painter couldn’t have screwed him up as bad as that, even as an apprentice.

origin: Speak yet.
modern: But tell me what you’re fighting about.

origin: Peace, sirrah!
modern: Calm down.

origin: You beastly knave, know you no reverence?
modern: Don’t you have any manners, you savage?

origin: Yes, sir, but anger hath a privilege.
modern: Yes, sir, but not when I’m enraged.

origin: Why art thou angry?
modern: Why are you enraged?

origin: Smile you my speeches as I were a fool?
modern: Are you laughing at what I say, as if I were a fool?

origin: Why, art thou mad, old fellow?
modern: Are you insane, old man?

origin: Why dost thou call him “knave”?
modern: Why are you calling him a jerk?

origin: What’s his offense?
modern: What did he do to you?

origin: His countenance likes me not.
modern: I don’t like his face.

origin: No more perchance does mine, nor his, nor hers.
modern: But maybe you don’t like mine, or his, or hers either.

origin: This is some fellow, Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect A saucy roughness and constrains the garb Quite from his nature.
modern: This is a guy who’s been praised for his honest bluntness, and who now insolently pretends to be plainspoken and twists the natural meanings of words.

origin: He cannot flatter, he.
modern: No flattery for him, no sir!

origin: An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth.
modern: He’s honest, he’s got to speak the truth.

origin: An they will take it, so.
modern: If people take what he says, fine.

origin: If not, he’s plain.
modern: If not, he’s got truth on his side!

origin: Sir, in good faith, or in sincere verity, Under th' allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus' front—      What mean’st by this?
modern: Dearest, kindest, most honorable sir, may I say, with your esteemed approval, which is lit up by the illuminating radiance of the sun-god Phoebus, that— What do you mean by that?

origin: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much.
modern: I tried to stop speaking plainly, since you dislike plain speech so much.

origin: I know, sir, I am no flatterer.
modern: Sir, I know I’m not a flatterer.

origin: I never gave him any.
modern: I never offended him at all.

origin: None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool.
modern: These cowards manage to make fools of brave men.

origin: Call not your stocks for me.
modern: Don’t put me in the stocks.

origin: I serve the king, On whose employment I was sent to you.
modern: I serve the king, who sent me here.

origin: You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger.
modern: If you put me in the stocks you’ll insult him both as a king and as a man.

origin: Fetch forth the stocks!
modern: Bring out the stocks!

origin: As I have life and honor, there shall he sit till noon.
modern: I swear on my life and honor, he’ll sit here in the stocks until noon.

origin: Till noon?
modern: Only until noon, my lord?

origin: Till night, my lord, and all night too.
modern: No, the whole day, and all night too.

origin: Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog, You should not use me so.
modern: Ma'am, you wouldn’t treat me like this if I were your father’s dog.

origin: Sir, being his knave, I will.
modern: But since you’re his scoundrel servant, I will.

origin: This is a fellow of the selfsame color Our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!
modern: This guy is exactly the kind of person your sister warned us about.—Come on, bring in the stocks, now!

origin: Let me beseech your grace not to do so.
modern: I beg you not to do this, my lord.

origin: His fault is much, and the good king his master Will check him for ’t.
modern: He’s done wrong, and his master the king will punish him for it.

origin: The king his master needs must take it ill, That he, so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restrained.
modern: The king will be offended to find out that his messenger is so badly treated.

origin: I’ll answer that.
modern: I’ll take responsibility for that.

origin: My sister may receive it much more worse To have her gentleman abused, assaulted For following her affairs.—Put in his legs.
modern: My sister would be much more offended to have her trusted messenger abused and assaulted just for carrying out her orders.—Put his legs in the stocks.

origin: I am sorry for thee, friend.
modern: I’m sorry, my friend.

origin: I’ll entreat for thee.
modern: I’ll try talking to him again.

origin: Pray you do not, sir.
modern: Please don’t, sir.

origin: A good man’s fortune may grow out at heels.
modern: Even good men have bad luck.

origin: Give you good morrow.
modern: Have a good morning.

origin: The duke’s to blame in this.
modern: It’s wrong for the duke to do this.

origin: Twill be ill taken.
modern: The king will be angry with him.

origin: Obey you, love you, and most honor you.
modern: honor you.

origin: Haply when I shall wed That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.
modern: Hopefully when I get married, I’ll give my husband half my love and half my sense of duty.

origin: Sure, I shall never marry like my sisters, To love my father all.
modern: I’m sure I’ll never get married in the way my sisters say they’re married, loving their father only.

origin: But goes thy heart with this?
modern: But do you mean what you’re saying?

origin: Ay, good my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: So young and so untender?
modern: So young and so cruel?

origin: So young, my lord, and true.
modern: So young, my lord, and honest.

origin: Let it be so.
modern: Then that’s the way it’ll be.

origin: Thy truth then be thy dower.
modern: The truth will be all the inheritance you get.

origin: The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved As thou my sometime daughter.
modern: Foreign savages who eat their own children for dinner will be as close to my heart as you, ex-daughter of mine.

origin: Good my liege— Peace, Kent.
modern: But sir— Be quiet, Kent.

origin: I heard myself proclaimed, And by the happy hollow of a tree Escaped the hunt.
modern: I heard myself declared an outlaw and escaped capture by hiding in the trunk of a hollow tree.

origin: No port is free, no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking.
modern: Every town and port is crawling with henchmen on the lookout, waiting to capture me.

origin: My face I’ll grime with filth, Blanket my loins, elf all my hair in knots, And with presented nakedness outface The winds and persecutions of the sky.
modern: I’ll smear my face with filth, put on a loincloth, make my hair matted and tangled, and face the bad weather wearing almost nothing.

origin: Poor Turlygod!” “Poor Tom!”— That’s something yet.
modern: Well, at least that’s something.

origin: Edgar I nothing am.
modern: As Edgar, I’m nothing at all.

origin: Tis strange that they should so depart from home, And not send back my messenger.
modern: It’s strange that Regan and her husband left their house without sending back my messenger.

origin: As I learned, The night before there was no purpose in them Of this remove.
modern: According to what I heard, they had no travel plans as of last night.

origin: Ha!
modern: What’s this?

origin: Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
modern: Are you sitting around in this humiliation to amuse yourself?

origin: No, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

origin: Ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha!

origin: Look, he wears cruel garters.
modern: That’s a nasty garter belt.

origin: Horses are tied by the heads, dogs and bears by the neck, monkeys by the loins, and men by the legs.
modern: You tie up horses by their heads, dogs and bears by their necks, monkeys by their waists, and humans by their legs.

origin: It is both he and she: Your son and daughter.
modern: Your daughter and son-in-law.

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Yes.
modern: Yes.

origin: No, no, they would not.
modern: No, no, they wouldn’t.

origin: Yes, they have.
modern: Yes, they have.

origin: By Jupiter, I swear “No.” By Juno, I swear “Ay.”    They durst not do ’t.
modern: By the god Jupiter above, I swear “No.” By Jupiter’s wife Juno, I swear “Yes.” They wouldn’t dare.

origin: They could not, would not do ’t.
modern: They couldn’t, they wouldn’t.

origin: Tis worse than murder To do upon respect such violent outrage.
modern: It’s worse than murder to humiliate a king’s messenger like this.

origin: My lord, when at their home I did commend your highness' letters to them.
