origin: Fut, I should have been that I am, had the maidenliest star in the firmament twinkled on my bastardizing.
modern: I would have been what I am even if the most virginal star in the heavens had twinkled at my conception.

origin: Fa, sol, la, mi.
modern: Fa, sol, la, mi.

origin: How now, brother Edmund?
modern: Hello, brother Edmund.

origin: What serious contemplation are you in?
modern: What are you thinking about so seriously?

origin: How long have you been a sectary astronomical?
modern: How long have you believed in astrology?

origin: Come, come.
modern: Come on.

origin: When saw you my father last?
modern: When was the last time you saw my father?

origin: Why, the night gone by.
modern: Why, last night.

origin: Spake you with him?
modern: Did you speak to him?

origin: Ay, two hours together.
modern: Yes, we talked for a couple of hours.

origin: Parted you in good terms?
modern: Did you leave on good terms?

origin: Found you no displeasure in him by word or countenance?
modern: Did he express any dissatisfaction with you, either in his words or his face?

origin: None at all.
modern: No, none at all.

origin: Some villain hath done me wrong.
modern: Some villain has told lies about me.

origin: That’s my fear.
modern: That’s what I’m afraid of.

origin: I pray you, have a continent forbearance till the speed of his rage goes slower.
modern: I suggest you lay low until his rage cools a little.

origin: And as I say, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my lord speak.
modern: In the meantime, come home with me, and when the time is right I’ll take you to talk to him.

origin: Pray ye, go.
modern: Please go.

origin: There’s my key.
modern: Here’s my key.

origin: If you do stir abroad, go armed.
modern: If you go outside, arm yourself.

origin: Armed, brother?
modern: Arm myself?

origin: Brother, I advise you to the best.
modern: Brother, I’m giving you good advice.

origin: Go armed.
modern: Arm yourself.

origin: Pray you, away.
modern: Now please go.

origin: Shall I hear from you anon?
modern: Will I hear from you soon?

origin: I do serve you in this business.
modern: I’ll help you through this business.

origin: A credulous father, and a brother noble— Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy.
modern: A gullible father and a brother who’s so innocent that he can’t suspect anyone else of wanting to hurt him—these are the two fools I need for my plan to work.

origin: I see the business.
modern: I know exactly how to proceed.

origin: Let me, if not by birth, have lands by wit.
modern: If I can’t have an estate by birthright, then I’ll get it by being clever.

origin: All with me’s meet that I can fashion fit.
modern: Any trick that works is good for me.

origin: Did my father strike my gentleman For chiding of his fool?
modern: Did my father hit one of my attendants for scolding his fool?

origin: Ay, madam.
modern: Yes, ma'am.

origin: By day and night he wrongs me.
modern: He constantly offends me.

origin: Every hour He flashes into one gross crime or other That sets us all at odds.
modern: Every hour he comes out with some horrible new offense that puts us all on edge.

origin: I’ll not endure it.
modern: I won’t stand for it.

origin: His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us On every trifle.
modern: His knights are getting out of control, and he himself reprimands us about every little detail.

origin: When he returns from hunting, I will not speak with him.
modern: When he comes back from hunting, I’m not going to speak to him.

origin: Say I am sick.
modern: Tell him I’m sick.

origin: If you come slack of former services, You shall do well.
modern: And if you’re not as attentive in serving him as you used to be, that’ll be good.

origin: The fault of it I’ll answer.
modern: I’ll take responsibility for it.

origin: He’s coming, madam.
modern: He’s coming, ma'am.

origin: I hear him.
modern: I hear him.

origin: Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your fellow servants.
modern: Be as lazy and neglectful as you like around him—you and the other servants.

origin: If he distaste it, let him to our sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Not to be overruled.
modern: If he doesn’t like it, he can go live with my sister.

origin: Idle old man That still would manage those authorities That he hath given away!
modern: That useless old man still thinks he can wield all the powers he’s given away.

origin: Now by my life, Old fools are babes again and must be used With checks as flatteries, when they are seen abused.
modern: I swear, old fools become like babies again.

origin: Remember what I have said.
modern: Remember what I’ve told you.

origin: Very well, madam.
modern: Very well, ma'am.

origin: And let his knights have colder looks among you.
modern: And make sure the servants are less friendly to his knights.

origin: What grows of it, no matter.
modern: Don’t worry about the consequences.

origin: Advise your fellows so.
modern: Tell your men as much.

origin: I would breed from hence occasions, and I shall, That I may speak.
modern: I want this to provoke confrontations, so I can give him a piece of my mind.

origin: I’ll write straight to my sister To hold my very course.
modern: I’ll write to my sister and tell her my plans.

origin: Go, prepare for dinner.
modern: Now go, set up for dinner.

origin: If but as well I other accents borrow, That can my speech diffuse, my good intent May carry through itself to that full issue For which I razed my likeness.
modern: If I can disguise my voice as well as my appearance, then I’ll be able to carry out my plan perfectly.

origin: Now, banished Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned, So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest, Shall find thee full of labors.
modern: I love my master, and he’ll find me very hard-working.

origin: Let me not stay a jot for dinner.
modern: Don’t make me wait for dinner even a moment.

origin: Go get it ready.
modern: Get it ready immediately.

origin: A man, sir.
modern: A man, sir.

origin: What dost thou profess?
modern: What’s your profession?

origin: What wouldst thou with us?
modern: What do you want from me?

origin: What art thou?
modern: But who are you?

origin: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the king.
modern: An honest guy who’s as poor as the king.

origin: If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou'rt poor enough.
modern: If you’re as poor a subject as he is a king, you definitely are poor.

origin: What wouldst thou?
modern: What do you want?

origin: Service.
modern: To work as a servant.

origin: Who wouldst thou serve?
modern: Who do you want to work for?

origin: You.
modern: You.

origin: Dost thou know me, fellow?
modern: Do you know me?

origin: Authority.
modern: Authority.

origin: What services canst thou do?
modern: What work can you do?

origin: I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a curious tale in telling it, and deliver a plain message bluntly.
modern: I can be discreet in honorable matters, ride a horse, run, tell a good story badly, and deliver a plain message bluntly.

origin: That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in.
modern: I’m good at everything that ordinary men can do.

origin: And the best of me is diligence.
modern: The best thing about me is that I’m hardworking.

origin: How old art thou?
modern: How old are you?

origin: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for anything.
modern: Not young enough to fall in love with a woman because she sings well, but not old enough to dote on a woman for any reason.

origin: I have years on my back forty- eight.
modern: I’m forty-eight.

origin: Follow me.
modern: Follow me.

origin: Thou shalt serve me.
modern: You’ll work for me.

origin: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
modern: Where’s my fool?—Go call my fool and have him come here.

origin: No, my lord.
modern: No, I don’t, my lord.

origin: My services to your lordship.
modern: Very pleased to meet you, my lord.

origin: I must love you and sue to know you better.
modern: I look forward to getting to know you better.

origin: Sir, I shall study deserving.
modern: I’ll try to make myself worth your knowledge.

origin: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
modern: He’s been gone for nine years and he’s leaving again soon.

origin: The king is coming.
modern: The king is coming.

origin: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.
modern: Go escort the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

origin: I shall, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
modern: You, sir, where’s my daughter?

origin: So please you— What says the fellow there?
modern: I beg your pardon, sir— What did that guy say?

origin: Call the clotpoll back.
modern: Call the numbskull back in here.

origin: Where’s my fool, ho?
modern: Where’s my fool?

origin: I think the world’s asleep.
modern: You’d think everyone was asleep.

origin: How now?
modern: So what’s going on?

origin: Where’s that mongrel?
modern: Where’s that dog?

origin: He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.
modern: He says your daughter’s not feeling well, my lord.

origin: Why came not the slave back to me when I called him.
modern: Why didn’t the jerk come back to me when I called him?

origin: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner he would not.
modern: Sir, he told me quite bluntly that he didn’t feel like it.

origin: He would not?
modern: Didn’t feel like it?

origin: My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my judgment your highness is not entertained with that ceremonious affection as you were wont.
modern: My lord, I don’t know what’s going on, but it seems to me that your highness isn’t being treated as politely as before.

origin: There’s a great abatement of kindness appears as well in the general dependants as in the duke himself also, and your daughter.
modern: The servants, the duke, and your daughter all seem to be treating you less kindly.

origin: Ha!
modern: Huh!

origin: Sayest thou so?
modern: Do you really mean that?

origin: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken—for my duty cannot be silent when I think your highness wronged.
modern: Please forgive me if I’m mistaken, my lord—but I can’t keep quiet when I think you’re being insulted.

origin: Thou but rememberest me of mine own conception.
modern: No, you’re just reminding me of something I’ve also noticed.

origin: I have perceived a most faint neglect of late, which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of unkindness.
modern: I’ve felt neglected recently, but I decided that it was more likely that I was being hypersensitive than that they were intentionally unkind.

origin: I will look further into ’t.
modern: I’ll look into it further.

origin: But where’s my fool?
modern: But where’s my fool?

origin: I have not seen him this two days.
modern: I haven’t seen him for two days.

origin: Since my young lady’s going into France, sir, the fool hath much pined away.
modern: Ever since Cordelia left for France, sir, the fool has been depressed.

origin: No more of that.
modern: Let’s not talk about it.

origin: I have noted it well.
modern: I’ve noticed it myself.

origin: Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.
modern: Go and tell my daughter I want to speak with her.

origin: Go you, call hither my fool.
modern: And you, go call my fool.

origin: O you sir, you, come you hither, sir.
modern: You there, sir, come here please.

origin: Who am I, sir?
modern: Who am I, sir?

origin: You slave, you cur!
modern: You scoundrel!

origin: I am none of these, my lord.
modern: You lowlife son-of-a-bitch!

origin: I beseech your pardon.
modern: You dog, you peasant!

origin: I’ll not be strucken, my lord.
modern: I won’t be hit, my lord.

origin: Now, my friendly knave, I thank thee.
modern: Now, my friendly servant, thank you.

origin: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.
modern: Wait, let me hire him too.—Here’s my fool’s cap, a token of my gratitude.

origin: How now, my pretty knave?
modern: Well hello, my good boy.

origin: How dost thou?
modern: How are you doing?

origin: Why, Fool?
modern: Why, Fool?

origin: Why?
modern: Why?

origin: For taking one’s part that’s out of favor.
modern: For standing up for this unpopular king.

origin: Nay, an thou canst not smile as the wind sits, thou'lt catch cold shortly.
modern: No, if you can’t adjust to political changes, you’ll suffer for it.

origin: There, take my coxcomb.
modern: There, take my fool’s cap.

origin: Why, this fellow has banished two on ’s daughters, and did the third a blessing against his will.
modern: This guy here has banished two of his daughters and blessed the third one without intending to.

origin: If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.—How now, nuncle?
modern: If you work for him, you’re a fool and should wear a fool’s cap.—So how’s it going, uncle?

origin: Would I had two coxcombs and two daughters.
modern: I wish I had two fool’s caps and two daughters.

origin: Why, my boy?
modern: Why, my boy?

origin: If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.
modern: If I gave them all I own, I’d have two fool’s caps for myself.

origin: There’s mine.
modern: Here’s mine.

origin: Beg another of thy daughters.
modern: Ask your daughters for another one.

origin: Take heed, sirrah—the whip.
modern: Watch out, boy—remember I can whip you.

origin: A pestilent gall to me!
modern: A constant pain to me!

origin: Sirrah, I’ll teach thee a speech.
modern: I’ll recite something for you, guy.

origin: Do.
modern: Yes, do that.

origin: Mark it, nuncle.
modern: Listen up, uncle.

origin: Have more than thou showest, Speak less than thou knowest, Lend less than thou owest, Ride more than thou goest, Learn more than thou trowest, Set less than thou throwest, Leave thy drink and thy whore And keep in-a-door, And thou shalt have more Than two tens to a score.
modern: Have more than you show, Speak less than you know, Lend less than you owe.

origin: This is nothing, Fool.
modern: It’s nothing.

origin: Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer.
modern: In that case it’s like the words of an unpaid lawyer.

origin: Why no, boy.
modern: Why, no, boy.

origin: Nothing can be made out of nothing.
modern: Nothing can be made out of nothing.

origin: A bitter fool.
modern: You’re a bitter fool.

origin: Dost thou know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet fool?
modern: Do you know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet one?

origin: No, lad.
modern: No, son.

origin: Teach me.
modern: Tell me.

origin: That lord that counseled thee To give away thy land, Come place him here by me.
modern: Bring here The gentleman who advised you To give away your land.

origin: Do thou for him stand.
modern: You can stand in his place.

origin: The sweet and bitter fool Will presently appear— The one in motley here, The other found out there.
modern: The sweet and bitter fool Will appear right away.

origin: Dost thou call me fool, boy?
modern: The sweet fool in a fool’s costume—that’s me.

origin: All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast born with.
modern: The bitter one is the other one—that’s you.LEAR Are you calling me a fool, boy?

origin: This is not altogether fool, my lord.
modern: Well, you’ve given away all your other rightful titles.

origin: No, faith, lords and great men will not let me.
modern: No.

origin: What two crowns shall they be?
modern: Which two crowns would those be?

origin: Why—after I have cut the egg i' th' middle and eat up the meat—the two crowns of the egg.
modern: Well, when I cut the egg in half and eat the whites, the yolk will be in two parts like two golden crowns.

origin: If I speak like myself in this, let him be whipped that first finds it so.
modern: If I’m telling the truth like a fool in saying all this, whip the first person who thinks I sound foolish.

origin: When were you wont to be so full of songs, sirrah?
modern: When did you become so fond of singing, boy?

origin: I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy daughters thy mothers.
modern: I’ve been singing ever since you made your daughters into your mothers by giving them all your power.

origin: For when thou gavest them the rod, and put’st down thine own breeches,            Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach thy fool to lie.
modern: That’s when you gave them the spanking paddle and pulled your pants down,            Please, uncle, hire a teacher who can teach your fool to lie.

origin: I would fain learn to lie.
modern: I want to learn how to lie.

origin: An you lie, sirrah, we’ll have you whipped.
modern: If you lie, boy, we’ll have you whipped.

origin: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are.
modern: I’m amazed how similar you and your daughters are.

origin: They’ll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I am whipped for holding my peace.
modern: They want to whip me for telling the truth, you want to whip me for lying, and sometimes I’m even whipped for keeping quiet.

origin: I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool.
modern: I’d rather be anything besides a fool.

origin: And yet I would not be thee, nuncle.
modern: And yet I wouldn’t want to be you, uncle.

origin: Here comes one o' the parings.
modern: Here comes the owner of one piece.

origin: How now, daughter?
modern: What’s going on, daughter?

origin: What makes that frontlet on?
modern: Why are you frowning like that?

origin: Methinks you are too much of late i' th' frown.
modern: I think you’ve been frowning too much recently.

origin: He that keeps nor crust nor crumb,  Weary of all, shall want some.
modern: The man who gives away his crust and his crumbs Will discover that he needs some crumbs back.

origin: But other of your insolent retinue Do hourly carp and quarrel, breaking forth In rank and not-to-be-endurèd riots.
modern: will damage your reputation with them—and under ordinary circumstances it would be unfortunate to have them see you as an ogre.

origin: Which else were shame, that then necessity Will call discreet proceeding.
modern: However, this is an extreme situation, and it’s more important to control it than to worry about how you’ll look.

origin: For you know, nuncle, The hedge-sparrow fed the cuckoo so long, That it’s had it head bit off by it young.
modern: You know, uncle, A sparrow once raised a cuckoo in its nest Until the cuckoo grew up and bit the sparrow’s head off.

origin: So out went the candle and we were left darkling.
modern: So the candle went out and now we’re all in the dark.

origin: Are you our daughter?
modern: Are you my daughter?

origin: Does any here know me?
modern: Does anyone here know who I am?

origin: Why, this is not Lear.
modern: I’m not Lear.

origin: Where are his eyes?
modern: Where are his eyes?

origin: Sure, ’tis not so.
modern: I don’t think so.

origin: Who is it that can tell me who I am?
modern: Who can tell me who I am?

origin: Lear’s shadow.
modern: You’re Lear’s shadow.

origin: Which they will make an obedient father.
modern: Daughters who can make you obey them.

origin: This admiration, sir, is much o' th' savor Of other your new pranks.
modern: This fake astonishment of yours is just like your other pranks.

origin: I do beseech you To understand my purposes aright.
modern: I’m asking you to understand my point of view.

origin: As you are old and reverend, should be wise.
modern: Since you’re old and respected, you should be wise.

origin: Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires, Men so disordered, so debauched and bold That this our court, infected with their manners, Shows like a riotous inn.
modern: But you’re keeping a hundred knights here who are so disorderly, vulgar, and obnoxious that our noble court is starting to look like a noisy cheap hotel.

origin: Epicurism and lust Make it more like a tavern or a brothel Than a graced palace.
modern: They’re such oversexed gluttons that I feel like we’re living in a pub or a whorehouse rather than a respectable palace.

origin: The shame itself doth speak For instant remedy.
modern: It’s shameful, and we have to make some changes right away.

origin: Darkness and devils!
modern: Hell and damnation!

origin: Saddle my horses.
modern: Saddle up my horses.

origin: Call my train together.— Degenerate bastard, I’ll not trouble thee.
modern: Call my knights together.

origin: Yet have I left a daughter.
modern: You’re not really my daughter, but I still have one daughter left.

origin: You strike my people, and your disordered rabble Make servants of their betters.
modern: You hit my servants, and your disorderly mob of knights treat their superiors like servants.

origin: Woe that too late repents!—   Is it your will?
modern: You’ll be sorry later, but it’ll be too late.

origin: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend, More hideous when thou show’st thee in a child Than the sea monster.
modern: Ingratitude is always hideous, but an ungrateful child is uglier than a sea monster!

origin: Pray, sir, be patient.
modern: Please, sir, be patient.

origin: It may be so, my lord.
modern: That may be true, my lord.

origin: Hear, Nature, hear, dear goddess, hear!
modern: Ah, dear Nature, my goddess, listen to me!

origin: Dry up in her the organs of increase, And from her derogate body never spring A babe to honor her.
modern: Make her sterile and dry up her womb so that no baby will ever come out of her body and honor her.

origin: To thine and Albany’s issue Be this perpetual.—What says our second daughter, Our dearest Regan, wife of Cornwall?
modern: This land will belong to your and Albany’s children forever.—And now what does my second daughter Regan, the wife of Cornwall, have to say?

origin: Speak.
modern: Tell me.

origin: Now gods that we adore, whereof comes this?
modern: Dear gods in heaven, what’s the reason for this?

origin: Thou shalt find That I’ll resume the shape which thou dost think I have cast off for ever.
modern: And then you’ll see that despite what you thought, I’ll be as powerful as I was before.

origin: Thou shalt, I warrant thee.
modern: You’ll see, I promise you.

origin: Do you mark that, my lord?
modern: Did you hear that?

origin: I cannot be so partial, Goneril, To the great love I bear you—      Pray you, content.
modern: Goneril, you know how much I love you, but still I have to say— Shush, please.

origin: Come, sire, no more.—What, Oswald, ho!
modern: Come, sir, no more.—Oswald, come here!

origin: A fox when one has caught her And such a daughter Should sure to the slaughter, If my cap would buy a halter.
modern: A fox you’ve trapped And such a daughter Should both be slaughtered, If my fool’s cap is worth a rope to bind them.

origin: So the fool follows after.
modern: So the fool follows you.

origin: This man hath had good counsel—a hundred knights!
modern: My father can’t think straight—a hundred knights!

origin: Well, you may fear too far.
modern: You may be exaggerating the risks.

origin: Safer than trust too far.
modern: That’s better than exaggerating our trust.

origin: Let me still take away the harms I fear, Not fear still to be taken.
modern: It’s always better to get rid of what you’re scared of than to be afraid.

origin: I know his heart.
modern: I know how his mind works.

origin: What he hath uttered I have writ my sister.
modern: I’ve written to my sister telling her everything he’s said.

origin: If she sustain him and his hundred knights When I have showed th' unfitness— Here, madam.
modern: If she welcomes him and his hundred knights after I’ve shown how inappropriately he’s behaved— Here, ma'am.

origin: How now, Oswald?
modern: Well, Oswald?

origin: What, have you writ that letter to my sister?
modern: Have you written that letter to my sister yet?

origin: Ay, madam.
modern: Yes, ma'am.

origin: Take you some company, and away to horse.
modern: Take some men and horses and go to her.

origin: Inform her full of my particular fear, And thereto add such reasons of your own As may compact it more.
modern: Add details of your own to back up what I’m saying.

origin: Get you gone And hasten your return.
modern: Now go, and hurry back.

origin: Striving to better, oft we mar what’s well.
modern: But people often screw things up trying to make them better.

origin: Nay, then— Well, well, th' event.
modern: No, not at all— All right, all right.

origin: I will not sleep, my lord, till I have delivered your letter.
modern: I won’t sleep until I’ve delivered your letter, my lord.

origin: If a man’s brains were in ’s heels, were ’t not in danger of kibes?
modern: If a man’s brain were in his feet, wouldn’t it be susceptible to frostbite?

origin: Ay, boy.
modern: Yes, boy.

origin: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: Shalt see thy other daughter will use thee kindly.
modern: Your other daughter Regan will treat you kindly, you’ll see.

origin: For though she’s as like this as a crab’s like an apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.
modern: Even though she’s as similar to Goneril as one crabapple is like another, still… I know what I know.

origin: Why, what canst thou tell, my boy?
modern: And what do you know, boy?

origin: She will taste as like this as a crab does to a crab.
modern: I know that Regan will taste just like Goneril—both of them sour crabapples.

origin: Thou canst tell why one’s nose stands i' th' middle on ’s face?
modern: Do you know why the nose is in the middle of a person’s face?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Why, to keep one’s eyes of either side ’s nose, that what a man cannot smell out, he may spy into.
modern: Why, to keep the eyes on the sides, so that you can see anything that you can’t sniff out.

origin: I did her wrong— Canst tell how an oyster makes his shell?
modern: I was wrong to her— Do you know how an oyster makes its shell?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Nor I neither.
modern: Me neither.

origin: But I can tell why a snail has a house.
modern: But I know why a snail carries its house on its back.

origin: Why?
modern: Why?

origin: Why, to put ’s head in—not to give it away to his daughters and leave his horns without a case.
modern: He can’t give his house away to his daughters, leaving himself without shelter.

origin: I will forget my nature.
modern: I want to forget what I am.

origin: So kind a father!—Be my horses ready?
modern: Such a kind father!—Are my horses ready?

origin: Thy asses are gone about 'em.
modern: Your attendant asses are getting the horses ready.

origin: The reason why the seven stars are no more than seven is a pretty reason.
modern: There’s a nice reason why the constellation Pleiades has only seven stars in it.

origin: Because they are not eight?
modern: Because it doesn’t have eight?

origin: Yes indeed.
modern: That’s right.

origin: Thou wouldst make a good fool.
modern: You’d make a good fool.

origin: To take ’t again perforce— Monster ingratitude!
modern: I could take back my crown by force—What outrageous ingratitude!

origin: If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I’d have thee beaten for being old before thy time.
modern: If you were my fool, uncle, I’d have you beaten for getting old before your time.

origin: How’s that?
modern: How’s that?

origin: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.
modern: You’re not supposed to get old until you’re wise.

origin: O, let me not be mad, not mad, sweet heaven!
modern: Oh, dear God, don’t let me go mad!

origin: Keep me in temper.
modern: Keep me balanced and sane.

origin: I would not be mad.
modern: I don’t want to go mad.

origin: Ready, my lord.
modern: They’re ready, my lord.

origin: Come, boy.
modern: Come on, boy.

origin: Save thee, Curan.
modern: Hello, Curan.

origin: And you, sir.
modern: Hello, sir.

origin: I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.
modern: I just saw your father the Lord Gloucester and notified him that the Duke of Cornwall and his wife Regan will stay with him here tonight.

origin: How comes that?
modern: Why is that?

origin: Nay, I know not.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: Have you heard of no likely wars toward ’twixt the two Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?
modern: You haven’t heard of the war brewing between the Dukes of Cornwall and Albany?

origin: Not a word.
modern: Not a word.

origin: You may do then in time.
modern: You may hear about it soon.

origin: Fare you well, sir.
modern: Goodbye, sir.

origin: The duke be here tonight?
modern: The duke will be here tonight?

origin: This weaves itself perforce into my business.
modern: His arrival fits perfectly into my plan.

origin: Briefness and fortune, work!— Brother, a word.
modern: Fast work and a little luck are all I need.—Brother, could I have a word with you?

origin: Descend, brother, I say.
modern: Come down, brother.

origin: My father watches.
modern: Father is on the lookout.

origin: O sir, fly this place.
modern: Get out of here quickly!

origin: Intelligence is given where you are hid.
modern: It has leaked out that you’re hiding here.

origin: Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall aught?
modern: You haven’t said anything against the Duke of Cornwall, have you?

origin: He’s coming hither—now, i' th' night, i' th' haste, And Regan with him.
modern: He’s rushing on his way here right now, and Regan’s with him.

origin: Advise yourself.
modern: Think about it.

origin: I hear my father coming.
modern: I hear my father coming.

origin: Pardon me.
modern: Forgive me.

origin: In cunning I must draw my sword upon you.
modern: I have to pretend to threaten you with my sword.

origin: Now quit you well.—             Torches, torches!
modern: Be convincing.

origin: Now Edmund, where’s the villain?
modern: Edmund, where’s your wicked brother?

origin: Look, sir, I bleed.
modern: Look, sir, I’m bleeding.

origin: Where is the villain, Edmund?
modern: Where is the villain, Edmund?

origin: Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could— Pursue him, ho!
modern: He ran out that way, sir, when he couldn’t— Follow him, now!

origin: Go after.
modern: Go.

origin: By no means” what?
modern: When he couldn’t what?

origin: Sir, in fine, Seeing how loathly opposite I stood To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion, With his preparèd sword he charges home My unprovided body, latched mine arm.
modern: In short, when I told him how firmly opposed I was to his hideous plan, he pulled out his sword and lunged at my defenseless body, cutting my arm.

origin: And when he saw my best alarumed spirits, Bold in the quarrel’s right, roused to the encounter, Or whether ghasted by the noise I made, Full suddenly he fled.
modern: Bolstered by righteousness, I prepared to fight, and when he saw my excitement—or perhaps because my shouting scared him—he ran away suddenly.

origin: Let him fly far.
modern: Let him run far away.

origin: Not in this land shall he remain uncaught.
modern: If he stays in this country he’ll be found.

origin: The noble duke my master, My worthy arch and patron, comes tonight.
modern: The Duke of Cornwall, my master and patron, is arriving tonight.

origin: And find I am alone felicitate In your dear highness' love.
modern: joy except my love for you, and I find that only your majesty’s love makes me happy.

origin: Speak.
modern: Speak.

origin: Nothing, my lord.
modern: Nothing, my lord.

origin: Nothing?
modern: Nothing?

origin: Nothing.
modern: Nothing.

origin: Nothing will come of nothing.
modern: Come on, “nothing” will get you nothing.

origin: Speak again.
modern: Try again.

origin: Unhappy that I am, I cannot heave My heart into my mouth.
modern: I don’t have a talent for putting my heart’s feelings into words.

origin: I love your majesty According to my bond, no more nor less.
modern: I love you as a child should love her father, neither more nor less.

origin: How, how, Cordelia?
modern: What are you saying, Cordelia?

origin: Mend your speech a little, Lest you may mar your fortunes.
modern: Revise your statement, or you may damage your inheritance.

origin: He that conceals him, death.
modern: justice will be rewarded.

origin: He replied, “Thou unpossessing bastard!
modern: He answered, “You penniless bastard!

origin: Dost thou think If I would stand against thee, would the reposal Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee Make thy words faithed?
modern: Do you really think that if it came down to my word against yours, anyone would believe you?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: What I should deny— As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce My very character—I’d turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.
modern: I’d deny whatever evidence you had against me—even if it were in my own handwriting—and turn it all into evidence against you and your plans for treachery.

origin: And thou must make a dullard of the world, If they not thought the profits of my death Were very pregnant and potential spirits To make thee seek it.”    O strange and fastened villain!
modern: And you must think people are stupid if you believe they wouldn’t realize all the motives you have for trying to kill me.” Oh, how monstrously evil!

origin: Would he deny his letter, said he?
modern: He said he would deny that he wrote his letter?

origin: I never got him.— Hark, the duke’s trumpets.
modern: The duke’s trumpets.

origin: I know not why he comes.
modern: I don’t know why he’s come here.

origin: All ports I’ll bar.
modern: I’ll forbid all ships from leaving our harbors.

origin: The villain shall not ’scape.
modern: The villain won’t escape.

origin: The duke must grant me that.
modern: The duke will agree with me on that.

origin: How now, my noble friend?
modern: How are you, my friend?

origin: Since I came hither, Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.
modern: Ever since I arrived here, just now, I’ve been hearing strange rumors.

origin: How dost, my lord?
modern: How are you, my lord?

origin: O madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.
modern: Oh, madam, my old heart is broken, broken.

origin: O, lady, lady, shame would have it hid.
modern: Oh, my lady, I’m ashamed to admit it.

origin: Was he not companion with the riotous knights That tend upon my father?
modern: Wasn’t he friends with all those brawling knights who serve my father?

origin: I know not, madam.
modern: I don’t know, madam.

origin: Tis too bad, too bad.
modern: Oh, it’s too terrible.

origin: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.
modern: To answer your question, ma'am—yes, he was friendly with those knights.

origin: No marvel then, though he were ill affected.
modern: Then it’s no surprise they had a bad influence on him.

origin: Tis they have put him on the old man’s death, To have th' expense and spoil of his revenues.
modern: They probably put him up to killing old man Gloucester to get his money.

origin: I have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them—and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I’ll not be there.
modern: Tonight I received a letter from my sister telling me all about them—and warning me not be at home in case they come to stay at my house.

origin: Nor I, assure thee, Regan.— Edmund, I hear that you have shown your father A childlike office.
modern: And I won’t be there either.—Edmund, I’m told you’ve acted like a true son to your father.

origin: It was my duty, sir.
modern: I just did my duty, sir.

origin: He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
modern: He exposed Edgar’s murderous plot, and was wounded, as you see there, when trying to apprehend him.

origin: Is he pursued?
modern: Are your men searching for him?

origin: Ay, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: If he be taken, he shall never more Be feared of doing harm.
modern: If he’s caught, he’ll never make trouble for anyone again.

origin: Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.
modern: I need people as trustworthy as you.

origin: I shall serve you, sir, Truly, however else.
modern: I’ll always be loyal to you, sir.

origin: You know not why we came to visit you— Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night.
modern: You don’t know why we came to visit you— Yes, and so unexpectedly, at night.

origin: The several messengers From hence attend dispatch.
modern: Their messengers are ready, waiting to deliver our response in these matters.

origin: Our good old friend, Lay comforts to your bosom, and bestow Your needful counsel to our business, Which craves the instant use.
modern: So please, old friend, give us some good advice.

origin: I serve you, madam.
modern: I’m at your service, madam.

origin: Your graces are right welcome.
modern: Both of you are very welcome here.

origin: Good dawning to thee, friend.
modern: Good morning to you, friend.

origin: Art of this house?
modern: Do you work in this house?

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes, I do.

origin: Where may we set our horses?
modern: Where should we stable our horses?

origin: I' th' mire.
modern: In the mud.

origin: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.
modern: Please, sir, be kind to me and tell me.

origin: I love thee not.
modern: I won’t be kind to you.

origin: Why, then, I care not for thee.
modern: In that case, I don’t much care for you either.

origin: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
modern: If I could get my hands on you, I’d make you care.

origin: Why dost thou use me thus?
modern: Why are you talking to me like this?

origin: I know thee not.
modern: I don’t even know you.

origin: Fellow, I know thee.
modern: Ah, but I know you.

origin: What dost thou know me for?
modern: Who am I then?

origin: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!
modern: What an ogre you are to slander someone you don’t know, and who doesn’t know you!

origin: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me!
modern: What a shameless jerk you are to pretend you don’t know me!

origin: Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels and beat thee before the king?
modern: It was just two days ago that I tripped you and beat you up in front of the king.

origin: Draw, you rogue, for though it be night yet the moon shines.
modern: Draw your sword, scoundrel.

origin: I’ll make a sop o' th' moonshine of you.
modern: I’ll make ground beef out of you.

origin: Away!
modern: Get away from me!

origin: I have nothing to do with thee.
modern: I’ve got nothing to do with you.

origin: Draw, you rascal.
modern: Draw your sword, you jerk!

origin: You come with letters against the king and take Vanity the puppet’s part against the royalty of her father.
modern: You come here with letters against the king, and you take his conceited daughter’s side against his royal highness.

origin: Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks.
modern: Draw your sword, scoundrel, or I’ll slice your thighs like flank steak.

origin: Draw, you rascal!
modern: Draw your sword!

origin: Come your ways.
modern: Come on!

origin: Help, ho!
modern: Help!

origin: Murder!
modern: Murderer!

origin: Help!
modern: Help!

origin: Stand, you neat slave, strike!
modern: Stand and fight, you overdressed servant, fight!

origin: Help, ho!
modern: Help!

origin: Murder, murder!
modern: Murder, murder!

origin: Macbeth.
modern: Macbeth.

origin: Then stand with us.
modern: Then stay with us.

origin: The west yet glimmers with some streaks of day.
modern: There’s still a bit of daylight in the sky.

origin: Now spurs the lated traveler apace To gain the timely inn, and near approaches The subject of our watch.
modern: Now all the late travellers are hurrying to reach their inns.

origin: Then ’tis he: the rest That are within the note of expectation Already are i' th' court.
modern: The rest of the king’s guests are already inside.

origin: Tis he.
modern: That’s him.

origin: Stand to ’t.
modern: Prepare yourselves.

origin: It will be rain tonight.
modern: It will rain tonight.

origin: Let it come down.
modern: Then let the rain come down.

origin: O treachery!
modern: Oh, this is treachery!

origin: Fly, good Fleance, fly, fly, fly!
modern: Get out of here, good Fleance, run, run, run!

origin: Thou may ’st revenge —O slave!
modern: Someday you can get revenge.—Oh, you bastard!

origin: Who did strike out the light?
modern: Who put out the light?

origin: Was ’t not the way?
modern: Wasn’t that the best thing to do?

origin: There’s but one down.
modern: There’s only one body here.

origin: The son is fled.
modern: The son ran away.

origin: We have lost best half of our affair.
modern: We failed in half of our mission.

origin: Well, let’s away and say how much is done.
modern: Well, let’s get out of here and tell Macbeth what we did accomplish.

origin: At first And last, the hearty welcome.
modern: From the highest to the lowest of you, I bid you a hearty welcome.

origin: Thanks to your majesty.
modern: Thanks to your majesty.

origin: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host.
modern: I will walk around and mingle with all of you, playing the humble host.

origin: Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends, For my heart speaks they are welcome.
modern: Say welcome to all of our friends for me, sir, for in my heart they are all welcome.

origin: See, they encounter thee with their hearts' thanks.
modern: And they respond to you with their hearts as well.

origin: Both sides are even.
modern: The table is full on both sides.

origin: Here I’ll sit i' th' midst.
modern: I will sit here in the middle.

origin: Be large in mirth.
modern: Be free and happy.

origin: Anon we’ll drink a measure The table round.
modern: Soon we will toast around the table.

origin: Tis Banquo’s then.
modern: Then it must be Banquo’s.

origin: My lord, his throat is cut.
modern: My lord, his throat is cut.

origin: That I did for him.
modern: I did that to him.

origin: Thou art the best o' th' cutthroats: Yet he’s good that did the like for Fleance.
modern: You are the best of the cutthroats.

origin: If thou didst it, thou art the nonpareil.
modern: If you cut both their throats, then you are the absolute best.

origin: Most royal sir, Fleance is ’scaped.
modern: Most royal sir, Fleance has escaped.

origin: Then comes my fit again.
modern: Now I’m scared again.

origin: I had else been perfect, Whole as the marble, founded as the rock, As broad and general as the casing air.
modern: Otherwise I would have been perfect, as solid as a piece of marble, as firm as a rock, as free as the air itself.

origin: Ay, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my good lord.

origin: Safe in a ditch he bides, With twenty trenchèd gashes on his head, The least a death to nature.
modern: He’s lying dead in a ditch, with twenty deep gashes in his head, any one of which would have been enough to kill him.

origin: Thanks for that.
modern: Thanks for that.

origin: There the grown serpent lies.
modern: The adult snake lies in the ditch.

origin: The worm that’s fled Hath nature that in time will venom breed; No teeth for th' present.
modern: The young snake that escaped will in time become poisonous and threatening, but for now he has no fangs.

origin: Get thee gone.
modern: Get out of here.

origin: Tomorrow We’ll hear ourselves again.
modern: I’ll talk to you again tomorrow.

origin: My royal lord, You do not give the cheer.
modern: My royal lord, you’re not entertaining the guests.

origin: To feed were best at home; From thence, the sauce to meat is ceremony; Meeting were bare without it.
modern: When you just want to eat, it’s better to do that at home.

origin: Where hast thou been, sister?
modern: Where have you been, sister?

origin: Killing swine.
modern: Killing pigs.

origin: Sister, where thou?
modern: And you, sister?

origin: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap, And munched, and munched, and munched.
modern: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap and munched away at them.

origin: Give me,”      quoth I.
modern: Give me one,” I said.

origin: Aroint thee, witch!” the rump-fed runnion cries.
modern: Get away from me, witch!” the fat woman cried.

origin: Thou 'rt kind.
modern: How nice of you!

origin: And I another.
modern: And I will give you some more.

origin: I’ll drain him dry as hay.
modern: I’ll drain the life out of him.

origin: Sleep shall neither night nor day Hang upon his penthouse lid.
modern: He won’t catch a wink of sleep, either at night or during the day.

origin: He shall live a man forbid.
modern: He will live as a cursed man.

origin: Weary sev'nnights nine times nine Shall he dwindle, peak and pine.
modern: For eighty-one weeks he will waste away in agony.

origin: Sweet remembrancer!
modern: It’s nice of you to remind me.

origin: May ’t please your highness sit.
modern: Why don’t you have a seat, your highness?

origin: His absence, sir, Lays blame upon his promise.
modern: His absence means he’s broken his promise, sir.

origin: Please ’t your highness To grace us with your royal company?
modern: If it pleases you, your highness, why don’t you sit with us and grace us with your royal company?

origin: The table’s full.
modern: The table’s full.

origin: Here is a place reserved, sir.
modern: Here’s an empty seat, sir.

origin: Where?
modern: Where?

origin: What, my good lord?
modern: What, my good lord?

origin: Gentlemen, rise.
modern: Gentlemen, stand up.

origin: His highness is not well.
modern: His highness is not well.

origin: Sit, worthy friends.
modern: Sit down, worthy friends.

origin: My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth.
modern: My husband is often like this, and he has been since he was a child.

origin: Pray you, keep seat.
modern: Please stay seated.

origin: If much you note him, You shall offend him and extend his passion.
modern: If you pay too much attention to him you’ll make him angry, and that will make his convulsions go on longer.

origin: Feed and regard him not.
modern: Eat your dinner and pay no attention to him.

origin: Ay, and a bold one, that dare look on that Which might appall the devil.
modern: Yes, and a brave one, who dares to look at something that would frighten the devil.

origin: O proper stuff!
modern: Oh, that’s nonsense!

origin: This is the very painting of your fear.
modern: This is just another one of the hallucinations you always get when you’re afraid.

origin: This is the air-drawn dagger which you said Led you to Duncan.
modern: These outbursts of yours don’t even look like real fear.

origin: Oh, these flaws and starts, Impostors to true fear, would well become A woman’s story at a winter’s fire, Authorized by her grandam.
modern: They’re more like how you would act if you were a woman telling a scary story by the fireside in front of her grandmother.

origin: Shame itself!
modern: Shame on you!

origin: Why do you make such faces?
modern: Why are you making these faces?

origin: When all’s done, You look but on a stool.
modern: When the vision passes, you’ll see that you’re just looking at a stool.

origin: Prithee, see there!
modern: Please, just look over there.

origin: Behold!
modern: Look!

origin: Look!
modern: Look!

origin: If I stand here, I saw him.
modern: As sure as I’m standing here, I saw him.

origin: Fie, for shame!
modern: Nonsense!

origin: The time has been That, when the brains were out, the man would die, And there an end.
modern: It used to be that when you knocked a man’s brains out he would just die, and that would be it.

origin: But now they rise again With twenty mortal murders on their crowns And push us from our stools.
modern: But now they rise from the dead with twenty fatal head wounds and push us off our stools.

origin: This is more strange Than such a murder is.
modern: This haunting business is even stranger than murder.

origin: My worthy lord, Your noble friends do lack you.
modern: My worthy lord, your noble friends miss your company.

origin: Our duties, and the pledge.
modern: Too bad it’s spoiling our pleasure tonight.

origin: Approach thou like the rugged Russian bear, The armed rhinoceros, or th' Hyrcan tiger; Take any shape but that, and my firm nerves Shall never tremble.
modern: Come at me in the form of a rugged Russian bear, an armor-plated rhinoceros, or a tiger from Iran.

origin: Or be alive again, And dare me to the desert with thy sword.
modern: Or come back to life again and challenge me to a duel in some deserted place.

origin: If trembling I inhabit then, protest me The baby of a girl.
modern: If I tremble then, you can call me a little girl.

origin: Hence, horrible shadow!
modern: Get out of here, you horrible ghost, you hallucination.

origin: Unreal mockery, hence!
modern: Get out!

origin: Why so, being gone,      Why so, being gone, I am a man again.
modern: I am a man again.

origin: Pray you sit still.
modern: Pray you sit still.

origin: You have displaced the mirth, broke the good meeting, With most admired disorder.
modern: Please, remain seated.

origin: What sights, my lord?
modern: What things, my lord?

origin: I pray you, speak not.
modern: Please, don’t speak to him.

origin: He grows worse and worse.
modern: He’s getting worse and worse.

origin: Question enrages him.
modern: Talk makes him crazy.

origin: At once, good night.
modern: Good night.

origin: A kind good night to all!
modern: A kind good night to all!

origin: Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.
modern: Gravestones have been known to move, and trees to speak, to bring guilty men to justice.

origin: Almost at odds with morning, which is which.
modern: It’s almost morning.

origin: Did you send to him, sir?
modern: Did you send for him, sir?

origin: I hear it by the way; but I will send.
modern: I’ve heard about this indirectly, but I will send for him.

origin: There’s not a one of them but in his house I keep a servant fee’d.
modern: In every one of the lords' households I have a servant paid to spy for me.

origin: I will tomorrow— And betimes I will—to the weird sisters.
modern: Tomorrow, while it’s still early, I will go see the witches.

origin: More shall they speak, for now I am bent to know, By the worst means, the worst.
modern: They will tell me more, because I’m determined to know the worst about what’s going to happen.

origin: For mine own good, All causes shall give way.
modern: My own safety is the only important thing now.

origin: Strange things I have in head, that will to hand, Which must be acted ere they may be scanned.
modern: I have to do these things before I have a chance to think about them.

origin: Come, we’ll to sleep.
modern: Yes, let’s go to sleep.

origin: My strange and self-abuse Is the initiate fear that wants hard use.
modern: My strange self-delusions just come from inexperience.

origin: We are yet but young in deed.
modern: We’re still just beginners when it comes to crime.

origin: Why, how now, Hecate!
modern: What’s wrong, Hecate?

origin: You look angerly.
modern: You look angry.

origin: Have I not reason, beldams as you are?
modern: Don’t I have a reason to be angry, you disobedient hags?

origin: But make amends now.
modern: But you can make it up to me.

origin: Get you gone, And at the pit of Acheron Meet me i' th' morning.
modern: Go away now and in the morning meet me in the pit by the river in hell.

origin: Thither he Will come to know his destiny.
modern: Macbeth will go there to learn his destiny.

origin: Your vessels and your spells provide, Your charms and everything beside.
modern: You bring your cauldrons, your spells, your charms, and everything else.

origin: I am for the air.
modern: I’m about to fly away.

origin: This night I’ll spend Unto a dismal and a fatal end.
modern: I’ll spend tonight working to make something horrible happen.

origin: Great business must be wrought ere noon.
modern: I have a lot to do before noon.

origin: Upon the corner of the moon There hangs a vap'rous drop profound.
modern: An important droplet is hanging from the corner of the moon.

origin: I’ll catch it ere it come to ground.
modern: I’ll catch it before it falls to the ground.

origin: And that distilled by magic sleights Shall raise such artificial sprites As by the strength of their illusion Shall draw him on to his confusion.
modern: When I work it over with magic spells, the drop will produce magical spirits that will trick Macbeth with illusions.

origin: He shall spurn fate, scorn death, and bear His hopes 'bove wisdom, grace, and fear.
modern: He will be fooled into thinking he is greater than fate, he will mock death, and he will think he is above wisdom, grace, and fear.

origin: And you all know, security Is mortals' chiefest enemy.
modern: As you all know, overconfidence is man’s greatest enemy.

origin: Hark!
modern: Listen!

origin: I am called.
modern: I’m being called.

origin: My little spirit, see, Sits in a foggy cloud and stays for me.
modern: Look, my little spirit is sitting in a foggy cloud waiting for me.

origin: Only I say Things have been strangely borne.
modern: All I’m saying is that strange things have been going on.

origin: Men must not walk too late.
modern: Clearly, men should not go out walking too late!

origin: Who cannot want the thought how monstrous It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain To kill their gracious father?
modern: And who can help thinking how monstrous it was for Malcolm and Donalbain to kill their gracious father?

origin: All which we pine for now.
modern: Those are the things we pine for now.

origin: And this report Hath so exasperated the king that he Prepares for some attempt of war.
modern: Macbeth has heard this news and he is so angry that he’s preparing for war.

origin: Sent he to Macduff?
modern: Did he tell Macduff to return to Scotland?

origin: I’ll send my prayers with him.
modern: I’ll send my prayers with him.

origin: Though his bark cannot be lost, Yet it shall be tempest-tossed.
modern: Although I can’t make his ship disappear, I can still make his journey miserable.

origin: Look what I have.
modern: Look what I have here.

origin: Show me, show me.
modern: Show me, show me.

origin: A drum, a drum!
modern: A drum, a drum!

origin: Macbeth doth come.
modern: Macbeth has come.

origin: Thrice the brinded cat hath mewed.
modern: The tawny cat has meowed three times.

origin: Harpier cries, “'Tis time, ’tis time.” Round about the cauldron go, In the poisoned entrails throw.
modern: My spirit friend, Harpier, is yelling, “It’s time, it’s time!” Dance around the cauldron and throw in the poisoned entrails.

origin: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.
modern: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.

origin: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
modern: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

origin: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
modern: Double, double toil and trouble, Fire burn and cauldron bubble.

origin: Cool it with a baboon’s blood, Then the charm is firm and good.
modern: We’ll cool the mixture with baboon blood.

origin: Oh well done!
modern: Well done!

origin: I commend your pains, And every one shall share i' th' gains.
modern: I admire your efforts, and all of you will share the rewards.

origin: And now about the cauldron sing, Like elves and fairies in a ring, Enchanting all that you put in.
modern: Now come sing around the cauldron like a ring of elves and fairies, enchanting everything you put in.

origin: By the pricking of my thumbs, Something wicked this way comes.
modern: I can tell that something wicked is coming by the tingling in my thumbs.

origin: Open, locks, Whoever knocks.
modern: Doors, open up for whoever is knocking!

origin: How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags?
modern: What’s going on here, you secret, evil, midnight hags?

origin: What is ’t you do?
modern: What are you doing?

origin: A deed without a name.
modern: Something there isn’t a word for.

origin: I conjure you by that which you profess— Howe'er you come to know it—answer me.
modern: Tell me what I want to know.

origin: Speak.
modern: Speak.

origin: Demand.
modern: Demand.

origin: We’ll answer.
modern: We’ll answer.

origin: Say, if th' hadst rather hear it from our mouths, Or from our masters'.
modern: Would you rather hear these things from our mouths or from our master’s?

origin: Call 'em.
modern: Call them.

origin: Let me see 'em.
modern: Let me see them.

origin: Pour in sow’s blood, that hath eaten Her nine farrow; grease that’s sweaten From the murderer’s gibbet throw Into the flame.
modern: Pour in the blood of a sow who has eaten her nine offspring.

origin: Tell me, thou unknown power—      He knows thy thought.
modern: Tell me, you unknown power— He can read your thoughts.

origin: Hear his speech but say thou nought.
modern: Listen, but don’t speak.

origin: Macbeth!
modern: Macbeth!

origin: Macbeth!
modern: Macbeth!

origin: Macbeth!
modern: Macbeth!

origin: Beware Macduff.
modern: Beware Macduff.

origin: Beware the thane of Fife.
modern: Beware the thane of Fife.

origin: Dismiss me.
modern: Let me go.

origin: Enough.
modern: Enough.

origin: Whate'er thou art, for thy good caution, thanks.
modern: Whatever you are, thanks for your advice.

origin: Thou hast harped my fear aright.
modern: You have guessed exactly what I feared.

origin: But one word more— He will not be commanded.
modern: But one word more— He will not be commanded by you.

origin: Here’s another More potent than the first.
modern: Here’s another, stronger than the first.

origin: Macbeth!
modern: Macbeth!

origin: Macbeth!— Had I three ears, I’d hear thee.
modern: If I had three ears I’d listen with all three.

origin: Be bloody, bold, and resolute.
modern: Be violent, bold, and firm.

origin: Laugh to scorn The power of man, for none of woman born Shall harm Macbeth.
modern: Laugh at the power of other men, because nobody born from a woman will ever harm Macbeth.

origin: But yet I’ll make assurance double sure, And take a bond of fate.
modern: But even so, I’ll make doubly sure.

origin: Thou shalt not live, That I may tell pale-hearted fear it lies, And sleep in spite of thunder.
modern: That way I can conquer my own fear and sleep easy at night.

origin: What is this That rises like the issue of a king, And wears upon his baby-brow the round And top of sovereignty?
modern: What is this spirit that looks like the son of a king and wears a crown on his young head?

origin: Listen but speak not to ’t.
modern: Listen but don’t speak to it.

origin: Be lion-mettled, proud, and take no care Who chafes, who frets, or where conspirers are.
modern: Be brave like the lion and proud.

origin: Macbeth shall never vanquished be until Great Birnam Wood to high Dunsinane Hill Shall come against him.
modern: Macbeth will never be defeated until Birnam Wood marches to fight you at Dunsinane Hill.

origin: That will never be.
modern: That will never happen.

origin: Who can impress the forest, bid the tree Unfix his earthbound root?
modern: Who can command the forest and make the trees pull their roots out of the earth?

origin: Sweet bodements!
modern: These were sweet omens!

origin: Good!
modern: Good!

origin: Rebellious dead, rise never till the wood Of Birnam rise, and our high-placed Macbeth Shall live the lease of nature, pay his breath To time and mortal custom.
modern: My murders will never come back to threaten me until the forest of Birnam gets up and moves, and I will be king for my entire natural life.

origin: Yet my heart Throbs to know one thing.
modern: But my heart is still throbbing to know one thing.

origin: Tell me, if your art Can tell so much: shall Banquo’s issue ever Reign in this kingdom?
modern: Tell me, if your dark powers can see this far: will Banquo’s sons ever reign in this kingdom?

origin: Seek to know no more.
modern: Don’t try to find out more.

origin: I will be satisfied.
modern: I demand to be satisfied.

origin: Deny me this, And an eternal curse fall on you!
modern: If you refuse, let an eternal curse fall on you.

origin: Let me know.
modern: Let me know.

origin: Why sinks that cauldron?
modern: Why is that cauldron sinking?

origin: And what noise is this?
modern: And what is that music?

origin: Show.
modern: Show.

origin: Show.
modern: Show.

origin: Show.
modern: Show.

origin: Show his eyes and grieve his heart.
modern: Show him and make him grieve.

origin: Come like shadows; so depart!
modern: Come like shadows and depart in the same way!

origin: Thou art too like the spirit of Banquo.
modern: You look too much like the ghost of Banquo.

origin: I’ll see no more.
modern: Go away!

origin: Horrible sight!
modern: What?

origin: What, is this so?
modern: Is this true?

origin: Come, sisters, cheer we up his sprites, And show the best of our delights.
modern: Come, sisters, let’s cheer him up and show him our talents.

origin: Where are they?
modern: Where are they?

origin: Gone?
modern: Gone?

origin: Let this pernicious hour Stand aye accursèd in the calendar!
modern: Let this evil hour be marked forever in the calendar as cursed.

origin: What’s your grace’s will?
modern: What does your grace want?

origin: Saw you the weird sisters?
modern: Did you see the weird sisters?

origin: No, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

origin: Came they not by you?
modern: Didn’t they pass by you?

origin: No, indeed, my lord.
modern: No, indeed, my lord.

origin: I did hear The galloping of horse.
modern: I heard the galloping of horses.

origin: Who was ’t came by?
modern: Who was it that came here?

origin: Tis two or three, my lord, that bring you word Macduff is fled to England.
modern: Two or three men, my lord, who brought the message that Macduff has fled to England.

origin: Fled to England?
modern: Fled to England?

origin: Ay, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my good lord.

origin: Time, thou anticipat’st my dread exploits.
modern: Time, you thwart my dreadful plans.

origin: No boasting like a fool.
modern: No more foolish talk.

origin: This deed I’ll do before this purpose cool.
modern: I will do this deed before I lose my sense of purpose.

origin: But no more sights!—Where are these gentlemen?
modern: But no more spooky visions!—Where are the messengers?

origin: Come, bring me where they are.
modern: Come, bring me to them.

origin: What had he done to make him fly the land?
modern: What did he do that made him flee this land?

origin: You must have patience, madam.
modern: You have to be patient, madam.

origin: He had none.
modern: He had no patience.

origin: His flight was madness.
modern: He was crazy to run away.

origin: When our actions do not, Our fears do make us traitors.
modern: Even if you’re not a traitor, you’re going to look like one if you run away.

origin: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.
modern: You don’t know whether it was wisdom or fear that made him flee.

origin: Wisdom!
modern: How could it be wisdom!

origin: To leave his wife, to leave his babes, His mansion and his titles in a place From whence himself does fly?
modern: To leave his wife, his children, his house, and his titles in a place so unsafe that he himself flees it!

origin: For the poor wren, The most diminutive of birds, will fight, Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.
modern: Even the fragile wren, the smallest of birds, will fight against the owl when it threatens her young ones in the nest.

origin: All is the fear and nothing is the love, As little is the wisdom, where the flight So runs against all reason.
modern: His running away has everything to do with fear and nothing to do with love.

origin: My dearest coz, I pray you school yourself.
modern: My dearest relative, I’m begging you, pull yourself together.

origin: But for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o' th' season.
modern: As for your husband, he is noble, wise, and judicious, and he understands what the times require.

origin: I take my leave of you.
modern: I’ll say good-bye now.

origin: Shall not be long but I’ll be here again.
modern: It won’t be long before I’m back.

origin: Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward To what they were before.—My pretty cousin, Blessing upon you.
modern: When things are at their worst they have to stop, or else improve to the way things were before.

origin: Fathered he is, and yet he’s fatherless.
modern: He has a father, and yet he is fatherless.

origin: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.
modern: If I stay longer, I’ll embarrass you and disgrace myself by crying.

origin: I take my leave at once.
modern: I’m leaving now.

origin: Sirrah, your father’s dead.
modern: Young man, your father’s dead.

origin: And what will you do now?
modern: What are you going to do now?

origin: How will you live?
modern: How are you going to live?

origin: As birds do, Mother.
modern: What?

origin: What, with worms and flies?
modern: Are you going to start eating worms and flies?

origin: With what I get, I mean, and so do they.
modern: I mean I will live on whatever I get, like birds do.

origin: Poor bird!
modern: You’d be a pitiful bird.

origin: Thou ’dst never fear the net nor lime, The pitfall nor the gin.
modern: You wouldn’t know enough to be afraid of traps.

origin: My father is not dead, for all your saying.
modern: No matter what you say, my father is not dead.

origin: Yes, he is dead.
modern: Yes, he is dead.

origin: How wilt thou do for a father?
modern: What are you going to do for a father?

origin: Nay, how will you do for a husband?
modern: Maybe you should ask, what will you do for a husband?

origin: Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.
modern: Oh, I can buy twenty husbands at any market.

origin: Speak, if you can: what are you?
modern: Speak, if you can.

origin: All hail, Macbeth!
modern: All hail, Macbeth!

origin: Hail to thee, thane of Glamis!
modern: Hail to you, thane of Glamis!

origin: All hail, Macbeth!
modern: All hail, Macbeth!

origin: Hail!
modern: Hail!

origin: Hail!
modern: Hail!

origin: Hail!
modern: Hail!

origin: Lesser than Macbeth and greater.
modern: You are lesser than Macbeth but also greater.

origin: Not so happy, yet much happier.
modern: You are not as happy as Macbeth, yet much happier.

origin: Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none.
modern: Your descendants will be kings, even though you will not be one.

origin: So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!
modern: So all hail, Macbeth and Banquo!

origin: Then you’ll buy 'em to sell again.
modern: If so, you’d be buying them to sell again.

origin: Thou speak’st with all thy wit; and yet, i' faith, With wit enough for thee.
modern: You talk like a child, but you’re very smart anyway.

origin: Was my father a traitor, Mother?
modern: Was my father a traitor, Mother?

origin: Ay, that he was.
modern: Yes, he was.

origin: What is a traitor?
modern: What is a traitor?

origin: Why, one that swears and lies.
modern: Someone who makes a promise and breaks it.

origin: And be all traitors that do so?
modern: And is everyone who swears and lies a traitor?

origin: Every one that does so is a traitor and must be hanged.
modern: Everyone who does so is a traitor and should be hanged.

origin: And must they all be hanged that swear and lie?
modern: And should everyone who makes promises and breaks them be hanged?

origin: Every one.
modern: Everyone.

origin: Who must hang them?
modern: Who should hang them?

origin: Why, the honest men.
modern: The honest men.

origin: Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enough to beat the honest men and hang up them.
modern: Then the liars are fools, for there are enough liars in the world to beat up the honest men and hang them.

origin: If he were dead, you’d weep for him.
modern: If he were dead, you’d be weeping for him.

origin: If you would not, it were a good sign that I should quickly have a new father.
modern: If you aren’t weeping, it’s a good sign that I’ll soon have a new father.

origin: Poor prattler, how thou talk’st!
modern: Silly babbler, how you talk!

origin: Bless you, fair dame!
modern: Bless you, fair lady!

origin: I am not to you known, Though in your state of honor I am perfect.
modern: You don’t know me, but I know you’re an important person.

origin: I doubt some danger does approach you nearly.
modern: I’m afraid something dangerous is coming toward you.

origin: If you will take a homely man’s advice, Be not found here.
modern: If you’ll take a simple man’s advice, don’t be here when it arrives.

origin: Hence with your little ones.
modern: Go away and take your children.

origin: To fright you thus methinks I am too savage; To do worse to you were fell cruelty, Which is too nigh your person.
modern: I feel bad for scaring you like this, but it would be much worse for me to let you come to harm.

origin: Heaven preserve you!
modern: And harm is getting close!

origin: I dare abide no longer.
modern: Heaven keep you safe!

origin: Whither should I fly?
modern: Where should I go?

origin: I have done no harm.
modern: I haven’t done anything wrong.

origin: But I remember now I am in this earthly world, where to do harm Is often laudable, to do good sometime Accounted dangerous folly.
modern: But I have to remember that I’m here on Earth, where doing evil is often praised, and doing good is sometimes a stupid and dangerous mistake.

origin: Why then, alas, Do I put up that womanly defense, To say I have done no harm?
modern: So then why should I offer this womanish defense that I’m innocent?

origin: What are these faces?
modern: Who are these men?

origin: Where is your husband?
modern: Where is your husband?

origin: I hope, in no place so unsanctified Where such as thou mayst find him.
modern: I hope he’s not anywhere so disreputable that thugs like you can find him.

origin: He’s a traitor.
modern: He’s a traitor.

origin: Thou liest, thou shag-haired villain!
modern: You’re lying, you shaggy-haired villain!

origin: Young fry of treachery!
modern: What’s that, you runt?

origin: He has killed me, mother.
modern: He has killed me, Mother.

origin: Run away, I pray you!
modern: Run away, I beg you!

origin: Let us seek out some desolate shade and there Weep our sad bosoms empty.
modern: Let’s seek out some shady place where we can sit down alone and cry our hearts out.

origin: Let us rather Hold fast the mortal sword and, like good men, Bestride our downfall'n birthdom.
modern: Instead of crying, let’s keep hold of our swords and defend our fallen homeland like honorable men.

origin: Each new morn New widows howl, new orphans cry, new sorrows Strike heaven on the face, that it resounds As if it felt with Scotland and yelled out Like syllable of dolor.
modern: Each day new widows howl, new orphans cry, and new sorrows slap heaven in the face, until it sounds like heaven itself feels Scotland’s anguish and screams in pain.

origin: What you have spoke, it may be so perchance.
modern: What you just said may perhaps be true.

origin: This tyrant, whose sole name blisters our tongues, Was once thought honest.
modern: This tyrant, whose mere name is so awful it hurts us to say it, was once considered an honest man.

origin: You have loved him well.
modern: You were one of his favorites.

origin: He hath not touched you yet.
modern: He hasn’t done anything to harm you yet.

origin: I am young, but something You may deserve of him through me, and wisdom To offer up a weak, poor, innocent lamb T' appease an angry god.
modern: It would be smart to offer someone poor and innocent like me as a sacrificial lamb to satisfy an angry god like Macbeth.

origin: I am not treacherous.
modern: I am not treacherous.

origin: But Macbeth is.
modern: But Macbeth is.

origin: A good and virtuous nature may recoil In an imperial charge.
modern: Even someone with a good and virtuous nature might give way to a royal command.

origin: But I shall crave your pardon.
modern: But I beg your pardon.

origin: That which you are, my thoughts cannot transpose.
modern: My fears can’t actually make you evil.

origin: Angels are bright still, though the brightest fell.
modern: Angels are still bright even though Lucifer, the brightest angel, fell from heaven.

origin: Though all things foul would wear the brows of grace, Yet grace must still look so.
modern: Even though everything evil wants to look good, good still has to look good too.

origin: Why in that rawness left you wife and child, Those precious motives, those strong knots of love, Without leave-taking?
modern: Why did you leave your wife and child vulnerable—the most precious things in your life, those strong bonds of love?

origin: I pray you, Let not my jealousies be your dishonors, But mine own safeties.
modern: But I beg you, don’t interpret my suspicions as slander against you.

origin: You may be rightly just, Whatever I shall think.
modern: You may really be honest, no matter what I think.

origin: Bleed, bleed, poor country!
modern: Bleed, bleed, poor country!

origin: I would not be the villain that thou think’st For the whole space that’s in the tyrant’s grasp, And the rich East to boot.
modern: I wouldn’t be the villain you think I am even if I were offered all of Macbeth’s kingdom and the riches of the East too.

origin: Be not offended.
modern: Don’t be offended.

origin: I speak not as in absolute fear of you.
modern: I don’t completely distrust you.

origin: I think our country sinks beneath the yoke.
modern: I do think Scotland is sinking under Macbeth’s oppression.

origin: It weeps, it bleeds, and each new day a gash Is added to her wounds.
modern: Our country weeps, it bleeds, and each day a fresh cut is added to her wounds.

origin: I think withal There would be hands uplifted in my right; And here from gracious England have I offer Of goodly thousands.
modern: The English have promised me thousands of troops.

origin: What should he be?
modern: Who are you talking about?

origin: Not in the legions Of horrid hell can come a devil more damned In evils to top Macbeth.
modern: Even in hell you couldn’t find a devil worse than Macbeth.

origin: I grant him bloody, Luxurious, avaricious, false, deceitful, Sudden, malicious, smacking of every sin That has a name.
modern: I admit that he’s murderous, lecherous, greedy, lying, deceitful, violent, malicious, and guilty of every sin that has a name.

origin: But there’s no bottom, none, In my voluptuousness.
modern: But there is no end, absolutely none, to my sexual desires.

origin: Your wives, your daughters, Your matrons, and your maids could not fill up The cistern of my lust, and my desire All continent impediments would o'erbear That did oppose my will.
modern: Your wives, your daughters, your old women, and your young maids together could not satisfy my lust.

origin: Better Macbeth Than such an one to reign.
modern: It would be better for Macbeth to rule than someone like me.

origin: Boundless intemperance In nature is a tyranny.
modern: Endless greed and lust in a man’s nature is a kind of tyranny.

origin: It hath been The untimely emptying of the happy throne And fall of many kings.
modern: It has caused the downfall of many kings.

origin: But fear not yet To take upon you what is yours.
modern: But don’t be afraid to take the crown that belongs to you.

origin: We have willing dames enough.
modern: There are more than enough willing women around.

origin: This avarice Sticks deeper, grows with more pernicious root Than summer-seeming lust, and it hath been The sword of our slain kings.
modern: Greed has been the downfall of many kings.

origin: But I have none.
modern: But I don’t have any good sides.

origin: Nay, had I power, I should Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell, Uproar the universal peace, confound All unity on earth.
modern: No, if I had power I would take world peace and throw it down to hell.

origin: O Scotland, Scotland!
modern: Oh Scotland, Scotland!

origin: If such a one be fit to govern, speak.
modern: If someone like me is fit to be king, let me know.

origin: Fare thee well!
modern: I’m still a virgin.

origin: Whither indeed, before thy here-approach, Old Siward, with ten thousand warlike men, Already at a point, was setting forth.
modern: Indeed, before you arrived here, old Siward, with ten thousand soldiers already prepared for battle, was making his way here.

origin: Why are you silent?
modern: Why are you silent?

origin: Such welcome and unwelcome things at once 'Tis hard to reconcile.
modern: It’s hard to make sense of such different stories.

origin: Well, more anon.—Comes the king forth, I pray you?
modern: Well, we’ll speak more soon.

origin: Ay, sir; there are a crew of wretched souls That stay his cure.
modern: Yes, sir.

origin: Their malady convinces The great assay of art, but at his touch— Such sanctity hath heaven given his hand— They presently amend.
modern: Their illness confounds the most advanced techniques of modern medicine, but when he touches them, they heal immediately because of the power granted to him by heaven.

origin: I thank you, doctor.
modern: Thank you, doctor.

origin: What’s the disease he means?
modern: What disease is he talking about?

origin: Tis called the evil.
modern: It’s called the evil.

origin: A most miraculous work in this good king, Which often since my here-remain in England I have seen him do.
modern: Edward’s healing touch is a miracle that I have seen him perform many times during my stay in England.

origin: With this strange virtue, He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy, And sundry blessings hang about his throne, That speak him full of grace.
modern: Along with this strange power, he also has the gift of prophecy and various other abilities.

origin: See, who comes here?
modern: Who’s that coming over here?

origin: My countryman, but yet I know him not.
modern: By his dress I can tell he’s my countryman, but I don’t recognize him.

origin: My ever-gentle cousin, welcome hither.
modern: My noble kinsman, welcome.

origin: Sir, amen.
modern: Hello, sir.

origin: Stands Scotland where it did?
modern: Is Scotland the same as when I left it?

origin: Alas, poor country!
modern: Alas, our poor country!

origin: Almost afraid to know itself.
modern: It’s too frightened to look at itself.

origin: Oh, relation Too nice and yet too true!
modern: Oh, your report is too poetic, but it sounds so true!

origin: Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!
modern: Banquo and Macbeth, all hail!

origin: Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more.
modern: Stay and tell me more.

origin: Say from whence You owe this strange intelligence, or why Upon this blasted heath you stop our way With such prophetic greeting.
modern: Tell me where you learned these strange things, and why you stop us at this desolate place with this prophetic greeting?

origin: Speak, I charge you.
modern: Speak, I command you.

origin: The earth hath bubbles, as the water has, And these are of them.
modern: The earth has bubbles, just like the water, and these creatures must have come from a bubble in the earth.

origin: Whither are they vanished?
modern: Where did they disappear to?

origin: Would they had stayed.
modern: I wish they had stayed!

origin: Were such things here as we do speak about?
modern: Were these things we’re talking about really here?

origin: Or have we eaten on the insane root That takes the reason prisoner?
modern: Or are we both on drugs?
