origin: And I know not what’s spent in the search.
modern: I don’t even know how much I’m spending to find them.

origin: Why thou, loss upon loss!
modern: Loss upon loss!

origin: Yes, other men have ill luck too.
modern: Well, other men have bad luck too.

origin: Antonio, as I heard in Genoa— What, what, what?
modern: Antonio, as I heard in Genoa— What, what, what?

origin: Ill luck, ill luck?
modern: Bad luck, bad luck?

origin: Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis.
modern: He’s had a ship wrecked coming from Tripolis.

origin: I thank God, I thank God!
modern: Thank God, thank God!

origin: Is ’t true, is ’t true?
modern: Is it true, is it true?

origin: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.
modern: I spoke with some of the sailors who survived the wreck.

origin: I thank thee, good Tubal.
modern: Thank you, Tubal.

origin: Good news, good news!
modern: Good news, good news!

origin: Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.
modern: Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.

origin: Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one night fourscore ducats.
modern: I also heard that your daughter spent eighty ducats in Genoa one night.

origin: Thou stickest a dagger in me.
modern: Oh, you’re sticking a dagger in me!

origin: I shall never see my gold again.
modern: I’ll never see my gold again.

origin: Fourscore ducats at a sitting!
modern: Eighty ducats in one shot!

origin: Fourscore ducats!
modern: Eighty ducats!

origin: There came divers of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.
modern: I came to Venice with a number of Antonio’s creditors who say he won’t be able to avoid going bankrupt.

origin: I am very glad of it.
modern: I’m very glad about that.

origin: I’ll plague him.
modern: I’ll hound him.

origin: I’ll torture him.
modern: I’ll torture him.

origin: I am glad of it.
modern: I’m very glad.

origin: One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.
modern: One creditor showed me a ring he got from your daughter in exchange for a monkey.

origin: Out upon her!
modern: Damn her!

origin: Thou torturest me, Tubal.
modern: You’re torturing me, Tubal.

origin: It was my turquoise.
modern: That was my turquoise ring!

origin: I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor.
modern: Leah gave it to me before we were married.

origin: I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.
modern: I wouldn’t have given it away for a whole jungle of monkeys.

origin: But Antonio is certainly undone.
modern: But Antonio’s certainly ruined.

origin: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true.
modern: That’s true, that’s very true.

origin: Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue.
modern: With him out of Venice, I can make whatever bargains I want when I lend money.—Go, Tubal.

origin: Go, good Tubal.
modern: Meet me at the synagogue.

origin: At our synagogue, Tubal.
modern: Let me choose now.

origin: Before you hazard, for in choosing wrong I lose your company.
modern: I feel tortured by all this talking.

origin: Therefore forbear awhile.
modern: Tortured,

origin: There may as well be amity and life 'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.
modern: They’re as opposite as hot and cold.

origin: Promise me life, and I’ll confess the truth.
modern: Promise me you’ll let me live, and I’ll confess the truth.

origin: Well then, confess and live.
modern: All right then, confess and live.

origin: Confess and love” Had been the very sum of my confession.
modern: Confess and love” is more like it.

origin: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
modern: But let me try my luck on the boxes.

origin: Away, then.
modern: Go ahead, then.

origin: I am locked in one of them.
modern: I’m locked in one of them.

origin: If you do love me you will find me out.— Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.
modern: If you really love me, you’ll find me.—Nerissa and the rest of you, get away from him.

origin: Let music sound while he doth make his choice.
modern: Play some music while he chooses.

origin: Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end, Fading in music.
modern: Then if he loses, it’ll be his swan song, music before the end.

origin: He may win, And what is music then?
modern: What music should we play then?

origin: The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives, With blearèd visages come forth to view The issue of th' exploit.—Go, Hercules!
modern: We’ve all come out to see what will happen.—Go, Hercules!

origin: Live thou, I live.
modern: If you survive, I’ll live.

origin: With much, much more dismay I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.
modern: I’m more anxious watching you fight than you are in the fight itself.

origin: Ding, dong, bell.
modern: Ding, dong, bell.

origin: How many cowards whose hearts are all as false As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars, Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk, And these assume but valor’s excrement To render them redoubted.
modern: How many people are cowards at heart but wear beards like Hercules or Mars, the god of war?

origin: So are those crispèd snaky golden locks Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind, Upon supposèd fairness, often known To be the dowry of a second head, The skull that bred them in the sepulcher.
modern: Curly golden hair moves so nicely in the wind and makes a woman beautiful.

origin: Thus ornament is but the guilèd shore To a most dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf Veiling an Indian beauty—in a word, The seeming truth which cunning times put on To entrap the wisest.
modern: A lovely, cunning shore can distract a man from the perils of a stormy sea, just as a pretty scarf can hide a dangerous dark-skinned beauty.

origin: Therefore then, thou gaudy gold, Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee.
modern: So I’ll have nothing to do with that gaudy gold box—it’s like the gold that Midas couldn’t eat.

origin: Since this fortune falls to you, Be content and seek no new.
modern: Since this prize is yours, Be happy with it, and don’t look for a new one.

origin: If you be well pleased with this And hold your fortune for your bliss, Turn you where your lady is And claim her with a loving kiss.”
modern: If you’re happy with what you’ve won And accept this prize as your blissful destiny, Then turn to where your lady is, And claim her with a loving kiss.”

origin: A gentle scroll.
modern: A nice message.

origin: Fair lady, by your leave, I come by note to give and to receive.
modern: My lady, with your permission, this note authorizes me to give myself to you with a kiss.

origin: Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in people’s eyes, Hearing applause and universal shout, Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether these pearls of praise be his or no— So, thrice fair lady, stand I even so, As doubtful whether what I see be true Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.
modern: And so, beautiful lady, I’m standing here just like that, wondering whether all this can be true until you tell me it is.

origin: You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand Such as I am.
modern: You see me standing here, Lord Bassanio.

origin: Though for myself alone I would not be ambitious in my wish To wish myself much better, yet for you I would be trebled twenty times myself— A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich— That only to stand high in your account I might in virtue, beauties, livings, friends Exceed account.
modern: Though I wouldn’t wish to be better for my own sake, for your sake I wish I were twenty times more than myself—a thousand times more beautiful and ten thousand times richer—just so you might value me more, so my good qualities, beauty, possessions, and friends would be more than you could calculate.

origin: Happier than this— She is not bred so dull but she can learn.
modern: I’m even happier that I’m not stupid, and I can learn.

origin: Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit Commits itself to yours to be directed As from her lord, her governor, her king.
modern: I’m happiest of all that I’m yours now, my lord, my king, and you can guide me as you wish.

origin: Myself and what is mine to you and yours Is now converted.
modern: Everything I am and everything I have now belongs to you.

origin: But now I was the lord Of this fair mansion, master of my servants, Queen o'er myself.
modern: Just a minute ago I was the owner of this beautiful mansion, master of these servants, and queen over myself.

origin: And even now, but now, This house, these servants, and this same myself Are yours, my lord’s.
modern: But as of right this second all these things are yours.

origin: I give them with this ring, Which when you part from, lose, or give away, Let it presage the ruin of your love
modern: With this ring I give them all to you.

origin: I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it.
modern: Please let me know your plan, Bassanio.

origin: And if it stand, as you yourself still do, Within the eye of honor, be assured My purse, my person, my extremest means Lie all unlocked to your occasions.
modern: As long as it’s honorable, you can be sure that I’ll let you use all my money and do everything I can to help you.

origin: In my school days, when I had lost one shaft, I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight The selfsame way with more advisèd watch To find the other forth—and by adventuring both, I oft found both.
modern: Back when I was a schoolboy, if I lost an arrow I would try to find it by shooting another arrow in the same direction, watching the second arrow more carefully than I had the first.

origin: I urge this childhood proof Because what follows is pure innocence.
modern: By risking the second arrow, I’d often get both of them back.

origin: I owe you much, and, like a willful youth, That which I owe is lost.
modern: I’m telling you this story for a reason.

origin: You know me well, and herein spend but time To wind about my love with circumstance.
modern: I owe you a lot, and like a spoiled kid I’ve lost what I owe you.

origin: And out of doubt you do me now more wrong In making question of my uttermost Than if you had made waste of all I have.
modern: But if you’d be willing to shoot another arrow the same way you shot the first, I’ll watch your arrow more carefully this time.

origin: Then do but say to me what I should do That in your knowledge may by me be done, And I am pressed unto it.
modern: Just tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.

origin: Therefore speak.
modern: Tell me.

origin: O, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!
modern: If you see me without it, you can be confident I’m dead.

origin: My lord and lady, it is now our time, That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper, To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady, I wish you all the joy that you can wish, For I am sure you can wish none from me.
modern: Now we can shout, “Congratulations, congratulations, my lord and lady!” My Lord Bassanio, and my dear lady, I wish you all the joy I can wish for.

origin: And when your honors mean to solemnize The bargain of your faith, I do beseech you Even at that time I may be married too.
modern: And when you get married, I hope I can be married at the same time.

origin: With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.
modern: Absolutely, if you can find a wife by then.

origin: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.
modern: I think I’ve found one already, thanks to you, my lord.

origin: What, and stake down?
modern: And do you mean what you’re saying, Gratiano?

origin: What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither, If that the youth of my new interest here Have power to bid you welcome.
modern: Hey, if I lay down my “ Welcome, Lorenzo and Salerio.

origin: So do I, my lord.
modern: I do too, my lord.

origin: They are entirely welcome.
modern: They’re entirely welcome.

origin: And I have reason for it.
modern: That’s true, and with good reason.

origin: Signor Antonio Commends him to you.
modern: This letter is for you from Signor Antonio.

origin: Ere I ope his letter, I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.
modern: Before I open this letter, please tell me how my good friend is doing.

origin: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind, Nor well, unless in mind.
modern: He’s not sick, my lord, but he’s very upset, and his problems are serious.

origin: His letter there Will show you his estate.
modern: His letter will tell you how he’s doing.

origin: There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.
modern: I wish you’d won the  Something bad in that letter is making Bassanio turn pale.

origin: Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world Could turn so much the constitution Of any constant man.
modern: Some good friend of his must have died, because nothing else in the world could change a man so much.

origin: What, worse and worse?— With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself, And I must freely have the half of anything That this same paper brings you.
modern: What, does the news only get worse?—Please, Bassanio, I’m half of you, so let me bear half the burden this letter brings you.

origin: O sweet Portia, Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words That ever blotted paper.
modern: Oh Portia, these are some of the worst words that ever stained a piece of paper.

origin: Gentle lady, When I did first impart my love to you, I freely told you, all the wealth I had Ran in my veins.
modern: My darling, when I gave my love to you, I told you that all the wealth I had ran within my veins—that I have noble blood, but no money.

origin: I was a gentleman, And then I told you true.
modern: When I said that, I told you the truth.

origin: When I told you My state was nothing, I should then have told you That I was worse than nothing, for indeed I have engaged myself to a dear friend, Engaged my friend to his mere enemy To feed my means.
modern: But my dear, when I said I was worth nothing, I was actually bragging—I should’ve said that I was worse than nothing.

origin: Have all his ventures failed?
modern: Have all his business ventures failed?

origin: What, not one hit?
modern: Not even one success?

origin: Not one, my lord.
modern: Not one, my lord.

origin: Besides, it should appear that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.
modern: Anyway, even if he had the money now, the Jew probably wouldn’t take it.

origin: Never did I know A creature that did bear the shape of man So keen and greedy to confound a man.
modern: I’ve never seen a creature with a human shape who was so eager to destroy a man.

origin: He plies the duke at morning and at night, And doth impeach the freedom of the state If they deny him justice.
modern: He’s at the duke’s morning and night, accusing the state of harming free trade if they deny him justice.

origin: When I was with him I have heard him swear To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen, That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh Than twenty times the value of the sum That he did owe him.
modern: When I was still living with him I heard him swear to Tubal and Cush, his countrymen, that he’d rather have Antonio’s flesh than twenty times the sum Antonio owed.

origin: And I know, my lord, If law, authority, and power deny not, It will go hard with poor Antonio.
modern: And I know that unless the law intervenes, it’ll be bad news for poor Antonio.

origin: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?
modern: Is this your good friend who’s in so much trouble?

origin: What sum owes he the Jew?
modern: How much does he owe the Jew?

origin: For me, three thousand ducats.
modern: Three thousand ducats.

origin: What, no more?
modern: What, that’s all?

origin: Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!
modern: Pay him six thousand and cancel the debt.

origin: You shall have gold To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
modern: I’ll give you enough gold to pay back your debt twenty times over.

origin: When it is paid, bring your true friend along.
modern: When it’s paid, bring your friend back.

origin: My maid Nerissa and myself meantime Will live as maids and widows.
modern: Until you get back, Nerissa and I will live like virgins and widows.

origin: Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer.
modern: Put on a happy face, and welcome your friends.

origin: But let me hear the letter of your friend.
modern: But let me hear the letter from your friend.

origin: Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried.
modern: Dear Bassanio, my ships have all been wrecked.

origin: My creditors grow cruel.
modern: My creditors are getting mean.

origin: My estate is very low.
modern: My money’s almost run out.

origin: My bond to the Jew is forfeit.
modern: I couldn’t pay my debt to the Jew on the due date.

origin: Notwithstanding, use your pleasure.
modern: In any case, do what you want.

origin: If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.” O love, dispatch all business and be gone!
modern: If your affection for me doesn’t convince you to come, don’t let my letter do so.” Oh, my darling, make your arrangements and go!

origin: Since I have your good leave to go away, I will make haste.
modern: Since you’re letting me leave, I’ll hurry.

origin: But till I come again, No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay, No rest be interposer ’twixt us twain.
modern: But I won’t sleep till I get back.

origin: Jailer, look to him.
modern: Jailer, watch out for this one.

origin: This is the fool that lent out money gratis.
modern: This is the fool who lent out money without charging interest.

origin: Jailer, look to him.
modern: Jailer, keep an eye on him.

origin: Hear me yet, good Shylock.
modern: Listen to me, good Shylock.

origin: I pray thee, hear me speak.
modern: I’m going to get my  Please, listen to me.

origin: I’ll have my bond.
modern: I want my bond.

origin: I will not hear thee speak.
modern: I won’t listen to you.

origin: I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.
modern: I want my bond, so stop talking.

origin: I’ll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool To shake the head, relent and sigh, and yield To Christian intercessors.
modern: I won’t be taken for a fool who sighs and gives in to Christian meddlers.

origin: Follow not.
modern: Don’t follow me.

origin: I’ll have no speaking.
modern: I’m not talking with you.

origin: I will have my bond.
modern: I want my bond.

origin: It is the most impenetrable cur That ever kept with men.
modern: He’s the most stubborn dog that ever lived among humans.

origin: Let him alone.
modern: Leave him alone.

origin: I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.
modern: I won’t follow him around with useless pleas anymore.

origin: He seeks my life.
modern: He wants me dead.

origin: His reason well I know.
modern: I know the real reason.

origin: I oft delivered from his forfeitures Many that have at times made moan to me.
modern: I’ve often given money to people who were unable to pay back their loans to him.

origin: Therefore he hates me.
modern: That’s why he hates me.

origin: I am sure the duke Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.
modern: I’m sure the duke will never allow this contract to be enforced.

origin: Therefore go.
modern: So go.

origin: These griefs and losses have so bated me, That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.— Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
modern: I’ve lost so much weight worrying about my losses have that I’ll hardly have a pound of flesh to spare for my bloody creditor tomorrow.—Well, jailer, let’s go.—I hope to God that Bassanio comes to see me pay his debt.

origin: Lorenzo, I commit into your hands The husbandry and manage of my house Until my lord’s return.
modern: Lorenzo, please take charge of the management of my house until my husband comes back.

origin: Madam, with all my heart.
modern: Madam, with all my heart.

origin: I shall obey you in all fair commands.
modern: I’ll do anything you ask.

origin: My people do already know my mind And will acknowledge you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
modern: They’ll consider you and Jessica masters of this house in place of Lord Bassanio and myself.

origin: So fare you well till we shall meet again.
modern: So goodbye until we meet again.

origin: Fare you well, Jessica.
modern: Goodbye, Jessica.

origin: Now, Balthazar, As I have ever found thee honest true, So let me find thee still.
modern: Now, Balthazar, you’ve always been honest and faithful to me, and I trust you still are.

origin: Sometimes from her eyes I did receive fair speechless messages.
modern: Sometimes the expression on her face tells me she likes me.

origin: Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.
modern: Her name is Portia.

origin: I shall be there before thee.
modern: I’ll meet you at the ferry.

origin: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
modern: I’ll go as fast as I can, madam.

origin: Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand That you yet know not of.
modern: Come on, Nerissa, I have many things to do that you don’t even know about yet.

origin: We’ll see our husbands Before they think of us.
modern: We’ll see our husbands before they even have a chance to miss us.

origin: Shall they see us?
modern: Will they see us?

origin: They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit That they shall think we are accomplishèd With that we lack.
modern: They will, Nerissa, but we’ll be disguised as men.

origin: And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell, That men shall swear I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth.
modern: I’ll tell twenty lies like that, so men will think I graduated from school at least a year ago.

origin: I have within my mind A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks Which I will practice.
modern: I know a thousand immature tricks like that, and I’ll use them all.

origin: Why, shall we turn to men?
modern: Why, are we turning to men?

origin: Fie, what a question’s that If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!
modern: What kind of question is that!

origin: But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device When I am in my coach, which stays for us At the park gate.
modern: Here, I’ll tell you my whole plan in my carriage, which is waiting for us at the gate.

origin: And therefore haste away, For we must measure twenty miles today.
modern: So hurry up, because we have twenty miles to cover today.

origin: Yes, truly, for look you, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children.
modern: Yes, look, it’s true that children are punished for the sins of their fathers.

origin: Therefore I promise ye I fear you.
modern: That’s why I’m worried about you.

origin: I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter.
modern: I’ve always been straightforward with you, so now I’m telling you what I think.

origin: Therefore be o' good cheer, for truly I think you are damned.
modern: Cheer up, because I think you’re going to hell.

origin: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.
modern: There’s only one hope for you, and even that’s a kind of illegitimate hope.

origin: And what hope is that, I pray thee?
modern: What hope is that, may I ask?

origin: Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.
modern: You can hope your father isn’t your real father.

origin: That were a kind of bastard hope indeed.
modern: That really is an illegitimate hope.

origin: So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.
modern: Then I’d be punished for the sins of my mother.

origin: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother.
modern: In that case I’m afraid you’re damned by both your father and your mother.

origin: Thus when I shun Scylla your father, I fall into Charybdis your mother.
modern: When you avoid one trap, you fall into another.

origin: Well, you are gone both ways.
modern: You’re in trouble either way.

origin: I shall be saved by my husband.
modern: My husband will save me.

origin: He hath made me a Christian.
modern: He’s made me a Christian.

origin: Truly, the more to blame he.
modern: He was wrong to do that.

origin: We were Christians eno' before, e'en as many as could well live one by another.
modern: There were enough Christians before—as many of them as could stand to live near each other.

origin: This making Christians will raise the price of hogs.
modern: All these new Christians will make the price of hogs go up.

origin: If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.
modern: If we’re all pork-eaters, we won’t be able to get our hands on a slice of bacon, even if we’ve got the money for it.

origin: I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say.
modern: I’ll tell my husband what you’ve said, Launcelot.

origin: Here he comes.
modern: Here he comes.

origin: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.
modern: You’re going to make me jealous, Launcelot, if you keep taking my wife into dark corners like this!

origin: Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo.
modern: No, you don’t need to worry about us, Lorenzo.

origin: Launcelot and I are out.
modern: Launcelot and I can’t agree on anything.

origin: He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.
modern: He says I won’t get into heaven because I’m a Jew’s daughter, and he says you’re irresponsible because by converting Jews to Christianity you’re raising the price of pork.

origin: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly.
modern: I can justify that better than you can justify sleeping with Portia’s African servant.

origin: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason.
modern: The  It’s too bad there’s more of the Moor than there ought to be.

origin: I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots.
modern: I think the best sign of intelligence will soon be silence, and talking will only be a good thing for parrots to do.

origin: That is done, sir.
modern: That’s already been done, sir.

origin: They have all stomachs.
modern: They’re all ready to eat dinner.

origin: Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you!
modern: Good Lord, what a clown you are!

origin: Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant?
modern: Are you planning on showing me all your wit at once?

origin: For the table, sir, it shall be served in.
modern: About the table, sir, dinner will be served on it.

origin: For the meat, sir, it shall be covered.
modern: As for the food, it will be served in covered dishes.

origin: For your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and conceits shall govern.
modern: As for your coming in to dinner, just do what you feel is right.

origin: O dear discretion, how his words are suited!
modern: Oh, he’s good at bending words around!

origin: How cheerest thou, Jessica?
modern: Anyway, how are you, Jessica?

origin: How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?
modern: And how do you like Lord Bassanio’s wife?

origin: Past all expressing.
modern: I like her more than I can say.

origin: And if on earth he do not merit it, In reason he should never come to heaven.
modern: And if he doesn’t deserve this joy on earth, he’ll never deserve it in heaven.

origin: Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match And on the wager lay two earthly women, And Portia one, there must be something else Pawned with the other, for the poor rude world Hath not her fellow.
modern: The poor rude world doesn’t have her equal.

origin: Even such a husband Hast thou of me as she is for a wife.
modern: As good a wife as she is, that’s how good a husband I am to you.

origin: First let us go to dinner.
modern: First let’s go to dinner.

origin: Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.
modern: No, let me say some good things about you while I’m in the mood.

origin: No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.
modern: No, please, save it for dinner conversation.

origin: What, is Antonio here?
modern: Is Antonio here?

origin: Ready, so please your grace.
modern: Yes, sir, I’m here.

origin: I am sorry for thee.
modern: I feel sorry for you.

origin: Thou art come to answer A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch Uncapable of pity, void and empty From any dram of mercy.
modern: You’ve come to face a ruthless enemy, an inhuman wretch incapable of pity, without any feelings of mercy.

origin: I have heard Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify His rigorous course.
modern: They tell me you’ve done everything you can to talk him out of what he’s doing.

origin: But since he stands obdurate And that no lawful means can carry me Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose My patience to his fury, and am armed To suffer with a quietness of spirit The very tyranny and rage of his.
modern: I’m ready to suffer peacefully whatever he does to me in his cruelty and anger.

origin: Go, one, and call the Jew into the court.
modern: One of you go call the Jew into court here.

origin: He is ready at the door.
modern: He’s standing ready outside the door.

origin: He comes, my lord.
modern: Here he comes, my lord.

origin: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
modern: We all expect a nice answer from you, Jew.

origin: I have possessed your grace of what I purpose, And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn To have the due and forfeit of my bond.
modern: I’ve told you what I intend to do, and I’ve sworn by the holy Sabbath to seek the penalty that is due according to our contract.

origin: If you deny it, let the danger light Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.
modern: If you refuse to allow me to do so, your city’s charter and its freedom are endangered.

origin: You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have A weight of carrion flesh than to receive Three thousand ducats.
modern: You’re going to ask me why I’d rather have a pound of decaying flesh than three thousand ducats.

origin: I’ll not answer that But say it is my humour.
modern: I won’t answer that.

origin: Is it answered?
modern: Is that enough of an answer?

origin: What if my house be troubled with a rat And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats To have it baned?
modern: What if I had a rat in my house, and I felt like paying ten thousand ducats to have it exterminated?

origin: What, are you answered yet?
modern: Do you have your answer yet?

origin: Some men there are love not a gaping pig, Some that are mad if they behold a cat, And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose, Cannot contain their urine.
modern: Some men don’t like roast pig, others go crazy if they see a cat, and others can’t help urinating when they hear bagpipes.

origin: Are you answered?
modern: So, to answer your question.

origin: This is no answer, thou unfeeling man, To excuse the current of thy cruelty.
modern: It doesn’t excuse your cruel behavior.

origin: I am not bound to please thee with my answers.
modern: I don’t have to give you answers that you like.

origin: Do all men kill the things they do not love?
modern: Does everyone kill what they don’t love?

origin: What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?
modern: What, would you let a snake bite you twice?

origin: You may as well do anything most hard, As seek to soften that—than which what’s harder?— His Jewish heart.
modern: You might as well do the impossible rather than try to soften his Jewish heart.

origin: I would have my bond.
modern: I would choose to take my penalty.

origin: How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?
modern: How can you ever hope for mercy for yourself, when you don’t give any now?

origin: What judgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?
modern: Why should I be afraid of your judgment when I haven’t done anything wrong?

origin: You have among you many a purchased slave, Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules— You use in abject and in slavish parts Because you bought them.
modern: Many of you own slaves, which—like your donkeys and dogs and mules—you use to perform awful jobs just because you bought them.

origin: Shall I say to you, “Let them be free!
modern: Should I say to you, “Set them free!

origin: Marry them to your heirs!
modern: Let them marry your children!

origin: Why sweat they under burdens?
modern: Why are you making them work so hard?

origin: Let their beds Be made as soft as yours and let their palates Be seasoned with such viands”?
modern: Let their beds be as soft as yours, and let them eat the same food as you”?

origin: You will answer, “The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.
modern: No, you’d answer, “The slaves are ours.” And that’s just how I’m answering you.

origin: The pound of flesh which I demand of him Is dearly bought.
modern: The pound of flesh that I want from him was very expensive.

origin: Tis mine and I will have it.
modern: It’s mine and I’m going to get it.

origin: If you deny me, fie upon your law— There is no force in the decrees of Venice.
modern: If you refuse me, the laws of Venice have no validity.

origin: I stand for judgment.
modern: I await justice.

origin: By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this great world.
modern: Oh Nerissa, my poor little body is tired of this great big world.

origin: And yet for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing.
modern: But as far as I can tell, people with too much suffer as much as people with nothing.

origin: It is no mean happiness, therefore, to be seated in the mean.
modern: The best way to be happy is to be in between.

origin: Good sentences, and well pronounced.
modern: Good point, and well said.

origin: They would be better if well followed.
modern: It would be better if you actually applied it to your life.

origin: It is a good divine that follows his own instructions.
modern: It takes a good priest to practice what he preaches.

origin: But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband.
modern: But thinking like this won’t help me choose a husband.

origin: Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?
modern: Isn’t it a pain that I can’t choose or refuse anyone, Nerissa?

origin: Upon my power I may dismiss this court, Unless Bellario, a learnèd doctor, Whom I have sent for to determine this, Come here today.
modern: I have the authority to dismiss this court, unless Bellario comes today.

origin: Bring us the letter.
modern: Bring us the letters.

origin: Call the messenger.
modern: Call the messenger in.

origin: Good cheer, Antonio!
modern: Cheer up, Antonio!

origin: What, man, courage yet!
modern: Keep up your courage, man!

origin: The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all, Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood.
modern: I’ll give the Jew my flesh, blood, bones, and everything before you lose one drop of blood for me.

origin: I am a tainted wether of the flock, Meetest for death.
modern: I’m like the one sick sheep in the flock, the one who deserves to die.

origin: The weakest kind of fruit Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me.
modern: The weakest fruit drops to the ground first, so let me drop.

origin: You cannot better be employed, Bassanio, Than to live still and write mine epitaph.
modern: Bassanio, the best thing you can do is to keep living and write an epitaph for my gravestone.

origin: Came you from Padua, from Bellario?
modern: Have you come from Bellario’s office in Padua?

origin: From both, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Bellario greets your grace.
modern: Bellario sends his greetings.

origin: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.
modern: To cut my penalty from that bankrupt man over there.

origin: Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew, Thou makest thy knife keen.
modern: You’re sharpening that knife not on your sole but on your soul, you cruel Jew.

origin: But no metal can— No, not the hangman’s axe—bear half the keenness Of thy sharp envy.
modern: No metal—not even the executioner’s axe—could ever be half as sharp as your hatred.

origin: Can no prayers pierce thee?
modern: Can’t any prayers reach your heart?

origin: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.
modern: No, none that you’re smart enough to make.

origin: Thou almost makest me waver in my faith To hold opinion with Pythagoras That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men.
modern: You make me want to agree with the philosopher Pythagoras that animal souls are reincarnated in human bodies.

origin: Thy currish spirit Governed a wolf who, hanged for human slaughter, Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet, And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam Infused itself in thee, for thy desires Are wolvish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.
modern: That’s why your desires are wolfish, bloody, and ravenous.

origin: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond, Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.
modern: Unless your taunts can undo the signature on my contract, you’re just wearing out your lungs by speaking so loud.

origin: Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall To cureless ruin.
modern: Be quiet, boy, or you’ll lose your mind.

origin: I stand here for law.
modern: I stand here with the law on my side.

origin: This letter from Bellario doth commend A young and learnèd doctor to our court.
modern: This letter from Bellario introduces us to a young and well-educated legal expert.

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: He attendeth here hard by To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.
modern: He’s waiting nearby to find out if you’ll invite him in.

origin: With all my heart.—Some three or four of you Go give him courteous conduct to this place.— Meantime the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.
modern: With all my heart.—Three or four of you go welcome him.—In the meantime, I’ll read Bellario’s letter out loud.

origin: His name is Balthazar.
modern: His name is Balthazar.

origin: I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.” You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.
modern: I leave him to you.

origin: Come you from old Bellario?
modern: Did old Bellario send you here?

origin: I did, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: You are welcome.
modern: Welcome.

origin: Take your place.
modern: Please have a seat.

origin: Are you acquainted with the difference That holds this present question in the court?
modern: Are you familiar with the case currently before the court?

origin: I am informèd thoroughly of the cause.
modern: Yes, thoroughly.

origin: Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.
modern: Antonio and Shylock, both of you come forward.

origin: Is your name Shylock?
modern: Is your name Shylock?

origin: Shylock is my name.
modern: Shylock is my name.

origin: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow, Yet in such rule that the Venetian law Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—   Ay, so he says.
modern: Your case is most unusual, though the Venetian law can’t stop you from proceeding.— Yes, so he says.

origin: Do you confess the bond?
modern: Do you acknowledge the contract?

origin: I do.
modern: Yes, I do.

origin: Then must the Jew be merciful.
modern: Then the Jew must show you mercy.

origin: On what compulsion must I?
modern: Why do I have to do that?

origin: Tell me that.
modern: Tell me.

origin: The quality of mercy is not strained.
modern: No one shows mercy because he has to.

origin: It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven Upon the place beneath.
modern: It just happens, the way gentle rain drops on the ground.

origin: It is twice blessed: It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
modern: It blesses the one who gives it and the one who receives it.

origin: Tis mightiest in the mightiest.
modern: It’s strongest in the strongest people.

origin: It becomes The thronèd monarch better than his crown.
modern: It looks better in a king than his own crown looks on him.

origin: And earthly power doth then show likest God’s When mercy seasons justice.
modern: Kingly power seems most like God’s power when the king mixes mercy with justice.

origin: I have spoke thus much To mitigate the justice of thy plea, Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.
modern: If you pursue it, this strict court of Venice will need to carry out the sentence against the merchant there.

origin: My deeds upon my head.
modern: I take all responsibility for my decisions.

origin: I crave the law, The penalty, and forfeit of my bond.
modern: I want the law, the penalty, and the fulfillment of my contract.

origin: Is he not able to discharge the money?
modern: Can’t he pay back the money?

origin: If that will not suffice, I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er, On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.
modern: If that’s not enough, I’ll sign a contract to pay ten times that much, and I’ll give you my hands, my head, and my heart as security.

origin: There is no power in Venice Can alter a decree establishèd.
modern: There’s no power in Venice that can change an established decree.

origin: Twill be recorded for a precedent, And many an error by the same example Will rush into the state.
modern: The change will be recorded as a precedent, and many bad legal decisions will result.

origin: It cannot be.
modern: That can’t happen.

origin: I pray you, let me look upon the bond.
modern: Please, let me review the contract.

origin: Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.
modern: Shylock, they’re offering you three times the money you lent.

origin: An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.
modern: But I made an oath, an oath, an oath in heaven.

origin: Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?
modern: Should I perjure my soul by disobeying it?

origin: No, not for Venice.
modern: No, not for all of Venice.

origin: And lawfully by this the Jew may claim A pound of flesh to be by him cut off Nearest the merchant’s heart.—Be merciful.
modern: And so the Jew may lawfully claim a pound of flesh nearest the merchant’s heart, to be cut off by him.—But please have mercy.

origin: Take thrice thy money.
modern: Take three times your money.

origin: Bid me tear the bond.
modern: Tell me to tear up this contract.

origin: When it is paid according to the tenor.
modern: I’ll tear it up when it’s paid.

origin: It doth appear you are a worthy judge.
modern: You seem like a good judge.

origin: You know the law.
modern: You know the law.

origin: I charge you by the law, Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar, Proceed to judgment.
modern: I urge you to deliver your verdict.

origin: By my soul I swear There is no power in the tongue of man To alter me.
modern: I swear that nothing anyone can say will change my mind.

origin: I stay here on my bond.
modern: I’m sticking to the contract.

origin: Most heartily I do beseech the court To give the judgment.
modern: I beg the court to deliver the verdict.

origin: Why then, thus it is: You must prepare your bosom for his knife.
modern: Well, then, here it is: you must prepare yourself for his knife.

origin: O noble judge!
modern: Oh, good judge!

origin: O excellent young man!
modern: Oh, you excellent young man!

origin: For the intent and purpose of the law Hath full relation to the penalty, Which here appeareth due upon the bond.
modern: The law fully authorizes the penalty, which you have to pay according to the contract.

origin: Tis very true.
modern: Very true.

origin: O wise and upright judge!
modern: Oh wise judge!

origin: How much more elder art thou than thy looks!
modern: You’re so much older than you look!

origin: Ay, his breast.
modern: Yes, his chest!

origin: Nearest his heart”—those are the very words.
modern: Nearest his heart.”—Those are the very words.

origin: It is so.
modern: Yes.

origin: Are there balance here to weigh The flesh?
modern: Is there a scale here to weigh the flesh?

origin: I have them ready.
modern: I have it ready.

origin: Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge, To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.
modern: Pay a surgeon to stand by and bind his wounds, Shylock, so he doesn’t bleed to death.

origin: Is it so nominated in the bond?
modern: Is that called for in the contract?

origin: It is not so expressed, but what of that?
modern: Not explicitly, but so what?

origin: Twere good you do so much for charity.
modern: It wouldn’t hurt you to be charitable.

origin: I cannot find it.
modern: I can’t find it.

origin: Tis not in the bond.
modern: It’s not in the contract.

origin: But little.
modern: Not much.

origin: I am armed and well prepared.— Give me your hand, Bassanio.
modern: I’m ready and waiting.—Give me your hand, Bassanio.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you, For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom.
modern: Don’t be sad that this happened because of you, because Lady Luck’s been nicer to me than usual.

origin: Repent but you that you shall lose your friend, And he repents not that he pays your debt.
modern: Be sad only at the fact that you’ll lose your friend—your friend doesn’t regret that he paid your debt.

origin: For if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.
modern: If the Jew cuts deep enough, I’ll pay it instantly with all my heart.

origin: Antonio, I am married to a wife Which is as dear to me as life itself.
modern: Antonio, I married a woman as dear to me as life itself.

origin: But life itself, my wife, and all the world Are not with me esteemed above thy life.
modern: But life itself, my wife, and the whole world aren’t more valuable to me than your life is.

origin: I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all Here to this devil—to deliver you.
modern: I’d give it all up—yes, I’d sacrifice them all to this devil here—to save you.

origin: Your wife would give you little thanks for that If she were by to hear you make the offer.
modern: Your wife wouldn’t like it if she were here to hear you make that offer.

origin: I have a wife, whom I protest I love.
modern: I have a wife I love.

origin: I would she were in heaven, so she could Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.
modern: I wish she were in heaven so she could appeal to some power to make this dog Jew change his mind.

origin: Tis well you offer it behind her back.
modern: It’s nice you’re offering to sacrifice her behind her back.

origin: These be the Christian husbands.
modern: That’s what you get for marrying Christian husbands.

origin: I have a daughter.
modern: I have a daughter.

origin: The court awards it, and the law doth give it.
modern: The court awards it and the law authorizes it.

origin: Most rightful judge!
modern: What a righteous judge!

origin: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast.
modern: And you have to cut this flesh from his chest.

origin: The law allows it, and the court awards it.
modern: The law allows it, and the court awards it.

origin: Most learnèd judge, a sentence!
modern: What a wise judge!

origin: Come, prepare.
modern: Come on, get ready.

origin: Tarry a little.
modern: But wait a moment.

origin: There is something else.
modern: There’s something else.

origin: This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood.
modern: This contract doesn’t give you any blood at all.

origin: The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.” Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh, But in the cutting it if thou dost shed One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods Are by the laws of Venice confiscate Unto the state of Venice.
modern: The words expressly specify “a pound of flesh.” So take your penalty of a pound of flesh, but if you shed one drop of Christian blood when you cut it, the state of Venice will confiscate your land and property under Venetian law.

origin: Is that the law?
modern: Is that the law?

origin: Thyself shalt see the act.
modern: You can see for yourself.

origin: For as thou urgest justice, be assured Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.
modern: You asked for justice, so rest assured you’ll get more justice than you bargained for.

origin: I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice And let the Christian go.
modern: Pay me three times the amount of the loan and let the Christian go.

origin: Here is the money.
modern: Here is the money.

origin: Soft!
modern: Wait!

origin: The Jew shall have all justice.
modern: The Jew will have justice.

origin: Soft, no haste.
modern: Wait, don’t rush!

origin: He shall have nothing but the penalty.
modern: He’s not getting anything except the penalty.

origin: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.
modern: So get ready to cut off the flesh.

origin: Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more But just a pound of flesh.
modern: Don’t shed any blood, or cut less or more than exactly a pound of flesh.

origin: If thou takest more Or less than a just pound, be it but so much As makes it light or heavy in the substance Or the division of the twentieth part Of one poor scruple—nay, if the scale do turn But in the estimation of a hair, Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.
modern: If you take more or less than exactly a pound, even if it’s just the tiniest fraction of an ounce—if the scale changes by even so much as a hair, you die, and all your property will be confiscated.

origin: A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!
modern: A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!

origin: Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.
modern: I’ve got you now, pagan.

origin: Why doth the Jew pause?
modern: Why is the Jew waiting?

origin: Take thy forfeiture.
modern: Take your penalty.

origin: Give me my principal, and let me go.
modern: Give me my money and let me go.

origin: I have it ready for thee.
modern: I have it ready for you.

origin: Here it is.
modern: Here it is.

origin: Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.
modern: Your father was an extremely moral man, and religious people get odd ideas on their deathbeds.

origin: I pray thee, overname them.
modern: But tell me.

origin: First, there is the Neapolitan prince.
modern: Well, first there was the prince from Naples.

origin: I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith.
modern: I’m afraid his mother may have had an affair with a blacksmith.

origin: Then there is the County Palatine.
modern: Then there’s the Count Palatine.

origin: He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears merry tales and smiles not.
modern: He does nothing but frown, as if he wants to say, “If you don’t want me, I don’t care.” He doesn’t even smile when he hears funny stories.

origin: I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth.
modern: If he’s so sad and solemn when he’s young, I can only imagine how much he’ll cry as an old man.

origin: I had rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these.
modern: No, I’d rather be married to a skull with a bone in its mouth than to either of those men.

origin: God defend me from these two!
modern: God protect me from these two!

origin: How say you by the French lord, Monsieur le Bon?
modern: What did you think about that French lord, Monsieur le Bon?

origin: He hath refused it in the open court.
modern: No, he refused it publicly, in open court.

origin: He shall have merely justice and his bond.
modern: He will have only justice and his penalty.

origin: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.
modern: You can’t have anything but the penalty, to be taken at your peril, Jew.

origin: Why then, the devil give him good of it!
modern: Well, then, I hope he chokes on it!

origin: I’ll stay no longer question.
modern: I’m not staying here to argue anymore.

origin: Tarry, Jew.
modern: Wait a minute, Jew.

origin: The law hath yet another hold on you.
modern: The law has another hold on you.

origin: It is enacted in the laws of Venice, If it be proved against an alien That by direct or indirect attempts He seek the life of any citizen, The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive Shall seize one half his goods.
modern: The laws of Venice state that if a foreign resident directly or indirectly attempts to kill any citizen, the person he tried to kill will receive one half of the foreigner’s goods.

origin: The other half Comes to the privy coffer of the state, And the offender’s life lies in the mercy Of the Duke only 'gainst all other voice.
modern: The other half goes to the state.

origin: Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.
modern: So get down on your knees and beg mercy from the duke.

origin: Therefore thou must be hanged at the state’s charge.
modern: So you’ll be hanged at the state’s expense.

origin: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit, I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.
modern: I want you to see the difference between us, so I pardon you even before you ask for a pardon.

origin: For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.
modern: Half of your wealth goes to Antonio.

origin: The other half comes to the general state, Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.
modern: The other half goes to the state.

origin: Ay, for the state, not for Antonio.
modern: Yes, the state’s half can be reduced, but not Antonio’s.

origin: Nay, take my life and all.
modern: No, go ahead and take my life.

origin: Pardon not that.
modern: Don’t pardon that.

origin: You take my house when you do take the prop That doth sustain my house.
modern: You take my house away when you take the money I need for upkeep.

origin: You take my life When you do take the means whereby I live.
modern: You take my life when you take away my means of making a living.

origin: What mercy can you render him, Antonio?
modern: What mercy can you show him, Antonio?

origin: A halter gratis, nothing else, for God’s sake.
modern: Nothing else, for God’s sake!

origin: So please my lord the duke and all the court, To quit the fine for one half of his goods I am content, so he will let me have The other half in use to render it Upon his death unto the gentleman That lately stole his daughter.
modern: If the duke and his court agree to set aside the fine for one half of his property, I’m happy, as long as he lets me have the other half in trust, to give it to the gentleman who recently stole his daughter.

origin: Two things provided more: that for this favor He presently become a Christian; The other, that he do record a gift Here in the court, of all he dies possessed, Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.
modern: Second, he must make a will here in this court that leaves all his property to his son-in-law Lorenzo and his daughter when he dies.

origin: He shall do this, or else I do recant The pardon that I late pronouncèd here.
modern: He must do this, or I’ll recant the pardon I just delivered.

origin: Art thou contented, Jew?
modern: Are you satisfied, Jew?

origin: What dost thou say?
modern: What do you say?

origin: I am content.
modern: I’m satisfied.

origin: I pray you, give me leave to go from hence.
modern: Please let me go.

origin: I am not well.
modern: I’m not well.

origin: Send the deed after me, And I will sign it.
modern: Send the deed after me and I’ll sign it.

origin: Get thee gone, but do it.
modern: Go, but sign the deed.

origin: I must away this night toward Padua, And it is meet I presently set forth.
modern: I should really leave right away.

origin: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.— Antonio, gratify this gentleman, For in my mind you are much bound to him.
modern: I’m sorry you don’t have time.—Antonio, give this gentleman a reward.

origin: And stand indebted, over and above, In love and service to you evermore.
modern: We owe you love and service forever.

origin: He is well paid that is well satisfied.
modern: Being satisfied with a job well done is payment enough.

origin: And I, delivering you, am satisfied, And therein do account myself well paid.
modern: In saving you I consider myself well paid.

origin: My mind was never yet more mercenary.
modern: My thoughts were never on money.

origin: I pray you, know me when we meet again.
modern: I hope you’ll recognize me when we meet again.

origin: I wish you well, and so I take my leave.
modern: I wish you well.

origin: Take some remembrance of us as a tribute, Not as a fee.
modern: Take some memento from us as a token of our gratitude, not as a fee.

origin: This ring, good sir—alas, it is a trifle.
modern: This ring, sir—oh no, it’s nothing.

origin: I will not shame myself to give you this.
modern: I’d be ashamed to give you this.

origin: I will have nothing else but only this.
modern: I don’t want anything but that.

origin: And now methinks I have a mind to it.
modern: Now that I think about it, I really want it.

origin: There’s more depends on this than on the value.
modern: There’s more to this ring than its cash value.

origin: The dearest ring in Venice will I give you, And find it out by proclamation.
modern: I’ll give you the most expensive ring in Venice, and I’ll make a public announcement to help me find it.

origin: Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.
modern: But as for this ring, please excuse me.

origin: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.
modern: I see you like to make big offers, sir.

origin: You taught me first to beg, and now methinks You teach me how a beggar should be answered.
modern: First you taught me how to beg, and now I think you’re teaching me how a beggar should be answered.

origin: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife.
modern: Good sir, this ring was given to me by my wife.

origin: And when she put it on, she made me vow That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.
modern: When she put it on my finger, she made me swear never to sell it, give it away, or lose it.

origin: That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts.
modern: Many men use that excuse to avoid giving gifts.

origin: An if your wife be not a madwoman, And know how well I have deserved the ring, She would not hold out enemy forever For giving it to me.
modern: If your wife’s not a madwoman, and you tell her how much I deserve this ring, she won’t stay angry at you forever if you give it to me.

origin: Well, peace be with you.
modern: Well, anyway, goodbye.

origin: My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.
modern: Bassanio, let him have the ring.

origin: Come, you and I will thither presently.
modern: Come on, you and I will go soon.

origin: And in the morning early will we both Fly toward Belmont.
modern: Early in the morning we’ll both rush to Belmont.

origin: Come, Antonio.
modern: Come on, Antonio.

origin: Inquire the Jew’s house out.
modern: Find out where the Jew’s house is.

origin: Give him this deed, And let him sign it.
modern: Give him this deed and have him sign it.

origin: We’ll away tonight, And be a day before our husbands home.
modern: We’ll leave tonight and be home a day before our husbands get back.

origin: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.
modern: Lorenzo will be happy with what we’ve done.

origin: Furthermore, I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.
modern: And could you please take my servant to old Shylock’s house?

origin: That will I do.
modern: I’ll do that.

origin: Away, make haste.
modern: Go, hurry.

origin: Thou know’st where I will tarry.
modern: You know where I’ll be waiting.

origin: The moon shines bright.
modern: The moon’s bright tonight.

origin: In such a night as this, When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees And they did make no noise, in such a night Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents Where Cressid lay that night.
modern: I think that on a night like this, when the wind blew the trees so gently that they didn’t make a sound,  On a night like this,  On a night like this,  On a night like this,

origin: In such a night Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well, Stealing her soul with many vows of faith, And ne'er a true one.
modern: On a night like this, young Lorenzo swore he loved her very much, stealing her heart with vows of love, but not one vow was true.

origin: In such a night Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew, Slander her love, and he forgave it her.
modern: On a night like this, pretty Jessica, in a bad mood, said outrageously wrong things about her lover, and he forgave her.

origin: But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
modern: I hear his footsteps.

origin: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
modern: Who are you, coming so fast in this quiet night?

origin: A friend.
modern: A friend.

origin: A friend?
modern: A friend?

origin: What friend?
modern: What friend?

origin: Your name, I pray you, friend?
modern: What’s your name, please, friend?

origin: Stephano is my name, and I bring word My mistress will before the break of day Be here at Belmont.
modern: My name’s Stephano, and I’ve come to tell you my mistress will arrive here at Belmont before sunrise.

origin: She doth stray about By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays For happy wedlock hours.
modern: She’s still at the monastery, kneeling and praying for a happy marriage.

origin: Who comes with her?
modern: Who’s coming with her?

origin: None but a holy hermit and her maid.
modern: No one except her maid and a holy hermit.

origin: I pray you, is my master yet returned?
modern: Has my master returned yet?

origin: Sola, sola!
modern: Hey, hey!

origin: Wo, ha, ho!
modern: Hey!

origin: Sola, sola!
modern: Yoo-hoo!

origin: Who calls?
modern: Who’s shouting?

origin: Sola!
modern: Hey!

origin: Did you see Master Lorenzo?
modern: Have you seen Master Lorenzo!

origin: Leave holloaing, man.
modern: Stop hollering, man!

origin: Here.
modern: I’m here.

origin: Sola!
modern: Hey!

origin: Where, where?
modern: Where, where?

origin: Here.
modern: Here.

origin: Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news.
modern: Tell him a messenger has arrived from my master with good news.

origin: My master will be here ere morning.
modern: My master will be here in the morning.

origin: Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.
modern: My dear, let’s go inside and wait for them to arrive.

origin: And yet no matter.
modern: But I guess it doesn’t matter.

origin: God made him and therefore let him pass for a man.
modern: We might as well call him a man, since God created him.

origin: In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, but he!—why, he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine.
modern: His horse is better than the Neapolitan’s and he frowns more than the Count Palatine.

origin: What say you then to Falconbridge, the young baron of England?
modern: What about Falconbridge, that young English baron?

origin: You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, nor I him.
modern: I have no opinion about him.

origin: He hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English.
modern: He doesn’t speak Latin, French, or Italian, and you know how little English I speak.

origin: He is a proper man’s picture, but alas, who can converse with a dumb show?
modern: He’s great-looking, but how can you talk to someone who doesn’t speak your language?

origin: How oddly he is suited!
modern: He was dressed so oddly too!

origin: I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.
modern: I think he got his jacket in Italy, his tights in France, his hat in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.

origin: What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?
modern: What do you think of his neighbor, the Scottish lord?

origin: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!
modern: How beautiful the moonlight’s shining on this bank!

origin: Here will we sit and let the sounds of music Creep in our ears.
modern: Let’s sit here and let the music fill our ears.

origin: Soft stillness and the night Become the touches of sweet harmony.
modern: Stillness and nighttime are perfect for beautiful music.

origin: Sit, Jessica.
modern: Sit down, Jessica.

origin: Look how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patens of bright gold.
modern: Look at the stars, see how the floor of heaven is inlaid with small disks of bright gold.

origin: Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn!
modern: Wake up the moon goddess with a hymn!

origin: With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear, And draw her home with music.
modern: Get her attention and draw her home with music.

origin: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
modern: I’m never in the mood to laugh when I hear sweet music.

origin: The motions of his spirit are dull as night, And his affections dark as Erebus.
modern: His soul is as dull as night and dark as the underworld.

origin: Let no such man be trusted.
modern: Nobody like that should be trusted.

origin: Mark the music.
modern: Pay attention to the music.

origin: That light we see is burning in my hall.
modern: That light we see is coming from my hall.

origin: How far that little candle throws his beams!
modern: Look how far that little candle sends its light!

origin: So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
modern: That’s the way a good deed shines in a naughty world.

origin: When the moon shone we did not see the candle.
modern: While the moon was shining we didn’t even notice the candle.

origin: So doth the greater glory dim the less.
modern: Well, brighter lights always dim the smaller ones.

origin: A substitute shines brightly as a king Until a king be by, and then his state Empties itself, as doth an inland brook Into the main of waters.
modern: A governor shines as brightly as a king until a king is near by, and the governor suddenly looks like a nobody.

origin: Music, hark.
modern: Music, listen!

origin: It is your music, madam, of the house.
modern: It’s your music, madam, from your house.

origin: Nothing is good, I see, without respect.
modern: Now I see that you can’t call anything good except in right context.

origin: How many things by season seasoned are To their right praise and true perfection!
modern: How many things in life seem good to us because of when they happen!

origin: Peace!
modern: Quiet now!

origin: How the moon sleeps with Endymion And would not be awaked.
modern: Look how the moon seems to be sleeping with its lover and can’t be awoken!

origin: That is the voice, Or I am much deceived, of Portia.
modern: If I’m not mistaken, that’s Portia’s voice.

origin: He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo— By the bad voice.
modern: He recognizes me like a blind man recognizes a cuckoo—by its bad voice.

origin: Dear lady, welcome home.
modern: Dear lady, welcome home.

origin: We have been praying for our husbands' welfare, Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.
modern: We’ve been praying for our husbands' welfare.

origin: Are they returned?
modern: Have they come back?

origin: Go in, Nerissa.
modern: Go inside, Nerissa.

origin: Give order to my servants that they take No note at all of our being absent hence.— Nor you, Lorenzo.—Jessica, nor you.
modern: Tell my servants not to mention that we were gone.

origin: I hear his trumpet.
modern: I hear his trumpet.

origin: This night methinks is but the daylight sick.
modern: I think this night is just like sick daylight.

origin: It looks a little paler.
modern: It only looks a little paler.

origin: Tis a day Such as the day is when the sun is hid.
modern: It looks like a day when the sun is hidden.

origin: I thank you, madam.
modern: I’ll give  Thank you, darling.

origin: Give welcome to my friend.
modern: I’d like to introduce you to my friend.

origin: This is the man, this is Antonio, To whom I am so infinitely bound.
modern: This is Antonio, my dearest friend.

origin: Sir, you are very welcome to our house.
modern: Sir, welcome to our house.

origin: It must appear in other ways than words, Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.
modern: But action speaks louder than words, so I’ll cut short these polite words.

origin: A quarrel, ho, already?
modern: What, an argument already?

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring That she did give me, whose posy was For all the world like cutler’s poetry Upon a knife, “Love me and leave me not.” What talk you of the posy or the value?
modern: It said, “Love me and don’t leave me.” How can you talk about the quality of the poem or the value of the ring?

origin: You swore to me when I did give it you That you would wear it till your hour of death, And that it should lie with you in your grave.
modern: You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it till you died, and that it would be buried with you.

origin: Gave it a judge’s clerk!
modern: And now you claim you gave it to a judge’s clerk!

origin: He will, an if he live to be a man.
modern: He will if he lives long enough to become a man.

origin: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.
modern: Yes, if a woman grows up to be a man.

origin: I could not for my heart deny it him.
modern: I didn’t have the heart to say no to him.

origin: You were to blame, I must be plain with you, To part so slightly with your wife’s first gift, A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
modern: You were wrong to give away your wife’s first gift so thoughtlessly, a thing you swore to keep on your finger and bound faithfully to your body.

origin: I gave my love a ring and made him swear Never to part with it.
modern: I gave my lover a ring and made him swear never to lose it or give it away.

origin: And here he stands.
modern: And here he is.

origin: I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth That the world masters.
modern: I’d swear he wouldn’t leave it behind, or even take it off his finger, for all the money in the world.

origin: Now in faith, Gratiano, You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief.
modern: To tell the truth, Gratiano, you’re giving your wife a valid reason to get upset.

origin: An ’twere to me, I should be mad at it.
modern: If it were me, I’d be very upset too.

origin: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away Unto the judge that begged it and indeed Deserved it too.
modern: Bassanio gave his ring to the judge who asked for it, and deserved it too.

origin: And then the boy, his clerk, That took some pains in writing, he begged mine.
modern: And then his clerk, who went to a lot of trouble with the writing, begged for mine.

origin: And neither man nor master would take aught But the two rings.
modern: Neither of them would take anything but the two rings.

origin: What ring gave you my lord?
modern: Which ring did you give away, my lord?

origin: Not that, I hope, which you received of me.
modern: Not the one I gave you, I hope.

origin: If I could add a lie unto a fault I would deny it.
modern: If I could make things better by lying, I’d deny it.

origin: but you see my finger Hath not the ring upon it.
modern: But you see my finger doesn’t have the ring on it.

origin: It is gone.
modern: It’s gone.

origin: Sweet Portia, If you did know to whom I gave the ring, If you did know for whom I gave the ring, And would conceive for what I gave the ring, And how unwillingly I left the ring When naught would be accepted but the ring, You would abate the strength of your displeasure.
modern: My dear Portia, if you knew who I gave the ring to, for whose sake I gave the ring to him, why I gave it to him, and how unwilling I was to leave it when he wouldn’t accept anything but the ring, you wouldn’t be so angry.

origin: If you had known the virtue of the ring, Or half her worthiness that gave the ring, Or your own honor to contain the ring, You would not then have parted with the ring.
modern: If you’d known how much that ring meant, how much the woman who gave it to you is worth, or how much your honor depended on your keeping the ring, you wouldn’t have let it go.

origin: Nerissa teaches me what to believe.
modern: Nerissa’s got the right idea.

origin: I’ll die for ’t but some woman had the ring.
modern: I’ll bet my life you gave some woman the ring!

origin: What should I say, sweet lady?
modern: What could I say, my dear?

origin: I was enforced to send it after him.
modern: I had to send it to him.

origin: Let not that doctor e'er come near my house!
modern: Don’t let that lawyer ever come near my house!

origin: Since he hath got the jewel that I loved, And that which you did swear to keep for me, I will become as liberal as you.
modern: Since he has the jewel I loved, which you swore you’d keep forever, I’ll be as generous as you were to him.

origin: I’ll not deny him anything I have, No, not my body, nor my husband’s bed.
modern: I won’t deny him anything of mine, including my own body and my husband’s bed.

origin: Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
modern: I’ll recognize him all right, I’m sure of it.

origin: Lie not a night from home.
modern: So don’t spend one night away from this house.

origin: Watch me like Argus.
modern: Watch me like a hawk.

origin: If you do not, if I be left alone, Now, by mine honor—which is yet mine own— I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.
modern: If you don’t, if I’m left alone, I swear I’ll have that legal expert as my bedfellow.

origin: I am th' unhappy subject of these quarrels.
modern: All these quarrels are about me.

origin: Sir, grieve not you.
modern: Don’t be upset.

origin: Portia, forgive me this enforcèd wrong, And in the hearing of these many friends I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes Wherein I see myself—     Mark you but that!
modern: All these friends are my witnesses, so I swear to you, I swear by your beautiful eyes, in which I see myself reflected— Did you hear that!

origin: In both my eyes he doubly sees himself— In each eye, one.
modern: He sees himself in my two eyes, so there’s two of him.

origin: Swear by your double self, And there’s an oath of credit!
modern: He should swear by his two-faced self, and that’s an oath I’ll believe!

origin: Nay, but hear me.
modern: No, just listen to me.

origin: Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear I never more will break an oath with thee.
modern: If you forgive my mistake, I swear I’ll never break an oath with you again.

origin: I once did lend my body for his wealth, Which but for him that had your husband’s ring Had quite miscarried.
modern: I lent my body once to make him rich.

origin: By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!
modern: My God, it’s the same one I gave the judge!

origin: I had it of him.
modern: I got it from him.

origin: What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it?
modern: What, did you cheat on us before we deserved it?

origin: Speak not so grossly.—You are all amazed.
modern: Don’t be crass.—You all look confused.

origin: I am dumb.
modern: I’m speechless.

origin: Ay, but the clerk that never means to do it Unless he live until he be a man.
modern: Yes, but the clerk will never do it, unless he grows up to be a man.

origin: Sweet lady, you have given me life and living.
modern: Madam, you’ve given me life and given me a living too.

origin: How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony’s nephew?
modern: How did you like the young German, the duke of Saxony’s nephew?

origin: Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober, and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk.
modern: He’s pretty awful in the morning when he’s sobering up, and even worse in the afternoon when he’s drunk.

origin: When he is best he is a little worse than a man, and when he is worst he is little better than a beast.
modern: At his best he’s a little less than a man, and at his worst he’s little more than an animal.

origin: I will do any thing, Nerissa, ere I’ll be married to a sponge.
modern: I’ll do anything rather than marry a drunk, Nerissa.

origin: You need not fear, lady, the having any of these lords.
modern: You don’t have to worry about any of these lords, my lady.

origin: And I pray God grant them a fair departure.
modern: I wish them all safe trips home.

origin: Do you not remember, lady, in your father’s time a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in company of the Marquess of Montferrat?
modern: Do you remember a Venetian scholar and soldier who accompanied the marquess of Montferrat here once when your father was still alive?

origin: How now, Lorenzo?
modern: How are you, Lorenzo?

origin: My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.
modern: My clerk has some comforting news for you, too.

origin: Ay, and I’ll give them him without a fee.
modern: Yes, and I’ll give it to him for free.

origin: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way Of starvèd people.
modern: Ladies, you’re dropping bread from the heavens to starving people.

origin: It is almost morning, And yet I am sure you are not satisfied Of these events at full.
modern: It’s almost morning, but I’m sure you’re not fully satisfied about what happened.

origin: Let us go in, And charge us there upon interr'gatories, And we will answer all things faithfully.
modern: Let’s go inside and we’ll answer all your questions truthfully.

origin: Let it be so.
modern: All right, then.

origin: The first interr'gatory That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is Whether till the next night she had rather stay, Or go to bed now, being two hours to day.
modern: My first question for Nerissa is whether she’d rather wait till tomorrow night or go to bed now, since there are only two more hours till morning.

origin: But were the day come, I should wish it dark, That I were couching with the doctor’s clerk.
modern: When the day comes, I’ll wish it were nighttime, so I could sleep with the legal expert’s clerk.

origin: True, madam.
modern: Yes, madam, that’s the one.

origin: He, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
modern: He deserves a beautiful wife more than all the other men I’ve ever seen.

origin: I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of thy praise.
modern: I remember him well, and my memory tells me that he deserves your praise.

origin: How now, what news?
modern: Hello, do you have any news?

origin: The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave.
modern: The four suitors are looking for you so they can say goodbye, madam.

origin: And there is a forerunner come from a fifth, the Prince of Morocco, who brings word the prince his master will be here tonight.
modern: And there’s a messenger representing a fifth one, the prince of Morocco, who says the prince will be here tonight.

origin: If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach.
modern: If I could say hello to the fifth one as happily as I’ll say goodbye to the first four, I’d be very happy he’s coming.

origin: If he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me.
modern: If he’s as good as a saint but is black like a devil, I’d rather he hear my confession than marry me.

origin: Come, Nerissa.—
modern: Let’s go, Nerissa.—
