origin: Three thousand ducats, well.
modern: Three thousand ducats, hmmm.

origin: Ay, sir, for three months.
modern: Yes, for three months.

origin: For three months, well.
modern: For three months, hmmm.

origin: For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.
modern: As I said before, Antonio will guarantee the loan.

origin: Antonio shall become bound, well.
modern: If I default, he’ll pay you.

origin: May you stead me?
modern: Antonio will guarantee it, hmmm.

origin: Will you pleasure me?
modern: Can you help me?

origin: Shall I know your answer?
modern: What’s your answer?

origin: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.
modern: Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio will guarantee it.

origin: Your answer to that?
modern: Your answer?

origin: Antonio is a good man.
modern: Antonio’s a good man.

origin: Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
modern: Have you heard anything to the contrary?

origin: Yet his means are in supposition.
modern: But his investments are uncertain right now.

origin: He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies.
modern: He has one ship bound for Tripoli, another heading for the Indies.

origin: I understand moreover, upon the Rialto, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he hath squandered abroad.
modern: What’s more, people at the

origin: But ships are but boards, sailors but men.
modern: But ships are just fragile boards, and sailors are just men.

origin: There be land rats and water rats, water thieves and land thieves—I mean pirates—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks.
modern: There are rats and thieves and pirates—not to mention storms, winds, and rocks.

origin: The man is notwithstanding sufficient.
modern: But in spite of all this, the man is still wealthy enough.

origin: Be assured you may.
modern: I assure you he can.

origin: This is Signor Antonio.
modern: Oh yes—to smell  This is Signor Antonio.

origin: In sooth, I know not why I am so sad.
modern: To be honest, I don’t know why I’m so sad.

origin: It wearies me; you say it wearies you.
modern: I’m tired of it, and you say you’re tired of it too.

origin: Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth, The better part of my affections would Be with my hopes abroad.
modern: I’d be peering over maps to figure out the best ports, piers, and waterways.

origin: And every object that might make me fear Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt Would make me sad.
modern: Everything that made me worry about my ships would make me sad.

origin: Shylock, do you hear?
modern: Shylock, are you listening?

origin: I am debating of my present store, And by the near guess of my memory I cannot instantly raise up the gross Of full three thousand ducats.
modern: If I remember correctly, I can’t raise the entire three thousand ducats immediately.

origin: What of that?
modern: But so what?

origin: Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe, Will furnish me.
modern: Tubal, a wealthy Jew I know, will supply me with the cash.

origin: But soft!
modern: But wait a minute!

origin: How many months Do you desire?
modern: How many months do you want?

origin: Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor borrow By taking nor by giving of excess, Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend, I’ll break a custom.
modern: Shylock, although I never lend or borrow with interest, I’m willing to break that habit to help a friend in need.

origin: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.
modern: Oh yes, three thousand ducats.

origin: And for three months.
modern: For three months.

origin: I had forgot—three months.
modern: Yes, I forgot—three months.

origin: You told me so.
modern: That’s right.

origin: I do never use it.
modern: That’s not how I do business.

origin: When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban’s sheep— This Jacob from our holy Abram was, As his wise mother wrought in his behalf, The third possessor, ay, he was the third— And what of him?
modern: When Jacob took care of his uncle Laban’s sheep—Jacob was the heir to his grandfather Abraham’s birthright, because his mother cleverly arranged for her husband Isaac to make Jacob his heir— What’s your point?

origin: Did he take interest?
modern: Did he charge interest?

origin: This was a venture, sir, that Jacob served for— A thing not in his power to bring to pass But swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven.
modern: Jacob didn’t have any control over what happened.

origin: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
modern: That your interest payments are like Jacob’s sheep?

origin: But note me, signor—
modern: But listen to me, signor—

origin: An evil soul producing holy witness Is like a villain with a smiling cheek, A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
modern: An evil soul using a holy story is like a criminal who smiles at you.

origin: Oh, what a goodly outside falsehood hath!
modern: Oh, liars can look so honest!

origin: Three months from twelve, then.
modern: Three months from twelve months of the year.

origin: Let me see.
modern: Let me see.

origin: The rate— Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?
modern: The interest rate will be— Well, Shylock?

origin: Signor Antonio, many a time and oft In the Rialto you have rated me About my moneys and my usances.
modern: Signor Antonio, you’ve often insulted my money and my business practices in the Rialto.

origin: You call me misbeliever, cutthroat dog, And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine— And all for use of that which is mine own.
modern: And all because I use my own money to make a profit.

origin: Well then, it now appears you need my help.
modern: And now it looks like you need my help.

origin: Go to, then!
modern: All right then.

origin: You come to me and you say, “Shylock, we would have moneys.” You say so!— You, that did void your rheum upon my beard And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur Over your threshold!
modern: You come to me saying, “Shylock, we need money.” You say that!—even though you spat on my beard and kicked me like you’d kick a stray mutt out your front door.

origin: Moneys is your suit.
modern: And now you’re asking for money.

origin: What should I say to you?
modern: What can I tell you?

origin: Should I not say, “Hath a dog money?
modern: Shouldn’t I say, “Does a dog have money?

origin: Is it possible A cur can lend three thousand ducats?” Or Shall I bend low and in a bondman’s key With bated breath and whispering humbleness Say this:
modern: Is it possible for a mutt to lend three thousand ducats?” Or should I bend down low, and in a humble and submissive voice say:

origin: If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not As to thy friends, for when did friendship take A breed for barren metal of his friend?
modern: If you’re going to lend us this money, don’t lend it to us as if we were your friends.

origin: But lend it rather to thine enemy, Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face Exact the penalty.
modern: Instead, lend it to me as your enemy.

origin: Why, look you how you storm!
modern: Look at you getting all riled up!

origin: I would be friends with you and have your love, Forget the shames that you have stained me with, Supply your present wants and take no doit Of usance for my moneys—and you’ll not hear me!
modern: I want to be friends with you, and forget all the times you’ve embarrassed and humiliated me.

origin: This is kind I offer.
modern: I’m making a kind offer—zero percent financing.

origin: This were kindness.
modern: That really would be kind.

origin: This kindness will I show.
modern: I’ll show you how kind I am.

origin: Go with me to a notary, seal me there Your single bond, and—in a merry sport— If you repay me not on such a day, In such a place, such sum or sums as are Expressed in the condition, let the forfeit Be nominated for an equal pound Of your fair flesh, to be cut off and taken In what part of your body pleaseth me.
modern: If you don’t repay me on the day we agree on, in the place we name, for the sum of money fixed in our contract, your penalty will be a pound of your pretty flesh, to be cut off and taken out of whatever part of your body I like.

origin: Content, in faith.
modern: It’s a deal.

origin: I’ll seal to such a bond, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
modern: I’ll agree to those terms and even say that Jews are nice.

origin: You shall not seal to such a bond for me!
modern: No, you can’t sign a contract like that for me!

origin: I’ll rather dwell in my necessity.
modern: I’d rather go without the money.

origin: Within these two months—that’s a month before This bond expires—I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
modern: In two months—a month before this loan is due—I expect to earn more than three times that much from my investments.

origin: A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man Is not so estimable, profitable neither, As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats.
modern: A pound of human flesh taken isn’t even as valuable as a pound of mutton or beef.

origin: If he will take it, so.
modern: If he agrees, great.

origin: If not, adieu.
modern: If not, goodbye.

origin: And for my love I pray you wrong me not.
modern: And I hope you won’t think badly of me.

origin: Yes, Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.
modern: Yes, Shylock, I’ll sign the contract and agree to its terms.

origin: Then meet me forthwith at the notary’s.
modern: Then meet me right away at the notary’s.

origin: Give him direction for this merry bond, And I will go and purse the ducats straight, See to my house left in the fearful guard Of an unthrifty knave, and presently I will be with you.
modern: Give him the instructions for our amusing little contract, and I’ll go get the money for you right away.

origin: Hie thee, gentle Jew.
modern: Hurry up, my Jewish friend.

origin: My ships come home a month before the day.
modern: My ships will come home a month before the money is due.

origin: I would not change this hue Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.
modern: I wouldn’t change it except to make you think of me, my darling queen.

origin: Even for that I thank you.
modern: Thank you for saying that.

origin: Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets To try my fortune.
modern: Show me the caskets and let me try my luck.

origin: By this scimitar That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look, Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth, Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear, Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey, To win the lady.
modern: I swear by my sword, which killed the Shah of Persia and a Persian prince and defeated the Sultan Suleiman three times, that I would face the meanest-looking warriors on earth.

origin: But, alas the while!
modern: But this is bad!

origin: Nor will not.
modern: Think about it carefully.

origin: Come, bring me unto my chance.
modern: Let me take my chances.

origin: First, forward to the temple.
modern: Let’s go to the temple first.

origin: After dinner Your hazard shall be made.
modern: You can take your chances after dinner.

origin: Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew, my master.
modern: I’m sure I’ll feel guilty if I run away from this Jew, my master.

origin: For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.” Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest man’s son”—or rather an honest woman’s son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to.
modern: Be tough,” says the devil, “and run!” But then my conscience, hanging around my heart, says very wisely to me, “My good friend Launcelot, you’re a good boy, the son of an honest man,” really, that should be the son of an honest woman, since my father cheated on my mother.

origin: He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend.
modern: Anyway, my conscience says, “Stay put.” “Go,” the devil says.

origin: Budge not,” says my conscience.
modern: Don’t go,” says my conscience.

origin: Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil.
modern: Conscience,” I say, “you give good advice.” “Devil,” I say, “you give good advice.” If I listened to my conscience, I’d stay with the Jew my master, who’s a devil.

origin: And to run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself.
modern: But if I ran away from the Jew, I’d be following the advice of the devil, who’s the very devil himself.

origin: The fiend gives the more friendly counsel.
modern: The devil’s advice is nicer.

origin: I will run, fiend.
modern: I’ll run, devil.

origin: I will run.
modern: Tell me to run, and I’ll run.

origin: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?
modern: Excuse me, young man, how do I get to the Jew’s residence?

origin: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?
modern: Young man, excuse me, how do I get to the Jew’s?

origin: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left.
modern: Turn right at the next turn, but at the following turn, turn left.

origin: Marry, at the very next turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.
modern: Oh, and then at the very next turn, don’t turn left or right, but turn down and around to the Jew’s house.

origin: By God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit.
modern: Good heavens, those are difficult directions.

origin: Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?
modern: Can you tell me if a man named Launcelot, who lives with him, is still there?

origin: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?
modern: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?

origin: No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son.
modern: He’s not a “master,” sir, he’s just a poor man’s son.

origin: His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.
modern: His father, if I do say so myself, is an honest but very poor man, and, thank God, likely to live a long time.

origin: Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.
modern: He’s just Launcelot.

origin: Shall I have the thought To think on this, and shall I lack the thought That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?
modern: Who wouldn’t get sad thinking about things like that?

origin: But tell not me.
modern: It’s obvious.

origin: Believe me, no.
modern: No, that’s not it, trust me.

origin: Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
modern: So it’s not my business that’s making me sad.

origin: Why then, you are in love.
modern: Well then, you must be in love.

origin: Not in love neither?
modern: You’re not in love either?

origin: But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?
modern: But excuse me,  Yes, I’m talking about Launcelot, sir.

origin: Ergo, Master Launcelot.
modern: Oh, no.

origin: Marry, God forbid!
modern: God forbid!

origin: The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.
modern: The boy was going to support me in my old age!

origin: Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?
modern: What am I, a cane?

origin: Do you know me, Father?
modern: Don’t you recognize me, father?

origin: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman.
modern: Heaven help me, I don’t know you, sir.

origin: But I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?
modern: But please tell me, is my boy—God rest his soul—alive or dead?

origin: Do you not know me, Father?
modern: You really don’t recognize me, father?

origin: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind.
modern: Sir, I’m half-blind.

origin: I know you not.
modern: I don’t know you.

origin: Nay, indeed if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me.
modern: Even if you had your eyes, you still might not recognize me.

origin: It is a wise father that knows his own child.
modern: It takes a wise father to know his own child.

origin: Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son.
modern: Well, old man, I’ll tell you news of your son.

origin: Give me your blessing.
modern: Give me your blessing.

origin: Pray you, sir, stand up.
modern: Please stand up!

origin: I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.
modern: I’m sure you aren’t Launcelot, my boy.

origin: Pray you, let’s have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing.
modern: Give me your blessing.

origin: I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.
modern: I’m Launcelot, who was your boy, is your son, and will be your child.

origin: I cannot think you are my son.
modern: I can’t believe you’re my son.

origin: Her name is Margery, indeed.
modern: Yes, you’re right, her name is Margery.

origin: I’ll be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood.
modern: If you’re Launcelot, then you’re my own flesh and blood.

origin: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward.
modern: Then Dobbin’s tail must be growing backward.

origin: I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.
modern: I’m sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face when I last saw him.

origin: Lord, how art thou changed!
modern: Lord, how you’ve changed!

origin: How dost thou and thy master agree?
modern: How are you and your master getting along?

origin: I have brought him a present.
modern: I’ve brought him a present.

origin: How 'gree you now?
modern: How are you?

origin: My master’s a very Jew.
modern: My master’s a total Jew.

origin: Give him a present.
modern: You’re giving him a present?

origin: Give him a halter.
modern: Give him a noose to hang himself.

origin: I am famished in his service.
modern: He’s starving me to death.

origin: You may tell every finger I have with my ribs.
modern: You can see my ribs so well you can count them.

origin: Father, I am glad you are come.
modern: I’m glad you’ve come, father.

origin: Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.
modern: Give me your present to give to Master Bassanio.

origin: Gramercy!
modern: Thank you.

origin: Wouldst thou aught with me?
modern: What do you want with me?

origin: What would you?
modern: What do you want?

origin: Serve you, sir.
modern: To work for you, sir.

origin: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.
modern: That’s what we’re trying to say, sir.

origin: I know thee well.
modern: I know who you are.

origin: Thou hast obtained thy suit.
modern: You can have what you want.

origin: Father, in.
modern: Father, go ahead.

origin: My best endeavours shall be done herein.
modern: BASSANIO Please, Leonardo, think about this  I’ll do my best.

origin: Yonder, sir, he walks.
modern: He’s walking over there, sir.

origin: Signor Bassanio!
modern: Signor Bassanio!

origin: Gratiano!
modern: Gratiano!

origin: I have a suit to you.
modern: I have a favor to ask.

origin: You have obtained it.
modern: Anything.

origin: You must not deny me.
modern: Don’t say no.

origin: I must go with you to Belmont.
modern: Let me go with you to Belmont.

origin: Why, then you must.
modern: Well, if you have to go, you have to go.

origin: But hear thee, Gratiano.
modern: But listen to me, Gratiano.

origin: Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice— Parts that become thee happily enough And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.
modern: Sometimes you get a bit too wild, and you let your voice get a bit loud and rude.

origin: Pray thee, take pain To allay with some cold drops of modesty Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior I be misconst’red in the place I go to, And lose my hopes.
modern: Please, try to act a little more serious, or the people in Belmont will get the wrong impression about me, and your wildness will make me blow my chance with Portia.

origin: Signor Bassanio, hear me.
modern: Listen, Signor Bassanio, there’s nothing to worry about.

origin: If I do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect and swear but now and then, Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely— Nay more.
modern: I’ll carry prayer books in my pocket and look sweet—even more.

origin: While grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh and say, “Amen”— Use all the observance of civility Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam, never trust me more.
modern: If I don’t do all this, never trust me again.

origin: Well, we shall see your bearing.
modern: Well, we’ll see how you act.

origin: Nay, but I bar tonight.
modern: Okay, but tonight doesn’t count.

origin: You shall not gauge me By what we do tonight.
modern: You can’t judge me based on what I do tonight.

origin: I would entreat you rather to put on Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends That purpose merriment.
modern: I’d rather see you having fun, because we have friends coming who want to have fun.

origin: But fare you well.
modern: Anyway, I have to say goodbye to you now.

origin: I have some business.
modern: I’ve got some business to take care of.

origin: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.
modern: I’m sorry you’re leaving my father like this.

origin: Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil, Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.
modern: It’s hell in our house, and you helped cheer it up, like a funny devil.

origin: And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.
modern: You’ll soon be meeting Lorenzo at supper; he’ll be a guest of your new master.

origin: Give him this letter.
modern: Give him this letter.

origin: Adieu!
modern: Goodbye.

origin: If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived.
modern: I’m sure some Christian will resort to trickery to get you.

origin: But adieu.
modern: But goodbye.

origin: These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit.
modern: It’s not manly to cry.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Farewell, good Launcelot.
modern: Goodbye, Launcelot.

origin: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me To be ashamed to be my father’s child!
modern: Oh God, what a heinous sinner I am, being ashamed to be my father’s child!

origin: But though I am a daughter to his blood, I am not to his manners.
modern: But I need to remember I’m related to him by blood, not behavior.

origin: O Lorenzo, If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife, Become a Christian and thy loving wife.
modern: Oh Lorenzo, if you keep your promise to me, I’ll end this agony by becoming a Christian and marrying you.

origin: Nay, we will slink away in supper time, Disguise us at my lodging, and return, All in an hour.
modern: No, we’ll sneak away at supper time, disguise ourselves with masks at my house, and come back in an hour.

origin: We have not made good preparation.
modern: But we haven’t made any preparations.

origin: We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.
modern: We haven’t even talked about who’ll be our torchbearers.

origin: Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered, And better in my mind not undertook.
modern: I think it’s better to call it off.

origin: Tis now but four o'clock.
modern: It’s only four o'clock now.

origin: We have two hours To furnish us.
modern: We have two hours to get ready.

origin: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?
modern: Launcelot, what’s going on?

origin: I know the hand.
modern: I recognize the handwriting.

origin: Love news, in faith?
modern: I bet it’s a love letter!

origin: Whither goest thou?
modern: Where are you going?

origin: Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.
modern: To invite my former boss, the Jew, to dine tonight with my new master, the Christian.

origin: And so will I.
modern: Me too.

origin: Meet me and Gratiano At Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.
modern: Meet me and Gratiano at his house in about an hour.

origin: Tis good we do so.
modern: It’s good we’re doing this.

origin: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?
modern: Wasn’t that letter from Jessica?

origin: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper, And other of such vinegar aspect That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
modern: Some people will laugh at anything, and others are so grouchy they won’t even crack a smile when they hear something hysterically funny.

origin: Fare ye well.
modern: Goodbye, then.

origin: Your worth is very dear in my regard.
modern: You’re both very precious to me.

origin: I take it your own business calls on you And you embrace th' occasion to depart.
modern: You need to leave to take care of your own business.

origin: Good signors both, when shall we laugh?
modern: We’re available.

origin: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you.
modern: Bassanio, we’ll say goodbye for now, since you’ve found Antonio.

origin: I will not fail you.
modern: Don’t worry, I’ll be there.

origin: I must needs tell thee all.
modern: I have to tell you everything.

origin: Who bids thee call?
modern: Who asked you to call her?

origin: I do not bid thee call.
modern: I’m not asking you to call her.

origin: Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.
modern: You always loved to tell me I couldn’t do anything without being told.

origin: Call you?
modern: Did you call me?

origin: What is your will?
modern: Do you need something?

origin: I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.
modern: I’ve been invited to supper, Jessica.

origin: There are my keys.—But wherefore should I go?
modern: Here are my keys.—But why should I go?

origin: I am not bid for love.
modern: I wasn’t invited because they like me.

origin: They flatter me.
modern: They’re just flattering me.

origin: But yet I’ll go in hate to feed upon The prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl, Look to my house.
modern: But I’ll go out of spite, to feed off the wasteful Christian.—Jessica, my girl, watch the house.

origin: I am right loath to go.
modern: I don’t feel like going.

origin: There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest, For I did dream of money bags tonight.
modern: I know because I dreamed of money bags last night.

origin: I beseech you, sir, go.
modern: Please go, sir.

origin: My young master doth expect your reproach.
modern: My new master is expecting your approach.

origin: So do I his.
modern: And I’m expecting his reproach.

origin: And they have conspired together.
modern: And they’ve been plotting things together.

origin: I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six o'clock i' th' morning falling out that year on Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.
modern: I knew there would be a masquerade when I got that bad omen of a bloody nose last Easter Monday, at six in the morning, four years after I got the same kind of bloody nose on Ash Wednesday, in the afternoon.

origin: What, are there masques?
modern: What, there’s going to be a masquerade?

origin: But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements— Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter My sober house.
modern: Don’t stick your head out into the public street to stare at the Christian fools with painted faces.

origin: By Jacob’s staff, I swear, I have no mind of feasting forth tonight.
modern: Block up my house’s ears—I mean the windows.

origin: I will go before, sir.— Mistress, look out at window, for all this.
modern: I’ll go ahead of you, sir.

origin: What says that fool of Hagar’s offspring, ha?
modern: What did that gentile fool say to you, hmmm?

origin: His words were, “Farewell, mistress.” Nothing else.
modern: He said “Goodbye, madam,” and nothing else.

origin: The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder, Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day More than the wildcat.
modern: The fool’s nice enough, but he’s such a huge eater, and slow as a snail when he works.

origin: Drones hive not with me.
modern: He sleeps all day like a cat.

origin: Well, Jessica, go in.
modern: Anyway, Jessica, go inside.

origin: Perhaps I will return immediately.
modern: I might come back soon.

origin: Do as I bid you.
modern: Do as I told you.

origin: Shut doors after you.
modern: Shut the doors after you.

origin: Fast bind, fast find.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Farewell, and if my fortune be not crost, I have a father, you a daughter, lost.
modern: If luck’s with me, I’ll lose a father, and you’ll lose a daughter.

origin: This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo Desired us to make stand.
modern: This is the roof under which Lorenzo said to meet him.

origin: His hour is almost past.
modern: He’s late.

origin: And it is marvel he outdwells his hour, For lovers ever run before the clock.
modern: Yes, and that’s surprising, because lovers are usually early.

origin: Oh, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly To seal love’s bonds new made than they are wont To keep obligèd faith unforfeited.
modern: Yes, for new lovers time passes ten times faster than for couples who’ve been married forever.

origin: That ever holds.
modern: That’s always true.

origin: Who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down?
modern: Who gets up from a meal with the same appetite he had when he sat down?

origin: Where is the horse that doth untread again His tedious measures with the unbated fire That he did pace them first?
modern: Can any horse retrace his footsteps with the same energy he had when he walked them the first time?

origin: All things that are, Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.
modern: We chase everything in life more excitedly than we actually enjoy it when we get it.

origin: Here comes Lorenzo.
modern: Here comes Lorenzo.

origin: More of this hereafter.
modern: We’ll talk about this later.

origin: Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.
modern: My dear friends, thanks for your patience.

origin: Not I but my affairs have made you wait.
modern: I had business that made me late.

origin: When you shall please to play the thieves for wives, I’ll watch as long for you then.
modern: When you have to steal your own wives some day, I’ll wait for you just as long.

origin: Approach.
modern: Come over here.

origin: Who’s within?
modern: Who’s in there?

origin: Who are you?
modern: Who are you?

origin: Tell me for more certainty, Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.
modern: Tell me so I can be sure, though I swear I recognize your voice.

origin: Lorenzo, and thy love.
modern: I’m Lorenzo, your love.

origin: Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed— For who love I so much?
modern: Lorenzo, that’s for sure, and I’m also sure you’re my love—who else do I love so much?

origin: And now who knows But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?
modern: And now who but you knows whether I’m yours?

origin: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
modern: As God is my witness, you know you’re mine.

origin: Here, catch this casket.
modern: Here, catch this box.

origin: It is worth the pains.
modern: It’ll be worth your while.

origin: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.
modern: You have to be my torchbearer for the masquerade.

origin: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?
modern: What, I have to hold a candle up so people can see what I’m doing?

origin: I will make fast the doors and gild myself With some more ducats, and be with you straight.
modern: I’ll lock up the doors, grab some more ducats, and be with you right away.

origin: Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.
modern: My God, she can’t be a Jew, she’s too nice!

origin: Beshrew me but I love her heartily.
modern: God, I’m crazy about her.

origin: For she is wise, if I can judge of her.
modern: She’s wise, if I’m judging her right.

origin: And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.
modern: She’s beautiful, if my eyes can see.

origin: And true she is, as she hath proved herself.
modern: And she’s loyal, as she has proven.

origin: And therefore, like herself—wise, fair and true— Shall she be placèd in my constant soul.
modern: And as long as she’s herself—wise, beautiful, and faithful—she’ll always have a place in my heart.

origin: What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!
modern: Ah, you’re here?—Come on, gentlemen, let’s go!

origin: Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
modern: Our masquerade mates are waiting for us.

origin: Who’s there?
modern: Who’s there?

origin: Signor Antonio?
modern: Signor Antonio?

origin: Tis nine o'clock.
modern: It’s nine o'clock!

origin: Our friends all stay for you.
modern: Our friends are all waiting for you.

origin: No masque tonight.
modern: There’s no masquerade tonight.

origin: I have sent twenty out to seek for you.
modern: I’ve sent twenty people to look for you.

origin: I am glad on ’t.
modern: I’m glad.

origin: I desire no more delight Than to be under sail and gone tonight.
modern: I want to head out tonight.

origin: The one of them contains my picture, Prince.
modern: One of them contains my picture.

origin: If you choose that, then I am yours withal.
modern: If you choose that one, I’m yours, along with the picture.

origin: Some god direct my judgment!
modern: I wish some god could help me choose!

origin: Let me see.
modern: Let me see.

origin: I will survey th' inscriptions back again.
modern: I’ll look over the inscriptions again.

origin: What says this leaden casket?
modern: What does the lead box say?

origin: Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.” Must give—for what?
modern: He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” Must give everything—for what?

origin: For lead?
modern: For lead?

origin: Hazard for lead?
modern: Risk everything for lead?

origin: This casket threatens.
modern: This box is too threatening.

origin: Men that hazard all Do it in hope of fair advantages.
modern: Men who risk everything hope to make profits.

origin: A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross.
modern: A golden mind doesn’t bend down to choose something worthless.

origin: I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.
modern: So I won’t give or risk anything for lead.

origin: What says the silver with her virgin hue?
modern: What does the silver one say?

origin: Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.” “As much as he deserves!”—pause there, Morocco, And weigh thy value with an even hand.
modern: He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves.” As much as he deserves—wait a minute there, Morocco, and consider your own value with a level head.

origin: What if I strayed no further, but chose here?
modern: What if I went no further and chose this one?

origin: Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold, “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.” Why, that’s the lady.
modern: But let’s see once more what the gold one says: “He who chooses me will get what many men want.” That’s Portia!

origin: All the world desires her.
modern: The whole world wants her.

origin: From the four corners of the earth they come To kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.
modern: They come from the four corners of the earth to kiss this shrine and see this living, breathing saint.

origin: The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now For princes to come view fair Portia.
modern: Princes travel across deserts and the vast wilderness of Arabia to come see the beautiful Portia.

origin: The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar To stop the foreign spirits, but they come As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.
modern: The wide ocean doesn’t prevent them from coming to see her—they travel across it as if it were a little stream.

origin: One of these three contains her heavenly picture.
modern: One of these three boxes contains her lovely picture.

origin: Is ’t like that lead contains her?
modern: Could the lead one contain it?

origin: Twere damnation To think so base a thought.
modern: No, it’d be a sin to think such a low thought.

origin: It were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.
modern: Lead’s too crass to hold her.

origin: Or shall I think in silver she’s immured, Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?
modern: Is she enclosed in silver, which is ten times less valuable than gold?

origin: O sinful thought!
modern: Oh, what a sinful thought!

origin: Never so rich a gem Was set in worse than gold.
modern: Nobody ever set a gem like her in a worse setting than gold.

origin: They have in England A coin that bears the figure of an angel Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.
modern: They have a coin in England stamped with the figure of an angel, but that’s just engraved on the surface.

origin: You look not well, Signor Antonio.
modern: You don’t look well, Antonio.

origin: You have too much respect upon the world.
modern: People with too much invested in the world always get hurt.

origin: And let my liver rather heat with wine Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.
modern: I’d rather overload my liver with wine than starve my heart by denying myself fun.

origin: I’ll tell thee more of this another time.
modern: I’ll talk to you more about this some other time.

origin: But fish not with this melancholy bait For this fool gudgeon, this opinion.— Come, good Lorenzo.—Fare ye well awhile.
modern: I’m a fool.—Let’s go, Lorenzo.—Goodbye for now.

origin: I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.
modern: I’ll finish my lecture after dinner.

origin: Lies all within.—Deliver me the key.
modern: Here an angel’s lying in a golden bed.—Give me the key.

origin: Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!
modern: I will choose this one and try my chances.

origin: There, take it, Prince.
modern: Damn it!

origin: O hell, what have we here?
modern: What’s this?

origin: A carrion death, within whose empty eye There is a written scroll.
modern: It’s a skull with a scroll in its empty eye socket.

origin: I’ll read the writing.
modern: I’ll read it aloud.

origin: All that glisters is not gold— Often have you heard that told.
modern: All that glitters is not gold— You’ve often heard that said.

origin: Many a man his life hath sold But my outside to behold.
modern: Many men have sold their souls Just to view my shiny surface.

origin: Gilded tombs do worms enfold.
modern: But gilded tombs contain worms.

origin: Had you been as wise as bold, Young in limbs, in judgment old, Your answer had not been inscrolled.
modern: If you’d been as wise as you were bold, With an old man’s mature judgment, You wouldn’t have had to read this scroll.

origin: Portia, adieu.
modern: Portia, goodbye to you.

origin: I have too grieved a heart To take a tedious leave.
modern: My heart’s too sad for long goodbyes.

origin: Thus losers part.
modern: Losers always leave quickly.

origin: A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.— Let all of his complexion choose me so.
modern: Good riddance!—Close the curtains and leave.—I hope everyone who looks like him will make the same choice.

origin: Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.
modern: I saw Bassanio sail away, and Gratiano went with him.

origin: With him is Gratiano gone along.
modern: I’m sure Lorenzo isn’t on their ship.

origin: And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.
modern: That wicked Jew got the duke to listen to his complaints.

origin: The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke, Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
modern: The duke went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.

origin: He came too late.
modern: He got there too late.

origin: The ship was under sail.
modern: The ship was already sailing.

origin: But there the Duke was given to understand That in a gondola were seen together Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.
modern: But once he got there, the duke learned that Lorenzo and his lover Jessica were together in a gondola.

origin: Besides, Antonio certified the Duke They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
modern: In any case, Antonio assured the duke they weren’t with Bassanio on his ship.

origin: I never heard a passion so confused, So strange, outrageous, and so variable, As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.
modern: I’ve never heard such confused emotions as what that Jew dog was shouting in the streets.

origin: O my daughter, Fled with a Christian!
modern: Ran off with a Christian!

origin: O my Christian ducats!
modern: Oh my Christian ducats!

origin: Justice, find the girl!
modern: Justice, find the girl!

origin: She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.” Why, all the boys in Venice follow him, Crying, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”
modern: She has the stones on her, and the ducats.” I know, all the boys in Venice are following him, yelling, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”

origin: Let good Antonio look he keep his day, Or he shall pay for this.
modern: I hope Antonio repays his loan on time, or he’ll suffer for this.

origin: Marry, well remembered.
modern: That’s a good point.

origin: I reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday, Who told me, in the narrow seas that part The French and English, there miscarried A vessel of our country richly fraught.
modern: I spoke with a Frenchman yesterday who said that a Venetian ship loaded with treasure was wrecked in the English Channel.

origin: You were best to tell Antonio what you hear— Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.
modern: You should tell Antonio what you hear—but don’t do it suddenly, because it might upset him.

origin: I saw Bassanio and Antonio part.
modern: I saw Bassanio and Antonio say goodbye.

origin: Bassanio told him he would make some speed Of his return.
modern: Bassanio told him he’d try to hurry back.

origin: And for the Jew’s bond which he hath of me, Let it not enter in your mind of love.
modern: As for the Jew’s contract, don’t let it be a factor in your plans.

origin: And so they parted.
modern: Then he shook Bassanio’s hand affectionately—and they separated.

origin: I think he only loves the world for him.
modern: I think he only loves life because of Bassanio.

origin: I pray thee, let us go and find him out And quicken his embracèd heaviness With some delight or other.
modern: Let’s go find him and cheer him up.

origin: Do we so.
modern: Yes, let’s do that.

origin: Draw the curtain straight.
modern: Hurry, hurry, close the curtain quick.

origin: The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath And comes to his election presently.
modern: The prince of Arragon has taken his oath, and he’s coming to make his choice now.

origin: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince.
modern: Look, here are the boxes, prince.

origin: If you choose that wherein I am contained, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.
modern: If you choose the one that contains my picture, we’ll be married right away.

origin: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord, You must be gone from hence immediately.
modern: But if you fail, you have to leave immediately.

origin: To these injunctions every one doth swear That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
modern: Everyone who comes to gamble on winning me has to swear to these three rules.

origin: And so have I addressed me.
modern: Okay, I’m ready.

origin: Fortune now To my heart’s hope!
modern: I hope luck will give me what my heart hopes for!

origin: Gold, silver, and base lead.
modern: Gold, silver, and common lead.

origin: Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.” You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.
modern: He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” You’d have to be more attractive for me to give or risk anything for you.

origin: What says the golden chest?
modern: What does the golden box say?

origin: Ha, let me see.
modern: Hmm, let me see:

origin: So, with two seeming bodies but one heart, Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, Due but to one and crownèd with one crest.
modern: We seemed to have two separate bodies, but we had one heart.

origin: And will you rent our ancient love asunder To join with men in scorning your poor friend?
modern: Do you want to destroy our old friendship by joining these men to insult your poor friend?

origin: It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.
modern: It’s not friendly, and it’s not ladylike.

origin: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it, Though I alone do feel the injury.
modern: All women would be angry with you for doing it, even though I’m the only one who’s hurt by it.

origin: I scorn you not.
modern: I’m not insulting you.

origin: It seems that you scorn me.
modern: It sounds more like you’re insulting me.

origin: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face?
modern: Didn’t you send Lysander, as an insult, to follow me around praising my eyes and my face?

origin: And made your other love, Demetrius— Who even but now did spurn me with his foot— To call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare, Precious, celestial?
modern: Haven’t you made your other love, Demetrius—who kicked me with his foot not long ago—call me a goddess and a divine, rare, precious, heavenly creature?

origin: Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates?
modern: Why does he talk like that to a girl he can’t stand?

origin: And wherefore doth Lysander Deny your love, so rich within his soul, And tender me, forsooth, affection, But by your setting on, by your consent?
modern: And why does Lysander deny that he loves you, when he loves you so deeply?

origin: What though I be not so in grace as you— So hung upon with love, so fortunate— But miserable most, to love unloved?
modern: Why does it matter that I’m not as lucky or lovable as you are and that the love I feel is unrequited?

origin: This you should pity rather than despise.
modern: You should pity me for that reason, not hate me.

origin: I understand not what you mean by this.
modern: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

origin: Ay, do.
modern: Oh, fine.

origin: Persever, counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when I turn my back, Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up— This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.
modern: All right, go ahead, keep up your little game, pretend to be sympathetic, but then nudge each other and wink and make faces at me when I turn my back.

origin: If you have any pity, grace, or manners, You would not make me such an argument.
modern: If you had any sense of pity, or manners, you wouldn’t pretend to fight over me like this.

origin: But fare ye well.
modern: But goodbye.

origin: Tis partly my own fault, Which death or absence soon shall remedy.
modern: It’s partly my own fault, since I followed you here.

origin: Stay, gentle Helena.
modern: Stay, lovely Helena.

origin: Hear my excuse.
modern: Listen to my excuse.

origin: My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!
modern: My love, my life, my soul, beautiful Helena!

origin: Oh, excellent!
modern: That’s a good one.

origin: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat.
modern: You can’t force me any more than Hermia can beg me.

origin: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.— Helen, I love thee.
modern: Your threats are no stronger than her whining.—Helena, I love you.

origin: By my life, I do.
modern: I swear I do.

origin: I swear by that which I will lose for thee To prove him false that says I love thee not.
modern: I’ll give my life for you, just to prove this guy wrong when he says I don’t love you.

origin: I say I love thee more than he can do.
modern: I say that I love you more than he does.

origin: If thou say so, withdraw and prove it too.
modern: If that’s what you say, go fight a duel with me and prove it.

origin: Lysander, whereto tends all this?
modern: Lysander, where are you going with all this?

origin: Why are you grown so rude?
modern: Why have you gotten so rude?

origin: Thy love?
modern: Your darling?

origin: Out, tawny Tartar, out!
modern: Get out, you dark-skinned gypsy!

origin: Out, loathèd medicine!
modern: Get out, you horrible poison.

origin: O hated potion, hence!
modern: Get out!

origin: Do you not jest?
modern: Are you joking?

origin: Yes, sooth, and so do you.
modern: Of course he is, and so are you.

origin: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.
modern: Demetrius, I’m ready to fight you as promised.

origin: I would I had your bond, for I perceive A weak bond holds you.
modern: I wish we had a signed legal contract.

origin: I’ll not trust your word.
modern: I don’t trust you.

origin: Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.
modern: Sure, I hate her, but I wouldn’t hurt her.

origin: Ay, by my life, And never did desire to see thee more.
modern: I certainly did, and I never wanted to see you again.

origin: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt.
modern: So stop hoping and wondering what I mean.

origin: Be certain, nothing truer.
modern: I’ve spelled it out for you clearly.

origin: O me!
modern: Oh, no!

origin: Fine, i' faith!
modern: Oh, that’s very nice!

origin: Have you no modesty, no maiden shame, No touch of bashfulness?
modern: You ought to be ashamed of yourself!

origin: Puppet”?
modern: Puppet”?

origin: Why so?—Ay, that way goes the game.
modern: Why “puppet”?—Oh, I see where this is going.

origin: How low am I, thou painted maypole?
modern: So how short am I, you painted barber pole?

origin: Speak.
modern: Tell me.

origin: How low am I?
modern: How short am I?

origin: Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.
modern: Good Hermia, please don’t act so bitter toward me.

origin: He followed you.
modern: He followed you.

origin: For love I followed him.
modern: And I followed him because I loved him.

origin: But he hath chid me hence and threatened me To strike me, spurn me—nay, to kill me too.
modern: But he told me to get lost and threatened to hit me, kick me—even kill me.

origin: Let me go.
modern: Please let me go.

origin: You see how simple and how fond I am.
modern: You see how naïve and foolish I’ve been.

origin: Why, get you gone!
modern: Well, get out of here then!

origin: Who is ’t that hinders you?
modern: What’s keeping you?

origin: A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.
modern: My stupid heart, which I’m leaving behind here.

origin: What, with Lysander?
modern: What, you’re leaving it with Lysander?

origin: With Demetrius.
modern: No, with Demetrius.

origin: Be not afraid.
modern: Don’t be afraid.

origin: She shall not harm thee, Helena.
modern: She can’t hurt you, Helena.

origin: She was a vixen when she went to school.
modern: She was a hellcat in school.

origin: And though she be but little, she is fierce.
modern: And she’s fierce, even though she’s little.

origin: Little” again?
modern: Little” again?

origin: Nothing but “low” and “little”!— Why will you suffer her to flout me thus?
modern: Nothing but “little” and “short”!— Why are you letting her insult me like this?

origin: Let me come to her.
modern: Let me at her!.

origin: What cheer, my love?— Demetrius and Egeus, go along.
modern: How are you, my love?—Demetrius and Egeus, come with us.

origin: I must employ you in some business Against our nuptial and confer with you Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
modern: I want you to do some things for our wedding, and I also want to discuss something that concerns you both.

origin: With duty and desire we follow you.
modern: We’re following you not only because it is our duty, but also because we want to.

origin: How now, my love?
modern: What’s going on, my love?

origin: Why is your cheek so pale?
modern: Why are you so pale?

origin: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?
modern: Why have your rosy cheeks faded so quickly?

origin: Belike for want of rain, which I could well Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
modern: Probably because my cheeks' roses needed rain, which I could easily give them with all the tears in my eyes.

origin: Ay me!
modern: Oh, honey!

origin: For aught that I could ever read, Could ever hear by tale or history, The course of true love never did run smooth.
modern: Listen, in books they say that true love always faces obstacles.

origin: But either it was different in blood—
modern: Either the lovers have different social standings—

origin: Let her alone.
modern: Leave Hermia alone.

origin: Speak not of Helena.
modern: Don’t talk about Helena.

origin: Take not her part.
modern: Don’t take Helena’s side.

origin: For if thou dost intend Never so little show of love to her, Thou shalt aby it.
modern: If you continue treating Hermia so badly, you’ll pay for it.

origin: Now she holds me not.
modern: Hermia’s not holding onto me anymore.

origin: Now follow, if thou darest, to try whose right, Of thine or mine, is most in Helena.
modern: Follow me if you’re brave enough, and we’ll fight over Helena.

origin: Follow”?
modern: Follow”?

origin: Nay, I’ll go with thee, cheek by jowl.
modern: No, I’ll walk right next to you, side by side.

origin: You, mistress, all this coil is long of you.
modern: All this fighting is because of you.

origin: Nay, go not back.
modern: Stay where you are.

origin: I am amazed and know not what to say.
modern: I don’t know what to say.

origin: Believe me, King of Shadows, I mistook.
modern: Believe me, King of Illusions, I made a mistake.

origin: Did not you tell me I should know the man By the Athenian garment he had on?
modern: Didn’t you tell me that I’d be able to recognize the man by the Athenian clothes he was wearing?

origin: And so far blameless proves my enterprise, That I have 'nointed an Athenian’s eyes.
modern: So far I’ve done exactly what I was supposed to do—I put the love potion on an Athenian’s eyes.

origin: And so far am I glad it so did sort, As this their jangling I esteem a sport.
modern: And so far I’m pleased with the way things have turned out, since I find all of this commotion very entertaining.

origin: Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight.
modern: As you can see, these lovers are looking for a place to fight.

origin: Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night.
modern: Hurry up, Robin, and make the night dark and cloudy.

origin: The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another’s way.
modern: Cover the sky with a low-hanging fog, as dark as hell, and get these overeager rivals so completely lost in the woods that they can’t run into each other.

origin: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.
modern: We’ve got to act fast, my lord of the fairies.

origin: But we are spirits of another sort.
modern: I like the morning.

origin: I with the morning’s love have oft made sport, And like a forester the groves may tread Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red, Opening on Neptune with fair blessèd beams, Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams.
modern: I often wander around in the woods like a forest ranger until the sun rises in the fiery red sky over the ocean, turning the salty green water to gold.

origin: But notwithstanding, haste.
modern: But you should hurry anyway.

origin: Make no delay.
modern: Don’t delay.

origin: We may effect this business yet ere day.
modern: We still have time to get all of this done before daybreak.

origin: Up and down, up and down,  I will lead them up and down.
modern: Up and down, up and down, I will lead them up and down.

origin: I am feared in field and town.
modern: The people fear me in the country and the town.

origin: Goblin, lead them up and down.
modern: Goblin, lead them up and down.

origin: Here comes one.
modern: Here comes one of them now.

origin: Where art thou, proud Demetrius?
modern: Where are you, Demetrius, you arrogant bastard?

origin: Speak thou now.
modern: Say something.

origin: Lysander, speak again!
modern: Lysander, say something!

origin: Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?
modern: You coward, did you run away from me?

origin: Speak!
modern: Say something!

origin: In some bush?
modern: Are you behind some bush?

origin: Where dost thou hide thy head?
modern: Where are you hiding?

origin: Yea, art thou there?
modern: Are you there?

origin: He goes before me and still dares me on.
modern: He’s walking ahead of me, and he keeps daring me to follow him.

origin: When I come where he calls, then he is gone.
modern: When I reach the place he’s calling from, he disappears.

origin: The villain is much lighter-heeled than I. I followed fast, but faster he did fly, That fallen am I in dark uneven way,
modern: This villain is much quicker than I am.

origin: And here will rest me.
modern: I’ll rest here.

origin: Where art thou now?
modern: Where are you now?

origin: Nay, then, thou mock’st me.
modern: No, you’re just taunting me.

origin: Thou shalt buy this dear If ever I thy face by daylight see.
modern: You’ll pay for this if I ever see you face-to-face in the daylight.

origin: Now go thy way.
modern: Go wherever you want.

origin: O weary night, O long and tedious night, Abate thy hours.
modern: Oh, what a long, tedious, exhausting night!

origin: Yet but three?
modern: Only three so far?

origin: Come one more.
modern: We’re still waiting for one more.

origin: Two of both kinds make up four.
modern: Two of both kinds makes four.

origin: Here she comes, cursed and sad.
modern: Ah, here she comes, angry and sad.

origin: Cupid is a knavish lad  Thus to make poor females mad.
modern: Cupid is a bad boy for making poor women go crazy like this.

origin: Here will I rest me till the break of day.
modern: I’ll sleep here until morning.

origin: Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!
modern: If they do fight, I hope Lysander is safe!

origin: On the ground  Sleep sound.
modern: Sleep well there on the ground.

origin: Where’s Peaseblossom?
modern: Where’s Peaseblossom?

origin: Ready.
modern: Here.

origin: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.
modern: Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.

origin: Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?
modern: Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?

origin: Ready.
modern: Here.

origin: Do not fret yourself too much in the action, monsieur.
modern: Don’t tire yourself out, monsieur.

origin: And good monsieur, have a care the honey bag break not.
modern: Oh, and monsieur, be careful not to break the honey-sac.

origin: I would be loath to have you overflown with a honey bag, signor.
modern: I’d hate to see you drowned in honey, sir.

origin: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?
modern: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?

origin: Ready.
modern: Here.

origin: Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed.
modern: Give me your first, Mr. Mustardseed.

origin: Pray you, leave your courtesy, good monsieur.
modern: Please, stop bowing, good sir.

origin: What’s your will?
modern: What would you like me to do?

origin: Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch.
modern: Nothing, good sir, except to help Sir Cobweb scratch my head.

origin: I must to the barber’s, monsieur, for methinks I am marvelous hairy about the face.
modern: I should go to the barber’s, monsieur, because I think I’m getting really hairy around the face.

origin: And I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.
modern: And I’m such a sensitive ass that if my hair even tickles me a little, I need to scratch.

origin: What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?
modern: Would you like to hear some music, my sweet love?

origin: I have a reasonable good ear in music.
modern: I have a pretty good ear for music.

origin: Let’s have the tongs and the bones.
modern: Let’s hear someone play the triangle and the sticks.

origin: Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.
modern: Or tell me, my sweet love, what you’d like to eat.

origin: Truly, a peck of provender.
modern: Actually, I’d like a few pounds of grass.

origin: I could munch your good dry oats.
modern: I’d like to munch on some good dry oats.

origin: Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay.
modern: Or maybe I’ve got a hankering for a bundle of hay.

origin: Good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.
modern: There’s nothing like good hay, really sweet hay.

origin: I have a venturous fairy that shall seek The squirrel’s hoard and fetch thee new nuts.
modern: I have an adventurous fairy who’ll go seek out the squirrel’s secret stash and get you some fresh nuts.

origin: I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas.
modern: I’d rather have a handful or two of dried peas.

origin: But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me.
modern: But please don’t let any of your people wake me up.

origin: I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
modern: I really want to sleep now.

origin: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.
modern: Go to sleep, and I will wrap my arms around you.

origin: Oh, how I love thee!
modern: Oh, how I love you!

origin: How I dote on thee!
modern: I’m so crazy about you!

origin: Welcome, good Robin.
modern: Welcome, good Robin.

origin: Seest thou this sweet sight?
modern: Do you see this sweet sight?

origin: Her dotage now I do begin to pity.
modern: Now I’m starting to pity Titania for being so infatuated.

origin: For, meeting her of late behind the wood, Seeking sweet favors from this hateful fool, I did upbraid her and fall out with her.
modern: I ran into her recently at the edge of the forest, looking for sweet presents for this hateful idiot, and I scolded her and argued with her.

origin: For she his hairy temples then had rounded With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers, And that same dew, which sometime on the buds Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.
modern: She had put a wreath of fresh, fragrant flowers around his hairy forehead, and the drops of dew that lay in the center of the flowers made the flowers look like they were crying with shame to be decorating the head of that ugly jackass.

origin: And now I have the boy, I will undo This hateful imperfection of her eyes.
modern: And now that I have the boy, I’ll undo the spell that makes her vision so disgustingly wrong.

origin: And, gentle Puck, take this transformèd scalp From off the head of this Athenian swain, That, he awaking when the other do, May all to Athens back again repair And think no more of this night’s accidents But as the fierce vexation of a dream.
modern: And, gentle Puck, take this transformed ass’s head off of the head of that Athenian man, so that when he wakes up at the same time as the rest of them do, they can all go back to Athens.

origin: But first I will release the fairy queen.
modern: But first I’ll release the fairy queen from the spell.

origin: Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.
modern: Now, Titania, wake up, my sweet queen.

origin: There lies your love.
modern: There’s your boyfriend, sleeping right over there.

origin: How came these things to pass?
modern: How did this happen?

origin: Oh, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!
modern: Oh, I hate looking at his face now!

origin: Silence awhile.—Robin, take off this head.— Titania, music call, and strike more dead Than common sleep of all these five the sense.
modern: Be quiet for a while.—Robin, take off his donkey head.—Titania, get the fairies to play some music, and make these five people sleep more soundly than humans have ever slept before.

origin: Music, ho!
modern: Music!

origin: Music such as charmeth sleep!
modern: Play the kind of music that puts people to sleep.

origin: Sound, music!—Come, my queen, take hands with me, And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.
modern: Play the music.—Take my hands, my queen, and we’ll lull these people to sleep with our soft dancing.

origin: Too old to be engaged to young.
modern: Being too old to marry someone young.

origin: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends— O hell, to choose love by another’s eyes!
modern: Or else their guardians and advisors said no— What hell, to have your love life determined by someone else!

origin: So quick bright things come to confusion.
modern: That’s how intense things like love are quickly destroyed.

origin: If then true lovers have been ever crossed, It stands as an edict in destiny.
modern: If true lovers are always thwarted, then it must be a rule of fate.

origin: A good persuasion.
modern: That’s the right attitude.

origin: Therefore, hear me, Hermia.
modern: So, listen, Hermia.

origin: I have a widow aunt, a dowager Of great revenue, and she hath no child.
modern: I have an aunt who is a widow, who’s very rich and doesn’t have any children.

origin: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues, And she respects me as her only son.
modern: She lives about twenty miles from Athens, and she thinks of me as a son.

origin: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee.
modern: I could marry you there, gentle Hermia, where the strict laws of Athens can’t touch us.

origin: And to that place the sharp Athenian law Cannot pursue us.
modern: So here’s the plan.

origin: Fairy King, attend, and mark.
modern: Listen, Fairy King.

origin: I do hear the morning lark.
modern: I can hear the lark singing.

origin: Then, my queen, in silence sad, Trip we after the night’s shade.
modern: Morning’s here.

origin: Come, my lord, and in our flight Tell me how it came this night That I sleeping here was found With these mortals on the ground.
modern: While we’re walking, you can tell me how I ended up sleeping on the ground with these humans last night.

origin: Go, one of you, find out the forester.
modern: One of you go find the forest ranger.

origin: Uncouple in the western valley.
modern: Unleash the dogs in the western valley.

origin: Let them go.
modern: Let them go.

origin: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
modern: Now go find the forest ranger.

origin: We will, fair queen, up to the mountain’s top, And mark the musical confusion Of hounds and echo in conjunction.
modern: My beautiful queen, we’ll go up the mountain and listen to the hounds as their barking echoes in the cliffs and sounds like music.

origin: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear With hounds of Sparta.
modern: I was with the heroes Hercules and Cadmus once, when their Spartan hunting dogs cornered a bear.

origin: The skies, the fountains, every region near Seemed all one mutual cry.
modern: The forests, the skies, the mountains, everything around us seemed to echo the barks of the hounds.

origin: I never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
modern: I’d never heard such raucous music, such pleasant thunder.

origin: I wonder of their being here together.
modern: I don’t understand why they’re all here together.

origin: But speak, Egeus.
modern: But tell me, Egeus.

origin: Is not this the day That Hermia should give answer of her choice?
modern: Isn’t today the day when Hermia has to tell us her decision about whether she’ll marry Demetrius?

origin: It is, my lord.
modern: It is, my lord.

origin: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.
modern: Go tell the hunters to blow their horns and wake them up.

origin: Good morrow, friends.
modern: Good morning, my friends.

origin: Saint Valentine is past.
modern: Valentine’s Day is over.

origin: Begin these woodbirds but to couple now?
modern: Are you lovebirds only starting to pair up now?

origin: Pardon, my lord.
modern: Forgive us, my lord.

origin: I pray you all, stand up.
modern: Please, all of you, stand up.

origin: My lord, I shall reply amazèdly, Half sleep, half waking.
modern: My lord, what I say may be a little confused, since I’m half asleep and half awake.

origin: But as yet, I swear, I cannot truly say how I came here.
modern: I swear, at the moment I really couldn’t tell you how I ended up here.

origin: But as I think—for truly would I speak, And now do I bethink me, so it is— I came with Hermia hither.
modern: But I think—I want to tell you the truth, and now that I think about it, I think this is true—I came here with Hermia.

origin: And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, The object and the pleasure of mine eye, Is only Helena.
modern: Now the only person I love, and believe in, and want to look at, is Helena.

origin: To her, my lord, Was I betrothed ere I saw Hermia.
modern: I was engaged to her before I ever met Hermia.

origin: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met.
modern: You pretty lovers are lucky you met me here.

origin: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.— Egeus, I will overbear your will.
modern: We’ll talk more about this later.—Egeus, I’m overriding your wishes.

origin: Away with us to Athens.
modern: Come with us to Athens.

origin: Three and three, We’ll hold a feast in great solemnity.
modern: We three couples will celebrate with a sumptuous feast.

origin: Are you sure That we are awake?
modern: Are you sure we’re awake?

origin: It seems to me That yet we sleep, we dream.
modern: It seems to me like we’re still sleeping, still dreaming.

origin: And he did bid us follow to the temple.
modern: And he told us to follow him to the temple.

origin: Why then, we are awake.
modern: Well, then, we’re awake.

origin: It shall be called “Bottom’s Dream” because it hath no bottom.
modern: I’ll call it “Bottom’s Dream” because it’s so deep that it has no bottom.

origin: And I will sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke.
modern: And I’ll sing it for the duke in the intermission of a play.

origin: Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.
modern: Or maybe, to make it even more lovely, I’ll sing it when the heroine dies.

origin: Have you sent to Bottom’s house?
modern: Have you sent anyone to Bottom’s house?

origin: Is he come home yet?
modern: Has he come home yet?

origin: He cannot be heard of.
modern: No one’s heard from him.

origin: Out of doubt he is transported.
modern: I’m sure he’s been kidnapped.

origin: If he come not, then the play is marred.
modern: If he doesn’t show up, the play is ruined.

origin: It goes not forward.
modern: It won’t go on.

origin: Doth it?
modern: Will it?

origin: It is not possible.
modern: No, it would be impossible.

origin: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in Athens.
modern: He’s quite simply the smartest working-man in Athens.

origin: Yea, and the best person too.
modern: Yes, and the best looking too.

origin: And he is a very paramour for a sweet voice.
modern: And his voice is the paramour of sweetness.

origin: You must say “paragon.” A “paramour” is, God bless us, a thing of naught.
modern: You mean “paragon.” A  The duke’s leaving the temple.

origin: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married.
modern: Two or three more lords and ladies have been married too.

origin: If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.
modern: If we’d been able to put on our play, we would have had it made.

origin: O sweet bully Bottom!
modern: Oh that great, funny guy, Bottom!

origin: Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life.
modern: He would have gotten a pension of six pence a day for his whole life.

origin: He could not have ’scaped sixpence a day.
modern: Six pence a day would’ve been forced on him.

origin: An the duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I’ll be hanged.
modern: I’ll be damned if the duke wouldn’t have given him six pence a day for playing Pyramus.

origin: He would have deserved it.
modern: And he would have deserved it too.

origin: Where are these hearts?
modern: Where are my good fellows?

origin: Bottom!
modern: Bottom!

origin: O most courageous day!
modern: Oh, how wonderful to see you!

origin: O most happy hour!
modern: Oh, what a relief!

origin: I will tell you everything, right as it fell out.
modern: I’ll tell you everything exactly as it happened.

origin: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.
modern: Tell us, Bottom.

origin: Not a word of me.
modern: No, you won’t get a word out of me.

origin: All that I will tell you is that the duke hath dined.
modern: All I’ll tell you is that the duke has had dinner already.

origin: Get your apparel together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your pumps.
modern: Now it’s time to get your costumes together.

origin: Meet presently at the palace.
modern: Meet me at the palace as soon as possible.

origin: Every man look o'er his part.
modern: Look over your lines again.

origin: And most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath.
modern: And no one eat any onions or garlic.

origin: And I do not doubt but to hear them say, “It is a sweet comedy.” No more words.
modern: If we have sweet-smelling breath, I’m sure they’ll say “it’s a sweet play.” Now no more talking.

origin: Away, go away!
modern: Get busy, go!

origin: Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.
modern: These lovers are saying some strange things, Theseus.

origin: I never may believe These antique fables nor these fairy toys.
modern: I’ll never believe any of these old legends or fairy tales.

origin: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet Are of imagination all compact.
modern: Lunatics, lovers, and poets all are ruled by their overactive imaginations.

origin: But all the story of the night told over, And all their minds transfigured so together, More witnesseth than fancy’s images And grows to something of great constancy, But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
modern: Their story is bizarre and astounding, but it’s solid and consistent.

origin: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.— Joy, gentle friends!
modern: Here come the lovers, laughing happily.—I wish you joy, my friends!

origin: Come now, what masques, what dances shall we have To wear away this long age of three hours Between our after-supper and bedtime?
modern: Now, what kind of entertainment do we have to fill up the long three hours between dinner and bedtime?

origin: Where is our usual manager of mirth?
modern: Where is our entertainment director?

origin: What revels are in hand?
modern: What performances have been prepared?

origin: Call Philostrate.
modern: Let me see Philostrate.

origin: Here, mighty Theseus.
modern: Here I am, Theseus.

origin: What masque, what music?
modern: Which plays, what music?

origin: How shall we beguile The lazy time if not with some delight?
modern: How will we pass the time without some entertainment?

origin: Keep promise, love.
modern: Keep your promise, my love.

origin: Look, here comes Helena.
modern: Look, here comes Helena.

origin: Godspeed, fair Helena!
modern: Hello, beautiful Helena!

origin: Whither away?
modern: Where are you going?

origin: Call you me “fair”?
modern: Did you just call me “beautiful”?

origin: That “fair” again unsay.
modern: Take it back.

origin: Demetrius loves your fair.
modern: You’re the beautiful one as far as Demetrius is concerned.

origin: O happy fair!
modern: Oh, you’re so lucky!

origin: Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.
modern: Your eyes are like stars, and your voice is more musical than a lark’s song is to a shepherd in the springtime.

origin: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated, The rest I’d give to be to you translated.
modern: If the world were mine, I’d give it all up—everything except Demetrius—to be you.

origin: The thrice three Muses mourning for the death  Of learning, late deceased in beggary.” That is some satire, keen and critical, Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.
modern: The nine Muses mourning the death of learning and scholarship.” That’s some sharp, critical satire, and it’s not appropriate for a wedding.

origin: Tedious” and “brief”?
modern: Short but still tedious?

origin: That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow.
modern: That’s like hot ice and strange snow.

origin: How shall we find the concord of this discord?
modern: How can this drama be so many contradictory things?

origin: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play.
modern: It’s a play about ten words long, which is the shortest play I’ve ever heard of.

origin: For in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted.
modern: In the entire play, not one word is well-written, and not one of the actors is right for his part.

origin: For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
modern: It’s tragic because Pyramus kills himself.

origin: Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess, Made mine eyes water—but more merry tears The passion of loud laughter never shed.
modern: I have to admit that when I saw his suicide during rehearsal, I had tears in my eyes—but they were tears of laughter.

origin: What are they that do play it?
modern: Who are the actors?

origin: And we will hear it.
modern: So let’s see it.

origin: No, my noble lord.
modern: No, my noble lord.

origin: It is not for you.
modern: This play isn’t right for you.

origin: I have heard it over, And it is nothing, nothing in the world— Unless you can find sport in their intents, Extremely stretched and conned with cru 'l pain To do you service.
modern: I’ve seen the whole thing, and it’s completely worthless—unless you think their bad acting and their misremembered lines—which they memorized so painfully—are funny.

origin: I will hear that play.
modern: I’ll watch this play.

origin: Go, bring them in.—And take your places, ladies.
modern: Come on, bring them in.

origin: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.
modern: You won’t see anything like that, sweetheart.

origin: He says they can do nothing in this kind.
modern: He just said that they’re no good at acting.

origin: Where I have come, great clerks have purposèd To greet me with premeditated welcomes, Where I have seen them shiver and look pale, Make periods in the midst of sentences, Throttle their practiced accent in their fears, And in conclusion dumbly have broke off, Not paying me a welcome.
modern: In my travels, great scholars have come up to me, meaning to greet me with well-rehearsed welcoming speeches, and I have seen them tremble and turn pale, and pause inappropriately in the middle of their sentences, and botch their well-rehearsed tones of voice because they’re so nervous, and then break off abruptly at the end, without actually welcoming me.

origin: Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity In least speak most, to my capacity.
modern: Therefore, love and tongue-tied simplicity can say the most even when they’re saying the least, in my opinion.

origin: So please your grace, the Prologue is addressed.
modern: Your grace, the person who is going to deliver the prologue is ready.

origin: Let him approach.
modern: Let him come forward.

origin: If we offend, it is with our good will.
modern: If we happen to offend you, it’s because we want to.

origin: That you should think we come not to offend, But with good will.
modern: We don’t want you to think we came here to offend you, except that we want to offend you with our good intentions.

origin: Consider then we come but in despite.
modern: Please keep in mind we’re only here out of spite.

origin: We do not come as minding to contest you, Our true intent is.
modern: We don’t come here with the intention of making you happy.

origin: All for your delight We are not here.
modern: We’re absolutely not here to delight you.

origin: That you should here repent you, The actors are at hand, and by their show You shall know all that you are like to know.
modern: By watching their show, you’ll find out everything you’re likely to know.

origin: This fellow doth not stand upon points.
modern: This guy doesn’t pay much attention to punctuation.

origin: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt.
