modern: He rode that prologue like a wild horse.

origin: He knows not the stop.
modern: He didn’t know how to stop it.

origin: A good moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but to speak true.
modern: The moral of this story is that it’s not enough to speak; you have to speak grammatically.

origin: His speech was like a tangled chain.
modern: His speech was like a tangled chain.

origin: Who is next?
modern: Who’s next?

origin: I wonder if the lion be to speak.
modern: I wonder if the lion’s going to talk.

origin: No wonder, my lord.
modern: It wouldn’t surprise me, my lord.

origin: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?
modern: Can you imagine cement and stone talking better?

origin: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.
modern: It’s the smartest partition I’ve ever heard speak, my lord.

origin: Pyramus draws near the wall.
modern: Pyramus is coming up to the wall.

origin: Silence!
modern: Be quiet!

origin: I fear my Thisbe’s promise is forgot!— And thou, O Wall, O sweet, O lovely Wall, That stand’st between her father’s ground and mine.
modern: I’m afraid my Thisbe has forgotten her promise!—And you, oh Wall, oh sweet, oh lovely Wall, you stand between her father’s property and mine, you Wall, oh Wall, oh sweet and lovely Wall.

origin: Jove shield thee well for this!
modern: God bless you for doing this.

origin: But what see I?
modern: But what’s this I see?

origin: No Thisbe do I see.
modern: I don’t see any Thisbe.

origin: O wicked Wall through whom I see no bliss!
modern: Oh wicked wall, through which I don’t see any happiness!

origin: Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!
modern: Damn your stones for disappointing me like this!

origin: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.
modern: Since the wall is conscious, it should curse back at him.

origin: I see a voice.
modern: I see a voice!

origin: Now will I to the chink, To spy an I can hear my Thisbe’s face.
modern: I’ll go to the hole to see if I can hear my Thisbe’s face.

origin: Thisbe?
modern: Thisbe?

origin: My love thou art, my love, I think.
modern: You are my love, my love, I think.

origin: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover’s grace.
modern: I’m your love, no matter what you think.

origin: Wilt thou at Ninny’s tomb meet me straightway?
modern: Will you meet me right away at Ninny’s grave?

origin: Tide life, tide death, I come without delay.
modern: Neither death nor life will stop me from coming.

origin: Thus have I, Wall, my part dischargèd so.
modern: I, Wall, have done my part.

origin: And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.
modern: Now that I’m done, Wall can go away.

origin: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.
modern: This is the silliest thing I’ve ever seen.

origin: The best in this kind are but shadows, and the worst are no worse if imagination amend them.
modern: The best plays are still only illusions, and the worst are just as good, if you just use your imagination to fill them in.

origin: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.
modern: In that case it’s your imagination that’s interesting, not the play.

origin: Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.
modern: Look, here come two noble animals, a man and a lion.

origin: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.
modern: Ah, it’s a sensitive animal, with a good conscience.

origin: This lion is a very fox, for his valor.
modern: He’s as brave as a fox.

origin: True.
modern: True.

origin: And a goose for his discretion.
modern: And as wise as a goose.

origin: Not so, my lord.
modern: Oh, that’s not true, my lord.

origin: For his valor cannot carry his discretion, and the fox carries the goose.
modern: He’s not brave enough to be wise.

origin: His discretion, I am sure, cannot carry his valor, for the goose carries not the fox.
modern: He’s not wise enough to be brave.

origin: It is well.
modern: Anyway, he is what he is.

origin: Leave it to his discretion, and let us listen to the moon.
modern: Let’s listen to the moon.

origin: This lanthorn doth the hornèd moon present.
modern: This lantern represents the moon.

origin: Myself the man i' th' moon do seem to be— This is the greatest error of all the rest.
modern: I myself am playing the man in the moon— Well then, that’s the biggest mistake of all.

origin: The man should be put into the lanthorn.
modern: The man should be inside the lantern.

origin: How is it else the “man i' th' moon”?
modern: How else is he the “man in the moon”?

origin: He dares not come there for the candle.
modern: He can’t go in there because of the candle.

origin: For you see, it is already in snuff.
modern: It’s too hot.

origin: I am aweary of this moon.
modern: I’m tired of this moon.

origin: Proceed, Moon.
modern: Go ahead, Moon.

origin: All that I have to say is to tell you that the lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon; this thornbush, my thornbush; and this dog, my dog.
modern: All I wanted to tell you is that the lantern is the moon, I’m the man in the moon, this thornbush is my thornbush, and this dog is my dog.

origin: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn, for all these are in the moon.—But silence!
modern: Well, all of these should be in the lantern, because they’re all in the moon.

origin: Here comes Thisbe.
modern: But be quiet, here comes Thisbe.

origin: This is old Ninny’s tomb.
modern: This is old Ninny’s tomb.

origin: Where is my love?
modern: But where is my love?

origin: Well roared, Lion!
modern: Good roaring, Lion!

origin: Well run, Thisbe!
modern: Good running, Thisbe!

origin: Well shone, Moon!—Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.
modern: Good shining, Moon!—Really, the Moon shines very well.

origin: Well moused, Lion!
modern: That’s good, Lion!

origin: O, teach me how you look and with what art You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
modern: Oh, teach me how you look the way you do, and which tricks you used to make Demetrius fall in love with you.

origin: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.
modern: I frown at him, but he still loves me.

origin: Oh, that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!
modern: Oh, if only my smiles could inspire love as effectively as your frowns!

origin: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.
modern: I curse him, but he loves me.

origin: Oh, that my prayers could such affection move!
modern: If only my prayers could inspire that kind of affection!

origin: The more I hate, the more he follows me.
modern: The more I hate him, the more he follows me around.

origin: The more I love, the more he hateth me.
modern: The more I love him, the more he hates me.

origin: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
modern: It’s not my fault he acts like that, Helena.

origin: None, but your beauty.
modern: That’s true, it’s your beauty’s fault.

origin: Would that fault were mine!
modern: I wish I had a fault like that!

origin: Take comfort.
modern: Don’t worry.

origin: He no more shall see my face.
modern: He won’t see my face ever again.

origin: Lysander and myself will fly this place.
modern: Lysander and I are running away from here.

origin: Before the time I did Lysander see Seemed Athens as a paradise to me.
modern: Before I saw Lysander, Athens seemed like paradise to me.

origin: Oh, then, what graces in my love do dwell, That he hath turned a heaven unto a hell!
modern: But Lysander’s so attractive that he’s turned heaven into hell!

origin: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold.
modern: Helena, we’ll tell you about our secret plan.

origin: Tomorrow night when Phoebe doth behold Her silver visage in the watery glass, Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass (A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal), Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.
modern: Tomorrow night, when the moon shines on the water and decorates the grass with tiny beads of pearly light (the time of night that always hides runaway lovers), we plan to sneak out of Athens.

origin: And then came Pyramus.
modern: And then Pyramus showed up.

origin: And so the lion vanished.
modern: So the lion disappeared.

origin: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams.
modern: Sweet Moon, I thank you for your sunny beams.

origin: But mark, poor knight, What dreadful dole is here!
modern: But, look, poor me, what a terrible tragedy is here!

origin: Eyes, do you see?
modern: Eyes, do you see?

origin: How can it be?
modern: How can it be?

origin: O dainty duck!
modern: Oh, dainty duck!

origin: O dear!
modern: Oh, dear!

origin: O Fates, come, come, Cut thread and thrum.
modern: Oh, Fate, come and cut the thread of my life.

origin: Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!
modern: Conquer, crush, conclude, and kill!

origin: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame?
modern: Oh, Mother Nature, why did you create lions?

origin: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.
modern: And so I’m dying.

origin: Now am I dead.
modern: Okay, now I’m dead.

origin: Now die, die, die, die, die.
modern: Now die, die, die, die, die.

origin: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover and prove an ass.
modern: With a doctor’s help he might recover and become an ass again.

origin: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a Pyramus.
modern: I don’t think a ridiculous Pyramus like that one deserves much moaning.

origin: I hope she will be brief.
modern: I hope she keeps it short.

origin: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.
modern: Look, she’s spotted him with those sweet eyes of hers.

origin: And thus she means, videlicet— Asleep, my love?
modern: And now she’ll start moaning, of course— Are you asleep, my love?

origin: What, dead, my dove?
modern: What, are you dead, my dove?

origin: O Pyramus, arise!
modern: Oh, Pyramus, get up!

origin: Speak, speak.
modern: Speak, speak.

origin: Quite dumb?
modern: Can’t you talk?

origin: Dead, dead?
modern: Dead, dead?

origin: A tomb Must cover thy sweet eyes.
modern: The dirt of a grave must cover your sweet eyes!

origin: These lily lips, This cherry nose, These yellow cowslip cheeks Are gone, are gone.
modern: Your lily-white lips, your cherry-red nose, and your buttercup-yellow cheeks are gone, gone forever.

origin: Lovers, make moan.
modern: Lovers, moan and weep.

origin: His eyes were green as leeks.
modern: His eyes were as green as leeks.

origin: O Sisters three, Come, come to me With hands as pale as milk.
modern: Oh, Fate, come, come to me, with hands as pale as milk.

origin: Lay them in gore, Since you have shore With shears his thread of silk.
modern: Soak your hands in blood and gore, since you have cut the thread of his life with scissors.

origin: Tongue, not a word.
modern: Tongue, do not speak.

origin: Come, trusty sword.
modern: Come, trusty sword.

origin: Come, blade, my breast imbrue.
modern: Come, blade, drench my breast with blood.

origin: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
modern: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

origin: Ay, and Wall too.
modern: Yes, and Wall too.

origin: No epilogue, I pray you, for your play needs no excuse.
modern: No epilogue, please.

origin: Never excuse—for when the players are all dead, there needs none to be blamed.
modern: Never apologize—when the actors are all dead, no one can be blamed.

origin: Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe’s garter, it would have been a fine tragedy.
modern: As a matter of fact, if the playwright had played Pyramus and hanged himself with Thisbe’s belt, it would have been a very good tragedy.

origin: And so it is, truly, and very notably discharged.
modern: It’s a good tragedy, very well done.

origin: But come, your Bergomask.
modern: But come on, let’s see you do your dance.

origin: Let your epilogue alone.
modern: Forget your epilogue.

origin: The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve.
modern: The clock has chimed midnight.

origin: Lovers, to bed.
modern: Lovers, it’s time to go to bed.

origin: Tis almost fairy time.
modern: It’s almost fairy time.

origin: Sweet friends, to bed.
modern: Dear friends, let’s go to bed.

origin: Through the house give glimmering light, By the dead and drowsy fire.
modern: Let the dying fire shine a glimmering light throughout the house.

origin: First, rehearse your song by rote, To each word a warbling note.
modern: First rehearse your song from memory, and make sure each note is pretty.

origin: Hand in hand with fairy grace Will we sing and bless this place.
modern: We’ll all join hands and sing, and bless this place with our fairy grace.

origin: If you pardon, we will mend.
modern: If you forgive us, we’ll make everything all right.

origin: And, as I am an honest Puck,  If we have unearnèd luck  Now to ’scape the serpent’s tongue,  We will make amends ere long.
modern: I’m an honest Puck, and I swear that if we’re lucky enough not to get hissed at, we’ll make it up to you soon.

origin: Else the Puck a liar call.
modern: If not, then I’m a liar.

origin: So good night unto you all.
modern: So good night to everyone.

origin: Give me your hands if we be friends,  And Robin shall restore amends.
modern: Give me some applause, if we’re friends, and Robin will make everything up to you.

origin: There my Lysander and myself shall meet.
modern: From then on we’ll turn our backs on Athens.

origin: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes To seek new friends and stranger companies.
modern: We’ll look for new friends and keep the company of strangers.

origin: Farewell, sweet playfellow.
modern: Goodbye, old friend.

origin: We must starve our sight From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
modern: We need to stay away from each other until midnight tomorrow.

origin: I will, my Hermia.
modern: I will, my Hermia.

origin: Helena, adieu.
modern: Goodbye, Helena.

origin: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!
modern: I hope Demetrius comes to love you as much as you love him!

origin: But what of that?
modern: But so what?

origin: Demetrius thinks not so.
modern: Demetrius doesn’t think so, and that’s all that matters.

origin: He will not know what all but he do know.
modern: He refuses to admit what everyone else knows.

origin: Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.
modern: Love can make worthless things beautiful.

origin: Love looks not with the eyes but with the mind.
modern: When we’re in love, we don’t see with our eyes but with our minds.

origin: And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind.
modern: That’s why paintings of Cupid, the god of love, always show him as blind.

origin: Nor hath Love’s mind of any judgment taste— Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste.
modern: And love doesn’t have good judgment either—Cupid, has wings and no eyes, so he’s bound to be reckless and hasty.

origin: And therefore is Love said to be a child, Because in choice he is so oft beguiled.
modern: That’s why they say love is a child.

origin: Then to the wood will he tomorrow night Pursue her.
modern: He’ll run after her.

origin: Is all our company here?
modern: Is everyone here?

origin: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.
modern: First, Peter Quince, tell us what the play is about, then read the names of the actors, and then shut up.

origin: Answer as I call you.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?
modern: Answer when I call your name.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?

origin: Ready.
modern: Here.

origin: Name what part I am for and proceed.
modern: Tell me which part I’m going to play, then go on.

origin: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.
modern: You, Nick Bottom, have been cast as Pyramus.

origin: What is Pyramus?
modern: What’s Pyramus?

origin: I will condole in some measure.—To the rest.—Yet my chief humor is for a tyrant.
modern: I’ll moan very believably.—Name the other actors.—But I’m really in the mood to play a tyrant.

origin: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in to make all split.
modern: I could do a great job with Hercules, or any other part that requires ranting and raving.

origin: A lover is more condoling.
modern: A lover would have to be weepier, of course.

origin: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender?
modern: Francis Flute, the bellows-repairman?

origin: Here, Peter Quince.
modern: Here, Peter Quince.

origin: What is Thisbe?
modern: Who’s Thisbe?

origin: A wandering knight?
modern: A knight on a quest?

origin: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.
modern: Thisbe is the lady Pyramus is in love with.

origin: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman.
modern: No, come on, don’t make me play a woman.

origin: I have a beard coming.
modern: I’m growing a beard.

origin: That’s all one.
modern: That doesn’t matter.

origin: You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.
modern: You’ll wear a mask, and you can make your voice as high as you want to.

origin: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!
modern: In that case, if I can wear a mask, let me play Thisbe too!

origin: You must play Pyramus.—And Flute, you Thisbe.
modern: Bottom, you’re Pyramus.—And Flute, you’re Thisbe.

origin: Robin Starveling, the tailor?
modern: Robin Starveling, the tailor?

origin: Here, Peter Quince.
modern: Here, Peter Quince.

origin: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the tinker?
modern: Robin Starveling, you’re going to play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the handyman.

origin: Here, Peter Quince.
modern: Here, Peter Quince.

origin: You, Pyramus' father.—Myself, Thisbe’s father.—Snug the joiner, you, the lion’s part.—And I hope here is a play fitted.
modern: I hope this play is well cast now.

origin: Have you the lion’s part written?
modern: Do you have the lion’s part written down?

origin: Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.
modern: If you do, please give it to me, because I need to start learning the lines.

origin: Let me play the lion too.
modern: Let me play the lion too.

origin: And that were enough to hang us all.
modern: And that would get us all executed.

origin: That would hang us, every mother’s son.
modern: Yeah, that would get every single one of us executed.

origin: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us.
modern: Well, my friends, you’ve got to admit that if you scare the living daylights out of the ladies, they’d have no choice but to execute us.

origin: For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely, gentlemanlike man.
modern: Because Pyramus is a good-looking man, the most handsome man that you could find on a summer’s day, a lovely gentlemanly man.

origin: Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.
modern: So you’re the only one who could play Pyramus.

origin: Well, I will undertake it.
modern: Well then, I’ll do it.

origin: What beard were I best to play it in?
modern: What kind of beard should I wear for the part?

origin: Why, what you will.
modern: Whatever kind you want, I guess.

origin: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night.
modern: No, you’ll see, four days will quickly turn into four nights.

origin: Four nights will quickly dream away the time.
modern: And since we dream at night, time passes quickly then.

origin: And then the moon, like to a silver bow New bent in heaven, shall behold the night Of our solemnities.
modern: Finally the new moon, curved like a silver bow in the sky, will look down on our wedding celebration.

origin: Turn melancholy forth to funerals.
modern: Sadness is only appropriate for funerals.

origin: The pale companion is not for our pomp.
modern: We don’t want it at our festivities.

origin: But I will wed thee in another key, With pomp, with triumph, and with reveling.
modern: But I’ll marry you under different circumstances—with extravagant festivals, public festivities, and celebration.

origin: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd duke.
modern: Long live Theseus, our famous and respected duke!

origin: I will discharge it in either your straw-color beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French crown-color beard, your perfect yellow.
modern: I’ll play the part wearing either a straw-colored beard, or a sandy beard, or a red beard, or one of those bright yellow beards that’s the color of a French coin.

origin: There will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known.
modern: It’s best to rehearse there, because if we do it here in the city, we’ll be bothered by crowds of people and everyone will know the plot of our play.

origin: In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants.
modern: Meanwhile, I’ll make a list of props that we’ll need for the play.

origin: I pray you, fail me not.
modern: Don’t leave me in the lurch.

origin: We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously.
modern: We’ll be there, and there we’ll rehearse courageously and wonderfully, truly obscenely.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: At the duke’s oak we meet.
modern: We’ll meet at the giant oak tree in the duke’s forest.

origin: Enough.
modern: Got it?

origin: Hold, or cut bowstrings.
modern: Be there, or don’t show your face again.

origin: How now, spirit?
modern: Hello, spirit!

origin: Whither wander you?
modern: Where are you going?

origin: Over hill, over dale,  Thorough bush, thorough brier,  Over park, over pale,  Thorough flood, thorough fire.
modern: I go over hills and valleys, through bushes and thorns, over parks and fenced-in spaces, through water and fire.

origin: I do wander everywhere  Swifter than the moon’s sphere.
modern: I wander everywhere faster than the moon revolves around the Earth.

origin: And I serve the fairy queen  To dew her orbs upon the green.
modern: I work for Titania, the Fairy Queen, and organize fairy dances for her in the grass.

origin: The cowslips tall her pensioners be.
modern: The cowslip flowers are her bodyguards.

origin: In those freckles live their savors.
modern: Their sweet smells come from those little freckles.

origin: I must go seek some dewdrops here  And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.
modern: Now I have to go find some dewdrops and hang a pearl earring on every cowslip flower.

origin: Farewell, thou lob of spirits.
modern: Goodbye, you dumb old spirit.

origin: I’ll be gone.
modern: I’ve got to go.

origin: Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
modern: The queen and her elves will be here soon.

origin: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath Because that she, as her attendant hath A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king.
modern: He’s furious because she stole an adorable boy from an Indian king.

origin: And jealous Oberon would have the child Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild.
modern: He wants the child for himself, to accompany him on his wanderings through the wild forests.

origin: But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy, Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.
modern: Instead, she puts flowers in the boy’s hair and makes a fuss over him.

origin: Those that “Hobgoblin” call you, and “sweet Puck,” You do their work, and they shall have good luck.
modern: You do their work for them and give them good luck.

origin: Are not you he?
modern: That’s you, right?

origin: Thou speak’st aright.
modern: What you say is true.

origin: I am that merry wanderer of the night.
modern: That’s me you’re talking about, the playful wanderer of the night.

origin: And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl In very likeness of a roasted crab, And when she drinks, against her lips I bob And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.
modern: When she takes a sip, I bob up against her lips and make her spill the drink all over her withered old neck.

origin: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she, And “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough, And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh, And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear A merrier hour was never wasted there.
modern: But I slip from underneath her and she falls down, crying, “Ow, my butt!” and starts coughing, and then everyone laughs and has fun.

origin: But, room, fairy!
modern: But step aside, fairy!

origin: Here comes Oberon.
modern: Here comes Oberon.

origin: And here my mistress.
modern: And here’s my mistress, Titania.

origin: Would that he were gone!
modern: I wish he’d go away!

origin: What, jealous Oberon?—Fairies, skip hence.
modern: How  What, are you jealous, Oberon?—Fairies, let’s get out of here.

origin: I have forsworn his bed and company.
modern: I’ve sworn I’ll never sleep with him or talk to him again.

origin: Tarry, rash wanton.
modern: Wait just a minute, you brazen hussy.

origin: Why art thou here, Come from the farthest step of India?
modern: The only reason you left India was to come here and see that butch Amazon Hippolyta.

origin: But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, Your buskined mistress and your warrior love, To Theseus must be wedded, and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity.
modern: She was your boot-wearing mistress and your warrior lover, and now that she’s getting married to Theseus, you’ve come to celebrate their marriage.

origin: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Knowing I know thy love to Theseus?
modern: How can you stand there shamelessly talking about me and Hippolyta, when you know that I know about your love for Theseus?

origin: Glance at my credit with Hippolyta, Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night From Perigouna, whom he ravishèd?
modern: Weren’t you the one who made him desert Perigouna in the middle of the night, right after he’d raped her?

origin: And make him with fair Ægles break his faith, With Ariadne and Antiopa?
modern: And weren’t you the one who made him cheat on all of his other girlfriends, like Aegles, Ariadne, and Antiopa?

origin: These are the forgeries of jealousy.
modern: These are nothing but jealous lies.

origin: And never, since the middle summer’s spring, Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead, By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook, Or in the beachèd margent of the sea, To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind, But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport.
modern: We haven’t been able to meet on a hill or in a valley, in the forest or a meadow, by a pebbly fountain or a rushing stream, or on the beach by the ocean without you disturbing us.

origin: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, As in revenge, have sucked up from the sea Contagious fogs, which falling in the land Have every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents.
modern: And because you interrupt us so that we can’t dance for them, the winds have made fogs rise up out of the sea and fall down on the rivers so that the rivers flood, just to get revenge on you.

origin: The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain, The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.
modern: So all the work that oxen and farmers have done in plowing the fields has been for nothing, because the unripe grain has rotted before it was ripe.

origin: The fold stands empty in the drownèd field, And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.
modern: Sheep pens are empty in the middle of the flooded fields, and the crows get fat from eating the dead bodies of infected sheep.

origin: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods, Pale in her anger, washes all the air, That rheumatic diseases do abound.
modern: So the pale, angry moon, who controls the tides, fills the air with diseases.

origin: The spring, the summer, The childing autumn, angry winter change Their wonted liveries, and the mazèd world, By their increase, now knows not which is which.
modern: Spring, summer, fertile autumn and angry winter have all changed places, and now the confused world doesn’t know which is which.

origin: And this same progeny of evils comes From our debate, from our dissension.
modern: And this is all because of our argument.

origin: We are their parents and original.
modern: We are responsible for this.

origin: Do you amend it then.
modern: Do something about it, then.

origin: It lies in you.
modern: You have the power to fix it.

origin: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?
modern: Why would Titania want to argue with her Oberon?

origin: I do but beg a little changeling boy, To be my henchman.
modern: All I’m asking for is to have that little human boy as part of my crew.

origin: Set your heart at rest.
modern: Get over it.

origin: The Fairyland buys not the child of me.
modern: I won’t give up this child for all of Fairyland.

origin: How long within this wood intend you stay?
modern: How long do you plan to stay here in this forest?

origin: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding day.
modern: Maybe until after Theseus’s wedding day.

origin: If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels, go with us.
modern: If you behave yourself and join us in our circle dance and moonlight celebrations, then you can come with us.

origin: If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.
modern: If not, leave me alone, and I’ll stay away from your turf.

origin: Give me that boy and I will go with thee.
modern: Give me that boy and I’ll come with you.

origin: Not for thy fairy kingdom.—Fairies, away!
modern: Not for your entire fairy kingdom.—Come, fairies, let’s go.

origin: We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.
modern: We’re going to have an out-and-out brawl if I stay any longer.

origin: Well, go thy way.
modern: Well, go on your way, then.

origin: Thou shalt not from this grove Till I torment thee for this injury.— My gentle Puck, come hither.
modern: You won’t leave this grove until I’ve paid you back for this insult.

origin: I remember.
modern: Yes, I remember.

origin: That very time I saw (but thou couldst not) Flying between the cold moon and the Earth, Cupid all armed.
modern: You couldn’t see him, but I could.

origin: A certain aim he took At a fair vestal thronèd by the west, And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.
modern: He took aim at a beautiful young virgin who was sitting on a throne in the western part of the world, and he shot his arrow of love well enough to have pierced a hundred thousand hearts.

origin: But I might see young Cupid’s fiery shaft Quenched in the chaste beams of the watery moon, And the imperial votaress passèd on, In maiden meditation, fancy-free.
modern: But I could see that Cupid’s fiery arrow was put out by watery, virginal moonbeams, so the royal virgin continued her virginal thoughts without being interrupted by thoughts of love.

origin: Yet marked I where the bolt of Cupid fell.
modern: But I paid attention to where Cupid’s arrow fell.

origin: It fell upon a little western flower, Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.
modern: It fell on a little western flower, which used to be white as milk but now has turned purple from being wounded by the arrow of love.

origin: And maidens call it “love-in-idleness.” Fetch me that flower.
modern: Young girls call it “love-in-idleness.” Bring me that flower.

origin: The herb I showed thee once.
modern: I showed it to you once.

origin: The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees.
modern: If its juice is put on someone’s eyelids while they’re asleep, that person will fall in love with the next living creature he or she sees.

origin: Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again Ere the leviathan can swim a league.
modern: Bring me this plant, and get back here before the sea monster has time to swim three miles.

origin: I’ll put a girdle round about the Earth In forty minutes.
modern: I could go around the world in forty minutes.

origin: Having once this juice, I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.
modern: When I have the juice of that flower, I’ll trickle some drops of it on Titania’s eyes while she’s sleeping.

origin: The next thing then she waking looks upon— Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull, On meddling monkey or on busy ape— She shall pursue it with the soul of love.
modern: She’ll fall madly in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up—even if it’s a lion, a bear, a wolf, a bull, a monkey, or an ape.

origin: And ere I take this charm from of her sight— As I can take it with another herb— I’ll make her render up her page to me.
modern: And before I make her normal again—I can cure her by treating her with another plant—I’ll make her give me that little boy as my page.

origin: But who comes here?
modern: But who’s that coming this way?

origin: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.
modern: Look, I don’t love you, so stop following me around.

origin: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?
modern: Where are Lysander and beautiful Hermia?

origin: The one I’ll stay, the other stayeth me.
modern: Lysander I want to stop, but Hermia stops my heart from beating.

origin: Thou told’st me they were stol'n unto this wood.
modern: You told me they escaped into this forest.

origin: And here am I, and wood within this wood, Because I cannot meet my Hermia.
modern: And here I am, going crazy in the middle of the woods because I can’t find my Hermia.

origin: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
modern: Go away, get out of here, and stop following me.

origin: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.
modern: You attract me to you, you cruel magnet!

origin: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart Is true as steel.
modern: But you must not attract iron, because my heart is as true as steel.

origin: Leave you your power to draw, And I shall have no power to follow you.
modern: If you let go of your power to attract me, I won’t have any power to follow you.

origin: Do I entice you?
modern: Do I ask you to follow me?

origin: Do I speak you fair?
modern: Do I speak to you kindly?

origin: Or rather, do I not in plainest truth Tell you I do not, nor I cannot, love you?
modern: Don’t I tell you in the clearest terms that I do not and cannot love you?

origin: And even for that do I love you the more.
modern: Yes, but that makes me love you even more.

origin: I am your spaniel.
modern: I’m your little dog, Demetrius.

origin: And, Demetrius, The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.
modern: The more you beat me, the more I’ll love you.

origin: Use me but as your spaniel—spurn me, strike me, Neglect me, lose me.
modern: Treat me like you would treat a dog—kick me, hit me, neglect me, try to lose me.

origin: Only give me leave, Unworthy as I am, to follow you.
modern: Just let me follow behind you, even though I’m not good enough for you.

origin: For I am sick when I do look on thee.
modern: Just looking at you makes me sick.

origin: And I am sick when I look not on you.
modern: And I get sick when I can’t look at you.

origin: Your virtue is my privilege.
modern: I rely on your virtue to protect me.

origin: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company, For you in my respect are all the world.
modern: This forest doesn’t seem deserted when you’re here, because you are all the world to me.

origin: Then how can it be said I am alone When all the world is here to look on me?
modern: So how can anyone say I’m alone, when the whole world is here to look at me?

origin: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes, And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
modern: I’ll run away from you and hide in the bushes, and leave you to the mercy of wild animals.

origin: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.
modern: The wildest animal isn’t as cruel as you are.

origin: Let me go.
modern: Leave me alone.

origin: Or if thou follow me, do not believe But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
modern: Or if you follow me, you’d better understand that I’ll do something bad to you in the forest.

origin: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field You do me mischief.
modern: Yes, you already hurt me in the church, in the town, and in the fields.

origin: Fie, Demetrius!
modern: Shame on you, Demetrius!

origin: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.
modern: Your behavior is an insult to all women.

origin: We cannot fight for love as men may do.
modern: We cannot fight for love as men can.

origin: I’ll follow thee and make a heaven of hell, To die upon the hand I love so well.
modern: I’ll follow you and turn this hell I’m in into a kind of heaven.

origin: Fare thee well, nymph.
modern: Goodbye, nymph.

origin: Ere he do leave this grove, Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.
modern: Before he leaves this part of the forest, you’ll change places: you’ll be the one running away, and he’ll be in love with you.

origin: Hast thou the flower there?
modern: Do you have the flower?

origin: Welcome, wanderer.
modern: Welcome, traveler.

origin: Ay, there it is.
modern: Yes, here it is.

origin: I pray thee, give it me.
modern: Please, give it to me.

origin: Thanks, good Egeus.
modern: Thanks, good Egeus.

origin: What’s the news with thee?
modern: What’s new with you?

origin: Full of vexation come I with complaint Against my child, my daughter Hermia.— Stand forth, Demetrius.—My noble lord, This man hath my consent to marry her.— Stand forth, Lysander.—And my gracious duke, This man hath bewitched the bosom of my child.— Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes, And interchanged love tokens with my child.
modern: I’m here, full of anger, to complain about my daughter Hermia.—Step forward, Demetrius.—My lord, this man, Demetrius, has my permission to marry her.—Step forward, Lysander.—But this other man, Lysander, has cast a magic spell over my child’s heart.—You, you, Lysander, you’ve given her poems, and exchanged tokens of love with my daughter.

origin: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung With feigning voice verses of feigning love, And stol'n the impression of her fantasy With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits, Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats—messengers Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth.
modern: You’ve pretended to be in love with her, singing fake love songs softly at her window by moonlight, and you’ve captured her imagination by giving her locks of your hair, rings, toys, trinkets, knickknacks, little presents, flowers, and candies—things that can really influence an impressionable young person.

origin: With cunning hast thou filched my daughter’s heart, Turned her obedience (which is due to me) To stubborn harshness.—And, my gracious duke, Be it so she will not here before your grace Consent to marry with Demetrius, I beg the ancient privilege of Athens.
modern: You’ve connived to steal my daughter’s heart, making her stubborn and harsh instead of obedient (like she should be).—And, my gracious duke, if she won’t agree to marry Demetrius right now, I ask you to let me exercise the right that all fathers have in Athens.

origin: As she is mine, I may dispose of her— Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death—according to our law Immediately provided in that case.
modern: Since she belongs to me, I can do what I want with her—as the law says: I can either make her marry Demetrius—or have her killed.

origin: What say you, Hermia?
modern: What do you have to say for yourself, Hermia?

origin: Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
modern: Demetrius is an admirable man.

origin: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night, Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.
modern: Titania sleeps there sometimes at night, lulled to sleep among the flowers by dances and other delights.

origin: And there the snake throws her enameled skin, Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.
modern: Snakes shed their skin there, and the shed skin is wide enough to wrap a fairy in.

origin: And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes And make her full of hateful fantasies.
modern: I’ll put the juice of this flower on Titania’s eyes, and fill her with horrible delusions and desires.

origin: Fear not, my lord.
modern: Don’t worry, sir.

origin: Your servant shall do so.
modern: I’m at your service.

origin: Hence, away!
modern: Okay, let’s go!

origin: Now all is well.
modern: Everything’s fine now.

origin: One aloof stand sentinel.
modern: One of us will stay and stand guard.

origin: What thou seest when thou dost wake, Do it for thy true love take.
modern: Whatever you see first when you wake up, think of it as your true love.

origin: Wake when some vile thing is near.
modern: Wake up when something nasty is nearby.

origin: Be it so, Lysander.
modern: Let’s do that, Lysander.

origin: Find you out a bed, For I upon this bank will rest my head.
modern: I’m going to rest my head on this little slope.

origin: One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.
modern: We’ll have one heart, one bed, two bodies, and one faithful vow.

origin: Nay, good Lysander.
modern: No, Lysander.

origin: Do not lie so near.
modern: Don’t sleep so close to me.

origin: I mean that my heart unto yours is knit So that but one heart we can make of it.
modern: I just meant that our hearts are joined, so we can almost think of them as one heart.

origin: Then by your side no bed room me deny.
modern: So let me sleep next to you.

origin: And, good night, sweet friend.
modern: Stay away for now, and good night, my sweet friend.

origin: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
modern: I hope your love for me remains this strong for your entire life!

origin: Amen, amen to that fair prayer, say I.
modern: Amen to that.

origin: Here is my bed.
modern: I’ll sleep over here.

origin: Pretty soul!
modern: Stop, Demetrius!

origin: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.
modern: Stop, even if only to kill me.

origin: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.
modern: I’m telling you, get out of here, and don’t follow me around like this.

origin: O, wilt thou darkling leave me?
modern: Oh, will you leave me alone in the dark?

origin: Do not so.
modern: Don’t.

origin: Stay, on thy peril.
modern: Stay here at your own risk.

origin: I alone will go.
modern: I’m going on alone.

origin: Oh, I am out of breath in this fond chase.
modern: Oh, I’m out of breath from this foolish chase.

origin: The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.
modern: The more I pray, the less I get out of it.

origin: Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies, For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.
modern: Hermia is lucky, wherever she is, because she has beautiful eyes.

origin: How came her eyes so bright?
modern: How did her eyes get so bright?

origin: Not with salt tears.
modern: Not from crying.

origin: If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers.
modern: If that’s the case, tears wash my eyes more than hers.

origin: No, no, I am as ugly as a bear, For beasts that meet me run away for fear.
modern: No, no, I’m as ugly as a bear, since animals that see me run away in terror.

origin: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus.
modern: So it’s no surprise that Demetrius runs away from me as if I were a monster.

origin: What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia’s sphery eyne?
modern: What evil and deceitful mirror made me think I could rival Hermia’s starry eyes?

origin: Do not say so, Lysander.
modern: Don’t say that, Lysander.

origin: Say not so.
modern: Don’t say that.

origin: What though he love your Hermia?
modern: Why do you care that he loves Hermia?

origin: Lord, what though?
modern: What does it matter?

origin: Content with Hermia?
modern: Happy with Hermia?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: I do repent The tedious minutes I with her have spent.
modern: I regret all the boring time I wasted with her.

origin: Not Hermia but Helena I love.
modern: I don’t love Hermia; I love Helena.

origin: Things growing are not ripe until their season.
modern: Fruits and vegetables don’t ripen until the right season of the year.

origin: So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason.
modern: Likewise, I’m young, and my sense of reason has just ripened.

origin: Is ’t not enough, is ’t not enough, young man, That I did never, no, nor never can, Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency?
modern: Is it not enough, is it not enough, young man, that I’ll never be pretty enough to get a kind look from Demetrius?

origin: Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do, In such disdainful manner me to woo.
modern: Do you have to harp on my inadequacy?

origin: But fare you well.
modern: But goodbye.

origin: Perforce I must confess I thought you lord of more true gentleness.
modern: I have to tell you, I thought you were a much kinder person than this.

origin: Oh, that a lady of one man refused Should of another therefore be abused!
modern: Oh, how awful that a lady who’s been rejected by one man should therefore be treated horribly by another one!

origin: Are we all met?
modern: Are we all here?

origin: Pat, pat.
modern: Right on time.

origin: And here’s a marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal.
modern: This is the perfect place to rehearse.

origin: This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house, and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.
modern: This clearing will be the stage, and this hawthorn bush will be our dressing room.

origin: Peter Quince— What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
modern: Peter Quince— What is it, jolly Bottom?

origin: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please.
modern: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never work.

origin: First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies cannot abide.
modern: First of all, Pyramus has to take out a sword to kill himself, which the ladies in the audience won’t be able to stand.

origin: How answer you that?
modern: What should we do about that?

origin: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.
modern: I think we’ll have to leave out all the killing, come to think of it.

origin: Not a whit.
modern: Not at all!

origin: I have a device to make all well.
modern: I’ve got a plan that will fix everything.

origin: Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed indeed.
modern: I’ll tell them that we won’t hurt anyone with our swords, and that Pyramus isn’t really dead.

origin: And for the more better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver.
modern: And to make it even clearer, we can tell them that I’m playing Pyramus but I’m not really Pyramus—really, I’m Bottom the weaver.

origin: This will put them out of fear.
modern: That’ll keep them from being afraid.

origin: Well.
modern: All right, we’ll have a prologue then.

origin: We will have such a prologue, and it shall be written in eight and six.
modern: We’ll write it in alternating eight- and six-syllable lines, just like in a ballad.

origin: No, make it two more.
modern: No, add a couple more syllables.

origin: Let it be written in eight and eight.
modern: Make it eight and eight.

origin: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?
modern: Won’t the ladies be scared of the lion?

origin: I fear it, I promise you.
modern: I’m really worried about that.

origin: For there is not a more fearful wildfowl than your lion living.
modern: There’s no scarier wild bird than the living lion, and we should remember that.

origin: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.
modern: So we need another prologue to tell everyone he’s not a real lion.

origin: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.
modern: No, we can just announce the actor’s name, and let his face show through the lion costume, and have him say something himself.

origin: For, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.
modern: Because, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.

origin: So is Lysander.
modern: So is Lysander.

origin: In himself he is.
modern: You’re right, Lysander’s admirable too.

origin: But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice, The other must be held the worthier.
modern: But since your father doesn’t want him to marry you, you have to consider Demetrius to be the better man.

origin: I would my father looked but with my eyes.
modern: I wish my father could see them with my eyes.

origin: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
modern: No, you must see them as your father sees them.

origin: I do entreat your grace to pardon me.
modern: Your grace, please forgive me.

origin: I know not by what power I am made bold Nor how it may concern my modesty In such a presence here to plead my thoughts, But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case, If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
modern: But please, tell me the worst thing that could happen to me if I refuse to marry Demetrius.

origin: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires.
modern: So think carefully about what you want, beautiful Hermia.

origin: Know of your youth.
modern: Consider how young you are, and question your feelings.

origin: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?
modern: Will the moon be shining on the night we’re performing our play?

origin: A calendar, a calendar!
modern: We need a calendar!

origin: Look in the almanac.
modern: Look in the almanac.

origin: Find out moonshine, find out moonshine!
modern: Look up moonshine, look up moonshine!

origin: What say you, Bottom?
modern: What do you think, Bottom?

origin: And let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisbe whisper.
modern: He can hold his fingers in a V-shape like this, and Pyramus and Thisbe can whisper to each other through that little crack.

origin: If that may be then all is well.
modern: If we can do that, everything will be all right.

origin: Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and rehearse your parts.—Pyramus, you begin.
modern: Now sit down, everybody, and rehearse your parts—Pyramus, you start.

origin: When you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake.—And so everyone according to his cue.
modern: When you have said your lines, go hide in that bush.—Everyone else, go there too when you’re not onstage.

origin: Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, stand forth.
modern: Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, come forward.

origin: Ay, marry, must you.
modern: Yes, you are.

origin: For you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.
modern: You’re supposed to show that you understand that Pyramus just went to check on a noise he heard and is coming right back.

origin: Ninus' tomb,” man.
modern: That’s “Ninus’s grave,” man.

origin: Why, you must not speak that yet.
modern: And don’t say all of that yet.

origin: You speak all your part at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter.
modern: You just said all your lines at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter.

origin: It is “never tire.” Oh.
modern: It’s “never get tired.” Oh!

origin: Oh, monstrous!
modern: Help!

origin: Oh, strange!
modern: It’s a monster!

origin: We are haunted.
modern: We’re being haunted.

origin: Fly, masters!
modern: Run, everyone, run!

origin: I’ll follow you.
modern: I’ll follow you.

origin: Sometime a horse I’ll be, sometime a hound, A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire.
modern: Sometimes I’ll turn into fire!

origin: And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn, Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.
modern: And I’ll neigh like a horse and bark like a hound and grunt like a pig and roar like a bear and burn like a fire at every turn.

origin: Why do they run away?
modern: Why are they running away?

origin: O Bottom, thou art changed!
modern: Oh, Bottom, you’ve changed!

origin: What do I see on thee?
modern: What have you got on your head?

origin: What do you see?
modern: What do you think I’ve got on my head?

origin: You see an ass head of your own, do you?
modern: You’re acting like an ass, don’t you think?

origin: Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee.
modern: God bless you, Bottom, God bless you.

origin: Thou art translated.
modern: Reborn.

origin: But I will not stir from this place, do what they can.
modern: But I won’t leave this spot, no matter what they do.

origin: I will walk up and down here and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid.
modern: I’ll walk up and down and sing a song, so they’ll know I’m not afraid.

origin: For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?
modern: Who’d waste his time talking to such a stupid bird?

origin: Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.
modern: I don’t think you’ve got much of a reason to love me.

origin: And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays.
modern: But to tell you the truth, reason and love have very little to do with each other these days.

origin: The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends.
modern: It’s too bad some mutual friend of theirs doesn’t introduce them.

origin: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.
modern: You’re as wise as you are beautiful.

origin: Not so, neither.
modern: No, that’s not true.

origin: But if I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.
modern: But if I were smart enough to get out of this forest, I’d be wise enough to satisfy myself.

origin: I am a spirit of no common rate.
modern: I’m no ordinary fairy.

origin: Therefore go with me.
modern: So come with me.

origin: And I will purge thy mortal grossness so That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.— Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!
modern: And I’ll turn you into a spirit like us, so you won’t die as humans do.—Come here, Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!

origin: Ready.
modern: Ready.

origin: And I.
modern: Me too.

origin: And I.
modern: Me too.

origin: And I.
modern: And me too.

origin: Where shall we go?
modern: Where should we go?

origin: Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.
modern: Be kind and polite to this gentleman.

origin: Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes.
modern: Leap and dance for him.

origin: Feed him with apricoks and dewberries, With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.
modern: Feed him apricots and blackberries, with purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.

origin: And pluck the wings from painted butterflies To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes.
modern: Pluck off colorful butterfly wings, and use them to fan moonbeams away from his eyes as he sleeps.

origin: Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
modern: Bow to him, fairies, and curtsy to him.

origin: Hail, mortal.
modern: Hello, mortal!

origin: Hail.
modern: Hello!

origin: Hail.
modern: Hello!

origin: Hail.
modern: Hello!

origin: I cry your worships' mercy, heartily.—I beseech your worship’s name.
modern: I beg your pardon, sirs.—Please tell me your name, sir?

origin: Cobweb.
modern: Cobweb.

origin: I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Cobweb.
modern: I’d like to get to know you better, Mr. Cobweb.

origin: If I cut my finger, I shall make bold with you.— Your name, honest gentleman?
modern: If I cut my finger, I’ll use you as a bandage to stop the bleeding.—And your name, sir?

origin: Peaseblossom.
modern: Peaseblossom.

origin: I pray you, commend me to Mistress Squash, your mother, and to Master Peascod, your father.
modern: Please, give my regards to your mother, Mrs. Peapod, and your father, Mr. Peapod.

origin: Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too.— Your name, I beseech you, sir?
modern: Good Mr. Peaseblossom, I’d like to get to know you better too.—And you, may I ask what your name is, sir?

origin: Mustardseed.
modern: Mustardseed.

origin: Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well.
modern: Good Mr. Mustardseed, I know you very well.

origin: That same cowardly, giantlike ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house.
modern: Those cowardly, gigantic sides of beef have been responsible for many of your family members getting eaten as a condiment on beef.

origin: I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now.
modern: I swear to you, many members of your mustard family have made my eyes water before.

origin: I desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.
modern: I look forward to getting to know you better, Mr. Mustardseed.

origin: Come, wait upon him.
modern: Take good care of him.

origin: Lead him to my bower.
modern: Take him to my sleeping area.

origin: The moon methinks looks with a watery eye.
modern: The moon looks sad to me.

origin: And when she weeps, weeps every little flower, Lamenting some enforcèd chastity.
modern: When she cries, all the little flowers cry too.

origin: Tie up my love’s tongue.
modern: Keep my lover quiet.

origin: Bring him silently.
modern: Bring him to me in silence.

origin: Here comes my messenger.—How now, mad spirit?
modern: Ah, here comes my messenger.—What’s going on, you crazy spirit?

origin: What night-rule now about this haunted grove?
modern: What havoc have you wreaked in this part of the forest?

origin: My mistress with a monster is in love.
modern: My mistress Titania is in love with a monster.

origin: I led them on in this distracted fear And left sweet Pyramus translated there.
modern: I led them on in this frightened, distracted state, and left sweet

origin: When in that moment so it came to pass, Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.
modern: At that exact moment, Titania woke up and immediately fell in love with him, an ass.

origin: This falls out better than I could devise.
modern: This is going even better than I planned.

origin: But hast thou yet latched the Athenian’s eyes With the love juice, as I did bid thee do?
modern: But have you put the love juice from the flower on the eyes of that Athenian, as I asked you to do?

origin: I took him sleeping—that is finished too— And the Athenian woman by his side, That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
modern: Yes, I found him when he was asleep—so that’s taken care of too—and the Athenian woman was sleeping near him.

origin: Oh, why rebuke you him that loves you so?
modern: Why are you so rude to someone who loves you so much?

origin: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.
modern: Save that kind of harsh language for your worst enemy.

origin: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep, And kill me too.
modern: If you killed Lysander while he was sleeping, then you’re already up to your ankles in blood.

origin: The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me.
modern: He was more faithful to me than the sun is to the daytime.

origin: Would he have stolen away From sleeping Hermia?
modern: Would he have snuck away from me while I was asleep?

origin: It cannot be but thou hast murdered him.
modern: The only possibility is that you’ve murdered him.

origin: So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.
modern: A murderer should look like you do, so pale and grim.

origin: So should the murdered look, and so should I, Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.
modern: That’s how someone who’s been murdered should look, and that’s how I look.

origin: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear, As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.
modern: You’ve pierced me through the heart with your cruelty, and yet you, the murderer, look as bright and clear as a star in the sky.

origin: What’s this to my Lysander?
modern: What does that have to do with my Lysander?

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?
modern: Oh, good Demetrius, will you find him for me?

origin: Hast thou slain him then?
modern: Did you kill him, then?

origin: O brave touch!
modern: Oh, how brave of you!

origin: Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?
modern: A snake could do that as easily as you could.

origin: An adder did it, for with doubler tongue Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.
modern: A snake did do it, because no snake ever had a more forked, lying tongue than you have.

origin: I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood.
modern: I didn’t kill Lysander.

origin: Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.
modern: As far as I know, he’s not even dead.

origin: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.
modern: Then please tell me he’s all right.

origin: An if I could, what should I get therefore?
modern: If I told you that, what would I get out of it?

origin: Relent, sweet Hermia—And, Lysander, yield Thy crazèd title to my certain right.
modern: Please give in, sweet Hermia.—And Lysander, stop acting like she’s yours.

origin: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.
modern: Her father loves you, Demetrius.

origin: And she is mine, and all my right of her I do estate unto Demetrius.
modern: She’s mine, and I’m giving her to Demetrius.

origin: A privilege never to see me more.
modern: The privilege of never seeing me again.

origin: And from thy hated presence part I so.
modern: And now I’m going to leave your despised company.

origin: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
modern: You’ll never see me again, whether or not he’s dead.

origin: Here therefore for a while I will remain.
modern: So I’ll stay here for a while.

origin: And laid the love juice on some true love’s sight.
modern: That’s the way of the world.

origin: About the wood go swifter than the wind, And Helena of Athens look thou find— All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer, With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.
modern: Go around the forest, moving faster than the wind, and make sure you find Helena of Athens.—She’s lovesick, and her face is pale from all the sighing she’s been doing, because sighing is bad for the blood.

origin: Flower of this purple dye, Hit with Cupid’s archery, Sink in apple of his eye.
modern: You purple flower, hit by Cupid’s arrow, sink into the pupils of this man’s eyes.

origin: When thou wakest, if she be by, Beg of her for remedy.
modern: Young man, when you wake up, if she’s nearby, beg her to cure your lovesickness.

origin: Shall we their fond pageant see?
modern: Should we watch this ridiculous scene?

origin: Lord, what fools these mortals be!
modern: Lord, what fools these mortals are!

origin: Stand aside.
modern: Step aside.

origin: The noise they make Will cause Demetrius to awake.
modern: The noise they’re making will wake up Demetrius.

origin: Then will two at once woo one.
modern: Then the two of them will both pursue one girl.

origin: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?
modern: Why do you think I’m making fun of you when I tell you I love you?

origin: Look, when I vow, I weep.
modern: People don’t cry when they’re mocking someone.

origin: How can these things in me seem scorn to you, Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true?
modern: How can it seem like I’m making fun of you, when my tears prove that I’m sincere?

origin: You do advance your cunning more and more.
modern: You get trickier and trickier.

origin: Will you give her o'er?
modern: Will you abandon her?

origin: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.
modern: Demetrius loves her, and he doesn’t love you.

origin: Crystal is muddy.
modern: Damn it!

origin: I see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment.
modern: I see you’re all determined to gang up on me for a few laughs.

origin: You are unkind, Demetrius.
modern: You’re competing for

origin: Be not so.
modern: Don’t be cruel, Demetrius.

origin: And yours of Helena to me bequeath, Whom I do love and will do till my death.
modern: In exchange, give up your claim to love Helena, since I love her and will love her until I die.

origin: Lysander, keep thy Hermia.
modern: Lysander, keep your Hermia.

origin: I will none.
modern: I don’t want her.

origin: Helen, it is not so.
modern: Helena, it’s not true.

origin: Look, where thy love comes.
modern: Look, here comes the woman you love.

origin: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, The ear more quick of apprehension makes.
modern: It’s hard to see clearly in the dark of night, but it’s easier to hear well.

origin: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found.
modern: I couldn’t see you, Lysander, but I heard your voice, and that’s how I found you.

origin: Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
modern: Why did you leave me alone so unkindly?

origin: Why should he stay, whom love doth press to go?
modern: Why stay when love tells you to go?

origin: What love could press Lysander from my side?
modern: But what love could make my Lysander leave me?

origin: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.
modern: I had to hurry to my love, beautiful Helena, who lights up the night better than all those fiery stars.

origin: Why seek’st thou me?
modern: Why are you looking for me?

origin: Could not this make thee know The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so?
modern: Didn’t you figure out that I left you because I hate you?

origin: You speak not as you think.
modern: You can’t mean what you’re saying.

origin: It cannot be.
modern: It’s impossible.

origin: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!
modern: So, she’s in on this too!

origin: Now I perceive they have conjoined all three To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.— Injurious Hermia!
modern: Now I see that all three of them have gotten together to play this cruel trick on me.

origin: Is all the counsel that we two have shared, The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us—oh, is it all forgot?
modern: Have you forgotten all the talks we’ve had together, the vows we made to be like sisters to one another, all the hours we spent together, wishing that we never had to say goodbye—have you forgotten?

origin: All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence?
modern: Our friendship in our schooldays, our childhood innocence?

origin: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, Have with our needles created both one flower, Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, Both warbling of one song, both in one key, As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds, Had been incorporate.
modern: We used to sit together and sew one flower with our two needles, sewing it on one piece of cloth, sitting on the same cushion, singing one song in the same key, as if our hands, our sides, our voices and our minds were stuck together.

origin: So we grew together, Like to a double cherry—seeming parted But yet an union in partition— Two lovely berries molded on one stem;
modern: We grew together like twin cherries—which seemed to be separate but were also together—two lovely cherries on one stem.

origin: Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes, Misprizing what they look on, and her wit Values itself so highly that to her All matter else seems weak.
modern: There is scorn and disdain in her eyes, and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon.

origin: She cannot love Nor take no shape nor project of affection She is so self-endeared.
modern: She can’t even imagine what “love” is.

origin: Sure, I think so, And therefore certainly it were not good She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
modern: It would be bad if she knew about Benedick’s love and teased him about it.

origin: Why, you speak truth.
modern: It’s true.

origin: So turns she every man the wrong side out And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
modern: And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has.

origin: But who dare tell her so?
modern: But who would dare tell her?

origin: If I should speak, She would mock me into air.
modern: If I said something, she’d mock me so mercilessly that I’d probably disintegrate into air.

origin: O, she would laugh me Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
modern: She’d laugh me right out of my body and kill me with her wit.

origin: Therefore let Benedick, like covered fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.
modern: Like a fire that gets covered up, Benedick should smother his love and waste away.

origin: It were a better death than die with mocks, Which is as bad as die with tickling.
modern: It would be better to die that way than to die from being mocked, which is as bad as being killed by tickling.

origin: No, rather I will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion; And truly I’ll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with.
modern: No, instead I’ll go to Benedick and advise him to fight his emotions.

origin: One doth not know How much an ill word may empoison liking.
modern: You don’t know how quickly affection can be killed with a single nasty word.

origin: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong!
modern: Oh, don’t injure your cousin like that!

origin: She cannot be so much without true judgment, Having so swift and excellent a wit As she is prized to have, as to refuse So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.
modern: With the quick, intelligent wit she’s rumored to have, she can’t really be such a bad judge of character that she’d refuse a man as exceptional as Signior Benedick.

origin: He is the only man of Italy, Always excepted my dear Claudio.
modern: He’s the only worthy man in Italy, aside from my dear Claudio.

origin: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.
modern: True, he has an excellent reputation.

origin: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
modern: And he deserves it, having been excellent before he had a reputation for it.

origin: When are you married, madam?
modern: When are you getting married, madam?

origin: Why, every day, tomorrow.
modern: Tomorrow, and then every day after that.

origin: Come, go in.
modern: Come on, let’s go inside.

origin: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Aragon.
modern: I’ll stay in Messina until you’re married, and then I’ll go to Aragon.

origin: I’ll bring you thither, my lord, if you’ll vouchsafe me.
modern: I’ll go with you, my lord, if you’ll allow me.

origin: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of your marriage as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.
modern: No, taking you away from your new marriage would be like showing a child a new coat and then not letting him wear it.

origin: I will only be bold with Benedick for his company, for from the crown of his head to the sole of his foot he is all mirth.
modern: I’ll ask only Benedick to come with me, for from the top of his head to the soles of his feet he’s a joker.

origin: He hath twice or thrice cut Cupid’s bow-string, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him.
modern: He’s evaded love once or twice, and since then Cupid doesn’t dare to shoot at him.

origin: He hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.
modern: Benedick’s heart is like a bell, with his tongue as the clapper: everything his heart thinks, his tongue speaks.

origin: Gallants, I am not as I have been.
modern: Gentleman, I am not the same man I was before.

origin: So say I. Methinks you are sadder.
modern: I agree.

origin: I hope he be in love.
modern: I hope he’s in love.

origin: There’s no true drop of blood in him to be truly touched with love.
modern: There isn’t a single drop of sincerity in him that could be touched with love.

origin: If he be sad, he wants money.
modern: If he looks serious, he must need money.

origin: What, sigh for the toothache?
modern: What, are you moaning on about your toothache?

origin: Yet say I, he is in love.
modern: I repeat, he’s in love.

origin: Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
modern: Unless you’re talking about his love for this kind of foolishness—which, judging from his appearance, he has—he is no fool for love, as you pretend.

origin: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no believing old signs.
modern: If he’s not in love with a woman, then you can’t trust the usual symptoms.

origin: He brushes his hat o' mornings.
modern: He brushes his hat in the mornings.

origin: What should that bode?
modern: What do you think that means?

origin: Hath any man seen him at the barber’s?
modern: Has any man seen him at the barber’s?

origin: No, but the barber’s man hath been seen with him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already stuffed tennis balls.
modern: No, but the barber’s assistant has been seen with him.

origin: Nay, he rubs himself with civet.
modern: And he’s rubbed himself with perfume.

origin: Can you smell him out by that?
modern: Can you smell out his secret now?

origin: You embrace your charge too willingly.
modern: But when  You take up your duties too cheerfully.

origin: Her mother hath many times told me so.
modern: That’s what her mother always tells me.

origin: You have it full, Benedick.
modern: Ah, he got you back, Benedick!

origin: Truly, the lady fathers herself.—Be happy, lady, for you are like an honorable father.
modern: Congratulations, lady: you resemble a most honorable man.

origin: If Signor Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.
modern: Well, even if he is her father, I’m sure she wouldn’t want to have the head of the old man on her shoulders!

origin: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signor Benedick.
modern: I’m amazed you’re still talking, Signior Benedick.

origin: Nobody marks you.
modern: No one’s listening to you.

origin: What, my dear Lady Disdain!
modern: Look, it’s my dear Lady Disdain!

origin: Are you yet living?
modern: Aren’t you dead yet?

origin: That’s as much as to say, the sweet youth’s in love.
modern: That’s as good as proof that the sweet young man’s in love.

origin: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.
modern: The biggest clue is his seriousness.

origin: And when was he wont to wash his face?
modern: And when has he ever been known to wash his face?

origin: Yea, or to paint himself?
modern: Yes, or to wear cosmetics?

origin: For the which I hear what they say of him.
modern: I hear what they say about him for doing that.

origin: Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute string and now governed by stops— Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him.
modern: Indeed, his mocking spirit has now crawled into a  Truly, it all adds up to a serious story for Benedick.

origin: Conclude, conclude, he is in love.
modern: A conclusion, a conclusion: he is in love.

origin: Nay, but I know who loves him.
modern: Oh, and I know who loves him.

origin: She shall be buried with her face upwards.
modern: She’ll be buried with her face upwards, then.

origin: Yet is this no charm for the toothache.—Old Signior, walk aside with me.
modern: This chatter is no cure for my toothache.

origin: Tis even so.
modern: It must be.

origin: My lord and brother, God save you.
modern: My lord and brother, God save you.

origin: Good e'en, brother.
modern: Good evening, brother.

origin: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.
modern: If you don’t mind, I’d like to speak with you.

origin: In private?
modern: In private?

origin: If it please you.
modern: If you wish.

origin: Yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I would speak of concerns him.
modern: But Count Claudio can stay, for what I’m about to say concerns him.

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: You know he does.
modern: You know that he does.

origin: I know not that, when he knows what I know.
modern: I don’t know that, once he knows what I know.

origin: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.
modern: If there’s any reason we shouldn’t get married, I urge you to tell me.

origin: You may think I love you not.
modern: You may think that I don’t love you.

origin: Let that appear hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest.
modern: I hope that, after I tell you my news, you will think better of me.

origin: For my brother, I think he holds you well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect your ensuing marriage—surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.
modern: My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage—but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.

origin: Why, what’s the matter?
modern: Why, what’s the matter?

origin: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances shortened, for she has been too long a-talking of, the lady is disloyal.
modern: I came here to tell you—I’ll make this short, since she’s already been talked about for too long—the lady is unfaithful.

origin: Who, Hero?
modern: Who, Hero?

origin: Even she: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.
modern: That’s the one: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.

origin: Disloyal?
modern: Unfaithful?

origin: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness.
modern: The word is too good to represent her wickedness.

origin: I could say she were worse.
modern: She is worse than wicked.

origin: Think you of a worse title, and I will fit her to it.
modern: If you can think of a more awful title, I’ll call her that.

origin: Wonder not till further warrant.
modern: But don’t keep wondering without more proof.

origin: Go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding day.
modern: Come with me tonight, and you’ll see a man enter her bedroom chamber—even tonight, the night before her wedding.

origin: If you love her then, tomorrow wed her.
modern: If you still love her after that, then marry her tomorrow.

origin: But it would better fit your honor to change your mind.
modern: But you would be more honorable if you changed your mind.

origin: I will not think it.
modern: I won’t consider it.

origin: If I see anything tonight why I should not marry her, tomorrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.
modern: If I see anything tonight that convinces me not to marry her, I’ll shame her tomorrow in the very congregation where I would have married her.

origin: And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join with thee to disgrace her.
modern: And since I wooed her in your name, I’ll join you in disgracing her.

origin: Bear it coldly but till midnight and let the issue show itself.
modern: Remain calm until midnight, and then you’ll see what the trouble is.

origin: O day untowardly turned!
modern: Oh, this day has turned into a disaster!

origin: O mischief strangely thwarting!
modern: Oh, mischief has ruined our plans!

origin: O plague right well prevented!
modern: Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God!

origin: So will you say when you have seen the sequel.
modern: That’s what you’ll say once you’ve seen part two.

origin: Are you good men and true?
modern: Are you all good and honest men?

origin: Come hither, neighbor Seacole.
modern: Come here, Sir Seacole.

origin: God hath blessed you with a good name.
modern: God has blessed you with a good name.

origin: To be a well-favored man is the gift of fortune, but to write and read comes by nature.
modern: To be good-looking is a matter of luck, but to read and write is a natural gift.

origin: Both which, Master Constable— You have.
modern: Both of which, master constable— You have.

origin: I knew it would be your answer.
modern: I knew that would be your answer.

origin: Well, for your favor, sir, why, give God thanks, and make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appear when there is no need of such vanity.
modern: Well, for your good looks, sir, thank God and don’t boast about it.
