origin: You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lantern.
modern: You’re thought to be the most

origin: How if he will not stand?
modern: you will  And what if he won’t stop?

origin: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go and presently call the rest of the watch together and thank God you are rid of a knave.
modern: Then immediately call the rest of the watch together and thank God that you’ve gotten rid of such a criminal.

origin: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’s subjects.
modern: If he won’t stop when he’s told to, then he isn’t one of the Prince’s subjects.

origin: We know what belongs to a watch.
modern: We know what’s appropriate for a watch.

origin: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend.
modern: Why, you speak like an experienced and quiet watchman.

origin: Well, you are to call at all the alehouses and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.
modern: Also, you’re supposed to visit all the bars and tell anyone who’s drunk to go home and go to bed.

origin: How if they will not?
modern: And what if they won’t go?

origin: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober.
modern: Well then, leave them alone until they’re sober.

origin: If they make you not then the better answer, you may say they are not the men you took them for.
modern: If even then they don’t answer to your satisfaction, you can say that they’re not the men you thought they were.

origin: Well, sir.
modern: Very good, sir.

origin: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?
modern: So if we know that a man is a thief, should we try to arrest him?

origin: You, constable, are to present the Prince’s own person.
modern: You, constable, are representing the Prince himself.

origin: If you meet the Prince in the night, you may stay him.
modern: If you meet the Prince in the night, you can order him to stop.

origin: Nay, by 'r Lady, that I think he cannot.
modern: No, by our Lady, I don’t think he can.

origin: Five shillings to one on ’t, with any man that knows the statutes, he may stay him—marry, not without the Prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offense to stay a man against his will.
modern: I’ll bet any man who knows the law five shillings to one on it.

origin: By 'r lady, I think it be so.
modern: By our Lady, I think that’s true.

origin: An there be any matter of weight chances, call up me.
modern: And if anything important happens, find me and let me know.

origin: Well, masters, we hear our charge.
modern: Well gentlemen, we’ve heard our assignment.

origin: Let us go sit here upon the church bench till two, and then all to bed.
modern: Let’s sit here on the church bench until two and then go off to bed.

origin: One word more, honest neighbors.
modern: One more thing, good gentlemen.

origin: I pray you watch about Signior Leonato’s door, for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight.
modern: Watch over Signior Leonato’s house; with the wedding being held there tomorrow, there’s a great to-do there tonight.

origin: Adieu, be vigitant, I beseech you.
modern: Adieu.

origin: What Conrade!
modern: Be  Conrade!

origin: Conrade, I say!
modern: Conrade, I say!

origin: Mass, and my elbow itched, I thought there would a scab follow.
modern: Come to think of it, I thought I felt a scab there.

origin: I will owe thee an answer for that.
modern: I’ll get you for that.

origin: And now forward with thy tale.
modern: Now get on with your story.

origin: Stand thee close, then, under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee.
modern: Since it’s drizzling, stand under this overhang with me and, like a true drunk, I’ll tell you everything.

origin: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.
modern: You should know I’ve earned a thousand gold pieces from Don John.

origin: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
modern: Is it possible that any crime could be so valuable?

origin: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich.
modern: You should ask instead if it’s possible that any criminal could be so rich.

origin: For when rich villains have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price they will.
modern: Because when rich villains need poor villains' services, those poor ones can name the price.

origin: I wonder at it.
modern: I can’t believe it.

origin: That shows thou art unconfirmed.
modern: That only proves how inexperienced you are.

origin: Thou knowest that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.
modern: You know that the style of a man’s jacket or hat or coat means nothing.

origin: Yes, it is apparel.
modern: Yes, it’s just clothing.

origin: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.
modern: Yes, fashion is fashion.

origin: Tush, I may as well say the fool’s the fool.
modern: C’mon, I might as well say the fool’s the fool!

origin: Didst thou not hear somebody?
modern: But don’t you see what a    Did you hear someone?

origin: No, ’twas the vane on the house.
modern: Just the weathervane moving.

origin: But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?
modern: But you’re all wound up about fashion, too.

origin: Not so, neither.
modern: No, I’m not wound up.

origin: But know that I have tonight wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero.
modern: But I will tell you that I seduced Margaret, the Lady Hero’s waiting woman, tonight.

origin: I should first tell thee how the Prince, Claudio and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.
modern: I should backtrack and begin with how my master, Don John, arranged for the Prince, Claudio, and himself to witness this friendly encounter from the orchard.

origin: Then is courtesy a turncoat.
modern: That makes Lady Courtesy a traitor.

origin: But it is certain I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted.
modern: All ladies love me, except you.

origin: And I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none.
modern: It’s too bad I’m so hard-hearted, because I really don’t love anyone.

origin: A dear happiness to women.
modern: Women are lucky, then.

origin: They would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor.
modern: You would make a nasty suitor.

origin: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.
modern: I would rather listen to my dog bark at a crow than hear a man swear that he loves me.

origin: God keep your Ladyship still in that mind, so some gentle- man or other shall ’scape a predestinate scratched face.
modern: Well, I hope you stay in that frame of mind or some poor man will end up with his face all scratched up.

origin: Scratching could not make it worse an ’twere such a face as yours were.
modern: If he has a face like yours, a good scratching couldn’t make him look any worse.

origin: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.
modern: Listen to you, instructing me like a parrot would.

origin: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.
modern: I’d rather be a squawking bird than an animal like you.

origin: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good a continuer.
modern: I wish my horse moved as fast as your mouth and was as tireless.

origin: I have done.
modern: That’s it—I’m done.

origin: You always end with a jade’s trick.
modern: You always slip out of the argument like this.

origin: I know you of old.
modern: I know you from before.

origin: That is the sum of all, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
modern: And that’s everything, Leonato.—Claudio, Benedick—my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina.

origin: I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month, and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer.
modern: I told him we’ll stay for at least a month, and he says that he hopes we’ll stay longer.

origin: I dare swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
modern: I think he’s actually serious, and not just being polite.

origin: And thought they Margaret was Hero?
modern: And they thought Margaret was Hero?

origin: We charge you, in the Prince’s name, stand!
modern: We charge you, in the Prince’s name, to stop!

origin: Call up the right Master Constable.
modern: Call up the Master Constable Dogberry.

origin: We have here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that ever was known in the commonwealth.
modern: We have  And one of them is the criminal Deformed.

origin: And one Deformed is one of them.
modern: I know him; he wears a lock of hair.

origin: I know him; he wears a lock.
modern: Gentlemen, gentlemen—   Gentlemen, don’t speak.

origin: Masters, masters—   warrant you.
modern: We

origin: Masters, never speak, we charge you, let us obey you go with us.
modern: We’re probably a very valuable catch for these guys.

origin: A commodity in question, I warrant you.—Come, we’ll obey you.
modern: Let’s go, we’ll obey you.

origin: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise.
modern: Good Ursula, go wake my cousin and ask her to get up.

origin: I will, lady.
modern: I will, lady.

origin: And bid her come hither.
modern: And request that she come here.

origin: Well.
modern: Very well.

origin: Troth, I think your other rebato were better.
modern: Really, I think your other ruff is better.

origin: No, pray thee, good Meg, I’ll wear this.
modern: No, please good Meg, I’ll wear this one.

origin: By my troth, ’s not so good, and I warrant your cousin will say so.
modern: Honestly, it’s not as good as the other one, and I’m sure your cousin will agree with me.

origin: My cousin’s a fool, and thou art another.
modern: My cousin’s a fool, and you are too.

origin: I’ll wear none but this.
modern: I’ll wear this one and none other.

origin: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair were a thought browner; and your gown’s a most rare fashion, i' faith.
modern: I like your new wig and headdress, though I’d like it more if the hair were a shade browner.

origin: I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown that they praise so.
modern: You know, I saw the Duchess of Milan’s gown, the one that everyone praises so highly.

origin: Oh, that exceeds, they say.
modern: Oh, they say that dress surpasses all others.

origin: But for a fine, quaint, graceful, and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on ’t.
modern: But for a fine, elegant, graceful, and excellent dress, yours is worth ten of those.

origin: God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is exceeding heavy.
modern: I hope I enjoy wearing it, for my heart is very heavy.

origin: Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.
modern: It will be made even heavier soon—by the weight of a man.

origin: Of what, lady?
modern: Shame of what, lady?

origin: Is not marriage honorable in a beggar?
modern: Sex and marriage are honorable things—even for a beggar, right?

origin: Is not your lord honorable without marriage?
modern: And isn’t your husband an honorable man?

origin: Good morrow, sweet Hero.
modern: Good morning, sweet Hero.

origin: Why, how now?
modern: Why do you sound so odd?

origin: Do you speak in the sick tune?
modern: Are you ill?

origin: I am out of all other tune, methinks.
modern: You sound out of tune.

origin: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.
modern: You sing, and I’ll dance.

origin: O illegitimate construction!
modern: Never!

origin: These gloves the Count sent me, they are an excellent perfume.
modern: The Count sent me an excellent pair of perfumed gloves.

origin: I am stuffed, cousin.
modern: Sorry, I’m all stuffed.

origin: Even since you left it.
modern: Ever since you lost yours.

origin: Doth not my wit become me rarely?
modern: Doesn’t my wit suit me well?

origin: It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap.
modern: It doesn’t get seen enough; you should wear it in your cap, the way fools wear coxcombs.

origin: By my troth, I am sick.
modern: God, I’m really sick.

origin: I meant plain holy thistle.
modern: I just meant that you should use some holy thistle.

origin: You may think perchance that I think you are in love.
modern: Maybe you think that I think you’re in love.

origin: Nay, by 'r Lady, I am not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or that you can be in love.
modern: No, by Our Lady, I’m not such a fool to think what I please, and I don’t please to think what I can, and in fact I cannot think, even if I could think my heart right past thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love.

origin: Yet Benedick was such another, and now is he become a man.
modern: But Benedick was once an enemy of love as well, and now he’s become a real man.

origin: He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.
modern: He swore that he’d never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly.

origin: And how you may be converted I know not, but methinks you look with your eyes as other women do.
modern: And yet I think you look with your eyes just like every other woman does.

origin: Not a false gallop.
modern: It’s not a false gallop, anyway.

origin: Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signor Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church.
modern: Madam, we have to go: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, Don John, and all the gentlemen of the town have come to bring you to church.

origin: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
modern: Good cousin, good Meg, good Ursula, come help me get dressed.

origin: What would you with me, honest neighbor?
modern: What do you want from me, my good man?

origin: Marry, this it is, sir.
modern: Indeed, sir, it is.

origin: Yes, in truth it is, sir.
modern: Yes, it truly is.

origin: What is it, my good friends?
modern: What’s the news, my good friends?

origin: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the matter.
modern: Sorry, sir, Goodman Verges tends to ramble.

origin: It pleases your Worship to say so, but we are the poor duke’s officers.
modern: Thank you for saying that, your Worship, but we’re just the poor duke’s officers.

origin: But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.
modern: But truly, if I were as

origin: All thy tediousness on me, ah?
modern: Oh, so you’d give me all your tediousness?

origin: Yea, an ’twere a thousand pound more than ’tis, for I hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the city, and though I be but a poor man, I am glad to hear it.
modern: Yes, even if I had a thousand more pounds than that, for I hear that you are  Me, too.

origin: Gifts that God gives.
modern: God gives those gifts—I had nothing to do with it.

origin: I must leave you.
modern: Now I must return to the wedding.

origin: One word, sir.
modern: One more thing, sir.

origin: Take their examination yourself and bring it me.
modern: Examine them yourselves, then bring me your findings.

origin: I am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.
modern: Now I’m in a great hurry, as I’m sure you can see.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to her husband.
modern: My lord, they’re waiting for you to give your daughter away to Claudio.

origin: I am ready.
modern: I’m coming.

origin: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole.
modern: Go to Francis Seacole, the constable of the watch.

origin: Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail.
modern: Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail.

origin: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you.
modern: We won’t hold back any of our wisdom.

origin: Here’s that shall drive some of them to a noncome.
modern: We’ll drive them to a

origin: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.
modern: I am being serious, my lord.

origin: I thank you.
modern: Thank you.

origin: I am not of many words, but I thank you.
modern: I’m not a man who talks a lot, but I thank you.

origin: Please it your Grace lead on?
modern: If it pleases you, your highness, will you lead us all inside?

origin: Your hand, Leonato.
modern: Give me your hand, Leonato.

origin: We will go together.
modern: We will go in together.

origin: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?
modern: Benedick, did you notice Signior Leonato’s daughter?

origin: I noted her not, but I looked on her.
modern: I saw her, but I didn’t notice her.

origin: Is she not a modest young lady?
modern: Isn’t she a well-mannered young lady?

origin: Do you question me as an honest man should do, for my simple true judgment?
modern: Do you want my true opinion?

origin: Or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
modern: Or do you want me to criticize her like I do all women?

origin: No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.
modern: No, please, speak seriously.

origin: Why, i' faith, methinks she’s too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise.
modern: Well, it seems to me that she is too short to be praised highly, too dark to be praised fairly, and too small to be praised greatly.

origin: Only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome, and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.
modern: I can only say this about her: if she looked different than she does, she would be ugly, and since she can’t be anything but herself, I don’t like her.

origin: Thou thinkest I am in sport.
modern: You think I’m kidding.

origin: I pray thee tell me truly how thou lik’st her.
modern: Please tell me seriously what you think of her.

origin: Come, Friar Francis, be brief, only to the plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.
modern: All right, Friar Francis, let’s keep this short.

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count?
modern: No, he comes to be married  Lady, do you come here to be married to this count?

origin: I do.
modern: I do.

origin: If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not be conjoined, charge you on your souls to utter it.
modern: If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage, I order you on your souls to say so.

origin: Know you any, Hero?
modern: Do you know any, Hero?

origin: None, my lord.
modern: None, my lord.

origin: Know you any, count?
modern: Do you know any, count?

origin: I dare make his answer, none.
modern: I’m sure I can answer for him—he doesn’t know any, either.

origin: O, what men dare do!
modern: Oh, the things men dare to do!

origin: What men may do!
modern: The things men are allowed to do!

origin: What men daily do, not knowing what they do!
modern: The things men do daily, not knowing what they’re doing!

origin: How now, interjections?
modern: What, are we playing with interjections?

origin: Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!
modern: Well then, add some interjections that indicate laughter, like  Hold on, Friar.

origin: As freely, son, as God did give her me.
modern: As freely, son, as God gave her to me.

origin: And what have I to give you back whose worth May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?
modern: And what should I give you that would be equal in value to this rare and precious gift?

origin: Nothing, unless you render her again.
modern: Nothing, sir, except grandchildren.

origin: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.— There, Leonato, take her back again.
modern: There, Leonato, take your daughter back.

origin: She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.
modern: She only appears honorable from the outside.

origin: Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
modern: Look, how she blushes like a virgin!

origin: Oh, what authority and show of truth Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
modern: Oh, sin can disguise itself so artfully!

origin: Comes not that blood as modest evidence To witness simple virtue?
modern: Doesn’t that rising blush suggest that she is virtuous and innocent?

origin: Would you not swear, All you that see her, that she were a maid By these exterior shows?
modern: All of you who are looking at her, wouldn’t you swear that she’s a virgin, judging by these outward shows?

origin: But she is none.
modern: But she is no virgin.

origin: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed.
modern: She has been in a man’s bed.

origin: Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.
modern: She blushes from guilt, not modesty.

origin: What do you mean, my lord?
modern: What do you mean, my lord?

origin: Dear my lord, if you in your own proof Have vanquished the resistance of her youth And made defeat of her virginity— I know what you would say: if I have known her, You will say she did embrace me as a husband, And so extenuate the forehand sin.
modern: My dear lord, if it was you who conquered her and took her virginity— I know what you’re about to say.

origin: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?
modern: And have I ever seemed less than modest or appropriate to you?

origin: Out on thee, seeming!
modern: Curse you for your false appearances!

origin: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?
modern: Is that why you’re talking so wildly?

origin: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?
modern: Good Prince, say something!

origin: What should I speak?
modern: What should I say?

origin: I stand dishonored, that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale.
modern: I’ve been dishonored: I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore.

origin: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?
modern: Are you really saying these things, or am I dreaming?

origin: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.
modern: They’re really being spoken, sir, and they’re true.

origin: This looks not like a nuptial.
modern: This doesn’t look like a wedding.

origin: True!
modern: It’s true!

origin: O God!
modern: Oh God!

origin: Leonato, stand I here?
modern: Leonato, am I standing here?

origin: Is this the Prince?
modern: Is this the Prince?

origin: Is this the Prince’s brother?
modern: Is this the Prince’s brother?

origin: Is this face Hero’s?
modern: Is this face Hero’s?

origin: Are our eyes our own?
modern: Are these our eyes?

origin: All this is so, but what of this, my lord?
modern: Yes, that’s all true—but what do you mean by it, my lord?

origin: Let me but move one question to your daughter, And by that fatherly and kindly power That you have in her, bid her answer truly.
modern: Let me just ask her one question, and by your authority as her father, order her to answer truthfully.

origin: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.
modern: As my child, I order you to do so.

origin: Oh, God defend me!
modern: Oh, God help me!

origin: how am I beset!— What kind of catechizing call you this?
modern: What kind of game is this?

origin: To make you answer truly to your name.
modern: We just want you to answer to your real name.

origin: Is it not Hero?
modern: Isn’t my name Hero?

origin: Who can blot that name With any just reproach?
modern: Who can stain that name with a just accusation?

origin: Marry, that can Hero!
modern: Indeed, Hero herself can!

origin: Hero itself can blot out Hero’s virtue.
modern: You’ve stained your virtue with your own actions.

origin: What man was he talked with you yesternight Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
modern: What man were you talking to at your window last night, between the hours of midnight and one?

origin: Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.
modern: If you’re a virgin, you’ll answer this question.

origin: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
modern: I wasn’t talking to any man at that time, my lord.

origin: Upon mine honor, Myself, my brother, and this grievèd count Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain, Confessed the vile encounters they have had A thousand times in secret.
modern: I swear on my honor that we saw and heard Hero talking to a brute at her window last night.

origin: There is not chastity enough in language, Without offense, to utter them.—Thus, pretty lady, I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.
modern: Pretty lady, I’m much ashamed of your shocking behavior.

origin: Why, how now, cousin!
modern: What’s wrong, cousin?

origin: wherefore sink you down?
modern: Why have you collapsed?

origin: Come, let us go.
modern: Come, let’s go.

origin: These things, come thus to light, Smother her spirits up.
modern: These revelations have overwhelmed her.

origin: How doth the lady?
modern: How is she?

origin: Dead, I think.—Help, uncle!— Hero, why, Hero!
modern: She’s dead, I think.—Help, uncle!—Hero, why Hero!

origin: Uncle!
modern: Uncle!

origin: Signor Benedick!
modern: Signior Benedick!

origin: Friar!
modern: Friar!

origin: Death is the fairest cover for her shame That may be wished for.
modern: Death is the best way to cover over her shame.

origin: How now, cousin Hero!
modern: How are you, Hero?

origin: Yea, wherefore should she not?
modern: Yes, why shouldn’t she?

origin: Wherefore!
modern: Why not!

origin: Why, doth not every earthly thing Cry shame upon her?
modern: Isn’t every living thing condemning her?

origin: Grieved I I had but one?
modern: Am I sorry that I only had one child?

origin: Chid I for that at frugal Nature’s frame?
modern: Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty?

origin: O, one too much by thee!
modern: Oh, one child is one too many!

origin: Why had I one?
modern: Why did I ever have one?

origin: Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
modern: Why did you once seem lovely to me?

origin: Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates, Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy, I might have said, “No part of it is mine; This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
modern: Why didn’t I just adopt a beggar’s child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?

origin: Sir, sir, be patient.
modern: Sir, sir, calm down.

origin: For my part, I am so attired in wonder I know not what to say.
modern: I’m so amazed by this, I don’t know what to say.

origin: Oh, on my soul, my cousin is belied!
modern: Oh, on my soul, my cousin has been slandered falsely!

origin: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
modern: Lady, did you sleep in her room last night?

origin: No, truly not, although until last night I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.
modern: No, I didn’t, but I did every night for the past year.

origin: Confirmed, confirmed!
modern: Then it’s confirmed!

origin: I have marked A thousand blushing apparitions To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames In angel whiteness beat away those blushes, And in her eye there hath appeared a fire To burn the errors that these princes hold Against her maiden truth.
modern: And in her eyes I see a fire that would seem to burn away the lies the princes have told about her chastity.

origin: Friar, it cannot be.
modern: But she must be, Friar.

origin: Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left Is that she will not add to her damnation A sin of perjury.
modern: You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges: she doesn’t want to add perjury to her list of sins.

origin: There is some strange misprision in the princes.
modern: The princes are under some strange misunderstanding.

origin: Two of them have the very bent of honor, And if their wisdoms be misled in this, The practice of it lives in John the Bastard, Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.
modern: Two of them are completely honorable, and if they have been tricked in this, we must blame John the Bastard, who lives to create conflict.

origin: I know not.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor, The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
modern: If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands.

origin: Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine Nor age so eat up my invention Nor fortune made such havoc of my means Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends But they shall find, awaked in such a kind, Both strength of limb and policy of mind, Ability in means and choice of friends, To quit me of them throughly.
modern: Age hasn’t dried up my body or eroded my intelligence so much, and luck hasn’t robbed me of so much of my fortune, and my bad ways haven’t deprived me of so many friends, that they won’t find me ready to seek revenge both physically and mentally, with money and friends at my disposal.

origin: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case.
modern: Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice.

origin: Your daughter here the princes left for dead.
modern: The princes left your daughter here for dead.

origin: Let her awhile be secretly kept in And publish it that she is dead indeed.
modern: Hide her for a while in your house, and tell everyone that she has, in fact, died.

origin: Maintain a mourning ostentation, And on your family’s old monument Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites That appertain unto a burial.
modern: Make a bug show of mourning for her, hang sad epitaphs up at your family’s tomb, and perform all the appropriate burial ceremonies.

origin: What shall become of this?
modern: Why should we do this?

origin: What will this do?
modern: What will this do?

origin: That is some good.
modern: That will be a good thing.

origin: She, dying, as it must so be maintained, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer.
modern: We’ll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions.

origin: So will it fare with Claudio.
modern: That’s how Claudio will respond.

origin: But if all aim but this be leveled false, The supposition of the lady’s death Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
modern: And even if they don’t, at least Hero’s supposed death will stop the rumors of her infidelity.

origin: And if it sort not well, you may conceal her, As best befits her wounded reputation, In some reclusive and religious life, Out of all eyes, tongues, minds, and injuries.
modern: And if it doesn’t go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation—away from the public’s eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.

origin: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you.
modern: Signior Leonato, listen to the friar’s plan.

origin: And though you know my inwardness and love Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio, Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this As secretly and justly as your soul Should with your body.
modern: And even though you know I’m very close to the Prince and Claudio, I swear I’ll keep your counsel and deal with this secretly and justly.

origin: Would you buy her, that you enquire after her?
modern: Are you thinking of buying her?

origin: But speak you this with a sad brow?
modern: But tell me, are you speaking seriously?

origin: Or do you play the flouting jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter?
modern: Or are you just teasing?

origin: Come, in what key shall a man take you to go in the song?
modern: If I’m going to sing along with you, I need to know what key you’re singing in.

origin: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.
modern: I think she’s the most wonderful woman I’ve ever laid eyes on.

origin: I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter.
modern: I’m still young enough to see without glasses, and I don’t see what you’re talking about.

origin: But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?
modern: But, hey, this doesn’t mean you’re looking to get married, does it?

origin: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.
modern: Even if I had sworn never to marry, I wouldn’t trust myself to keep that promise if Hero would marry me.

origin: Is ’t come to this?
modern: What’s going on these days?

origin: In faith, hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?
modern: Isn’t there one man left in the world who knows not to take a wife?

origin: Look, Don Pedro is returned to seek you.
modern: Look, Don Pedro has come back for you.

origin: Tis well consented.
modern: This is a good agreement.

origin: Presently away, For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.— Come, lady, die to live.
modern: Come, lady; you must die in order to live.

origin: This wedding day Perhaps is but prolonged.
modern: Hopefully, your wedding day is only postponed.

origin: Have patience and endure.
modern: Have patience and endure.

origin: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?
modern: Lady Beatrice, have you been crying this entire time?

origin: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
modern: Yes, and I’ll keep crying a while longer.

origin: I will not desire that.
modern: I don’t wish that on you.

origin: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
modern: I really believe your cousin was falsely accused.

origin: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her!
modern: Oh, the man who avenged her could ask anything of me!

origin: Is there any way to show such friendship?
modern: Is there any way I could show such friendship to you?

origin: A very even way, but no such friend.
modern: A very clear way, but there is no friend who will undertake it.

origin: May a man do it?
modern: Can a man do it?

origin: It is a man’s office, but not yours.
modern: It’s a job meant for a man, but not you.

origin: I do love nothing in the world so well as you.
modern: There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you.

origin: Is not that strange?
modern: Isn’t that strange?

origin: As strange as the thing I know not.
modern: It’s as strange as this other thing which I don’t understand.

origin: I am sorry for my cousin.
modern: I feel awful for my cousin.

origin: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.
modern: By my sword, Beatrice, you love me.

origin: With no sauce that can be devised to it.
modern: Not with any sauce they could provide for them.

origin: I protest I love thee.
modern: I swear, I love you.

origin: Why then, God forgive me.
modern: Well then, God forgive me!

origin: What offense, sweet Beatrice?
modern: Why, what have you done, sweet Beatrice?

origin: You have stayed me in a happy hour.
modern: You got to me first.

origin: I was about to protest I loved you.
modern: I was about to swear that I loved you.

origin: And do it with all thy heart.
modern: Then do so, with all your heart.

origin: I love you with so much of my heart that none is left to protest.
modern: I love you with so much of my heart that none of it is left to protest with.

origin: Come, bid me do anything for thee.
modern: Come, ask me to do anything for you.

origin: Kill Claudio.
modern: Kill Claudio.

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: Not for the wide world.
modern: I wouldn’t do that for the whole wide world.

origin: You kill me to deny it.
modern: Then, rejecting my request, you kill

origin: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.
modern: Wait, sweet Beatrice.

origin: I am gone, though I am here.
modern: My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone.

origin: There is no love in you.
modern: You don’t really love me.

origin: Nay, I pray you let me go.
modern: I beg you to let me go.

origin: Beatrice— In faith, I will go.
modern: Beatrice— I swear, I’m going.

origin: We’ll be friends first.
modern: Not until we part as friends.

origin: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.
modern: How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy.

origin: Is Claudio thine enemy?
modern: Is Claudio your enemy?

origin: Is he not approved in the height a villain, that hath slandered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman?
modern: Hasn’t he proven himself to be a great villain—slandering, scorning, and dishonoring my cousin?

origin: Oh, that I were a man!
modern: Oh, I wish I were a man!

origin: What, bear her in hand until they come to take hands and then, with public accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancor—O God, that I were a man!
modern: He pretended that everything was fine until the moment they were exchanging vows, and then—with public accusation, blatant slander, pure hatred—Oh God, if only I were a man!

origin: I would eat his heart in the marketplace.
modern: I would rip his heart out in public and eat it.

origin: Hear me, Beatrice— Talk with a man out at a window!
modern: Listen to me, Beatrice— Talking with a man outside her bedroom window!

origin: A proper saying!
modern: A likely story!

origin: Nay, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.
modern: No, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she’s been wronged, she’s been slandered, she’s been ruined.

origin: Beat—
modern: Beat—

origin: Princes and counties!
modern: Princes and counts!

origin: Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!
modern: He’s a proper count, that Count Sugarplum, a sweet gentleman, for sure!

origin: Oh, that I were a man for his sake!
modern: Oh, if only I were a man!

origin: Or that I had any friend would be a man for my sake!
modern: Or had a friend who would be a man for me!

origin: But manhood is melted into curtsies, valor into compliment, and men are only turned into tongue, and trim ones too.
modern: All this conversing has turned men into tongues—and fancy ones, at that.

origin: He is now as valiant as Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it.
modern: The man who tells a lie and swears by it is now considered as brave as Hercules.

origin: I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.
modern: I can’t make myself a man by wishing I were, so as a woman I’ll die, from grieving.

origin: Tarry, good Beatrice.
modern: Wait, good Beatrice.

origin: By this hand, I love thee.
modern: I swear by this hand that I love you.

origin: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.
modern: Don’t just swear by it; put your hand to some use that will prove you love me.

origin: Enough, I am engaged.
modern: That’s enough for me, then.

origin: I will challenge him.
modern: I’ll challenge him.

origin: I will kiss your hand, and so I leave you.
modern: I’ll kiss your hand, and with that I leave you.

origin: By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dear account.
modern: I swear that Claudio will pay dearly for this.

origin: Go comfort your cousin.
modern: Keep me in your thoughts and go comfort your cousin.

origin: Which be the malefactors?
modern: Which ones are the malefactors?

origin: Marry, that am I and my partner.
modern: Sir, that would be me and my partner.

origin: Let them come before Master Constable.
modern: Have them come in front of the master constable.

origin: Yea, marry, let them come before me.
modern: Yes, indeed, bring them before me.

origin: What’s your name, friend?
modern: What’s your name, friend?

origin: Borachio.
modern: Borachio.

origin: Pray, write down, “Borachio.”—Yours, sirrah?
modern: Please, write down “Borachio.”—And yours?

origin: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.
modern: I’m a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

origin: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Masters, do you serve God?
modern: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Gentlemen, are you good Christians, and do you serve God?

origin: Yea, sir, we hope.
modern: Yes, sir, we hope so.

origin: How answer you for yourselves?
modern: How do you both plead?

origin: Marry, sir, we say we are none.
modern: Honestly, sir, we say that we are not criminals.

origin: A marvelous witty fellow, I assure you, but I will go about with him.—Come you hither, sirrah, a word in your ear.
modern: He’s a marvelously witty fellow, no doubt, but I’ll outmaneuver him.—Come over here; I’ll whisper a word in your ear.

origin: Sir, I say to you it is thought you are false knaves.
modern: Sir, I tell you we believe you’re both lying criminals.

origin: Sir, I say to you we are none.
modern: Sir, I tell you that we are not.

origin: Well, stand aside.—'Fore God, they are both in a ale.
modern: Well, okay.—I swear to God, both their stories match.

origin: Have you writ down that they are none?
modern: Have you written that down, that they aren’t criminals?

origin: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine.
modern: Master Constable, you’re going about this all wrong.

origin: You must call forth the watch that are their accusers.
modern: First, you have to speak to the watchmen who accused them.

origin: Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way.—Let the watch come forth.
modern: Yes, good idea; that’s the

origin: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.
modern: This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’s brother, was a villain.

origin: Write down Prince John a villain.
modern: Write down that Prince John is a villain.

origin: I do not like thy look, I promise thee.
modern: I swear, I don’t like the look of you.

origin: Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.
modern: That Don John had given him a thousand pieces of gold for wrongfully accusing the Lady Hero.

origin: Flat burglary as ever was committed.
modern: That’s burglary, that is.

origin: Yea, by Mass, that it is.
modern: Yes, by God, that it is.

origin: What else, fellow?
modern: What else did you hear?

origin: What else?
modern: What else?

origin: This is all.
modern: That’s all.

origin: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away.
modern: I’ll get there first and tell him what we found out.

origin: God’s my life, where’s the Sexton?
modern: Honest to God, where’s the sexton?

origin: Let him write down the Prince’s officer “coxcomb.” Come, bind them.—Thou naughty varlet!
modern: Come on, tie them up.

origin: Away!
modern: Get away from me, you ass!

origin: You are an ass, you are an ass!
modern: You ass!

origin: Dost thou not suspect my place?
modern: Don’t you suspect my office?

origin: Dost thou not suspect my years?
modern: Don’t you

origin: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself, And ’tis not wisdom thus to second grief Against yourself.
modern: If you keep on the way you’ve been going, you’ll kill yourself.

origin: I pray thee, cease thy counsel, Which falls into mine ears as profitless As water in a sieve.
modern: Stop advising me; your words pass through my ears like water through a sieve.

origin: Bring me a father that so loved his child, Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine, And bid him speak of patience.
modern: Find a father who loved his child as overwhelmingly as I loved Hero and ask

origin: Therefore give me no counsel.
modern: So don’t advise me.

origin: I pray thee, peace.
modern: Please, leave me alone.

origin: I will be flesh and blood, For there was never yet philosopher That could endure the toothache patiently, However they have writ the style of gods And made a push at chance and sufferance.
modern: I intend to be flesh and blood, not airy philosophy, for there has never yet been a philosopher who could endure a toothache patiently, even though they all write as if they had risen above human suffering and misfortune.

origin: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself.
modern: But don’t take all that pain on yourself.

origin: Make those that do offend you suffer too.
modern: Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too.

origin: There thou speak’st reason.
modern: Now you’re talking.

origin: Nay, I will do so.
modern: I definitely will.

origin: My soul doth tell me Hero is belied, And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince And all of them that thus dishonor her.
modern: In my soul, I believe Hero has been falsely accused.

origin: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
modern: The Prince and Claudio are hurrying this way.

origin: Good e'en, good e'en.
modern: Good evening, good evening.

origin: Good day to both of you.
modern: Good day to both of you.

origin: Hear you, my lords—     We have some haste, Leonato.
modern: Listen, my lords— We’re in a bit of a hurry, Leonato.

origin: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.
modern: Your highness will have to force me to tell.

origin: Amen, if you love her, for the lady is very well worthy.
modern: It’s good if you love Hero, because she’s worthy of your love.

origin: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.
modern: You’re trying to trick me, my lord.

origin: By my troth, I speak my thought.
modern: I swear, I’m telling you what I honestly think.

origin: Some haste, my lord!
modern: A bit of a hurry, my lord!

origin: Well, fare you well, my lord.
modern: Well then, good bye, my lord.

origin: Are you so hasty now?
modern: You’re in a hurry, are you?

origin: Well, all is one.
modern: Well then, don’t bother.

origin: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
modern: Come on, don’t quarrel with us, good old man.

origin: If he could right himself with quarreling, Some of us would lie low.
modern: If it’s fighting he is after, some of us here should run and hide.

origin: Who wrongs him?
modern: Who has wronged him?

origin: Marry, thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou.
modern: Indeed, you have wronged me, you liar.

origin: Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword.
modern: Don’t bother trying to intimidate me by putting your hand on your sword.

origin: I fear thee not.
modern: I’m not scared of you.

origin: Marry, beshrew my hand If it should give your age such cause of fear.
modern: Curse my hand if it ever threatened an old man like you.

origin: In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.
modern: Really, I had no intention of going for my sword.

origin: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
modern: Damn you, don’t mock and sneer at me.

origin: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool, As under privilege of age to brag What I have done being young, or what would do Were I not old.
modern: I’m not a doddering old fool who brags about the things he did when he was young, and what he would do now if he weren’t so old.

origin: Know, Claudio, to thy head, Thou hast so wronged mine innocent child and me That I am forced to lay my reverence by, And with gray hairs and bruise of many days Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
modern: Claudio, I’m telling you right to your face that you have wronged me and my innocent child.

origin: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
modern: You have ruined my innocent child.

origin: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart, And she lies buried with her ancestors, Oh, in a tomb where never scandal slept Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.
modern: Your slander has broken her heart, and now she lies buried with her ancestors in a tomb—ancestors who had never been tainted by scandal until you caused one with your wickedness.

origin: My villainy?
modern: My wickedness?

origin: Thine, Claudio, thine, I say.
modern: Yours, Claudio, yours, I say.

origin: You say not right, old man.
modern: You’ve got it wrong, old man.

origin: My lord, my lord, I’ll prove it on his body if he dare, Despite his nice fence and his active practice, His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.
modern: I’ll beat him despite his fancy fencing techniques and all the practicing he does, despite his youth and manliness.

origin: Away!
modern: Not a chance!

origin: I will not have to do with you.
modern: I’ll have nothing to do with you.

origin: Canst thou so daff me?
modern: You think you can get rid of me that easily?

origin: Thou hast killed my child.
modern: You killed my child.

origin: If thou kill’st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.
modern: Take on someone your own size: if you kill me, boy, you’ll have killed a man.

origin: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed, But that’s no matter.
modern: He’ll have to kill both of us, and indeed we’re both men.

origin: Let him kill one first.
modern: But let him start off easy by killing one of us.

origin: Win me and wear me!
modern: Come on—kill me and brag about it!

origin: Let him answer me.— Come, follow me, boy.
modern: Let me at him.

origin: Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence, Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
modern: I will, as surely as I am a gentleman.

origin: Brother— Content yourself.
modern: Brother— Quiet.

origin: God knows I loved my niece, And she is dead, slandered to death by villains That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
modern: God knows I loved my niece, and now she’s dead—slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue.

origin: Brother Anthony—
modern: Brother Anthony—

origin: Hold you content.
modern: Hold your peace.

origin: But brother Anthony—     Come, ’tis no matter.
modern: But brother Anthony— Don’t, it’s no big deal.

origin: Do not you meddle.
modern: Don’t bother with it.

origin: Let me deal in this.
modern: Let me deal with this.

origin: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
modern: Gentlemen, we won’t stay here and anger you further.

origin: My heart is sorry for your daughter’s death, But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing But what was true and very full of proof.
modern: I’m sorry about your daughter’s death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.

origin: My lord, my lord— I will not hear you.
modern: My lord, my lord— I don’t want to hear any more about it.

origin: No?
modern: No?

origin: Come, brother; away!
modern: Come on, brother!

origin: I will be heard.
modern: I’m determined to be heard by someone.

origin: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.
modern: And you will be, or some people here will suffer for it.

origin: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.
modern: Look, here comes just the man we were looking for.

origin: Now, Signior, what news?
modern: What’s up, mister?

origin: Welcome, Signior.
modern: Welcome, sir.

origin: You are almost come to part almost a fray.
modern: You just missed a fight that was barely avoided.

origin: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off with two old men without teeth.
modern: We were about to have our noses snapped off by two old men with no teeth.

origin: Leonato and his brother.
modern: Leonato and his brother.

origin: What think’st thou?
modern: What do you think?

origin: Had we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.
modern: I think if we had fought, we would have proven too young and strong for them after all.

origin: In a false quarrel there is no true valor.
modern: There’s no bravery in an unfair fight.

origin: As I am an honest man, he looks pale.—Art thou sick, or angry?
modern: Look: Benedick is so pale—are you sick, or angry?

origin: killed a cat?
modern: Lighten up.

origin: Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
modern: Sir, don’t even try to beat me in a battle of wits.

origin: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, an you charge it against me.
modern: I’ll meet all your attacks, even if you come charging at me with a lance at full gallop.

origin: I pray you, choose another subject.
modern: Choose another tack.

origin: I think he be angry indeed.
modern: I think he really is angry.

origin: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.
modern: If he is, that’s his problem.

origin: Shall I speak a word in your ear?
modern: Can I have a word with you privately?

origin: God bless me from a challenge!
modern: God forbid he wants to challenge me!

origin: Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice.
modern: lain.

origin: You have killed a sweet lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you.
modern: You’ve killed an innocent woman, and you’re going to pay dearly for her death.

origin: Let me hear from you.
modern: What do you say?

origin: What, a feast, a feast?
modern: What, are we having a feast?

origin: I' faith, I thank him.
modern: Yes, we are.

origin: I’ll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit he other day.
modern: Benedick, Beatrice praised your wit the other day.

origin: I said thou hadst a fine wit.
modern: I said you had a fine wit.

origin: True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues.
modern: True,” she said, “a fine little one.” “No,” I said, “a huge wit.” “Right,” she said, “a hugely awful one.” “No,” I said, “he has a good wit.” “Exactly,” she said, “it’s good and mild; it doesn’t hurt anyone.” “No,” I said, “Benedick is wise.” “He is certainly,” she said,  She cried a lot at that, and said she didn’t care.

origin: Yea, that she did.
modern: That she did.

origin: But yet for all that, an if she did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly.
modern: And yet for all that, if she didn’t hate him to death, she’d love him to death.

origin: The old man’s daughter told us all.
modern: Leonato’s daughter had told us everything.

origin: All, all.
modern: Absolutely everything.

origin: And, moreover, God saw him when he was hid in the garden.
modern: And, moreover, God saw Benedick when he was hid in the garden.

origin: But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on the sensible Benedick’s head?
modern: But when exactly will we see Benedick married?

origin: Yea, and text underneath: “Here dwells Benedick the married man”?
modern: Yes, with the sign underneath him that says: “Here lives Benedick the married man”?

origin: Fare you well, boy.
modern: Goodbye, boy.

origin: You know my mind.
modern: You know what I intend.

origin: I will leave you now to your gossip-like humor.
modern: I’ll leave you now to chatter and gossip like an old woman.

origin: You break jests as braggarts do their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not.—My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you.
modern: The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword—it can’t hurt anyone, thank God.—My lord, I thank you for your many kindnesses.

origin: I must discontinue your company.
modern: I’m leaving your court now.

origin: Your brother the Bastard is fled from Messina.
modern: Your brother Don John the Bastard has run away from Messina.

origin: You have among you killed a sweet and innocent lady.
modern: The three of you have killed a sweet, innocent woman.

origin: For my Lord Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be with him.
modern: Lord Babyface over there will meet me in a duel, and good luck to him then.

origin: He is in earnest.
modern: He’s serious.

origin: In most profound earnest, and, I’ll warrant you, for the love of Beatrice.
modern: Very serious, and I’m sure it’s because of Beatrice.

origin: And hath challenged thee?
modern: And he challenged you to a duel?

origin: Most sincerely.
modern: He did, very sincerely.

origin: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!
modern: What a strange sight—a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home!

origin: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a doctor to such a man.
modern: A guy like that is bigger than an ape, but the ape could be his doctor, it’s so much smarter.

origin: But soft you, let me be.
modern: But wait a minute.

origin: Pluck up, my heart, and be sad.
modern: Let me gather my wits and get serious here.

origin: Did he not say my brother was fled?
modern: Didn’t he say my brother has run away?

origin: Come you, sir.
modern: Come on, you.

origin: If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance.
modern: If they let you off, then we’ll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power.

origin: Nay, an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.
modern: Since you are a lying hypocrite, we must look after you.

origin: How now?
modern: What’s this?

origin: Two of my brother’s men bound!
modern: Two of my brother’s men, all tied up!

origin: Officers, what offense have these men done?
modern: Officers, what crime have these men committed?

origin: Marry, sir, they have committed false report; moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily, they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.
modern: Well sir, they’ve lied; moreover, they have said things that were not true; secondarily, they are slanderers; sixth and lastly, they have falsely accused a lady; thirdly, they have confirmed things that did not in fact happen; and, in conclusion, they are lying scoundrels.

origin: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I ask thee what’s their offense; sixth and lastly, why they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay to their charge.
modern: First, I ask you what they’ve done; thirdly, I ask you what offense they’re charged with; sixth and lastly, I ask you why they’ve been committed here; and, in conclusion, I ask what they’re accused of.

origin: I have deceived even your very eyes.
modern: I tricked your own eyes.

origin: My villainy they have upon record, which I had rather seal with my death than repeat over to my shame.
modern: They’ve recorded my crimes, and I would rather die than have to retell this shameful story.

origin: The lady is dead upon mine and my master’s false accusation.
modern: The lady has died because of the false accusations of me and my master.

origin: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.
modern: His words are like poison to me.

origin: Yea, and paid me richly for the practice of it.
modern: Yes, and paid me well for doing it.

origin: He is composed and framed of treachery, And fled he is upon this villainy.
modern: He is made of treachery, and has run away to avoid his crimes.

origin: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
modern: Sweet Hero; when I imagine you now, you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you.

origin: Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the Sexton too.
modern: Come, take away the  Here comes Master Signior Leonato with the sexton.

origin: Which is the villain?
modern: Which one of them did it?

origin: Let me see his eyes, That, when I note another man like him, I may avoid him.
modern: Let me see what he looks like, so when I see another man who resembles him, I’ll know to avoid him.

origin: Which of these is he?
modern: Which one is it?

origin: If you would know your wronger, look on me.
modern: If you want to see your deceiver, then look at me.

origin: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast killed Mine innocent child?
modern: Are you the slave who, with your slanderous words, killed my innocent child?

origin: Yea, even I alone.
modern: Yes, I am the one.

origin: No, not so, villain, thou beliest thyself.
modern: No, villain, but you didn’t work alone.

origin: I know not how to pray your patience, Yet I must speak.
modern: I don’t know how to ask you for forgiveness, but I have to say something.

origin: Choose your revenge yourself.
modern: Choose your revenge.

origin: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live— That were impossible—but, I pray you both, Possess the people in Messina here How innocent she died.
modern: I can’t ask you to make my daughter live—that’s impossible—but I beg you both to tell the people of Messina that she was innocent when she died.

origin: And if your love Can labor ought in sad invention, Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones.
modern: And if your love can produce something from its sadness, write a poem for her; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones.

origin: Sing it tonight.
modern: Sing it tonight.

origin: Tomorrow morning come you to my house, And since you could not be my son-in-law, Be yet my nephew.
modern: Then come to my house tomorrow morning, and since you couldn’t be my son-in-law, be my nephew instead.

origin: My brother hath a daughter, Almost the copy of my child that’s dead, And she alone is heir to both of us.
modern: My brother has a daughter who looks exactly like Hero; this girl is heir to both our estates.

origin: Give her the right you should have given her cousin, And so dies my revenge.
modern: Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.

origin: That I love her, I feel.
modern: And  I feel that I love her.

origin: That she is worthy, I know.
modern: I know that she is worthy of that love.

origin: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.
modern: Or in the power of reason.

origin: That a woman conceived me, I thank her.
modern: I was conceived by a woman, and I thank her very much for all her effort.

origin: That she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks.
modern: And then she brought me up, and I thank her for that, too.

origin: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.
modern: I swear, before I die I’m going to see you sick with love.

origin: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not with love.
modern: With anger, with fever, or with hunger, sure, my friend, but never sick with love.

origin: Prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a ballad-maker’s pen and hang me up at the door of a brothel house for the sign of blind Cupid.
modern: If you can prove that I’ll ever be so in love that I can’t be brought to my senses with a good round of beers, you can pluck out my eyes with a love-poet’s pen and hang me on a brothel’s door where the picture of blind Cupid usually goes.

origin: O noble sir!
modern: Oh, noble sir!

origin: Your overkindness doth wring tears from me.
modern: Your overwhelming kindness makes me weep.

origin: I do embrace your offer; and dispose For henceforth of poor Claudio.
modern: I willingly accept your offer and put my future in your hands.

origin: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming.
modern: I will see you tomorrow, then.

origin: Tonight I take my leave.
modern: Now I have to leave.

origin: This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret, Who I believe was packed in all this wrong, Hired to it by your brother.
modern: This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret, who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot.

origin: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.
modern: Thank you for all your efforts.

origin: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and reverent youth, and I praise God for you.
modern: You speak like a very thankful and respectful boy, and may God bless you.

origin: God save the foundation!
modern: God save the charitable organization!

origin: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
modern: I leave a slimy bastard with you, your Worship, for you to punish and make an example of.

origin: God keep your Worship!
modern: God bless your Worship!

origin: I wish your Worship well.
modern: I wish you well.

origin: God restore you to health!
modern: I hope that God restores you to health.

origin: Farewell, my lords.
modern: Goodbye, gentlemen.

origin: We look for you tomorrow.
modern: We’ll see you tomorrow.

origin: We will not fail.
modern: We’ll be there.

origin: Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.
modern: I will mourn Hero tonight.

origin: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.
modern: Please Margaret, help me write this poem for Beatrice.

origin: To have no man come over me!
modern: You certainly deserve it.

origin: A most manly wit, Margaret, it will not hurt a woman.
modern: It’s just that my wit is very gentlemanly, Margaret, and refuses to hurt a woman.

origin: And so, I pray thee, call Beatrice.
modern: Now please, tell Beatrice to come out.

origin: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
modern: I’ll go get Beatrice for you, who can walk here by herself—she has legs.

origin: And therefore will come.
modern: So that means she’ll come.

origin: I mean in singing.
modern: I’m really a pitiful singer.

origin: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
modern: Take  Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?

origin: Yea, Signior, and depart when you bid me.
modern: Yes, sir, and I’ll leave when you ask me to.

origin: Oh , stay but till then!
modern: Oh, well, stay till then!

origin: Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss thee.
modern: I spoke angry, foul words to him, and with that I will kiss you.

origin: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome.
modern: If you had foul words in your mouth, then your breath must be foul, and foul breath is nauseating.

origin: Therefore I will depart unkissed.
modern: Thus, I’ll leave without being kissed.

origin: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense, so forcible is thy wit.
modern: Your wit is so forceful, it frightens the very meaning out of your words.

origin: But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward.
modern: But I will tell you this very plainly: I have challenged Claudio, and either he’ll accept the challenge or admit he’s a coward.

origin: And I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?
modern: Now, tell me—which of my bad qualities did you fall in love with first?

origin: For them all together, which maintained so politic a state of evil that they will not admit any good part to intermingle with them.
modern: With all of them at once: they work together to create such an entirely evil person that no good ever manages to enter the mix.

origin: But for which of my good parts did you first suffer love for me?
modern: But tell me—which of my good qualities first made you suffer love for me?

origin: Suffer love!
modern: Suffer love!

origin: A good epithet!
modern: That’s a good way of putting it.

origin: I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.
modern: I do suffer love, because I love you against my will.

origin: In spite of your heart, I think.
modern: You love me in spite of your heart, I think.

origin: If a man do not erect in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps.
modern: In this day and age, if a man doesn’t erect his own monument before he dies, he won’t be remembered past the funeral bell’s ringing and his widow’s crying.

origin: And how long is that, think you?
modern: Exactly how long is that, do you think?

origin: Question: why, an hour in clamor and a quarter in rheum.
modern: About an hour for the ringing and fifteen minutes for the crying.

origin: Therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own virtues, as I am to myself.
modern: That’s why it’s better for wise men to trumpet their own virtues, like I do.

origin: So much for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy.
modern: That’s why I praise myself, who—if I do say so myself—is quite praiseworthy.

origin: An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
modern: But tell me, how is your cousin?

origin: Very ill, too.
modern: I’m very sick, too.

origin: Serve God, love me, and mend.
modern: Have faith, love me, and you will get better.

origin: Madam, you must come to your uncle.
modern: Madam, you have to go to your uncle’s.

origin: It is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio mightily abused, and Don John is the author of all, who is fled and gone.
modern: It’s been proven that Lady Hero is innocent, that the Prince and Claudio have been utterly deceived, and that Don John—who has run away—is the source of all the trouble.

origin: Will you come presently?
modern: Will you come immediately?

origin: Will you go hear this news, Signior?
modern: Will you come with me to hear this news, sir?

origin: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eyes—and moreover, I will go with thee to thy uncle’s.
modern: I will live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes—and, what’s more, I will go with you to your uncle’s.

origin: Is this the monument of Leonato?
modern: Is this the family tomb of Leonato?

origin: It is, my lord.
modern: It is, my lord.

origin: Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies.
modern: Here lies Hero, The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words.

origin: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs, Gives her fame which never dies.
modern: To repay her for her troubles, Death Gives her undying fame.

origin: So the life that died with shame Lives in death with glorious fame.
modern: So the life that died with shame Lives on with fame.

origin: Hang thou there upon the tomb, Praising her when I am dumb.
modern: This epitaph will hang here forever, Continuing to praise Hero after I die.

origin: Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
modern: Now start the music, and sing the solemn hymn.

origin: Now, unto thy bones good night!
modern: Now I say good night to your bones, Hero.

origin: Yearly will I do this rite.
modern: I will perform this ceremony every year.

origin: Good morrow, masters.
modern: Good morning, gentlemen.

origin: Put your torches out.
modern: Put out your torches.

origin: The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day, Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
modern: The wolves have finished preying for the night, and look—the gentle dawn is rising, dappling the sleepy eastern sky with spots of light.

origin: Good morrow, masters.
modern: Good morning, gentlemen.

origin: Did I not tell you she was innocent?
modern: Didn’t I tell you she was innocent?

origin: So are the Prince and Claudio, who accused her Upon the error that you heard debated.
modern: And the Prince and Claudio, who accused her, are innocent as well, because they were deceived by Don John.

origin: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
modern: Well, I’m glad that everything has been sorted out.

origin: And so am I, being else by faith enforced To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.
modern: Me too—otherwise I would have had to duel with Claudio.

origin: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all, Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves, And when I send for you, come hither masked.
modern: When I send for you, come out wearing masks.

origin: The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour To visit me.—You know your office, brother.
modern: The Prince and Claudio are supposed to be here by now.—You know your job, brother.

origin: You must be father to your brother’s daughter, And give her to young Claudio.
modern: You have to pretend to be your niece’s father, and give her away to Claudio.

origin: To do what, Signior?
modern: What do you need me to do?

origin: That eye my daughter lent her; ’tis most true.
modern: She sees you with the eyes my daughter lent her, it’s true.

origin: And I do with an eye of love requite her.
modern: And I see her also through the eyes of love.

origin: The sight whereof I think you had from me, From Claudio and the Prince.
modern: And those eyes were endowed with sight by Claudio, the Prince, and me.

origin: But what’s your will?
modern: But what did you want?

origin: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical.
modern: Sir, I’m puzzled by what you just said.

origin: And my help.
modern: And I’ll help you.

origin: Here comes the Prince and Claudio.
modern: Here comes the Prince and Claudio.

origin: Good morrow to this fair assembly.
modern: Good morning to all these lovely people.

origin: Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio.
modern: Good morning, Prince; good morning, Claudio.

origin: We here attend you.
modern: We’re waiting here for you.

origin: Are you yet determined Today to marry with my brother’s daughter?
modern: Are you still set on marrying my brother’s daughter?

origin: I’ll hold my mind were she an Ethiope.
modern: I wouldn’t change my mind even if she were

origin: Well, as time shall try.
modern: Well, time will tell.

origin: Well, you temporize with the hours.
modern: Just you wait.

origin: Commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper, for indeed he hath made great preparation.
modern: Give him my respects, and tell him I’ll definitely be there for dinner, since I know he has gone to great lengths for this meal.

origin: Call her forth, brother.
modern: Bring her out, brother.

origin: Here’s the friar ready.
modern: The friar’s ready.

origin: Good morrow, Benedick.
modern: Good morning, Benedick.

origin: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
modern: I think he’s nervous—he’s about to become the savage bull who got domesticated.

origin: Tush, fear not, man.
modern: Oh, don’t worry about it—we’ll dip your    I’ll get you for that one.

origin: Here comes other reck'nings.
modern: But here are other matters to be dealt with.

origin: Which is the lady I must seize upon?
modern: Which is the lady I’m supposed to marry?

origin: This same is she, and I do give you her.
modern: This one, and I will give her to you.

origin: No, that you shall not till you take her hand Before this friar and swear to marry her.
modern: No, you can’t do that until you take her hand and, in front of this friar, swear to marry her.

origin: Another Hero!
modern: It’s another Hero!

origin: Nothing certainer.
modern: Exactly right.

origin: One Hero died defiled, but I do live, And surely as I live, I am a maid.
modern: And as surely as I am alive, I am a virgin.

origin: The former Hero!
modern: It’s the former Hero!

origin: Hero that is dead!
modern: The Hero that died!

origin: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
modern: She was only dead, my lord, as long as her slander lived.

origin: All this amazement can I qualify When after that the holy rites are ended I’ll tell you largely of fair Hero’s death.
modern: I can confirm that all these shocking things are true.

origin: Soft and fair, Friar.—Which is Beatrice?
modern: Which one of you is Beatrice?

origin: Do not you love me?
modern: Do you love me?

origin: Why no, no more than reason.
modern: No, no more than is reasonable.

origin: Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived.
modern: Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived.

origin: They swore you did.
modern: They swore you did.

origin: Do not you love me?
modern: Do you love me?

origin: Troth, no, no more than reason.
modern: Truly, no—no more than is reasonable.

origin: Why then, my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.
modern: Well then, Margaret, Ursula, and my cousin have been very much deceived, for they swore you did.

origin: They swore that you were almost sick for me.
modern: They swore that you were sick with love for me.

origin: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
modern: They swore that you were nearly dead with love for me.

origin: Tis no such matter.
modern: Oh, well.

origin: Then you do not love me?
modern: So you don’t love me?

origin: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.
modern: No, I don’t—except as a friend.

origin: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.
modern: Come on, niece, I’m sure you love him.

origin: And here’s another, Writ in my cousin’s hand, stol'n from her pocket, Containing her affection unto Benedick.
modern: And here’s another poem, which I stole from my cousin’s pocket—in her handwriting and all about her adoration for Benedick.

origin: A miracle!
modern: What a miracle!

origin: Here’s our own hands against our hearts.
modern: Our handwriting gives away our hearts.

origin: Come, I will have thee, but, by this light, I take thee for pity.
modern: Come on, I’ll take you, but honestly I’m only doing it out of pity.

origin: I would not deny you, but, by this good day, I yield upon great persuasion, and partly to save your life, for I was told you were in a consumption.
modern: I won’t say no to you, but let it be known that I’m only doing this after a lot of persuasion and to save your life —I hear you were quickly wasting away without me.

origin: Peace!
modern: Oh, shut up!

origin: I will stop your mouth.
modern: I’ll stop your mouth with a kiss.

origin: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?
modern: How does it feel to be Benedick the Married Man?

origin: I’ll tell thee what, Prince: a college of wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humor.
modern: I’ll tell you what, Prince: a whole university full of wisecrackers couldn’t change my mood today.

origin: Dost thou think I care for a satire or an epigram?
modern: You think I care what I’m called?

origin: No.
modern: Well, I don’t.

origin: First, of my word!
modern: No, before!

origin: Therefore play, music.—Prince, thou art sad.
modern: Musicians, play us a song.—Prince, you look sad.

origin: Get thee a wife, get thee a wife.
modern: You should get a wife!

origin: To the tuition of God.
modern: Into God’s hands.

origin: From my house, if I had it— The sixth of July.
modern: From my house, if I had a house—” “The sixth of July.

origin: My liege, your highness now may do me good.
modern: Before you make  My lord, you could really help me out now.

origin: My love is thine to teach.
modern: I am at your service.

origin: Teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.
modern: Just tell me what you want me to do, and however hard it is, you’ll see that I’m eager to do it.

origin: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?
modern: Does Leonato have a son, my lord?

origin: No child but Hero; she’s his only heir.
modern: Hero is his only child, and his only heir.

origin: Dost thou affect her, Claudio?
modern: Do you like her, Claudio?

origin: If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her.
modern: Look, if you really love the beautiful Hero, enjoy it.

origin: Was ’t not to this end That thou began’st to twist so fine a story?
modern: Isn’t that the reason you told me all this?

origin: But lest my liking might too sudden seem, I would have salved it with a longer treatise.
modern: But I didn’t want you to think that I’m hasty in my emotions.

origin: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
modern: That’s like building a bridge wider than the river it crosses.

origin: I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio, And in her bosom I’ll unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale.
