modern: I’ll disguise myself as you and pour out “my” feelings to Hero, taking her prisoner with the force of my love story.

origin: In practice let us put it presently.
modern: Let’s get started right away.

origin: Hath he provided this music?
modern: Has he taken care of the music?

origin: He is very busy about it.
modern: He is taking care of it as we speak.

origin: But, brother, I can tell you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.
modern: But brother, I have some strange news for you.

origin: Are they good?
modern: Is it good news?

origin: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
modern: Is this servant of yours a smart man?

origin: A good sharp fellow.
modern: He’s very bright.

origin: I will send for him, and question him yourself.
modern: I’ll get him to come here, and you can ask him yourself.

origin: He is very near by this.
modern: He must be very near by now.

origin: He was not three leagues off when I left him.
modern: When I left him, he was less than nine miles from here.

origin: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?
modern: How many noblemen were killed in the battle you just fought?

origin: But few of any sort, and none of name.
modern: Not many, and no one important.

origin: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers.
modern: A victory in battle is twice as victorious when all the soldiers return home safely.

origin: I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
modern: Claudio deserves to be honored, and Don Pedro has rewarded him accordingly.

origin: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.
modern: He has an uncle here in Messina who will be glad to hear this news.

origin: No, no, we will hold it as a dream till it appear itself.
modern: No, no, until it comes true we’ll pretend it was just a dream we had.

origin: But I will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the better prepared for an answer if peradventure this be true.
modern: But my daughter should know about this, so she can be prepared with an answer just in case.

origin: Go you and tell her of it.
modern: Go to her and tell her for me.

origin: Cousins, you know what you have to do.—O, I cry you mercy, friend.
modern: Cousins, you all have work to do.—Oh, I beg your pardon.

origin: Go you with me and I will use your skill.— Good cousin, have a care this busy time.
modern: Come with me now, and help me out.

origin: What the goodyear, my lord, why are you thus out of measure sad?
modern: Really, my lord, why are you so excessively sad?

origin: Therefore the sadness is without limit.
modern: Therefore my sadness is without limit.

origin: You should hear reason.
modern: You should listen to reason.

origin: I cannot hide what I am.
modern: I can’t hide what I am.

origin: Yea, but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controlment.
modern: Sure, but don’t do it at full volume until there’s no danger in it.

origin: You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace, where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself.
modern: Not long ago you challenged and opposed your brother, and it is only very recently that he has forgiven you.

origin: It is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.
modern: You have to wait for the appropriate time to let loose.

origin: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any.
modern: I’d rather be a weed in a hedge than a rose in my brother’s garden.

origin: In this, though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain.
modern: Though I am not a flattering, righteous man, at least you can say that I am honest about being a villain.

origin: In the meantime, let me be that I am, and seek not to alter me.
modern: Until that happens, let me be who I am and don’t try to change me.

origin: Can you make no use of your discontent?
modern: Can’t you somehow use your dissatisfaction to your own advantage?

origin: I make all use of it, for I use it only.
modern: I use it all the time, since it’s all that I have.

origin: Who comes here?
modern: Who’s that?

origin: What news, Borachio?
modern: What’s going on, Borachio?

origin: What is he for a fool that betroths himself to unquietness?
modern: Who is this fool who wants all the fuss of marriage?

origin: Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
modern: Your brother’s right-hand man.

origin: Who?
modern: Who?

origin: The most exquisite Claudio?
modern: That pretty boy, Claudio?

origin: Even he.
modern: That’s the one.

origin: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.
modern: Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

origin: A very forward March-chick!
modern: A lively young one!

origin: How came you to this?
modern: How did you learn about this?

origin: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in sad conference.
modern: As I was working on one musty room, the Prince and Claudio entered.

origin: Come, come, let us thither.
modern: Come, let’s go to the dance.

origin: This may prove food to my displeasure.
modern: This just may cheer me up.

origin: If I can cross him any way, I bless myself every way.
modern: If there’s any way I can spoil his life, I’ll be overjoyed.

origin: You are both sure, and will assist me?
modern: You’ll both help me, right?

origin: To the death, my lord.
modern: Until the day we die, my lord.

origin: Let us to the great supper.
modern: Let’s go to this great feast.

origin: We’ll wait upon your lordship.
modern: Lead the way, sir.

origin: Was not Count John here at supper?
modern: Wasn’t Don John at dinner tonight?

origin: I saw him not.
modern: I didn’t see him.

origin: How tartly that gentleman looks!
modern: That man always looks so sour!

origin: I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after.
modern: Just looking at him gives me heartburn.

origin: He is of a very melancholy disposition.
modern: He has a very gloomy attitude.

origin: He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick.
modern: It would be excellent if they could make a man halfway between Don John and Benedick.

origin: The one is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too like my lady’s eldest son, evermore tattling.
modern: One of them is too much like a painting of a man—he never speaks—and the other is too much like a spoiled little boy, always chattering.

origin: Then half Signor Benedick’s tongue in Count John’s mouth, and half Count John’s melancholy in Signor Benedick’s face— With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world, if he could get her goodwill.
modern: So, the man would talk half as much as Benedick and be half as serious as Don John— And if he were handsome, agile, and rich, too, he could have any woman in the world—all he’d need was her good will.

origin: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.
modern: Really, niece, you’ll never get a husband if you keep saying such harsh things about people.

origin: In faith, she’s too curst.
modern: Honestly, she is too ill-tempered.

origin: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
modern: Maybe you will find a husband without a beard.

origin: What should I do with him?
modern: And then what would I do with him?

origin: Well then, go you into hell?
modern: So you’ll go to hell?

origin: No, but to the gate, and there will the devil meet me like an old cuckold with horns on his head, and say, “Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven; here’s no place for you maids.” So deliver I up my apes and away to Saint Peter.
modern: No, just to the gates of hell, where the devil will meet me, with the horns on his head like a cuckold, and say, “Go up to heaven, Beatrice.

origin: For the heavens, he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.
modern: He will show me the part of heaven where the bachelors sit, and I’ll have fun there forever.

origin: Not till God make men of some other metal than earth.
modern: No, I won’t take a husband until they make men out of something other than dirt.

origin: Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust?
modern: What woman wouldn’t be distressed, being lorded over by a handful of dust?

origin: To make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?
modern: Can you imagine being hitched to a lump of clay?

origin: No, uncle, I’ll none.
modern: No, uncle, I won’t be married.

origin: If the Prince be too important, tell him there is measure in everything, and so dance out the answer.
modern: If he is too insistent, tell him that romance is like a dance: it has its own rhythm and timing.

origin: For hear me, Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinquepace.
modern: The wooing is like a Scottish jig: hot and fast and full of whimsy and illusion.

origin: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.
modern: Niece, you are exceptionally perceptive.

origin: I have a good eye, uncle.
modern: I have a good eye, uncle.

origin: I can see a church by daylight.
modern: I can see what’s in broad daylight.

origin: The revelers are entering, brother.
modern: The partygoers have arrived.

origin: Make good room.
modern: Let’s give them room.

origin: Lady, will you walk a bout with your friend?
modern: My lady, will you have a dance with me?

origin: So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say nothing, I am yours for the walk, and especially when I walk away.
modern: As long as you move gracefully, look handsome, and say nothing, I’m yours for the dance.

origin: And when please you to say so?
modern: And when will that be?

origin: When I like your favor, for God defend the lute should be like the case!
modern: When I like the way you look, for God forbid your face be as ugly as your mask!

origin: My visor is Philemon’s roof; within the house is Jove.
modern: My mask is like the roof of the poor

origin: Speak low if you speak love.
modern: If you wish to speak of love, speak more softly.

origin: Well, I would you did like me.
modern: Well, I wish you liked me.

origin: Which is one?
modern: Tell me one.

origin: I say my prayers aloud.
modern: I say my prayers out loud.

origin: I love you the better; the hearers may cry “Amen.” God match me with a good dancer!
modern: That makes me love you even more.

origin: Amen.
modern: Amen.

origin: No more words.
modern: Go ahead—say “Amen.” No more talking.

origin: The clerk is answered.
modern: I’ve got my answer.

origin: At a word, I am not.
modern: No, really, I’m not.

origin: I know you by the waggling of your head.
modern: I can tell by the way you waggle your head.

origin: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.
modern: Really, I’m only pretending to be him.

origin: You could never do him so ill-well unless you were the very man.
modern: You could only imitate his imperfections so well if you were the man himself.

origin: Here’s his dry hand up and down.
modern: Look, you’ve got his wrinkled hands.

origin: You are he, you are he.
modern: You are Antonio, you are he.

origin: At a word, I am not.
modern: In short, I’m not.

origin: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your excellent wit?
modern: Come on, do you think I can’t recognize you by your excellent wit?

origin: Can virtue hide itself?
modern: Can a good thing hide itself?

origin: Go to, mum, you are he.
modern: Be quiet, you are Antonio.

origin: Graces will appear, and there’s an end.
modern: A man’s virtues will always show themselves, and that’s the end of that.

origin: Will you not tell me who told you so?
modern: Won’t you tell me who told you that?

origin: No, you shall pardon me.
modern: No, you’ll have to excuse me.

origin: Nor will you not tell me who you are?
modern: And you won’t tell me who you are?

origin: Not now.
modern: Not now.

origin: That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales!
modern: Who said that I was disdainful, and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book?!

origin: Well this was Signor Benedick that said so.
modern: Well, it must have been Signior Benedick.

origin: What’s he?
modern: Who’s that?

origin: I am sure you know him well enough.
modern: I’m sure you know him.

origin: Not I, believe me.
modern: No I don’t, believe me.

origin: Did he never make you laugh?
modern: What, he never made you laugh?

origin: In great measure.
modern: Yes, heavily.

origin: There are no faces truer than those that are so washed.
modern: There’s no face more sincere than one washed in tears.

origin: How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!
modern: And it’s definitely better to cry because you’re happy than laugh because you’re sad!

origin: There was none such in the army of any sort.
modern: There was no Signior Montanto in our army.

origin: What is he that you ask for, niece?
modern: Who are you talking about, niece?

origin: My cousin means Signor Benedick of Padua.
modern: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

origin: Oh, he’s returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.
modern: Oh, yes, Benedick has returned and is as cheerful as ever.

origin: I pray you, what is he?
modern: Please tell me, who is this man?

origin: Why, he is the Prince’s jester, a very dull fool, only his gift is in devising impossible slanders.
modern: Why, he’s the Prince’s fool, and a very dull fool at that.

origin: I am sure he is in the fleet.
modern: I’m sure he’s out there dancing.

origin: I would he had boarded me.
modern: I could have sworn he trampled on me.

origin: When I know the gentleman, I’ll tell him what you say.
modern: When I meet this gentleman, I’ll tell him what you’ve said.

origin: Do, do.
modern: Oh, please do.

origin: He’ll but break a comparison or two on me, which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into melancholy, and then there’s a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night.
modern: And that will save a partridge wing from being eaten, because he’ll be too miserable for dinner.

origin: We must follow the leaders.
modern: Come on, we have to follow the leaders of the dance.

origin: In every good thing.
modern: In every good thing they do.

origin: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.
modern: No, if they try to lead us to harm, I will leave the dance floor at the next song.

origin: And that is Claudio.
modern: That’s Claudio.

origin: You know me well.
modern: You know me too well.

origin: I am he.
modern: I am Benedick.

origin: Signor, you are very near my brother in his love.
modern: Sir, my brother is very fond of you.

origin: He is enamored on Hero.
modern: He is in love with Hero.

origin: I pray you, dissuade him from her.
modern: Please make him change his mind.

origin: How know you he loves her?
modern: How do you know he loves her?

origin: I heard him swear his affection.
modern: I heard him swear he did.

origin: So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
modern: I did too, and he also swore he would marry her tonight.

origin: Come, let us to the banquet.
modern: Come on, let’s get to the banquet.

origin: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
modern: Though I said my name was Benedick, I heard this news with Claudio’s ears.

origin: Tis certain so, the Prince woos for himself.
modern: Of course the Prince wants Hero for himself.

origin: Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love.
modern: Friendship is enduring except when love is involved.

origin: Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
modern: Therefore, all lovers should speak for themselves.

origin: Let every eye nogetiate for itself And trust no agent, for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
modern: Beauty is a witch whose spells can turn loyalty into passion.

origin: Farewell, therefore, Hero.
modern: Goodbye then, Hero.

origin: Count Claudio?
modern: Claudio?

origin: Yea, the same.
modern: Yes, that’s me.

origin: Come, will you go with me?
modern: Will you come with me?

origin: Whither?
modern: Where?

origin: I wish him joy of her.
modern: Right over to that  I hope he enjoys her.

origin: Why, that’s spoken like an honest drover; so they sell bullocks.
modern: You sound like a cattle dealer: that’s the way they sell bulls.

origin: But did you think the Prince would have served you thus?
modern: But do you really think the Prince would treat you that way?

origin: I pray you, leave me.
modern: Please, leave me alone.

origin: Ho, now you strike like the blind man.
modern: Look at you, thrashing about like a blind man.

origin: Twas the boy that stole your meat, and you’ll beat the post.
modern: A boy robbed you, but you’ll beat up the post instead.

origin: If it will not be, I’ll leave you.
modern: If you won’t leave, then

origin: Alas, poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into sedges.
modern: Oh, the poor bird.

origin: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me!
modern: But how strange that Beatrice should seem to know who I was and yet not know at the same time.

origin: The Prince’s fool!
modern: The Prince’s fool”!

origin: Ha, it may be I go under that title because I am merry.
modern: Maybe they call me that because I am cheerful.

origin: Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong.
modern: Yes, but I am insulting myself by thinking this way.

origin: I am not so reputed!
modern: I don’t have that kind of reputation!

origin: Well, I’ll be revenged as I may.
modern: Well, I’ll get my revenge.

origin: Now, Signior, where’s the Count?
modern: Now, sir, where is Claudio?

origin: Did you see him?
modern: Did you see him?

origin: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.
modern: Yes, my lord, I played the part of a gossip and brought him the news.

origin: I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren.
modern: I found him here,  Beating?

origin: What’s his fault?
modern: Why, what did he do?

origin: The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.
modern: He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird’s nest and happily shows it to his friend, who then steals it from him.

origin: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression?
modern: What, is trusting a friend such a crime?

origin: The transgression is in the stealer.
modern: The criminal is the one who stole the nest.

origin: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you.
modern: Lady Beatrice is angry with you.

origin: The gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.
modern: The gentleman she danced with told her you insulted her.

origin: She speaks poniards, and every word stabs.
modern: She speaks daggers, and every word stabs.

origin: If her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her; she would infect to the north star.
modern: If her breath were as terrible as her words, she would kill every living thing from here to the furthest star.

origin: I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed.
modern: I wouldn’t marry her, even if she were as blessed as paradise.

origin: Come, talk not of her.
modern: Please, don’t mention her.

origin: Look, here she comes.
modern: Look, here she comes.

origin: Will your grace command me any service to the world’s end?
modern: Your highness, could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth?

origin: I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on.
modern: I’ll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of.

origin: Marry, once before he won it of me with false dice.
modern: Really, he won it from me once before in a dishonest game of dice.

origin: Therefore your Grace may well say I have lost it.
modern: So I suppose your grace can truly say that I have lost it.

origin: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.
modern: You’ve humiliated him, lady: you’ve put him down.

origin: Why, how now, Count, wherefore are you sad?
modern: Why are you so sad?

origin: Not sad, my lord.
modern: I’m not sad, my lord.

origin: How then, sick?
modern: What then, sick?

origin: Neither, my lord.
modern: I’m neither, my lord.

origin: The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well, but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.
modern: The count is neither sad nor sick nor cheerful nor well—he’s just civil, as Seville as an orange, with the same jealous-yellow complexion.

origin: I have broke with her father and his goodwill obtained.
modern: I’ve told her father, and he’s given his permission.

origin: Name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy.
modern: Tell us when you wish to get married, and may God give you joy.

origin: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.
modern: Claudio, take my daughter, and, with her, take my fortunes.

origin: His grace hath made the match, and all grace say “Amen” to it.
modern: The Prince has made the match, and may God bless it.

origin: Speak, Count, ’tis your cue.
modern: Speak, Claudio, that’s your cue.

origin: I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.
modern: For you, I give myself away and I’m ecstatic about the exchange.

origin: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.
modern: Truly, lady, you have a merry heart.

origin: Yea, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care.
modern: I thank my heart—the poor fool—for it keeps away from seriousness.

origin: My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.
modern: Look, my cousin is whispering to Claudio that she loves him.

origin: And so she doth, cousin.
modern: Why, you’re absolutely right, cousin.

origin: Good Lord for alliance!
modern: Thank the lord for alliances!

origin: Thus goes everyone to the world but I, and I am sunburnt.
modern: So everyone goes off into the world except me, who stays in because I’m sunburned.

origin: I may sit in a corner and cry, “Heigh-ho for a husband!” Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.
modern: I should sit in the corner and sing that song, “Heigh-Ho for a Husband!” Lady Beatrice, I’ll get you a husband.

origin: I would rather have one of your father’s getting.
modern: I’d rather get a husband from your father.

origin: Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you?
modern: Don’t you have any brothers like you?

origin: Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.
modern: Your father’s sons would make excellent husbands, if only a girl could catch one for herself.

origin: Will you have me, lady?
modern: Will you take me, my lady?

origin: No, my lord, unless I might have another for working days.
modern: No, my lord, unless I could have another husband for the work week.

origin: Your Grace is too costly to wear every day.
modern: You are too expensive to wear every day.

origin: But I beseech your Grace pardon me.
modern: But please, forgive me, your highness.

origin: I was born to speak all mirth and no  matter.
modern: I was born to speak cleverly, not seriously.

origin: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
modern: Niece, will you take care of those things I mentioned?

origin: I cry you mercy, uncle.—By your Grace’s pardon.
modern: Oh, yes, I’m sorry, uncle.—If you’ll excuse me, your grace.

origin: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
modern: I swear, she’s a very good-natured lady.

origin: There’s little of the melancholy element in her, my lord.
modern: There’s very little about her that’s gloomy, my lord.

origin: She is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then, for I have heard my daughter say she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.
modern: She’s only sad when she sleeps—and not even then.

origin: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.
modern: She can’t stand to hear about getting a husband.

origin: Oh, by no means.
modern: No, not at all.

origin: She mocks all her wooers out of suit.
modern: She mocks all her suitors so severely that they drop the suit.

origin: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.
modern: She would make a good wife for Benedick.

origin: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.
modern: Oh, Lord, if they were married, they’d drive themselves crazy within a week.

origin: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
modern: Count Claudio, when do you plan to go to church and be married?

origin: Tomorrow, my lord.
modern: Tomorrow, my lord.

origin: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights' watchings.
modern: My lord, I will help you, even if it means I have to stay awake for ten nights straight.

origin: And I, my lord.
modern: Me too, my lord.

origin: And you too, gentle Hero?
modern: And you, sweet Hero?

origin: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.
modern: I’ll do any decent thing, my lord, to help my cousin get a good husband.

origin: And Benedick is not the unhopefulest husband that I know.
modern: And Benedick is not the worst husband I can think of.

origin: Thus far can I praise him: he is of a noble strain, of approved valor, and confirmed honesty.
modern: This much I can say about him: he is well-born, has proven his bravery in battle, and has established his good character.

origin: Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
modern: Come inside with me, and I will tell you my plan.

origin: Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be meet with you, I doubt it not.
modern: But I’m sure he’ll get even with you.

origin: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
modern: Signior Benedick served well in the war, my lady.

origin: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it.
modern: You had rotten food, and he helped you eat it.

origin: And a good soldier too, lady.
modern: He’s a good soldier too, lady.

origin: A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stuffed with all honorable virtues.
modern: He’s a lord to a lord and a man to a man.

origin: He is no less than a stuffed man.
modern: He is positively stuffed with honorable virtues.

origin: But for the stuffing—well, we are all mortal.
modern: Absolutely—he is stuffed, like a dummy.

origin: You must not, sir, mistake my niece.
modern: Please don’t take my niece the wrong way, sir.

origin: There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signor Benedick and her.
modern: Benedick and Beatrice have been waging a war of wits between themselves.

origin: They never meet but there’s a skirmish of wit between them.
modern: Whenever they meet, there’s a little battle.

origin: He hath every month a new sworn brother.
modern: Every month he has a new best friend.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

origin: It is so.
modern: It’s arranged.

origin: The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.
modern: The Count Claudio will marry Leonato’s daughter.

origin: Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
modern: Yes, my lord, but I can spoil it.

origin: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be med'cinable to me.
modern: Any obstacle or barrier to Claudio’s happiness will be like medicine to me.

origin: I am sick in displeasure to him, and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges evenly with mine.
modern: I hate him so much it makes me sick, and whoever can ruin his happiness will make me happy.

origin: How canst thou cross this marriage?
modern: How will you wreck this marriage?

origin: Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty shall appear in me.
modern: I can only do it by lying, my lord, but I can do it so secretly that no one will suspect me.

origin: Show me briefly how.
modern: Quickly, tell me how.

origin: I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
modern: I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret, Hero’s servant woman, likes me.

origin: I remember.
modern: I remember.

origin: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to look out at her lady’s chamber window.
modern: I can arrange it so that at some indecent hour of the night, she looks out Hero’s bedroom window.

origin: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
modern: How will that kill this marriage?

origin: The poison of that lies in you to temper.
modern: That part is up to you.

origin: What proof shall I make of that?
modern: What will be my evidence?

origin: Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato.
modern: Evidence enough to deceive the Prince, anger Claudio, ruin Hero, and kill Leonato.

origin: Look you for any other issue?
modern: Is there anything else you wish?

origin: Only to despite them, I will endeavor anything.
modern: That’s all I want, and I’ll do anything to accomplish it.

origin: Go then, find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count Claudio alone.
modern: Find a time to speak with Don Pedro and Claudio alone.

origin: Tell them that you know that Hero loves me.
modern: Tell them you know that Hero loves me.

origin: Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as in love of your brother’s honor, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus.
modern: Pretend to be very concerned about both the Prince, who has compromised his honor by making the match, and Claudio, whose reputation will be ruined by this woman who’s pretending to be a virgin.

origin: They will scarcely believe this without trial.
modern: Of course, they won’t believe you without proof.

origin: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.
modern: If you make the accusation convincingly, then my cunning won’t fail me.

origin: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.
modern: I’ll go now to find out the date of the wedding.

origin: Boy!
modern: Boy!

origin: Signior?
modern: Yes Signior?

origin: In my chamber window lies a book.
modern: In my bedroom window there is a book.

origin: Bring it hither to me in the orchard.
modern: Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard.

origin: I am here already, sir.
modern: I’m already here, sir.

origin: I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
modern: I see that you are here, but I’d like you to go there and then come back again.

origin: I have known when there was no music with him but the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the tabor and the pipe.
modern: I knew him when he listened to nothing but the military drum and fife; now he would rather hear the sweet and refined music of the tabor and pipe.

origin: I have known when he would have walked ten mile afoot to see a good armor, and now will he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet.
modern: I knew him when he would’ve walked ten miles to see a well-crafted suit of armor; now he spends ten nights awake in his room designing himself a fancy new jacket.

origin: I cannot tell; I think not.
modern: I’m not sure, but I don’t think so.

origin: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster, but I’ll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool.
modern: I can’t promise that love won’t transform me, but I can promise you this: until I truly fall in love, a woman will never make me act like such a fool.

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: The Prince and Monsieur Love!
modern: Look, it’s the Prince and Mr. Love.

origin: I will hide me in the arbor.
modern: I’ll hide in the arbor.

origin: Come, shall we hear this music?
modern: Well, should we hear some music?

origin: Yea, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Come, Balthasar, we’ll hear that song again.
modern: Come on, Balthasar, let’s hear that song again.

origin: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice To slander music anymore than once.
modern: Oh, my good lord, don’t make me insult music again with my awful singing.

origin: I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.
modern: Come on, please sing.

origin: Note this before my notes: There’s not a note of mine that’s worth the noting.
modern: Just know this before I begin: I can’t play a single note that’s worthy of note.

origin: strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out of men’s bodies?
modern: Listen to him speaking in quarter notes!

origin: By my troth, a good song.
modern: That’s a good song.

origin: And an ill singer, my lord.
modern: And a bad singer, my lord.

origin: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar?
modern: Yes, do you hear me, Balthasar?

origin: I pray thee, get us some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero’s chamber window
modern: Please, get some excellent music, because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window.

origin: The best I can, my lord.
modern: I’ll do the best I can, my lord.

origin: Do so.
modern: Please do.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Come hither, Leonato.
modern: Come here, Leonato.

origin: What was it you told me of today, that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signor Benedick?
modern: What was it that you told me today—that your niece Beatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?

origin: Oh, ay.
modern: Oh yes.

origin: sits.—I did never think that lady would have loved any man.
modern: I didn’t, either.

origin: No, nor I neither, but most wonderful that she should so dote on Signor Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.
modern: But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick, whom she has always appeared to hate.

origin: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.
modern: Really, my lord, I don’t know what to make of it, but she loves him with such a passion that it’s past all understanding.

origin: May be she doth but counterfeit.
modern: Maybe she’s just pretending.

origin: Faith, like enough.
modern: Yes, that’s quite likely.

origin: O God!
modern: Oh God!

origin: Counterfeit?
modern: Pretending?

origin: There was never counterfeit of passion came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.
modern: No one has ever faked passion as skillfully as this, then.

origin: Why, what effects of passion shows she?
modern: Why, what symptoms of love does she exhibit?

origin: What effects, my lord?
modern: What symptoms, my lord?

origin: She will sit you—you heard my daughter tell you how.
modern: She will have a seat—you heard my daughter tell you how.

origin: She did indeed.
modern: Yes, she did tell us.

origin: How, how I pray you?
modern: Please, please tell me!

origin: You amaze me.
modern: This is amazing.

origin: I would have thought her spirit had been invincible against all assaults of affection.
modern: I would have thought she was invincible against any assault of love.

origin: I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedick.
modern: I would have sworn that, too, my lord, especially against Benedick.

origin: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?
modern: Has she told Benedick how she feels?

origin: No, and swears she never will.
modern: No, and she swears she never will.

origin: That’s her torment.
modern: That’s what’s driving her crazy.

origin: Tis true indeed, so your daughter says.
modern: It’s true, Hero says so.

origin: My daughter tells us all.
modern: My daughter told me everything.

origin: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told.
modern: Now that you speak of paper, I remember a funny story of Hero’s.

origin: Oh, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she found “Benedick” and “Beatrice” between the sheet?
modern: Oh, you mean when Beatrice writes a letter and Hero sees that it has “Benedick” and “Beatrice” written all over it?

origin: That.
modern: Yes, that’s the one.

origin: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, railed at herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she knew would flout her.
modern: Oh, she tears that letter into a thousand small pieces and berates herself for being so forward as to write a letter to a man she knows would mock her.

origin: It is very true.
modern: It’s true.

origin: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if she will not discover it.
modern: If she won’t tell Benedick, someone else should.

origin: To what end?
modern: And what would that accomplish?

origin: He would make but a sport of it and torment the poor lady worse.
modern: He’ll just turn it into a joke and torment the poor woman even more.

origin: An he should, it were an alms to hang him.
modern: If he did that, it would be a charitable deed to hang him.

origin: She’s an excellent sweet lady, and, out of all suspicion, she is virtuous.
modern: She’s an excellent, sweet woman, and there’s no doubt that she is virtuous.

origin: And she is exceeding wise.
modern: And she is very smart.

origin: Oh, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.
modern: Oh, my lord, when wisdom and passion are in one body, it’s ten to one that the passion will win.

origin: I am sorry for her, as I have just cause, being her uncle and her guardian.
modern: I am sorry for her, as I should be, since I am both her uncle and her guardian.

origin: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me.
modern: I wish she were in love with me instead.

origin: I would have daffed all other respects and made her half myself.
modern: I would have thrown away all other considerations and made her my wife.

origin: I pray you tell Benedick of it and hear what he will say.
modern: Please, tell Benedick about her feelings and see what he has to say.

origin: Were it good, think you?
modern: Is that a good idea, do you think?

origin: Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she will die if he love her not, and she will die ere she make her love known, and she will die if he woo her rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed crossness.
modern: Hero thinks Beatrice will surely die, for she says she’ll die if he doesn’t love her, and that she’ll die before she tells him, and she’ll die if he woos her and she’s made to hold back even one of her usual insults.

origin: She doth well.
modern: She’s probably right.

origin: If she should make tender of her love, ’tis very possible he’ll scorn it, for the man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.
modern: If she offers him her love, it’s very possible that he’ll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.

origin: He is a very proper man.
modern: He’s a very proper man.

origin: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.
modern: And I swear to God he’s very smart.

origin: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.
modern: He does indeed show sparks of something like wit.

origin: Very easily possible.
modern: It’s entirely possible.

origin: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
modern: I can see you don’t like this gentleman.

origin: No.
modern: No, absolutely not.

origin: But I pray you, who is his companion?
modern: But please tell me, who’s his best friend?

origin: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.
modern: He spends most of his time with the good, noble Claudio.

origin: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease!
modern: Oh God, Benedick will plague him like a disease!

origin: God help the noble Claudio!
modern: God help Claudio!

origin: If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.
modern: If he’s caught the Benedick, he’ll lose all his money before he’s cured.

origin: I will hold friends with you, lady.
modern: I’m going to make sure I stay on your good side, lady.

origin: Do, good friend.
modern: Do that, my friend.

origin: You will never run mad, niece.
modern: You will never fall victim to Benedick’s charms, my niece.

origin: No, not till a hot January.
modern: No, not until we see a hot January.

origin: Don Pedro is approached.
modern: Don Pedro is here.

origin: If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace.
modern: If he fears God, he must necessarily keep the peace.

origin: If he break the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.
modern: If he breaks the peace, he ought to enter into a quarrel with fear and trembling.

origin: Well, I am sorry for your niece.
modern: Well, I’m sorry for your niece.

origin: Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?
modern: Should we go find Benedick and tell him about Beatrice’s love?

origin: Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
modern: Against my will, I’ve been told to bring you in to dinner.

origin: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
modern: Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.

origin: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take pains to thank me.
modern: I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.

origin: If it had been painful, I would not have come.
modern: If the job had been painful, I would not have come.

origin: You take pleasure then in the message?
modern: So you took pleasure in bringing me this message?

origin: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife’s point and choke a daw withal.
modern: Yes, as much pleasure as one might take in choking a bird at knifepoint.

origin: You have no stomach, Signior.
modern: You don’t want to eat, sir?

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Goodbye, then.

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.” There’s a double meaning in that.
modern: Against my will, I’ve been told to bring you in to dinner.” There’s a double meaning in that.

origin: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
modern: I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.” That’s like saying, “Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.’” If this doesn’t move me to take pity on her, I’m a horrible person.

origin: If I do not love her, I am a Jew.
modern: If I don’t love her, I’m completely

origin: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.
modern: Margaret, run into the sitting room.

origin: There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice Proposing with the Prince and Claudio.
modern: You’ll find Beatrice there, talking to Claudio and the Prince.

origin: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her.
modern: Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we’re talking all about her.

origin: Say that thou overheardst us, And bid her steal into the pleachèd bower Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites Made proud by princes, that advance their pride Against that power that bred it.
modern: Tell her you heard us, and that she should sneak into the arbor where the crisscrossing branches overhead keep the honeysuckles out of the sun.

origin: There will she hide her To listen our propose.
modern: She can hide there and eavesdrop on our conversation.

origin: This is thy office.
modern: This is your job.

origin: Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.
modern: Do it well, and then leave us.

origin: I’ll make her come, I warrant you, presently.
modern: I’ll make her come right away, I promise you.

origin: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come, As we do trace this alley up and down, Our talk must only be of Benedick.
modern: All right Ursula, as Beatrice arrives, we’ll be walking up and down this alley and speaking about nothing but Benedick.

origin: When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit.
modern: Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves.

origin: My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice.
modern: It’ll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice.

origin: Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
modern: Let’s start.

origin: But are you sure That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
modern: But are you sure that Benedick loves Beatrice that much?

origin: So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
modern: That’s what the Prince and my fiancé say.

origin: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
modern: And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this, madam?

origin: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it, But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick, To wish him wrestle with affection And never to let Beatrice know of it.
modern: They did want me to tell her, but I persuaded them that, if they truly loved Benedick, they would try to get him to battle his emotions and keep Beatrice in the dark.

origin: Why did you so?
modern: Why did you do that?

origin: Doth not the gentleman Deserve as full as fortunate a bed As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
modern: Doesn’t Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice?

origin: What’s the matter, lieutenant?
modern: What’s the matter, lieutenant?

origin: I’ll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.
modern: I’ll beat him until the welts look like basket-weave!

origin: Beat me?
modern: You’ll beat me?

origin: Dost thou prate, rogue?
modern: Are you talking, you villain?

origin: Nay, good lieutenant!
modern: No, don’t hit him, lieutenant!

origin: I pray you, sir, hold your hand.
modern: Please, sir, restrain yourself.

origin: Let me go, sir, or I’ll knock you o'er the mazzard.
modern: Let me go, or I’ll knock you on the head.

origin: Come, come, you’re drunk.
modern: Come on, you’re drunk.

origin: Drunk?
modern: Drunk?

origin: Alas, gentlemen— Help, ho!— Lieutenant—sir, Montano— Help, masters!—Here’s a goodly watch indeed!
modern: No, lieutenant—God, gentlemen—Help—Lieutenant—sir, Montano—Help, men!—The night guard is coming!

origin: Who’s that which rings the bell?—Diablo, ho!
modern: Who’s sounding that alarm?

origin: The town will rise.
modern: The whole town will riot!

origin: Fie, Fie, lieutenant, You’ll be ashamed for ever.
modern: You’ll be ashamed of this forever!

origin: What is the matter here?
modern: What is the matter here?

origin: He dies!
modern: I’ll kill him!

origin: Hold, for your lives!
modern: Stop right now!

origin: Hold, ho!
modern: Stop!

origin: Hold!
modern: Stop!

origin: The general speaks to you.
modern: The general is talking to you!

origin: Hold, for shame!
modern: Stop, for God’s sake!

origin: For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.
modern: For heaven’s sake, stop this savage brawl!

origin: He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion.
modern: The next man who swings his sword must not care about his life, because the instant he strikes, he dies.

origin: Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the isle From her propriety.
modern: Stop that alarm from ringing, it’s scaring the islanders.

origin: What is the matter, masters?— Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving, Speak, who began this?
modern: What’s the matter here, gentlemen?—Honest Iago, you look upset.

origin: On thy love, I charge thee.
modern: Answer me.

origin: I do not know.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: Swords out, and tilting one at other’s breasts In opposition bloody.
modern: I don’t

origin: I cannot speak Any beginning to this peevish odds, And would in action glorious I had lost Those legs that brought me to a part of it.
modern: I’d rather have lost my legs in battle than be a part of this!

origin: Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil.
modern: You’re famous for it.

origin: What’s the matter That you unlace your reputation thus And spend your rich opinion for the name Of a night-brawler?
modern: What in the world made you risk your reputation like this and become a street brawler?

origin: Give me answer to it.
modern: Tell me.

origin: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger.
modern: Othello, I’ve been seriously hurt.

origin: Nor know I aught By me that’s said or done amiss this night, Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.
modern: I didn’t do anything wrong that I know of, unless it was a sin to defend myself when someone attacked me.

origin: Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied, Assays to lead the way.
modern: All right, now I’m starting to lose my cool.

origin: Tis monstrous.
modern: That’s unbelievably bad.

origin: Iago, who began ’t?
modern: Iago, who started it?

origin: Touch me not so near.
modern: You’re hitting close to home there.

origin: I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio.
modern: I’d rather cut my tongue out of my mouth than say anything bad about Michael Cassio.

origin: Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him.
modern: But I don’t think it’ll hurt him to tell the truth.

origin: When I came back— For this was brief— I found them close together At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them.
modern: They were nearly killing each other, as you saw when you pulled them apart.

origin: More of this matter cannot I report.
modern: I can’t tell you anything else.

origin: Though Cassio did some little wrong to him, As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received From him that fled some strange indignity Which patience could not pass.
modern: Cassio was wrong to hurt Montano, who was only trying to help him, but I’m sure the guy who ran away must have offended Cassio in some terrible way, and Cassio couldn’t let it pass.

origin: I’ll make thee an example.
modern: I’ll make you an example for the others to learn from.

origin: What’s the matter, dear?
modern: What’s the matter, dear?

origin: All’s well, sweeting, Come away to bed.— Myself will be your surgeon.
modern: Everything’s fine, now, sweetheart.

origin: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?
modern: Are you hurt, lieutenant?

origin: Ay, past all surgery.
modern: Yes, but no doctor can help me.

origin: Marry, heaven forbid!
modern: Oh I hope that’s not true!

origin: But thou must needs be sure My spirits and my place have in their power To make this bitter to thee.
modern: You know I’m powerful enough to make you pay for this.

origin: Patience, good sir.
modern: Please wait, sir.

origin: What tell’st thou me of robbing?
modern: Why are you talking about robbery?

origin: Because we come to do you service and you think we are ruffians, you’ll have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse.
modern: We come here to help you and you treat us like thugs, but you let an African horse climb all over your daughter.

origin: You’ll have your nephews neigh to you.
modern: Your grandsons will neigh to you like horses.

origin: You’ll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans.
modern: Your whole family will be ruined.

origin: What profane wretch art thou?
modern: What kind of crude jerk are you?

origin: I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs.
modern: The kind that tells you that the Moor is having sex with your daughter right now.

origin: Thou art a villain!
modern: You’re a villain!

origin: You are a senator!
modern: You’re a senator!

origin: This thou shalt answer.
modern: You’re going to pay for this, Roderigo.

origin: I know thee, Roderigo.
modern: I know who you are.

origin: Sir, I will answer any thing.
modern: I’ll answer for everything.

origin: Reputation, reputation, reputation!
modern: My reputation, my reputation!

origin: My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
modern: Oh, my reputation, Iago, my reputation!

origin: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily wound.
modern: I swear I thought you meant you’d been hurt physically.

origin: There is more sense in that than in reputation.
modern: Your physical health matters more than your reputation.

origin: You have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser.
modern: You haven’t lost it unless you think you have.

origin: What, man, there are ways to recover the general again.
modern: There are lots of ways to get on the general’s good side again.

origin: Sue to him again and he’s yours.
modern: Go to him, petition him.

origin: Drunk?
modern: Drunk?

origin: And speak parrot?
modern: Babbling senselessly?

origin: And squabble?
modern: Squabbling?

origin: Swagger?
modern: Swaggering?

origin: And discourse fustian with one’s own shadow?
modern: Ranting and raving to my own shadow!

origin: O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!
modern: Oh, wine is the devil!

origin: What was he that you followed with your sword?
modern: Who were you chasing with your sword?

origin: What had he done to you?
modern: What did he do to you?

origin: I know not.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

origin: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly.
modern: I remember a jumble of impressions, but nothing distinctly.

origin: A quarrel, but nothing wherefore.
modern: I remember a fight, but not why we were fighting.

origin: That we should, with joy, pleasance revel and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!
modern: Why do we party until we’re like animals?

origin: Why, but you are now well enough.
modern: You seem all right now.

origin: How came you thus recovered?
modern: How did you get better?

origin: One unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.
modern: One weakness led to another, to make me hate myself.

origin: Come, you are too severe a moraler.
modern: Come on, you’re being too hard on yourself.

origin: As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish this had not befallen.
modern: I wish none of this had happened, given the situation here, and your rank.

origin: But since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.
modern: But since this has happened, you should fix it for your own good.

origin: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard.
modern: I’ll ask him for my position back again, and he’ll tell me I’m a drunk.

origin: Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all.
modern: Even if I had a whole bunch of mouths, I wouldn’t be able to answer that.

origin: To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast!
modern: I was a reasonable man, then I became a fool, and finally a beast!

origin: Oh, strange!
modern: Oh, how strange!

origin: Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.
modern: Every glass of liquor is damned, and the devil’s the main ingredient!

origin: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used.
modern: Come on now, wine is good for you, if you know how to use it.

origin: Exclaim no more against it.
modern: Don’t say anything bad about wine anymore.

origin: And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.
modern: Lieutenant, I think you know I’m your friend.

origin: I have well approved it, sir.
modern: I know that, sir.

origin: I drunk!
modern: Imagine, me, a drunk!

origin: You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man.
modern: Any man can get drunk sometime.

origin: I tell you what you shall do.
modern: I’ll tell you what to do.

origin: Our general’s wife is now the general.
modern: Othello’s wife has a lot of influence now.

origin: Confess yourself freely to her, importune her help to put you in your place again.
modern: Ask her to help you get back your position.

origin: She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested.
modern: She is so generous, kind, and ready to help that she thinks it’s wrong not to do everything she can, even more than she is asked to do.

origin: This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
modern: Ask her to help you heal the rift between her husband and you.

origin: You advise me well.
modern: That’s good advice.

origin: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.
modern: I believe it completely.

origin: I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me.
modern: Early in the morning I’ll go visit Desdemona and plead my case.

origin: I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me.
modern: My situation is desperate.

origin: You are in the right.
modern: You’re doing the right thing.

origin: Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.
modern: Good night, lieutenant.

origin: Good night, honest Iago.
modern: Good night, honest Iago.

origin: And what’s he then that says I play the villain?
modern: Who can say I’m evil when my advice is so good?

origin: When this advice is free I give and honest, Probal to thinking and indeed the course To win the Moor again?
modern: That’s really the best way to win the Moor back again.

origin: For ’tis most easy Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue In any honest suit.
modern: It’s easy to get Desdemona on your side.

origin: She’s framed as fruitful As the free elements.
modern: She’s full of good intentions.

origin: How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course, Directly to his good?
modern: How am I evil to advise Cassio to do exactly what’ll do him good?

origin: When devils will the blackest sins put on They do suggest at first with heavenly shows As I do now.
modern: When devils are about to commit their biggest sins they put on their most heavenly faces, just like I’m doing now.

origin: And by how much she strives to do him good She shall undo her credit with the Moor.
modern: The more she

origin: So will I turn her virtue into pitch And out of her own goodness make the net That shall enmesh them all.
modern: And that’s how I’ll turn her good intentions into a big trap to snag them all.

origin: How now, Roderigo!
modern: Hello, Roderigo!

origin: My money is almost spent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains.
modern: I’ve spent most of my money, and tonight I got beaten up.

origin: And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.
modern: So with no money, but a little more wisdom, I’m going back to Venice.

origin: How poor are they that have not patience!
modern: You’re a poor man if you’re this impatient!

origin: What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
modern: No, it heals gradually.

origin: Thou know’st we work by wit and not by witchcraft, And wit depends on dilatory time.
modern: We achieve things with our intelligence, not by magic, and intelligent planning takes time.

origin: Does’t not go well?
modern: Aren’t things going well?

origin: In troth, ’tis morning.
modern: My God, it’s morning.

origin: Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
modern: All this excitement has made the time fly by.

origin: Retire thee, go where thou art billeted.
modern: Go back to where you’re staying and go to sleep.

origin: Nay, get thee gone.
modern: Go.

origin: Two things are to be done: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.
modern: Now two things still need to be done.

origin: I’ll set her on.
modern: I’ll put her on that.

origin: Ay, that’s the way.
modern: Yes, that’s the way I’ll do it.

origin: Masters, play here, I will content your pains.
modern: I’ll pay you for your trouble.

origin: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?
modern: Are these wind instruments?

origin: Ay, marry, are they, sir.
modern: Yes, they are.

origin: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.
modern: Oh, there’s the problem.

origin: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?
modern: What’s the problem?

origin: Well, sir, we will not.
modern: Well, we’ll stop, then.

origin: If you have any music that may not be heard, to ’t again.
modern: If you’ve got any music that can’t be heard, then play that.

origin: But, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly care.
modern: But as I said, the general isn’t really in the mood to hear music now.

origin: We have none such, sir.
modern: We don’t have any music that can’t be heard.

origin: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I’ll away.
modern: Then pack up your instruments and go away.

origin: Go, vanish into air, away!
modern: Go!

origin: Dost thou hear, my honest friend?
modern: Do you hear, my friend?

origin: Prithee, keep up thy quillets.
modern: Please don’t play games.

origin: She is stirring, sir.
modern: CASSIO  She’s awake, sir.

origin: If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.
modern: If she feels like coming over here, I’ll give her your message.

origin: In happy time, Iago.
modern: Good to see you, Iago.

origin: You have not been abed, then?
modern: You didn’t go to sleep, then?

origin: Why, no.
modern: No.

origin: My suit to her Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona Procure me some access.
modern: I’m going to ask her to let me talk to Desdemona.

origin: I humbly thank you for’t.
modern: I humbly thank you.

origin: Good morrow, good Lieutenant.
modern: Even for a  Good morning, lieutenant.

origin: I am sorry For your displeasure, but all will sure be well.
modern: I’m sorry about what happened, but I’m sure everything will turn out all right.

origin: The general and his wife are talking of it, And she speaks for you stoutly.
modern: The general and his wife are talking about it now, and she’s defending you strongly.

origin: The Moor replies That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom He might not but refuse you.
modern: The Moor says the man you hurt is very important in Cyprus, and that under the circumstances he has no choice but to refuse to reinstate you.

origin: But he protests he loves you And needs no other suitor but his likings To take the safest occasion by the front To bring you in again.
modern: But he says he still loves and respects you, and based on his own feelings alone he’s looking for an opportunity to safely take you back.

origin: Yet I beseech you, If you think fit, or that it may be done, Give me advantage of some brief discourse With Desdemona alone.
modern: Please find a way to give me some time alone with Desdemona, if you think that’s all right.

origin: Pray you come in.
modern: Please come in.

origin: I will bestow you where you shall have time To speak your bosom freely.
modern: I’ll take you to a place where you can speak freely.

origin: I am much bound to you.
modern: Thank you very much.

origin: These letters give, Iago, to the pilot, And by him do my duties to the senate.
modern: Iago, give these letters to the ship’s captain who brought me here, and ask him to pay my respects to the Senate of Venice.

origin: That done, I will be walking on the works, Repair there to me.
modern: Now that’s done, I’m going to walk on the fortification walls.

origin: Well, my good lord, I’ll do ’t.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see ’t?
modern: Shall we go see this fortification, men?

origin: We’ll wait upon your lordship.
modern: We’re at your service, my lord.

origin: Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do All my abilities in thy behalf.
modern: I’ll do everything I can for you, Cassio.

origin: Good madam, do.
modern: Please do, madam.

origin: Do not doubt, Cassio, But I will have my lord and you again As friendly as you were.
modern: I’m sure you and my husband will be as friendly as you were before.

origin: You do love my lord.
modern: Yes, my lady.

origin: Ay, but, lady, That policy may either last so long, Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet, Or breed itself so out of circumstances, That, I being absent and my place supplied, My general will forget my love and service.
modern: But those political considerations might last such a long time that the general will forget my love and service, especially if I’m gone and someone else has my job.

origin: My lord shall never rest, I’ll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.
modern: My husband will never get a moment’s rest, I’ll keep him up at night talking about you until he runs out

origin: But if you know not this my manners tell me We have your wrong rebuke.
modern: But if you didn’t know about it, then you were wrong to get mad at us.

origin: Do not believe That, from the sense of all civility, I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
modern: I’d never play pranks on you.

origin: If she be in her chamber or your house, Let loose on me the justice of the state For thus deluding you.
modern: If she is, you can sue me for lying to you.

origin: Strike on the tinder, ho!
modern: Light the candles!

origin: Give me a taper, call up all my people!
modern: Wake up my whole household!

origin: This accident is not unlike my dream, Belief of it oppresses me already.
modern: I dreamt about this.

origin: Light, I say, light!
modern: Give me some light!

origin: Farewell, for I must leave you.
modern: It’s time for me to say goodbye to you.

origin: It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place, To be producted (as, if I stay, I shall) Against the Moor.
modern: It would be inappropriate—dangerous, even—for me to be seen working against the Moor, as I would if I stayed.

origin: In which regard,
modern: of patience.

origin: Therefore be merry, Cassio, For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away.
modern: I’m your advocate, and I’d rather die than give up on you.

origin: Madam, here comes my lord.
modern: Madam, here comes your husband.

origin: Madam, I’ll take my leave.
modern: Madam, I’d better leave now.

origin: Why, stay and hear me speak.
modern: Why not stay and hear me talk to him?

origin: Madam, not now.
modern: No, madam.

origin: I am very ill at ease, Unfit for mine own purposes.
modern: I’m very uncomfortable, and that won’t help my case.

origin: Well, do your discretion.
modern: Well, do whatever you think best.

origin: Ha!
modern: Hey!

origin: I like not that.
modern: I don’t like that.

origin: What dost thou say?
modern: What did you say?

origin: Nothing, my lord, or if—I know not what.
modern: Nothing, my lord, or if I did—I don’t know what.

origin: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?
modern: Wasn’t that Cassio leaving my wife?

origin: Cassio, my lord?
modern: Cassio, my lord?

origin: I do believe ’twas he.
modern: I really think it was him.

origin: How now, my lord?
modern: What’s this, my lord?

origin: I have been talking with a suitor here, A man that languishes in your displeasure.
modern: I was talking to a petitioner here just now, someone who’s suffering from your anger.

origin: Who is ’t you mean?
modern: Who do you mean?

origin: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio.
modern: Your lieutenant, Cassio.

origin: Good my lord, If I have any grace or power to move you His present reconciliation take.
modern: Oh, if I’ve got any influence over you at all, please patch things up with him.

origin: I prithee, call him back.
modern: Please call him and tell him to come back here.

origin: Went he hence now?
modern: Was that him just now?

origin: Ay, sooth, so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him.
modern: Yes.

origin: Good love, call him back.
modern: My love, call him back in here.

origin: Not now, sweet Desdemona.
modern: Not now, my sweet Desdemona.

origin: Some other time.
modern: Some other time.

origin: But shall ’t be shortly?
modern: But will it be soon?

origin: The sooner, sweet, for you.
modern: Very soon, because you want it.

origin: Shall ’t be tonight at supper?
modern: Will it be tonight at supper?

origin: No, not tonight.
modern: No, not tonight.

origin: Tomorrow dinner, then?
modern: Then tomorrow at dinner?

origin: Why, then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn.
modern: Well then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morning.

origin: On Tuesday noon, or night, or Wednesday morn.
modern: Or Tuesday noon or at night, or Wednesday morning.

origin: I prithee name the time, but let it not Exceed three days.
modern: Please just name a time, but don’t wait more than three days.

origin: In faith, he’s penitent, And yet his trespass, in our common reason (Save that, they say, the wars must make example Out of her best) is not, almost, a fault T' incur a private check.
modern: His mistake was hardly worth punishing him for in the first place—though in wartime it is sometimes necessary to make examples out of even the best soldiers.

origin: When shall he come?
modern: So when should he come?

origin: Tell me, Othello.
modern: Tell me, Othello.

origin: Trust me, I could do much— Prithee, no more.
modern: I swear, I could do so much— Please, no more.

origin: Let him come when he will, I will deny thee nothing.
modern: I won’t refuse you anything.

origin: Why, this is not a boon, 'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves, Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm, Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit To your own person.
modern: This is like if I asked you to wear your gloves when it’s cold outside, or eat nutritious food, or do something that’s good for you.

origin: Nay, when I have a suit Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed It shall be full of poise and difficult weight And fearful to be granted.
modern: If I ever have to ask you for something that will put your luck to the test, it’ll be something difficult and terrible.

origin: I will deny thee nothing!
modern: I won’t deny you anything!

origin: Whereon I do beseech thee, grant me this, To leave me but a little to myself.
modern: But in return, please, do one thing for me: leave me alone for a little while.

origin: Shall I deny you?
modern: Would I ever deny you anything?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Farewell, my lord.
modern: Goodbye, my husband.

origin: Farewell, my Desdemona.
modern: Goodbye, my Desdemona.

origin: I’ll come to thee straight.
modern: I’ll come see you right away.

origin: Perdition catch my soul But I do love thee!
modern: God help me, I love you!

origin: My noble lord— What dost thou say, Iago?
modern: My noble lord— What is it, Iago?

origin: Did Michael Cassio, when you wooed my lady, Know of your love?
modern: When you were wooing Desdemona, did Michael Cassio know about it?

origin: He did, from first to last.
modern: Yes, he knew about it the whole time.

origin: Why dost thou ask?
modern: Why do you ask?

origin: Why of thy thought, Iago?
modern: Why are you curious, Iago?

origin: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
modern: I didn’t realize he knew her.

origin: Indeed?
modern: Oh, really?

origin: Indeed?
modern: Oh, really?

origin: Ay, indeed!
modern: Yes, really.

origin: Discern’st thou aught in that?
modern: Do you see something wrong with that?

origin: Is he not honest?
modern: Isn’t he an honest man?

origin: Honest, my lord?
modern: Honest, my lord?

origin: Honest, ay, honest.
modern: Honest, yes, honest.

origin: My lord, for aught I know.
modern: As far as I know, sir.

origin: What dost thou think?
modern: What are you thinking?

origin: Think, my lord?
modern: Thinking, my lord?

origin: Think, my lord?” Alas, thou echo’st me As if there were some monster in thy thought Too hideous to be shown.
modern: Thinking, my lord?” My God, you keep repeating everything I say as if you were thinking something too horrible to say out loud.

origin: Thou dost mean something.
modern: You’re thinking something.

origin: I heard thee say even now thou lik’st not that When Cassio left my wife.
modern: Just a minute ago I heard you say you didn’t like it when Cassio left my wife.

origin: What didst not like?
modern: What didn’t you like?

origin: And when I told thee he was of my counsel Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried’st “Indeed?” And didst contract and purse thy brow together As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit.
modern: And when I told you he was involved the whole time I was trying to get Desdemona, you were like, “Oh, really?” And then you frowned and wrinkled up your forehead as if you were imagining something horrible.

origin: If thou dost love me Show me thy thought.
modern: If you’re my friend, tell me what you’re thinking.

origin: My lord, you know I love you.
modern: My lord, you know I’m your friend.

origin: I think thou dost.
modern: I think you are.

origin: For Michael Cassio, I dare be sworn, I think, that he is honest.
modern: As for Michael Cassio, I think it would be safe for me to swear that he’s honest.

origin: I think so too.
modern: I think so too.

origin: Men should be what they seem, Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
modern: If they’re not honest, they shouldn’t look like they are!

origin: Certain, men should be what they seem.
modern: Absolutely, people should be what they appear to be.

origin: Why then I think Cassio’s an honest man.
modern: In that case, I think Cassio’s an honest man.

origin: Nay, yet there’s more in this.
modern: No, I think there’s more to this than you’re letting on.

origin: I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings, As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts The worst of words.
modern: Please tell me what you’re thinking—even your worst suspicions.

origin: Utter my thoughts?
modern: You want me to say what I’m thinking?

origin: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou but think’st him wronged and mak’st his ear A stranger to thy thoughts.
modern: You’re not being a good friend, Iago, if you even  Please don’t ask me to tell you.

origin: What dost thou mean?
modern: What are you talking about?

origin: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord, Is the immediate jewel of their souls.
modern: A good reputation is the most valuable thing we have—men and women alike.

origin: Who steals my purse steals trash.
modern: If you steal my money, you’re just stealing trash.

origin: Tis something, nothing: 'Twas mine, ’tis his, and has been slave to thousands.
modern: It’s something, it’s nothing: it’s yours, it’s mine, and it’ll belong to thousands more.

origin: But he that filches from me my good name Robs me of that which not enriches him And makes me poor indeed.
modern: But if you steal my reputation, you’re robbing me of something that doesn’t make you richer, but makes me much poorer.

origin: I’ll know thy thoughts.
modern: I’m going to find out what you’re thinking.

origin: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand, Nor shall not, whilst ’tis in my custody.
modern: You can’t find that out, even if you held my heart in your hand you couldn’t make me tell you.

origin: Ha!
modern: What?

origin: Oh, beware, my lord, of jealousy!
modern: Beware of jealousy, my lord!

origin: It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock The meat it feeds on.
modern: It’s a green-eyed monster that makes fun of the victims it devours.

origin: Oh, misery!
modern: Oh, what misery!

origin: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
modern: The person who’s poor and contented is rich enough.

origin: Good heaven, the souls of all my tribe defend From jealousy!
modern: God, help us not be jealous!

origin: Why, why is this?
modern: Why are you telling me this?

origin: Think’st thou I’d make a life of jealousy, To follow still the changes of the moon With fresh suspicions?
modern: Do you think I would live a life of jealousy, tormented by new suspicions every hour?

origin: No!
modern: No.

origin: To be once in doubt Is to be resolved.
modern: If there’s any doubt, there is no doubt.

origin: Tis not to make me jealous To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company, Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances.
modern: If you say my wife is beautiful, eats well, loves good company, speaks freely, sings, plays music, and dances well, you’re not making me jealous.

origin: Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.
modern: When a woman is virtuous, talents like these just make her better.

origin: Therefore, as I am bound, Receive it from me.
modern: So please listen to me.

origin: I speak not yet of proof.
modern: I’m not talking about proof yet.

origin: Look to ’t.
modern: Watch out!

origin: I know our country disposition well.
modern: I know the people of Venice well.

origin: In Venice they do let God see the pranks They dare not show their husbands.
modern: They let God see things they wouldn’t show their husbands.

origin: Dost thou say so?
modern: Do you really think so?

origin: And so she did.
modern: That’s right, she did.

origin: Why, go to then.
modern: Well, there you go.

origin: She that, so young, could give out such a seeming, To seel her father’s eyes up close as oak, He thought ’twas witchcraft.
modern: She was so young, but she deceived her father so thoroughly he thought it was witchcraft!

origin: But I am much to blame.
modern: But I’m sorry I’ve blurted all this out.

origin: I humbly do beseech you of your pardon For too much loving you.
modern: I beg your pardon for loving you too much.

origin: I am bound to thee forever.
modern: I’m indebted to you forever.

origin: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.
modern: You seem a little depressed about this.

origin: Not a jot, not a jot.
modern: Not at all, not at all.

origin: Trust me, I fear it has.
modern: Really, I’m afraid you are.

origin: I hope you will consider what is spoke Comes from my love.
modern: I hope you remember that I said all this because I love you.

origin: But I do see you’re moved.
modern: But I see you’re troubled.

origin: I am to pray you not to strain my speech To grosser issues nor to larger reach Than to suspicion.
modern: Please don’t take what I said more seriously than it deserves to be taken.

origin: I will not.
modern: I won’t.

origin: Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success Which my thoughts aimed not at.
modern: If you take it too seriously, it’ll have bad effects that I didn’t want it to have.

origin: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.
modern: Cassio’s a good friend of mine—My lord, I can see you’re upset.

origin: No, not much moved.
modern: No, not too upset.

origin: Farewell, farewell.
modern: Goodbye, goodbye.

origin: If more thou dost perceive, let me know more.
modern: If you see anything else, let me know.

origin: Set on thy wife to observe.
modern: Tell your wife to watch her.

origin: Leave me, Iago.
modern: Leave me alone now, Iago.

origin: My lord, I take my leave.
modern: My lord, I’ll say goodbye now.

origin: Note if your lady strain his entertainment
modern: and affection, even if it’s just an act.

origin: That you shall surely find him, Lead to the Sagittary the raisèd search, And there will I be with him.
modern: He and I will be there.

origin: It is too true an evil.
modern: It’s true.

origin: Gone she is.
modern: She’s gone.

origin: And what’s to come of my despisèd time Is naught but bitterness.
modern: The rest of my life will be nothing but bitterness.
