origin: Now, Roderigo, Where didst thou see her?—Oh, unhappy girl!— With the Moor, say’st thou?—Who would be a father?— How didst thou know ’twas she?—Oh, she deceives me Past thought!—What said she to you?—Get more tapers, Raise all my kindred.
modern: Now, Roderigo, where did you see her?—Oh, that miserable wretch!—You say you saw her with the Moor?—Oh, who would want to be a father?—How did you know it was her?—To think she tricked me so easily!—What did she say to you?—Get me more candles, and wake up all my relatives.

origin: Are they married, think you?
modern: Do you think they’re married?

origin: Truly, I think they are.
modern: Yes, I really think so.

origin: Oh, heaven, how got she out?
modern: Oh, heaven, how did she get out?

origin: Oh, treason of the blood!
modern: My own flesh and blood rebels against me!

origin: Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds By what you see them act.
modern: Fathers, never trust your daughters just because they act obedient and innocent.

origin: Is there not charms By which the property of youth and maidhood May be abused?
modern: Are there magic spells that can lead young virgins astray?

origin: Have you not read, Roderigo, Of some such thing?
modern: Have you ever heard of anything like that, Roderigo?

origin: Yes, sir, I have indeed.
modern: Yes, sir, I have.

origin: I think I can discover him, if you please To get good guard and go along with me.
modern: I think I can find him.

origin: With any strong or vehement importunity.
modern: giving it back to him.

origin: Much will be seen in that.
modern: That will tell you a lot.

origin: In the meantime, Let me be thought too busy in my fears— As worthy cause I have to fear I am— And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.
modern: But in the meantime, just assume that I’m paranoid—as I’m pretty sure I am—and keep thinking she’s innocent, please.

origin: Fear not my government.
modern: Don’t worry about how I handle it.

origin: I once more take my leave.
modern: I’ll say goodbye once more.

origin: This fellow’s of exceeding honesty And knows all quantities, with a learnèd spirit, Of human dealings.
modern: This Iago is extremely honest and good, and he knows a lot about human behavior.

origin: If I do prove her haggard, Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings, I’d whistle her off and let her down the wind To prey at fortune.
modern: If it turns out that she really is running around on me, I’ll send her away, even though it’ll break my heart.

origin: Oh, curse of marriage That we can call these delicate creatures ours And not their appetites!
modern: Oh what a curse marriage is!

origin: I had rather be a toad And live upon the vapor of a dungeon Than keep a corner in the thing I love For others' uses.
modern: I’d rather be a toad in a moldy basement than to have only a part of someone I love, sharing the rest of her with others.

origin: Yet ’tis the plague to great ones, Prerogatived are they less than the base.
modern: This is the plague of important men—our wives betray us more than those of poor men.

origin: Tis destiny unshunnable, like death.
modern: It’s our destiny, like death.

origin: Even then this forkèd plague is fated to us When we do quicken.
modern: We are destined to be betrayed when we are born.

origin: Look where she comes.
modern: Oh, here she comes.

origin: If she be false, heaven mocked itself.
modern: If she’s cheated on me, then heaven itself is a fake.

origin: I’ll not believe ’t.
modern: I don’t believe it.

origin: How now, my dear Othello?
modern: What’s going on, Othello, darling?

modern: The nobles of Cyprus whom you invited to dinner are waiting for you.

origin: I am to blame.

origin: Why do you speak so faintly?
modern: Why are you whispering?

origin: I have a pain upon my forehead, here.
modern: I have a  That’s from lack of sleep.

origin: Why that’s with watching, ’twill away again.
modern: It’ll go away.

modern: Let me wrap up your head, and it will feel okay in less than an hour.

origin: I am very sorry that you are not well.

origin: My wayward husband hath a hundred times
modern: hundred times.

origin: Wooed me to steal it, but she so loves the token (For he conjured her she should ever keep it) That she reserves it evermore about her To kiss and talk to.
modern: But she loves it so much (since Othello told her she should always keep it with her) that she always keeps it near her to kiss it and talk to it.

origin: I’ll have the work ta'en out And give ’t Iago.
modern: I’ll copy the embroidery pattern and then give it to Iago.

origin: What he will do with it Heaven knows, not I. I nothing but to please his fantasy.
modern: Heaven knows what he’s going to do with it.

origin: How now!
modern: What’s going on?

origin: What do you here alone?
modern: What are you doing here alone?

origin: Do not you chide.
modern: Don’t snap at me.

modern: I’ve got something for you.

modern: You’ve got something for me?

origin: It is a common thing— Ha?
modern: It’s a common  What?

origin: To have a foolish wife.
modern: to have a stupid wife.

origin: Oh, is that all?
modern: Oh, is that so?

modern: And what would you give me for the handkerchief?

origin: What handkerchief?
modern: What handkerchief?

origin: What handkerchief?
modern: What handkerchief?

origin: Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona, That which so often you did bid me steal.
modern: The one the Moor gave to Desdemona, which you asked me to steal so many times.

origin: Hast stolen it from her?
modern: You stole it from her?

origin: No, but she let it drop by negligence And, to th' advantage, I being here, took ’t up.
modern: She dropped it carelessly, and, seizing the opportunity, since I was here, I picked it up.

origin: Look, here it is.
modern: Look, here it is.

origin: A good wench, give it me.
modern: Good girl, give it to me.

origin: What will you do with ’t, that you have been so earnest To have me filch it?
modern: And what are you going to do with it?

origin: Why, what is that to you?
modern: What’s it to you?

origin: If it be not for some purpose of import, Give ’t me again.
modern: If you don’t need it for some important reason, then give it back to me.

origin: Poor lady, she’ll run mad When she shall lack it.
modern: Poor lady, she’ll go crazy when she sees it’s missing.

origin: Go, leave me.
modern: Now go, leave me.

origin: The Moor already changes with my poison.
modern: The Moor’s mind has already become infected with my poisonous suggestions.

origin: Look, where he comes.
modern: Here he comes.

origin: Not poppy nor mandragora Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world, Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep Which thou owedst yesterday.
modern: No drugs or sleeping pills will ever give you the restful sleep that you had last night.

origin: False to me?
modern: She’s cheating on me?

origin: I swear ’tis better to be much abused Than but to know ’t a little.
modern: It is better to be tricked completely than to only suspect a little.

origin: How now, my lord!
modern: What’s with you, my lord?

origin: What sense had I in her stol'n hours of lust?
modern: I had no idea she was cheating on me.

origin: I saw ’t not, thought it not, it harmed not me.
modern: I never saw it or suspected it, so it never hurt me.

origin: I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry.
modern: I slept well, ate well, and was happy.

origin: I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips.
modern: I never saw Cassio’s kisses on her lips.

origin: He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n, Let him not know’t, and he’s not robbed at all.
modern: A man who’s robbed, but doesn’t miss what’s stolen, isn’t robbed at all.

origin: I am sorry to hear this.
modern: I’m sorry to hear this.

origin: I had been happy if the general camp, Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body, So I had nothing known.
modern: I would’ve been happy if the whole army had had sex with her, the lowest-ranking grunts and all, as long as I didn’t know anything about it.

origin: Oh, now forever Farewell the tranquil mind!
modern: Oh, goodbye to my peace of mind!

origin: Farewell content!

origin: Farewell the plumèd troops and the big wars That makes ambition virtue!
modern: Goodbye to the soldiers and to the wars that make men great!

origin: Oh, farewell!
modern: Goodbye!

origin: Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump, The spirit-stirring drum, th' ear-piercing fife, The royal banner, and all quality, Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
modern: Goodbye to the horses and the trumpets and the drums, the flute and the splendid banners, and all those proud displays and pageantry of war!

origin: And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats The immortal Jove’s dead clamors counterfeit, Farewell!
modern: And you deadly cannons that roar like thunderbolts thrown by the gods, goodbye!

origin: Othello’s occupation’s gone.
modern: Othello’s career is over.

origin: Is ’t possible, my lord?
modern: Is this possible, my lord?

origin: Is ’t come to this?
modern: Has it come to this?

origin: Make me to see ’t, or at the least so prove it That the probation bear no hinge nor loop To hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!
modern: Show me, or at least prove it beyond the shadow of a doubt.

origin: Oh, heaven forgive me!
modern: Oh, heaven help me!

origin: Are you a man?

origin: Have you a soul or sense?
modern: Don’t you have any sense at all?

origin: God buy you, take mine office.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: O monstrous world!
modern: What a horrible world we live in!

modern: It’s not safe to be straightforward and honest.

origin: Nay, stay.
modern: No, stop.

origin: Thou shouldst be honest.
modern: You should always be honest.

origin: I should be wise, for honesty’s a fool And loses that it works for.

modern: I swear, I think my wife’s faithful, and I think she’s not.

origin: I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
modern: I think you’re trustworthy one minute and then not the next.

origin: I’ll have some proof.
modern: I need proof!

origin: Her name, that was as fresh As Dian’s visage, is now begrimed and black As mine own face.
modern: Her reputation was as pure as the snow, but now it’s as dirty and black as my own face.

origin: Would I were satisfied!
modern: As long as there are

origin: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion.
modern: I see you’re all eaten up with emotion.

origin: I do repent me that I put it to you.

origin: You would be satisfied?
modern: You want proof?

origin: Would?
modern: Want?

origin: And may, but how?

origin: How satisfied, my lord?

origin: Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on, Behold her topped?
modern: Are you going to hide and watch them having sex?

origin: Death and damnation!
modern: Death and damnation!

origin: Oh!
modern: Oh!

origin: It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect.
modern: I think it would be very hard to arrange for them to have sex while you watched.

origin: What shall I say?
modern: What can I say?

origin: Where’s satisfaction?

origin: It is impossible you should see this, Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys, As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross As ignorance made drunk.
modern: It’d be impossible for you to watch them, even if they were as horny as animals in heat and as stupid as drunks.

origin: But yet, I say, If imputation and strong circumstances Which lead directly to the door of truth Will give you satisfaction, you may have ’t.
modern: But if you would be willing to accept circumstantial evidence as proof, we can get that.

origin: Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.
modern: Give me one good reason to think she’s cheating on me.

origin: I do not like the office.
modern: I don’t like what you’re asking me to do.

origin: But, sith I am entered in this cause so far, Pricked to ’t by foolish honesty and love, I will go on.
modern: But since I’ve gotten myself involved this far, because I’m so stupidly honest and because I like you so much, I’ll keep going.

origin: I lay with Cassio lately And, being troubled with a raging tooth, I could not sleep.
modern: I recently shared a bed with Cassio, and I couldn’t sleep because of a raging toothache.

origin: Monstrous!
modern: Monstrous!

origin: Nay, this was but his dream.
modern: No, it was just a dream.

origin: Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.
modern: It’s a reason for suspicion, even though it’s just a dream.

origin: And this may help to thicken other proofs That do demonstrate thinly.
modern: And it might back up other evidence that may seem too flimsy.

origin: I’ll tear her all to pieces!
modern: I’ll tear her to pieces!

modern: Just tell me this: have you ever seen her holding a handkerchief with an embroidered strawberry pattern on it?

origin: If it be that— If it be that, or any that was hers, It speaks against her with the other proofs.
modern: If it’s the same one— If it’s the same one, or any one that belongs to her, then together with the other evidence it’s pretty strong.

origin: Oh, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
modern: Oh, I’d kill that bastard Cassio forty thousand times if I could!

origin: One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.

origin: Now do I see ’tis true.
modern: Now I see it’s true.

origin: Swell, bosom, with thy fraught, For ’tis of aspics' tongues!
modern: My heart feels like it’s full of poisonous snakes!

origin: Patience, I say.
modern: Be patient, I’m telling you.

origin: Your mind may change.

origin: Never, Iago.

modern: I swear to God I’ll get revenge.

origin: Do not rise yet.
modern: Don’t get up yet.

origin: Witness, you ever-burning lights above, You elements that clip us round about, Witness that here Iago doth give up The execution of his wit, hands, heart, To wronged Othello’s service.
modern: Let heaven be my witness—I’m putting my mind, my heart, and my hands in Othello’s control.

origin: Let him command, And to obey shall be in me remorse, What bloody business ever.
modern: Let him command me, and I’ll do whatever he asks, no matter how violent.

origin: I greet thy love Not with vain thanks but with acceptance bounteous, And will upon the instant put thee to ’t.
modern: I accept your devotion with my deepest love.

origin: Within these three days let me hear thee say That Cassio’s not alive.
modern: Within the next three days I want to hear you tell me that Cassio’s dead.

origin: But let her live.
modern: But let her live.

origin: Oh, damn her, damn her!

origin: Why, man?

origin: Go to.

modern: Telling you where he’s sleeping is like telling you where I’m lying.

origin: Can anything be made of this?

origin: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.
modern: I don’t know where he’s staying, so if I told you he’s sleeping here or there, I’d be lying.

origin: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report?
modern: Can you ask around and find out?

origin: Seek him, bid him come hither.
modern: Find him and tell him to come here.

origin: Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.
modern: Tell him I’ve spoken to my husband on his behalf, and I think everything will be all right.

origin: To do this is within the compass of man’s wit, and therefore I will attempt the doing it.

origin: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?
modern: Where could I have lost that handkerchief, Emilia?

origin: I know not, madam.

origin: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse Full of crusadoes.
modern: Believe me, I’d rather have lost a purse full of gold coins.

origin: And but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are, it were enough To put him to ill thinking.
modern: This would be enough to make my husband suspect me, if he wasn’t so free of jealousy.

origin: Is he not jealous?
modern: He’s not jealous?

origin: Who, he?

origin: I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him.

origin: Look where he comes.

modern: I won’t leave him alone until he gives Cassio his job back.—How are you, my lord?

modern: Hot, hot and moist.

origin: This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer,
modern: With a hand like this you need to

origin: Much castigation, exercise devout, For here’s a young and sweating devil here, That commonly rebels.
modern: fast and pray to stave off temptations.

origin: Tis a good hand, A frank one.
modern: It’s a nice hand, an open one.

origin: The hearts of old gave hands, But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

origin: I cannot speak of this.

modern: I sent for Cassio to come talk with you.

origin: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.

origin: That’s a fault.

origin: The thoughts of people.
modern: almost read people’s thoughts.

origin: She told her, while she kept it 'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made gift of it, my father’s eye Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt After new fancies.
modern: She told my mother that as long as she kept it with her, my father would love and desire her.

origin: She, dying, gave it me And bid me, when my fate would have me wived, To give it her.
modern: When she was dying she gave it to me and told me to give it to my wife when I got married.

origin: I did so, and take heed on ’t, Make it a darling like your precious eye.
modern: I did.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

origin: Tis true.
modern: Yes, it’s true.

origin: There’s magic in the web of it.

origin: A sibyl, that had numbered in the world The sun to course two hundred compasses, In her prophetic fury sewed the work.
modern: A two-hundred-year-old witch sewed it while she was in a fevered trance.

origin: The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk, And it was dyed in mummy which the skillful Conserved of maidens' hearts.
modern: The silk came from sacred silkworms, and it was dyed with fluid made from embalmed virgins' hearts.

origin: Indeed?
modern: Really?

origin: Is ’t true?

origin: Most veritable, therefore look to ’t well.
modern: It’s absolutely true, so take good care of it.

origin: Ha!

origin: Wherefore?

modern: Why are you yelling at me so angrily?

origin: Is ’t lost?

origin: Is ’t gone?

origin: Speak, is ’t out o' th' way?

origin: Bless us!

origin: Say you?

origin: How!

origin: Fetch me the handkerchief—my mind misgives.

origin: Come, come, You’ll never meet a more sufficient man.

origin: To eat us hungerly, and when they are full, They belch us.
modern: They eat us up hungrily, and when they’re full, they vomit us up.

origin: Tis she must do ’t, And, lo, the happiness!

origin: My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered.

origin: I prithee, do so.

modern: There must be some political news from Venice, or some dangerous plot here in Cyprus has ruined his good mood.

origin: Tis even so, For let our finger ache and it endues Our other healthful members even to that sense Of pain.

origin: But jealous souls will not be answered so.

origin: They are not ever jealous for the cause, But jealous for they’re jealous.
modern: They’re never jealous for a reason; they’re just jealous.

modern: It’s like a monster that just grows and grows, out of nothing.

origin: Lady, amen.
modern: Amen to that, lady.

origin: I will go seek him.—Cassio, walk hereabout.
modern: I’ll go look for him—Cassio, stay around here.

origin: If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
modern: If he’s in a good mood I’ll mention you again, and do everything I can.

origin: I humbly thank your ladyship.
modern: I thank you, lady.

origin: Save you, friend Cassio!
modern: Hello, Cassio!

origin: What make you from home?
modern: Why are you so far from home?

origin: How is ’t with you, my most fair Bianca?
modern: How are you, my pretty Bianca?

origin: Indeed, sweet love, I was coming to your house.
modern: To tell you the truth, I was just going to your house.

origin: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
modern: And I was just going to yours.

origin: What, keep a week away?
modern: You’ve kept away from me for a week?

origin: Seven days and nights?
modern: Seven days and seven nights?

origin: Eight score eight hours?
modern: A hundred and sixty-eight hours?

origin: And lovers' absent hours More tedious than the dial eightscore times!
modern: And lovers' hours are a hundred and sixty times longer than normal ones!

origin: Oh weary reckoning!
modern: What a tedious wait!

origin: O Cassio, whence came this?
modern: Oh, Cassio, where did you get this?

origin: Is ’t come to this?
modern: Has it come to this?

origin: Well, well.
modern: Well, well.

origin: Go to, woman, Throw your vile guesses in the devil’s teeth From whence you have them.
modern: Oh, come on, woman.

origin: Why, whose is it?
modern: Well, whose is it?

origin: I like the work well.
modern: It’s pretty.

origin: Ere it be demanded, As like enough it will, I would have it copied.
modern: So I’d like it copied.

origin: Take it and do ’t, and leave me for this time.
modern: Take it and do that for me, and leave me alone for a while.

origin: Leave you!
modern: Leave you alone!

origin: Wherefore?
modern: Why?

origin: I do attend here on the general And think it no addition, nor my wish, To have him see me womaned.
modern: I’m waiting here for the general, and I don’t want him to see me with a woman.

origin: Why, I pray you?
modern: And why’s that?

origin: Not that I love you not.
modern: It’s not because I don’t love you.

origin: But that you do not love me.
modern: But you don’t love me.

origin: I pray you bring me on the way a little And say if I shall see you soon at night.
modern: Please, just walk with me a little ways, and tell me if I’ll see you later tonight.

origin: Tis but a little way that I can bring you, For I attend here.
modern: I can only walk a little way with you, since I’m waiting here.

origin: But I’ll see you soon.
modern: But I’ll see you soon.

origin: Tis very good.
modern: All right, have it your way.

origin: I must be circumstanced.
modern: I have to make do.

origin: Nine or ten times I had thought t' have yerked him here under the ribs.
modern: Nine or ten times I wanted to stab him under the ribs.

origin: Tis better as it is.
modern: It’s better that you didn’t kill him.

origin: Nay, but he prated And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms Against your honor That, with the little godliness I have, I did full hard forbear him.
modern: But he kept chattering so foolishly, talking about you in such insulting and despicable terms, that it was hard for me to restrain myself.

origin: Let him do his spite.
modern: But please tell me, sir, is your marriage  Let him do his worst.

origin: My services which I have done the signiory Shall out-tongue his complaints.
modern: The services I have done for the Venetian government will count for more than his complaints will.

origin: Will you think so?
modern: Do you really think so?

origin: Think so, Iago?
modern: What do you mean, do I think so?

origin: What, To kiss in private?
modern: What, just because they kissed in private?

origin: An unauthorized kiss!
modern: An illicit kiss!

origin: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm?
modern: Maybe she was just naked in bed with him for an hour or so, but they didn’t do anything.

origin: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
modern: Naked in bed together, but without doing anything?

origin: It is hypocrisy against the devil.
modern: Come on, Iago.

origin: So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.
modern: As long as they didn’t do anything, it would only be a minor sin.

origin: But if I give my wife a handkerchief— What then?
modern: But if I gave my wife a handkerchief— Then what?

origin: She is protectress of her honor too.
modern: Her reputation is also her own.

origin: May she give that?
modern: Can she give that away too?

origin: But for the handkerchief— By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
modern: But a handkerchief— God, I wish I could forget about the handkerchief!

origin: Thou saidst—Oh, it comes o'er my memory, As doth the raven o'er the infectious house, Boding to all—he had my handkerchief.
modern: What you told me it haunts me like a nightmare—he’s got my handkerchief!

origin: Ay, what of that?
modern: Yes, what about it?

origin: That’s not so good now.
modern: That’s not good.

origin: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
modern: What if I’d said I saw him do something to hurt you?

origin: He hath, my lord, but be you well assured No more than he’ll unswear.
modern: Yes, but he’d deny it all.

origin: What hath he said?
modern: What did he say?

origin: Why, that he did—I know not what he did.
modern: He said he did—I don’t know.

origin: Lie—   With her?
modern: He was in bed with— With her?

origin: With her, on her, what you will.
modern: With her, on top of her—however you want to say it.

origin: Lie with her?
modern: In bed with her?

origin: lie on her?
modern: On top of her?

origin: Lie with her—that’s fulsome.
modern: My God, it’s nauseating!

origin: Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief!
modern: Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief!

origin: Noses, ears, and lips.
modern: Noses, ears, lips.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is it possible?

origin: Confess!—Handkerchief!—Oh, devil!— Work on, My medicine, work!
modern: This is the way to trick gullible fools.

origin: How now, Cassio!
modern: Hey, Cassio!

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: This is his second fit.
modern: This is his second fit like this.

origin: He had one yesterday.
modern: He had one yesterday.

origin: Rub him about the temples.
modern: Rub his temples.

origin: No, forbear.
modern: No, don’t.

origin: If not, he foams at mouth and by and by Breaks out to savage madness.
modern: If you interrupt it, he’ll foam at the mouth and go crazy.

origin: Look, he stirs.
modern: Look, he’s moving.

origin: Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
modern: Why don’t you go away for a bit?

origin: When he is gone I would on great occasion speak with you.
modern: When he leaves, it’s very important that I talk to you.

origin: How is it, general?
modern: What happened, general?

origin: Have you not hurt your head?
modern: Did you hit your head?

origin: Dost thou mock me?
modern: Are you making fun of me?

origin: Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
modern: I wish you could face your bad news like a man!

origin: A hornèd man’s a monster and a beast.
modern: He’s subhuman, like an animal.

origin: Did he confess it?
modern: Did he confess?

origin: Good sir, be a man, Think every bearded fellow that’s but yoked May draw with you.
modern: Sir, be a man.

origin: Your case is better.
modern: Your case is better than that.

origin: No, let me know, And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
modern: Then I’ll know exactly what she is, just as I know what I am.

origin: Oh, thou art wise!
modern: You’re wise!

origin: Tis certain.
modern: That’s for sure.

origin: Whilst you were here o'erwhelmèd with your grief— A passion most resulting such a man— Cassio came hither.
modern: While you were dazed by grief—which isn’t appropriate for a man like you—Cassio showed up here.

origin: I shifted him away And laid good ’scuses upon your ecstasy,
modern: I got him to leave, and made up an excuse for your trance.

origin: Bade him anon return and here speak with me, The which he promised.
modern: I told him to come back and talk to me in a bit, and he promised he would.

origin: For I will make him tell the tale anew Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
modern: I’ll make him tell me the whole story again—where, how often, how long ago—and when he plans to sleep with your wife in the future.

origin: I say, but mark his gesture.
modern: I’m telling you, just watch his face.

origin: Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man.
modern: But stay calm, and don’t get carried away by rage, or I’ll think you’re not a man.

origin: Dost thou hear, Iago?
modern: Do you hear what I’m saying, Iago?

origin: Will you withdraw?
modern: Will you go hide?

origin: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca, A huswife that by selling her desires Buys herself bread and clothes.
modern: Now I’ll ask Cassio about Bianca, a prostitute who sells her body for food and clothes.

origin: It is a creature That dotes on Cassio, as ’tis the strumpet’s plague To beguile many and be beguiled by one.
modern: That’s the whore’s curse, to seduce many men, but to be seduced by one.

origin: He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain From the excess of laughter.
modern: Whenever he talks about her he can’t stop laughing.

origin: As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.
modern: And when he laughs, Othello will go crazy.

origin: And his unbookish jealousy must construe Poor Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and light behavior Quite in the wrong.—How do you now, lieutenant?
modern: In his ignorant jealousy, he’ll totally misunderstand Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and jokes.—How are you, lieutenant?

origin: Alas, poor caitiff!
modern: The poor thing!

origin: Look how he laughs already!
modern: He’s laughing already!

origin: I never knew woman love man so.
modern: I never knew a woman who loved a man so much.

origin: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.
modern: The poor thing, I really think she loves me.

origin: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.
modern: Now he denies it a bit, and tries to laugh it off.

origin: Do you hear, Cassio?
modern: Have you heard this, Cassio?

origin: Now he importunes him To tell it o'er.
modern: He’s asking him to tell the story again.

origin: Go to, well said, well said.
modern: Go on, tell it.

origin: She gives it out that you shall marry her.
modern: She says you’re going to marry her.

origin: Do you intend it?
modern: Are you?

origin: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: Do you triumph?
modern: Do you think you’ve won?

origin: I marry her!
modern: Me, marry her?

origin: What?
modern: That whore?

origin: Prithee bear some charity to my wit.
modern: Please give me a little credit!

origin: Do not think it so unwholesome.
modern: I’m not that stupid.

origin: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: So, so, so, so!
modern: So, so, so, so!

origin: Prithee say true!
modern: You’re kidding!

origin: Well.
modern: All right, then.

origin: She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.
modern: She thinks I’ll marry her because she loves me.

origin: Iago beckons me.
modern: Iago is gesturing for me to come closer.

origin: Now he begins the story.
modern: Now he’s telling the story.

origin: She was here even now.
modern: She was here just now.

origin: She haunts me in every place.
modern: She hangs around me all the time.

origin: I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck— Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were.
modern: I was talking to some Venetians down by the shore, and the fool showed up.

origin: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber.
modern: Now he’s saying how she took him into our bedroom.

origin: Look, where she comes.
modern: Look out, here she comes.

origin: Tis such another fitchew.
modern: Damn you!

origin: What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now?
modern: What did you mean by giving me this handkerchief?

origin: I was a fine fool to take it.
modern: I was an idiot to take it!

origin: I must take out the work?
modern: You want me to copy the embroidery pattern?

origin: A likely piece of work, that you should find it in your chamber, and not know who left it there!
modern: That was a likely story, that you found it in your room and didn’t know who it belonged to.

origin: This is some minx’s token, and I must take out the work?
modern: This is a love token from some other slut, and you want me to copy its pattern for you?

origin: How now, my sweet Bianca!
modern: What is it, my dear Bianca?

origin: How now, how now?
modern: What’s wrong?

origin: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
modern: My God, that’s my handkerchief!

origin: If you’ll come to supper tonight, you may.
modern: If you want to come have dinner with me, you can.

origin: If you will not, come when you are next prepared for.
modern: If you don’t want to, then good riddance.

origin: After her, after her.
modern: Go after her, go.

origin: I must, she’ll rail in the street else.
modern: Actually, I should.

origin: Will you sup there?
modern: Will you be having dinner with her tonight?

origin: Yes, I intend so.
modern: Yes, I will.

origin: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
modern: Did you see how he laughed about sleeping with her?

origin: O Iago!
modern: Oh Iago!

origin: And did you see the handkerchief?
modern: And did you see the handkerchief?

origin: Was that mine?
modern: Was it mine?

origin: Yours by this hand.
modern: It was yours, I swear.

origin: And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife!
modern: And do you see how much your foolish wife means to him?

origin: She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
modern: She gave it to him, and he gave it to his whore.

origin: I would have him nine years a-killing.
modern: I wish I could keep killing him for nine years straight.

origin: A fine woman!
modern: Oh, she’s a fine woman!

origin: A fair woman!
modern: A fair woman!

origin: A sweet woman!
modern: A sweet woman!

origin: Nay, you must forget that.
modern: No, you have to forget all that now.

origin: Ay, let her rot and perish and be damned tonight, for she shall not live.
modern: Yes, let her die and rot and go to hell tonight.

origin: Oh, the world hath not a sweeter creature, she might lie by an emperor’s side and command him tasks.
modern: Oh, the world never saw a sweeter creature.

origin: Nay, that’s not your way.
modern: But that’s not how you’re going to be.

origin: So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician.
modern: She’s so good at sewing, and a wonderful musician.

origin: Oh, she will sing the savageness out of a bear!
modern: Oh, she could sing a wild bear to sleep!

origin: Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
modern: Oh, she’s so witty and creative!

origin: She’s the worse for all this.
modern: All the worse that she stooped this low, then.

origin: Oh, a thousand thousand times—and then of so gentle a condition!
modern: Oh, a thousand times worse, a thousand times—and what a sweet personality she has!

origin: Ay, too gentle.
modern: Yes, a little too sweet.

origin: Nay, that’s certain.
modern: Yes, that’s for sure.

origin: O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!
modern: Oh, it’s dreadful, dreadful, Iago!

origin: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
modern: If you still feel so affectionate toward her, then why not give her permission to cheat on you?

origin: I will chop her into messes!
modern: I’ll chop her into pieces.

origin: Oh, ’tis foul in her.
modern: Oh, it’s horrible of her.

origin: That’s fouler.
modern: That’s worse.

origin: Get me some poison, Iago, this night.
modern: Get me some poison tonight, Iago.

origin: I’ll not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again—This night, Iago!
modern: I won’t argue with her, so her beautiful body won’t disarm me.—Tonight, Iago.

origin: Do it not with poison.
modern: Don’t do it with poison.

origin: Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.
modern: Strangle her in her bed, the same bed she’s contaminated.

origin: Good, good, the justice of it pleases!
modern: Good, good, I like that—it’s only fair!

origin: Very good!
modern: Very good!

origin: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker.
modern: And let me kill Cassio.

origin: You shall hear more by midnight.
modern: You’ll hear more from me by midnight.

origin: Excellent good.
modern: Excellent, good.

origin: Those are the raisèd father and his friends.
modern: That’s her father and his friends, who’ve been roused out of bed.

origin: You were best go in.
modern: You’d better go inside.

origin: Not I, I must be found.
modern: No, I must let them find me.

origin: My parts, my title, and my perfect soul Shall manifest me rightly.
modern: My good qualities, my legal status as Desdemona’s husband, and my innocence will protect me.

origin: Is it they?
modern: Is it them?

origin: By Janus, I think no.
modern: I don’t think so.

origin: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?
modern: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?

origin: The goodness of the night upon you, friends!
modern: Hello, everyone!

origin: What is the news?
modern: What’s going on?

origin: The Duke does greet you, general, And he requires your haste-post-haste appearance, Even on the instant.
modern: He needs to see you right away.

origin: What’s the matter, think you?
modern: What do you think he wants?

origin: Something from Cyprus as I may divine.
modern: Something about Cyprus.

origin: It is a business of some heat.
modern: I think it’s important.

origin: The galleys Have sent a dozen sequent messengers This very night at one another’s heels, And many of the consuls, raised and met, Are at the Duke’s already.
modern: The warships have sent a dozen messages tonight, one after the other, and many of the senators have been awakened and are at the Duke’s already.

origin: You have been hotly called for.
modern: They’re very anxious for you to get there.

origin: When being not at your lodging to be found The Senate hath sent about three several guests To search you out.
modern: When you weren’t at home, the Senate sent out three different search parties to find you.

origin: Tis well I am found by you.
modern: It’s good you found me.

origin: I will but spend a word here in the house And go with you.
modern: I’ll just speak a word or two here in the house and then I’ll go with you.

origin: What trumpet is that same?
modern: What’s that trumpet for?

origin: I warrant something from Venice.
modern: I think someone’s coming from Venice.

origin: See, your wife’s with him.
modern: Look, your wife is with him.

origin: Save you, worthy general!
modern: Greetings, good general!

origin: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
modern: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

origin: And what’s the news, good cousin Lodovico?
modern: What’s new, cousin Lodovico?

origin: I am very glad to see you, signior.
modern: Very nice to see you, sir.

origin: Welcome to Cyprus.
modern: Welcome to Cyprus.

origin: I thank you.
modern: Thank you.

origin: How does lieutenant Cassio?
modern: How is lieutenant Cassio?

origin: Lives, sir.
modern: Well, he’s alive.

origin: Are you sure of that?
modern: Are you sure of that?

origin: My lord?
modern: Excuse me?

origin: He did not call, he’s busy in the paper.
modern: He didn’t say anything, he’s reading.

origin: Is there division ’twixt my lord and Cassio?
modern: So there’s a rift between Othello and Cassio?

origin: A most unhappy one.
modern: Yes, unfortunately.

origin: I would do much T' atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.
modern: I’d do anything to bring them back together, since I really care for Cassio.

origin: Fire and brimstone!
modern: Damn it all!

origin: My lord?
modern: Excuse me, my lord?

origin: Are you wise?
modern: Are you in your right mind?

origin: What, is he angry?
modern: Is he angry?

origin: Maybe the letter moved him, For, as I think, they do command him home, Deputing Cassio in his government.
modern: I think they want him to go home and appoint Cassio governor in his place.

origin: Trust me, I am glad on ’t.
modern: I’m happy about that.

origin: Indeed!
modern: Oh, are you really!

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: I am glad to see you mad.
modern: I’m glad you’re insane enough to admit it in front of me.

origin: Why, sweet Othello—   I have not deserved this.
modern: Why, sweet Othello—   I haven’t done anything to deserve this!

origin: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice, Though I should swear I saw ’t.
modern: My lord, no one will believe this in Venice, even though I’d swear I saw it with my own eyes.

origin: Tis very much.
modern: That was too much.

origin: Make her amends, she weeps.
modern: She’s crying.

origin: Oh, devil, devil!
modern: Oh, you devil, you devil!

origin: Out of my sight!
modern: Get out of my sight!

origin: I will not stay to offend you.
modern: I wouldn’t want to stay here and make you angry.

origin: Truly, an obedient lady.
modern: She’s obedient—a fine lady.

origin: I do beseech your lordship, call her back.
modern: Please, my lord, call her back.

origin: Mistress!
modern: Madam!

origin: My lord?
modern: My lord?

origin: What would you with her, sir?
modern: What do you want with her, sir?

origin: Who, I, my lord?
modern: Who, me?

origin: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.
modern: See how well she can turn?

origin: Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on, And turn again.
modern: She can turn and turn, and then turn on you again.

origin: And she can weep, sir, weep.
modern: And she can cry, sir—oh, how she can cry!

origin: And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient, Very obedient.—Proceed you in your tears.— Concerning this, sir—Oh, well-painted passion!— I am commanded home.—Get you away, I’ll send for you anon.—Sir, I obey the mandate And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!
modern: Very obedient—keep crying.—Concerning this—oh, what fake emotion!—I am being ordered home—Get away from me, I’ll send for you later.—Sir, I’ll obey the order and return to Venice.

origin: Cassio shall have my place.
modern: Cassio can have my job.

origin: And, sir, tonight I do entreat that we may sup together.
modern: And tonight, sir, I invite you have dinner with me.

origin: You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.
modern: Welcome to Cyprus.

origin: Goats and monkeys!
modern: Horny animals!

origin: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate Call all in all sufficient?
modern: Is this the same Moor whom the senate considers so capable?

origin: He is much changed.
modern: He’s changed a great deal.

origin: Are his wits safe?
modern: Is he sane?

origin: Is he not light of brain?
modern: Is he losing his mind?

origin: He’s that he is.
modern: He is what he is.

origin: I may not breathe my censure What he might be.
modern: I won’t say anything negative about what he might be.

origin: If what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were!
modern: If he isn’t what he might be, then I wish to God he were!

origin: Strike his wife?
modern: Hitting his wife?

origin: Faith, that was not so well.
modern: It’s true, that wasn’t such a nice thing to do.

origin: Yet would I knew That stroke would prove the worst!
modern: But I wish I could say that’s the last time he’ll do it!

origin: Is it his use?
modern: Is it a habit of his?

origin: Or did the letters work upon his blood And new-create his fault?
modern: Or did the letter make him emotional somehow, and this is the first time he’s done it?

origin: Alas, alas!
modern: Oh, it’s too bad!

origin: It is not honesty in me to speak What I have seen and known.
modern: It wouldn’t be right for me to tell you everything I’ve seen and heard.

origin: Do but go after And mark how he continues.
modern: Just go after him and watch what he does next.

origin: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
modern: I’m sorry I was so wrong about him.

origin: You have seen nothing then?
modern: You haven’t seen anything, then?

origin: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.
modern: No, and I didn’t hear anything either, or suspect anything at all.

origin: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.
modern: But you’ve seen her and Cassio together.

origin: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that breath made up between them.
modern: Yes, but I didn’t see anything wrong, and I heard every syllable they said.

origin: What, did they never whisper?
modern: Didn’t they ever whisper?

origin: Never, my lord.
modern: Never, my lord.

origin: Nor send you out o' th' way?
modern: Or ask you to leave the room?

origin: Never.
modern: Never.

origin: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?
modern: Not even to get her fan, or her gloves, or her mask, or anything?

origin: Never, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

origin: That’s strange.
modern: That’s strange.

origin: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake.
modern: I’d swear to you on my soul that she’s a good, honest person, sir.

origin: Bid her come hither.
modern: Tell her to come here.

origin: Go.
modern: Go.

origin: She says enough, yet she’s a simple bawd That cannot say as much.
modern: She says all the right things, but the dumbest brothel-keeper would tell the same story.

origin: And yet she’ll kneel and pray, I have seen her do ’t.
modern: I’ve seen her do it.

origin: My lord, what is your will?
modern: My lord, what do you want?

origin: Pray, chuck, come hither.
modern: Please, dear, come here.

origin: What is your pleasure?
modern: What can I do for you?

origin: Let me see your eyes.
modern: Let me see your eyes.

origin: Look in my face.
modern: Look at my face.

origin: What horrible fancy’s this?
modern: What horrible thing are you imagining?

origin: I understand a fury in your words, But not the words.
modern: I can tell you’re furious, but I don’t understand what you’re saying.

origin: Therefore be double damned, Swear thou art honest!
modern: Go ahead, swear to that, so you’ll be damned to hell for lying.

origin: Heaven doth truly know it.
modern: Heaven knows I am.

origin: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
modern: Heaven knows you’re as unfaithful as hell.

origin: To whom, my lord?
modern: Unfaithful, my lord?

origin: With whom?
modern: With whom?

origin: How am I false?
modern: How am I unfaithful?

origin: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away!
modern: Leave me alone, Desdemona, go away!

origin: Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
modern: Because of me?

origin: If haply you my father do suspect An instrument of this your calling back, Lay not your blame on me.
modern: If you’ve been ordered back to Venice because of my father, don’t blame me.

origin: If you have lost him, Why, I have lost him too.
modern: You may have lost his respect, but so have I.

origin: Yet could I bear that too, well, very well.
modern: Even that I could put up with.

origin: But there where I have garnered up my heart, Where either I must live or bear no life, The fountain from the which my current runs Or else dries up—to be discarded thence!
modern: be like the fountain that my children and all my descendants flow from, has rejected me!

origin: Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads To knot and gender in!
modern: Worse than that, she’s polluted herself, so that the fountain is a place where disgusting toads copulate and reproduce!

origin: Turn thy complexion there, Patience, thou young and rose-lipped cherubin,— Ay, there, look grim as hell!
modern: Even the goddess of patience couldn’t look at this and be patient—it’s too horrifying!

origin: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
modern: I hope you think I’m faithful to you.

origin: Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing.
modern: As faithful as flies in rotting meat, which give birth to maggots every time the wind blows.

origin: O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell’st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
modern: Oh, I wish you’d never been born!

origin: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?
modern: Have I done something to offend you without knowing it?

origin: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book, Made to write “whore” upon?
modern: Was someone as beautiful as you meant to be a whore?

origin: What committed?
modern: What have you done?

origin: Committed?
modern: What have you done?

origin: O thou public commoner!
modern: Oh, you streetwalker!

origin: What committed?
modern: What have you done?

origin: Impudent strumpet!
modern: You brazen whore!

origin: By heaven, you do me wrong!
modern: I swear to God you’re accusing me wrongly!

origin: Are you not a strumpet?
modern: So you’re saying you’re not a whore?

origin: No, as I am a Christian.
modern: No, I’m as honest as I am Christian.

origin: What, not a whore?
modern: What, you’re not a whore?

origin: No, as I shall be saved.
modern: No, I swear it.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

origin: Oh, heaven forgive us!
modern: Oh, heaven help us!

origin: I cry you mercy, then, I took you for that cunning whore of Venice That married with Othello.—You, mistress, That have the office opposite to Saint Peter And keep the gate of hell!
modern: I mistook you for that sly Venetian woman who married Othello.—You whorehouse-keeper.

origin: You, you, ay, you!
modern: You!

origin: We have done our course.
modern: We’ve finished our business.

origin: There’s money for your pains.
modern: Here’s some money for you.

origin: I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.
modern: Please lock the door and keep quiet.

origin: Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
modern: What’s he talking about?

origin: How do you, madam?
modern: How are you, madam?

origin: Ancient, what makes he here?
modern: Ensign, what’s he doing in there?

origin: Faith, he tonight hath boarded a land carrack.
modern: Tonight he boarded a treasure ship.

origin: If it prove lawful prize, he’s made for ever.
modern: If he can keep it, he’ll be set forever.

origin: I do not understand.
modern: I don’t understand.

origin: He’s married.
modern: He’s married.

origin: To who?
modern: To whom?

origin: Here comes another troop to seek for you.
modern: Here comes another group looking for you.

origin: It is Brabantio.
modern: It’s Brabantio.

origin: General, be advised, He comes to bad intent.
modern: He intends to do something bad to you.

origin: Holla!
modern: Hey!

origin: Stand there!
modern: Stop right there!

origin: Signior, it is the Moor.
modern: Sir, it’s the Moor.

origin: Down with him, thief!
modern: Get him, he’s a thief!

origin: With who?
modern: With who?

origin: I have none.
modern: I don’t have a lord.

origin: Do not talk to me, Emilia.
modern: Don’t talk to me, Emilia.

origin: Here’s a change indeed!
modern: Things have certainly changed!

origin: Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
modern: It’s fair for him to treat me like this, very fair.

origin: How have I been behaved that he might stick The small’st opinion on my least misuse?
modern: What have I ever done that he has anything to complain about?

origin: What is your pleasure, madam?
modern: What can I do for you, madam?

origin: How is ’t with you?
modern: How are you?

origin: I cannot tell.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: Those that do teach young babes Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
modern: When grown-ups teach little children, they do it gently and easily.

origin: He might have chid me so, for, in good faith, I am a child to chiding.
modern: He might have treated me like that, because I’m as unused to abuse as a little child.

origin: What is the matter, lady?
modern: What’s the matter, lady?

origin: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her, Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her, That true hearts cannot bear it.
modern: He called her a whore so many times, and heaped up so much abuse on her that good people can’t stand to hear it.

origin: Am I that name, Iago?
modern: Am I that name, Iago?

origin: What name, fair lady?
modern: What name, madam?

origin: Such as she says my lord did say I was.
modern: What my lord said I was.

origin: Why did he so?
modern: Why did he do that?

origin: I do not know.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: I am sure I am none such.
modern: I just know I’m not one.

origin: Do not weep, do not weep.
modern: Don’t cry, don’t cry.

origin: Alas the day!
modern: What a day this is!

origin: Hath she forsook so many noble matches, Her father and her country, and her friends, To be called “whore”?
modern: Did she give up all those chances to marry noblemen, give up her father and country and friends, just to be called a whore?

origin: Would it not make one weep?
modern: Doesn’t that make you want to cry?

origin: It is my wretched fortune.
modern: It’s just my bad luck.

origin: Beshrew him for ’t!
modern: Damn him!

origin: How comes this trick upon him?
modern: How did he get such an idea?

origin: Nay, heaven doth know.
modern: Heaven knows.

origin: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander.
modern: I bet my life some evil busybody, some meddling, lying jerk made up this rumor to get some position.

origin: I will be hanged else!
modern: I bet my life on it.

origin: Fie, there is no such man.
modern: Nobody’s that bad.

origin: It is impossible.
modern: It’s impossible.

origin: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!
modern: If there is, then heaven help him!

origin: Why should he call her “whore”?
modern: Why should he call her a whore?

origin: Who keeps her company?
modern: Who’s been with her?

origin: The Moor’s abused by some most villainous knave, Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
modern: The Moor is being tricked by some crook, some terrible villain, some rotten bastard.

origin: O heavens, that such companions thou’dst unfold, And put in every honest hand a whip To lash the rascals naked through the world Even from the east to th' west!
modern: Oh, I wish we could unmask scoundrels like that, and give a whip to every good man to beat them senseless with!

origin: Speak within door.
modern: Keep your voice down.

origin: Oh, fie upon them!
modern: Oh, to hell with those people!

origin: Some such squire he was That turned your wit the seamy side without And made you to suspect me with the Moor.
modern: It’s the same kind of guy who got you upset and made you suspect I’d cheated on you with the Moor.

origin: You are a fool.
modern: You’re a fool.

origin: Go to.
modern: Shut up.

origin: Alas Iago, What shall I do to win my lord again?
modern: Oh God, Iago, what can I do to win my husband back again?

origin: Good friend, go to him.
modern: Please go to him, my friend.

origin: For, by this light of heaven, I know not how I lost him.
modern: I swear I have no idea why he stopped loving me.

origin: Here I kneel: If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love, Either in discourse of thought or actual deed, Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense, Delighted them, or any other form, Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
modern: Here I’m kneeling to swear that if I ever did anything to destroy his love for me, either by thoughts or actions, or if I ever took pleasure in anyone else, or if I never did love him, or don’t love him now—even though he tries to shake me off—

origin: And ever will—though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement—love him dearly, Comfort forswear me!
modern: then I hope I have a life of misery!

origin: Unkindness may do much, And his unkindness may defeat my life, But never taint my love.
modern: Unkindness is powerful, and his unkindness may kill me, but it’ll never destroy my love.

origin: I cannot say “whore,” It does abhor me now I speak the word.
modern: I can’t say “whore.” It makes me sick to say the word even now.

origin: The business of the state does him offence, And he does chide with you.
modern: Political business is bothering him, and he’s just taking it out on you.

origin: If ’twere no other— 'Tis but so, I warrant.
modern: If only that were all it is— It is, I promise.

origin: Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.
modern: Those trumpets are calling us in to dinner.

origin: The messengers of Venice stays the meat.
modern: The Venetians are waiting for their food.

origin: Go in, and weep not.
modern: Go in, and don’t cry.

origin: All things shall be well.
modern: Everything will be all right.

origin: How now, Roderigo!
modern: How are you, Roderigo?

origin: I do not find that thou deal’st justly with me.
modern: I don’t think you’re treating me fairly.

origin: What in the contrary?
modern: What makes you say that?

origin: I will indeed no longer endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.
modern: Well, I won’t take it any longer.

origin: Will you hear me, Roderigo?
modern: Will you listen to me, Roderigo?

origin: I have heard too much, and your words and performances are no kin together.
modern: Your words and actions don’t match up.

origin: You charge me most unjustly.
modern: That’s not fair.

origin: With naught but truth.
modern: It’s the truth.

origin: The jewels you have had from me to deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a votaress.
modern: The jewels you took from me to deliver to Desdemona would’ve made even a nun want to sleep with me.

origin: You have told me she hath received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance, but I find none.
modern: You told me she got them, and that she promised to give me a little something in return soon, but nothing like that ever happens.

origin: Well, go to.
modern: Well, all right then.

origin: Very well.
modern: Fine.

origin: Very well,” “go to”!
modern: Fine!” he says.

origin: I cannot go to, man, nor ’tis not very well.
modern: All right!” It’s not fine, and I’m not all right!

origin: Nay, I think it is scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.
modern: It’s wrong, and I’m starting to realize I’m being cheated!

origin: Very well.
modern: Okay.

origin: I tell you ’tis not very well.
modern: It’s not okay!

origin: I will make myself known to Desdemona.
modern: I’m going to tell Desdemona my feelings.

origin: If she will return me my jewels I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation.
modern: If she returns my jewels, I’ll stop pursuing her and apologize to her.

origin: If not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction of you.
modern: If not, I’ll challenge you to a duel.

origin: You have said now.
modern: You’ve said what you have to say now.

origin: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.
modern: Yes, and I’ll do everything I just said.

origin: Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before.
modern: From this moment on I have a higher opinion of you than before.

origin: Give me thy hand, Roderigo.
modern: Give me your hand, Roderigo.

origin: Thou hast taken against me a most just exception, but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy affair.
modern: Your complaint against me is perfectly understandable, but I still insist I’ve done everything I could to help you.

origin: It hath not appeared.
modern: It doesn’t look that way to me.

origin: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment.
modern: I admit it doesn’t look that way to me, and the fact that you suspect me shows that you’re smart.

origin: But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now than ever—I mean purpose, courage and valor—this night show it.
modern: But Roderigo, if you’re as courageous and determined as I think you are, then wait just a bit longer.

origin: If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.
modern: If you’re not having sex with Desdemona tomorrow night, then I suggest you find some way to stab me in the back and kill me.

origin: Well, what is it?
modern: Well, what’s your plan?

origin: Is it within reason and compass?
modern: Is it feasible?

origin: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.
modern: Venice has made Cassio governor here on Cyprus.

origin: Is that true?
modern: Is that true?

origin: Why, then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.
modern: Then Desdemona and Othello will go back to Venice.

origin: How do you mean, removing of him?
modern: What do you mean, get rid of him?

origin: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place: knocking out his brains.
modern: I mean knock his brains out, so he can’t take Othello’s place.

origin: And that you would have me to do!
modern: And that’s what you want me to do!

origin: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.
modern: Yes, if you want to help yourself.

origin: He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him.
modern: He’s having dinner tonight with a prostitute, and I’ll go visit him.

origin: He knows not yet of his honorable fortune.
modern: He doesn’t know he’s been appointed governor yet.

origin: If you will watch his going thence (which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one) you may take him at your pleasure.
modern: When you see him walking by here (as I’ll make sure he does between twelve and one) you can nab him.

origin: I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us.
modern: I’ll be nearby to help you, and between the two of us we can handle him.

origin: I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him.
modern: I’ll give you such reasons for killing him that you’ll feel obliged to snuff him out.

origin: It is now high suppertime, and the night grows to waste.
modern: It’s nearly dinner time, and the night’s going to be wasted.

origin: About it!
modern: Let’s go!

origin: I will hear further reason for this.
modern: I want to hear more about this.

origin: And you shall be satisfied.
modern: You will.

origin: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.
modern: Please, sir, don’t trouble yourself.

origin: Madam, good night.
modern: Good night, madam.

origin: I humbly thank your ladyship.
modern: Thank you.

origin: Your honor is most welcome.
modern: You’re most welcome.

origin: Will you walk, sir?—O Desdemona— My lord?
modern: Would you walk out with me, sir?—Oh, Desdemona— Yes, my lord?

origin: Get you to bed on th' instant, I will be returned Forthwith.
modern: Go to bed right this minute.

origin: Dismiss your attendant there, look ’t be done.
modern: I’ll be there shortly.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: How goes it now?
modern: How are things now?

origin: He looks gentler than he did.
modern: He looks calmer than he did before.

origin: Dismiss me?
modern: Send me away?

origin: It was his bidding.
modern: That’s what he said.

origin: Therefore, good Emilia, Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
modern: So give me my nightgown, Emilia, and I’ll say goodnight.

origin: We must not now displease him.
modern: We shouldn’t displease him.

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Would you had never seen him!
modern: I wish you’d never met him.

origin: So would not I.
modern: That’s not what I wish.

origin: My love doth so approve him That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns— Prithee, unpin me—have grace and favor.
modern: I love him even when he’s harsh and mean—Help me unpin this, would you?—I love even his stubbornness, his frowns, his bad moods.

origin: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
modern: I put those wedding sheets on your bed, as you asked.

origin: All’s one.
modern: It doesn’t matter.

origin: Good Father, how foolish are our minds!
modern: Oh, how silly we are!

origin: If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me In one of these same sheets.
modern: If I die before you do make sure I’m wrapped in those sheets in my coffin.

origin: Come, come!
modern: Listen to you!

origin: You talk!
modern: Don’t be silly!

origin: She had a song of “Willow,” An old thing ’twas, but it expressed her fortune And she died singing it.
modern: She knew an old song called “Willow” that reminded her of her own story, and she died singing it.

origin: That song tonight Will not go from my mind.
modern: I can’t get that song out of my head tonight.

origin: I have much to do But to go hang my head all at one side And sing it like poor Barbary.
modern: It’s all I can do to keep myself from hanging my head down in despair and singing it like poor Barbary.

origin: Prithee, dispatch.
modern: Please, hurry up.

origin: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?
modern: Should I get your nightgown?

origin: No, unpin me here.
modern: No, just help me unpin this.

origin: This Lodovico is a proper man.
modern: That Lodovico is a good-looking man.

origin: A very handsome man.
modern: He’s very handsome.

origin: He speaks well.
modern: He speaks well.

origin: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.
modern: I know a lady in Venice who’d walk all the way to Palestine for a kiss from him.

origin: It’s the wind.
modern: It’s the wind.

origin: Mine eyes do itch, Doth that bode weeping?
modern: My eyes itch—is that an omen I’ll be crying soon?

origin: Tis neither here nor there.
modern: No, it doesn’t mean anything.

origin: I have heard it said so.
modern: I heard someone say that’s what it means.

origin: Oh, these men, these men!
modern: Oh, these men, these men!

origin: Dost thou in conscience think—tell me, Emilia— That there be women do abuse their husbands In such gross kind?
modern: Do you honestly think—tell me, Emilia—there are women who’d cheat on their husbands in such a disgusting manner?

origin: There be some such, no question.
modern: There are women like that out there, no question.

origin: You, Roderigo!
modern: You, Roderigo!

origin: Come, sir, I am for you.
modern: Come on, I’ll fight you.

origin: Good signior, you shall more command with years Than with your weapons.
modern: Sir, your age and status inspire more respect than your weapons do.

origin: O thou foul thief, where hast thou stowed my daughter?
modern: You evil thief, where have you hidden my daughter?

origin: Damned as thou art, thou hast enchanted her!
modern: You devil, you’ve put a spell on her!

origin: Judge me the world if ’tis not gross in sense That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms, Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals That weakens motion.
modern: It’s obvious to everyone that you’ve tricked her, drugged her, or kidnapped her.

origin: If he do resist, Subdue him at his peril!
modern: If he struggles, use force!

origin: Whither will you that I go To answer this your charge?
modern: Where do you want me to go to respond to these charges?

origin: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
modern: Would you ever do such a thing for all the world?

origin: Why, would not you?
modern: Why, wouldn’t you?

origin: No, by this heavenly light!
modern: By the light of heaven, no, I would not!

origin: Nor I neither, by this heavenly light.
modern: I wouldn’t either, by daylight.

origin: I might do ’t as well i' th' dark.
modern: It would be easier to do it in the dark.

origin: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
modern: Could you really do such a thing, for all the world?

origin: The world’s a huge thing.
modern: The world’s huge.

origin: It is a great price for a small vice.
modern: It’s a big prize for such a small sin.

origin: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.
modern: I don’t think you would.

origin: In troth, I think I should, and undo ’t when I had done.
modern: Actually I think I would, and then I’d undo it after I did it.

origin: Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition.
modern: I wouldn’t do it for a nice ring, or fine linen, or pretty gowns or petticoats or hats.

origin: But for the whole world?
modern: But for the whole world?

origin: Why, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch?
modern: Who wouldn’t cheat on her husband to make him king?

origin: I should venture purgatory for ’t.
modern: I’d risk my soul for that.

origin: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong For the whole world.
modern: I’d never do such a bad thing, not for the whole world!

origin: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' th' world, and having the world for your labor, ’tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.
modern: Why, a bad action is just a wrong in this world, but when you’ve won the whole world, it’s a wrong in your own world, so you can make it right then.

origin: I do not think there is any such woman.
modern: I don’t think any woman like that exists.

origin: Yes, a dozen, and as many to th' vantage as would store the world they played for.
modern: Yes, a dozen of them—as many as there are women in the world, in fact.

origin: But I do think it is their husbands' faults If wives do fall.
modern: But I do think it’s the husband’s fault if we wives cheat on them.

origin: Say that they slack their duties
modern: For instance, our husbands

origin: Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace, Yet have we some revenge.
modern: We have feelings.

origin: Let husbands know Their wives have sense like them.
modern: Husbands need to know that their wives are human beings too.

origin: They see and smell And have their palates both for sweet and sour, As husbands have.
modern: They see, smell, and taste sweet and sour just like their husbands.

origin: I think it is.
modern: I think they do.

origin: And doth affection breed it?
modern: Is it out of lust?

origin: I think it doth.
modern: I think so.

origin: Is ’t frailty that thus errs?
modern: Is it a weakness?

origin: It is so too.
modern: It is.

origin: And have not we affections, Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
modern: And don’t we have passions, and a taste for fun, and weaknesses, just like men?

origin: Then let them use us well, else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
modern: Then tell them to treat us well.

origin: Good night, good night.
modern: Good night, good night.

origin: Heaven me such uses send, Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!
modern: I pray that God will let me learn from women like that—not to follow their bad example, but to avoid it!

origin: Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come.
modern: Here, stand behind this wall; he’ll come right away.

origin: Quick, quick!
modern: Quick, quick.

origin: Fear nothing.
modern: Don’t be afraid.

origin: I’ll be at thy elbow.
modern: I’ll be right next to you.

origin: It makes us, or it mars us.
modern: This will either make us or break us.

origin: Here, at thy hand.
modern: I’m right behind you.

origin: Be bold, and take thy stand.
modern: Be bold, and get ready.

origin: I have no great devotion to the deed And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
modern: I don’t really want to do this, but he’s given me good reasons.

origin: Tis but a man gone.
modern: I guess it’s only one man—no big deal.

origin: I know his gait, ’tis he.—Villain, thou diest!
modern: I know the sound of his walk.—Die, villain!

origin: Oh, I am slain!
modern: Oh, I’m dead!

origin: I am maimed for ever.
modern: I’ll be crippled forever!

origin: Help, ho!
modern: Help!

origin: Murder!
modern: Murder!

origin: Murder!
modern: murder!

origin: The voice of Cassio.
modern: That’s Cassio’s voice.

origin: Iago keeps his word.
modern: Iago has kept his word.

origin: Oh, villain that I am!
modern: Oh, what a villain I am!

origin: It is even so.
modern: That’s the truth.

origin: Oh, help, ho!
modern: Help me!

origin: Light!
modern: Get some light!

origin: A surgeon!
modern: Get me a surgeon!

origin: Tis he.
modern: It’s him!

origin: Oh, brave Iago, honest and just, That hast such noble sense of thy friend’s wrong!
modern: Brave Iago, how honest and trustworthy you are!

origin: Thou teachest me.
modern: You teach me how I should act.

origin: Minion, your dear lies dead, And your unblest fate hies.
modern: Whore, your lover’s dead now, and you’ll be going to hell soon.

origin: Strumpet, I come.
modern: I’m coming, slut!

origin: For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted.
modern: I’ve shut the memory of your beautiful eyes out of my heart.

origin: Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.

modern: Look in on me, and talk with me, or I’ll attack even without a weapon.

origin: What is the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: Behold, I have a weapon.

origin: That with this little arm and this good sword I have made my way through more impediments Than twenty times your stop.
modern: I’ve fought my way through obstacles twenty times more terrifying than you with this weapon.

origin: But, oh, vain boast!
modern: But

origin: tis not so now.
modern: I’m not like that now.

origin: Be not afraid, though you do see me weaponed.

origin: Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt, And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.

origin: Do you go back dismayed?

origin: tis a lost fear.
modern: There’s no reason to be afraid.

modern: Where would Othello go?—Oh, look at you!

origin: O ill-starred wench, Pale as thy smock!

modern: When we meet on Judgment Day, that look of yours will send me from heaven to hell, where devils will grab me.

origin: Cold, cold, my girl, Even like thy chastity.
modern: You’re cold, cold, and you were never hot with lust.

modern: Where’s that snake?

origin: Bring the villain forth.

origin: I take it much unkindly That thou, Iago, who hast had my purse As if the strings were thine, shouldst know of this.
modern: I don’t like it that you knew about this, Iago.

origin: Sblood, but you’ll not hear me!
modern: Damn it, you’re not listening to me!

origin: Thou told’st me Thou didst hold him in thy hate.
modern: You told me you hated him.

origin: Despise me If I do not.
modern: I do hate

origin: I look down towards his feet, but that’s a fable.

origin: If that thou be’st a devil, I cannot kill thee.
modern: If you are a devil, I won’t be able to kill you.

origin: Wrench his sword from him.

modern: I want you to live, since to me, death is happiness.

origin: Did you and he consent in Cassio’s death?
modern: Did you plan Cassio’s death with him?

modern: Yes.

modern: Dear general, I never gave you any reason to hate me.

origin: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.

modern: Will you please make this half-devil say why he tricked me and damned my soul?

origin: Demand me nothing.

origin: What you know, you know.

modern: From this moment on, I’ll never say another word.

origin: What, not to pray?

origin: Well, thou dost best.
modern: Well, do your best.

origin: The one of them imports The death of Cassio to be undertook By Roderigo.
modern: This one talks about how Roderigo should kill Cassio.

origin: Oh, villain!
modern: Oh, you villain!

origin: Most heathenish and most gross!
modern: Ungodly and monstrous!

origin: O thou pernicious caitiff!
modern: Oh, you wicked scoundrel!

origin: How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief That was my wife’s?
modern: Cassio, how did you get my wife’s handkerchief?

origin: I found it in my chamber, And he himself confessed but even now That there he dropped it for a special purpose Which wrought to his desire.
modern: I found it in my room, and Iago just confessed that he put it there for his own purposes.

origin: Your power and your command is taken off And Cassio rules in Cyprus.
modern: You’re stripped of your power and your command, and Cassio will govern Cyprus.

origin: For this slave, If there be any cunning cruelty That can torment him much and hold him long, It shall be his.
modern: As for this slave, Iago, if we can think of any torture that will hurt him a lot but keep him alive a long time, he’ll have it.

origin: You shall close prisoner rest Till that the nature of your fault be known To the Venetian state.—Come, bring him away.
modern: You’ll remain a prisoner until we bring your crimes to the Venetian government.—Okay, take him away.

origin: Nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice.
modern: But enough about that.

origin: Then must you speak Of one that loved not wisely, but too well.
modern: When you record these sad events in your letters, please describe me exactly as I am.

origin: Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought, Perplexed in the extreme.
modern: Don’t tone things down or exaggerate them out of hostility.

origin: Of one whose hand, Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe.
modern: If you’re being fair, you’ll have to describe me as someone who loved too much, but who wasn’t wise about it.

origin: Set you down this,
modern: Write all this

modern: down, and then say also that in Aleppo I once saw a Turk beating a Venetian, so I grabbed the Turk by the throat and hit him like this.

origin: Oh, bloody period!
modern: Oh, what a bloody end to all this!

origin: All that is spoke is marred.
modern: Everything we’ve heard is bad.

origin: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon, For he was great of heart.
modern: I was afraid this would happen, because he was a noble, brave man, but I didn’t think he had a weapon.

origin: How say you by this change?
modern: What do you think about this change?

origin: This cannot be, By no assay of reason.
modern: They can’t have changed; there’s no way this could be true.

origin: Tis a pageant, To keep us in false gaze.
modern: It’s a trick to confuse us.

origin: Here is more news.
modern: Here’s some more news coming in.

origin: Ay, so I thought.

origin: How many, as you guess?
modern: How many, can you guess?

origin: Of thirty sail.
modern: Thirty ships.

origin: And now they do re-stem Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance Their purposes toward Cyprus.
modern: Now they’ve turned around and are clearly heading for Cyprus.
