modern: Signor Montano, your brave and loyal servant, gives you this information and asks you to send reinforcements to relieve him.

origin: Tis certain then for Cyprus.
modern: Then it’s certain they’re heading for Cyprus.

origin: Marcus Luccicos, is not he in town?
modern: Is Marcus Luccicos in town?

origin: He’s now in Florence.
modern: No, he’s in Florence.

origin: Write from us to him.
modern: Write to him immediately.

origin: Post-post-haste, dispatch.
modern: Hurry.

origin: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.
modern: Here come Brabantio and the brave Moor.

origin: Good your grace, pardon me.
modern: Forgive me, your grace.

origin: Why, what’s the matter?
modern: Why, what’s the matter?

origin: My daughter!
modern: It’s my daughter!

origin: Oh, my daughter!
modern: Oh, my daughter!

origin: Dead?
modern: Is she dead?

origin: Ay, to me.
modern: She’s dead to me.

origin: Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself And you of her, the bloody book of law You shall yourself read in the bitter letter, After your own sense, yea, though our proper son Stood in your action.
modern: And you yourself will determine the sentence as you see fit, and impose the death penalty if you choose to, even if the criminal were my own son.

origin: Humbly I thank your grace.
modern: I humbly thank you, sir.

origin: We are very sorry for’t.
modern: We’re sorry to hear this.

origin: Nothing, but this is so.
modern: Nothing, but this is true.

origin: The very head and front of my offending Hath this extent, no more.
modern: There’s nothing more.

origin: More than pertains to feats of broils and battle, And therefore little shall I grace my cause In speaking for myself.
modern: I’m awkward in my speech and I’m not a smooth talker.

origin: A maiden never bold, Of spirit so still and quiet that her motion Blushed at herself.
modern: She blushes at the slightest thing.

origin: Against all rules of nature, and must be driven To find out practices of cunning hell Why this should be.
modern: The devil must be behind this.

origin: I therefore vouch again That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood Or with some dram, conjured to this effect, He wrought upon her.
modern: Therefore I say again that he must have used some powerful drug or magic potion on her.

origin: But, Othello, speak.
modern: Tell us, Othello.

origin: Or came it by request and such fair question As soul to soul affordeth?
modern: Or did you agree to this as equals?

origin: And let her speak of me before her father.
modern: of her father.

origin: Fetch Desdemona hither.
modern: Bring Desdemona here.

origin: You best know the place.
modern: You know where she is.

origin: And till she come, as truly as to heaven I do confess the vices of my blood So justly to your grave ears I’ll present How I did thrive in this fair lady’s love And she in mine.
modern: In the meantime I’ll tell you all, as honestly as I confess my sins to God, how I wooed this beautiful lady, and how she came to love me.

origin: Say it, Othello.
modern: Tell us, Othello.

origin: Her father loved me, oft invited me, Still questioned me the story of my life From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortunes, That I have passed.
modern: Her father loved me and used to invite me to his house often, continually asking me about my life and all the battles I’ve fought.

origin: These things to hear Would Desdemona seriously incline.
modern: When I talked about all these things, Desdemona used to listen attentively.

origin: She wished she had not heard it, yet she wished That heaven had made her such a man.
modern: She said she wished she hadn’t heard it, but she also wished there was a man like me for her.

origin: She thanked me And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her, I should but teach him how to tell my story And that would woo her.
modern: She thanked me and told me that if a friend of mine had a story like mine to tell, she’d fall in love with him.

origin: Upon this hint I spake.
modern: I took the hint and spoke to her.

origin: She loved me for the dangers I had passed, And I loved her that she did pity them.
modern: She said she loved me for the dangers I’d survived, and I loved her for feeling such strong emotions about me.

origin: This only is the witchcraft I have used.
modern: That’s the only witchcraft I ever used.

origin: Here comes the lady.
modern: Here comes my wife now.

origin: Let her witness it.
modern: She’ll confirm everything.

origin: I think this tale would win my daughter too.
modern: I think a story like that would win my own daughter over.

origin: I pray you, hear her speak.
modern: Please let her speak.

origin: If she confess that she was half the wooer, Destruction on my head if my bad blame Light on the man.—Come hither, gentle mistress.
modern: If she admits she wanted this, then I won’t blame Othello.—Come here, my child.

origin: Do you perceive in all this noble company Where most you owe obedience?
modern: Who do you obey here?

origin: My noble father, I do perceive here a divided duty.
modern: Father, this isn’t easy for me.

origin: To you I am bound for life and education.
modern: I’m torn.

origin: You are the lord of duty.
modern: You’re the one I have to obey.

origin: I am hitherto your daughter.
modern: I’m your daughter.

origin: I have done.
modern: I’m finished, then.

modern: Duke, please go ahead with your state business.

origin: I had rather to adopt a child than get it.— Come hither, Moor.
modern: I’d rather adopt a child than have one of my own.—Come here, Moor.

origin: I here do give thee that with all my heart Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart I would keep from thee.
modern: With all my heart, I give you that thing which, if you didn’t already have it, I’d try with all my heart to keep from you.

origin: For thy escape would teach me tyranny, To hang clogs on them.—I have done, my lord.
modern: You would have made me treat them like a tyrant.—I’m done, my lord.

origin: Let me speak like yourself and lay a sentence Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers.
modern: Let me refer to a proverb that may help you forgive these lovers: if you can’t change something, don’t cry about it.

origin: I humbly beseech you, proceed to th' affairs of state.
modern: Please, I’m asking you, go ahead and get back to your state affairs.

origin: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus.
modern: The Turks are heading for Cyprus with a powerful fleet.

origin: Why, at her father’s.
modern: She can stay at her father’s house.

origin: I’ll not have it so.
modern: I won’t allow it.

origin: Nor I.
modern: Neither will I.

origin: Most gracious Duke, To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear And let me find a charter in your voice, T' assist my simpleness.
modern: Dear Duke, please listen to what I have to say.

modern: What do you want to do, Desdemona?

origin: That I did love the Moor to live with him, My downright violence and storm of fortunes May trumpet to the world.
modern: When I fell in love with Othello I made up my mind that I wanted to live with him.

origin: I saw Othello’s visage in his mind, And to his honors and his valiant parts Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate.
modern: I saw Othello’s true face when I saw his mind.

origin: Let me go with him.
modern: Let me go with him.

origin: Let her have your voice.

origin: Be it as you shall privately determine, Either for her stay or going.

origin: Th' affair cries haste And speed must answer it.
modern: What’s important is the urgency of this mission.

modern: You’ll have to leave tonight.

origin: With all my heart.
modern: With all my heart, I’ll go right away.

origin: At nine i' th' morning here we’ll meet again.
modern: We’ll meet again at nine in the morning.

origin: Othello, leave some officer behind And he shall our commission bring to you, And such things else of quality and respect As doth import you.
modern: Othello, have one of your officers stay behind to bring you your commission and whatever else is important to you.

origin: To his conveyance I assign my wife, With what else needful your good grace shall think To be sent after me.
modern: He’ll accompany my wife, and bring whatever else you think I might need.

origin: Wherein the toged consuls can propose As masterly as he.
modern: which any peace-lover can do.

origin: Mere prattle without practice Is all his soldiership.
modern: His military understanding is all theory, no practice.

origin: Why, there’s no remedy.
modern: And there’s nothing I can do about it.

origin: Tis the curse of service.
modern: That’s the curse of military service.

origin: Now sir, be judge yourself, Whether I in any just term am affined To love the Moor.
modern: Now, you tell me: should I feel loyal to the Moor?

origin: I would not follow him then.
modern: If you don’t like him you should quit.

origin: O sir, content you.

origin: I follow him to serve my turn upon him.
modern: I’m serving under him to take advantage of him.

origin: We cannot all be masters, nor all masters Cannot be truly followed.
modern: We can’t all be masters, and not all masters should be followed.

modern: Look at all the devoted servants who work for their masters their whole lives for nothing but their food, and then when they get old they’re terminated.

origin: Whip me such honest knaves.
modern: They ought to be whipped for being so stupid.

origin: These fellows have some soul,
modern: Let me tell

origin: Let it be so.
modern: All right, then.

modern: Treat Desdemona well.

origin: Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see.
modern: Keep an eye on her, Moor.

modern: She lied to me, and she may lie to you.

modern: Iago, I’m leaving my dear Desdemona with you.

modern: Have your wife attend to her, and bring them along as soon as you can.

modern: Come on, Desdemona, I’ve only got an hour of love to spend with you, to tell you what you need to do.

origin: We must obey the time.
modern: We’re on a tight schedule.

origin: Iago.
modern: Iago.

origin: What say’st thou, noble heart?
modern: What do you have to say, noble friend?

origin: What will I do, think’st thou?
modern: What do you think I should do?

origin: Why, go to bed, and sleep.
modern: Go to bed, and sleep.

origin: I will incontinently drown myself.
modern: I’m going to go drown myself.

origin: If thou dost I shall never love thee after.
modern: If you do that, I’ll never respect you again.

origin: Why, thou silly gentleman!
modern: Why, you silly man!

origin: Oh, villainous!
modern: Oh, how stupid!

origin: I have looked upon the world for four times seven years, and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man that knew how to love himself.
modern: I’ve been alive for twenty-eight years, and I’ve never met a man who knew what was good for him.

origin: Ere I would say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen, I would change my humanity with a baboon.
modern: I’d rather be a baboon than kill myself out of love for some woman I can’t have.

origin: What should I do?
modern: What should I do?

origin: I confess it is my shame to be so fond, but it is not in my virtue to amend it.
modern: I know it’s foolish to be so much in love, but I can’t help it.

origin: Virtue?
modern: Can’t help it?

origin: A fig!
modern: Nonsense!

origin: Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus.
modern: What we are is up to us.

origin: Our bodies are our gardens, to the which our wills are gardeners.
modern: Our bodies are like gardens and our willpower is like the gardener.

origin: So that if we will plant nettles or sow lettuce, set hyssop and weed up thyme, supply it with one gender of herbs or distract it with many—either to have it sterile with idleness, or manured with industry—why, the power and corrigible authority of this lies in our wills.
modern: Depending on what we plant—weeds or lettuce, or one kind of herb rather than a variety, the garden will either be barren and useless, or rich and productive.

origin: If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us to most prepost'rous conclusions.
modern: If we didn’t have rational minds to counterbalance our emotions and desires, our bodily urges would take over.

origin: But we have reason to cool our raging motions, our carnal stings, our unbitted lusts.
modern: Thankfully, we have reason to cool our raging lusts.

origin: It cannot be.
modern: I don’t believe it.

origin: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will.
modern: You feel love because you feel lust and you have no willpower.

origin: Come, be a man.
modern: Come on, be a man.

origin: Drown thyself?
modern: Drown yourself?

origin: Drown cats and blind puppies!
modern: Drowning is for cats or blind puppies—don’t drown yourself!

origin: I have professed me thy friend, and I confess me knit to thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness.
modern: I’ve told you I’m your friend, and I’ll stick by you.

origin: I could never better stead thee than now.
modern: I’ve never been more useful to you than I will be now.

origin: Put money in thy purse.
modern: Here’s what you’ll do.

origin: These Moors are changeable in their wills—fill thy purse with money.
modern: Moors are moody people.—So sell your lands and raise a lot of cash.

origin: The food that to him now is as luscious as locusts shall be to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida.
modern: What seems sweet to him now will soon turn bitter.

origin: She must change for youth.
modern: She’ll have to have it.

origin: Therefore, put money in thy purse.
modern: So have your money ready.

origin: If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more delicate way than drowning.
modern: If you want to go to hell, there are better ways to do it than killing yourself.

origin: Make all the money thou canst.
modern: Raise all the money you can.

origin: If sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and supersubtle Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, thou shalt enjoy her.
modern: I can get the better of religion and a few flimsy vows between a misguided barbarian and a depraved Venetian girl.

origin: A pox of drowning thyself!
modern: And to hell with drowning yourself!

origin: Tis clean out of the way.
modern: That’s completely beside the point.

origin: Thou art sure of me.
modern: You can trust me.

origin: Go, make money.
modern: Go now and get cash.

origin: I have told thee often, and I re-tell thee again and again, I hate the Moor.
modern: I told you before, and I’ll tell you again and again: I hate the Moor.

origin: Let us be conjunctive in our revenge against him.
modern: So let’s join forces and get revenge.

origin: Traverse, go, provide thy money.
modern: Go get money.

origin: We will have more of this tomorrow.
modern: We’ll speak again tomorrow.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Where shall we meet i' th' morning?
modern: Where will we meet in the morning?

origin: At my lodging.
modern: At my house.

origin: I’ll be with thee betimes.
modern: I’ll be there early.

origin: No more of drowning, do you hear?
modern: No more talk about killing yourself, okay?

origin: I am changed.
modern: I’ve changed my mind about that.

origin: Go to, farewell.
modern: Go then, goodbye.

origin: Put money enough in your purse.
modern: Put a lot of cash together.

origin: I’ll sell all my land.
modern: I’m going to sell all my land.

origin: Thus do I ever make my fool my purse.
modern: That’s how I always do it, getting money from fools.

origin: For I mine own gained knowledge should profane If I would time expend with such a snipe But for my sport and profit.
modern: I’d be wasting my skills dealing with an idiot like that if I couldn’t get something useful out of him.

origin: I hate the Moor, And it is thought abroad that ’twixt my sheets He’s done my office.
modern: I hate the Moor, and there’s a widespread rumor that he’s slept with my wife.

origin: I know not if ’t be true, But I, for mere suspicion in that kind, Will do as if for surety.
modern: I’m not sure it’s true, but just the suspicion is enough for me.

origin: He holds me well.
modern: He thinks highly of me.

origin: Cassio’s a proper man.
modern: Cassio’s a handsome man.

origin: Let me see now,
modern: Let’s see, how can I

origin: To get his place and to plume up my will In double knavery.
modern: get his position and use him to hurt Othello at the same time?

origin: How?
modern: How?

origin: How?
modern: How?

origin: Let’s see.
modern: Let’s see.

origin: I have ’t.
modern: I’ve worked it out.

origin: What from the cape can you discern at sea?
modern: What can you see out on the ocean?

origin: Nothing at all.
modern: Nothing.

origin: It is a high-wrought flood.
modern: It was windy on shore too.

origin: Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land, A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.
modern: A big blast of wind shook our fortifications.

origin: What shall we hear of this?
modern: What do you think will be the result of this storm?

origin: A segregation of the Turkish fleet.
modern: The Turkish navy will be broken up.

origin: For do but stand upon the foaming shore, The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds, The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane, Seems to cast water on the burning bear, And quench the guards of th' ever-fixèd pole.
modern: The wind’s whipping up the waves so high you expect them to reach the clouds and splash against the stars in the sky.

origin: I never did like molestation view On the enchafèd flood.
modern: I’ve never seen the waters so disturbed.

origin: If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.
modern: If the Turkish fleet isn’t protected in some harbor, their men must all be drowned.

origin: It is impossible they bear it out.
modern: No ship could survive this storm.

origin: News, lads, Our wars are done!
modern: I’ve got news, boys, the war’s over!

origin: The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks, That their designment halts.
modern: This terrible storm has smashed the Turks so badly that their plans are ruined.

origin: A noble ship of Venice Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance On most part of their fleet.
modern: One of our ships has reported that it saw most of their fleet shipwrecked.

origin: How?
modern: What?

origin: Is this true?
modern: Is this true?

origin: Michael Cassio, Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello, Is come on shore.
modern: Michael Cassio, lieutenant of the Moor Othello, has arrived on shore.

origin: The Moor himself at sea And is in full commission here for Cyprus.
modern: The Moor himself is still at sea.

origin: I am glad on ’t.
modern: I’m happy about that.

origin: Tis a worthy governor.
modern: He’ll be a good governor.

origin: For they were parted With foul and violent tempest.
modern: The two of them were separated during the storm.

origin: Pray heavens he be, For I have served him, and the man commands Like a full soldier.
modern: I hope to God Othello’s all right.

origin: Come, let’s do so.
modern: Let’s do that.

origin: For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.
modern: Every minute we expect more ships to arrive.

origin: Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle That so approve the Moor.
modern: Thanks, you brave men who defend this island and respect Othello.

origin: Oh, let the heavens Give him defense against the elements, For I have lost him on a dangerous sea.
modern: I hope heaven protects him from the weather, because I lost sight of him on the stormy sea.

origin: Is he well shipped?
modern: Is his ship sturdy?

origin: His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure.
modern: Yes, it’s well built, and the ship’s pilot is very expert and experienced.

origin: What noise?
modern: What’s all that shouting about?

origin: I pray you sir, go forth And give us truth who ’tis that is arrived.
modern: Please go find out for certain who has arrived.

origin: I shall.
modern: I’ll do that.

origin: But good lieutenant, is your general wived?
modern: Good lieutenant, is your general married?

origin: Tis one Iago, ancient to the general.
modern: A man named Iago, the general’s ensign.

origin: What is she?
modern: Who’s that?

origin: Oh, behold, The riches of the ship is come on shore!
modern: Look, the precious Desdemona has arrived on shore.

origin: You men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.
modern: We should all kneel before her, men of Cyprus!

origin: Hail to thee, lady, and the grace of heaven, Before, behind thee, and on every hand, Enwheel thee round!
modern: Greetings, my lady, and may God always be with you.

origin: I thank you, valiant Cassio.
modern: Thank you, brave Cassio.

origin: What tidings can you tell me of my lord?
modern: Is there any news about my husband?

origin: He is not yet arrived.
modern: He hasn’t arrived yet.

origin: Nor know I aught But that he’s well and will be shortly here.
modern: As far as I know, he’s okay and will arrive here soon.

origin: Oh, but I fear.
modern: Oh, but I’m worried.

origin: How lost you company?
modern: How did you two get separated?

origin: The great contention of the sea and skies Parted our fellowship—   But, hark!
modern: The storm separated us.

origin: See for the news.
modern: Go find out the news.

origin: For, sir, It is as sure as you are Roderigo, Were I the Moor, I would not be Iago.
modern: you, as sure as your name’s Roderigo, if I were the Moor I wouldn’t want to be Iago.

origin: I am not what I am.
modern: I’m not who I appear to be.

origin: Do, with like timorous accent and dire yell As when, by night and negligence, the fire Is spied in populous cities.
modern: Do it, and shout like the city’s on fire.

origin: What, ho, Brabantio!
modern: Hey, Brabantio!

origin: Signior Brabantio, ho!
modern: Signor Brabantio, hey!

origin: Thieves!
modern: Thieves!

origin: Thieves!
modern: Thieves!

origin: Look to your house, your daughter, and your bags!
modern: Check on your daughter, your house, your money!

origin: Thieves!
modern: Thieves!

origin: thieves!
modern: Thieves!

origin: Sir, would she give you so much of her lips As of her tongue she oft bestows on me, You’ll have enough.
modern: If she gave you as much lip as she gives me, you’d be sick of her by now.

origin: I find it still, when I have leave to sleep.
modern: She’s always talking when I want to sleep.

origin: Marry, before your ladyship, I grant, She puts her tongue a little in her heart And chides with thinking.
modern: I admit that in front of you, my lady, she keeps a bit quiet.

origin: You have little cause to say so.
modern: You have no reason to say that.

origin: Come on, come on.
modern: Come on, come on.

origin: You are pictures out of door, bells in your parlors, wild-cats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds.
modern: In your own kitchens you act like wildcats.

origin: Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer!
modern: Shame on you, you slanderer!

origin: Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk.
modern: No, it’s true, or if it’s not, I’m a villain.

origin: You rise to play and go to bed to work.
modern: You wake up to have fun, and you start work when you go to bed.

origin: No, let me not.
modern: No, I don’t.

origin: What wouldst thou write of me, if thou should’st praise me?
modern: But if you had to say something nice about me, what would you say?

origin: O gentle lady, do not put me to ’t, For I am nothing, if not critical.
modern: Don’t make me do it, my lady.

origin: Come on, assay.
modern: I’m critical by nature.

origin: Ay, madam.
modern: Yes, madam.

origin: I am not merry, but I do beguile The thing I am by seeming otherwise.
modern: I’m not as happy as I seem.

origin: Come, how wouldst thou praise me?
modern: Come on, what would you say about me?

origin: Well praised!
modern: Very clever!

origin: If she be black, and thereto have a wit, She’ll find a white that shall her blackness fit.
modern: Even if she’s ugly, she’ll be smart enough to find a guy to sleep with her.

origin: Worse and worse!
modern: This is getting worse and worse!

origin: How if fair and foolish?
modern: What if she’s pretty but stupid?

origin: Oh, heavy ignorance!
modern: You don’t know a thing!

origin: Thou praisest the worst best.
modern: You give your best praise to the worst women.

origin: But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed, one that in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch of very malice itself?
modern: But how would you praise a truly good woman, someone who had no reason to worry about what anyone said about her?

origin: She that was ever fair and never proud, Had tongue at will and yet was never loud, Never lacked gold and yet went never gay, Fled from her wish and yet said “Now I may,” She that being angered, her revenge being nigh, Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly, She that in wisdom never was so frail To change the cod’s head for the salmon’s tail, She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind, See suitors following and not look behind, She was a wight, if ever such wights were— To do what?
modern: A woman who was beautiful but never proud, who could speak well but knew when to be quiet, who dressed well but was never overdressed, who had self-restraint even when she could get what she wanted, a woman who never took revenge, who overlooked it when people hurt her, who was too wise to do anything stupid, who could think without revealing her thoughts, and who could refrain from flirting with men in love with her, that kind of woman, if she ever existed, would— Would do what?

origin: To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.
modern: Would raise babies and clip coupons.

origin: Oh, most lame and impotent conclusion!
modern: Oh, that’s pathetic!

origin: Do not learn of him, Emilia, though he be thy husband.
modern: Don’t listen to him, Emilia, even though he’s your husband.

origin: How say you, Cassio?
modern: What do you think about him, Cassio?

origin: Is he not a most profane and liberal counselor?
modern: Isn’t he a horrible man?

origin: He speaks home, madam.
modern: He speaks bluntly, madam.

origin: You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar.
modern: He’s more of a soldier than a wise man.

origin: I know his trumpet.
modern: I recognize his trumpet.

origin: Tis truly so.
modern: Yes, it is.

origin: Let’s meet him and receive him.
modern: Let’s go greet him when he lands.

origin: Lo, where he comes!
modern: Look, here he comes.

origin: Oh my fair warrior!
modern: My beautiful warrior!

origin: My dear Othello!
modern: My darling Othello!

origin: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me.
modern: I’m amazed you got here before me.

origin: Oh, my soul’s joy!
modern: But I’m overjoyed!

origin: If it were now to die, 'Twere now to be most happy, for I fear My soul hath her content so absolute That not another comfort like to this Succeeds in unknown fate.
modern: If I died right now I’d be completely happy, since I’ll probably never be as happy as this again in my life.

origin: The heavens forbid But that our loves and comforts should increase, Even as our days do grow.
modern: God willing, our love and our happiness will only increase as we get older.

origin: Amen to that, sweet powers!
modern: Amen to that!

origin: I cannot speak enough of this content.
modern: I can’t talk about my happiness anymore.

origin: It stops me here, it is too much of joy.
modern: It’s too much.

origin: Come, let us to the castle.
modern: Let’s go up to the castle.

origin: News, friends!
modern: Good news, friends.

origin: Our wars are done, the Turks are drowned.
modern: The war’s over and the Turks are drowned.

origin: How does my old acquaintance of this isle?— Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus, I have found great love amongst them.
modern: How are my old friends from this island doing?—Honey, they’ll love you here in Cyprus.

origin: Bring thou the master to the citadel.
modern: And bring the ship’s captain to the castle.

origin: He is a good one, and his worthiness Does challenge much respect.—Come, Desdemona, Once more, well met at Cyprus.
modern: He’s a good man.—Let’s go, Desdemona.

origin: Do thou meet me presently at the harbor.—Come hither.
modern: Meet me down at the harbor.—Come here.

origin: The lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard.
modern: Lieutenant Cassio will be on guard duty tonight.

origin: First, I must tell thee this: Desdemona is directly in love with him.
modern: But first, I have to tell you that Desdemona’s completely in love with him.

origin: With him?
modern: With Cassio?

origin: Why, ’tis not possible.
modern: That’s impossible.

origin: Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed.
modern: Be quiet and listen to me.

origin: All which the Moor is defective in.
modern: Othello isn’t any of those things.

origin: Now sir, this granted—as it is a most pregnant and unforced position—who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does?
modern: Now, if that’s true—and it’s obviously true—who’s in a better position than Cassio?

origin: Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after.
modern: Besides, he’s young and handsome, and he’s got all the qualities that naïve and silly girls go for.

origin: I cannot believe that in her.
modern: I can’t believe that.

origin: She’s full of most blessed condition.
modern: She’s very moral.

origin: The wine she drinks is made of grapes.
modern: Like hell she is!

origin: If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor.
modern: If she were so moral, she would never have fallen in love with the Moor in the first place.

origin: Blessed pudding!
modern: Good lord!

origin: Didst not mark that?
modern: Did you see that?

origin: They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together.
modern: They were lusting after each other.

origin: Pish!
modern: Disgusting!

origin: But, sir, be you ruled by me.
modern: But listen to me; let me guide you.

origin: I have brought you from Venice.
modern: I brought you here from Venice.

origin: Watch you tonight for the command, I’ll lay ’t upon you.
modern: Be on guard duty tonight.

origin: Cassio knows you not.
modern: Cassio doesn’t know you.

origin: I’ll not be far from you.
modern: I’ll be nearby.

origin: Do you find some occasion to anger Cassio, either by speaking too loud, or tainting his discipline, or from what other course you please, which the time shall more favorably minister.
modern: Make Cassio angry somehow, either by speaking too loud, or insulting his military skills, or however else you want.

origin: Well.
modern: All right.

origin: Sir, he’s rash and very sudden in choler, and haply may strike at you.
modern: He’s hot-tempered, and he might try to hit you with his staff.

origin: Provoke him that he may.
modern: Try to get him to do that.

origin: For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.
modern: To get what you want, you need to get Cassio out of the way.

origin: I will do this, if you can bring it to any opportunity.
modern: I’ll do it, if you help me out.

origin: I warrant thee.
modern: I promise I will.

origin: Meet me by and by at the citadel.
modern: Meet me in a little while at the citadel.

origin: I must fetch his necessaries ashore.
modern: I need to get Othello’s things from the ship.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Adieu.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: The thought whereof Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards, And nothing can or shall content my soul Till I am evened with him, wife for wife.
modern: I won’t be satisfied until I get even with him, wife for wife.

origin: Or, failing so, yet that I put the Moor At least into a jealousy so strong That judgment cannot cure.
modern: If I can’t do that, I can at least make the Moor so jealous that he can’t think straight.

origin: For besides these beneficial news, it is the celebration of his nuptial.
modern: For besides the good news, we are also celebrating his marriage.

origin: So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed.
modern: That’s the end of the announcement.

origin: All offices are open, and there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five till the bell have told eleven.
modern: There will be a feast from five o'clock until eleven.

origin: Bless the isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!
modern: God bless the island of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!

origin: Iago is most honest.
modern: Iago’s a good man.

origin: Michael, good night.
modern: Goodnight, Michael.

origin: Tomorrow with your earliest Let me have speech with you.— Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue: That profit’s yet to come ’tween me and you.
modern: Come talk to me tomorrow as early as you can.—Come with me, my dear love.

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night, everyone.

origin: Welcome, Iago.
modern: Hello, Iago.

origin: We must to the watch.
modern: It’s time for us to stand guard.

origin: Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona—who let us not therefore blame.
modern: The general got rid of us early tonight so he could be with Desdemona.—I can’t blame him.

origin: What is the reason of this terrible summons?
modern: What’s the reason for this horrible shouting?

origin: What is the matter there?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: Signior, is all your family within?
modern: Sir, is everyone in your family at home?

origin: Are your doors locked?
modern: Are your doors locked?

origin: Why, wherefore ask you this?
modern: Why are you asking me that?

origin: Zounds, sir, you’re robbed!
modern: For God’s sake, sir, you’ve been robbed.

origin: For shame, put on your gown.
modern: Your heart’s going to break.

origin: Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul.
modern: It’s like half your soul’s been ripped out.

origin: Even now, now, very now, an old black ram Is tupping your white ewe.
modern: At this very minute an old black ram is having sex with your little white lamb.

origin: Arise, arise, Awake the snorting citizens with the bell Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you.
modern: Wake up, wake up, ring a bell and wake up all the snoring citizens.

origin: Arise, I say!
modern: Get up, I tell you!

origin: What, have you lost your wits?
modern: Are you crazy?

origin: Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?
modern: Do you recognize my voice, noble lord?

origin: Not I.
modern: Not me.

origin: What are you?
modern: Who are you?

origin: My name is Roderigo.
modern: My name’s Roderigo.

origin: I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors.
modern: I told you not to hang around my house.

origin: In honest plainness thou hast heard me say My daughter is not for thee.
modern: I’ve already told you quite plainly that my daughter will never marry you.

origin: Sir, sir, sir—
modern: Sir, sir, sir—

origin: Indeed she’s a most fresh and delicate creature.
modern: Yes, she’s young and tender.

origin: What an eye she has!
modern: Like an invitation.

origin: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.
modern: But she’s modest and ladylike too.

origin: And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love?
modern: And when she speaks, doesn’t her voice stir up passion?

origin: She is indeed perfection.
modern: She’s a perfect woman, it’s true.

origin: Well, happiness to their sheets!
modern: Well, good luck to them tonight in bed!

origin: Not tonight, good Iago.
modern: Not tonight, Iago.

origin: I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking.
modern: I’m not much of a drinker.

origin: I could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment.
modern: I wish there was less social pressure to drink.

origin: Oh, they are our friends.
modern: Oh, but these are our friends.

origin: But one cup.
modern: Just one glass.

origin: I’ll drink for you.
modern: I’ll do most of the drinking for you.

origin: I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here.
modern: I’ve already had a glass of wine tonight, watered down, but look how drunk I am.

origin: What, man, ’tis a night of revels!
modern: What are you talking about, man?

origin: The gallants desire it.
modern: Tonight is for celebrating!

origin: Where are they?
modern: Where are they?

origin: Here at the door.
modern: By the door.

origin: I pray you call them in.
modern: Please invite them in.

origin: I’ll do ’t, but it dislikes me.
modern: I’ll do it, but I don’t like it.

origin: If I can fasten but one cup upon him, With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He’ll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog.
modern: If I can just get him to drink one more glass after what he’s drunk already, he’ll be as argumentative and eager to fight as a little dog.

origin: Now ’mongst this flock of drunkards Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle.
modern: Now I’ll get Cassio to do something in front of all these drunkards that will offend everyone on the island.

origin: But here they come.
modern: Here they come.

origin: If consequence do but approve my dream My boat sails freely, both with wind and stream.
modern: If the future turns out as I hope it will, I’m all set for success.

origin: Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.
modern: My God, they’ve given me a lot to drink.

origin: Good faith, a little one, not past a pint, As I am a soldier.
modern: No, it was a little one, not more than a pint.

origin: Some wine, ho!
modern: Bring in more wine!

origin: Fore heaven, an excellent song.
modern: My God, what a great song!

origin: I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting.
modern: I learned it in England, where they have a talent for drinking.

origin: Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander—Drink, ho!—are nothing to your English.
modern: The Danes, the Germans, and the Dutch—come on, drink, drink!—are nothing compared to the English.

origin: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
modern: Are Englishmen really such heavy drinkers?

origin: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain.
modern: They drink Danes under the table, and it takes them no effort at all to out-drink Germans.

origin: To the health of our general!
modern: Let’s drink to our general!

origin: I am for it, lieutenant, and I’ll do you justice.
modern: I’ll drink as much as you do!

origin: Oh, sweet England!
modern: Oh, sweet England!

origin: Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other.
modern: God, that song’s even better than the other one.

origin: Will you hear ’t again?
modern: Do you want to hear it again?

origin: No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things.
modern: No, because we shouldn’t be doing that—stuff.

origin: Well, heaven’s above all, and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.
modern: Oh well, God’s in charge, and some people have to go to heaven, while other people have to go to hell.

origin: It’s true, good lieutenant.
modern: That’s true, lieutenant.

origin: For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.
modern: Speaking for myself—and no offense to the general or anyone else—I hope I’m going to heaven.

origin: And so do I too, lieutenant.
modern: Me too, lieutenant.

origin: Ay, but (by your leave) not before me.
modern: Okay, but please not before me.

origin: The lieutenant is to be saved before the ancient.
modern: The lieutenant has to get to heaven before the ensign.

origin: Let’s have no more of this, let’s to our affairs.—Forgive us our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s look to our business.
modern: But let’s stop this drinking and get down to business.—God forgive our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s get down to business.

origin: Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk.
modern: By the way, I don’t want anyone thinking I’m drunk.

origin: I am not drunk now.
modern: I’m not drunk.

origin: I can stand well enough, and I speak well enough.
modern: I can stand well enough, and I can speak just fine.

origin: Excellent well!
modern: Yes, you’re speaking very well.

origin: Why, very well then.
modern: Yes, very well.

origin: You must not think then that I am drunk.
modern: So don’t think that I’m drunk.

origin: Tis pity of him.
modern: It’s too bad.

origin: But is he often thus?
modern: But is he often like this?

origin: Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.
modern: He drinks like this every night before he goes to sleep.

origin: He’ll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle.
modern: He’d stay up all night and all day if he didn’t drink himself to sleep.

origin: It were well The general were put in mind of it.
modern: The general should be informed about this.

origin: Is not this true?
modern: Don’t you think so?

origin: And ’tis great pity that the noble Moor Should hazard such a place as his own second With one of an ingraft infirmity.
modern: And it’s too bad that the Moor chose a man with such a deep-rooted drinking problem as his second-in-command.

origin: It were an honest action to say So to the Moor.
modern: We should definitely say something to the Moor.

origin: Why, so.
modern: Well.

origin: Now have I done a good day’s work.
modern: Now I’ve done a good day’s work.

origin: You peers, continue this united league.
modern: You must all keep up this united front.

origin: Dissemble not your hatred.
modern: Don’t simply hide your hatred.

origin: Swear your love.
modern: Swear your love for each other.

origin: And with my hand I seal my true heart’s love.
modern: On my honor, I swear I love Rivers with all my heart.

origin: And I as I love Hastings with my heart.
modern: And I love Hastings with all my heart.

origin: You have been factious one against the other.— Wife, love Lord Hastings.
modern: Take my hand, Hastings.

origin: Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.
modern: Dorset, embrace Hastings.—Hastings, express your affection for the marquess of Dorset.

origin: This interchange of love, I here protest, Upon my part shall be inviolable.
modern: I swear I will never break this promise of love.

origin: And so swear I.
modern: And so do I, my lord.

origin: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league With thy embracements to my wife’s allies And make me happy in your unity.
modern: Now, noble Buckingham, seal this alliance by embracing my wife’s friends, and make me happy in your unity.

origin: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham, Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.
modern: Noble Buckingham, your promise is like medicine to my ailing heart.

origin: And in good time, Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
modern: And just in time, here he comes with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.

origin: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen, And, princely peers, a happy time of day.
modern: Good morning to my sovereign king and queen.

origin: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.
modern: Happy indeed, the way we have spent the day.

origin: A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.
modern: What blessed work, my king.

origin: Tis death to me to be at enmity; I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.
modern: I hate it and want all good men’s love.

origin: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.
modern: Today shall always be remembered as a holy day.

origin: I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
modern: If only all struggles ended this well.

origin: My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
modern: Please pardon our brother Clarence.

origin: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?
modern: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be flouted in front of the king?

origin: Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?
modern: Who doesn’t know that the good duke is dead?

origin: Who knows not he is dead!
modern: Who doesn’t know he’s dead?

origin: Who knows he is?
modern: Who says he is?

origin: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
modern: Oh my God, what a terrible world this is!

origin: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?
modern: Do I look as pale as everyone else does, Lord Dorset?

origin: Is Clarence dead?
modern: Is Clarence dead?

origin: The order was reversed.
modern: But I reversed the death sentence.

origin: But he, poor man, by your first order died, And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.
modern: Well, the poor man died by your first order, which was carried by a winged messenger.

origin: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand, That came too lag to see him burièd.
modern: Some tardy cripple must have taken the counter-order, who came after Clarence was already buried.

origin: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion.
modern: It’s clear that someone less noble, less loyal, more bloody-minded than Clarence but not a blood relation, deserves as bad an end as my brother, but he goes free.

origin: I prithee, peace.
modern: Please be quiet.

origin: My soul is full of sorrow.
modern: My soul is full of sorrow.

origin: I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.
modern: I will not rise until your Highness hears me.

origin: Then say at once what is it thou requests.
modern: Then hurry up and tell me what you want.

origin: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant’s life, Who slew today a riotous gentleman Lately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.
modern: That you lift the death sentence on my servant, who killed a rowdy and belligerent former servant of the duke of Norfolk.

origin: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
modern: We know you have a job to do, Brakenbury, and we’ll do what you say.

origin: We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.— Brother, farewell.
modern: Farewell, brother.

origin: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
modern: It doesn’t make either of us happy, I know.

origin: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long.
modern: Well, your imprisonment won’t last long.

origin: I will deliver you or else lie for you.
modern: I will either get you out, lying if I have to, or stay in prison in your place.

origin: Meantime, have patience.
modern: In the meantime, be patient.

origin: I must perforce.
modern: I have no choice.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
modern: Go walk the path that you will never return from.

origin: Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.
modern: I love you so much that I’ll send your soul to heaven very soon—if heaven will accept anything from me, that is.

origin: But who comes here?
modern: But who’s coming?

origin: Good time of day unto my gracious lord.
modern: Good afternoon, my dear lord!

origin: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain.
modern: The same to you, my lord!

origin: Well are you welcome to the open air.
modern: Welcome to the open air again.

origin: How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?
modern: How did you tolerate prison?

origin: My brother killed no man; his fault was thought, And yet his punishment was bitter death.
modern: But his punishment was bitter death.

origin: Who sued to me for him?
modern: Who pleaded with me to pardon

origin: This is the fruits of rashness.
modern: This is what happens when you act rashly.

origin: Marked you not How that the guilty kindred of the queen Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
modern: Did you notice how the queen’s guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence’s death?

origin: O, they did urge it still unto the king.
modern: Oh, they continually urged the king to do it.

origin: God will revenge it.
modern: God will revenge it.

origin: Come, lords, will you go To comfort Edward with our company?
modern: But come, lords, will you come with me to Edward’s room to comfort him?

origin: We wait upon your Grace.
modern: We’ll come with you, your Grace.

origin: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?
modern: Tell me, good grandmother, is our father dead?

origin: No, boy.
modern: No, boy.

origin: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.
modern: My pretty children, both of you misunderstand me.

origin: Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.
modern: So you’re admitting Clarence, my father, is dead.

origin: The king mine uncle is to blame for it.
modern: My uncle the king is to blame for this.

origin: God will revenge it, whom I will importune With earnest prayers, all to that effect.
modern: God will take revenge.

origin: And so will I.
modern: And so will I.

origin: Peace, children, peace.
modern: Quiet, children, quiet.

origin: The king doth love you well.
modern: The king loves you very much.

origin: Incapable and shallow innocents, You cannot guess who caused your father’s death.
modern: Innocent sweethearts, you have no idea who’s responsible for your father’s death.

origin: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
modern: You think my uncle was lying, grandmother?

origin: Ay, boy.
modern: Yes, boy.

origin: I cannot think it.
modern: I can’t believe that.

origin: Hark, what noise is this?
modern: What’s that noise?

origin: I’ll join with black despair against my soul And to myself become an enemy.
modern: I plan to fall into the blackest despair.

origin: Why grow the branches when the root is gone?
modern: Why are the branches still living when the root is gone?

origin: Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
modern: Why aren’t the leaves withering now that the sap is all dried up?

origin: If you will live, lament.
modern: If you do intend to live, then mourn.

origin: If die, be brief, That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the king’s, Or, like obedient subjects, follow him To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.
modern: If you’re going to die, be quick about it so you can catch the king’s departing soul or follow him, like obedient subjects, to his new kingdom of endless night.

origin: O, what cause have I, Thine being but a moiety of my moan, To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!
modern: Since your woes are only a portion of mine, I have every reason to surpass your lamentations and drown out your cries with my own.

origin: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes, That I, being governed by the watery moon, May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.
modern: I could drown the world.

origin: Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!
modern: My poor husband, my dear Edward!

origin: Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
modern: Our poor father, Clarence!

origin: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!
modern: My sons Edward and Clarence!

origin: What stay had I but Edward?
modern: What support did I have other than Edward?

origin: And he’s gone.
modern: And now he’s gone.

origin: What stay had we but Clarence?
modern: What support did we have besides our father?

origin: And he’s gone.
modern: And now he’s gone.

origin: And they are gone.
modern: And now they’re both gone.

origin: Was never widow had so dear a loss.
modern: There has never been a widow who suffered such loss as me.

origin: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.
modern: There have never been orphans who’ve suffered what we have.

origin: Was never mother had so dear a loss.
modern: There was never a mother who suffered so much loss.

origin: Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.
modern: Alas, I am the mother of all these others' griefs.

origin: She for an Edward weeps, and so do I; I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.
modern: She weeps for Edward and so do I, while she does not weep for Clarence, though I do.

origin: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I; I for an Edward weep; so do not they.
modern: These young children cry for Clarence and so do I, though they don’t cry for Edward, as I do.

origin: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother, Of the young prince your son.
modern: Be a careful mother, madam, and think about your son, the young prince.

origin: In him your comfort lives.
modern: Your peace of mind depends on him.

origin: Sister, have comfort.
modern: Sister, calm down.

origin: All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them.— Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your Grace.
modern: All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of our shining star the king.

origin: Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.
modern: On my knee, I humbly ask your blessing.

origin: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
modern: God bless you and make you obedient, loving, and kind.

origin: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers That bear this heavy mutual load of moan, Now cheer each other in each other’s love.
modern: You mournful princes and grieving gentlemen who have been sharing this burden of grief, now it’s time to cheer each other up with love.

origin: Though we have spent our harvest of this king, We are to reap the harvest of his son.
modern: Though we have lost a generous king, we are about to enjoy the benefits of a new king.

origin: The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates, But lately splintered, knit, and joined together, Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.
modern: We must preserve our goodwill toward each other and not break into factions again.

origin: Meseemeth good that with some little train Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet Hither to London, to be crowned our king.
modern: I think a few members of the court should fetch the young prince from Wales and bring him to London to be crowned our king.

origin: Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?
modern: Why only a few courtiers, my lord of Buckingham?

origin: I hope the king made peace with all of us; And the compact is firm and true in me.
modern: The king made peace among all of us.

origin: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.
modern: And so do I. I think we all do.

origin: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.
modern: So, I agree with noble Buckingham—only a few should go to meet the prince.

origin: And so say I.
modern: I think so too.

origin: My lord, whoever journeys to the prince, For God’s sake let not us two at home.
modern: For God’s sake, my lord, let’s be sure to be part of the group that meets the prince.

origin: For by the way I’ll sort occasion, As index to the story we late talked of, To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.
modern: Along the way, I’ll find an opportunity to separate him from the queen’s proud relatives, as step one in the plan we’ve discussed.

origin: My other self, my council’s consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
modern: You are my other self, my oracle, my prophet, my dear brother!

origin: Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?
modern: Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?

origin: I promise you I scarcely know myself.
modern: I’m telling you, I hardly know myself.

origin: Hear you the news abroad?
modern: Did you hear the news that’s going around?

origin: Yes, that the king is dead.
modern: Yes, that the king is dead.

origin: Neighbors, God speed.
modern: Neighbors, hello.

origin: Give you good morrow, sir.
modern: Good day to you, sir.

origin: Doth this news hold of good King Edward’s death?
modern: Is it true that good King Edward has died?

origin: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.
modern: Yes, sir, it’s all too true, God help us.

origin: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.
modern: Then, gentlemen, we can count on trouble.

origin: No, no, by God’s good grace, his son shall reign.
modern: No, no, with God’s help, his son will be king.

origin: Woe to the land that’s governed by a child.
modern: It’s bad news when a country is ruled by a child.

origin: In him there is a hope of government, Which, in his nonage, council under him, And, in his full and ripened years, himself, No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.
modern: His counselors will govern as long as he’s a minor, and then he’ll take over.

origin: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.
modern: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.

origin: More pity that the eagle should be mewed While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
modern: It’s a shame that we eagles are caged up while the vultures are free to do whatever they please.

origin: What news abroad?
modern: What’s the news abroad?

origin: Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
modern: Very sad.

origin: Where is he, in his bed?
modern: Where is he, in his bed?

origin: He is.
modern: He is.

origin: Go you before, and I will follow you.
modern: You go ahead, and I will follow you.

origin: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.
modern: That’s how it was with Henry the Sixth, who was crowned in Paris when he was only nine months old.

origin: Stood the state so?
modern: Really?

origin: Better it were they all came by his father, Or by the father there were none at all, For emulation who shall now be nearest Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.
modern: It would be better if they were all on his father’s side, or that there were none at all on his father’s side.

origin: O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester, And the queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud, And were they to be ruled, and not to rule, This sickly land might solace as before.
modern: Richard, the duke of Gloucester, is very dangerous, and the queen’s sons and brothers are haughty and proud—it would be better for this ailing country if they were subjects, not rulers.

origin: Come, come, we fear the worst.
modern: Come, come, we’re worrying about the worst-case scenario.

origin: All will be well.
modern: I’m sure everything will be fine.

origin: Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.
modern: When storms arrive early, you can expect the harvest will be damaged.

origin: All may be well; but if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.
modern: So, if all turns out fine, as you say, it’s more than we deserve or I expect.

origin: Before the days of change, still is it so.
modern: It’s always like this in times of change.

origin: But leave it all to God.
modern: But leave it all to God.

origin: Whither away?
modern: Where are you all off to?

origin: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.
modern: The court has sent for us.

origin: Tomorrow or next day they will be here.
modern: They’ll be here tomorrow or the next day.

origin: I long with all my heart to see the prince.
modern: I’m dying to see the prince.

origin: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
modern: I hope he’s grown a lot since I last saw him.

origin: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.
modern: Yes, mother, but I wish I hadn’t.

origin: Why, my young cousin?
modern: Why, dear child?

origin: It is good to grow.
modern: It’s good to grow.

origin: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow More than my brother: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester, “Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.” And since, methinks I would not grow so fast Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
modern: Yes,” said my uncle Gloucester, “Small plants are graceful, while ugly weeds grow fast.” And since then, I’ve wished I wouldn’t grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow while the weeds grow in a hurry.

origin: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee!
modern: Well, it certainly wasn’t true for Richard!

origin: He was the wretched’st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
modern: As a child, he took such a long time to grow up that, according to his rule, he should have grown up into a gracious adult.

origin: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
modern: And no doubt he is, gracious madam.

origin: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
modern: I hope he is, but mothers get to have their doubts.

origin: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
modern: Hey, if I’d remembered something about him, I could have had a good comeback for my uncle, touching on his growth worse than he touched on mine.

origin: How, my pretty York?
modern: What would you have said, my young York?

origin: I prithee let me hear it.
modern: Do tell.

origin: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.
modern: Indeed, they say my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw on a crust of bread when he was two hours old.

origin: Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.
modern: It took me two years before I had a single tooth.

origin: Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.
modern: Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

origin: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?
modern: Pretty York, who told you about his teeth?

origin: Grandam, his nurse.
modern: His nurse, grandmother.

origin: His nurse?
modern: His nurse?

origin: Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.
modern: Why, she was dead before you were even born.

origin: If ’twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
modern: Well, if it wasn’t her, I don’t know.

origin: A parlous boy!
modern: A mischievous child.

origin: Go to, you are too shrewd.
modern: Come, come, you are too clever for your own good.

origin: Good madam, be not angry with the child.
modern: Good lady, don’t be angry with the child.

origin: Pitchers have ears.
modern: Little pitchers have big ears.

origin: Here comes a messenger.
modern: Here comes a messenger.

origin: What news?
modern: What’s the news?

origin: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.
modern: My lord, it’s news I wish I didn’t have to report.

origin: How doth the prince?
modern: How’s the prince?

origin: Well, madam, and in health.
modern: He’s fine and healthy, madam.

origin: What is thy news then?
modern: What is your news?

origin: The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.
modern: The powerful dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.

origin: For what offence?
modern: What did they do wrong?

origin: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.
modern: I’ve told you everything I know.

origin: Why, or for what, the nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
modern: Why the nobles were imprisoned, and on what charges, I don’t know, my gracious lord.

origin: Ay me!
modern: Oh no!

origin: I see the ruin of my house.
modern: I see the downfall of my family.

origin: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.
modern: Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre!

origin: My husband lost his life to get the crown, And often up and down my sons were tossed For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.
modern: My husband lost his life to get the crown, and my sons' fortunes have been tossed up and down, leaving me to rejoice over their victories and weep over their losses.

origin: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen, Or let me die, to look on death no more.
modern: Let it end, or let me die so I won’t have to watch any more of it.

origin: The weary way hath made you melancholy.
modern: The tiring journey seems to have made you gloomy.

origin: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.
modern: It wasn’t the journey itself, uncle, but the troubles we encountered that made it wearisome and dull.

origin: I want more uncles here to welcome me.
modern: I want more uncles here to welcome me.

origin: Those uncles which you want were dangerous.
modern: Those uncles that you wish were here were dangerous.

origin: Your Grace attended to their sugared words But looked not on the poison of their hearts.
modern: Your Grace heard their saccharine words, but didn’t take note of their poisonous intentions.

origin: God keep you from them, and from such false friends.
modern: God protect you from them and from other false friends!

origin: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.
modern: God should keep me from false friends, but they weren’t false.

origin: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.
modern: My lord, the mayor of London is here to greet you.

origin: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.
modern: God bless your Grace with health and happy days.

origin: Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!
modern: And what a slug Hastings is that he hasn’t even arrived to tell us whether they’re coming!

origin: And in good time here comes the sweating lord.
modern: And, just in time, here comes the sweaty lord.

origin: Welcome, my lord.
modern: Welcome, my lord.

origin: What, will our mother come?
modern: What, isn’t my mother coming?

origin: On what occasion God He knows, not I, The queen your mother and your brother York Have taken sanctuary.
modern: God knows why, but your mother and your brother have taken sanctuary in Westminster Abbey.

origin: The tender prince Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace, But by his mother was perforce withheld.
modern: Your sweet brother wanted to come meet you, but his mother wouldn’t let him.

origin: Not for all this land Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
modern: I wouldn’t commit so serious a crime for anything.

origin: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age, You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
modern: In these less dainty times, you’re not breaking the laws of sanctuary to seize him.

origin: This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
modern: The prince has done neither; therefore, in my opinion, he isn’t really protected by sanctuary.

origin: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men, But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.
modern: Often I have heard of “sanctuary men,” but until now I’ve never heard of “sanctuary children.” My lord, you’ve won me over this time.

origin: My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once.— Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?
modern: Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

origin: I go, my lord.
modern: I’m coming, my lord.

origin: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
modern: Go as fast as you can.

origin: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come, Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
modern: Say, uncle Richard, if my brother comes, where will I stay till my coronation?

origin: Where it seems best unto your royal self.
modern: Whatever seems best to you.

origin: I do not like the Tower, of any place.— Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
modern: Of all places, I don’t like the

origin: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place, Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
modern: He started it, my noble lord, and succeeding generations rebuilt it.

origin: Is it upon record, or else reported Successively from age to age, he built it?
modern: Is it on record that he built it, or is it just word of mouth?

origin: Upon record, my gracious lord.
modern: On record, my gracious lord.

origin: But say, my lord, it were not registered, Methinks the truth should live from age to age, As ’twere retailed to all posterity, Even to the general all-ending day.
modern: Well, I think that even if it weren’t on record, the truth would be remembered from one generation to the next—all the way to Doomsday.

origin: What say you, uncle?
modern: What did you say, uncle?

origin: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror, For now he lives in fame, though not in life.
modern: Death didn’t conquer

origin: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.
modern: The king won’t live, I hope.

origin: For then I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.
modern: I’ll marry the earl of Warwick’s youngest daughter, Lady Anne.

origin: What though I killed her husband and her father?
modern: So what if I killed her husband and her father?

origin: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father; The which will I, not all so much for love As for another secret close intent By marrying her which I must reach unto.
modern: So that’s what I’ll do, not because I love her but because I’ll get something out of it.

origin: But yet I run before my horse to market.
modern: But I’m running ahead of myself.

origin: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns.
modern: Clarence is still alive; Edward is not only alive, he’s king.

origin: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
modern: Only when they’re dead can I start to count my gains.

origin: What, my gracious lord?
modern: What, my dear lord?

origin: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?
modern: Richard of York, how are you doing, my loving brother?

origin: Well, my dread lord—so must I call you now.
modern: Very well, my supreme lord—that’s what I have to call you now.

origin: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?
modern: How’s my nephew doing, noble lord of York?

origin: I thank you, gentle uncle.
modern: Thank you for asking, uncle.

origin: O, my lord, You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.
modern: Oh, my lord, you once said that lazy weeds grow fast.

origin: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
modern: The prince has far outgrown me.

origin: He hath, my lord.
modern: He has, my lord.

origin: And therefore is he idle?
modern: Does that mean he’s lazy?

origin: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.
modern: Oh, my handsome nephew, I must not say that.

origin: Then is he more beholding to you than I.
modern: In that case, he’s more obliged to you than I am.

origin: He may command me as my sovereign, But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
modern: He may command me as my king, but you still have power over me as a relative.

origin: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.
modern: Uncle, please give me your dagger.

origin: My dagger, little cousin?
modern: My dagger, little nephew?

origin: With all my heart.
modern: With all my heart.

origin: A beggar, brother?
modern: Are you begging, brother?

origin: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give, And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
modern: From my kind uncle, who I know will give it to me, especially as it’s not worth much.

origin: A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.
modern: I’ll give you a greater gift than that, nephew.

origin: A greater gift?
modern: A greater gift?

origin: O, that’s the sword to it.
modern: That must mean a sword.

origin: Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.
modern: Yes, gentle cousin, if it were light enough for you.

origin: O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.
modern: Oh, I see, you will only part with lightweight presents.

origin: In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.
modern: For more important things, you’ll say no.

origin: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
modern: A sword’s too heavy for you to wear.

origin: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
modern: I wouldn’t think much of it even if it were heavier.

origin: How?
modern: What’s that?

origin: Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.
modern: But, uncle, you know how to bear with him.

origin: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.— Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me.
modern: You mean, to bear me, not to bear        My protector, Richard, insists on it.

origin: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
modern: I can’t sleep quietly in the Tower.

origin: Why, what should you fear?
modern: Why, what are you afraid of?

origin: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost.
modern: My uncle Clarence’s angry ghost.

origin: My grandam told me he was murdered there.
modern: My grandmother told me he was murdered there.

origin: I fear no uncles dead.
modern: I’m not afraid of dead uncles.

origin: Nor none that live, I hope.
modern: Nor living ones, I hope.

origin: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
modern: Well, I hope not.

origin: No doubt, no doubt.
modern: No doubt, no doubt.

origin: O, ’tis a parlous boy, Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.
modern: Oh, he’s a dangerously clever boy—bold, quick-witted, capable.

origin: He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
modern: He’s his mother’s child from head to toe.

origin: Well, let them rest.—Come hither, Catesby.
modern: Well, enough about them.—Come here, Catesby.

origin: He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.
modern: Hastings loved the prince’s father so much that we won’t be able to persuade him to do anything against the prince.

origin: What think’st thou then of Stanley?
modern: What about Stanley?

origin: Will not he?
modern: Won’t he join us?

origin: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
modern: He’ll do whatever Hastings does.

origin: Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby, And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings How he doth stand affected to our purpose And summon him tomorrow to the Tower To sit about the coronation.
modern: Okay, just do this, noble Catesby: sound out Lord Hastings, but make it seem as if you’re just mulling over the idea, that it hasn’t been firmed up yet.

origin: If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him and show him all our reasons.
modern: If he seems game to our plan, encourage him to join us and explain all our reasons.

origin: If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling, Be thou so too, and so break off the talk, And give us notice of his inclination; For we tomorrow hold divided councils, Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.
modern: But if he’s resistant and chilly, then be like that too and break off the conversation.

origin: Commend me to Lord William.
modern: Give my regards to Hastings, Catesby.

origin: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
modern: My good lords, I plan to.

origin: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?
modern: Will we hear from you before bedtime, Catesby?

origin: You shall, my lord.
modern: You will, my lord.

origin: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.
modern: You’ll find us both at Crosby Place.

origin: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
modern: Now, my lord, what are we going to do if we find that Lord Hastings won’t go along with our plans?

origin: Chop off his head.
modern: Chop off his head.

origin: Something we will determine.
modern: Whatever we decide to do.

origin: And look when I am king, claim thou of me The earldom of Hereford, and all the moveables Whereof the king my brother was possessed.
modern: And when I’m king, remember to ask me for the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it, which my brother the king used to own.

origin: I’ll claim that promise at your Grace’s hands.
modern: I look forward to that present.

origin: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.
modern: You’ll find I’ll give it to you very willingly.

origin: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards We may digest our complots in some form.
modern: Come, let’s have an early dinner so that we have time to work out our plans.

origin: One from the Lord Stanley.
modern: A messenger from Lord Stanley.

origin: Upon the stroke of four.
modern: Four o'clock in the morning.

origin: Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?
modern: Can’t Lord Stanley sleep?

origin: So it appears by that I have to say.
modern: I guess not—for good reason, as you’ll soon hear.

origin: First, he commends him to your noble self.
modern: First, he sends his regards.

origin: What then?
modern: And then?

origin: Then certifies your Lordship that this night He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm Besides, he says there are two councils kept, And that may be determined at the one Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.
modern: Besides that, he says that two meetings are going to be held tomorrow, and something may be decided at one of them that may make you and him, who are at the other, sorry.

origin: His Honor and myself are at the one, And at the other is my good friend Catesby, Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
modern: While he and I are at one, my loyal servant Catesby will be at the other, so nothing will happen that we won’t find out about.

origin: Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.
modern: Tell your master there is no sound basis for his worries.

origin: And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.
modern: And as for his dreams, I’m surprised he’s so foolish as to trust the fantasies of a restless night.

origin: To fly the boar before the boar pursues Were to incense the boar to follow us And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
modern: If we flee from the boar before the boar even pursues us, we’ll only make the boar angry and suspicious, causing him to chase us when he never intended to.

origin: Many good morrows to my noble lord.
modern: Good morning, my noble lord.

origin: Good morrow, Catesby.
modern: Good day, Catesby.

origin: You are early stirring.
modern: You’re up early.

origin: What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
modern: What news can you tell me in this fast-moving, unsteady state of ours?

origin: It is a reeling world indeed, my lord, And I believe will never stand upright Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.
modern: I believe it won’t stop moving and stand upright till Richard wears the wreath of the realm.

origin: How “wear the garland”?
modern: What do you mean, “wears the wreath”?

origin: Dost thou mean the crown?
modern: Are you talking about the crown?

origin: Ay, my good lord.
modern: Yes, my good lord.

origin: I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.
modern: I’ll have my head cut from my shoulders before I’ll see the crown so misplaced.

origin: But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
modern: But do you think that’s what he’s aiming for?

origin: Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward Upon his party for the gain thereof; And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
modern: For that reason he sends you this good news—that this very day your enemies, the queen’s relatives, will die at Pomfret.

origin: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still my adversaries.
modern: Well, I’m not sorry to hear that, because they have always been my enemies.

origin: God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.
modern: Well, let’s hope you stay in that noble frame of mind.

origin: Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older I’ll send some packing that yet think not on ’t.
modern: But as for now—before two weeks have gone by, I’m going to send some people packing.

origin: Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
modern: It’s a horrible thing to die when you’re not prepared for it, my gracious lord.

origin: O monstrous, monstrous!
