modern: Yes, monstrous, monstrous!

origin: And so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so ’twill do With some men else that think themselves as safe As thou and I, who, as thou know’st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
modern: That’s how it will be for some other men, too, who think they’re as safe as you and I, who are well-loved by noble Richard and Buckingham.

origin: The princes both make high account of you—  I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
modern: I know they do, and I certainly deserve it.

origin: Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
modern: You’re afraid of the boar but you go around without your spear?

origin: My lord, good morrow.
modern: My lord, good morning.

origin: Good morrow, Catesby.— You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood, I do not like these several councils, I.
modern: Good morning, Catesby.

origin: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours, And never in my days, I do protest, Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.
modern: My lord, my life is as important to me as yours is to you, and it was never as precious to me as it is now.

origin: Think you but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
modern: Do you think I would be feeling as triumphant as I am if I didn’t know that our situation was secure?

origin: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
modern: I hope to God I’m proven wrong!

origin: What, shall we toward the Tower?
modern: Well, should we head to the Tower?

origin: The day is spent.
modern: The day is well on its way.

origin: Set down, set down your honorable load, If honor may be shrouded in a hearse, Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament Th' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
modern: Set down your honorable load, men, if there is ever any honor in being dead.

origin: Wot you what, my lord?
modern: You know what, my lord?

origin: Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.
modern: Those men you just mentioned will be beheaded today.

origin: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
modern: They deserved to keep their heads more than some people who have managed to keep their positions.

origin: But come, my lord, let’s away.
modern: But come, my lord, let’s go.

origin: Go on before.
modern: Go on ahead.

origin: I’ll talk with this good fellow.
modern: I’ll talk with this good man.

origin: How now, sirrah!
modern: What’s up, man?

origin: How goes the world with thee?
modern: How’s it going?

origin: The better that your Lordship please to ask.
modern: Better, since your lordship was nice enough to ask.

origin: I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.
modern: I tell you, man, it’s better for me, too, than the last time we met here.

origin: But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself— This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.
modern: But now, I tell you—keep it to yourself, though—those enemies of mine are being put to death today, and I’m better than I’ve ever been.

origin: God hold it, to your Honor’s good content!
modern: Well, let’s hope your good fortune continues!

origin: There, drink that for me.
modern: Here, drink to me.

origin: I thank your Honor.
modern: God be good to you!

origin: Well met, my lord.
modern: A nice coincidence, my lord.

origin: I am glad to see your Honor.
modern: I’m glad to see you.

origin: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.
modern: I thank you, Sir John, with all my heart.

origin: I am in your debt for your last exercise.
modern: I am indebted to you for your last sermon.

origin: Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.
modern: By next week, I’ll be able to pay you.

origin: Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
modern: Your friends at Pomfret, they’re the ones who need a priest.

origin: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, The men you talk of came into my mind.
modern: When I ran into this holy man, those men you mentioned did come to mind, in fact.

origin: What, go you toward the Tower?
modern: Are you headed to the Tower?

origin: I shall return before your Lordship thence.
modern: I’ll be off before you are.

origin: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
modern: Yes, probably, because I’m staying for lunch.

origin: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
modern: I’ll follow you, my lord.

origin: Dispatch.
modern: Hurry up.

origin: The limit of your lives is out.
modern: Your lives are over.

origin: O Pomfret, Pomfret!
modern: Oh, Pomfret, Pomfret!

origin: O thou bloody prison, Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
modern: Oh, you bloody prison, fatal and threatening to noble lords!

origin: Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads, When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I, For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.
modern: Now Margaret’s curse has fallen on our heads, for standing by and doing nothing when Richard stabbed her son.

origin: Then cursed she Hastings.
modern: She cursed Hastings then.

origin: O, remember, God, To hear her prayer for them, as now for us!
modern: Oh God, remember to hear her prayer for them, just as for us!

origin: And for my sister and her princely sons, Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood, Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.
modern: But don’t kill my sister and her royal sons, be satisfied, dear God, with our blood, which is being spilled unjustly, as you know.

origin: Make haste.
modern: Hurry up.

origin: The hour of death is expiate.
modern: The hour of death is approaching.

origin: Come, Grey.
modern: Come, Grey.

origin: Come, Vaughan.
modern: Come, Vaughan.

origin: Let us all embrace.
modern: Let’s embrace

origin: In God’s name, speak.
modern: In God’s name, speak.

origin: When is the royal day?
modern: When should the royal day be?

origin: Is all things ready for the royal time?
modern: Is everything ready for that event?

origin: It is, and wants but nomination.
modern: It is.

origin: Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.
modern: Tomorrow’s a good day.

origin: Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?
modern: Who knows what the Lord Protector thinks?

origin: Who is most inward with the noble duke?
modern: Who’s closest to him?

origin: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
modern: You, I think, would best know what he’s thinking.

origin: We know each other’s faces; for our hearts, He knows no more of mine than I of yours, Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.— Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.
modern: We know each other’s faces, but as for our thoughts, he doesn’t know any more about my thinking than I do about yours or his—or you do about mine.

origin: I thank his Grace.
modern: Lord Hastings, you and he are close.

origin: I know he loves me well.
modern: Thank you.

origin: But for his purpose in the coronation, I have not sounded him, nor he delivered His gracious pleasure any way therein.
modern: I know he holds me dear, but I haven’t asked him about the coronation, and he hasn’t told me.

origin: But you, my honorable lords, may name the time, And in the duke’s behalf I’ll give my voice, Which I presume he’ll take in gentle part.
modern: But you, my noble lords, may name a time, and I’ll second it on the duke’s behalf, which I don’t think he’ll mind.

origin: In happy time here comes the duke himself.
modern: Right on cue, here’s the duke himself.

origin: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
modern: My noble lords and relatives, good morning.

origin: Had you not come upon your cue, my lord, William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part— I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
modern: If you hadn’t shown up on cue, my lord, Lord Hastings was going to take your part—I mean, he was going to speak for you—in the crowning of the king.

origin: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.
modern: No one may be bolder than my Lord Hastings.

origin: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
modern: Buckingham, I need to have a word with you.

origin: I’ll go with you.
modern: I’ll come soon.

origin: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
modern: We have not yet set the coronation day.

origin: Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?
modern: Where is my lord, the duke of Gloucester?

origin: I have sent for these strawberries.
modern: I have sent for the strawberries.

origin: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.
modern: Richard is looking cheerful today.

origin: There’s some conceit or other likes him well When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.
modern: You always know he’s got some plan that pleases him when he says good morning with such gusto.

origin: I think there’s never a man in Christendom Can lesser hide his love or hate than he, For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
modern: I don’t think there’s a man under the sun who’s worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard.

origin: I pray God he be not, I say.
modern: I pray to God he isn’t.

origin: Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.
modern: Then see the evidence of their evil with your own eyes.

origin: If they have done this deed, my noble lord— If?
modern: If they have done this thing, my noble lord— If?

origin: Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet, Talk’st thou to me of “ifs”?
modern: You lover of that damned whore, you’re talking to me of “ifs”?

origin: Thou art a traitor— Off with his head.
modern: You’re a traitor.—Off with his head.

origin: Woe, woe for England!
modern: I pity England, but not myself.

origin: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm, And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.
modern: Stanley dreamed the boar beheaded him, and I laughed and refused to flee with him.

origin: Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble, And started when he looked upon the Tower, As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.
modern: Three times today my horse stumbled and started when he looked in the direction of the Tower, as if he hated to carry me to this slaughterhouse.

origin: O, now I need the priest that spake to me!
modern: Oh, now I really need that priest who spoke to me today!

origin: I now repent I told the pursuivant, As too triumphing, how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered, And I myself secure in grace and favor.
modern: And I regret having bragged to the messenger about how my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I, as I said, was in good standing with Richard.

origin: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
modern: Oh Margaret, Margaret, your heavy curse has now landed on poor Hastings’s miserable head!

origin: Make a short shrift.
modern: Make your confession short.

origin: He longs to see your head.
modern: He’s eager to see your head.

origin: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
modern: We spend more time seeking out the fleeting glories of this temporary world than looking to the permanent grace of God!

origin: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready with every nod to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
modern: Anyone who builds his hopes on air lives like a drunken sailor hanging on a mast, ready with every dizzy nod of his head to tumble to the bottom of the sea.

origin: Come, come, dispatch.
modern: Come, come, hurry up.

origin: Tis bootless to exclaim.
modern: It’s pointless to talk now.

origin: O bloody Richard!
modern: Oh bloody Richard!

origin: Miserable England, I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee That ever wretched age hath looked upon.— Come, lead me to the block.
modern: Miserable England, I foresee for you the most frightening time you have ever experienced.—Come, lead me to the block.

origin: Bear him my head.
modern: Bring him my head.

origin: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
modern: Those who smile at it will soon be dead themselves.

origin: Ghastly looks Are at my service, like enforcèd smiles, And both are ready in their offices, At any time to grace my stratagems.
modern: Frightening looks are also at my service, as are fake smiles.

origin: But what, is Catesby gone?
modern: But has Catesby gone?

origin: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.
modern: A drum!

origin: If ever he have wife, let her be made More miserable by the death of him Than I am made by my poor lord and thee.— Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load, Taken from Paul’s to be interrèd there.
modern: And if he ever has a wife, let her be more miserable when he dies than I am now.

origin: What black magician conjures up this fiend To stop devoted charitable deeds?
modern: What wicked magician has conjured up this devil to interrupt this sacred burial rite?

origin: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent— Look back!
modern: Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent— Look behind you!

origin: Defend thee!
modern: Defend yourself!

origin: Here are enemies.
modern: There are enemies here.

origin: God and our innocence defend and guard us!
modern: God defend and guard us innocents against them!

origin: Be patient.
modern: Stay calm.

origin: They are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.
modern: They’re friends—Ratcliffe and Lovell.

origin: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor, The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.
modern: Here’s the head of that notorious traitor, the dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

origin: So dear I loved the man that I must weep.
modern: I loved this man so much it makes me weep.

origin: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted— I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife— He lived from all attainder of suspects.
modern: He was so slick in covering over his plans that if it hadn’t been for his love affair with Shore’s wife, I would never have suspected him.

origin: Had he done so?
modern: He would have?

origin: What, think you we are Turks or infidels?
modern: What, do you think we’re Turks or savages, instead of Christians?

origin: I never looked for better at his hands After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.
modern: I didn’t expect any better from him once he got involved with Mistress Shore.

origin: But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve As well as I had seen and heard him speak; And do not doubt, right noble princes both, But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens With all your just proceedings in this case.
modern: But, my good lord, the words of you and Lord Buckingham are as trustworthy to me as if I had seen and heard him speak myself.

origin: And to that end we wished your Lordship here T' avoid the censures of the carping world.
modern: That is exactly why we wanted you here, your lordship—to avoid the public carping and complaints.

origin: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury And bestial appetite in change of lust, Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives, Even where his raging eye or savage heart, Without control, lusted to make his prey.
modern: There was no limit to what his lustful eye and savage heart would prey on.

origin: Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person: Tell them when that my mother went with child Of that insatiate Edward, noble York My princely father then had wars in France, And, by true computation of the time, Found that the issue was not his begot, Which well appearèd in his lineaments, Being nothing like the noble duke my father.
modern: And, if you need to, approach the subject of me: tell them that when my mother became pregnant with the insatiable Edward, my noble father was fighting in France.

origin: Yet touch this sparingly, as ’twere far off, Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.
modern: But only hint at this vaguely, because, as you know, my mother’s still alive.

origin: And so, my lord, adieu.
modern: Goodbye, my lord.

origin: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard’s Castle, Where you shall find me well accompanied With reverend fathers and well-learnèd bishops.
modern: If things go well, bring the crowd to  I’m off.

origin: I go; and towards three or four o'clock Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
modern: Around three or four o'clock, look for news from the meeting hall.

origin: Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaw.
modern: Lovell, go as fast as you can to Doctor Shaw.

origin: Now will I go to take some privy order To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight, And to give order that no manner of person Have any time recourse unto the princes.
modern: Now I’ll go inside and write out a secret order to keep Clarence’s brats out of sight and to forbid anyone whatsoever from seeing King Edward’s sons.

origin: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed, That it may be today read o'er in Paul’s.
modern: Here’s the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, which has been written out in a clear hand, like any legal document, so it can be read aloud in public outside St. Paul’s Cathedral.

origin: Here’s a good world the while.
modern: What a backward world we live in!

origin: Who is so gross That cannot see this palpable device?
modern: Why, who’s so stupid that he can’t see through this fraud?

origin: Bad is the world, and all will come to naught When such ill dealing must be seen in thought.
modern: The world is a bad place, where you can’t speak what you know.

origin: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord, The citizens are mum, say not a word.
modern: It’s incredible—they didn’t say a word.

origin: Touched you the bastardy of Edward’s children?
modern: Did you mention that Edward’s children are bastards?

origin: No.
modern: I did.

origin: His answer was, the people were not used To be spoke to but by the recorder.
modern: He said that the people weren’t used to being spoken to except by the  What blocks of wood!

origin: Would not they speak?
modern: They wouldn’t say anything?

origin: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?
modern: Aren’t the mayor and his fellow citizens coming?

origin: The mayor is here at hand.
modern: The mayor is here at hand.

origin: And look you get a prayer book in your hand And stand between two churchmen, good my lord, For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.
modern: And make sure to carry a prayer book in your hand and to stand between two priests, okay?

origin: And be not easily won to our requests.
modern: But don’t be easily won over.

origin: I go.
modern: I’m going now.

origin: An if you plead as well for them As I can say “nay” to thee for myself, No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.
modern: If you’re as good at pleading to them as I am at saying no to you, this will definitely come to a happy end.

origin: Go, go, up to the leads.
modern: Hurry, go up to the roof.

origin: The Lord Mayor knocks.
modern: The Lord Mayor is knocking.

origin: Welcome, my lord.
modern: Welcome, my lord.

origin: I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
modern: I don’t think he wants to be disturbed.

origin: Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
modern: Now, Catesby, what does your lord say to my request?

origin: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day.
modern: My lord, he asks that you please visit him tomorrow or the next day.

origin: Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.
modern: Return to the gracious duke, good Catesby.

origin: Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen, No less importing than our general good, In deep designs, and matters of great moment Are come to have some conference with his grace.
modern: Tell him that the mayor, some citizens, and I have come to confer with his grace in matters of great importance concerning the general good.

origin: I’ll signify so much unto him straight.
modern: I’ll tell him right away, my lord.

origin: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!
modern: Ah, my lord, this prince is nothing like Edward!

origin: He is not lolling on a lewd love bed, But on his knees at meditation; Not dallying with a brace of courtesans, But meditating with two deep divines; Not sleeping, to engross his idle body, But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.
modern: He’s not sleeping to fatten up his lazy body, but praying, to nourish his attentive soul.

origin: Happy were England would this virtuous prince Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof.
modern: England would be lucky to have this virtuous prince as king.

origin: But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.
modern: But I’m afraid we’ll never get him to agree to be king.

origin: Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!
modern: But God forbid he says no to us!

origin: I fear he will.
modern: I’m afraid he will.

origin: Here Catesby comes again.
modern: Here comes Catesby again.

origin: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
modern: What’s up, Catesby, what does your master say?

origin: He wonders to what end you have assembled Such troops of citizens to come to him, His grace not being warned thereof before.
modern: My lord, he wonders why you have assembled such troops of citizens to speak with him, since he had no idea they were coming.

origin: He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
modern: My lord, he’s afraid you mean him harm.

origin: Sorry I am my noble cousin should Suspect me that I mean no good to him.
modern: I’m sorry my noble brother is suspicious of me.

origin: When holy and devout religious men Are at their beads, ’tis much to draw them thence, So sweet is zealous contemplation.
modern: When devoutly religious men are praying, it’s hard to draw them out of it, because they get lost in the wonder of their contemplation.

origin: See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.
modern: See how he stands between two clergymen!

origin: My lord, there needs no such apology.
modern: My lord, you don’t need to apologize.

origin: I do beseech your Grace pardon me, Who, earnest in the service of my God, Deferred the visitation of my friends.
modern: I beg you to pardon me.

origin: I do suspect I have done some offense That seems disgracious in the city’s eye, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
modern: I suspect that I have committed some offence to the city and you have come to reprimand me for not knowing better.

origin: You have, my lord.
modern: You have, my lord.

origin: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.
modern: Sweet saint, for goodness’s sake, don’t be so angry.

origin: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
modern: If you enjoy looking at your awful deeds, take a look at this noteworthy example of your butcheries.

origin: O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh!— Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity, For ’tis thy presence that exhales this blood From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.
modern: It’s your presence that draws out this blood from his empty veins.

origin: O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!
modern: Oh earth, which soaks up this blood, revenge his death!

origin: Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead, Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick, As thou dost swallow up this good king’s blood, Which his hell-governed arm hath butcherèd!
modern: Either let heaven send lightning to strike the murderer dead or let the earth open wide and devour him, as it does this good king’s blood.

origin: If not to answer, you might haply think Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty, Which fondly you would here impose on me.
modern: If I don’t answer, perhaps you’ll think I’m accepting the heavy responsibility you foolishly want to impose on me.

origin: First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
modern: First of all, even if all the obstacles were eliminated and my path led straight to the crown—if it were truly my birthright—I would rather hide from my greatness than hide inside the greatness of the position itself and be smothered by it.

origin: But, God be thanked, there is no need of me, And much I need to help you, were there need.
modern: So, thank God, there is no real need for me, as I wouldn’t be able to help you much.

origin: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit, Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time, Will well become the seat of majesty, And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
modern: The royal tree has left us other fruit, which, with time, will do just fine on the throne and make us all happy as king, I’m sure.

origin: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars, Which God defend that I should wring from him.
modern: God forbid that I snatch the crown from him.

origin: For first was he contract to Lady Lucy— Your mother lives a witness to that vow— And afterward by substitute betrothed To Bona, sister to the king of France.
modern: King Edward was going to marry Lady Lucy—your mother can vouch for that—and then he was betrothed to Bona, the King of France’s sister-in-law.

origin: These both put off, a poor petitioner, A care-crazed mother to a many sons, A beauty-waning and distressèd widow, Even in the afternoon of her best days, Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye, Seduced the pitch and height of his degree To base declension and loathed bigamy.
modern: But both of these were put off by Elizabeth Grey, a careworn mother of many children who had once been a beauty but was now a stressed-out widow long past her prime.

origin: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.
modern: Don’t refuse the love we offer you.

origin: O, make them joyful.
modern: Oh, make them joyful!

origin: Grant their lawful suit.
modern: Grant their law-abiding request!

origin: Alas, why would you heap this care on me?
modern: Alas, why would you heap all these responsibilities on me?

origin: I am unfit for state and majesty.
modern: I am unfit to rule and to be king.

origin: I do beseech you, take it not amiss; I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.
modern: Please, don’t take it badly, but I cannot and will not give in to you.

origin: Zounds, I’ll entreat no more.
modern: But listen, if

origin: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!
modern: Oh, please don’t swear, my lord of Buckingham.

origin: If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
modern: If you refuse it, the whole country will regret it.

origin: Will you enforce me to a world of cares?
modern: Would you tie me to a whole world of worries?

origin: Call them again.
modern: Well, call them back again.

origin: I am not made of stones, But penetrable to your kind entreaties, Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
modern: I am not made of stone; I am affected by all these kind pleas, though it goes against my conscience and my soul.

origin: God bless your Grace!
modern: God bless your Grace!

origin: We see it and will say it.
modern: We understand you’re just doing it for us, and we’ll be sure to say so.

origin: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.
modern: If you say that, you’ll only be telling the truth.

origin: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!
modern: Then I salute you with this royal title: long live Richard, England’s worthy king!

origin: Amen.
modern: Amen.

origin: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?
modern: Will you be crowned tomorrow?

origin: Even when you please, since you will have it so.
modern: Whenever you want, since you’re the one who wants it.

origin: Who meets us here?
modern: Who’s this?

origin: My niece Plantagenet Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
modern: My granddaughter, with her kind aunt, the duchess of Gloucester, leading her by the hand?

origin: Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower, On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.— Daughter, well met.
modern: Now, on my life, the young child must be headed to the Tower to greet the young princes, whom she adores.

origin: Whither away?
modern: Where are you going?

origin: No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess, Upon the like devotion as yourselves, To gratulate the gentle princes there.
modern: Just to the Tower—I’m guessing, for the same reason you are: to salute the noble princes who are staying there.

origin: Kind sister, thanks.
modern: Yes, kind sister.

origin: We’ll enter all together.
modern: We can all go together.

origin: And in good time here the lieutenant comes.— Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave, How doth the prince and my young son of York?
modern: And here comes the warden, just in time.

origin: Right well, dear madam.
modern: They’re just fine, my dear madam.

origin: By your patience, I may not suffer you to visit them.
modern: But I’m sorry—I’m not allowed to let you visit them.

origin: The king hath strictly charged the contrary.
modern: The king has strictly forbidden it.

origin: The king?
modern: The king?

origin: Who’s that?
modern: Who’s that?

origin: I mean, the Lord Protector.
modern: I meant to say the Lord Protector.

origin: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
modern: The Lord keep him from the title of king!

origin: Hath he set bounds between their love and me?
modern: Richard has set boundaries between my love and theirs?

origin: I am their mother.
modern: I am their mother.

origin: Who shall bar me from them?
modern: Who’s going to keep me from them?

origin: I am their father’s mother.
modern: I am their father’s mother.

origin: I will see them.
modern: I will see them.

origin: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother.
modern: I am their aunt, and I love them like a mother.

origin: Then bring me to their sights.
modern: So take me to see them.

origin: I’ll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
modern: Officer, I’ll take the responsibility from you, and the blame too.

origin: No, madam, no.
modern: No, madam, no.

origin: I may not leave it so.
modern: I can’t do this.

origin: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.
modern: I am bound by oath, so please forgive me.

origin: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence, And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.
modern: In just an hour from now, Duchess of York, I’ll be saluting you as the mother of two beautiful queens.

origin: Ah, cut my lace asunder, That my pent heart may have some scope to beat, Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!
modern: Oh, cut my bodice-staps so that my pent-up heart can have some room to breathe, or I’ll faint from this deadly news!

origin: O, unpleasing news!
modern: Cruel, cruel news!

origin: Thy mother’s name is ominous to children.
modern: Your mother’s name has become a threat to her own children.

origin: You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way.
modern: I’ll write to my stepson Richmond on your behalf, so that he’ll meet you on the way.

origin: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
modern: But don’t delay.

origin: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
modern: O, this evil wind that spreads nothing but misery.

origin: And I in all unwillingness will go.
modern: It has hatched a    I go unwillingly.

origin: O, would to God that the inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!
modern: I wish to God that the golden crown that I’ll have to wear were red-hot steel and burned me straight through to the brain!

origin: To feed my humor, wish thyself no harm.
modern: If you want to make me happy, don’t wish yourself harm.

origin: No?
modern: No?

origin: Why?
modern: Why?

origin: Poor heart, adieu.
modern: Every night I’m awakened by his  Poor dear, goodbye.

origin: I pity thy complaining.
modern: I pity your situation.

origin: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
modern: No more than I do yours.

origin: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow For tender princes, use my babies well.
modern: You are a rude, ragged nurse and an old, sullen playmate for such tender princes.

origin: So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.
modern: Please treat my babies well.

origin: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
modern: Dear woman, you don’t know the rules of charity.

origin: Villain, thou know’st not law of God nor man.
modern: Villain, you don’t know the laws of God or of man.

origin: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
modern: Even the fiercest wild animal has some touch of pity.

origin: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
modern: If I know nothing about pity, that must mean I’m not an animal.

origin: More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
modern: It’s even stranger when an angel is so angry.

origin: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposèd crimes to give me leave By circumstance but to acquit myself.
modern: Divine, perfect woman, give me a chance to prove in detail that I’m innocent of the evils you accuse me of.

origin: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man, Of these known evils but to give me leave By circumstance to curse thy cursèd self.
modern: Contagious infection of humanity, give me a chance to condemn you for the evils I know you’ve committed.

origin: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have Some patient leisure to excuse myself.
modern: You who are beautiful beyond words, calm down and let me explain myself.

origin: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make No excuse current but to hang thyself.
modern: You who are wicked beyond belief, the only “explanation” I’ll accept from you is for you to hang yourself.

origin: By such despair I should accuse myself.
modern: Such an expression of despair would only prove that I was guilty.

origin: My gracious sovereign.
modern: My gracious king.

origin: Give me thy hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: Thus high, by thy advice And thy assistance is King Richard seated.
modern: Because of your advice and your help, I have a high position now.

origin: But shall we wear these glories for a day, Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?
modern: But will I wear these honors for only a day or will I enjoy them for a long time?

origin: Still live they, and forever let them last.
modern: Let them last forever.

origin: Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch, To try if thou be current gold indeed.
modern: Oh Buckingham, now I’m going to test to see if you’re truly made of gold.

origin: Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
modern: Young Prince Edward is still alive—what do you think I’m going to say next?

origin: Say on, my loving lord.
modern: Go on, my loving lord.

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: Tis so—but Edward lives.
modern: But Edward is still alive.

origin: True, noble prince.
modern: True, noble prince.

origin: O bitter consequence That Edward still should live “true noble prince”!
modern: Oh, how bitter it is that Edward—the real “true, noble prince”—should still be alive!

origin: Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.
modern: Cousin, you didn’t used to be so thickheaded.

origin: Shall I be plain?
modern: Shall I put it plainly?

origin: What sayest thou now?
modern: What do you say?

origin: Your Grace may do your pleasure.
modern: Your Grace can do whatever he wants.

origin: Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.
modern: Tut, tut, you’ve become rather icy.

origin: Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?
modern: Tell me, do I have your consent to kill them?

origin: Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord, Before I positively speak in this.
modern: Give me a little breathing space, my lord, a little pause to think.

origin: I will resolve you herein presently.
modern: I’ll let you know my answer shortly.

origin: And unrespective boys.
modern: My lord?

origin: Know’st thou not any whom corrupting gold Will tempt unto a close exploit of death?
modern: Do you know anyone who would kill someone for money?

origin: What is his name?
modern: What’s his name?

origin: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
modern: His name is Tyrrel, my lord.

origin: I partly know the man.
modern: I know the man a bit.

origin: Go, call him hither, boy   No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels Hath he so long held out with me, untired, And stops he now for breath?
modern: Go, bring him here, boy.

origin: Well, be it so.
modern: Look who’s here!

origin: How now, Lord Stanley, what’s the news?
modern: What’s the news with you?

origin: Know, my long lord, The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.
modern: You should know, my loving lord, I’ve heard that the marquess Dorset has fled to Brittany, to the earl of Richmond.

origin: Come hither, Catesby.
modern: Come here, Catesby.

origin: Rumor it abroad That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.
modern: Spread the rumor abroad that Anne, my wife, is very sick.

origin: Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.
modern: And find a poverty stricken gentleman who I can marry straightaway to Clarence’s daughter.

origin: Look how thou dream’st!
modern: Look at you, standing there in a stupor!

origin: I say again, give out That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.
modern: I repeat, spread the rumor that Anne, my wife, is sick and likely to die.

origin: Is thy name Tyrrel?
modern: Are you Tyrrel?

origin: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
modern: James Tyrrel—and your most obedient subject.

origin: Art thou indeed?
modern: Are you indeed?

origin: Dar’st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
modern: Do you dare kill a friend of mine?

origin: Why then, thou hast it.
modern: Well, that’s what you get to do.

origin: Two deep enemies, Foes to my rest, and my sweet sleep’s disturbers, Are they that I would have thee deal upon.
modern: Two great enemies, in fact, enemies to my peace of mind.

origin: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.
modern: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

origin: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.
modern: Give me access to them, and soon you won’t have to worry about them anymore.

origin: Thou sing’st sweet music.
modern: That’s music to my ears.

origin: Hark, come hither, Tyrrel.
modern: Come here, Tyrrel.

origin: Go, by this token.
modern: By this token, you’ll be admitted to their cell.

origin: Rise, and lend thine ear.
modern: Get up and listen to me.

origin: There is no more but so.
modern: That’s all there is to it.

origin: Say it is done, And I will love thee and prefer thee for it.
modern: As soon as the deed is done, you will be in my favor and I will promote you.

origin: I will dispatch it straight.
modern: I’ll do it right away.

origin: My lord, I have considered in my mind The late request that you did sound me in.
modern: My lord, I have thought over the request you just made of me.

origin: Well, let that rest.
modern: Well, it doesn’t matter anymore.

origin: Dorset is fled to Richmond.
modern: Dorset has fled to the earl of Richmond.

origin: I hear the news, my lord.
modern: I heard the news, my lord.

origin: Stanley, he is your wife’s son.
modern: Stanley, Richmond is your wife’s son.

origin: Well, look unto it.
modern: Get information from her.

origin: My lord, I claim the gift, my due by promise, For which your honor and your faith is pawned— Th' earldom of Hereford and the movables Which you promisèd I shall possess.
modern: My lord, I’d want to have the gift you promised me on your honor: the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it.

origin: Stanley, look to your wife.
modern: Stanley, pay attention to your wife’s doings.

origin: If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
modern: If she sends any letters to Richmond, you will be accountable to me for it.

origin: What says your Highness to my just request?
modern: What do you say, your Highness, about my just request?

origin: I do remember me, Henry the Sixth Did prophesy that Richmond should be king, When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
modern: As I remember, Henry the Sixth prophesied that Richmond would be king when Richmond was only a foolish little boy.

origin: A king, perhaps— My lord— How chance the prophet could not at that time Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?
modern: A king, perhaps— My lord— How is it that the prophet didn’t tell me at the time that I would kill him?

origin: My lord, your promise for the earldom— Richmond!
modern: My lord, your promise of the earldom— Richmond!

origin: When last I was at Exeter, The mayor in courtesy showed me the castle And called it Rougemont, at which name I started, Because a bard of Ireland told me once I should not live long after I saw Richmond.
modern: The last time I was in Exeter, the mayor kindly showed me the castle there and called it “ My lord!

origin: My Lord— Ay, what’s o'clock?
modern: Yes, what time is it?

origin: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind Of what you promised me.
modern: I’m reminding your grace what you promised me.

origin: Well, but what’s o'clock?
modern: Well, but what time is it?

origin: Upon the stroke of ten.
modern: It’s almost ten o'clock.

origin: Well, let it strike.
modern: Well, let it strike ten then.

origin: Why let it strike?
modern: Why “let it strike”?

origin: Because that, like a jack, thou keep’st the stroke Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
modern: Because you’re like the lowborn fellow who strikes the bell—you keep interrupting my thoughts.

origin: I am not in the giving vein today.
modern: I am not in the giving mood today.

origin: Why then, resolve me whether you will or no.
modern: You’re bothering me.

origin: Thou troublest me; I am not in the vein.
modern: I’m not in the mood.

origin: And is it thus?
modern: Is this really happening?

origin: Repays he my deep service With such deep contempt?
modern: Does he reward my dedicated service with such deep contempt?

origin: Made I him king for this?
modern: Did I work to make him king for this?

origin: O, let me think on Hastings and be gone To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
modern: Oh, let me remember what happened to Hastings and hurry to

origin: The tyrannous and bloody act is done, The most arch deed of piteous massacre That ever yet this land was guilty of.
modern: It was the most ruthless massacre this country has ever been guilty of.

origin: Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn To do this piece of ruthless butchery, Albeit they were fleshed villains, bloody dogs, Melted with tenderness and mild compassion, Wept like two children in their deaths' sad story.
modern: Dighton and Forrest, whom I hired to perform the butchery, are used to killing people, the bloody dogs.

origin: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, And in their summer beauty kissed each other.
modern: Their lips, like four red roses on a stalk, touched.

origin: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?
modern: Kind Tyrrel, will your news make me happy?

origin: If to have done the thing you gave in charge Beget your happiness, be happy then, For it is done.
modern: If my doing what you told me to makes you happy, then be happy, because I did it.

origin: But did’st thou see them dead?
modern: But did you see them dead?

origin: I did, my lord.
modern: I did, my lord.

origin: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?
modern: And buried, noble Tyrrel?

origin: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them, But where, to say the truth, I do not know.
modern: The Tower’s chaplain has buried them, but to tell you the truth, I don’t know where.

origin: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after-supper, When thou shalt tell the process of their death.
modern: Tyrrel, come back shortly after dinner and tell me the details of their deaths.

origin: Meantime, but think how I may do thee good, And be inheritor of thy desire.
modern: In the meantime, think about how I can do you good and give you what you want.

origin: Farewell till then.
modern: See you soon.

origin: I humbly take my leave.
modern: I humbly say goodbye.

origin: The son of Clarence have I pent up close, His daughter meanly have I matched in marriage, The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham’s bosom, And Anne my wife hath bid this world goodnight.
modern: Edward’s sons have been carried off by the angels and Anne, my wife, has bid good night to the world.

origin: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims At young Elizabeth, my brother’s daughter, And by that knot looks proudly on the crown, To her go I, a jolly thriving wooer.
modern: Now I go, a jolly, thriving wooer, to marry my brother Edward’s young daughter, Elizabeth, because I know Richmond has his eye on her.

origin: My lord!
modern: My lord!

origin: Good or bad news, that thou com’st in so bluntly?
modern: Is the news good or bad that you enter without knocking?

origin: Bad news, my lord.
modern: Bad news, my lord.

origin: Morton is fled to Richmond, And Buckingham, backed with the hardy Welshmen, Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.
modern: The Bishop of Ely has fled to Richmond, and Buckingham, backed by a hardy Welsh army, is on the march.

origin: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near Than Buckingham and his rash-levied strength.
modern: Ely joining Richmond troubles me more than Buckingham and his quickly assembled army.

origin: Say that I slew them not.
modern: Let’s say I didn’t kill them.

origin: Then say they were not slain.
modern: Then you might as well say they’re not dead.

origin: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
modern: But they are dead, and you killed them, you slave of the devil.

origin: I did not kill your husband.
modern: I did not kill your husband.

origin: Why then, he is alive.
modern: Well, then he must be alive.

origin: In thy foul throat thou liest.
modern: You’re lying.

origin: Queen Margaret saw Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood, The which thou once didst bend against her breast, But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
modern: Queen Margaret saw your sword steaming with his blood.

origin: I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue, That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
modern: She provoked me with her lying mouth, accusing me of crimes I didn’t commit.

origin: Thou wast provokèd by thy bloody mind, That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.
modern: No, what provoked you was your own bloody mind, which never thinks about anything but butchering.

origin: Didst thou not kill this king?
modern: You killed this king, didn’t you?

origin: I grant you.
modern: Yes, I’ll grant you that.

origin: Dost grant me, hedgehog?
modern: You’ll grant me, you hedgehog?

origin: Then, God grant me too Thou mayst be damnèd for that wicked deed.
modern: Then let God grant me that you’ll be damned for that wicked deed.

origin: O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.
modern: Oh, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

origin: The better for the King of heaven that hath him.
modern: That will please God, who has him now.

origin: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
modern: He is in heaven, where you will never go.

origin: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither, For he was fitter for that place than earth.
modern: Let him thank me, who helped him get there.

origin: Here in these confines slyly have I lurked To watch the waning of mine enemies.
modern: I’ve lurked in the shadows here to watch the downfall of my enemies.

origin: A dire induction am I witness to, And will to France, hoping the consequence Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
modern: I’ll head to France soon.

origin: Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret.
modern: It’s time to hide, wretched Margaret.

origin: Who comes here?
modern: Who’s coming?

origin: Ah, my poor princes!
modern: Ah, my poor princes!

origin: Ah, my tender babes, My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets, If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fixed in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother’s lamentation.
modern: If your gentle souls are still flying in the air and have not yet landed where they will remain forever, hover around me with your airy wings and hear your mother’s lament.

origin: Hover about her; say that right for right Hath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.
modern: Hover about her and tell her she got what she deserved, with her children dead before their time.

origin: So many miseries have crazed my voice That my woe-wearied tongue is still and mute.
modern: I’ve been crazed with so many miseries that my tongue has tired of lamenting and gone mute.

origin: Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
modern: Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?

origin: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
modern: Will you abandon such gentle lambs, God, and throw them to the wolves?

origin: When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
modern: Have you ever slept before while such a terrible deed was done?

origin: Give mine the benefit of seigniory, And let my griefs frown on the upper hand.
modern: Let my sorrow have the upper hand.

origin: I had a Richard too, and thou did’st kill him; I had a Rutland too; thou holp’st to kill him.
modern: You had a Clarence, too, and Richard killed him.

origin: O upright, just, and true-disposing God, How do I thank thee that this carnal cur Preys on the issue of his mother’s body And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!
modern: Oh righteous God, how can I thank you enough that this meat-eating mutt preys on his mother’s children and forces her to join others in their grief!

origin: O Harry’s wife, triumph not in my woes!
modern: O Harry’s wife, do not triumph in my sorrow!

origin: God witness with me, I have wept for thine.
modern: With God as my witness, I swear I have wept for yours.

origin: Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward, Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; Young York, he is but boot, because both they Matched not the high perfection of my loss.
modern: Your son Edward, who stabbed my son Edward, is dead.

origin: Thy Clarence he is dead that stabbed my Edward, And the beholders of this frantic play, Th' adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey, Untimely smothered in their dusky graves.
modern: Your Clarence, who stabbed my Edward, is also dead.

origin: Richard yet lives, hell’s black intelligencer, Only reserved their factor to buy souls And send them thither.
modern: Richard, a fiendish spy for hell itself, still lives, but only long enough to buy souls to send below.

origin: Cancel his bond of life, dear God I pray, That I may live to say, “The dog is dead.”
modern: I pray that God ends his life before I die, so I can say, “The dog is dead!”

origin: O, thou didst prophesy the time would come That I should wish for thee to help me curse That bottled spider, that foul bunch-backed toad!
modern: Oh, you prophesied that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that humpbacked spider, that hideous toad!

origin: I called thee then “vain flourish of my fortune.” I called thee then poor shadow, “painted queen,” The presentation of but what I was, The flattering index of a direful pageant, One heaved a-high, to be hurled down below, A mother only mocked with two fair babes, A dream of what thou wast, a garish flag To be the aim of every dangerous shot, A sign of dignity, a breath, a bubble, A queen in jest, only to fill the scene.
modern: Back then, I called you “a poor, imitation queen,” a badly reproduced copy of what I was, a pretty prologue for the tragedy that was about to follow, a woman who was lifted high only to be hurled down to hell, a mother only teased with two beautiful children, who would soon die.

origin: Where is thy husband now?
modern: And I was right, because where’s your husband now?

origin: Where be thy brothers?
modern: Your brothers?

origin: Where are thy two sons?
modern: Your two sons?

origin: Thus hath the course of justice whirled about And left thee but a very prey to time, Having no more but thought of what thou wast To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
modern: Now you have only the memory of what you were, which tortures you when you consider what you’ve become.

origin: Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not Usurp the just proportion of my sorrow?
modern: You once stole my position; now you get to have the grief that goes with it.

origin: These English woes will make me smile in France.
modern: Your English sorrows will make me smile in France.

origin: O, thou well-skilled in curses, stay awhile, And teach me how to curse mine enemies.
modern: You who are so skilled in cursing, stay awhile and teach me how to curse my enemies.

origin: Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days; Compare dead happiness with living woe; Think that thy babes were sweeter than they were, And he that slew them fouler than he is.
modern: Remember your children as being sweeter than they actually were, and think of the man who killed them as worse than he is.

origin: Bettering thy loss makes the bad causer worse.
modern: Making your loss greater makes the person who caused it worse.

origin: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
modern: Think like this all day, and you’ll learn how to curse.

origin: My words are dull.
modern: My words are dull.

origin: O, quicken them with thine!
modern: Enliven them with yours!

origin: Thy woes will make them sharp and pierce like mine.
modern: Your misery will make them sharp and piercing like mine.

origin: Why should calamity be full of words?
modern: But give words a chance.

origin: If so, then be not tongue-tied.
modern: If that’s true, then don’t be tongue-tied.

origin: Go with me, And in the breath of bitter words let’s smother My damnèd son that thy two sweet sons smothered.
modern: Come with me, and let’s smother my fiendish son—who smothered your two sweet sons—in bitter words.

origin: Who intercepts my expedition?
modern: Who’s blocking the way?

origin: O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursèd womb, From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
modern: The woman who might have blocked you from all the murders you’ve committed by strangling you in her cursed womb.

origin: Hid’st thou that forehead with a golden crown Where should be branded, if that right were right, The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown And the dire death of my poor sons and brothers?
modern: Are you hiding your forehead with a golden crown, when, if there was any justice in this world, it should be branded with the murders you committed—your slaughter of the prince who held that crown, and of my sons and my brothers?

origin: Tell me, thou villain-slave, where are my children?
modern: Tell me, you villainous lowlife, where are my children?

origin: Where is gentle Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?
modern: Where are the noble Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

origin: Where is kind Hastings?
modern: Where is kind Hastings?

origin: Strike alarum, drums!
modern: Play, trumpets!

origin: Let not the heavens hear these telltale women Rail on the Lord’s anointed.
modern: Don’t let the heavens hear these chattery women abuse the Lord’s anointed king.

origin: Strike, I say!
modern: Play, I say!

origin: Either be patient and entreat me fair, Or with the clamorous report of war Thus will I drown your exclamations.
modern: Either be calm and polite or I’ll drown you out with the music of war.

origin: Art thou my son?
modern: Are you my son?

origin: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.
modern: Yes, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

origin: Then patiently hear my impatience.
modern: Then patiently listen to my impatience.

origin: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
modern: Madam, I’m a bit like you in that I can’t tolerate a tone of disapproval.

origin: O, let me speak!
modern: Oh, let me speak!

origin: Do then, but I’ll not hear.
modern: Go ahead, but I won’t listen.

origin: I will be mild and gentle in my words.
modern: I’ll be gentle and mild.

origin: And brief, good mother, for I am in haste.
modern: And brief, good mother—I’m in a hurry.

origin: Art thou so hasty?
modern: Are you that impatient?

origin: I have stayed for thee, God knows, in torment and in agony.
modern: God knows I waited for you in anguish, pain, and agony when I gave birth to you.

origin: And came I not at last to comfort you?
modern: And didn’t I finally arrive to comfort you?

origin: What comfortable hour canst thou name, That ever graced me in thy company?
modern: So, what hour of comfort have I ever had in your company?

origin: Faith, none but Humfrey Hower, that called your Grace To breakfast once, forth of my company.
modern: Name one.

origin: I prithee, hear me speak.
modern: You’re too bitter.

origin: You speak too bitterly.
modern: Just listen this once.

origin: Hear me a word, For I shall never speak to thee again.
modern: I’ll never speak to you again.

origin: So.
modern: So be it.

origin: Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse Abides in me.
modern: Though I have far more reason, I don’t have as much energy to curse you.

origin: I say amen to her.
modern: But I say amen to everything she said.

origin: Stay, madam.
modern: Wait, madam.

origin: I must talk a word with you.
modern: I need to speak a word with you.

origin: I have no more sons of the royal blood For thee to slaughter.
modern: I have no more royal sons for you to murder.

origin: You have a daughter called Elizabeth, Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.
modern: You have a daughter named Elizabeth, who is virtuous and beautiful, aristocratic and full of grace.

origin: And must she die for this?
modern: And does she have to die for this?

origin: O, let her live, And I’ll corrupt her manners, stain her beauty, Slander myself as false to Edward’s bed, Throw over her the veil of infamy.
modern: Oh, let her live, and I’ll ruin her manners and her beauty.

origin: So she may live unscarred of bleeding slaughter, I will confess she was not Edward’s daughter.
modern: So that she may live, I’ll say I cheated on Edward and that she is not really his child.

origin: Wrong not her birth.
modern: Don’t wrong her birth.

origin: She is a royal princess.
modern: She has royal blood.

origin: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.
modern: To save her life, I’ll say she doesn’t.

origin: And only in that safety died her brothers.
modern: Yes, as safe as her brothers' lives were.

origin: No, to their lives ill friends were contrary.
modern: Bad friends were.

origin: My babes were destined to a fairer death If grace had blessed thee with a fairer life.
modern: My children would have enjoyed a better death if God had blessed you with a purer life.

origin: Whose hand soever launched their tender hearts, Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction.
modern: Whichever hand literally stabbed their tender hearts, you’re the one who gave the order.

origin: No doubt the murd'rous knife was dull and blunt Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart, To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
modern: No doubt the murderous knife was blunt till it was sharpened on your stony heart—you reveled in my lambs' bloody guts.

origin: But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame, My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys Till that my nails were anchored in thine eyes, And I, in such a desp'rate bay of death, Like a poor bark of sails and tackling reft, Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.
modern: But constant expression of wild grief will only make it tame, so I’m not going to say any more about my boys until I’ve gouged your eyes out with my bare hands.

origin: Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise And dangerous success of bloody wars As I intend more good to you and yours Than ever you or yours were by me harmed!
modern: Madam, if I do as well as I think I’m going to do in these dangerous, violent wars, you and your relatives will have more good at my hands than you’ve ever had bad!

origin: What good is covered with the face of heaven, To be discovered, that can do me good?
modern: What good does heaven have in store that can do me any good now?

origin: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.
modern: The advancement of your children, noble lady.

origin: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads.
modern: Advancement to some scaffold, to lose their heads.

origin: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth’s glory.
modern: No, advancement to the dignity and height of honor, to a high, imperial kind of glory.

origin: And thou unfit for any place but hell.
modern: And you’re not suited for any place except hell.

origin: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.
modern: Yes, and one other place, if you’ll only let me name it.

origin: Some dungeon.
modern: Some dungeon.

origin: Your bedchamber.
modern: Your bedroom.

origin: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
modern: There is no rest to be had in any bedroom where you are!

origin: So will it, madam till I lie with you.
modern: Exactly, madam, until I sleep with you.

origin: Be brief, lest that the process of thy kindness Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.
modern: Well, explain—but do it fast so that your puny store of kindness isn’t used up by talking about it.

origin: Then know that from my soul I love thy daughter.
modern: Then know that from my soul I love your daughter.

origin: My daughter’s mother thinks it with her soul.
modern: I believe it.

origin: What do you think?
modern: What do you believe?

origin: That thou dost love my daughter from thy soul.
modern: That you love my daughter to spite your soul.

origin: Be not so hasty to confound my meaning.
modern: Don’t be so quick to twist my meaning.

origin: Even he that makes her queen.
modern: The one who makes her queen, of course.

origin: Who else should be?
modern: Who else should it be?

origin: What, thou?
modern: What, you?

origin: How think you of it?
modern: What do you think, madam?

origin: How canst thou woo her?
modern: How would you woo her?

origin: Madam, with all my heart.
modern: And  Madam, with all my heart.

origin: You mock me, madam.
modern: Come, come, you’re making fun of me.

origin: This is not the way To win your daughter.
modern: This is not the way to win your daughter.

origin: There is no other way, Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.
modern: There isn’t any other way, unless you took on another form and became someone else.

origin: Say that I did all this for love of her.
modern: But suppose I did all the things you named out of love for her.

origin: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
modern: Then she has no choice but to hate you, as you purchased her love with murder.

origin: Look what is done cannot be now amended.
modern: Whatever has already been done can’t be undone now.

origin: Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes, Which after-hours give leisure to repent.
modern: Men act imprudently sometimes, then realize their mistakes when they have time to think about them.

origin: If I did take the kingdom from your sons, To make amends I’ll give it to your daughter.
modern: If I took the kingdom from your sons, I’ll give it to your daughter to make up for it.

origin: If I have killed the issue of your womb, To quicken your increase I will beget Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter.
modern: If I have killed your children, I will have children with your daughter.

origin: A grandam’s name is little less in love Than is the doting title of a mother.
modern: A grandmother is loved hardly less than a mother is.

origin: Your children were vexation to your youth, But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
modern: Your children caused you trouble in your youth, but mine will bring you comfort in your old age.

origin: I cannot make you what amends I would; Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
modern: I can’t make up for everything that I’d like to, so accept such kindness as I can offer.

origin: What, we have many goodly days to see!
modern: Indeed, we have many good days to look forward to!

origin: Go then, my mother; to thy daughter go.
modern: Go, then, mother, to your daughter.

origin: What were I best to say?
modern: What should I say to her?

origin: Her father’s brother Would be her lord?
modern: That her father’s brother wants to be her husband?

origin: Or shall I say her uncle?
modern: Or should I say it’s her uncle?

origin: Or he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
modern: Or should I describe you as the one who killed her brothers and her uncles?

origin: Under what title shall I woo for thee, That God, the law, my honor and her love Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?
modern: How can I describe you that will make you appeal to the young woman and will also agree with God, the law, my honor, and her feelings?

origin: Infer fair England’s peace by this alliance.
modern: Claim fair England’s peace depends on this alliance.

origin: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.
modern: She will purchase that peace with an everlasting war.

origin: Tell her the king, that may command, entreats— That, at her hands, which the king’s King forbids.
modern: Tell her that the king, who has the power to command people, asks her.

origin: Say she shall be a high and mighty queen.
modern: He asks her to do what God  Say she will be a high and mighty queen.

origin: To vail the title, as her mother doth.
modern: Only to watch that title become worthless, as her mother has.

origin: Say I will love her everlastingly.
modern: Say I will love her everlastingly.

origin: But how long shall that title “ever” last?
modern: But how long will “ever” last?

origin: Sweetly in force unto her fair life’s end.
modern: Until her beautiful life’s end.

origin: But how long fairly shall her sweet life last?
modern: But how long will her beautiful life last?

origin: As long as heaven and nature lengthens it.
modern: As long as heaven and nature extend it.

origin: As long as hell and Richard likes of it.
modern: As long as hell and Richard want it.

origin: Say I, her sovereign, am her subject low.
modern: Tell her that I, her king, am her lowly subject.

origin: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.
modern: But she, your subject, hates such a king.

origin: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.
modern: Be eloquent on my behalf.

origin: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.
modern: An honest tale succeeds best when it is told simply.

origin: Then plainly to her tell my loving tale.
modern: Then tell her my loving story in simple terms.

origin: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.
modern: You can’t tell a story simply when it’s a lie.

origin: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
modern: Your answers are too shallow and too hasty.

origin: O no, my reasons are too deep and dead— Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their graves.
modern: Oh no, my reasons are deep and as permanent as death.

origin: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.
modern: Don’t harp on that point, madam—it’s past.

origin: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
modern: I will harp on it till my heartstrings break.

origin: Now by my George, my Garter, and my crown— Profaned, dishonored, and the third usurped.
modern: Now, by St. George, my knighthood, and my crown— The first you profaned, the second you dishonored, and the third you stole.

origin: I swear—      By nothing, for this is no oath.
modern: I swear— By nothing, because this is no oath.

origin: Then, by myself—      Thyself is self-misused.
modern: St. George loses his holiness once  Then, by myself— You’ve misused yourself.

origin: Now, by the world—      'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.
modern: Now, by the world— It’s full of your ugly wrongdoings.

origin: My father’s death—      Thy life hath it dishonored.
modern: By my father’s death— Your life has dishonored his death.

origin: If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him, Th' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child, And both the princes had been breathing here, Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust, Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
modern: If you had been afraid to break an oath with him, the crown you are currently wearing would have graced the head of my child, and both princes would still be alive, not preyed on by worms.

origin: What canst thou swear by now?
modern: What can you swear by now?

origin: The time to come.
modern: By the future.

origin: The children live whose fathers thou hast slaughtered, Ungoverned youth, to wail it in their age; The parents live whose children thou hast butchered, Old barren plants, to wail it with their age.
modern: There are parents living whose children you have butchered; they are now old withered plants who will moan over their losses as they grow old.

origin: Swear not by time to come, for that thou hast Misused ere used, by times ill-used o'erpast.
modern: Don’t swear by the future, because you’ve ruined it before it has even arrived.

origin: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms!
modern: May I only do well in these dangerous battles if my intention to repent and prosper is sincere!

origin: Myself myself confound, Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours, Day, yield me not thy light, nor night thy rest, Be opposite all planets of good luck To my proceedings if, with dear heart’s love, Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts, I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter.
modern: Let me destroy myself, let heaven and destiny deprive me of happy hours, let day remain dark and night sleepless, and let me have nothing but terrible luck if I do not love with a pure heart, clean devotion, and holy thoughts your beautiful royal daughter.

origin: In her consists my happiness and thine.
modern: My happiness and yours lie in her.

origin: Urge the necessity and state of times, And be not peevish found in great designs.
modern: It

origin: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
modern: Shall I be tempted by the devil?

origin: Ay, if the devil tempt you to do good.
modern: Yes, if the devil tempts you to do good.

origin: Ay, if your self’s remembrance wrong yourself.
modern: Yes, if your memories do you no good.

origin: Yet thou didst kill my children.
modern: Yet you killed my children.

origin: But in your daughter’s womb I bury them, Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breed Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.
modern: But in your daughter’s womb I will bury them.

origin: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
modern: Should I go convince my daughter to marry you?

origin: And be a happy mother by the deed.
modern: And be a happy mother by doing so.

origin: I go.
modern: I’m going.

origin: Write to me very shortly, And you shall understand from me her mind.
modern: Write to me very soon and I’ll let you know what she thinks.

origin: To our shores Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends, Unarmed and unresolved to beat them back.
modern: Many former friends of ours have gathered to meet the fleet and aren’t willing to beat it back.

origin: Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral; And there they hull, expecting but the aid Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.
modern: Word is that Richmond is the navy’s admiral.

origin: Some light-foot friend post to the duke of Norfolk— Ratcliffe, thyself, or Catesby.
modern: Someone who can ride fast, go to the duke of  Here, my good lord.

origin: Catesby, fly to the duke.
modern: Catesby, fly to the duke.

origin: I will, my lord, with all convenient haste.
modern: I will my lord, as fast as I can.

origin: Ratcliffe, come hither.
modern: Ratcliffe, come here.

origin: Post to Salisbury.
modern: Ride to Salisbury.

origin: O true, good Catesby.
modern: Oh, right, good Catesby.

origin: Bid him levy straight The greatest strength and power that he can make And meet me suddenly at Salisbury.
modern: Tell him to gather together the greatest army he can muster in a hurry and meet me right away at Salisbury.

origin: I go.
modern: I’m off.

origin: What, may it please you, shall I do at Salisbury?
modern: What would you like me to do at Salisbury?

origin: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?
modern: Why, what is there to do before I get there?

origin: Your Highness told me I should post before.
modern: Your Highness just told me that I should ride there before you.

origin: My mind is changed.
modern: I changed my mind.

origin: Stanley, what news with you?
modern: Stanley, what news do you have?

origin: None good, my liege, to please you with the hearing, Nor none so bad but well may be reported.
modern: Nothing that you want to hear, my lord, but nothing so bad that I can’t mention it.

origin: Hoyday, a riddle!
modern: Well, how nice, a riddle!

origin: Neither good nor bad.
modern: Neither good nor bad.

origin: What need’st thou run so many mile about When thou mayst tell thy tale the nearest way?
modern: Why do you go around in circles when you could get to the point?

origin: Once more, what news?
modern: Once again, what’s the news?

origin: Richmond is on the seas.
modern: Richmond is sailing on the sea.

origin: There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
modern: Let him sink there so the sea will cover him!

origin: White-livered runagate, what doth he there?
modern: Lily-livered coward, what’s he doing there?

origin: Well, as you guess?
modern: Well, what do you guess?

origin: Stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, He makes for England, here to claim the crown.
modern: That, stirred up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Morton, he’s coming to England to claim the crown.

origin: It is my day, my life.
modern: They are my daylight, my life.

origin: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life.
modern: Then I hope night shadows your day, and death takes your life!

origin: Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.
modern: Don’t damn yourself.

origin: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.
modern: I wish I were, so I could deprive you of both day and life.

origin: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
modern: There is no better one on earth.

origin: Is the chair empty?
modern: Is the throne empty?

origin: Is the sword unswayed?
modern: Is the army without a leader?

origin: Is the king dead, the empire unpossessed?
modern: Is the king dead, the empire dispossessed?

origin: What heir of York is there alive but we?
modern: What heir of the York family is there alive other than myself?

origin: And who is England’s king but great York’s heir?
modern: And who is England’s king but an heir of the great York?

origin: Then tell me, what makes he upon the seas?
modern: Therefore, tell me, what is he doing at sea?

origin: Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?
modern: Where is your army, then, to beat him back?

origin: Where be thy tenants and thy followers?
modern: Where are your tenants and your followers?

origin: Are they not now upon the western shore, Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships?
modern: Aren’t they at this very moment on the western shore helping the rebels land safely from their ships?

origin: Cold friends to me.
modern: Then they’re cold friends to me.

origin: What do they in the north When they should serve their sovereign in the west?
modern: What are they doing in the north when they should be in the west serving their king?

origin: They have not been commanded, mighty king.
modern: They haven’t been commanded to go to the west, mighty king.

origin: Pleaseth your Majesty to give me leave, I’ll muster up my friends and meet your Grace Where and what time your Majesty shall please.
modern: If your Majesty would like, I’ll muster up my friends and meet you wherever and whenever you like.

origin: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.
modern: Most mighty sovereign, you have no reason to doubt my friendship.

origin: I never was nor never will be false.
modern: I was never disloyal, and I never will be.

origin: Go then and muster men, but leave behind Your son George Stanley.
modern: Then go gather your men, but leave behind your son, George Stanley.

origin: My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire, As I by friends am well advertisèd, Sir Edward Courtney and the haughty prelate, Bishop of Exeter, his elder brother, With many more confederates are in arms.
modern: My noble king, my friends have informed me that Sir Edward Courtney and his brother, the haughty Bishop of Exeter, are now in  My king, the Guildfords in  My lord, the duke of Buckingham’s army— Enough, you

origin: In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms, And every hour more competitors Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.
modern: The news I have to tell your majesty is that Buckingham’s army has dispersed from sudden floods and heavy rainfall.

origin: My lord, the army of great Buckingham— Out on you, owls!
modern: Buckingham himself has wandered away alone to who knows where.

origin: Nothing but songs of death.
modern: I beg your pardon.

origin: But this good comfort bring I to your Highness: The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest.
modern: Yes, your Highness.

origin: March on, march on, since we are up in arms, If not to fight with foreign enemies, Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
modern: Even if we don’t fight foreign enemies, we’ll beat down these rebels at home.

origin: While we reason here, A royal battle might be won and lost.
modern: While we’re talking here, a royal battle could be won and lost.

origin: Someone take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury.
modern: Someone deliver the order that Buckingham be brought to Salisbury.

origin: The rest march on with me.
modern: Everyone else, march on with me.

origin: But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
modern: But, tell me, where is the noble Richmond now?

origin: At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.
modern: At Pembroke, or at Harfordwest in Wales.

origin: Sir Walter Herbert, a renownèd soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley, Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt, And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew, And many other of great name and worth; And towards London they do bend their power, If by the way they be not fought withal.
modern: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot; Sir William Stanley; Oxford; the highly feared Pembroke; Sir James Blunt; Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew; and many other famous and powerful noblemen.

origin: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this son of York, And all the clouds that loured upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
modern: Now we wear the wreaths of victory on our heads.

origin: Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front; And now, instead of mounting barbèd steeds To fright the souls of fearful adversaries, He capers nimbly in a lady’s chamber To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
modern: I’m left with nothing to do in this weak, idle peacetime, unless I want to look at my lumpy shadow in the sun and sing about

origin: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?
modern: Won’t King Richard let me speak with him?

origin: No, my good lord.
modern: No, my good lord.

origin: Therefore be patient.
modern: So be calm.
