origin: Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers, Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward, Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice, If that your moody, discontented souls Do through the clouds behold this present hour, Even for revenge mock my destruction.— This is All Souls' Day, fellow, is it not?
modern: Hastings and Edward’s children, Rivers and Grey, holy King Henry and your fine son Edward, Vaughan, and all who have died from underhanded, corrupt, fiendish injustice, if your angry souls are witnessing this moment through the clouds, enjoy the revenge—laugh at my ruin!

origin: It is.
modern: This is  It is, my lord.

origin: Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.
modern: Why, then, it’s my body’s doomsday.

origin: This is the day which, in King Edward’s time, I wished might fall on me when I was found False to his children and his wife’s allies.
modern: Today I’m going to get what I said I wished would happen to me if I was ever false to King Edward’s children or his wife’s allies.

origin: This is the day wherein I wished to fall By the false faith of him who most I trusted.
modern: This is the day I’m going to get what I wished for when I wished that the person I most trusted would betray me.

origin: This, this All Souls' Day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs.
modern: This, this All-Souls' day, is my just desserts.

origin: That high All-seer which I dallied with Hath turned my feignèd prayer on my head And given in earnest what I begged in jest.
modern: I tried to play games with God, and he turned my fake prayer on my head, giving me for real what I’d asked for as a joke.

origin: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms.
modern: This is how God forces wicked men to turn their swords against themselves.

origin: Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.
modern: I have done wrong, so I will suffer wrong.

origin: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
modern: I suspect his friends will join us.

origin: He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.
modern: He has no friends except those who are too afraid to defy him.

origin: Which in his dearest need will fly from him.
modern: In his greatest need, even they will desert him.

origin: All for our vantage.
modern: All to our advantage.

origin: Then, in God’s name, march.
modern: So, in God’s name, let’s march.

origin: True hope is swift, and flies with swallow’s wings.
modern: Hope with good cause is swift; it flies as fast as a swallow.

origin: Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.
modern: It turns kings into gods and men of lower rank into kings.

origin: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
modern: My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

origin: My Lord of Norfolk— Here, most gracious liege.
modern: My Lord of Norfolk— Here, most gracious king.

origin: Norfolk, we must have knocks, ha, must we not?
modern: Norfolk, we’re going to have a few blows, right?

origin: We must both give and take, my loving lord.
modern: We’ve got to give them and take them, my lord.

origin: Up with my tent!—Here will I lie tonight.
modern: I’ll lie here tonight.

origin: But where tomorrow?
modern: But where will I lie tomorrow?

origin: Well, all’s one for that.
modern: Well, it doesn’t matter.

origin: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
modern: Six or seven thousand, at most.

origin: Why, our battalia trebles that account.
modern: Why, our troops amount to three times that.

origin: Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength Which they upon the adverse party want.
modern: Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength; the opposition doesn’t have that advantage.

origin: Let’s lack no discipline, make no delay, For, lords, tomorrow is a busy day.
modern: Let’s be disciplined and not delay, because tomorrow is a busy day.

origin: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.
modern: My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, and you, Sir Walter Herbert, are going to stay with me.

origin: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment— Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him, And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent.
modern: Good Captain Blunt, tell the earl goodnight from me, and tell him that by two in the morning I would like him to visit my tent.

origin: Unless I have mista'en his colors much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile, at least, South from the mighty power of the king.
modern: Unless I’ve mistaken his battle flags, which I’m sure I haven’t, his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the king’s mighty army.

origin: If without peril it be possible, Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him, And give him from me this most needful note.
modern: If it’s possible to do this without putting yourself in danger, dear Captain Blunt, say goodnight to him from me and give him this important note.

origin: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll undertake it.
modern: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll do it.

origin: He lives that loves thee better than he could.
modern: There is a man who loves you better than your husband could.

origin: Name him.
modern: Name him.

origin: Plantagenet.
modern: Plantagenet.

origin: Why, that was he.
modern: Yes, that’s my husband’s name.

origin: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
modern: Someone else has the same name, but he’s a better man.

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is this man?

origin: Here.
modern: Here.

origin: Why dost thou spit at me?
modern: Why do you spit at me?

origin: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.
modern: If only I could spit poison.

origin: Never came poison from so sweet a place.
modern: Poison never came from such a sweet place.

origin: Never hung poison on a fouler toad.
modern: Poison never landed on such an ugly toad.

origin: Out of my sight!
modern: Get out of my sight!

origin: Thou dost infect mine eyes.
modern: You’re poisoning my eyes.

origin: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
modern: Your beautiful eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine with love.

origin: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.
modern: I wish my eyes were

origin: Good night, good Captain Blunt.
modern: Good night, dear Captain Blunt.

origin: Come, gentlemen, Let us consult upon tomorrow’s business Into my tent.
modern: Come, gentlemen, let’s discuss tomorrow’s action in my tent.

origin: The dew is raw and cold.
modern: The night air is too raw and cold for us to stay outdoors.

origin: What is “t o”clock?
modern: What time is it?

origin: It’s suppertime, my lord.
modern: It’s dinnertime, my lord.

origin: It’s nine o'clock.
modern: It’s nine o'clock.

origin: I will not sup tonight.
modern: I’m not going to eat dinner tonight.

origin: Give me some ink and paper.
modern: Give me some ink and paper.

origin: What, is my beaver easier than it was?
modern: Is the visor of my helmet working better now?

origin: And all my armor laid into my tent?
modern: And has my armor been put in my tent?

origin: Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge.
modern: My good man Norfolk, hurry to your post.

origin: I go, my lord.
modern: I’m off, my lord.

origin: Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.
modern: Get up early tomorrow—at the sound of the lark—noble Norfolk.

origin: I warrant you, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: Catesby.
modern: Catesby.

origin: My lord.
modern: Yes, my lord?

origin: My lord.
modern: Yes, my lord?

origin: Sawst thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
modern: Did you see the gloomy Lord Northumberland?

origin: Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself, Much about cockshut time, from troop to troop Went through the army cheering up the soldiers.
modern: Thomas, the earl of Surrey, and he were moving from troop to troop around twilight cheering up the soldiers.

origin: So, I am satisfied.
modern: Good, I’m satisfied.

origin: Set it down.
modern: Set it down.

origin: Is ink and paper ready?
modern: Is my ink and paper ready?

origin: It is, my lord.
modern: It is, my lord.

origin: Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tent And help to arm me.
modern: Ratcliffe, around midnight come to my tent and help me put on my armor.

origin: Leave me, I say.
modern: Now leave me alone, as I said.

origin: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
modern: Let fortune and victory be yours!

origin: All comfort that the dark night can afford Be to thy person, noble father-in-law.
modern: I wish you all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer, noble father-in-law.

origin: Tell me, how fares our loving mother?
modern: Tell me, how is my mother?

origin: I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother, Who prays continually for Richmond’s good.
modern: Your mother sends her blessings.

origin: In brief, for so the season bids us be, Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrament Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
modern: To be brief—as the occasion requires—prepare to fight early in the morning, when your future will be decided.

origin: I, as I may—that which I would I cannot,— With best advantage will deceive the time, And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms.
modern: I can’t do everything I want to, but I’ll help you as well as I can.

origin: But on thy side I may not be too forward, Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George, Be executed in his father’s sight.
modern: But I can’t be too obvious about being on your side without risking the life of your stepbrother, young George.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: The leisure and the fearful time Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love And ample interchange of sweet discourse, Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.
modern: The lack of time and the risk I’m under will have to keep us from bonding and catching up on each other’s news the way we usually would after not seeing each other for so long.

origin: God give us leisure for these rites of love!
modern: I hope we have the time some day!

origin: Once more, adieu.
modern: Again, goodbye.

origin: Be valiant, and speed well.
modern: Be brave and do well!

origin: Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.
modern: Again, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.

origin: O Thou, whose captain I account myself, Look on my forces with a gracious eye.
modern: Oh God, whose side I think I’m fighting on, look kindly on my forces.

origin: Make us thy ministers of chastisement, That we may praise thee in the victory!
modern: Make us your agents of revenge, so we can praise you when we’re victorious!

origin: To thee I do commend my watchful soul, Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes.
modern: Before I fall asleep, I entrust my soul to you.

origin: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!
modern: Defend me, God, both when I’m asleep and when I’m awake.

origin: Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fear Let fall thy lance.
modern: I’m sweating and trembling with fear.

origin: Despair, and die!
modern: Myself?

origin: Edward’s unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.
modern: Yes, I am.

origin: Think on Lord Hastings.
modern: Then run away.

origin: Despair and die!
modern: What, from myself?

origin: Thy adversary’s wife doth pray for thee.
modern: Why?

origin: The last was I that felt thy tyranny.
modern: Did I do anything good to myself?

origin: O, in the battle think on Buckingham, And die in terror of thy guiltiness.
modern: Oh, no.

origin: Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.
modern: I am a villain.

origin: But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismayed.
modern: Fool, do not flatter yourself.

origin: Give me another horse!
modern: Give me another horse!

origin: Bind up my wounds!
modern: Bandage my wounds!

origin: Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.
modern: Have mercy, Jesus!—Wait, I was only dreaming.

origin: O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!
modern: Oh cowardly conscience, how you’re torturing me!

origin: What do I fear?
modern: But what am I afraid of?

origin: Myself?
modern: Myself?

origin: There’s none else by.
modern: There’s no one else here.

origin: Richard loves Richard; that is, I and I.
modern: Richard loves Richard, that is, there’s just me and myself here.

origin: Is there a murderer here?
modern: Is there a murderer here?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Yes, I am.
modern: Yes, I am.

origin: Then fly!
modern: Then run away.

origin: What, from myself?
modern: What, from myself?

origin: Alack, I love myself.
modern: Unfortunately, I love myself.

origin: Wherefore?
modern: Why?

origin: For any good That I myself have done unto myself?
modern: Did I do anything good to myself?

origin: O, no!
modern: Oh, no.

origin: Alas, I rather hate myself For hateful deeds committed by myself.
modern: Alas, I hate myself instead, because of the hateful deeds I’ve committed.

origin: I am a villain.
modern: I am a villain.

origin: Fool, of thyself speak well.
modern: Fool, speak well of yourself.

origin: Fool, do not flatter.
modern: Fool, do not flatter yourself.

origin: My lord.
modern: My lord.

origin: Zounds, who is there?
modern: Damn it, who’s there?

origin: Ratcliffe, my lord, ’tis I.
modern: Ratcliffe, my lord, it’s me.

origin: The early village cock Hath twice done salutation to the morn.
modern: The rooster has already crowed twice.

origin: Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.
modern: Your friends are up and buckling on their armor.

origin: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream!
modern: Oh Ratcliffe, I had a terrifying dream!

origin: What think’st thou, will our friends prove all true?
modern: What do you think, will my friends prove loyal?

origin: No doubt, my lord.
modern: No doubt, my lord.

origin: By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond.
modern: By St. Paul, ghosts have struck more terror in my soul tonight than ten thousand of worthless Richmond’s soldiers could, dressed up in their most sword-proof armor.

origin: Tis not yet near day.
modern: It’s not yet daylight.

origin: Come, go with me; Under our tents I’ll play the eavesdropper To see if any mean to shrink from me.
modern: Come with me; I’ll spy under the tents to see if any of my own people plan to desert me.

origin: Good morrow, Richmond.
modern: Good morning, Richmond.

origin: Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen, That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.
modern: Pardon me, lords and gentlemen who stayed awake.

origin: How have you slept, my lord?
modern: How did you sleep, my lord?

origin: The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams That ever entered in a drowsy head Have I since your departure had, my lords.
modern: Since you left, I’ve been enjoying the sweetest sleep and most promising dreams I’ve ever had, my lords.

origin: Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered Came to my tent and cried on victory.
modern: I dreamed the souls of the people Richard murdered came to my tent and promised me victory.

origin: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
modern: I tell you, I feel very jolly remembering such a beautiful dream.

origin: How far into the morning is it, lords?
modern: How late is it, lords?

origin: Upon the stroke of four.
modern: It’s almost four.

origin: Why, then ’tis time to arm and give direction.
modern: Why, then, it’s time to put on my armor and instruct the troops.

origin: God and our good cause fight upon our side.
modern: We have God and a good cause on our side.

origin: The prayers of holy saints and wrongèd souls, Like high-reared bulwarks, stand before our faces.
modern: The prayers of saints and those that Richard wronged support us like high-walled fortresses.

origin: Richard except, those whom we fight against Had rather have us win than him they follow.
modern: Other than Richard, even those whom we fight against would rather we won.

origin: For what is he they follow?
modern: Because who is this man they follow?

origin: If you do sweat to put a tyrant down, You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain.
modern: If you struggle to bring down a tyrant, you will sleep peacefully when the tyrant is killed.

origin: If you do fight against your country’s foes, Your country’s fat shall pay your pains the hire.
modern: When you fight against your country’s enemies, you will be paid for your efforts with your country’s wealth.

origin: If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors.
modern: If you fight to protect your wives, your wives will welcome you home as conquerors.

origin: If you do free your children from the sword, Your children’s children quits it in your age.
modern: When you free your children from the sword, your grandchildren will repay you in your old age.

origin: Then, in the name of God and all these rights, Advance your standards.
modern: So, in the name of God and all the good that will come of this

origin: I would they were, that I might die at once, For now they kill me with a living death.
modern: I wish they were, so that I could die right now, because, at this point, I live a living death.

origin: I never sued to friend, nor enemy; My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.
modern: I never tried to win over a friend or enemy with sweet words.

origin: If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive, Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword, Which if thou please to hide in this true breast And let the soul forth that adoreth thee, I lay it naked to the deadly stroke And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
modern: If your vengeful heart can’t forgive me, here—take my sword and bury it in my heart so that my soul, which adores you, can be free.

origin: Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry— But ’twas thy beauty that provokèd me.
modern: No, don’t pause, because I

origin: What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?
modern: What did Northumberland say about Richmond?

origin: That he was never trainèd up in arms.
modern: That he was never trained as a soldier.

origin: He said the truth.
modern: That’s true.

origin: And what said Surrey then?
modern: And what did Surrey say to that?

origin: He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.” He was in the right, and so indeed it is.
modern: He smiled and said, “The better for us.” He’s right, and that’s how it is.

origin: Tell the clock there.
modern: Read the time there.

origin: Give me a calendar.
modern: Give me an almanac.

origin: Not I, my lord.
modern: I didn’t, my lord.

origin: Ratcliffe!
modern: Ratcliffe!

origin: My lord.
modern: My lord?

origin: The sun will not be seen today.
modern: The sun will not appear today.

origin: The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.
modern: The sky frowns and scowls on our army.

origin: I would these dewy tears were from the ground.
modern: I wish there wasn’t so much dew on the ground.

origin: Not shine today?
modern: So, the sun won’t shine today!

origin: Arm, arm, my lord.
modern: Get ready, my lord.

origin: The foe vaunts in the field.
modern: The enemy is making its appearance on the battlefield.

origin: Come, bustle, bustle.
modern: Hurry, hurry—prepare my horse.

origin: John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey, Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.
modern: John Duke of Norfolk and Thomas Earl of Surrey will lead the horsemen and foot soldiers.

origin: They thus directed, we will follow In the main battle, whose puissance on either side Shall be well wingèd with our chiefest horse.
modern: I’ll follow in the center of the troop formation, which I’ll defend with my best horse, and with Saint George on my side, as well!

origin: This, and Saint George to boot—What think’st thou, Norfolk?
modern: What do you think, Norfolk?

origin: A good direction, warlike sovereign.
modern: A good plan, warrior king.

origin: This found I on my tent this morning.
modern: I found this pinned to my tent this morning.

origin: Hark!
modern: Listen!

origin: I hear their drum.
modern: I hear their drums.

origin: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—
modern: Startle even the sky with the sound of your lances cracking.

origin: What says Lord Stanley?
modern: What does Lord Stanley say?

origin: Will he bring his power?
modern: Will he bring his army?

origin: My lord, he doth deny to come.
modern: My lord, he refuses to come.

origin: Off with his son George’s head!
modern: Off with his son George’s head!

origin: My lord, the enemy is past the marsh.
modern: My lord, the enemy has already passed the marsh.

origin: After the battle let George Stanley die.
modern: Let George Stanley die after the battle.

origin: Upon them!
modern: Let’s go!

origin: Victory sits on our helms.
modern: Victory is with us.

origin: Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!
modern: Help, my lord of Norfolk, help, help!

origin: The king enacts more wonders than a man, Daring an opposite to every danger.
modern: The king performs more wonders than seem humanly possible, challenging every enemy he sees.

origin: His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights, Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.
modern: His horse is killed, so he’s fighting on foot, risking his life to search out Richmond.

origin: Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
modern: Help, dear lord, or the battle will be lost!

origin: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
modern: A horse, a horse, I’d give my kingdom for a horse!

origin: Withdraw, my lord.
modern: Get off the field, my lord.

origin: I’ll help you to a horse.
modern: I’ll find you another horse.

origin: God and your arms be praised, victorious friends!
modern: God and your work be praised, victorious friends.

origin: Great God of heaven, say amen to all!
modern: Great God of heaven, say amen to all this!

origin: But tell me, is young George Stanley living?
modern: But, tell me, is young George Stanley alive?

origin: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town, Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
modern: He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester, where, if you’d like, we can retreat to.

origin: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.
modern: John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.

origin: And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament, We will unite the white rose and the red.
modern: As I vowed, I will unite the York and Lancaster families.

origin: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction, That long have frowned upon their enmity.
modern: Smile, then, on this beautiful union.

origin: What traitor hears me and says not “Amen?” England hath long been mad and scarred herself.
modern: What traitor hears me and doesn’t say amen?

origin: O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth, The true succeeders of each royal house, By God’s fair ordinance conjoin together, And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so.
modern: Now let Richmond and Elizabeth, the true heirs of each royal house, be joined together!

origin: Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord, That would reduce these bloody days again, And make poor England weep in streams of blood!
modern: Gracious Lord, blunt the swords of those traitors who mean to tear poor England apart again!

origin: Let them not live to taste this land’s increase, That would with treason wound this fair land’s peace.
modern: Let those who would mar this fair land’s peace with treason die before they can enjoy its wealth.

origin: Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.
modern: Civil wounds now can heal, and peace can live again.

origin: That she may long live here, God say amen.
modern: So that England may live a long life like this, let God say amen!

origin: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
modern: Take up the sword again, or take me up.

origin: Arise, dissembler.
modern: Get up, liar.

origin: Though I wish thy death, I will not be the executioner.
modern: Though I wish you were dead, I’m not going to be the one to kill you.

origin: I have already.
modern: I have already.

origin: That was in thy rage.
modern: You said it when you were furious.

origin: Speak it again and, even with the word, This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love, Shall for thy love kill a far truer love.
modern: Say it again—just one word, and my hand, which killed your lover out of love, will kill your far truer lover.

origin: To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.
modern: You will be an accessory to both crimes.

origin: I would I knew thy heart.
modern: I wish I knew what was in your heart.

origin: Tis figured in my tongue.
modern: I’ve told you.

origin: I fear me both are false.
modern: I fear that your words and your heart are both false.

origin: Then never man was man true.
modern: Then no man has ever been honest.

origin: Well, well, put up your sword.
modern: Well, then, put your sword away.

origin: Say then my peace is made.
modern: Tell me that you’ll accept my love.

origin: That shall you know hereafter.
modern: You’ll know about that later.

origin: But shall I live in hope?
modern: But can I have some hope?

origin: All men I hope live so.
modern: I’d like to think all men have some hope.

origin: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
modern: Please wear this ring.

origin: Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
modern: Wear both the ring and my heart, because both are yours.

origin: And if thy poor devoted servant may But beg one favor at thy gracious hand, Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.
modern: And if I, your poor devoted servant, may ask you for one small favor, you will guarantee my happiness forever.

origin: What is it?
modern: What’s that?

origin: That it would please you leave these sad designs To him that hath more cause to be a mourner, And presently repair to Crosby House, Where, after I have solemnly interred At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king And wet his grave with my repentant tears, I will with all expedient duty see you.
modern: Please leave it to me to take care of the burial, as I have more reason to mourn than you do.

origin: For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you, Grant me this boon.
modern: For various reasons that must remain secret, please do this for me.

origin: With all my heart, and much it joys me too To see you are become so penitent.— Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
modern: I’ll do it with all my heart.

origin: Bid me farewell.
modern: Say goodbye to me.

origin: Sirs, take up the corse.
modern: Sirs, take up the corpse.

origin: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
modern: Toward Chertsey, noble lord?

origin: No, to Whitefriars.
modern: No, to the Whitefriars monastery.

origin: There attend my coming.
modern: Wait for me there.

origin: Was ever woman in this humor wooed?
modern: Has anyone ever courted a woman in this state of mind?

origin: Was ever woman in this humor won?
modern: And has anyone ever won her, as I’ve done?

origin: I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.
modern: I’ll get her, but I won’t keep her long.

origin: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!
modern: And yet, against all odds, I win her over!

origin: Ha!
modern: Ha!

origin: Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I some three months since Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury?
modern: Has she already forgotten her brave husband, Prince Edward, whom I stabbed on the battlefield three months ago in my anger?

origin: A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford.
modern: He was graced with lots of natural gifts, he was young, valiant, wise, and no doubt meant to be king.

origin: And will she yet abase her eyes on me, That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince And made her widow to a woeful bed?
modern: And yet she cheapens herself by turning her gaze on me, who cut her sweet prince’s life short and made her a widow?

origin: On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?
modern: On me, though I am barely half the man that Edward was?

origin: On me, that halts and am misshapen thus?
modern: On me, though I am limping and deformed?

origin: My dukedom to a beggarly denier, I do mistake my person all this while!
modern: I bet I’ve been wrong about myself all this time.

origin: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot, Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.
modern: Even though I don’t see it, this lady thinks I’m a marvelously good-looking man.

origin: I’ll be at charges for a looking glass And entertain a score or two of tailors To study fashions to adorn my body.
modern: Time to buy myself a mirror and employ a few dozen tailors to dress me up in the current fashions.

origin: Since I am crept in favor with myself, I will maintain it with some little cost.
modern: Since I’m suddenly all the rage, it will be worth the cost.

origin: But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave And then return lamenting to my love.
modern: But first, I’ll dump this fellow in his grave, then return to my love weeping with grief.

origin: Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.
modern: Come out, beautiful sun—until I’ve bought a mirror to admire my reflection in, I’ll watch my shadow as I stroll along.

origin: Have patience, madam.
modern: Be patient, madam.

origin: There’s no doubt his majesty Will soon recover his accustomed health.
modern: I’m sure his majesty will recover his health soon.

origin: If he were dead, what would betide on me?
modern: Then you’ll be able to cheer  If he were dead, what would happen to me?

origin: Ah, he is young, and his minority Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester, A man that loves not me nor none of you.
modern: But he’s young, and as long as he’s too young to become king, Richard, the duke of Gloucester, has power over him.

origin: Is it concluded that he shall be Protector?
modern: Richard loves neither me nor any of you.

origin: It is determined, not concluded yet; But so it must be if the king miscarry.
modern: Has it been decided that Richard will be  It’s been decided, though not yet officially announced.

origin: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been.
modern: I hope God makes you happy again, like you once were.

origin: Saw you the king today, my lord of Derby?
modern: Did you see the king today, Lord Derby?

origin: But now the duke of Buckingham and I Are come from visiting his majesty.
modern: Yes, the duke of Buckingham and I have just returned from visiting him.

origin: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?
modern: What are the chances of his getting better, lords?

origin: Madam, good hope.
modern: Madam, keep up hope.

origin: His grace speaks cheerfully.
modern: He seems cheerful.

origin: God grant him health.
modern: God give him health.

origin: Did you confer with him?
modern: Did you talk with him?

origin: Ay, madam.
modern: Yes, madam.

origin: Would all were well—but that will never be.
modern: I wish I could believe you that all was well!

origin: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!
modern: They’re out to get me, and I won’t stand for it!

origin: Who is it that complains unto the king That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not?
modern: Which of you has been complaining to the king that I don’t like them?

origin: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused With silken, sly, insinuating jacks?
modern: Can’t a plain man live and do no harm to anyone without being taken advantage of by a bunch of slick, sneaky lowlifes?

origin: To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace?
modern: Which of us are you referring to?

origin: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.
modern: You, who are neither honest nor good.

origin: When have I injured thee?
modern: When did I ever do you any harm?

origin: Or any of your faction?
modern: Or any of you?

origin: A plague upon you all!
modern: Damn you all!

origin: His royal grace, Whom God preserve better than you would wish, Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
modern: The king—whom I hope God will protect better than you would like—can’t get a minute’s rest without you bothering him with your outrageous complaints.

origin: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.
modern: Brother, you’ve made a mistake.

origin: I cannot tell.
modern: He  I can’t tell what’s going on.

origin: The world is grown so bad That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch.
modern: The world has become so bad that now little wrens have settled where eagles used to roost.

origin: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester.
modern: Come, come, I know what you’re referring to, Richard.

origin: You envy my advancement, and my friends'.
modern: You resent my friends' rise in society, and my own.

origin: God grant we never may have need of you.
modern: Let’s hope we never need your help for anything.

origin: Meantime God grants that we have need of you.
modern: Meanwhile, we’re the ones who need you.

origin: Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
modern: My brother is imprisoned because of you, I am disgraced, and the nobility are held in contempt while those who two days ago weren’t worth a dime have suddenly been promoted.

origin: By Him that raised me to this careful height From that contented hap which I enjoyed, I never did incense his majesty Against the duke of Clarence, but have been An earnest advocate to plead for him.
modern: By the Lord who raised me to this weighty post from the happy and carefree life I used to enjoy, I promise you I never did anything to get the king to turn against the duke of Clarence.

origin: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover To entertain these fair well-spoken days, I am determinèd to prove a villain And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
modern: Since I can’t amuse myself by being a lover, I’ve decided to become a villain.

origin: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous, By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, To set my brother Clarence and the king In deadly hate, the one against the other; And if King Edward be as true and just As I am subtle, false, and treacherous, This day should Clarence closely be mewed up About a prophecy which says that “G” Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.
modern: I’ve set dangerous plans in motion, using lies, drunken prophecies, and stories about dreams to set my brother Clarence and the king against each other.

origin: His majesty, Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
modern: His majesty is so concerned about my personal safety that he has ordered them to conduct me to the  You’re being arrested?

origin: Upon what cause?
modern: Why?

origin: Because my name is George.
modern: Because my name is George.

origin: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours.
modern: That’s not your fault!

origin: He should, for that, commit your godfathers.
modern: He should imprison the person who named you, instead.

origin: O, belike his majesty hath some intent That you shall be new christened in the Tower.
modern: Maybe the king is sending you to the Tower to have you renamed.

origin: But what’s the matter, Clarence?
modern: But, really, what’s going on, Clarence?

origin: May I know?
modern: Can you tell me?

origin: What may she not?
modern: She could even what?

origin: I wis, your grandam had a worser match.
modern: Certainly, your grandmother had a worse match.

origin: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.
modern: My lord of Gloucester, I have suffered your blunt upbraidings and your bitterness toward me for too long.

origin: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty With those gross taunts that oft I have endured.
modern: By God, I will tell the king about these taunts.

origin: I had rather be a country servant-maid Than a great queen with this condition, To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.
modern: I would rather be a country serving maid than a great queen if it meant I could escape your scorn and constant harassment.

origin: Small joy have I in being England’s queen.
modern: I’ve had very little joy as England’s queen.

origin: So should we you, if you should be our king.
modern: If you were king, we would do the same.

origin: If I should be?
modern: If I were king?

origin: I had rather be a peddler.
modern: I’d rather be a peddler.

origin: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out In sharing that which you have pilled from me!
modern: Hear me, you wrangling pirates.

origin: Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
modern: Which of you does not tremble when you see me?

origin: Foul, wrinkled witch, what mak’st thou in my sight?
modern: Ugly, wrinkled witch, what are you doing here?

origin: But repetition of what thou hast marred.
modern: Only describing what you have ruined.

origin: That will I make before I let thee go.
modern: Or at least that’s what I plan to do before I let you go.

origin: Wert thou not banishèd on pain of death?
modern: Weren’t you banished on pain of death?

origin: I was, but I do find more pain in banishment Than death can yield me here by my abode.
modern: I was.

origin: The sorrow that I have by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.
modern: The sorrow that I feel actually belongs to you, and the high life you enjoy actually belongs to me.

origin: O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
modern: Oh, killing that child was the dirtiest, most merciless deed there ever was!

origin: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
modern: Tyrants themselves wept when they heard about it.

origin: What, were you snarling all before I came, Ready to catch each other by the throat, And turn you all your hatred now on me?
modern: Even  What, were you all snarling before I arrived, ready to catch each other by the throat like dogs, but now that I’m here, you turn your hatred toward me?

origin: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen, Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self.
modern: All because of what happened to that brat Rutland?

origin: Have done thy charm, thou hateful, withered hag.
modern: Enough of your magic spells, you hateful, withered hag.

origin: And leave out thee?
modern: And leave you out?

origin: Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
modern: Don’t move, dog.

origin: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul.
modern: It’s your turn now.

origin: Richard!
modern: Richard.

origin: Ha?
modern: Yes?

origin: I call thee not.
modern: I didn’t call you.

origin: I cry thee mercy, then, for I did think That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.
modern: I beg your pardon—I thought it was me whom you were calling all those terrible names.

origin: Why, so I did, but looked for no reply.
modern: Yes, I was, but I don’t want an answer from you.

origin: O, let me make the period to my curse!
modern: Let me finish my curse.

origin: Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”   Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
modern: I’ve finished it for you, and it ends in “Margaret.” He’s turned your curse against you, Margaret.

origin: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune, Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider, Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
modern: Poor imitation queen, why do you align yourself with this humpbacked spider when he’s got you trapped in his deadly web?

origin: The day will come that thou shalt wish for me To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad.
modern: The day will come when you’ll wish I could help you cast spells against this poisonous, hunchbacked toad.

origin: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse, Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.
modern: Woman, stop your frantic curses and false prophesies before we run out of patience and do something bad to you.

origin: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.
modern: Shame on you; I’ve already run out of patience with you all.

origin: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
modern: If you got what you deserved, you would learn some respect.

origin: To serve me well, you all should do me duty: Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects.
modern: What I deserve is that you treat me like a queen, and what you deserve is to act like my subjects.

origin: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
modern: Give me what I deserve, and do your duty!

origin: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
modern: People in high positions are shaken by many blasts of wind, and when they fall, they shatter into pieces.

origin: Good counsel, marry.
modern: Good advice, indeed.

origin: Learn it, learn it, marquess.
modern: Take it to heart, Dorset.

origin: It touches you, my lord, as much as me.
modern: It applies to you as much as to me, my lord.

origin: And turns the sun to shade.
modern: But you turn that sun into a shadow.

origin: Urge neither charity nor shame to me.
modern: You are building your nest in

origin: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered.
modern: Stop—if you can’t be kind, at least have some shame.

origin: My charity is outrage, life my shame, And in that shame still live my sorrows' rage.
modern: How dare you talk about kindness or shame.

origin: Have done, have done.
modern: Enough, enough.

origin: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood, Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
modern: Your clothes aren’t spattered with my family’s blood, and you aren’t affected by my curse.

origin: Nor no one here, for curses never pass The lips of those that breathe them in the air.
modern: No one here is affected by your curse, because curses are just words with no power.

origin: What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?
modern: What is she saying, my lord?

origin: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
modern: Nothing that interests me, my good lord.

origin: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel, And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
modern: What, you ignore my kind advice and try to please the devil I’m warning you about?

origin: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.
modern: Her curses have made my hair stand on end.

origin: And so doth mine.
modern: Mine, too.

origin: I muse why she’s at liberty.
modern: I don’t understand why she’s not locked up.

origin: I cannot blame her.
modern: I can’t blame her.

origin: I never did her any, to my knowledge.
modern: I never caused her any harm, as far as I know.

origin: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.
modern: But you have all the advantages from the harm done.

origin: Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid; He is franked up to fatting for his pains.
modern: And look how he’s repaid poor Clarence for his loyalty—penned him up like a pig being fattened for slaughter.

origin: God pardon them that are the cause thereof.
modern: God pardon those who are responsible for Clarence’s troubles.

origin: So do I ever  For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
modern: I always pray for them

origin: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest As yet I do not.
modern: I’ll tell you as soon as I know, Richard, because at this point I have no idea.

origin: But, as I can learn, He hearkens after prophecies and dreams, And from the crossrow plucks the letter  And says a wizard told him that by “G” His issue disinherited should be.
modern: He picked out the letter “G” from the alphabet and said a wizard told him that “G” will take the throne away from his children.

origin: And for my name of George begins with  It follows in his thought that I am he.
modern: He thinks “G” is me.

origin: Why, this it is when men are ruled by women.
modern: Well, this is what happens when men let themselves be ruled by women.

origin: Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower.
modern: The king isn’t the one sending you to the Tower, Clarence.

origin: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she That tempers him to this extremity.
modern: It’s his wife, Lady Grey, who got him to do this.

origin: Madam, his majesty doth call for you,— And for your Grace, —and yours, my gracious lords.
modern: Madam, his majesty asks for you, and for you, Duke of Gloucester, and for you, my noble lords.

origin: We wait upon your Grace.
modern: We will wait on you, your majesty.

origin: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
modern: I do the wrong and am the first to start quarrels.

origin: Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
modern: Dressing my out-and-out wickedness in scraps of Scripture, I look like a saint exactly when I’m most like the devil.

origin: But, soft!
modern: But quiet.

origin: Are you now going to dispatch this thing?
modern: Are you going to take care of this thing now?

origin: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant That we may be admitted where he is.
modern: We are, my lord.

origin: Well thought upon.
modern: Good thinking.

origin: I have it here about me.
modern: I have it on me here.

origin: Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate.
modern: Tut, tut, my lord, we’re not going to stand around chit-chatting.

origin: Talkers are no good doers.
modern: Talkers aren’t good doers.

origin: Be assured We go to use our hands and not our tongues.
modern: Rest assured that we’re going there to use our hands, not our tongues.

origin: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears.
modern: When fools cry, you remain stony.

origin: I like you lads.
modern: I like you guys.

origin: Go, go, dispatch.
modern: Hurry now, get the job done.

origin: We will, my noble lord.
modern: We will, my noble lord.

origin: Why looks your grace so heavily today?
modern: Why do you look so depressed today, your Grace?

origin: What was your dream, my lord?
modern: What was your dream?

origin: I pray you tell me.
modern: Tell me.

origin: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower And was embarked to cross to Burgundy, And in my company my brother Gloucester, Who from my cabin tempted me to walk Upon the hatches.
modern: I thought I had escaped from the Tower and was on a ship to France with my brother Richard, who persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on deck with him.

origin: Thence we looked toward England And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.
modern: Looking toward England, we reminisced about the countless frightening experiences we’d had in the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters.

origin: O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown, What dreadful noise of waters in my ears, What sights of ugly death within my eyes.
modern: Lord, how painful it was to drown.

origin: Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks, A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon, Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl, Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels, All scattered in the bottom of the sea.
modern: I saw a thousand shipwrecks, a thousand men whom fish had gnawed to the bone, huge anchors, chunks of gold, heaps of pearls, and precious jewels—all scattered on the bottom of the sea.

origin: Had you such leisure in the time of death To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
modern: So you had time as you were dying to look around?

origin: Methought I had, and often did I strive To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air, But smothered it within my panting bulk, Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.
modern: It wouldn’t let my soul find its way to air but smothered it inside my gasping body.

origin: I passed, methought, the melancholy flood, With that sour ferryman which poets write of, Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
modern: In fact, the real nightmare had only just begun.

origin: The first that there did greet my stranger-soul Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick, Who spake aloud, “What scourge for perjury Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?” And so he vanished.
modern: With the help of the grim  The first to greet me there was my great

origin: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you.
modern: Clarence has arrived—lying, cowardly  I’m not surprised it scared you, my lord.

origin: I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
modern: It scares me just to hear you talk about it.

origin: Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things, That now give evidence against my soul, For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me.— O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds, Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!
modern: I did them for Edward’s sake—and look how he rewards me.—Oh God, if my prayers don’t satisfy you, and you have to avenge the wrongs I’ve done, at least punish me alone!

origin: O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!— Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.
modern: Please spare my innocent wife and children!—Kind warden, please stay with me for a while.

origin: My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
modern: I’m feeling very low, and I need to sleep.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: I’ll stay, my lord.

origin: God give your Grace good rest.
modern: May God bring you sleep!

origin: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.
modern: Sorrow interrupts all hours and seasons.

origin: Princes have but their titles for their glories, An outward honor for an inward toil,
modern: The only glory princes have are their titles.

origin: What wouldst thou, fellow?
modern: What do you want, fellow?

origin: And how cam’st thou hither?
modern: And how did you get in here?

origin: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.
modern: I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.

origin: What, so brief?
modern: That’s it?

origin: Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.—Let him see our commission, and talk no more.
modern: Well, sir, it’s better to say little than to be tedious.

origin: I am in this commanded to deliver The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.
modern: It orders me to hand the noble duke of Clarence over to you.

origin: There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.
modern: Here are the keys, and there is the duke, sleeping.

origin: You may, sir.
modern: You may, sir.

origin: Tis a point of wisdom.
modern: That’s a wise idea.

origin: Fare you well.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?
modern: What, should I stab him while he sleeps?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
modern: When he wakes up!

origin: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
modern: Why, he won’t wake up till Judgment Day.

origin: Why, then he’ll say we stabbed him sleeping.
modern: Okay, so that’s when he’ll say we stabbed him in his sleep.

origin: The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
modern: That word “judgment” makes me feel a bit guilty.

origin: What, art thou afraid?
modern: What, are you afraid?

origin: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
modern: Not of killing him, because I have a warrant for it, but of being damned for killing him, which no warrant can protect me from.

origin: I thought thou hadst been resolute.
modern: I thought you were resolved to do this.

origin: So I am—to let him live.
modern: I am resolved—to let him live.

origin: I’ll back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
modern: I’ll go back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

origin: Nay, I prithee stay a little.
modern: Please, just wait a minute.

origin: I hope this passionate humor of mine will change.
modern: I’m hoping my holy mood will pass.

origin: It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.
modern: It usually only lasts about twenty seconds.

origin: How dost thou feel thyself now?
modern: How are you feeling now?

origin: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
modern: Actually, I’m still feeling some pangs of conscience.

origin: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.
modern: Remember the reward we’re getting when the deed’s done.

origin: Zounds, he dies!
modern: Jesus, let’s kill him!

origin: I had forgot the reward.
modern: I forgot about the reward.

origin: Where’s thy conscience now?
modern: Where’s your conscience now?

origin: O, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.
modern: Oh, in the duke of Gloucester’s wallet.

origin: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
modern: When he opens his wallet to give us our pay, your conscience will fly out?

origin: Tis no matter.
modern: It won’t matter.

origin: Let it go.
modern: Let it fly out.

origin: There’s few or none will entertain it.
modern: No one will listen to it.

origin: What if it come to thee again?
modern: And what will you do if it returns to you?

origin: I’ll not meddle with it.
modern: I won’t bother with it.

origin: Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom.
modern: It blushes, is easily embarrassed, and stages regular uprisings in a man’s heart.

origin: I am strong-framed.
modern: I’m strong-willed.

origin: He cannot prevail with me.
modern: He won’t get the better of me.

origin: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation.
modern: Spoken like a brave man who respects his reputation.

origin: Come, shall we fall to work?
modern: Shall we get to work?

origin: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.
modern: We’ll hit him on the head with the handles of our swords, then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.

origin: O excellent device— and make a sop of him.
modern: What an excellent idea—he’ll soak up the wine!

origin: Strike!
modern: Strike!

origin: No, we’ll reason with him.
modern: No, first let’s talk to him.

origin: Where art thou, keeper?
modern: Where are you, keeper?

origin: Give me a cup of wine.
modern: Give me a cup of wine.

origin: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
modern: You’ll have wine enough, my lord, soon.

origin: In God’s name, what art thou?
modern: In God’s name, who are you?

origin: A man, as you are.
modern: A man, like you.

origin: But not, as I am, royal.
modern: But not a member of the royal family, like me.

origin: Nor you, as we are, loyal.
modern: And you’re not loyal, like us.

origin: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
modern: Your voice is loud and commanding, but you look like a working man.

origin: My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
modern: I’m speaking for the king, but I look like myself.

origin: Your eyes do menace me.
modern: Your eyes look threatening.

origin: Why look you pale?
modern: And why are you so pale?

origin: Who sent you hither?
modern: Who sent you here?

origin: Wherefore do you come?
modern: Why are you here?

origin: To, to, to— To murder me?
modern: To, to, to— To murder me?

origin: Ay, ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so, And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
modern: You barely have the heart to tell me, so you can’t possibly have the nerve to do it.

origin: Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?
modern: Besides, how have I offended you, my friends?

origin: Offended us you have not, but the king.
modern: You didn’t offend us, you offended the king.

origin: I shall be reconciled to him again.
modern: He and I will make up.

origin: Never, my lord.
modern: Never, my lord.

origin: Therefore prepare to die.
modern: So prepare to die.

origin: Are you drawn forth among a world of men To slay the innocent?
modern: It’s your job in life to kill the innocent?

origin: What is my offense?
modern: What did I do wrong?

origin: Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?
modern: Where’s the evidence against me?

origin: What lawful quest have given their verdict up Unto the frowning judge?
modern: Where’s the jury, the judge, the lawful proceedings, the verdict?

origin: Or who pronounced The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death Before I be convict by course of law?
modern: Who pronounced this death sentence before a court of law could even convict me?

origin: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
modern: For you to threaten to kill me is most unlawful.

origin: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption, By Christ’s dear blood shed for our grievous sins, That you depart, and lay no hands on me.
modern: If you hope to have your sins forgiven by Christ’s dear blood, which He shed for our terrible sins, you must leave and keep your hands off me.

origin: What we will do, we do upon command.
modern: What we do we have been commanded to do.

origin: Even so.
modern: All right.

origin: An please your Worship, Brakenbury, You may partake of anything we say.
modern: If you like, Brakenbury, you can listen to anything we say.

origin: We speak no treason, man.
modern: We’re not saying anything treasonous, man.

origin: We say the king Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous.
modern: We say the king is wise and good, and his noble queen is getting old, pretty, and not jealous.

origin: We say that Shore’s wife hath a pretty foot, A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue, And that the queen’s kindred are made gentlefolks.
modern: And that Mr. Shore’s wife has nice feet, cherry lips, pretty eyes, and a very pleasant way of expressing herself.

origin: How say you, sir?
modern: What do you think?

origin: Can you deny all this?
modern: Is there anything inaccurate in that?

origin: With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.
modern: I have nothing to do with what you’re talking about, my lord.

origin: Her husband, knave.
modern: Her husband, you rascal.

origin: Wouldst thou betray me?
modern: Are you going to get me in trouble?

origin: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
modern: I beg your

origin: And he that hath commanded is our king.
modern: And the one who commands us is our king.

origin: And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee For false forswearing and for murder too.
modern: He does, and now he’s taking revenge on you—for breaking promises and for murder, too.

origin: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
modern: Whom you swore you would protect and defend.

origin: How canst thou urge God’s dreadful law to us When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?
modern: How dare you tell us about God’s laws when you have broken them so savagely yourself?

origin: For whose sake did I that ill deed?
modern: But for whose sake did I do that sick deed?

origin: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
modern: For my brother Edward’s sake.

origin: If God will be avengèd for this deed, O, know you yet He doth it publicly!
modern: If God will be revenged for this deed, he will do it publicly.

origin: Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm; He needs no indirect or lawless course To cut off those that have offended Him.
modern: God doesn’t need to use indirect or illegal means to kill those who have offended him.

origin: My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.
modern: My brother’s love, the devil, and my own anger made me do it.

origin: I am his brother, and I love him well.
modern: I am his brother, and I love him very much.

origin: You are deceived.
modern: You’re mistaken.

origin: Your brother Gloucester hates you.
modern: Richard, the duke of Gloucester, hates you.

origin: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.
modern: No, he loves and cherishes me.

origin: Go you to him from me.
modern: Go to him from me.

origin: Ay, so we will.
modern: We will.

origin: Tell him, when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, He little thought of this divided friendship.
modern: Tell him that when our noble father, the duke of York, gave his three sons his blessing, he never imagined that our friendship would come to this.

origin: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
modern: Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.

origin: Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.
modern: Yes, he’ll weep stones, as he taught us to do.

origin: Right, as snow in harvest.
modern: Yes, as kind as snow to a harvest.

origin: Come, you deceive yourself.
modern: Come on, you’re fooling yourself.

origin: Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.
modern: It’s Richard who sent us here to slaughter you.

origin: Why, so he doth, when he delivers you From this earth’s thralldom to the joys of heaven.
modern: Well, that’s what he’s doing—making you free to enjoy heaven.

origin: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
modern: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

origin: Have you that holy feeling in your souls To counsel me to make my peace with God, And art you yet to your own souls so blind That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?
modern: You have enough holy feeling to advise me to “make peace with God,” but you’re willing to go to war with God by murdering me?

origin: O sirs, consider: they that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
modern: Oh sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.

origin: Relent, and save your souls.
modern: Relent, and save your souls.

origin: Which of you—if you were a prince’s son Being pent from liberty, as I am now— If two such murderers as yourselves came to you, Would not entreat for life?
modern: If either of you were a prince’s son, and you were imprisoned as I am now, and two murderers like yourselves came to you—wouldn’t you beg for your life?

origin: Ay, you would beg, Were you in my distress.
modern: Yes, you would beg, if you were in my position.

origin: Relent?
modern: Relent?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Tis cowardly and womanish.
modern: That’s cowardly and womanish.

origin: Look behind you, my lord.
modern: Look behind you, my lord.

origin: Take that, and that.
modern: Take that, and that.

origin: How now?
modern: A  What’s going on?

origin: What mean’st thou, that thou help’st me not?
modern: What did you mean by not helping me?

origin: By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.
modern: By God, I’m going to tell the duke how slack you’ve been.

origin: I would he knew that I had saved his brother.
modern: I wish you could tell him I saved his brother.

origin: So do not I.
modern: I’m not.

origin: Go, coward as thou art.
modern: Go, coward that you are.

origin: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole Till that the duke give order for his burial.
modern: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole until the duke gives orders for his burial.

origin: And when I have my meed, I will away, For this will out, and then I must not stay.
modern: And when I get my reward, I’ll get out of here.

origin: Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.
modern: A jumbled confession can only receive a jumbled absolution.

origin: Then plainly know my heart’s dear love is set On the fair daughter of rich Capulet.
modern: I love rich Capulet’s daughter.

origin: As mine on hers, so hers is set on mine, And all combined, save what thou must combine By holy marriage.
modern: We’re bound to each other in every possible way, except we need you to marry us.

origin: When and where and how We met, we wooed and made exchange of vow, I’ll tell thee as we pass, but this I pray: That thou consent to marry us today.
modern: I’ll tell you more later about when and where we met, how we fell in love, and how we exchanged promises, but now I’m begging you: please, agree to marry us today.

origin: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
modern: Holy Saint Francis, this is a drastic change!

origin: Is Rosaline, whom thou didst love so dear, So soon forsaken?
modern: Have you given up so quickly on Rosaline, whom you loved so much?

origin: Young men’s love then lies Not truly in their hearts, but in their eyes.
modern: Then young men love with their eyes, not with their hearts.

origin: The sun not yet thy sighs from heaven clears, Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears.
modern: The groans you used to make are still ringing in my old ears.

origin: Lo, here upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet.
modern: There’s still a stain on your cheek from an old tear that hasn’t been washed off yet.

origin: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline.
modern: If you were ever yourself, and this sadness was yours, you and your sadness were all for Rosaline.

origin: And art thou changed?
modern: And now you’ve changed?

origin: Pronounce this sentence then: Women may fall when there’s no strength in men.
modern: Then repeat this after me: you can’t expect women to be faithful when men are so unreliable.

origin: Thou chid’st me oft for loving Rosaline.
modern: You scolded me often for loving Rosaline.

origin: For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
modern: I scolded you for obsessing about her, not for loving her, my student.

origin: And badest me bury love.
modern: And you told me to bury my love.

origin: Not in a grave, To lay one in, another out to have.
modern: I didn’t tell you to get rid of one love and replace her with another.

origin: I pray thee, chide not.
modern: Please, I beg you, don’t scold me.

origin: The other did not so.
modern: The other girl did not love me.

origin: Oh, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
modern: Oh, she knew very well that you were acting like you were in love without really knowing what love means.

origin: But come, young waverer, come, go with me, In one respect I’ll thy assistant be, For this alliance may so happy prove To turn your households' rancor to pure love.
modern: But come on, inconsistent young man, come with me.

origin: Oh, let us hence.
modern: Let’s get out of here.

origin: I stand on sudden haste.
modern: I’m in a rush.

origin: Wisely and slow.
modern: Go wisely and slowly.

origin: They stumble that run fast.
modern: Those who rush stumble and fall.

origin: Where the devil should this Romeo be?
modern: Where the devil can Romeo be?

origin: Came he not home tonight?
modern: Didn’t he come home last night?

origin: Not to his father’s.
modern: Not to his father’s house.

origin: I spoke with his man.
modern: I asked a servant.

origin: Why, that same pale hard-hearted wench, that Rosaline, Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
modern: That fair-skinned, hard-hearted hussy, Rosaline is going to torment him until he goes insane.

origin: Tybalt, the kinsman to old Capulet, Hath sent a letter to his father’s house.
modern: Tybalt, old Capulet’s nephew, has sent a letter to Romeo’s father’s house.

origin: A challenge, on my life.
modern: I bet it’s a challenge.

origin: Romeo will answer it.
modern: Romeo will answer the challenge.

origin: Any man that can write may answer a letter.
modern: Any man who knows how to write can answer a letter.

origin: Nay, he will answer the letter’s master, how he dares, being dared.
modern: No, Romeo will respond to the letter’s writer, telling him whether he accepts the challenge.

origin: Alas, poor Romeo!
modern: Oh, poor Romeo!

origin: And is he a man to encounter Tybalt?
modern: Is he man enough at this point to face off with Tybalt?

origin: Why, what is Tybalt?
modern: Why, what’s Tybalt’s story?

origin: The what?
modern: He knows what?

origin: Without his roe, like a dried herring.
modern: He looks skinny, like a dried herring without its eggs, and he hasn’t got his girl.

origin: O flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified!
modern: O flesh, flesh, you’ve turned pale and weak like a fish.

origin: Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in.
modern: Now he’s ready for

origin: Good morrow to you both.
modern: Good morning to you both.

origin: What counterfeit did I give you?
modern: What do you mean I faked you out?

origin: The slip, sir, the slip.
modern: You gave us the slip, sir, the slip.

origin: Can you not conceive?
modern: Can’t you understand what I’m saying?

origin: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.
modern: The  Right.

origin: I serve as good a man as you.
modern: My employer is as good as yours.

origin: No better.
modern: But he’s not better than mine.

origin: Well, sir.
modern: Well then.

origin: You lie.
modern: You lie.

origin: You know not what you do.
modern: Gregory, remember how to slash.

origin: What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds?
modern: What?

origin: Come between us, good Benvolio.
modern: Come break this up, Benvolio.

origin: My wits faints.
modern: I’m losing this duel of wits.

origin: Switch and spurs, switch and spurs, or I’ll cry a match.
modern: Keep going, keep going, or I’ll declare myself the winner.

origin: Nay, if our wits run the wild-goose chase, I am done, for thou hast more of the wild-goose in one of thy wits than, I am sure, I have in my whole five.
modern: You have more wild goose in one of your jokes than I have in five of mine.

origin: Was I with you there for the goose?
modern: Was I even close to you in the chase for the goose?

origin: Thou wast never with me for anything when thou wast not there for the goose.
modern: You were never with me for anything if you weren’t there for the goose.

origin: I will bite thee by the ear for that jest.
modern: I’ll bite you on the ear for that joke.

origin: Nay, good goose, bite not.
modern: No, good goose, don’t bite me.

origin: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting.
modern: Your joke is a very bitter apple.

origin: It is a most sharp sauce.
modern: Your humor is a spicy sauce.

origin: And is it not well served into a sweet goose?
modern: Then isn’t it just the right dish for a sweet goose?

origin: Oh, here’s a wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ell broad!
modern: Oh, that’s a joke made out of leather that spreads itself thin, from the width of an inch to as fat as a yard.

origin: I stretch it out for that word “broad,” which, added to the goose, proves thee far and wide a broad goose.
modern: I stretch my joke for that word “fat.” If you add that word to the word “goose,” it shows that you are a fat goose.

origin: Why, is not this better now than groaning for love?
modern: Why, isn’t all this joking better than groaning about love?

origin: Now art thou sociable.
modern: Now you’re sociable.

origin: Now art thou Romeo.
modern: Now you’re Romeo.

origin: Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
modern: Oh, you’re wrong.

origin: Oh, thou art deceived.
modern: I would have made it short.

origin: I would have made it short, for I was come to the whole depth of my tale, and meant, indeed, to occupy the argument no longer.
modern: I had come to the deepest part of my tale, and I planned to say nothing more on the topic.

origin: Here’s goodly gear.
modern: Here’s something good.

origin: Two, two—a shirt and a smock.
modern: There’s two—a man and a woman.

origin: Peter!
modern: Peter!

origin: Anon!
modern: I’m at your service.

origin: My fan, Peter.
modern: Give me my fan, Peter.

origin: God ye good morrow, gentlemen.
modern: Good morning, gentlemen.

origin: God ye good e'en, fair gentlewoman.
modern: Good afternoon, fair lady.

origin: Is it good e'en?
modern: Is it now afternoon?

origin: Tis no less, I tell you, for the bawdy hand of the dial is now upon the prick of noon.
modern: It’s not earlier than that, I tell you.

origin: Out upon you!
modern: The  Get out of here!

origin: What a man are you?
modern: What kind of man are you?

origin: One, gentlewoman, that God hath made, himself to mar.
modern: I’m a man, my lady, that God has made for himself to ruin.

origin: By my troth, it is well said.
modern: I swear, you speak the truth.

origin: For himself to mar,” quoth he?
modern: For himself to ruin,” he says.

origin: Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I may find the young Romeo?
modern: Gentlemen, can any of you tell me where I can find young Romeo?

origin: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you have found him than he was when you sought him.
modern: I can tell you, but young Romeo will be older when you find him than he was when you started looking for him.

origin: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
modern: I am the youngest man by that name, because there is no one younger, or worse.

origin: You say well.
modern: You speak well.

origin: Yea, is the worst well?
modern: Is the worst well?

origin: Very well took, i' faith, wisely, wisely.
modern: Very well taken, I believe, very wise.

origin: She will indite him to some supper.
modern: She will  A pimp!

origin: So ho!
modern: I’ve found it out.

origin: What hast thou found?
modern: What have you found out?

origin: Romeo, will you come to your father’s?
modern: Romeo, are you going to your father’s for lunch?

origin: We’ll to dinner, thither.
modern: Let’s go there.

origin: I will follow you.
modern: I’ll follow after you.

origin: A gentleman, Nurse, that loves to hear himself talk, and will speak more in a minute than he will stand to in a month.
modern: He says more in one minute than he does in a whole month.

origin: An he speak any thing against me, I’ll take him down, an he were lustier than he is, and twenty such Jacks.
modern: If he says anything against me, I’ll humble him, even if he were stronger than he is—and twenty punks like him.

origin: And if I cannot, I’ll find those that shall.
modern: If I can’t do it myself, I’ll find someone who can.

origin: Scurvy knave!
modern: That dirty rat!

origin: I am none of his flirt-gills.
modern: I’m not one of his sluts.

origin: I am none of his skains-mates.
modern: I’m not one of his punk friends who carries a knife.

origin: I saw no man use you at his pleasure.
modern: I didn’t see anybody use you for kicks.

origin: If I had, my weapon should quickly have been out, I warrant you.
modern: If I had seen something like that, I would have quickly pulled out my weapon.

origin: I dare draw as soon as another man if I see occasion in a good quarrel and the law on my side.
modern: Believe me, I’ll draw my sword as quick as any other man if I see a fight starting and the law is on my side.

origin: Now, afore God, I am so vexed that every part about me quivers.
modern: Now, I swear, I’m so angry that I’m shaking all over.

origin: Scurvy knave!
modern: That rotten scoundrel!

origin: Nurse, commend me to thy lady and mistress.
modern: Nurse, give my regards to to your lady.

origin: I protest unto thee— Good heart, and i' faith, I will tell her as much.
modern: I swear to you— You have a good heart, and believe me, I’ll tell her that.

origin: Lord, Lord, she will be a joyful woman.
modern: Lord, Lord, she’ll be a happy woman.

origin: What wilt thou tell her, Nurse?
modern: What are you going to tell her, Nurse?

origin: Thou dost not mark me.
modern: You’re not paying attention to me.

origin: And there she shall at Friar Lawrence' cell Be shrived and married.
modern: At Friar Lawrence’s cell she can make confession and be married.

origin: And stay, good Nurse.
modern: Wait good Nurse.

origin: Behind the abbey wall Within this hour my man shall be with thee And bring thee cords made like a tackled stair, Which to the high top-gallant of my joy Must be my convoy in the secret night.
modern: Within an hour, one of my men will come to you behind the abbey wall and give you a rope ladder.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Be trusty, and I’ll quit thy pains.
modern: Be honest and helpful, and I’ll repay you for your efforts.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Commend me to thy mistress.
modern: Sing my praises to your mistress.

origin: Now God in heaven bless thee!
modern: May God in heaven bless you.

origin: Hark you, sir.
modern: Now please listen, sir.

origin: What sayst thou, my dear Nurse?
modern: What do you have to say, my dear Nurse?

origin: Is your man secret?
modern: Can your man keep a secret?

origin: Did you ne'er hear say, “Two may keep counsel, putting one away”?
modern: Haven’t you ever heard the saying, “Two can conspire to put one away”?

origin: Warrant thee, my man’s as true as steel.
modern: I assure you, my man is as true as steel.

origin: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.—Lord, Lord!
modern: Well, sir, my mistress is the sweetest lady.

origin: when ’twas a little prating thing.—Oh, there is a nobleman in town, one Paris, that would fain lay knife aboard, but she, good soul, had as lief see a toad, a very toad, as see him.
modern: Lord, Lord, when she was a little baby—Oh, there is one nobleman in the city, a guy named Paris, who would be happy to claim her as his own.

origin: I anger her sometimes and tell her that Paris is the properer man.
modern: I make her angry sometimes by saying that Paris is more handsome than you are.

origin: But, I’ll warrant you, when I say so, she looks as pale as any clout in the versal world.
modern: But when I say so, I swear she turns white as a sheet.

origin: Doth not  Ay, Nurse, what of that?
modern: Don’t “ Yes, Nurse, what about that?

origin: Both with an  Ah, mocker, that’s the dog’s name.
modern: They both begin with the letter “R.” Ah, you jokester—that’s the dog’s name.

origin: Commend me to thy lady.
modern: Give my compliments to your lady.

origin: Ay, a thousand times.—Peter!
modern: Yes, a thousand times.

origin: Anon!
modern: Peter!

origin: Before and apace.
modern: I’m ready.

origin: The clock struck nine when I did send the Nurse.
modern: I sent the Nurse at nine o'clock.

origin: Perchance she cannot meet him.
modern: Maybe she can’t find him.

origin: That’s not so.
modern: That can’t be.

origin: Oh, she is lame!
modern: Oh, she’s slow!

origin: Love’s heralds should be thoughts, Which ten times faster glide than the sun’s beams, Driving back shadows over louring hills.
modern: Love’s messengers should be thoughts, which fly ten times faster than sunbeams.

origin: Now is the sun upon the highmost hill Of this day’s journey, and from nine till twelve Is three long hours, yet she is not come.
modern: That’s three hours since nine o'clock, but she hasn’t come back.

origin: Had she affections and warm youthful blood, She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
modern: If she was young and passionate, she’d move as fast as a ball.

origin: My words would bandy her to my sweet love, And his to me.
modern: My words would bounce her to my sweet love, and his words would bounce her back to me.

origin: But old folks, many feign as they were dead, Unwieldy, slow, heavy, and pale as lead.
modern: But a lot of old people act like they’re already dead—sluggish, slow, fat, and colorless, like lead.

origin: O God, she comes.—O honey Nurse, what news?
modern: Oh sweet Nurse, what news do you bring?

origin: Hast thou met with him?
modern: Have you spoken to him?

origin: Send thy man away.
modern: Send your man away.

origin: Peter, stay at the gate.
modern: Peter, wait for me at the gate.

origin: Now, good sweet Nurse— O Lord, why look’st thou sad?
