modern: Now, good sweet Nurse—Oh Lord, why do you look so sad?

origin: Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily.
modern: Even if the news is sad, tell me with a smile on your face.

origin: If good, thou shamest the music of sweet news By playing it to me with so sour a face.
modern: If the news is good, you’re ruining the sweet news by playing a trick with a sour face like that.

origin: I am aweary.
modern: I am tired.

origin: Give me leave awhile.
modern: Leave me alone for a minute.

origin: Fie, how my bones ache!
modern: Oh my, my bones ache so much.

origin: I would thou hadst my bones and I thy news.
modern: I wish you had my bones, and I had your news.

origin: Can you not stay awhile?
modern: Can’t you wait for a moment?

origin: Do you not see that I am out of breath?
modern: Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

origin: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath?
modern: How can you be out of breath when you have enough breath to tell me that you’re out of breath?

origin: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
modern: The excuse you make to delay the news is longer than the news itself.

origin: Is thy news good, or bad?
modern: Is the news good or bad?

origin: Answer to that.
modern: Answer that question.

origin: Say either, and I’ll stay the circumstance.
modern: Tell me if it’s good or bad, and I’ll wait for the details.

origin: Let me be satisfied.
modern: Tell me so I can be satisfied.

origin: Is ’t good or bad?
modern: Is it good or bad?

origin: Well, you have made a simple choice.
modern: Well, you have made a foolish choice.

origin: You know not how to choose a man.
modern: You don’t know how to pick a man.

origin: Romeo!
modern: Romeo?

origin: No, not he, though his face be better than any man’s, yet his leg excels all men’s, and for a hand and a foot and a body, though they be not to be talked on, yet they are past compare.
modern: No, not him, though his face is more handsome than any man’s, and his legs are prettier, and as for his hands and feet and body, they’re not much to speak of, and yet they’re beyond compare.

origin: He is not the flower of courtesy, but, I’ll warrant him, as gentle as a lamb.
modern: He’s not the most polite man in the world, but, believe me, he’s gentle as a lamb.

origin: Go thy ways, wench.
modern: Well, do what you want.

origin: Serve God.
modern: Be good.

origin: What, have you dined at home?
modern: Have you had lunch yet?

origin: No, no.
modern: No, I haven’t had lunch.

origin: But all this did I know before.
modern: Everything you told me I already knew.

origin: What says he of our marriage?
modern: What does he say about our marriage?

origin: What of that?
modern: What about that?

origin: My back a' t' other side.
modern: My head is pounding.

origin: Ah, my back, my back!
modern: My back aches too—

origin: I' faith, I am sorry that thou art not well.
modern: Believe me, I’m sorry you’re in pain.

origin: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what says my love?
modern: Sweet, sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me, what did my love Romeo say?

origin: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, and a courteous, and a kind, and a handsome, and, I warrant, a virtuous— Where is your mother?
modern: Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, who is courteous, kind, handsome, and, I believe, virtuous— where is your mother?

origin: Where is my mother?
modern: Where is my mother?

origin: Why, she is within.
modern: Why, she’s inside.

origin: Where should she be?
modern: Where else would she be?

origin: How oddly thou repliest!
modern: Your answer is so strange!

origin: Your love says, like an honest gentleman, 'Where is your mother?
modern: Your love says, like an honorable gentleman, 'Where is your mother?

origin: O God’s lady dear, Are you so hot?
modern: Are you this impatient?

origin: Marry, come up, I trow.
modern: Come on, you’re being ridiculous!

origin: Is this the poultice for my aching bones?
modern: Is this the cure for my aching bones?

origin: Henceforward do your messages yourself.
modern: From now on, take care of your messages yourself.

origin: Here’s such a coil.
modern: You’re making such a fuss.

origin: Come, what says Romeo?
modern: Come on, what did Romeo say?

origin: Have you got leave to go to shrift today?
modern: Do you have permission to go out and take confession today?

origin: I have.
modern: I do.

origin: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence’s cell.
modern: Then hurry up and rush over to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

origin: There stays a husband to make you a wife.
modern: There’s a husband there who’s waiting to make you his wife.

origin: Now comes the wanton blood up in your cheeks.
modern: Now I see the blood rushing to your cheeks.

origin: They’ll be in scarlet straight at any news.
modern: You blush bright red as soon as you hear any news.

origin: Hie you to church.
modern: Go to the church.

origin: I must another way To fetch a ladder, by the which your love Must climb a bird’s nest soon when it is dark.
modern: Your love will use it to climb up to your window while it’s dark.

origin: Go.
modern: Go.

origin: I’ll to dinner.
modern: I’ll go to lunch.

origin: Hie you to the cell.
modern: You go to Friar Lawrence’s cell.

origin: I do but keep the peace.
modern: I’m only trying to keep the peace.

origin: Put up thy sword, Or manage it to part these men with me.
modern: Either put away your sword or use it to help me stop this fight.

origin: What, drawn, and talk of peace?
modern: What?

origin: I hate the word, As I hate hell, all Montagues, and thee.
modern: I hate the word peace like I hate hell, all Montagues, and you.

origin: Have at thee, coward!
modern: Let’s go at it, coward!

origin: Clubs, bills, and partisans!
modern: Use your clubs and spears!

origin: Strike!
modern: Hit them!

origin: Beat them down!
modern: Beat them down!

origin: Down with the Capulets!
modern: Down with the Capulets!

origin: Down with the Montagues!
modern: Down with the Montagues!

origin: What noise is this?
modern: What’s this noise?

origin: My sword, I say!
modern: I want my sword.

origin: Old Montague is come, And flourishes his blade in spite of me.
modern: Old Montague is here, and he’s waving his sword around just to make me mad.

origin: Thou villain Capulet!
modern: Capulet, you villain!

origin: Thou shalt not stir one foot to seek a foe.
modern: You’re not taking one step toward an enemy.

origin: Hie to high fortune!
modern: Wish me luck.

origin: Honest Nurse, farewell.
modern: Thank you, dear Nurse.

origin: Amen, amen.
modern: Amen, amen.

origin: But come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight.
modern: But whatever misfortunes occur, they can’t ruin the joy I feel with one look at her.

origin: Therefore love moderately.
modern: Therefore, love each other in moderation.

origin: Long love doth so.
modern: That is the key to long-lasting love.

origin: Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
modern: Too fast is as bad as too slow.

origin: Here comes the lady.
modern: Here comes the lady.

origin: Oh, so light a foot Will ne'er wear out the everlasting flint.
modern: Oh,a footstep as light as hers will never endure the rocky road of life.

origin: Good even to my ghostly confessor.
modern: That’s how flimsy and unreal pleasure is.

origin: Romeo shall thank thee, daughter, for us both.
modern: Romeo will thank you, my girl, for both of us.

origin: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
modern: I’ll give him equal thanks, so we’re even.

origin: Ah, Juliet, if the measure of thy joy Be heaped like mine, and that thy skill be more To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath This neighbor air, and let rich music’s tongue Unfold the imagined happiness that both Receive in either by this dear encounter.
modern: Ah, Juliet if you’re as happy as I am, and you’re better with words, tell me about the happiness you imagine we’ll have in our marriage.

origin: Conceit, more rich in matter than in words, Brags of his substance, not of ornament.
modern: I can imagine more than I can say—I have more on my mind than words.

origin: Come, come with me, and we will make short work.
modern: Come, come with me, and we’ll do the job quickly.

origin: I pray thee, good Mercutio, let’s retire.
modern: I’m begging you, good Mercutio, let’s call it a day.

origin: Thou art like one of those fellows that, when he enters the confines of a tavern, claps me his sword upon the table and says “God send me no need of thee!” and, by the operation of the second cup, draws it on the drawer when indeed there is no need.
modern: You’re like one of those guys who walks into a bar, slams his sword on the table, and then says, “I pray I never have to use you.” By the time he orders his second drink, he pulls his sword on the bartender for no reason at all.

origin: Am I like such a fellow?
modern: Am I really like one of those guys?

origin: Come, come, thou art as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy, and as soon moved to be moody, and as soon moody to be moved.
modern: Come on, you can be as angry as any guy in Italy when you’re in the mood.

origin: And what to?
modern: And what about that?

origin: Nay, an there were two such, we should have none shortly, for one would kill the other.
modern: If there were two men like you, pretty soon there’d be none because the two of you would kill each other.

origin: Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.
modern: You would fight with a man if he had one more whisker or one less whisker in his beard than you have in your beard.

origin: Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.
modern: You’ll fight with a man who’s cracking nuts just because you have hazelnut-colored eyes.

origin: What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel?
modern: Only you would look for a fight like that.

origin: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat, and yet thy head hath been beaten as addle as an egg for quarreling.
modern: Your head is as full of fights as an egg is full of yolk, but your head has been beaten like scrambled eggs from so much fighting.

origin: Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun.
modern: You started a fight with a man who coughed in the street because he woke up a dog that was sleeping in the sun.

origin: Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?
modern: Didn’t you argue it out with your tailor for wearing one of his new suits before the right season?

origin: With another, for tying his new shoes with old ribbon?
modern: And with another for tying the new shoes he made with old laces?

origin: And yet thou wilt tutor me from quarreling!
modern: And yet you’re the one who wants to teach me about restraint!

origin: An I were so apt to quarrel as thou art, any man should buy the fee simple of my life for an hour and a quarter.
modern: If I were in the habit of fighting the way you are, my life insurance rates would be sky high.

origin: The fee simple?
modern: Your life insurance?

origin: O simple!
modern: That’s foolish.

origin: By my head, here comes the Capulets.
modern: Oh great, here come the Capulets.

origin: By my heel, I care not.
modern: Well, well, I don’t care.

origin: Couple it with something.
modern: Put it together with something else.

origin: Make it a word and a blow.
modern: Make it a word and a blow.

origin: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
modern: You’ll find me ready enough to do that, sir, if you give me a reason.

origin: Could you not take some occasion without giving?
modern: Can’t you find a reason without my giving you one?

origin: Mercutio, thou consort’st with Romeo.
modern: Mercutio, you hang out with Romeo.

origin: What, dost thou make us minstrels?
modern: Hang out?” Who do you think we are, musicians in a band?

origin: An thou make minstrels of us, look to hear nothing but discords.
modern: If we look like musicians to you, you can expect to hear nothing but noise.

origin: We talk here in the public haunt of men.
modern: We’re talking here in a public place.

origin: Either withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of your grievances, Or else depart.
modern: Either go someplace private, or talk it over rationally, or else just go away.

origin: Here all eyes gaze on us.
modern: Out here everybody can see us.

origin: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.
modern: Men’s eyes were made to see things, so let them watch.

origin: I will not budge for no man’s pleasure, I.
modern: I won’t move to please anybody.

origin: Well, peace be with you, sir.
modern: Well, may peace be with you.

origin: Here comes my man.
modern: Here comes my man, the man I’m looking for.

origin: But I’ll be hanged, sir, if he wear your livery.
modern: He’s not your man.

origin: Tybalt, the reason that I have to love thee Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting.
modern: Tybalt, I have a reason to love you that lets me put aside the rage I should feel and excuse that insult.

origin: Villain am I none.
modern: I am no villain.

origin: Therefore, farewell.
modern: So, goodbye.

origin: I see thou know’st me not.
modern: I can tell that you don’t know who I am.

origin: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me.
modern: Boy, your words can’t excuse the harm you’ve done to me.

origin: Therefore turn and draw.
modern: So now turn and draw your sword.

origin: And so, good Capulet—which name I tender As dearly as my own—be satisfied.
modern: And so, good Capulet—which is a name I love like my own name—you should be satisfied with what I say.

origin: O calm dishonourable, vile submission!
modern: This calm submission is dishonorable and vile.

origin: What wouldst thou have with me?
modern: What do you want from me?

origin: Will you pluck your sword out of his pilcher by the ears?
modern: Will you pull your sword out of its sheath?

origin: Make haste, lest mine be about your ears ere it be out.
modern: Hurry up, or I’ll smack you on the ears with my sword before you have yours drawn.

origin: I am for you.
modern: I’ll fight you.

origin: Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
modern: Noble Mercutio, put your sword away.

origin: Away, Tybalt.
modern: Let’s get away, Tybalt.

origin: I am hurt.
modern: I’ve been hurt.

origin: A plague o' both your houses!
modern: May a plague curse both your families.

origin: I am sped.
modern: I’m finished.

origin: Is he gone and hath nothing?
modern: Did he get away clean?

origin: What, art thou hurt?
modern: What, are you hurt?

origin: Marry, ’tis enough.
modern: But it’s enough.

origin: Where is my page?—Go, villain, fetch a surgeon.
modern: Where is my page?

origin: Courage, man.
modern: Have courage, man.

origin: The hurt cannot be much.
modern: The wound can’t be that bad.

origin: No, ’tis not so deep as a well nor so wide as a church-door, but ’tis enough, ’twill serve.
modern: No, it’s not as deep as a well, or as wide as a church door, but it’s enough.

origin: Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.
modern: Ask for me tomorrow, and you’ll find me in a grave.

origin: I am peppered, I warrant, for this world.
modern: I’m done for in this world, I believe.

origin: A plague o' both your houses!
modern: May a plague strike both your houses.

origin: Zounds, a dog, a rat, a mouse, a cat to scratch a man to death!
modern: I can’t believe that dog, that rat, that mouse, that cat could scratch me to death!

origin: A braggart, a rogue, a villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!
modern: That braggart, punk villain who fights like he learned swordsmanship from a manual!

origin: Why the devil came you between us?
modern: Why the hell did you come in between us?

origin: I was hurt under your arm.
modern: He struck me from under your arm.

origin: I thought all for the best.
modern: I thought it was the right thing to do.

origin: Help me into some house, Benvolio, Or I shall faint.
modern: Take me inside some house, Benvolio, or I’ll pass out.

origin: A plague o' both your houses!
modern: May a plague strike both your families!

origin: They have made worms' meat of me.
modern: They’ve turned me into food for worms.

origin: I have it, And soundly too.
modern: I’m done for.

origin: Your houses!
modern: Curse your families!

origin: O Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!
modern: Oh Romeo, Romeo, brave Mercutio is dead!

origin: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.
modern: Here comes the furious Tybalt back again.

origin: Alive in triumph—and Mercutio slain!
modern: He’s alive and victorious, and Mercutio’s dead?

origin: Either thou or I, or both, must go with him.
modern: Either you, or I, or both of us have to go with him.

origin: Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here Shalt with him hence.
modern: Wretched boy, you hung out with him here, and you’re going to go to heaven with him.

origin: This shall determine that.
modern: This fight will decide who dies.

origin: Romeo, away, be gone!
modern: Romeo, get out of here.

origin: The citizens are up, and Tybalt slain.
modern: The citizens are around, and Tybalt is dead.

origin: Stand not amazed.
modern: Don’t stand there shocked.

origin: The Prince will doom thee death If thou art taken.
modern: The Prince will give you the death penalty if you get caught.

origin: Hence, be gone, away!
modern: So get out of here!

origin: Why dost thou stay?
modern: Why are you waiting?

origin: Which way ran he that killed Mercutio?
modern: The man who killed Mercutio, which way did he go?

origin: Tybalt, that murderer, which way ran he?
modern: Tybalt, that murderer, which way did he run?

origin: There lies that Tybalt.
modern: Tybalt is lying over there.

origin: Speak, nephew.
modern: Speak, nephew.

origin: Were you by when it began?
modern: Were you here when it started?

origin: Where are the vile beginners of this fray?
modern: Where are the evil men who started this fight?

origin: O noble prince, I can discover all The unlucky manage of this fatal brawl.
modern: Oh, noble prince, I can tell you everything about the unfortunate circumstances of this deadly fight.

origin: There lies the man, slain by young Romeo, That slew thy kinsman, brave Mercutio.
modern: He killed your relative, brave Mercutio, and then young Romeo killed him.

origin: Tybalt, my cousin!
modern: Tybalt was my nephew!

origin: O my brother’s child!
modern: He was my brother’s son!

origin: O cousin, cousin!
modern: Oh cousin, cousin!

origin: Benvolio, who began this bloody fray?
modern: Benvolio, who started this fight?

origin: Romeo, he cries aloud, “Hold, friends!
modern: Romeo cried out, “Stop, my friends.

origin: Friends, part!” and, swifter than his tongue, His agile arm beats down their fatal points, And ’twixt them rushes—underneath whose arm An envious thrust from Tybalt hit the life Of stout Mercutio, and then Tybalt fled.
modern: Break it up.” Then he jumped in between them and forced them to put their swords down.

origin: But by and by comes back to Romeo, Who had but newly entertained revenge, And to ’t they go like lightning, for ere I Could draw to part them was stout Tybalt slain.
modern: Before I could break up the fight, Tybalt was killed.

origin: And, as he fell, did Romeo turn and fly.
modern: Romeo ran away when Tybalt fell dead.

origin: This is the truth, or let Benvolio die.
modern: Benvolio is part of the Montague family.

origin: He speaks not true.
modern: He’s not telling the truth.

origin: Some twenty of them fought in this black strife, And all those twenty could but kill one life.
modern: There were twenty Montagues fighting in this awful riot, and together those twenty could only kill one man.

origin: I beg for justice, which thou, Prince, must give.
modern: You, Prince, are the man who can give me justice.

origin: Romeo slew Tybalt.
modern: Romeo killed Tybalt.

origin: Romeo must not live.
modern: Romeo must die.

origin: Romeo slew him; he slew Mercutio.
modern: Romeo killed Tybalt.

origin: Who now the price of his dear blood doth owe?
modern: Who should now pay the price for Mercutio’s life?

origin: His fault concludes but what the law should end, The life of Tybalt.
modern: His crime did justice’s job by taking Tybalt’s life.

origin: I have an interest in your hearts' proceeding.
modern: I’m involved in your rivalry.

origin: But I’ll amerce you with so strong a fine That you shall all repent the loss of mine.
modern: I’ll punish you so harshly that you’ll regret causing me this loss.

origin: I will be deaf to pleading and excuses.
modern: I won’t listen to your pleas or excuses.

origin: Nor tears nor prayers shall purchase out abuses, Therefore use none.
modern: You can’t get out of trouble by praying or crying, so don’t bother.

origin: Bear hence this body and attend our will.
modern: Take away this body, and do what I say.

origin: Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
modern: Showing mercy by pardoning killers only causes more murders.

origin: Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.
modern: Or else love is blind, and its best time is the night.

origin: Come, civil night, Thou sober-suited matron, all in black, And learn me how to lose a winning match Played for a pair of stainless maidenhoods.
modern: I wish night would come, like a widow dressed in black, so I can learn how to submit to my husband and lose my virginity.

origin: Hood my unmanned blood bating in my cheeks, With thy black mantle, till strange love, grow bold, Think true love acted simple modesty.
modern: Let the blood rushing to my cheeks be calmed.

origin: Come, night.
modern: Come, night.

origin: Come, Romeo.
modern: Come, Romeo.

origin: Come, thou day in night, For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night Whiter than new snow upon a raven’s back.
modern: You’re whiter than snow on the black wings of a raven.

origin: And when I shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine That all the world will be in love with night And pay no worship to the garish sun.
modern: His face will make the heavens so beautiful that the world will fall in love with the night and forget about the garish sun.

origin: The cords That Romeo bid thee fetch?
modern: Is that the rope ladder Romeo told you to pick up?

origin: Ay, ay, the cords.
modern: Yes, yes, this is the rope ladder.

origin: Ay me, what news?
modern: Oh my, what’s the news?

origin: Why dost thou wring thy hands?
modern: Why do you look so upset?

origin: Ah, welladay!
modern: He’s dead.

origin: We are undone, lady, we are undone!
modern: We’re ruined, lady, we’re ruined!

origin: Alack the day!
modern: What an awful day!

origin: Can heaven be so envious?
modern: Can God be so jealous and hateful?

origin: Romeo can, Though heaven cannot.
modern: Romeo is hateful, even though God isn’t.

origin: What devil art thou that dost torment me thus?
modern: What kind of devil are you to torture me like this?

origin: This torture should be roared in dismal hell.
modern: This is as bad as the tortures of hell.

origin: Hath Romeo slain himself?
modern: Has Romeo killed himself?

origin: Say thou but “ay,” And that bare vowel  Than the death-darting eye of cockatrice.
modern: Just say “Yes” and I will turn more poisonous than the snake with the evil eye.

origin: I am not I if there be such an  Or those eyes shut that makes thee answer “ay.” If he be slain, say “ay,” or if not, “no.” Brief sounds determine of my weal or woe.
modern: If he’s been killed, say “Yes.” If not, say “No.” These short words will determine my joy or my pain.

origin: To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty.
modern: I’ll send my eyes to prison, and they’ll never be free to look at anything again.

origin: Vile earth, to earth resign.
modern: I’ll give my vile body back to the earth.

origin: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best friend I had!
modern: Oh, Tybalt, Tybalt, he was the best friend I had.

origin: That ever I should live to see thee dead.
modern: I wish I had not lived long enough to see him die.

origin: Is Romeo slaughtered, and is Tybalt dead?
modern: Has Romeo been killed, and is Tybalt dead too?

origin: My dearest cousin and my dearer lord?
modern: Tybalt was my dearest cousin.

origin: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.
modern: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.

origin: O God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?
modern: Oh God, did Romeo’s hand shed Tybalt’s blood?

origin: It did, it did.
modern: It did, it did.

origin: Alas the day, it did.
modern: Curse the day this happened, but it did.

origin: O serpent heart hid with a flowering face!
modern: Oh, he’s like a snake disguised as a flower.

origin: Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?
modern: Did a dragon ever hide in such a beautiful cave?

origin: Dove-feathered raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!
modern: He’s a raven with the feathers of the dove.

origin: O nature, what hadst thou to do in hell When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend In moral paradise of such sweet flesh?
modern: Oh nature, what were you doing in hell?

origin: Was ever book containing such vile matter So fairly bound?
modern: Was there ever such an evil book with such a beautiful cover?

origin: Ah, where’s my man?—Give me some aqua vitae.— These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old.
modern: Ah, where’s my servant?—Give me some brandy.—These griefs, these pains, these sorrows make me old.

origin: Shame come to Romeo!
modern: Shame on Romeo!

origin: Blistered be thy tongue For such a wish!
modern: I hope sores cover your tongue for a wish like that!

origin: He was not born to shame.
modern: He was not born to be shameful.

origin: Upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit, For ’tis a throne where honor may be crowned.
modern: He deserves only honor, complete honor.

origin: Sole monarch of the universal earth, Oh, what a beast was I to chide at him!
modern: Oh, I was such a beast to be angry at him.

origin: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
modern: Are you going to say good things about the man who killed your cousin?

origin: But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?
modern: But why, you villain, did you kill my cousin?

origin: That villain cousin would have killed my husband.
modern: Probably because my cousin the villain would have killed my husband.

origin: All this is comfort.
modern: All this is comforting news.

origin: Wherefore weep I then?
modern: Why, then, should I cry?

origin: I would forget it fain, But oh, it presses to my memory, Like damnèd guilty deeds to sinners' minds.
modern: I would be glad to forget about it, but it weighs on my memory like sins linger in guilty minds.

origin: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”
modern: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banished.”

origin: That “banishèd,” that one word “banishèd” Hath slain ten thousand Tybalts.
modern: That banishment is worse than the murder of ten thousand Tybalts.

origin: Tybalt’s death Was woe enough, if it had ended there.
modern: Tybalt’s death would be bad enough if that was all.

origin: Or, if sour woe delights in fellowship And needly will be ranked with other griefs, Why followed not, when she said “Tybalt’s dead,” “Thy father” or “thy mother,” nay, or both, Which modern lamentations might have moved?
modern: It would have been better if, after she said, “Tybalt’s dead,” she told me my mother or my father, or both, were gone.

origin: But with a rearward following Tybalt’s death, “Romeo is banishèd.” To speak that word, Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet, All slain, all dead.
modern: But to say that Tybalt’s dead and then say, “Romeo has been banished.” To say that is like saying that my father, my mother, Tybalt, Romeo, and Juliet have all been killed, they’re all dead.

origin: Romeo is banishèd.” There is no end, no limit, measure, bound, In that word’s death.
modern: Romeo has been banished.” That news brings infinite death.

origin: No words can that woe sound.
modern: No words can express the pain.

origin: Where is my father and my mother, Nurse?
modern: Where are my father and my mother, Nurse?

origin: Weeping and wailing over Tybalt’s corse.
modern: They are crying and moaning over Tybalt’s corpse.

origin: Will you go to them?
modern: Are you going to join them?

origin: I will bring you thither.
modern: I’ll bring you there.

origin: Wash they his wounds with tears?
modern: Are they washing out his wounds with their tears?

origin: Mine shall be spent When theirs are dry, for Romeo’s banishment.
modern: I’ll cry my tears for Romeo’s banishment when their tears are dry.

origin: Take up those cords.—Poor ropes, you are beguiled, Both you and I, for Romeo is exiled.
modern: Pick up this rope ladder.

origin: He made you for a highway to my bed, But I, a maid, die maiden-widowèd.
modern: He made this rope ladder to be a highway to my bed, but I am a virgin, and I will die a virgin and a widow.

origin: And death, not Romeo, take my maidenhead!
modern: And death, not Romeo, can take my virginity!

origin: Hie to your chamber.
modern: Go to your bedroom.

origin: I’ll find Romeo To comfort you.
modern: I’ll find Romeo to comfort you.

origin: I wot well where he is.
modern: I know where he is.

origin: Hark ye, your Romeo will be here at night.
modern: Listen, your Romeo will be here tonight.

origin: I’ll to him.
modern: I’ll go to him.

origin: He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
modern: He’s hiding out in Friar Lawrence’s cell.

origin: Romeo, come forth.
modern: Romeo, come out.

origin: Come forth, thou fearful man.
modern: Come out, you frightened man.

origin: Father, what news?
modern: Father, what’s the news?

origin: Too familiar Is my dear son with such sour company.
modern: You know too much about suffering.

origin: I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
modern: I have news for you about the Prince’s punishment.

origin: What less than doomsday is the Prince’s doom?
modern: Is the Prince’s punishment any less awful than doomsday?

origin: Ha, banishment!
modern: Ha, banishment?

origin: Be merciful, say “death,” For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death.
modern: Be merciful and say “death.” Exile is much worse than death.

origin: Do not say “banishment.” Hence from Verona art thou banishèd.
modern: Don’t say “banishment.” From now on, you are banished from Verona.

origin: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
modern: You should be able to endure this because the world is broad and wide.

origin: There is no world without Verona walls But purgatory, torture, hell itself.
modern: There is no world for me outside the walls of Verona, except purgatory, torture, and hell itself.

origin: Hence “banishèd” is banished from the world, And world’s exile is death.
modern: So to be banished from Verona is like being banished from the world, and being banished from the world is death.

origin: Calling death “banishment,” Thou cutt’st my head off with a golden ax And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.
modern: Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I’m being murdered.

origin: O deadly sin!
modern: Oh, deadly sin!

origin: O rude unthankfulness!
modern: Oh, rude and unthankful boy!

origin: Tis torture and not mercy.
modern: It’s torture, not mercy.

origin: More validity, More honorable state, more courtship lives In carrion flies than Romeo.
modern: Flies are healthier and more honorable and better suited for romance than Romeo.

origin: Flies may do this, but I from this must fly.
modern: Flies can kiss her, but I must flee the city.

origin: They are free men, but I am banishèd.
modern: Flies are like free men, but I have been banished.

origin: And sayst thou yet that exile is not death?
modern: And yet you say that exile is not death?

origin: Hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharp-ground knife, No sudden mean of death, though ne'er so mean, But “banishèd” to kill me?—“Banishèd”!
modern: Did you have no poison, no sharp knife, no weapon you could use to kill me quickly, nothing so disgraceful, except banishment?

origin: O Friar, the damnèd use that word in hell.
modern: Oh Friar, damned souls use the word banishment to describe hell.

origin: Howling attends it.
modern: They howl about banishment.

origin: How hast thou the heart, Being a divine, a ghostly confessor, A sin-absolver, and my friend professed, To mangle me with that word “banishèd”?
modern: If you’re a member of a divine spiritual order of men who forgive sins, and you say you’re my friend, how do you have the heart to mangle me with the word banishment?

origin: Thou fond mad man, hear me a little speak.
modern: You foolish madman, listen to me for a moment.

origin: Here were the servants of your adversary, And yours, close fighting ere I did approach.
modern: Your servants were fighting your enemy’s servants before I got here.

origin: I drew to part them.
modern: I drew my sword to part them.

origin: While we were interchanging thrusts and blows, Came more and more and fought on part and part, Till the Prince came, who parted either part.
modern: As we were trading blows, more and more people showed up to join the fight, until the Prince came and broke everyone up.

origin: Oh, where is Romeo?
modern: Oh, where’s Romeo?

origin: Saw you him today?
modern: Have you seen him today?

origin: Right glad I am he was not at this fray.
modern: I’m glad he wasn’t here for this fight.

origin: Towards him I made, but he was 'ware of me And stole into the covert of the wood.
modern: I headed toward him, but he saw me coming and hid in the woods.

origin: Many a morning hath he there been seen, With tears augmenting the fresh morning’s dew, Adding to clouds more clouds with his deep sighs.
modern: He’s been seen there many mornings, crying tears that add drops to the morning dew and making a cloudy day cloudier with his sighs.

origin: But all so soon as the all-cheering sun Should in the farthest east begin to draw The shady curtains from Aurora’s bed, Away from light steals home my heavy son,
modern: But as soon as the sun rises in the east, my sad son comes home to escape the light.

origin: Oh, thou wilt speak again of banishment.
modern: Oh, you’re just going to talk about banishment again.

origin: Talk no more.
modern: Don’t say anything else.

origin: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
modern: Oh, so madmen like you are also deaf.

origin: How should they, when that wise men have no eyes?
modern: How should madmen hear, if wise men can’t even see?

origin: Let me dispute with thee of thy estate.
modern: Let me talk to you about your situation.

origin: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel.
modern: You can’t talk about something that you don’t feel.

origin: Wert thou as young as I, Juliet thy love, An hour but married, Tybalt murderèd, Doting like me, and like me banishèd, Then mightst thou speak, then mightst thou tear thy hair And fall upon the ground, as I do now, Taking the measure of an unmade grave.
modern: If you were as young as I am, if you were in love with Juliet, if you had just married her an hour ago, if then you murdered Tybalt, if you were lovesick like me, and if you were banished, then you might talk about it.

origin: Arise.
modern: Get up.

origin: One knocks.
modern: Somebody’s knocking.

origin: Good Romeo, hide thyself.
modern: Hide yourself, good Romeo.

origin: Not I, unless the breath of heartsick groans, Mistlike, infold me from the search of eyes.
modern: I won’t hide unless all the mist from my heartsick groans envelopes me like fog and conceals me from people’s searching eyes.

origin: Who knocks so hard?
modern: Why are you knocking so hard?

origin: Whence come you?
modern: Where do you come from?

origin: What’s your will?
modern: What do you want?

origin: O holy Friar, O, tell me, holy Friar, Where is my lady’s lord?
modern: Oh, holy Friar, Oh, tell me, holy Friar, where is my lady’s husband?

origin: Where’s Romeo?
modern: Where’s Romeo?

origin: Oh, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case.
modern: Oh, he’s acting just like Juliet, just like her.

origin: O woeful sympathy, Piteous predicament!
modern: Oh painful sympathy!

origin: Even so lies she, Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.
modern: She’s lying on the ground just like him, blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering.

origin: Stand, an you be a man.
modern: Stand up if you’re really a man.

origin: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand.
modern: For Juliet’s sake, for her sake, rise and stand up.

origin: Why should you fall into so deep an O?
modern: Why should you fall into so deep a moan?

origin: Nurse!
modern: Nurse!

origin: Ah sir, ah sir.
modern: Ah sir, ah sir.

origin: Death’s the end of all.
modern: Well, death is the end for everybody.

origin: Spakest thou of Juliet?
modern: Were you talking about Juliet?

origin: How is it with her?
modern: How is she?

origin: Where is she?
modern: Where is she?

origin: And how doth she?
modern: How is she doing?

origin: And what says My concealed lady to our canceled love?
modern: What does my hidden wife say about our ruined love?

origin: As if that name, Shot from the deadly level of a gun, Did murder her, as that name’s cursed hand Murdered her kinsman.
modern: She’s calling out my name as if I were a bullet murdering her, just like I murdered her relative.

origin: O, tell me, Friar, tell me, In what vile part of this anatomy Doth my name lodge?
modern: Tell me, Friar, in what part of my body is my name embedded?

origin: Tell me, that I may sack The hateful mansion.
modern: Tell me, so I can cut it out of myself.

origin: Art thou a man?
modern: Are you a man?

origin: Thy wild acts denote The unreasonable fury of a beast.
modern: Your wild actions resemble the irrational fury of a beast.

origin: Thou hast amazed me.
modern: You have amazed me.

origin: By my holy order, I thought thy disposition better tempered.
modern: I swear by my holy order, I thought you were smarter and more rational than this.

origin: Hast thou slain Tybalt?
modern: Have you killed Tybalt?

origin: Why rail’st thou on thy birth, the heaven, and earth?
modern: Why do you complain about your birth, the heavens, and the earth?

origin: Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit, Which, like a usurer, abound’st in all And usest none in that true use indeed Which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit.
modern: You have so much natural talent, but like someone who hoards money, you use none of your talent for the right purpose—not your body, not your love, not your mind.

origin: What, rouse thee, man!
modern: Get up, man!

origin: Thy Juliet is alive, For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead— There art thou happy.
modern: Your Juliet is alive.

origin: Tybalt would kill thee, But thou slew’st Tybalt—there art thou happy.
modern: Tybalt wanted to kill you, but you killed Tybalt.

origin: The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
modern: Be happy that you’re alive.

origin: A pack of blessings light upon thy back, Happiness courts thee in her best array,
modern: You have the best sorts of happiness to enjoy.

origin: But, like a misbehaved and sullen wench, Thou pout’st upon thy fortune and thy love.
modern: But like a misbehaved, sullen girl, you’re whining about your bad luck and your love.

origin: Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed.
modern: Go be with your love, as it was decided at your wedding.

origin: Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.
modern: Climb up to her bedroom and comfort her.

origin: Commend me to thy lady, And bid her hasten all the house to bed, Which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.
modern: Give my regards to your lady, and tell her to hurry everybody in the house to bed.

origin: Romeo is coming.
modern: Romeo is coming.

origin: O Lord, I could have stayed here all the night To hear good counsel.
modern: O Lord, I could stay here all night listening to such good advice.

origin: Oh, what learning is!
modern: Educated men are so impressive!

origin: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
modern: Do so, and tell my sweet to be ready to scold me.

origin: Here, sir, a ring she bid me give you, sir.
modern: Here, sir, this is a ring she asked me to give you.

origin: Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.
modern: Hurry up, it’s getting late.

origin: How well my comfort is revived by this!
modern: This makes me feel so much better!

origin: Go hence.
modern: Now get out of here.

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night.

origin: And here stands all your state: Either be gone before the watch be set, Or by the break of day disguised from hence.
modern: Everything depends on this: either be out of here before the night watchmen take their positions, or leave in disguise after daybreak.

origin: Sojourn in Mantua.
modern: Take a little vacation in Mantua.

origin: I’ll find out your man, And he shall signify from time to time Every good hap to you that chances here.
modern: I’ll find your servant, and he’ll update you now and then on your case as it stands here.

origin: Give me thy hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: Tis late.
modern: It’s late.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Farewell.

origin: Things have fall'n out, sir, so unluckily, That we have had no time to move our daughter.
modern: Things have turned out so unluckily, sir, that we haven’t had time to convince our daughter to marry you.

origin: Look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly, And so did I.
modern: Listen, she loved her cousin Tybalt dearly, and so did I.

origin: Well, we were born to die.
modern: Well, we were all born to die.

origin: These times of woe afford no time to woo.
modern: These times of pain are bad times for romance.

origin: Madam, good night.
modern: Madam, good night.

origin: Commend me to your daughter.
modern: Give my regards to your daughter.

origin: I will, and know her mind early tomorrow.
modern: I will.

origin: Tonight she is mewed up to her heaviness.
modern: Tonight she is shut up in her room, alone with her sadness.

origin: Sir Paris, I will make a desperate tender Of my child’s love.
modern: Sir Paris, I’ll make a desperate argument for my child’s love.

origin: Acquaint her here of my son Paris' love, And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next— But, soft!
modern: Tell her about my son Paris’s love for her.

origin: What day is this?
modern: And tell her, listen to me, on Wednesday—Wait—What day is today?

origin: Monday, my lord.
modern: Monday, my lord.

origin: Monday!
modern: Monday!

origin: Ha, ha.
modern: Ha, ha!

origin: Do you like this haste?
modern: Do you think it’s a good idea to rush?

origin: We’ll keep no great ado, a friend or two.
modern: We shouldn’t have too big a celebration—we can invite a friend or two.

origin: For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late, It may be thought we held him carelessly, Being our kinsman, if we revel much.
modern: Listen, because Tybalt was just killed, people might think that we don’t care about his memory as our relative if we have too grand a party.

origin: Therefore we’ll have some half a dozen friends, And there an end.
modern: Therefore we’ll have about half a dozen friends to the wedding, and that’s it.

origin: But what say you to Thursday?
modern: What do you think about Thursday?

origin: My lord, I would that Thursday were tomorrow.
modern: My lord, I wish Thursday were tomorrow.

origin: Well get you gone.
modern: Well go on home.

origin: O' Thursday be it, then.— Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed.
modern: Thursday it is, then.

origin: Wilt thou be gone?
modern: Are you going?

origin: It is not yet near day.
modern: It’s still a long time until daybreak.

origin: It was the nightingale, and not the lark, That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.
modern: That sound you heard was the  It was the lark, the bird that sings at dawn, not the nightingale.

origin: Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east.
modern: Look, my love, what are those streaks of light in the clouds parting in the east?

origin: Night’s candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops.
modern: Night is over, and day is coming.

origin: Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.
modern: That light is not daylight, I know it.

origin: It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer, And light thee on thy way to Mantua.
modern: It’s some meteor coming out of the sun to light your way to Mantua.

origin: Therefore stay yet.
modern: So stay for a while.

origin: Thou need’st not to be gone.
modern: You don’t have to go yet.

origin: Let me be ta'en.
modern: Let me be captured.

origin: Let me be put to death.
modern: Let me be put to death.

origin: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
modern: I am content, if that’s the way you want it.

origin: I have more care to stay than will to go.
modern: I want to stay more than I want to go.

origin: Come, death, and welcome!
modern: Come, death, and welcome!

origin: Let’s talk.
modern: Let’s talk.

origin: It is not day.
modern: It’s not daylight.

origin: It is, it is.
modern: It is, it is.

origin: It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.
modern: It’s the lark that sings so out of tune, making such harsh noise.

origin: Some say the lark makes sweet division.
modern: Some say the lark makes a sweet division between day and night.

origin: This doth not so, for she divideth us.
modern: It’s not true because she separates us.

origin: More light and light it grows.
modern: More and more light.

origin: More light and light, more dark and dark our woes!
modern: More and more pain for us.

origin: Madam.
modern: Madam.

origin: Nurse?
modern: Nurse?

origin: Your lady mother is coming to your chamber.
modern: Your mother is coming to your bedroom.

origin: The day is broke.
modern: Day has broken.

origin: Then, window, let day in and let life out.
modern: Then the window lets day in, and life goes out the window.

origin: Farewell, farewell.
modern: Farewell, farewell!

origin: One kiss, and I’ll descend.
modern: Give me one kiss, and I’ll go down.

origin: And private in his chamber pens himself, Shuts up his windows, locks fair daylight out, And makes himself an artificial night.
modern: He locks himself up alone in his bedroom, shuts his windows to keep out the beautiful daylight, and makes himself an artificial night.

origin: My noble uncle, do you know the cause?
modern: My noble uncle, do you know why he acts this way?

origin: I neither know it nor can learn of him.
modern: I don’t know, and he won’t tell me.

origin: Have you importuned him by any means?
modern: Have you done everything you could to make him tell you the reason?

origin: I would thou wert so happy by thy stay To hear true shrift.—Come, madam, let’s away.
modern: I hope you’re lucky enough to hear the true story by sticking around.

origin: Art thou gone so, love, lord?
modern: Are you gone like that, my love, my lord?

origin: Oh, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo.
modern: Oh, by this count I’ll be many years older before I see my Romeo again.

origin: Farewell!
modern: Farewell!

origin: I will omit no opportunity That may convey my greetings, love, to thee.
modern: I won’t miss any chance to send my love to you.

origin: Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?
modern: Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?

origin: O God, I have an ill-divining soul.
modern: Oh God, I have a soul that predicts evil things!

origin: Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low As one dead in the bottom of a tomb.
modern: Now that you are down there, you look like someone dead in the bottom of a tomb.

origin: Either my eyesight fails, or thou look’st pale.
modern: Either my eyesight is failing me, or you look pale.

origin: And trust me, love, in my eye so do you.
modern: And trust me, love, you look pale to me too.

origin: Dry sorrow drinks our blood.
modern: Sadness takes away our color.

origin: Adieu, adieu!
modern: Goodbye, Goodbye!

origin: O fortune, fortune!
modern: Oh luck, luck.

origin: All men call thee fickle.
modern: Everyone says you can’t make up your mind.

origin: Be fickle, fortune, For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long, But send him back.
modern: I hope maybe then you’ll send him back home soon.

origin: Who is ’t that calls?
modern: Who’s that calling?

origin: Is it my lady mother?
modern: Is it my mother?

origin: What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?
modern: What strange reason could she have for coming here?

origin: Why, how now, Juliet?
modern: What’s going on, Juliet?

origin: Madam, I am not well.
modern: Madam, I am not well.

origin: Evermore weeping for your cousin’s death?
modern: Will you cry about your cousin’s death forever?

origin: What, wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?
modern: Are you trying to wash him out of his grave with tears?

origin: An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.
modern: If you could, you couldn’t bring him back to life.

origin: Therefore, have done.
modern: So stop crying.

origin: Some grief shows much of love, But much of grief shows still some want of wit.
modern: A little bit of grief shows a lot of love.

origin: Yet let me weep for such a feeling loss.
modern: Let me keep weeping for such a great loss.

origin: So shall you feel the loss, but not the friend Which you weep for.
modern: You will feel the loss, but the man you weep for will feel nothing.

origin: Feeling so the loss, Cannot choose but ever weep the friend.
modern: Feeling the loss like this, I can’t help but weep for him forever.

origin: Well, girl, thou weep’st not so much for his death, As that the villain lives which slaughtered him.
modern: Well, girl, you’re weeping not for his death as much as for the fact that the villain who killed him is still alive.

origin: What villain, madam?
modern: What villain, madam?

origin: That same villain, Romeo.
modern: That villain, Romeo.

origin: That is because the traitor murderer lives.
modern: That’s because the murderer is alive.

origin: Ay, madam, from the reach of these my hands.
modern: Yes, madam, he lies beyond my reach.

origin: Would none but I might venge my cousin’s death!
modern: I wish that no one could avenge my cousin’s death except me!

origin: Then weep no more.
modern: Stop crying.

origin: I’ll send to one in Mantua, Where that same banished runagate doth live, Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram That he shall soon keep Tybalt company.
modern: I’ll send a man to Mantua, where that exiled rogue is living.

origin: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
modern: And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.

origin: Indeed, I never shall be satisfied With Romeo, till I behold him—dead— Is my poor heart for a kinsman vexed.
modern: I’ll never be satisfied with Romeo until I see him .

origin: Madam, if you could find out but a man To bear a poison, I would temper it, That Romeo should, upon receipt thereof, Soon sleep in quiet.
modern: Madam, if you can find a man to deliver the poison, I’ll mix it myself so that Romeo will sleep quietly soon after he drinks it.

origin: To wreak the love I bore my cousin Upon his body that slaughtered him!
modern: I want to take the love I had for my cousin and take it out on the body of the man who killed him.

origin: Find thou the means, and I’ll find such a man.
modern: Find out the way, and I’ll find the right man.

origin: But now I’ll tell thee joyful tidings, girl.
modern: But now I have joyful news for you, girl.

origin: And joy comes well in such a needy time.
modern: And it’s good to have joy in such a joyless time.

origin: What are they, beseech your ladyship?
modern: Please tell me.

origin: Well, well, thou hast a careful father, child.
modern: Well, well, you have a careful father, child.

origin: Madam, in happy time, what day is that?
modern: Madam, tell me quickly, what day is that?

origin: Marry, my child, early next Thursday morn, The gallant, young, and noble gentleman, The County Paris, at Saint Peter’s Church, Shall happily make thee there a joyful bride.
modern: Indeed, my child, at Saint Peter’s Church early Thursday morning, the gallant, young, and noble gentleman Count Paris will happily make you a joyful bride.

origin: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
modern: Now, I swear by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he will not make me a joyful bride there.

origin: I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
modern: How can I marry him, this husband, before he comes to court me?

origin: I pray you, tell my lord and father, madam, I will not marry yet.
modern: Please, tell my father, madam, I won’t marry yet.

origin: And when I do, I swear It shall be Romeo, whom you know I hate, Rather than Paris.
modern: And, when I do marry, I swear, it will be Romeo, whom you know I hate, rather than Paris.

origin: These are news indeed!
modern: That’s really news!

origin: Here comes your father.
modern: Here comes your father.

origin: Tell him so yourself, And see how he will take it at your hands.
modern: Tell him so yourself, and see how he takes the news.

origin: How now?
modern: What are you, girl?

origin: A conduit, girl?
modern: Some kind of fountain?

origin: What, still in tears, Evermore showering?
modern: Why are you still crying?

origin: Have you delivered to her our decree?
modern: Have you told her our decision?

origin: I would the fool were married to her grave!
modern: I wish the fool were dead and married to her grave!

origin: How, will she none?
modern: How can this be?

origin: Is she not proud?
modern: Isn’t she proud of such a match?

origin: Doth she not count her blessed, Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought So worthy a gentleman to be her bride?
modern: Doesn’t she realize how unworthy she is of the gentleman we have found to be her bridegroom?

origin: Not proud you have, but thankful that you have.
modern: But I am thankful that you have found it.

origin: How, how, how, how?
modern: What is this?

origin: Chopped logic!
modern: What is this fuzzy logic?

origin: What is this?
modern: What is this?

origin: Proud,” and “I thank you,” and “I thank you not,” And yet “not proud”?
modern: I hear you say “proud” and “I thank you,” and then “no thank you” and “not proud,” you spoiled little girl.

origin: Out, you green sickness, carrion!
modern: You disgust me, you little bug!

origin: Out, you baggage!
modern: You worthless girl!

origin: You tallow face!
modern: You pale face!

origin: Fie, fie!
modern: Shame on you!

origin: What, are you mad?
modern: What, are you crazy?

origin: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
modern: Good father, I’m begging you on my knees, be patient and listen to me say just one thing.

origin: Speak not.
modern: Don’t say anything.

origin: Reply not.
modern: Don’t reply.

origin: Do not answer me.
modern: Don’t talk back to me.

origin: Out on her, hilding!
modern: She disgusts me, the little hussy!

origin: God in heaven bless her!
modern: God in heaven bless her!

origin: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
modern: My lord, you’re wrong to berate her like that.

origin: And why, my Lady Wisdom?
modern: And why, wise lady?

origin: Smatter with your gossips, go.
modern: Go blabber with your gossiping friends.

origin: I speak no treason.
modern: I’ve said nothing wrong.

origin: Oh, God 'i' good e'en.
modern: Oh, for God’s sake.

origin: May not one speak?
modern: Can’t I say something?

origin: Peace, you mumbling fool!
modern: Be quiet, you mumbling fool!

origin: Utter your gravity o'er a gossip’s bowl, For here we need it not.
modern: We don’t need to hear it.

origin: You are too hot.
modern: You’re getting too angry.

origin: God’s bread!
modern: Goddammit!

origin: It makes me mad.
modern: It makes me mad.

origin: Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play, Alone, in company, still my care hath been To have her matched.
modern: Day and night, hour after hour, all the time, at work, at play, alone, in company, my top priority has always been to find her a husband.

origin: Thursday is near.
modern: Thursday is coming.

origin: Lay hand on heart, advise.
modern: Put your hand on your heart and listen to my advice.

origin: An you be mine, I’ll give you to my friend.
modern: If you act like my daughter, I’ll marry you to my friend.

origin: Trust to ’t, bethink you.
modern: Think about it.

origin: I’ll not be forsworn.
modern: I won’t break this promise.

origin: Delay this marriage for a month, a week.
modern: Delay this marriage for a month, or a week.

origin: Or, if you do not, make the bridal bed In that dim monument where Tybalt lies.
modern: Or, if you don’t delay, make my wedding bed in the tomb where Tybalt lies.

origin: Talk not to me, for I’ll not speak a word.
modern: Don’t talk to me, because I won’t say a word.

origin: Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
modern: Do as you please, because I’m done worrying about you.

origin: O God!—O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?
modern: Oh God!—Oh Nurse, how can this be stopped?

origin: My husband is on earth, my faith in heaven.
modern: My husband is alive on earth, my vows of marriage are in heaven.

origin: How shall that faith return again to earth, Unless that husband send it me from heaven By leaving earth?
modern: How can I bring those promises back down to earth, unless my husband sends them back down to me by dying and going to heaven?

origin: Comfort me.
modern: Give me comfort.

origin: Hast thou not a word of joy?
modern: Don’t you have one word of joy?

origin: Some comfort, Nurse.
modern: Give me some comfort, Nurse.

origin: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.
modern: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman!

origin: Romeo’s a dishclout to him.
modern: Romeo’s a dishcloth compared to him.

origin: An eagle, madam, Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye As Paris hath.
modern: Madam, an eagle does not have eyes as green, as quick, and as fair as the eyes of Paris.

origin: Beshrew my very heart, I think you are happy in this second match, For it excels your first.
modern: Curse my very heart, but I think you should be happy in this second marriage, because it’s better than your first.

origin: Or if it did not, Your first is dead, or ’twere as good he were, As living here and you no use of him.
modern: Even if it’s not better, your first marriage is over.

origin: Speakest thou from thy heart?
modern: Are you speaking from your heart?

origin: Amen!
modern: Amen!

origin: What?
modern: What?

origin: Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much.
modern: Well, you have given me great comfort.

origin: Go in, and tell my lady I am gone, Having displeased my father, to Lawrence’s cell To make confession and to be absolved.
modern: I made my father angry, so I went to Friar Lawrence’s cell to confess and be forgiven.

origin: Marry, I will, and this is wisely done.
modern: Alright, I will.

origin: O most wicked fiend!
modern: Oh, that most wicked fiend!

origin: I’ll to the friar to know his remedy.
modern: I’m going to the Friar to find out his solution.

origin: If all else fail, myself have power to die.
modern: If everything else fails, at least I have the power to take my own life.

origin: On Thursday, sir?
modern: On Thursday, sir?

origin: The time is very short.
modern: That’s very soon.

origin: You say you do not know the lady’s mind.
modern: You say you don’t know what the girl thinks.

origin: I like it not.
modern: I don’t like it.

origin: Now do you know the reason of this haste.
modern: Now you know the reason for the rush.

origin: Look, sir, here comes the lady toward my cell.
modern: Look, sir, here comes the lady walking toward my cell.

origin: Happily met, my lady and my wife.
modern: I’m happy to meet you, my lady and my wife.

origin: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.
modern: That might be the case sir,

origin: Good morrow, cousin.
modern: Good morning, cousin.

origin: Is the day so young?
modern: Is it that early in the day?

origin: But new struck nine.
modern: It’s only just now nine o'clock.

origin: Was that my father that went hence so fast?
modern: Was that my father who left here in such a hurry?

origin: It was.
modern: It was.

origin: Not having that which, having, makes them short.
modern: I don’t have the thing that makes time fly.

origin: In love?
modern: You’re in love?

origin: Out.
modern: Out.

origin: Of love?
modern: Out of love?

origin: Where shall we dine?—O me!
modern: So, where should we eat?

origin: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday next.
modern: That “may be” must be, love, on Thursday.

origin: What must be shall be.
modern: What must be will be.

origin: That’s a certain text.
modern: That is a certain truth.

origin: Come you to make confession to this Father?
modern: Have you come to make confession to this father?

origin: To answer that, I should confess to you.
modern: If I answered that question, I’d be making confession to you.

origin: Do not deny to him that you love me.
modern: Don’t deny to him that you love me.

origin: I will confess to you that I love him.
modern: I’ll confess to you that I love him.

origin: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.
modern: You will also confess, I’m sure, that you love me.

origin: If I do so, it will be of more price Being spoke behind your back than to your face.
modern: If I do so, it will mean more if I say it behind your back than if I say it to your face.

origin: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.
modern: You poor soul, your face has suffered many tears.

origin: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.
modern: Your face is mine, and you have slandered it.

origin: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.— My lord, we must entreat the time alone.
modern: I have time for you now, my sad daughter.

origin: God shield I should disturb devotion!— Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye.
modern: God forbid that I should prevent sacred devotion!

origin: O Juliet, I already know thy grief.
modern: Oh, Juliet, I already know about your sad situation.

origin: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it, On Thursday next be married to this county.
modern: I hear that you must marry this count on Thursday, and that nothing can delay it.

origin: Tell me not, Friar, that thou hear’st of this, Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it.
modern: Don’t tell me that you’ve heard about this marriage, Friar, unless you can tell me how to prevent it.

origin: If in thy wisdom thou canst give no help, Do thou but call my resolution wise, And with this knife I’ll help it presently.
modern: If you who are so wise can’t help, please be kind enough to call my solution wise.

origin: Hold, then.
modern: Hold on, then.

origin: Wednesday is tomorrow.
modern: Tomorrow is Wednesday.

origin: Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone.
modern: Tomorrow night make sure that you are alone.

origin: Let not the Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.
modern: Don’t let the Nurse stay with you in your bedroom.

origin: No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest.
modern: Give me the vial.

origin: Give me, give me!
modern: Give it to me!

origin: Love give me strength, and strength shall help afford.
modern: Love will give me strength, and strength will help me accomplish this plan.

origin: Farewell, dear Father.
modern: Goodbye, dear Father.

origin: You shall have none ill, sir, for I’ll try if they can lick their fingers.
modern: You won’t get any bad cooks from me.

origin: How canst thou try them so?
modern: How can you test them like that?

origin: Therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.
modern: So the cooks who can’t lick their fingers aren’t hired.

origin: Go, be gone.
modern: Go, get out of here.

origin: We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
modern: We’re unprepared for this wedding celebration.

origin: Ay, forsooth.
modern: Yes, that’s true.

origin: See where she comes from shrift with merry look.
modern: Look, she’s come home from confession with a happy look on her face.

origin: Where I have learned me to repent the sin Of disobedient opposition To you and your behests, and am enjoined By holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here To beg your pardon.
modern: Holy Father Lawrence instructed me to fall on my knees and beg your forgiveness.

origin: Send for the county.
modern: Send for the Count.

origin: Go tell him of this.
modern: Go tell him about this.

origin: I’ll have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.
modern: I’ll make this wedding happen tomorrow morning.

origin: I met the youthful lord at Lawrence' cell, And gave him what becomèd love I might, Not stepping o'er the bounds of modesty.
modern: I met the young man at Lawrence’s cell.

origin: Why, I am glad on ’t.
modern: Well, I’m glad about this.

origin: This is well.
modern: This is good.

origin: Stand up.
modern: Stand up.

origin: Ay, marry, go, I say, and fetch him hither.— Now, afore God, this reverend holy friar!
modern: Yes, alright, go, I say, and bring him here.

origin: Our whole city is much bound to him.
modern: Now, before God, our whole city owes this friar a great debt.

origin: Nurse, will you go with me into my closet To help me sort such needful ornaments As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?
modern: Nurse, will you come with me to my closet and help me pick out the clothes and the jewelry I’ll need to wear tomorrow?

origin: No, not till Thursday.
modern: No, not until Thursday.

origin: There is time enough.
modern: There’s plenty of time.

origin: We’ll to church tomorrow.
modern: We’ll have the wedding at the church tomorrow.

origin: Tis now near night.
modern: It’s already almost night.

origin: Tush, I will stir about, And all things shall be well, I warrant thee, wife.
modern: And everything will be alright, I promise you, wife.

origin: Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her.
modern: You should go to Juliet and dress her up.

origin: I’ll not to bed tonight.
modern: I’m not going to bed tonight.

origin: Let me alone.
modern: Leave me alone.

origin: I’ll play the housewife for this once.
modern: I’ll pretend to be the housewife for once.

origin: Ay, those attires are best.
modern: Yes, those are the best clothes.

origin: What, are you busy, ho?
modern: What, are you busy?

origin: Need you my help?
modern: Do you need my help?

origin: For, I am sure, you have your hands full all In this so sudden business.
modern: I’m sure you have your hands full preparing for the sudden festivities.

origin: Good night.
modern: Good night.

origin: Farewell!—God knows when we shall meet again.
modern: Only God knows when we’ll meet again.

origin: My dismal scene I needs must act alone.
modern: In my desperate situation, I have to act alone.

origin: Come, vial.
modern: Alright, here’s the vial.

origin: What if this mixture do not work at all?
modern: What if this mixture doesn’t work at all?

origin: Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?
modern: Will I be married tomorrow morning?

origin: Lie thou there.
modern: Lie down right there.

origin: Oh, look!
modern: Oh, look!

origin: Methinks I see my cousin’s ghost Seeking out Romeo, that did spit his body Upon a rapier’s point.
modern: I think I see my cousin Tybalt’s ghost.

origin: Stay, Tybalt, stay!
modern: Wait, Tybalt, wait!

origin: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!
modern: Romeo, Romeo, Romeo!

origin: Here’s drink.
modern: Here’s a drink.

origin: I drink to thee.
modern: I drink to you.

origin: No, coz, I rather weep.
modern: No, cousin, I’m crying.

origin: Good heart, at what?
modern: Good man, why are you crying?

origin: Why, such is love’s transgression.
modern: Yes, this is what love does.

origin: What is it else?
modern: What else is love?

origin: A madness most discreet, A choking gall, and a preserving sweet.
modern: It’s a sweet lozenge that you choke on.

origin: Farewell, my coz.
modern: Goodbye, cousin.

origin: Soft!
modern: Wait.

origin: I will go along.
modern: I’ll come with you.

origin: And if you leave me so, you do me wrong.
modern: If you leave me like this, you’re doing me wrong.

origin: Tut, I have lost myself.
modern: I’m not myself.

origin: I am not here.
modern: I’m not here.

origin: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.
modern: Tell me seriously, who is the one you love?

origin: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
modern: You mean I should groan and tell you?

origin: Groan!
modern: Groan?

origin: Why, no.
modern: No.

origin: But sadly, tell me who.
modern: But tell me seriously who it is.

origin: Hold, take these keys, and fetch more spices, Nurse.
modern: Take these keys and get more spices, Nurse.

origin: They call for dates and quinces in the pastry.
modern: They’re calling for dates and quinces in the pastry kitchen.

origin: Come, stir, stir, stir!
modern: Come on, wake up, wake up, wake up!

origin: The second cock hath crowed.
modern: The second cock crowed.

origin: The curfew bell hath rung.
modern: The curfew-bell rang.

origin: Spare not for the cost.
modern: Don’t worry about the cost.

origin: Go, you cot-quean, go.
modern: Go, you old housewife, go.

origin: Get you to bed, faith.
modern: Go to bed, dear.

origin: You’ll be sick tomorrow For this night’s watching.
modern: You’ll be sick tomorrow because you’ve stayed up all night.

origin: I have watched ere now All night for lesser cause, and ne'er been sick.
modern: I’ve stayed up all night many times before for less important matters, and I’ve never gotten sick.

origin: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time, But I will watch you from such watching now.
modern: Yes, you’ve been a ladies' man in your time.

origin: A jealous hood, a jealous hood!
modern: A jealous woman, a jealous woman!

origin: Now, fellow, What is there?
modern: Now, fellow, what have you got there?

origin: Make haste, make haste, sirrah.
modern: Hurry up, hurry up.

origin: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.
modern: I’m smart enough to find the logs myself without bothering Peter.

origin: Mass, and well said.
modern: Right, and well said.

origin: A merry whoreson, ha!
modern: That guy’s funny.

origin: Thou shalt be loggerhead.—Good faith, ’tis day.
modern: Goodness, it’s daylight.

origin: Wife!
modern: Wife!

origin: What, ho?
modern: What?

origin: What, Nurse, I say!
modern: Hey, Nurse!

origin: Go waken Juliet.
modern: Go wake Juliet.

origin: Go and trim her up.
modern: Go and get her dressed.

origin: I’ll go and chat with Paris.
modern: I’ll go and chat with Paris.

origin: Hie, make haste, Make haste.
modern: Hey, hurry up, hurry up!

origin: The bridegroom he is come already.
modern: The bridegroom is already here.

origin: Make haste, I say.
modern: Hurry up, I say.

origin: Mistress!
modern: Mistress!

origin: What, mistress!
modern: Hey, mistress!

origin: Juliet!—Fast, I warrant her, she.— Why, lamb!
modern: I bet she’s fast asleep.

origin: Why, lady!
modern: Hey, lady!

origin: Why, love, I say.
modern: Hey, love, I say!

origin: Madam!
modern: Madam!

origin: Sweet-heart!
modern: Sweetheart!

origin: Why, bride!
modern: Hey, bride!

origin: What, not a word?
modern: What, you don’t say a word?

origin: You take your pennyworths now.
modern: You take your beauty sleep now.

origin: How sound is she asleep!
modern: How sound asleep she is!

origin: Ay, let the county take you in your bed.
modern: Yes, let the count take you in your bed.

origin: He’ll fright you up, i' faith.
modern: He’ll wake you up, I bet.

origin: Will it not be?
modern: Won’t he?

origin: What noise is here?
modern: What’s all the noise in here?

origin: O lamentable day!
modern: Oh, sad day!

origin: What is the matter?
modern: What is the matter?

origin: Look, look.
modern: Look, look!

origin: O heavy day!
modern: Oh, what a sad day!

origin: O me, O me!
modern: Oh my, Oh my!

origin: My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!— Help, help!
modern: My child, my reason for living, wake up, look up, or I’ll die with you!

origin: For shame, bring Juliet forth.
modern: For shame, bring Juliet out here.

origin: Her lord is come.
modern: Her bridegroom is here.

origin: She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead.
modern: She’s dead, deceased, she’s dead.

origin: Alack the day!
modern: Curse the day!

origin: Alack the day.
modern: Curse the day!

origin: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!
modern: She’s dead, she’s dead, she’s dead!

origin: Ha?
modern: No!

origin: Let me see her.
modern: Let me see her.

origin: Out, alas!
modern: Oh no!

origin: She’s cold.
modern: She’s cold.

origin: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.
modern: Her blood has stopped, and her joints are stiff.

origin: Life and these lips have long been separated.
modern: She’s been dead for some time.

origin: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
modern: She’s dead, like a beautiful flower, killed by an unseasonable frost.

origin: O lamentable day!
modern: Oh, sad day!

origin: O woeful time.
modern: Oh, this is a painful time!

origin: Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.
modern: Death, which has taken her away to make me cry, now ties up my tongue and won’t let me speak.

origin: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
modern: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

origin: Ready to go, but never to return.
modern: She’s ready to go, but she’ll never return.

origin: Death is my son-in-law.
modern: Death is my son-in-law.

origin: Death is my heir.
modern: Death is my heir.

origin: My daughter he hath wedded.
modern: My daughter married death.

origin: I will die, And leave him all.
modern: I will die and leave Death everything.

origin: Life, living, all is Death’s.
modern: Life, wealth, everything belongs to Death.

origin: Have I thought long to see this morning’s face, And doth it give me such a sight as this?
modern: Have I waited so long to see this morning, only to see this?

origin: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!
modern: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!

origin: Most miserable hour that e'er time saw In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.
modern: This is the most miserable hour of all time!

origin: But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!
modern: I had only one child, one poor child, one poor and loving child, the one thing I had to rejoice and comfort myself, and cruel Death has stolen it from me!

origin: O woe!
modern: Oh pain!

origin: O woeful, woeful, woeful day!
modern: Oh painful, painful, painful day!

origin: Never was seen so black a day as this.
modern: There has never been so black a day as today.

origin: O woeful day, O woeful day!
modern: Oh painful day, Oh painful day!

origin: Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!
modern: She was tricked, divorced, wronged, spited, killed!

origin: Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled, By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!
modern: Cruel, cruel Death killed her.

origin: O love!
modern: Oh love!

origin: O life!
modern: Oh life!

origin: Not life, but love in death.
modern: There is no life, but my love is dead!

origin: Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!
modern: Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed!

origin: Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity?
modern: Why did this have to happen now?

origin: My soul, and not my child!
modern: My soul and not my child!

origin: Dead art thou!
modern: You are dead!

origin: Peace, ho, for shame!
modern: Be quiet, for shame!

origin: Confusion’s cure lives not In these confusions.
modern: The cure for confusion is not yelling and screaming.

origin: Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid.
modern: You had this child with the help of heaven.

origin: Now heaven hath all,
modern: Now heaven has her.

origin: And all the better is it for the maid.
modern: She is in a better place.

origin: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.
modern: You could not prevent her from dying someday, but heaven will give her eternal life.

origin: The most you sought was her promotion, For ’twas your heaven she should be advanced.
modern: The most you hope for was for her to marry wealthy and rise up the social ladder—that was your idea of heaven.

origin: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?
modern: And now you cry, even though she has risen up above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?

origin: Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill That you run mad, seeing that she is well.
modern: Oh, in this love, you love your child so badly, that you go mad, even though she is in heaven.

origin: She’s not well married that lives married long, But she’s best married that dies married young.
modern: It is best to marry well and die young, better than to be married for a long time.

origin: Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.
modern: Our wedding banquet will become a sad burial feast.

origin: Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.
modern: Our celebratory hymns will change to sad funeral marches.

origin: Every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave.
modern: Everyone prepare to take this beautiful corpse to her grave.

origin: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill. Move them no more by crossing their high will.
modern: Don’t disturb the heavens any more by trying to go against heaven’s will.

origin: Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.
modern: Well, we can put away our pipes and go home.

origin: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
modern: Yes, well, things could get better.

origin: Not a dump, we.
modern: No, not a sad song.

origin: Tis no time to play now.
modern: It’s not the right time to play.

origin: You will not then?
modern: You won’t, then?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: I will then give it you soundly.
modern: Then I’ll really give it to you.

origin: What will you give us?
modern: What will you give us?

origin: No money, on my faith, but the gleek.
modern: No money, I swear.

origin: I will give you the minstrel.
modern: I’ll call you a minstrel.

origin: Then I will give you the serving creature.
modern: Then I’ll call you a serving-creature.

origin: Then will I lay the serving creature’s dagger on your pate.
modern: Then I’ll smack you on the head with the serving-creature’s knife.

origin: I will carry no crotchets.
modern: I’ll make you sing.

origin: Then have at you with my wit.
modern: Do you hear me?

origin: Answer me like men.
modern: Answer me like men.

origin: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
modern: Well, sir, because silver has a sweet sound.

origin: Prates too.—What say you, James Soundpost?
modern: Another studpid answer!

origin: Faith, I know not what to say.
modern: What do you say, James  Well, I don’t know what to say.

origin: I will say for you.
modern: I’ll answer for you.

origin: It is “music with her silver sound” because musicians have no gold for sounding.
