modern: It is “music with her silver sound,” because musicians have no gold to use to make sounds.

origin: What a pestilent knave is this same!
modern: What an annoying man, this guy is!

origin: Hang him, Jack!
modern: Forget about him, Jack!

origin: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep, My dreams presage some joyful news at hand.
modern: If I can trust my dreams, then some joyful news is coming soon.

origin: Ah me!
modern: Oh my!

origin: How sweet is love itself possessed When but love’s shadows are so rich in joy!
modern: How sweet it would be to actually have the woman I love, when merely thinking about love makes me so happy.

origin: News from Verona!—How now, Balthasar?
modern: Do you have news from Verona!—What is it, Balthasar?

origin: Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
modern: Do you bring me a letter from the friar?

origin: How doth my lady?
modern: How is my wife?

origin: Is my father well?
modern: Is my father well?

origin: How fares my Juliet?
modern: How is my Juliet?

origin: That I ask again, For nothing can be ill if she be well.
modern: I ask that again because nothing can be wrong if she is well.

origin: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
modern: Then she is well, and nothing is wrong.

origin: Her body sleeps in Capels' monument, And her immortal part with angels lives.
modern: Her body sleeps in the Capulet tomb, and her immortal soul lives with the angels in heaven.

origin: I saw her laid low in her kindred’s vault And presently took post to tell it you.
modern: I saw her buried in her family’s tomb, and then I came here to tell you the news.

origin: O, pardon me for bringing these ill news, Since you did leave it for my office, sir.
modern: Oh, pardon me for bringing this bad news, but you told me it was my job, sir.

origin: A sick man in sadness makes his will, A word ill urged to one that is so ill.
modern: You wouldn’t tell a sick man he “seriously” has to make his will—it would just make him worse.

origin: In sadness, cousin, I do love a woman.
modern: Seriously, cousin, I love a woman.

origin: A right good markman!
modern: Then you were right on target.

origin: And she’s fair I love.
modern: The woman I love is beautiful.

origin: A right fair mark, fair coz, is soonest hit.
modern: A beautiful target is the one that gets hit the fastest.

origin: Well, in that hit you miss.
modern: Well, you’re not on target there.

origin: She hath, and in that sparing makes huge waste, For beauty, starved with her severity, Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
modern: Yes she has, and by keeping celibate, she wastes her beauty.

origin: She is too fair, too wise, wisely too fair, To merit bliss by making me despair.
modern: She’s too beautiful and too wise to deserve heaven’s blessing by making me despair.

origin: Be ruled by me.
modern: Take my advice.

origin: Forget to think of her.
modern: Don’t think about her.

origin: O, teach me how I should forget to think!
modern: Teach me to forget to think!

origin: Is it e'en so?
modern: Is it really true?

origin: Then I defy you, stars!
modern: Then I rebel against you, stars!

origin: Thou know’st my lodging.
modern: You know where I live.

origin: Get me ink and paper, And hire post horses.
modern: Get me some ink and paper, and hire some horses to ride.

origin: I will hence tonight.
modern: I will leave here for Verona tonight.

origin: I do beseech you, sir, have patience.
modern: Please, sir, have patience.

origin: Your looks are pale and wild, and do import Some misadventure.
modern: You look pale and wild as if you’re going to hurt yourself.

origin: Tush, thou art deceived.
modern: Tsk, you’re wrong.

origin: Leave me and do the thing I bid thee do.
modern: Leave me and do what I told you to do.

origin: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
modern: Don’t you have a letter for me from the friar?

origin: No, my good lord.
modern: No, my good lord.

origin: No matter.
modern: No matter.

origin: Get thee gone, And hire those horses.
modern: Get on your way and hire those horses.

origin: I’ll be with thee straight.
modern: I’ll be with you right away.

origin: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee tonight.
modern: Well, Juliet, I’ll lie with you tonight.

origin: Let’s see for means.
modern: Let’s see how.

origin: O mischief, thou art swift To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
modern: Destructive thoughts come quickly to the minds of desperate men!

origin: As I remember, this should be the house.
modern: As I remember, this should be the house.

origin: Being holiday, the beggar’s shop is shut.
modern: Today’s a holiday, so the beggar’s shop is shut.

origin: What, ho!
modern: Hey!

origin: Apothecary!
modern: Pharmacist!

origin: Who calls so loud?
modern: Who’s that calling so loud?

origin: Come hither, man.
modern: Come here, man.

origin: I see that thou art poor.
modern: I see that you are poor.

origin: Hold, there is forty ducats.
modern: Here are forty ducats.

origin: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness, And fear’st to die?
modern: You’re this poor and wretched and still afraid to die?

origin: Famine is in thy cheeks.
modern: Your cheeks are thin because of hunger.

origin: Need and oppression starveth in thine eyes.
modern: I can see in your eyes that you’re starving.

origin: The world is not thy friend nor the world’s law.
modern: The world is not your friend, and neither is the law.

origin: The world affords no law to make thee rich.
modern: The world doesn’t make laws to make you rich.

origin: Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.— Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.
modern: I pay you because you’re poor, not because you want me to buy this.

origin: Holy Franciscan Friar!
modern: Holy Franciscan Friar!

origin: Brother, ho!
modern: Brother, hey!

origin: This same should be the voice of Friar John.
modern: That sounds like the voice of Friar John.

origin: Welcome from Mantua.
modern: Welcome back from Mantua.

origin: What says Romeo?
modern: What does Romeo say?

origin: Or, if his mind be writ, give me his letter.
modern: Or, if he wrote down his thoughts, give me his letter.

origin: So that my speed to Mantua there was stayed.
modern: I couldn’t go to Mantua because I was stuck there.

origin: Who bare my letter, then, to Romeo?
modern: Then who took my letter to Romeo?

origin: Unhappy fortune!
modern: Unhappy fortune!

origin: Brother, I’ll go and bring it thee.
modern: Brother, I’ll go and bring it to you.

origin: Now must I to the monument alone.
modern: Now I must go to the tomb alone.

origin: Within this three hours will fair Juliet wake.
modern: Within three hours Juliet will wake up.

origin: But I will write again to Mantua, And keep her at my cell till Romeo come.
modern: But I’ll write again to Mantua, and I’ll keep her in my cell until Romeo comes.

origin: Poor living corse, closed in a dead man’s tomb!
modern: She’s shut inside a dead man’s tomb!

origin: Give me thy torch, boy.
modern: Give me your torch, boy.

origin: Hence, and stand aloof.
modern: Go away and stay apart from me.

origin: Yet put it out, for I would not be seen.
modern: Put the torch out, so I can’t be seen.

origin: Give me those flowers.
modern: Give me those flowers.

origin: Do as I bid thee, go.
modern: Do as I tell you.

origin: Yet I will adventure.
modern: Go.

origin: The boy gives warning something doth approach.
modern: The boy is warning me that someone approaches.

origin: What cursèd foot wanders this way tonight To cross my obsequies and true love’s rite?
modern: Who’s ruining my rituals of true love?

origin: What with a torch!
modern: It’s someone with a torch!

origin: Muffle me, night, awhile.
modern: I must hide in the darkness for awhile.

origin: Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.
modern: Give me that pickax and the crowbar.

origin: I will be gone, sir, and not trouble you.
modern: I’ll go, sir, and I won’t bother you.

origin: So shalt thou show me friendship.
modern: That’s the way to show me friendship.

origin: Take thou that.
modern: Take this.

origin: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.
modern: Good and noble young man, don’t mess with someone who’s desperate.

origin: Fly hence and leave me.
modern: Get away from here and leave me.

origin: Think upon these gone.
modern: Think about the ones who have died.

origin: Let them affright thee.
modern: Let them put fear in your heart.

origin: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.
modern: Please, young man, don’t make me angry.

origin: O, be gone!
modern: Oh, go away!

origin: Stay not, be gone.
modern: Don’t stay here, go away.

origin: Live, and hereafter say A madman’s mercy bid thee run away.
modern: Live, and from now on, say a madman mercifully told you to run away.

origin: I do defy thy commination And apprehend thee for a felon here.
modern: I’m arresting you as a criminal.

origin: Wilt thou provoke me?
modern: Are you going to provoke me?

origin: Then have at thee, boy!
modern: Alright, let’s fight, boy!

origin: O Lord, they fight!
modern: Oh Lord, they’re fighting!

origin: I will go call the watch.
modern: I’ll go call the watch.

origin: Open the tomb.
modern: Alright, I will.

origin: Mercutio’s kinsman, noble County Paris.
modern: It’s Mercutio’s relative, noble Count Paris!

origin: What said my man, when my betossèd soul Did not attend him as we rode?
modern: What did my man say?

origin: I think He told me Paris should have married Juliet.
modern: I think he told me Paris was about to marry Juliet.

origin: Said he not so?
modern: Isn’t that what he said?

origin: Or did I dream it so?
modern: Or was I dreaming?

origin: I’ll bury thee in a triumphant grave.
modern: I’ll bury you in a magnificent grave.

origin: A grave?
modern: A grave?

origin: Oh, no.
modern: Oh no!

origin: A lantern, slaughtered youth, For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes This vault a feasting presence full of light.
modern: Juliet lies here, and her beauty fills this tomb with light.

origin: Death, that hath sucked the honey of thy breath, Hath had no power yet upon thy beauty.
modern: Death has sucked the honey from your breath, but it has not yet ruined your beauty.

origin: Thou art not conquered.
modern: You haven’t been conquered.

origin: O, what more favor can I do to thee, Than with that hand that cut thy youth in twain To sunder his that was thine enemy?
modern: Oh, what better favor can I do for you than to kill the man who killed you with the same hand that made you die young.

origin: Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous, And that the lean abhorrèd monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour?
modern: Should I believe that death is in love with you, and that the awful monster keeps you here to be his mistress?

origin: Here, here will I remain With worms that are thy chamber maids.
modern: Here, here I’ll remain with worms that are your chamber-maids.

origin: Oh, here Will I set up my everlasting rest, And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars From this world-wearied flesh.
modern: Oh, I’ll rest here forever.

origin: Eyes, look your last.
modern: Eyes, look out for the last time!

origin: Arms, take your last embrace.
modern: Arms, make your last embrace!

origin: Thy drugs are quick.
modern: His drugs work quickly.

origin: Thus with a kiss I die.
modern: So I die with a kiss.

origin: These happy masks that kiss fair ladies' brows, Being black, puts us in mind they hide the fair.
modern: Look at other beautiful girls.

origin: Saint Francis be my speed!
modern: Saint Francis, help me!

origin: How oft tonight Have my old feet stumbled at graves!—Who’s there?
modern: How often tonight have my old feet stumbled on gravestones!

origin: Here’s one, a friend, and one that knows you well.
modern: I’m a friend, a friend who knows you well.

origin: Bliss be upon you!
modern: God bless you!

origin: Tell me, good my friend, What torch is yond that vainly lends his light To grubs and eyeless skulls?
modern: Tell me, my good friend, what is that light over there?

origin: As I discern, It burneth in the Capels' monument.
modern: It looks to me like it’s burning in the Capulet tomb.

origin: Who is it?
modern: Who is it?

origin: Romeo.
modern: Romeo.

origin: How long hath he been there?
modern: How long has he been there?

origin: Full half an hour.
modern: For a full half hour.

origin: Go with me to the vault.
modern: Go with me to the tomb.

origin: I dare not, sir.
modern: I don’t dare, sir.

origin: Stay, then.
modern: Stay, then.

origin: I’ll go alone.
modern: I’ll go alone.

origin: Fear comes upon me.
modern: I’m suddenly afraid.

origin: Oh, much I fear some ill unthrifty thing.
modern: Oh, I’m very scared something awful has happened.

origin: As I did sleep under this yew tree here, I dreamt my master and another fought, And that my master slew him.
modern: As I slept under this yew-tree here, I had a dream that my master and someone else were fighting and that my master killed him.

origin: Romeo!— Alack, alack, what blood is this, which stains The stony entrance of the sepulcher?
modern: What is this blood that stains the stony entrance of this tomb?

origin: O comfortable Friar!
modern: Oh friendly friar!

origin: Where is my lord?
modern: Where is my husband?

origin: I do remember well where I should be, And there I am.
modern: I remember very well where I should be, and here I am.

origin: Where is my Romeo?
modern: Where is my Romeo?

origin: I hear some noise.
modern: I hear some noise.

origin: Lady, come from that nest Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep.
modern: Lady, come out of the tomb.

origin: A greater power than we can contradict Hath thwarted our intents.
modern: A greater power than we can fight has ruined our plan.

origin: Come, come away.
modern: Come, come away.

origin: Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead, And Paris too.
modern: Your husband lies dead there, and Paris too.

origin: Come, I’ll dispose of thee Among a sisterhood of holy nuns.
modern: Come, I’ll place you among the sisterhood of holy nuns.

origin: A cup, closed in my true love’s hand?
modern: It’s a cup, closed in my true love’s hand?

origin: Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end.— O churl, drunk all, and left no friendly drop To help me after?
modern: Poison, I see, has been the cause of his death.

origin: I will kiss thy lips.
modern: I will kiss your lips.

origin: Haply some poison yet doth hang on them, To make me die with a restorative.
modern: Perhaps there’s still some poison on them, to make me die with a medicinal kiss.

origin: Yea, noise?
modern: Oh, noise?

origin: Then I’ll be brief.
modern: Then I’ll be quick.

origin: O happy dagger, This is thy sheath.
modern: Oh, good, a knife!

origin: There rust and let me die.
modern: Rust inside my body and let me die.

origin: This is the place.
modern: This is the place.

origin: There, where the torch doth burn.
modern: There, where the torch is burning.

origin: The ground is bloody.—Search about the churchyard.
modern: The ground is bloody.

origin: Pitiful sight!
modern: This is a pitiful sight!

origin: Here lies the county slain, And Juliet bleeding, warm and newly dead, Who here hath lain these two days buried.— Go, tell the Prince.
modern: Go, tell the Prince.

origin: Run to the Capulets.
modern: Run to the Capulets.

origin: Raise up the Montagues.
modern: Wake up the Montagues.

origin: Some others search.
modern: Have some others search.

origin: Here’s Romeo’s man.
modern: Here’s Romeo’s man.

origin: We found him in the churchyard.
modern: We found him in the churchyard.

origin: Hold him in safety till the Prince come hither.
modern: Hold him in custody until the Prince gets here.

origin: Here is a friar that trembles, sighs and weeps.
modern: Here is a friar who’s trembling, sighing and weeping.

origin: We took this mattock and this spade from him As he was coming from this churchyard’s side.
modern: We took this pickax and this shovel from him, as he was walking from this side of the graveyard.

origin: A great suspicion.
modern: Very suspicious.

origin: Stay the friar too.
modern: Hold the friar too.

origin: What misadventure is so early up That calls our person from our morning rest?
modern: What crimes happen so early in the morning that I have to wake up before the usual time?

origin: What should it be that is so shrieked abroad?
modern: What’s the problem, that they cry out so loud?

origin: Oh, the people in the street cry “Romeo,” Some “Juliet,” and some “Paris,” and all run With open outcry toward our monument.
modern: Some people in the street are crying “Romeo.” Some are crying “Juliet,” and some are crying “Paris.” They’re all running in an open riot toward our tomb.

origin: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
modern: Investigate how this foul murder came about.

origin: O heavens!
modern: Oh heavens!

origin: O wife, look how our daughter bleeds!
modern: Oh wife, look at how our daughter bleeds!

origin: This dagger hath mista'en—for, lo, his house Is empty on the back of Montague, And it mis-sheathèd in my daughter’s bosom.
modern: That knife should be in its sheath on that Montague’s back, but instead it’s mis-sheathed in my daughter’s breast.

origin: O me!
modern: Oh my!

origin: This sight of death is as a bell, That warns my old age to a sepulcher.
modern: This sight of death is like a bell that warns me I’m old and I’ll die soon.

origin: Alas, my liege, my wife is dead tonight.
modern: Oh, my liege, my wife died tonight.

origin: Grief of my son’s exile hath stopped her breath.
modern: Sadness over my son’s exile stopped her breath.

origin: What further woe conspires against mine age?
modern: What further pain must I endure in my old age?

origin: Look, and thou shalt see.
modern: Look, and you’ll see.

origin: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while, Till we can clear these ambiguities And know their spring, their head, their true descent, And then will I be general of your woes, And lead you even to death.
modern: And then I’ll be the leader of pain, and maybe I’ll lead you as far as death.

origin: Meantime forbear, And let mischance be slave to patience.— Bring forth the parties of suspicion.
modern: In the meantime, hold on, and be patient.

origin: I am the greatest, able to do least, Yet most suspected, as the time and place Doth make against me, of this direful murder.
modern: I am the greatest, but I was able to do the least.

origin: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
modern: I have already condemned and excused myself.

origin: Then say at once what thou dost know in this.
modern: Tell us what you know about this affair.

origin: I will be brief, for my short date of breath Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
modern: I will be brief because I’m not going to live long enough to tell a boring story.

origin: Meantime I writ to Romeo, That he should hither come as this dire night, To help to take her from her borrowed grave, Being the time the potion’s force should cease.
modern: In the meantime I wrote to Romeo and told him to come here on this awful night to help remove her from her temporary grave when the sleeping potion wore off.

origin: What can he say in this?
modern: I know all of this.

origin: Their course of love, the tidings of her death.
modern: I brought my master news of Juliet’s death.

origin: Montague!
modern: Give me the letter.

origin: O brother Montague, give me thy hand.
modern: Oh, brother Montague, give me your hand.

origin: But now, my lord, what say you to my suit?
modern: But what do you say to my request?

origin: But saying o'er what I have said before.
modern: I can only repeat what I’ve said before.

origin: My child is yet a stranger in the world.
modern: My daughter is still very young.

origin: She hath not seen the change of fourteen years.
modern: She’s not even fourteen years old.

origin: Younger than she are happy mothers made.
modern: Girls younger than she often marry and become happy mothers.

origin: And too soon marred are those so early made.
modern: Girls who marry so young grow up too soon.

origin: But woo her, gentle Paris, get her heart.
modern: But go ahead and charm her, gentle Paris; make her love you.

origin: This night I hold an old accustomed feast, Whereto I have invited many a guest Such as I love.
modern: Tonight I’m having a feast that we’ve celebrated for many years.

origin: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life, Whose misadventured piteous overthrows Doth with their death bury their parents' strife.
modern: At my humble house tonight, you can expect to see dazzling stars that walk on the ground and light the sky from below.

origin: The fearful passage of their death-marked love And the continuance of their parents' rage, Which, but their children’s end, naught could remove, Is now the two hours' traffic of our stage— The which, if you with patient ears attend, What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
modern: In the beautiful city of Verona, where our story takes place, a long-standing hatred between two families erupts into new violence, and citizens stain their hands with the blood of their fellow citizens.

origin: Such comfort as do lusty young men feel When well-appareled April on the heel Of limping winter treads.
modern: Two unlucky children of these enemy families become lovers and commit suicide.

origin: Even such delight Among fresh fennel buds shall you this night Inherit at my house.
modern: Their unfortunate deaths put an end to their parents' feud.

origin: Go, sirrah, trudge about Through fair Verona.
modern: Come along with me.

origin: Find them out whose names are written here?
modern: Find the people whose names are on this list?

origin: It is written, that the shoemaker should meddle with his yard and the tailor with his last, the fisher with his pencil and the painter with his nets.
modern: It is written that shoemakers and tailors should play with each others' tools, that fisherman should play with paints, and painters should play with with fishing nets.

origin: But I am sent to find those persons whose names are here writ, and can never find what names the writing person hath here writ.
modern: But I’ve been sent to find the people whose names are written on this list, and I can’t read!

origin: Take thou some new infection to thy eye, And the rank poison of the old will die.
modern: But here come some people, right in the nick of time.

origin: Your plantain leaf is excellent for that.
modern: For when you cut your shin.

origin: For what, I pray thee?
modern: What?

origin: Why Romeo, art thou mad?
modern: Romeo, are you crazy?

origin: Not mad, but bound more than a madman is, Shut up in prison, kept without my food, Whipped and tormented and—Good e'en, good fellow.
modern: I’m locked up in a prison and deprived of food.

origin: God 'i' good e'en.
modern: I’m whipped and tortured— May God give you a good evening.

origin: I pray, sir, can you read?
modern: Excuse me, sir, do you know how to read?

origin: Ay, mine own fortune in my misery.
modern: I can read my own fortune in my misery.

origin: Perhaps you have learned it without book.
modern: Perhaps you’ve learned from life and not from books.

origin: But I pray, can you read anything you see?
modern: But please tell me, can you read anything you see?

origin: Ay, if I know the letters and the language.
modern: Yes, if I know the language and the letters.

origin: Ye say honestly.
modern: I see.

origin: Stay, fellow.
modern: Well, that’s an  Stay, fellow.

origin: I can read.
modern: I can read.

origin: Seigneur Martino and his wife and daughters; County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; The lady widow of Vitruvio; Seigneur Placentio and his lovely nieces; Mercutio and his brother Valentine; Mine uncle Capulet, his wife and daughters; My fair niece Rosaline and Livia;
modern: Signor Martino and his wife and daughters, Count Anselme and his beautiful sisters, Vitruvio’s widow, Signor Placentio and his lovely nieces, Mercutio and his brother Valentine, My uncle Capulet and his wife and daughters, My fair niece Rosaline and Livia,

origin: Seigneur Valentio and his cousin Tybalt; Lucio and the lively Helena.” A fair assembly.
modern: Signor Valentio and his cousin Tybalt, Lucio and the lively Helena.” That’s a nice group of people.

origin: Whither should they come?
modern: Where are they supposed to come?

origin: Up.
modern: Up.

origin: Whither?
modern: Where?

origin: To supper?
modern: To supper?

origin: To our house.
modern: To our house.

origin: Whose house?
modern: Whose house?

origin: My master’s.
modern: My master’s house.

origin: Indeed, I should have asked thee that before.
modern: Indeed, I should have asked you before who he was.

origin: Now I’ll tell you without asking.
modern: Now I’ll tell you so you don’t have to ask.

origin: My master is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Montagues, I pray come and crush a cup of wine.
modern: My master is the great and rich Capulet, and if you don’t belong to the house of Montague, please come and drink a cup of wine.

origin: Rest you merry!
modern: Have a nice day!

origin: At this same ancient feast of Capulet’s Sups the fair Rosaline whom thou so loves With all the admired beauties of Verona.
modern: The beautiful Rosaline whom you love so much will be at Capulet’s traditional feast, along with every beautiful woman in Verona.

origin: Go thither, and with unattainted eye Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
modern: Go there and compare her objectively to some other girls I’ll show you.

origin: One fairer than my love?
modern: A woman more beautiful than the one I love?

origin: The all-seeing sun Ne'er saw her match since first the world begun.
modern: The sun itself has never seen anyone as beautiful since the world began.

origin: I’ll go along, no such sight to be shown, But to rejoice in splendor of mine own.
modern: I’ll go with you.

origin: Nurse, where’s my daughter?
modern: Nurse, where’s my daughter?

origin: Call her forth to me.
modern: Tell her to come to me.

origin: Now, by my maidenhead at twelve year old I bade her come.
modern: I swear to you by my virginity at age twelve, I already told her to come.

origin: What, lamb!
modern: Come on!

origin: How now, who calls?
modern: Who’s calling me?

origin: Your mother.
modern: Your mother.

origin: Madam, I am here.
modern: Madam, I’m here.

origin: What is your will?
modern: What do you want?

origin: Thou know’st my daughter’s of a pretty age.
modern: You know how young my daughter is.

origin: Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
modern: Yes, I know her age down to the hour.

origin: She’s not fourteen.
modern: She’s not even fourteen.

origin: I’ll lay fourteen of my teeth—and yet, to my teen be it spoken, I have but four—she is not fourteen.
modern: I’d bet fourteen of my own teeth—but, I’m sorry to say, I only have four teeth—she’s not fourteen.

origin: Even or odd, of all days in the year, Come Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
modern: Whether it’s even or odd, of all the days in the year, on the night of Lammas Eve, she’ll be fourteen.

origin: Susan and she—God rest all Christian souls!— Were of an age.
modern: She and Susan—God rest her and all Christian souls—were born on the same day.

origin: Well, Susan is with God.
modern: Well, Susan died and is with God.

origin: She was too good for me.
modern: She was too good for me.

origin: But, as I said, On Lammas Eve at night shall she be fourteen.
modern: But like I said, on the night of Lammas Eve, she will be fourteen.

origin: That shall she.
modern: Yes, she will.

origin: Marry, I remember it well.
modern: Indeed, I remember it well.

origin: Tis since the earthquake now eleven years, And she was weaned—I never shall forget it— Of all the days of the year, upon that day.
modern: It’s been eleven years since the earthquake.

origin: For I had then laid wormwood to my dug, Sitting in the sun under the dovehouse wall.
modern: I had put bitter wormwood on my breast as I was sitting in the sun, under the wall of the dovehouse.

origin: My lord and you were then at Mantua.— Nay, I do bear a brain.—But, as I said, When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple Of my dug and felt it bitter, pretty fool, To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
modern: But like I said, when she tasted the bitter wormwood on my nipple, the pretty little babe got irritated and started to quarrel with my breast.

origin: Shake!” quoth the dovehouse.
modern: Then the dovehouse shook with the earthquake.

origin: Twas no need, I trow, To bid me trudge.
modern: There was no need to tell me to get out of there.

origin: Yea,” quoth he, “Dost thou fall upon thy face?
modern: Oh,” he said, “Did you fall on your face?

origin: And, pretty fool, it stinted and said “ay.” Enough of this.
modern: You’ll  Enough of this.

origin: I pray thee, hold thy peace.
modern: Please be quiet.

origin: Yes, madam.
modern: Yes ,madam.

origin: Yet I cannot choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say “ay.” And yet, I warrant, it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel’s stone, A perilous knock, and it cried bitterly.
modern: But I can’t help laughing to think that the baby stopped crying and said, “Yes.” I swear, she had a bump on her forehead as big as a rooster’s testicle.

origin: Yea,” quoth my husband, “Fall’st upon thy face?
modern: It was a painful bruise, and she was crying bitterly.

origin: Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age.
modern: Yes,” said my husband, “Did you fall on your face?

origin: Wilt thou not, Jule?” It stinted and said “ay.” And stint thou too, I pray thee, Nurse, say I.
modern: You’ll fall backward when you grow up, won’t you, Jule?” And she stopped crying and said, “Yes.” Now you stop too, Nurse, please.

origin: God mark thee to his grace!
modern: May God choose you to receive his grace.

origin: Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed.
modern: You were the prettiest baby I ever nursed.

origin: An I might live to see thee married once, I have my wish.
modern: If I live to see you get married someday, all my wishes will come true.

origin: Tell me, daughter Juliet, How stands your disposition to be married?
modern: Tell me, my daughter Juliet, what is your attitude about getting married?

origin: It is an honor that I dream not of.
modern: It is an honor that I do not dream of.

origin: Well, think of marriage now.
modern: Well, start thinking about marriage now.

origin: Younger than you Here in Verona, ladies of esteem Are made already mothers.
modern: Here in Verona there are girls younger than you—girls from noble families—who have already become mothers.

origin: By my count, I was your mother much upon these years That you are now a maid.
modern: By my count, I was already your mother at just about your age, while you remain a virgin.

origin: Thus then in brief: The valiant Paris seeks you for his love.
modern: Well then, I’ll say this quickly: the valiant Paris wants you as his bride.

origin: A man, young lady!
modern: What a man, young lady.

origin: Verona’s summer hath not such a flower.
modern: Summertime in Verona has no flower as fine as him.

origin: What say you?
modern: Lose nothing?

origin: I’ll look to like if looking liking move.
modern: I’ll look at him and try to like him, at least if what I see is likable.

origin: But no more deep will I endart mine eye Than your consent gives strength to make it fly.
modern: But I won’t let myself fall for him any more than your permission allows.

origin: I must hence to wait.
modern: Everything’s out of control.

origin: I beseech you, follow straight.
modern: Please, follow straight after me.

origin: We follow thee.—Juliet, the county stays.
modern: We’ll follow you.

origin: Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.
modern: Go, girl, look for a man who’ll give you happy nights at the end of happy days.

origin: What, shall this speech be spoke for our excuse?
modern: What will we say is our excuse for being here?

origin: Or shall we on without apology?
modern: Or should we enter without apologizing?

origin: The date is out of such prolixity.
modern: It’s out of fashion to give lengthy explanations like that.

origin: But let them measure us by what they will.
modern: Let them judge us however they please.

origin: Give me a torch.
modern: Give me a torch.

origin: I am not for this ambling.
modern: I don’t want to dance.

origin: Nay, gentle Romeo, we must have you dance.
modern: No, noble Romeo, you’ve got to dance.

origin: Not I, believe me.
modern: Not me, believe me.

origin: You have dancing shoes With nimble soles.
modern: You’re wearing dancing shoes with nimble soles.

origin: I have a soul of lead So stakes me to the ground I cannot move.
modern: My soul is made out of lead, and it’s so heavy it keeps me stuck on the ground so I can’t move.

origin: You are a lover.
modern: You’re a lover.

origin: Borrow Cupid’s wings And soar with them above a common bound.
modern: Take Cupid’s wings and fly higher than the average man.

origin: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
modern: His arrow has pierced me too deeply, so I can’t fly high with his cheerful feathers.

origin: Under love’s heavy burden do I sink.
modern: I sink under the heavy weight of love.

origin: I mean, an we be in choler, we’ll draw.
modern: We won’t take their garbage.

origin: I strike quickly, being moved.
modern: I hit hard when I’m angry.

origin: But thou art not quickly moved to strike.
modern: Angry enough to run away.

origin: To move is to stir, and to be valiant is to stand.
modern: You won’t stand and fight.

origin: A dog of that house shall move me to stand.
modern: A dog from that house will make me angry enough to take a stand.

origin: And to sink in it, should you burthen love— Too great oppression for a tender thing.
modern: If you sink, you’re dragging love down.

origin: Is love a tender thing?
modern: Is love really tender?

origin: It is too rough, Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.
modern: I think it’s too rough, too rude, too rowdy, and it pricks like a thorn.

origin: If love be rough with you, be rough with love.
modern: If love plays rough with you, play rough with  Come on, let’s knock and go in.

origin: Let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.
modern: Let playful people with light hearts dance.

origin: Come, we burn daylight, ho!
modern: Come on, we’re wasting precious daylight.

origin: Nay, that’s not so.
modern: Let’s go!

origin: We waste our lights in vain, like lights by day.
modern: No we’re not—it’s night.

origin: And we mean well in going to this mask, But ’tis no wit to go.
modern: We mean well by going to this masquerade ball, but it’s not smart of us to go.

origin: Why, may one ask?
modern: Why, may I ask?

origin: I dreamt a dream tonight.
modern: I had a dream last night.

origin: And so did I.
modern: So did I.

origin: Well, what was yours?
modern: Well, what was your dream?

origin: That dreamers often lie.
modern: My dream told me that dreamers often lie.

origin: In bed asleep while they do dream things true.
modern: They lie in bed while they dream about the truth.

origin: Oh, then, I see Queen Mab hath been with you.
modern: Oh, then I see you’ve been with  Who’s Queen Mab?

origin: Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier’s nose, And then dreams he of smelling out a suit.
modern: Sometimes she rides over a courtier’s lips, and he dreams of making money off of someone.

origin: And sometime comes she with a tithe-pig’s tail Tickling a parson’s nose as he lies asleep, Then he dreams of another benefice.
modern: Sometimes she tickles a priest’s nose with a  Enough, enough!

origin: This is she—    Peace, peace, Mercutio, peace!
modern: Mercutio, be quiet.

origin: This wind you talk of, blows us from ourselves.
modern: The wind you’re talking about is blowing us off our course.

origin: Supper is done, and we shall come too late.
modern: Dinner is over, and we’re going to get there too late.

origin: On, lusty gentlemen.
modern: Onward, lover boys!

origin: Strike, drum.
modern: Beat the drum.

origin: Where’s Potpan, that he helps not to take away?
modern: Where’s Potpan?

origin: When good manners shall lie all in one or two men’s hands, and they unwashed too, ’tis a foul thing.
modern: When only one or two men have all the good manners, and even they are dirty, things are bad.

origin: Away with the joint-stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to the plate.
modern: Take away the stools, the sideboards, and the plates.

origin: Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane, and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!
modern: You, good friend, save me a piece of marzipan, and if you love me, have the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.

origin: Ay, boy, ready.
modern: Yes, boy, I’m ready.

origin: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
modern: They’re looking for you in the great chamber.

origin: We cannot be here and there too.
modern: We can’t be in two places at once, both here and there!

origin: Cheerly, boys.
modern: Cheers, boys.

origin: Be brisk 0awhile, and the longer liver take all.
modern: Be quick for a while and let the one who lives the longest take everything.

origin: Welcome, gentlemen!
modern: Welcome, gentlemen.

origin: She that makes dainty, She, I’ll swear, hath corns.
modern: Whichever of you acts shy, I’ll swear she has corns.

origin: Am I come near ye now?— Welcome, gentlemen!
modern: Welcome, gentlemen.

origin: By'r Lady, thirty years.
modern: I swear, it must be thirty years.

origin: Tis more, ’tis more.
modern: It’s been longer, it’s been longer.

origin: His son is elder, sir.
modern: Lucentio’s son is older than that, sir.

origin: His son is thirty.
modern: He’s thirty years old.

origin: Will you tell me that?
modern: Are you really going to tell me that?

origin: His son was but a ward two years ago.
modern: His son was a minor only two years ago.

origin: I know not, sir.
modern: I don’t know, sir.

origin: Oh, she doth teach the torches to burn bright!
modern: Oh, she shows the torches how to burn bright!

origin: For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
modern: My eyes were liars, then, because I never saw true beauty before tonight.

origin: This, by his voice, should be a Montague.—   What, dares the slave Come hither, covered with an antic face, To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
modern: I can tell by his voice that this man is a Montague.

origin: Wherefore storm you so?
modern: Why are you acting so angry?

origin: Uncle, this is a Montague, our foe, A villain that is hither come in spite To scorn at our solemnity this night.
modern: Uncle, this man is a Montague—our enemy.

origin: Young Romeo is it?
modern: Is it young Romeo?

origin: Tis he, that villain Romeo.
modern: That’s him, that villain Romeo.

origin: Content thee, gentle coz.
modern: Calm down, gentle cousin.

origin: Let him alone.
modern: Leave him alone.

origin: He bears him like a portly gentleman, And, to say truth, Verona brags of him To be a virtuous and well-governed youth.
modern: He carries himself like a dignified gentleman, and, to tell you the truth, he has a reputation throughout Verona as a virtuous and well-behaved young man.

origin: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement.
modern: I wouldn’t insult him in my own house for all the wealth in this town.

origin: Therefore be patient.
modern: So calm down.

origin: Take no note of him.
modern: Just ignore him.

origin: You’ll not endure him!
modern: I won’t tolerate him.

origin: Why, uncle, ’tis a shame.
modern: You  But, uncle, we’re being disrespected.

origin: Go to, go to.
modern: Go on, go on.

origin: You are a saucy boy.
modern: You’re an insolent little boy.

origin: Is ’t so, indeed?
modern: Is that how it is, really?

origin: This trick may chance to scathe you, I know what.
modern: I know what I’ll do.

origin: You must contrary me.
modern: You have to contradict me, do you?

origin: I’ll make you quiet.—What, cheerly, my hearts!
modern: I’ll teach you a lesson.

origin: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?
modern: Don’t saints and pilgrims have lips too?

origin: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
modern: Yes, pilgrim—they have lips that they’re supposed to pray with.

origin: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do.
modern: Well then, saint, let lips do what hands do.

origin: They pray; grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.
modern: Please grant my prayer so my faith doesn’t turn to despair.

origin: Saints do not move, though grant for prayers' sake.
modern: Saints don’t move, even when they grant prayers.

origin: Then move not, while my prayer’s effect I take.
modern: Then don’t move while I act out my prayer.

origin: Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purged.
modern: Now my sin has been taken from my lips by yours.

origin: Then have my lips the sin that they have took.
modern: Then do my lips now have the sin they took from yours?

origin: Sin from thy lips?
modern: Sin from my lips?

origin: Give me my sin again.
modern: Give me my sin back.

origin: You kiss by th' book.
modern: You kiss like you’ve studied how.

origin: Madam, your mother craves a word with you.
modern: Madam, your mother wants to talk to you.

origin: What is her mother?
modern: Who is her mother?

origin: I nursed her daughter that you talked withal.
modern: I nursed her daughter, whom you were just talking to.

origin: I tell you, he that can lay hold of her Shall have the chinks.
modern: Let me tell you, the man who marries her will become very wealthy.

origin: Nay, gentlemen, prepare not to be gone.
modern: No gentlemen, don’t get ready to go now.

origin: We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.— Is it e'en so?
modern: We have a little dessert coming up.

origin: I’ll to my rest.
modern: You’re right.

origin: The quarrel is between our masters and us their men.
modern: The fight is between our masters, and we men who work for them.

origin: Tis all one.
modern: It’s all the same.

origin: I will show myself a tyrant.
modern: I’ll be a harsh master to them.

origin: The heads of the maids?
modern: Cut off their heads?

origin: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.
modern: You mean their  Cut off their heads, take their maidenheads—whatever.

origin: Take it in what sense thou wilt.
modern: Take my remark in whichever sense you like.

origin: They must take it in sense that feel it.
modern: The women you rape are the ones who’ll have to “sense” it.

origin: Me they shall feel while I am able to stand, and ’tis known I am a pretty piece of flesh.
modern: Everybody knows I’m a nice piece of flesh.

origin: Tis well thou art not fish.
modern: It’s a good thing you’re not a piece of fish.

origin: Draw thy tool!
modern: You’re    Pull out your tool now.

origin: My naked weapon is out.
modern: I have my naked sword out.

origin: Come hither, Nurse.
modern: Come over here, nurse.

origin: What is yond gentleman?
modern: Who is that gentleman?

origin: The son and heir of old Tiberio.
modern: He is the son and heir of old Tiberio.

origin: What’s he that now is going out of door?
modern: Who’s the one who’s going out the door right now?

origin: Marry, that, I think, be young Petruchio.
modern: Well, that one, I think, is young Petruchio.

origin: I know not.
modern: I don’t know his name.

origin: Go ask his name.—If he be married.
modern: Go ask.

origin: What’s this?
modern: What’s this?

origin: What’s this?
modern: What’s this?

origin: The strangers all are gone.
modern: The strangers are all gone.

origin: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
modern: But he has to make his speeches of love to a woman who’s supposed to be his enemy.

origin: And she as much in love, her means much less To meet her new beloved anywhere.
modern: And Juliet’s just as much in love as he, but she has even less opportunity to meet her lover.

origin: But passion lends them power, time means, to meet, Tempering extremities with extreme sweet.
modern: But love gives them power, and time gives them the chance to meet, sweetening the extreme danger with intense pleasure.

origin: Can I go forward when my heart is here?
modern: Can I go away while my heart stays here?

origin: He is wise, And, on my life, hath stol'n him home to bed.
modern: I bet he slipped away and went home to bed.

origin: He ran this way and leapt this orchard wall.
modern: He ran this way and jumped over this orchard wall.

origin: Call, good Mercutio.
modern: Call to him, Mercutio.

origin: Nay, I’ll conjure too!
modern: I’ll conjure him as if I were summoning a spirit.

origin: Romeo!
modern: Romeo!

origin: Appear thou in the likeness of a sigh!
modern: Show yourself in the form of a sigh.

origin: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.
modern: Speak one rhyme, and I’ll be satisfied.

origin: Cry but “Ay me!” Pronounce but “love” and “dove.” Speak to my gossip Venus one fair word, One nickname for her purblind son and heir, Young Abraham Cupid, he that shot so true When King Cophetua loved the beggar maid.— He heareth not, he stirreth not, he moveth not.
modern: Just cry out, “Ah me!” Just say “love” and “dove.” Say just one lovely word to my good friend

origin: An if he hear thee, thou wilt anger him.
modern: If he hears you, you’ll make him angry.

origin: This cannot anger him.
modern: What I’m saying can’t anger him.

origin: My invocation Is fair and honest.
modern: The things I’m saying are fair and honest.

origin: Blind is his love and best befits the dark.
modern: His love is blind, so it belongs in the dark.

origin: If love be blind, love cannot hit the mark.
modern: If love is blind, it can’t hit the target.

origin: Now will he sit under a medlar tree And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit As maids call medlars when they laugh alone.— O Romeo, that she were!
modern: Now he’ll sit under a  Let’s go.

origin: Go, then, for ’tis in vain To seek him here that means not to be found.
modern: There’s no point in looking for him if he doesn’t want to be found.

origin: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.
modern: It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.

origin: Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.
modern: Virginity makes her look sick and green.

origin: Cast it off!
modern: Let it go.

origin: It is my lady.
modern: Oh, there’s my lady!

origin: Oh, it is my love.
modern: Oh, it is my love.

origin: Oh, that she knew she were!
modern: Oh, I wish she knew how much I love her.

origin: She speaks, yet she says nothing.
modern: She’s talking, but she’s not saying anything.

origin: What of that?
modern: So what?

origin: Her eye discourses.
modern: Her eyes are saying something.

origin: Tis not to me she speaks.
modern: She’s not talking to me.

origin: Two of the fairest stars in all the heaven, Having some business, do entreat her eyes To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
modern: Two of the brightest stars in the whole sky had to go away on business, and they’re asking her eyes to twinkle in their places until they return.

origin: Her eye in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night.
modern: If her eyes were in the night sky, they would shine so brightly through space that birds would start singing, thinking her light was the light of day.

origin: See how she leans her cheek upon her hand.
modern: Look how she leans her hand on her cheek.

origin: Oh, that I were a glove upon that hand That I might touch that cheek!
modern: Oh, I wish I was the glove on that hand so that I could touch that cheek.

origin: O Romeo, Romeo!
modern: Oh, my!

origin: Wherefore art thou Romeo?
modern: Who are you?

origin: Tis but thy name that is my enemy.
modern: I hate my name, dear saint, because my name is your enemy.

origin: Henceforth I never will be Romeo.
modern: Aren’t you Romeo?

origin: What man art thou that, thus bescreened in night, So stumblest on my counsel?
modern: And aren’t you a Montague?

origin: By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am.
modern: Tell me, how did you get in here?

origin: Art thou not Romeo, and a Montague?
modern: And why did you come?

origin: The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here.
modern: If any of my relatives find you here they’ll kill you because of who you are.

origin: Therefore thy kinsmen are no stop to me.
modern: Therefore your relatives are no obstacle.

origin: If they do see thee they will murder thee.
modern: If they see you, they’ll murder you.

origin: Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity.
modern: Just look at me kindly, and I’m invincible against their hatred.

origin: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
modern: I’d give anything to keep them from seeing you here.

origin: My life were better ended by their hate Than death proroguèd, wanting of thy love.
modern: I’d rather they killed me than have to live without your love.

origin: Thou know’st the mask of night is on my face, Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek For that which thou hast heard me speak tonight.
modern: Otherwise, you’d see me blushing about the things you’ve heard me say tonight.

origin: Dost thou love me?
modern: Do you love me?

origin: I know thou wilt say “ay,” And I will take thy word.
modern: I know you’ll say “yes,” and I’ll believe you.

origin: What shall I swear by?
modern: What should I swear by?

origin: Do not swear at all.
modern: Don’t swear at all.

origin: Or, if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry, And I’ll believe thee.
modern: But if you have to swear, swear by your wonderful self, which is the god I worship like an idol, and then I’ll believe you.

origin: If my heart’s dear love— Well, do not swear.
modern: If my heart’s dear love— Well, don’t swear.

origin: Although I joy in thee, I have no joy of this contract tonight.
modern: Although you bring me joy, I can’t take joy in this exchange of promises tonight.

origin: This bud of love, by summer’s ripening breath, May prove a beauteous flower when next we meet.
modern: Our love, which right now is like a flower bud in the summer air, may turn out to be a beautiful flower by the next time we meet.

origin: As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast.
modern: I hope you enjoy the same sweet peace and rest I feel in my heart.

origin: O, wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?
modern: Oh, are you going to leave me so unsatisfied?

origin: What satisfaction canst thou have tonight?
modern: What satisfaction could you possibly have tonight?

origin: Th' exchange of thy love’s faithful vow for mine.
modern: I pledged my love to you before you asked me to.

origin: I gave thee mine before thou didst request it, And yet I would it were to give again.
modern: Yet I wish I could take that promise back, so I had it to give again.

origin: Wouldst thou withdraw it?
modern: You would take it back?

origin: For what purpose, love?
modern: Why would you do that, my love?

origin: But to be frank, and give it thee again.
modern: Only to be generous and give it to you once more.

origin: And yet I wish but for the thing I have.
modern: But I’m wishing for something I already have.

origin: My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep.
modern: My generosity to you is as limitless as the sea, and my love is as deep.

origin: I hear some noise within.
modern: I hear a noise inside.

origin: Dear love, adieu.— Anon, good Nurse!—Sweet Montague, be true.
modern: Sweet Montague, be true.

origin: Stay but a little.
modern: Stay here for a moment.

origin: I will come again.
modern: I’ll come back.

origin: O blessèd, blessèd night!
modern: Oh, blessed, blessed night!

origin: I am afeard, Being in night, all this is but a dream, Too flattering sweet to be substantial.
modern: Because it’s dark out, I’m afraid all this is just a dream, too sweet to be real.

origin: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
modern: Three words, dear Romeo, and then it’s good night for real.

origin: Fear me not.
modern: Don’t worry about me.

origin: Let us take the law of our sides.
modern: I  Let’s not break the law by starting a fight.

origin: Let them begin.
modern: Let them start something.

origin: I will frown as I pass by, and let them take it as they list.
modern: I’ll frown at them as they pass by, and they can react however they want.

origin: Nay, as they dare.
modern: You mean however they dare.

origin: I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
modern: I’ll bite my thumb at them.

origin: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
modern: Hey, are you biting your thumb at us?

origin: I do bite my thumb, sir.
modern: I’m biting my thumb.

origin: Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
modern: Are you biting your thumb at us?

origin: Do you quarrel, sir?
modern: Are you trying to start a fight?

origin: Quarrel, sir?
modern: Start a fight?

origin: No, sir.
modern: No, sir.

origin: Tomorrow will I send.
modern: Tomorrow I’ll send the messenger.

origin: So thrive my soul— A thousand times good night!
modern: My soul depends on it— A thousand times good night.

origin: A thousand times the worse to want thy light.
modern: Leaving you is a thousand times worse than being near you.

origin: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.
modern: Oh, I wish I could make a  My soul is calling out my name.

origin: How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, Like softest music to attending ears!
modern: The sound of lovers calling each others names through the night is silver-sweet.

origin: Romeo!
modern: Romeo!

origin: My nyas?
modern: My baby hawk?

origin: What o'clock tomorrow Shall I send to thee?
modern: What time tomorrow should I send a messenger to you?

origin: By the hour of nine.
modern: By nine o'clock.

origin: I will not fail.
modern: I won’t fail.

origin: Tis twenty year till then.
modern: From now until then seems like twenty years.

origin: I have forgot why I did call thee back.
modern: I have forgotten why I called you back.

origin: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
modern: Let me stand here until you remember your reason.

origin: And I’ll still stay, to have thee still forget, Forgetting any other home but this.
modern: I’ll forget that I have any home besides this spot right here.

origin: Tis almost morning.
modern: It’s almost morning.

origin: And yet no further than a wanton’s bird, That lets it hop a little from his hand Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves, And with a silken thread plucks it back again, So loving-jealous of his liberty.
modern: He lets the bird hop a little from his hand and then yanks him back by a string.

origin: I would I were thy bird.
modern: I wish I was your bird.

origin: Sweet, so would I.
modern: My sweet, so do I.

origin: Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
modern: But I would kill you by petting you too much.

origin: Good night, good night!
modern: Good night, good night.

origin: Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow.
modern: Parting is such sweet sorrow that I’ll say good night until tonight becomes tomorrow.

origin: Sleep dwell upon thine eyes, peace in thy breast.
modern: I hope you sleep peacefully.

origin: Would I were sleep and peace, so sweet to rest.
modern: I wish I were Sleep and Peace, so I could spend the night with you.

origin: Hence will I to my ghostly friar’s close cell, His help to crave and my dear hap to tell.
modern: Now I’ll go see my priest, to ask for his help and tell him about my good luck.

origin: The gray-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night, Checkering the eastern clouds with streaks of light, And fleckled darkness like a drunkard reels From forth day’s path and Titan’s fiery wheels.
modern: Darkness is stumbling out of the sun’s path like a drunk man.

origin: Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye, The day to cheer and night’s dank dew to dry, I must upfill this osier cage of ours With baleful weeds and precious-juicèd flowers.
modern: Now, before the sun comes up and burns away the dew, I have to fill this basket of mine with poisonous weeds and medicinal flowers.

origin: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.
modern: The Earth is nature’s mother and also nature’s tomb.

origin: And from her womb children of divers kind We sucking on her natural bosom find, Many for many virtues excellent, None but for some and yet all different.
modern: From the Earth’s womb, many different sorts of plants and animals come forth, and the Earth provides her children with many excellent forms of nourishment.

origin: Oh, mickle is the powerful grace that lies In herbs, plants, stones, and their true qualities.
modern: Herbs, plants, and stones possess great power.

origin: For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.
modern: There is nothing on Earth that is so evil that it does not provide the earth with some special quality.

origin: Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied, And vice sometime by action dignified.
modern: Virtue turns to vice if it’s misused.

origin: Within the infant rind of this small flower Poison hath residence and medicine power.
modern: Inside the little rind of this weak flower, there is both poison and powerful medicine.

origin: Two such opposèd kings encamp them still, In man as well as herbs—grace and rude will.
modern: There are two opposite elements in everything, in men as well as in herbs—good and evil.

origin: And where the worser is predominant, Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
modern: When evil is dominant, death soon kills the body like cancer.

origin: Good morrow, Father.
modern: Good morning, father.

origin: Benedicite.
modern: God bless you.

origin: What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
modern: Who greets me so early in the morning?

origin: Young son, it argues a distempered head So soon to bid good morrow to thy bed.
modern: Young man, something’s wrong if you’re getting out of bed this early.

origin: Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.
modern: Every old man has worries, and worried men never get any sleep, but young men shouldn’t have a care in the world.

origin: But where unbruisèd youth with unstuffed brain Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign.
modern: They should get to bed early and get plenty of sleep.

origin: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.
modern: Therefore, the fact that you’re awake this early tells me you’ve been upset with some anxiety.

origin: Or if not so, then here I hit it right: Our Romeo hath not been in bed tonight.
modern: If that’s not the case, then this must be the answer: You, Romeo, have not been to bed tonight.

origin: That last is true.
modern: Your last guess is right.

origin: The sweeter rest was mine.
modern: I enjoyed a sweeter rest than sleep.

origin: With Rosaline, my ghostly Father?
modern: With Rosaline, father?

origin: That’s my good son.
modern: That’s good, my boy.

origin: But where hast thou been, then?
modern: But where have you been?

origin: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
modern: I’ll tell you before you have to ask me again.

origin: Both our remedies Within thy help and holy physic lies.
modern: You have the sacred power to cure both of us.

origin: I bear no hatred, blessèd man, for, lo, My intercession likewise steads my foe.
modern: I carry no hatred, holy man, because my request will benefit my enemy.

origin: Here comes your father.
modern: Here comes your father.

origin: Never make denial.
modern: Don’t even think about refusing.

origin: I must and will have Katherine to my wife.
modern: I must and will have Katherine for my wife.

origin: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
modern: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you getting on with my daughter?

origin: How but well, sir?
modern: Beautifully, sir, beautifully!

origin: Why, how now, daughter Katherine?
modern: Now, daughter Katherine?

origin: In your dumps?
modern: Are you down in the dumps?

origin: Call you me daughter?
modern: You have the nerve to call me daughter?

origin: Father, ’tis thus: yourself and all the world That talked of her have talked amiss of her.
modern: Sir, this is the truth: you and the rest—all the people who have ever talked about her—have all been wrong.

origin: I’ll see thee hanged on Sunday first.
modern: She has the patience of a  I’ll see you hanged on Sunday first!

origin: Hark, Petruchio: she says she’ll see thee hanged first.
modern: Listen to that Petruchio: she says she’ll see you hanged first.

origin: Is this your speeding?
modern: Is this your idea of success?

origin: Nay, then, good night our part.
modern: So much for our plan.

origin: Be patient, gentlemen.
modern: Relax, gentlemen.

origin: I choose her for myself.
modern: I’ve made my choice.

origin: If she and I be pleased, what’s that to you?
modern: If she and I are happy, what’s it to you?

origin: Tis bargained ’twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company.
modern: When we were alone, we agreed that in public she would go on being unpleasant.

origin: I tell you, ’tis incredible to believe How much she loves me.
modern: I tell you, though, it’s incredible how much she loves me.

origin: O, the kindest Kate!
modern: Darling Kate!

origin: O, you are novices!
modern: You men are rank beginners!

origin: Tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew.— Give me thy hand, Kate.
modern: Give me your hand, Kate.

origin: I will unto Venice To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day.
modern: I’m off to Venice to buy outfits for the wedding.

origin: God send you joy, Petruchio.
modern: God give you joy, Petruchio.

origin: Tis a match.
modern: Call it a match!

origin: Amen, say we.
modern: Amen to that!

origin: We will be witnesses.
modern: We’ll be your witnesses.

origin: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
modern: Father, wife, friends—farewell!

origin: I will to Venice.
modern: I’m off to Venice.

origin: Sunday comes apace.
modern: Sunday is just around the corner.

origin: We will be married o' Sunday.
modern: We’re to be married on Sunday.

origin: Was ever match clapped up so suddenly?
modern: Was there ever a match put together so quickly?

origin: Twill bring you gain or perish on the seas.
modern: I’ve made a risky investment.

origin: The gain I seek is quiet in the match.
modern: The only profit I seek is a peaceful match.

origin: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.
modern: There’s no doubt that Petruchio’s got quite a catch.

origin: But now, Baptista, to your younger daughter.
modern: Now, Baptista, let’s turn to your younger daughter.

origin: Now is the day we long have lookèd for.
modern: We’ve been waiting a long time for this day.

origin: I am your neighbor, and was suitor first.
modern: I’m your neighbor and came courting first.

origin: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.   Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.
modern: Callow youth, you don’t yet know how to love!

origin: But thine doth fry.
modern: And you’re all sizzle.

origin: Skipper, stand back.
modern: Stand back, boy.

origin: Tis age that nourisheth.
modern: Age is the thing that nourishes.

origin: Content you, gentlemen.
modern: Enough, gentlemen.

origin: I will compound this strife.
modern: I will settle this matter.

origin: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnishèd with plate and gold, Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands; My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry, In ivory coffers I have stuffed my crowns, In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossed with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass, and all things that belong To house or housekeeping.
modern: First of all, my house in the city, as you know, is filled with expensive furniture and household articles, china and gold, basins and pitchers for her to wash her dainty hands in.

origin: Then, at my farm I have a hundred milch-kine to the pail, Six score fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion.
modern: Then, at my farm I have a hundred milk cows, a hundred and twenty fat oxen in my stables, and all the equipment necessary to maintain them.

origin: Two thousand ducats by the year of land!
modern: Two thousand ducats a year from his land!

origin: Nay, I have offered all, I have no more, And she can have no more than all I have.
modern: I can’t offer her more than all I have.

origin: I must confess your offer is the best, And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own; else, you must pardon me.
modern: I must admit your offer is the best.

origin: If you should die before him, where’s her dower?
modern: Otherwise—forgive me, but if you should die before him, what becomes of her dowry?

origin: And may not young men die as well as old?
modern: Oh, and young men never die?

origin: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved: On Sunday next, you know My daughter Katherina is to be married.
modern: As you know, next Sunday my daughter Katherina is to be married.

origin: I think ’twas Soto that your Honor means.
modern: I believe your Honor is thinking of a character called Soto.

origin: Tis very true.
modern: Yes, that was it.

origin: Thou didst it excellent.
modern: You gave an excellent performance.

origin: There is a lord will hear you play tonight; But I am doubtful of your modesties, Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior— For yet his Honor never heard a play— You break into some merry passion And so offend him.
modern: There is a particular lord who will watch you perform tonight.

origin: Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery And give them friendly welcome every one.
modern: Go, lad, and take them to the pantry.

origin: Adieu, good neighbor.
modern: Farewell, good neighbor.

origin: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all and in his waning age Set foot under thy table.
modern: Your father would be a fool to give you all his wealth and spend his declining years as a guest in your house.

origin: Tut, a toy!
modern: It’s absurd.

origin: An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
modern: An old Italian fox is never that generous, my boy.

origin: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!
modern: Sneaky, dried-up old coot!

origin: Fathers commonly Do get their children.
modern: Usually fathers produce children, not the other way around.

origin: But in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
modern: But in this case of wooing, a child shall father his own father—if my wits don’t fail me.

origin: His lecture will be done ere you have tuned.
modern: I’ll have my lessons in the order and manner

origin: Where left we last?
modern: Where did we leave off?

origin: Here, madam:     Conster them.
modern: Here, madam:     Translate.

origin: Now let me see if I can conster it.
modern: Now let me see if I can translate it.

origin: I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt.
modern: There’s no need to be, really, for—  You’re my teacher, so I must believe you.

origin: But let it rest.—Now, Litio, to you.
modern: But let it go.—Now, Litio, it’s your turn.

origin: Good master, take it not unkindly, pray, That I have been thus pleasant with you both.
modern: I hope, sir, that you’re not angry that I’ve been equally attentive to you both!

origin: Call you this “gamut”?
modern: You call this a scale?

origin: Tut, I like it not.
modern: I don’t like it.

origin: Old fashions please me best.
modern: I like doing things the old-fashioned way.

origin: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister’s chamber up.
modern: Mistress, your father requests that you leave your books and come help decorate your sister’s room.

origin: You know tomorrow is the wedding day.
modern: You know tomorrow is her wedding day.

origin: Farewell, sweet masters both.
modern: Farewell to both of you, dear teachers.

origin: I must be gone.
modern: I have to go.

origin: But I have cause to pry into this pedant.
modern: But there’s reason for me to look more closely at this schoolmaster.

origin: Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
modern: He acts like a man in love.

origin: No shame but mine.
modern: The humiliation is all mine.

origin: Now must the world point at poor Katherine And say, “Lo, there is mad Petruchio’s wife, If it would please him come and marry her!”   Upon my life, Petruchio means but well, Whatever fortune stays him from his word: Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise; Though he be merry, yet withal he’s honest.
modern: So now everyone will point at me and say, “Look, there goes the wife of that comedian Petruchio—if he could be bothered to marry the pathetic thing!”

origin: Would Katherine had never seen him, though!
modern: Maybe, but I wish I’d never laid eyes on him.

origin: Go, girl.
modern: Go, daughter.

origin: I cannot blame thee now to weep, For such an injury would vex a very saint, Much more a shrew of thy impatient humor.
modern: I cannot blame you now for weeping.

origin: Master, master!
modern: Master, master!

origin: News, old news, and such news as you never heard of!
modern: I have news—old news such as you never heard before!

origin: Is it new and old too?
modern: You say you have news that’s old?

origin: How may that be?
modern: How can that be?

origin: Why, is it not news to hear of Petruchio’s coming?
modern: Well, is it not news that Petruchio’s coming?

origin: Is he come?
modern: Is he here?

origin: Why, no, sir.
modern: Why, no, sir.

origin: What then?
modern: What then?

origin: He is coming.
modern: He is coming.

origin: When will he be here?
modern: When will he be here?

origin: When he stands where I am and sees you there.
modern: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

origin: Who comes with him?
modern: Who comes with him?

origin: A monster, a very monster in apparel, and not like a Christian footboy or a gentleman’s lackey.
modern: He’s dressed like a freak, a total freak, and not at all like a proper footman or a gentleman’s valet.

origin: I am glad he’s come, howsoe'er he comes.
modern: I am glad he’s coming, however he’s dressed.

origin: Why, sir, he comes not.
modern: Why, sir, he’s not coming.

origin: Didst thou not say he comes?
modern: Didn’t you just say he was?

origin: Who?
modern: Who?

origin: That Petruchio came?
modern: Petruchio?

origin: Ay, that Petruchio came.
modern: Yes, Petruchio.

origin: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.
modern: No, I said his horse is coming, with him on its back.

origin: Why, that’s all one.
modern: Well, that’s the same thing.

origin: Nay, by Saint Jamy, I hold you a penny, A horse and a man Is more than one And yet not many.
modern: No, by Saint Jamy, I’ll bet you a penny!

origin: You are welcome, sir.
modern: You are welcome, sir.

origin: See this dispatched with all the haste thou canst: Anon I’ll give thee more instructions.
modern: I’ll give you more instructions later.

origin: I know the boy will well usurp the grace, Voice, gait, and action of a gentlewoman.
modern: I know the boy will be a convincing gentlewoman, taking up her exact walk and talk and gentle gestures.

origin: I long to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.
modern: I can’t wait to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” and to watch my men smother their laughter as they pay their respects to this simple peasant.

origin: I’ll in to counsel them.
modern: I’ll go and coach them.

origin: Where is my love?
modern: Where is my lovely bride?

origin: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day.
modern: Why, sir, you know this is your wedding day.

origin: Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.
modern: It’s a long story—and tough to listen to.

origin: But where is Kate?
modern: But where is Kate?

origin: I stay too long from her.
modern: We’re wasting time here.

origin: See not your bride in these unreverent robes.
modern: Don’t greet your bride in these disgraceful clothes.

origin: Go to my chamber, put on clothes of mine.
modern: Go to my room and put on something of mine.

origin: Not I, believe me.
modern: Not me.

origin: Thus I’ll visit her.
modern: I’ll see her like this.

origin: But thus, I trust, you will not marry her.
modern: But surely you’re not planning to

origin: Good sooth, even thus.
modern: Yes, just like this.

origin: Could I repair what she will wear in me As I can change these poor accoutrements, 'Twere well for Kate and better for myself.
modern: Though I expect she’ll wear me out more quickly than I’ll wear out what I’m wearing—which will be good for her and even better for me!

origin: But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss!
modern: But what a fool I am to stand here chatting when I should bid good morning to my bride and seal the bargain with a loving kiss.

origin: He hath some meaning in his mad attire.
modern: He must be wearing this crazy outfit for some reason.

origin: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.
modern: I’ll try to persuade him to put on something more appropriate before going to the church, if it’s at all possible.

origin: I’ll after him, and see the event of this.
modern: I’ll go too and make sure that happens.

origin: So shall you quietly enjoy your hope And marry sweet Bianca with consent.
modern: And

origin: We’ll overreach the graybeard, Gremio, The narrow-prying father, Minola, The quaint musician, amorous Litio, All for my master’s sake, Lucentio.
modern: We’ll outwit them all—that old geezer, Gremio; the suspicious father, Minola; the prim musician lover, Litio—all for the sake of my master, Lucentio.

origin: Signior Gremio, came you from the church?
modern: Signior Gremio, are you coming from the church?

origin: As willingly as e'er I came from school.
modern: As eagerly as I ever came from school.

origin: A bridegroom, say you?
modern: Bridegroom?

origin: Why, he’s a devil, a devil, a very fiend.
modern: No, he’s a devil—a devil, I tell you!

origin: Tut, she’s a lamb, a dove, a fool to him!
modern: Why, she’s a lamb, a dove, a child compared to him!

origin: Now take them up,” quoth he, “if any list.”   Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
modern: She trembled and shook because he stamped and swore and carried on as though the vicar were trying to put something over on him.

origin: But after many ceremonies done, He calls for wine.
modern: Finally, the ceremony done, he called for wine.

origin: This done, he took the bride about the neck And kissed her lips with such a clamorous smack That at the parting all the church did echo.
modern: Next he slung his arm around the bride’s neck and kissed her with such a smack that when they parted the sound of their lips made the whole church echo.

origin: Such a mad marriage never was before.
modern: That was the limit for me.

origin: Hark, hark!
modern: It’s disgraceful!

origin: I hear the minstrels play.
modern: There go the minstrels.

origin: Is ’t possible you will away tonight?
modern: You’re not thinking of leaving tonight, surely?

origin: Make it no wonder.
modern: Not tonight—today.

origin: If you knew my business, You would entreat me rather go than stay.
modern: If you knew the reason, you’d understand and would urge me to go rather than stay.

origin: And, honest company, I thank you all, That have beheld me give away myself To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife.
modern: Good friends, I thank you all for coming to see me wed this patient, sweet, virtuous wife.

origin: Let me entreat you.
modern: Goodbye to you all.

origin: It cannot be.
modern: Can’t do it.

origin: Let me entreat you.
modern: As a favor to  Nope.

origin: I am content.
modern: As a favor to  I’m delighted.

origin: Are you content to stay?
modern: Delighted to stay?

origin: I am content you shall entreat me stay, But yet not stay, entreat me how you can.
modern: Delighted to hear you ask so nicely, but I won’t stay in any case.

origin: Now, if you love me, stay.
modern: Look, if you love me, stay.

origin: Grumio, my horse.
modern: Grumio, get me my horse.

origin: Ay, sir, they be ready.
modern: Yes, sir, they’re ready.

origin: The oats have eaten the horses.
modern: They’ve eaten themselves sick.

origin: The door is open, sir.
modern: The door is open, sir.

origin: There lies your way.
modern: Go on, wear your boots out!

origin: For me, I’ll not be gone till I please myself.
modern: As for me, I’ll leave when I like.

origin: O Kate, content thee.
modern: Calm down, Kate.

origin: Prithee, be not angry.
modern: Please don’t be angry.

origin: I will be angry.
modern: I will be angry.

origin: What hast thou to do?— Father, be quiet.
modern: What business is it of yours?—Father, be quiet.

origin: He shall stay my leisure.
modern: He’ll stay as long as I say.

origin: Ay, marry, sir, now it begins to work.
modern: Okay, now it starts!

origin: Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner.
modern: Gentlemen, on to the bridal dinner.

origin: I see a woman may be made a fool If she had not a spirit to resist.
modern: I see a woman may be made a fool of if she doesn’t have nerve enough to stand up for herself.

origin: I’ll buckler thee against a million.
modern: They

origin: Nay, let them go, a couple of quiet ones.
modern: No, let them go.

origin: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
modern: They’re certainly a peaceful couple!

origin: That, being mad herself, she’s madly mated.
modern: That since she’s mad herself, she’s married a madman.

origin: Neighbors and friends, though bride and bridegroom wants For to supply the places at the table, You know there wants no junkets at the feast.
modern: Neighbors and friends, though we don’t have anyone for the bride and bridegroom’s places at the table, you know there’s nothing missing in the feast itself.

origin: She shall, Lucentio.
modern: She shall, Lucentio.

origin: Come, gentlemen, let’s go.
modern: Come, gentlemen, let’s go in.

origin: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and all foul ways!
modern: To hell with all worn-out horses, all crazy masters, and all bad roads.

origin: Was ever man so beaten?
modern: Was a man ever beaten as much as me?

origin: Was ever man so 'rayed?
modern: Was a man ever as dirty as me?

origin: Was ever man so weary?
modern: Was a man ever so tired?

origin: I am sent before to make a fire, and they are coming after to warm them.
