modern: I have been sent on ahead to light a fire, and they are coming after to warm themselves.

origin: Now, were not I a little pot and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire to thaw me.
modern: It’s a good thing I’m like a little pot and warm up quickly, or else my lips themselves would freeze and stick to my teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, and my heart would freeze in my belly, before I managed to get thawed out.

origin: But I with blowing the fire shall warm myself.
modern: I’ll warm myself by blowing on the fire.

origin: Who is that calls so coldly?
modern: Who calls so coldly?

origin: A piece of ice.
modern: A piece of ice.

origin: If thou doubt it, thou mayst slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a run but my head and my neck.
modern: Trust me, you could slide all the way from my shoulder to my heel taking no more of a running start than the distance between my head and my neck.

origin: A fire, good Curtis.
modern: Start the fire, good Curtis.

origin: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?
modern: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

origin: Oh, ay, Curtis, ay, and therefore fire, fire.
modern: Yes, yes, Curtis, so hurry up and start the fire.

origin: Cast on no water.
modern: Leave out the water.

origin: Is she so hot a shrew as she’s reported?
modern: Is she as fiery a shrew as they say?

origin: She was, good Curtis, before this frost.
modern: Well she was, good Curtis, before this frost.

origin: Why, thy horn is a foot, and so long am I, at the least.
modern: Your horn is a foot long, and I’m at least that size.

origin: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?
modern: So tell me, Grumio, how goes the world?

origin: Do thy duty, and have thy duty, for my master and mistress are almost frozen to death.
modern: Therefore, do your duty and take your reward, because my master and mistress are nearly frozen to death.

origin: There’s fire ready.
modern: The fire is ready.

origin: And therefore, good Grumio, the news.
modern: So go on, tell me the news.

origin: Why, therefore fire, for I have caught extreme cold.
modern: I think I’m getting delirious.

origin: Where’s the cook?
modern: Where’s the cook?

origin: Is supper ready, the house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept, the servingmen in their new fustian, their white stockings, and every officer his wedding garment on?
modern: Is supper ready?

origin: Be the Jacks fair within, the Jills fair without, the carpets laid, and everything in order?
modern: Are all the cups and glasses in their places, the tablecloths laid out—everything in order?

origin: For God’s sake, a pot of small ale.
modern: For God’s sake, would someone bring me a mug of beer!

origin: Will ’t please your Honor taste of these conserves?
modern: Would your Honor like to try this dried fruit?

origin: What raiment will your Honor wear today?
modern: What garment would your Honor like to wear today?

origin: I am Christophero Sly.
modern: I’m Christopher Sly.

origin: All ready.
modern: Everything’s ready.

origin: And therefore, I pray thee, news.
modern: So tell me what’s been going on.

origin: First, know my horse is tired, my master and mistress fallen out.
modern: Well, first of all, my horse is tired and my master and mistress have had a falling out.

origin: How?
modern: How?

origin: Out of their saddles into the dirt, and thereby hangs a tale.
modern: From their saddles into the dirt—but that’s another story.

origin: Let’s ha' ’t, good Grumio.
modern: Well, let’s have it, Grumio.

origin: Lend thine ear.
modern: Lean forward.

origin: Here.
modern: Here.

origin: There!
modern: There!

origin: This ’tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.
modern: This is to feel the news, not hear it.

origin: And therefore ’tis called a sensible tale.
modern: That’s what makes it “sensitive” news.

origin: And this cuff was but to knock at your ear and beseech list'ning.
modern: I was just knocking to see if anyone was home.

origin: Now I begin: Imprimis, we came down a foul hill, my master riding behind my mistress— Both of one horse?
modern: Now, I’ll begin: first, we came down a steep hill, my master riding behind my mistress— Both on one horse?

origin: What’s that to thee?
modern: What’s the difference?

origin: Why, a horse.
modern: Well, the difference of a horse!

origin: Tell thou the tale!
modern: It’s too bad.

origin: Ay, and that thou and the proudest of you all shall find when he comes home.
modern: Yes—as you and the rest will find out as soon as he’s home.

origin: But what talk I of this?
modern: But why am I telling you this?

origin: Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest.
modern: Get them in here—Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas, Philip, Walter, Sugarsop, and the rest.

origin: Let their heads be slickly combed, their blue coats brushed, and their garters of an indifferent knit.
modern: Tell them to slick down their hair, brush their blue coats, and make sure their socks match.

origin: Let them curtsy with their left legs, and not presume to touch a hair of my master’s horse-tail till they kiss their hands.
modern: Have them click their heels together and don’t dare touch a hair of the master’s horse’s tail till they kiss their hands.

origin: Are they all ready?
modern: Are they all ready?

origin: They are.
modern: They are.

origin: Call them forth.
modern: Get them in here.

origin: Why, she hath a face of her own.
modern: She already has a face.

origin: Who knows not that?
modern: Yeah, so?

origin: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance her.
modern: You just said they had to face her.

origin: I call them forth to credit her.
modern: I meant they had to give her credit.

origin: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.
modern: She’s not going to borrow money from them.

origin: Welcome home, Grumio.
modern: Welcome home, Grumio.

origin: How now, Grumio?
modern: What’s up, Grumio?

origin: What, Grumio!
modern: Hey, Grumio!

origin: Fellow Grumio!
modern: My man Grumio!

origin: How now, old lad?
modern: So what’s the story, old boy?

origin: E'en at hand, alighted by this.
modern: Any minute.

origin: Where be these knaves?
modern: Where are those bastards?

origin: Here, here, sir!
modern: Here, here, sir!

origin: Here, sir!
modern: Here, sir!

origin: Here, sir!
modern: Here, sir!

origin: Here, sir!
modern: Here, sir!

origin: Here, sir!
modern: Here, sir!

origin: Here, sir!” You loggerheaded and unpolished grooms!
modern: Here, sir!” You stupid, unpolished dolts!

origin: Where is the foolish knave I sent before?
modern: Where is the fool I sent on ahead?

origin: Here, sir, as foolish as I was before.
modern: Here, sir, as foolish as ever.

origin: You peasant swain!
modern: You unwashed farmworker!

origin: You whoreson malt-horse drudge!
modern: You bastard workhorse drudge!

origin: Did I not bid thee meet me in the park And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?
modern: Didn’t I tell you to meet me outside and bring these morons with you?

origin: Nathaniel’s coat, sir, was not fully made, And Gabriel’s pumps were all unpinked i' th' heel.
modern: Nathaniel’s coat was being fixed, sir.

origin: There was no link to color Peter’s hat, And Walter’s dagger was not come from sheathing.
modern: And Walter couldn’t get his dagger out of its sheath.

origin: There were none fine but Adam, Rafe, and Gregory.
modern: Only Adam, Rafe, and Gregory were ready.

origin: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
modern: Go, blockheads, go, and bring my supper to me.

origin: One, Kate, that you must kiss and be acquainted with.— Where are my slippers?
modern: Where are my slippers?

origin: Shall I have some water?— Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.— You whoreson villain!
modern: Can we have some water please here?— Come and wash, Kate, make yourself at home.

origin: Will you let it fall?
modern: Take it easy!

origin: Patience, I pray you!
modern: Please!

origin: Twas a fault unwilling.
modern: It was just an accident!

origin: Will you give thanks, sweet Kate, or else shall I?— What’s this?
modern: Will you say grace, sweet Kate, or shall I?—What is this?

origin: Mutton?
modern: Mutton?

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes.

origin: Who brought it?
modern: Who brought it out here?

origin: I.
modern: I did.

origin: What dogs are these!
modern: You bastards!

origin: Where is the rascal cook?
modern: Where is that moron of a cook?

origin: How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser And serve it thus to me that love it not?
modern: How dare you serve it to me this way!

origin: There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all!
modern: There, take it all back—plates, cups, the whole thing.

origin: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet.
modern: Please, dear, calm down.

origin: The meat was well, if you were so contented.
modern: The meat was fine if you wanted to eat it.

origin: I tell thee, Kate, ’twas burnt and dried away.
modern: And I’m telling you it was burnt and dried out.

origin: Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber.
modern: Come, I’ll show you your bridal chamber.

origin: Peter, didst ever see the like?
modern: Peter, did you ever see anything like it?

origin: He kills her in her own humor.
modern: He’s giving her a taste of her own medicine.

origin: Where is he?
modern: Where is he?

origin: Away, away, for he is coming hither!
modern: Look out, he’s coming!

origin: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And ’tis my hope to end successfully.
modern: Well, I’ve begun my reign with a carefully thought-out plan, and I have every hope of succeeding.

origin: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty, And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.
modern: My falcon is now hungry and unfed and must not be given enough to eat until she comes to me, for if her hunger is satisfied, she’ll pay no attention to the bait.

origin: Another way I have to man my haggard, To make her come and know her keeper’s call.
modern: I have another plan to make my bird come to me and recognize her owner’s call is to keep her from sleeping—

origin: That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
modern: the way trainers do with young hawks that flutter and flap and will not obey.

origin: She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.
modern: She had no food today and will have none.

origin: Last night she slept not, nor tonight she shall not.
modern: Last night she got no sleep, and she won’t get any tonight.

origin: As with the meat, some undeservèd fault I’ll find about the making of the bed, And here I’ll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.
modern: Just as I did with the meat, I’ll make up some problem with the way the bed is made, and throw the pillow one way and the cushion the other, and the blanket over here and the sheets over there.

origin: And, in conclusion, she shall watch all night, And if she chance to nod I’ll rail and brawl, And with the clamor keep her still awake.
modern: And if she starts to drop off, I’ll rant and yell until I wake her up.

origin: He that knows better how to tame a shrew, Now let him speak; ’tis charity to show.
modern: If anyone here knows a better way to tame a shrew, speak up, please.

origin: Is ’t possible, friend Litio, that mistress Bianca Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
modern: It would be much appreciated.

origin: What, master, read you?
modern: What are you reading, teacher?

origin: First resolve me that.
modern: Answer me that first.

origin: And may you prove, sir, master of your art.
modern: I hope you’re an expert in your field.

origin: I tell thee, Litio, this is wonderful!
modern: Let me come clean.

origin: Mistake no more.
modern: I’m not really Litio.

origin: Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.
modern: My name is Hortensio, sir.

origin: See how they kiss and court!
modern: Look how they kiss and carry on!

origin: Fie on her!
modern: The hell with her!

origin: See how beastly she doth court him!
modern: Look how she carries on with him!

origin: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
modern: It’s revolting!

origin: For me, that I may surely keep mine oath, I will be married to a wealthy widow, Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
modern: Well, to be on the safe side—so I don’t go back on my promise—I plan to get myself married to a wealthy widow within the next three days.

origin: And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.
modern: Farewell, then, Signior Lucentio.

origin: Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks, Shall win my love, and so I take my leave, In resolution as I swore before.
modern: From now on, goodness in women, not superficial beauty, will win my heart.

origin: What, would you make me mad?
modern: What, are you trying to make me crazy?

origin: Am not I Christopher Sly, old Sly’s son of Burton Heath, by birth a peddler, by education a cardmaker, by transmutation a bearherd, and now by present profession a tinker?
modern: I’m Christopher Sly, son of old Sly of Barton-on-Heath, a peddler by birth, a  Oh, this is why your poor wife is mourning!

origin: Oh, this is it that makes your servants droop!
modern: And this is why your servants hang their heads in sorrow!

origin: O noble lord, bethink thee of thy birth, Call home thy ancient thoughts from banishment, And banish hence these abject lowly dreams.
modern: Oh noble lord, consider your lineage.

origin: Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck.
modern: Look how your servants wait on you, each one ready to do whatever you command.

origin: Wilt thou have music?
modern: Would you care to hear some music?

origin: Hark!
modern: Listen!

origin: Apollo plays, And twenty cagèd nightingales do sing: Or wilt thou sleep?
modern: Do you want to sleep?

origin: We’ll have thee to a couch Softer and sweeter than the lustful bed On purpose trimmed up for Semiramis.
modern: We’ll have a couch made up that’s softer and more fragrant even than the bed of lustful

origin: Or wilt thou hunt?
modern: You’re busted.

origin: Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love, And have forsworn you with Hortensio.
modern: Hortensio and I have given you up.

origin: Tranio, you jest.
modern: You can’t mean it, Tranio!

origin: But have you both forsworn me?
modern: Have you both really given me up?

origin: Mistress, we have.
modern: Yes, ma'am, we have.

origin: Then we are rid of Litio.
modern: So Litio’s out of the picture.

origin: I' faith, he’ll have a lusty widow now That shall be wooed and wedded in a day.
modern: He’s going after a young widow.

origin: God give him joy!
modern: Well, good for him!

origin: Ay, and he’ll tame her.
modern: Yeah, and he’s going to tame her.

origin: He says so, Tranio?
modern: Is that what he says?

origin: The taming school?
modern: The taming school?

origin: What, is there such a place?
modern: Is there such a place?

origin: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
modern: Master, master, I’ve been on the lookout so long, I’m ready to fall down dead—but I’ve got one, finally!

origin: What is he, Biondello?
modern: What does he look like, Biondello?

origin: And what of him, Tranio?
modern: And what about him, Tranio?

origin: Take in your love, and then let me alone.
modern: Go, take your sweetheart and leave him to me.

origin: God save you, sir.
modern: May God keep you well, sir.

origin: You are welcome.
modern: This is it, for now.

origin: Of Mantua.
modern: Mantua.

origin: My life, sir!
modern: Killed?

origin: how, I pray?
modern: Why?

origin: For that goes hard.
modern: That would be a little extreme!

origin: Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua.
modern: It’s a capital offense for anyone from Mantua to come to Padua.

origin: Know you not the cause?
modern: Didn’t you know?

origin: Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
modern: It’s strange that you haven’t heard.

origin: Alas, sir, it is worse for me than so, For I have bills for money by exchange From Florence, and must here deliver them.
modern: I have promissory notes from Florence that I have to deliver.

origin: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been, Pisa renownèd for grave citizens.
modern: Oh yes, sir, I have often been to Pisa—Pisa, City of Wise Men.

origin: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.
modern: Oh sir, I accept.

origin: In all these circumstances I’ll instruct you.
modern: And I’ll be eternally grateful to you.

origin: No, no, forsooth, I dare not for my life.
modern: No, no, I can’t, really.

origin: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears.
modern: The more I suffer, the more spiteful he becomes.

origin: What, did he marry me to famish me?
modern: Did he marry me just to starve me?

origin: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity.
modern: And if they don’t find charity there, they find it someplace else.

origin: But I, who never knew how to entreat, Nor never needed that I should entreat, Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep, With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed.
modern: But I, who have never known how to beg and never had to beg, am starved for food, dizzy with lack of sleep, kept awake with curses and fed with brawling.

origin: And that which spites me more than all these wants, He does it under name of perfect love, As who should say, if I should sleep or eat, 'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.
modern: And what irks me more than all these things put together is that he does it under the pretense of love—as though for me to eat or sleep would bring on fatal illness or sudden death.

origin: What say you to a neat’s foot?
modern: What do you say to a calf’s foot?

origin: Tis passing good.
modern: Oh, lovely.

origin: I prithee let me have it.
modern: Can I have some?

origin: I fear it is too choleric a meat.
modern: I’m afraid it will  I’d love it.

origin: Good Grumio, fetch it me.
modern: Nice Grumio, bring me some.

origin: I cannot tell.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: I fear ’tis choleric.
modern: I’m afraid it will make you too hot, too.

origin: What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?
modern: What do you say to a piece of beef with mustard?

origin: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.
modern: Yes, but the mustard is probably too hot.

origin: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.
modern: Well then, the beef without the mustard.

origin: Nay then, I will not.
modern: Absolutely not.

origin: You shall have the mustard Or else you get no beef of Grumio.
modern: You’ll take the mustard or you’ll get no beef from Grumio.

origin: Then both, or one, or anything thou wilt.
modern: Then both, or one, or anything you like.

origin: Why then, the mustard without the beef.
modern: How about the mustard without the beef.

origin: Go, get thee gone, I say.
modern: Get out of here, you measly, lying wretch.

origin: Mistress, what cheer?
modern: Cheer up.

origin: Pluck up thy spirits.
modern: Give us a smile.

origin: Here love, thou seest how diligent I am, To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee.
modern: Look, love, see how devoted I am?

origin: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
modern: I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness deserves thanks.

origin: What, not a word?
modern: What, not a word?

origin: Nay, then thou lov’st it not And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
modern: I guess you don’t want it.

origin: Here, take away this dish.
modern: Here, take away the dish.

origin: I pray you, let it stand.
modern: Please, leave it here.

origin: I thank you, sir.
modern: Thank you, sir.

origin: Come, mistress Kate, I’ll bear you company.
modern: Come, mistress Kate, I’ll join you.

origin: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments.
modern: Now, tailor, let’s see what you’ve got.

origin: Lay forth the gown.
modern: Lay out the gown.

origin: What news with you, sir?
modern: What can I do for you, sir?

origin: Here is the cap your Worship did bespeak.
modern: Here is the cap your Worship ordered.

origin: Why, this was molded on a porringer!
modern: Why, this was modeled on a porridge bowl!

origin: A velvet dish!
modern: No, definitely not!

origin: Fie, fie, ’tis lewd and filthy!
modern: It’s cheap and nasty!

origin: Why, ’tis a cockle or a walnut shell, A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby’s cap.
modern: It’s like a cockleshell or a walnut shell, a joke, a prank, a doll’s cap.

origin: Away with it!
modern: Take it away.

origin: Come, let me have a bigger.
modern: Bring me a bigger one.

origin: I’ll have no bigger.
modern: I won’t have one any bigger.

origin: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.
modern: When you are gentle, you shall have one, too, and not till then.

origin: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak, And speak I will.
modern: Sir, I think I have the right to speak, and speak I certainly will.

origin: I am no child, no babe.
modern: I am not a child or an infant.

origin: Your betters have endured me say my mind, And if you cannot, best you stop your ears.
modern: Better men than you have heard me speak my mind, and if you can’t take it, then you’d better plug your ears.

origin: Why, thou say’st true.
modern: You know, you’re right.

origin: It is a paltry cap, A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie.
modern: It’s a measly little cap, a dessert crust, a plaything, a silk pie.

origin: I love thee well in that thou lik’st it not.
modern: I love you all the more for not liking it.

origin: Love me or love me not, I like the cap, And it I will have, or I will have none.
modern: I don’t care if you love me or not, I like the cap and I’ll have it or I won’t have any.

origin: Thy gown?
modern: Now, your gown?

origin: Why, ay.
modern: Yes, yes.

origin: Come, tailor, let us see ’t.
modern: Come, tailor, show it to us.

origin: O mercy, God!
modern: Merciful God!

origin: What’s this?
modern: What do you call this?

origin: A sleeve?
modern: A sleeve?

origin: Tis like a demi-cannon.
modern: It’s like a cannon.

origin: What, up and down, carved like an apple tart?
modern: Carved it up and down like an apple tart?

origin: Here’s snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber’s shop.
modern: Snip and snip and cut and slash—it’s got more holes than a sieve!

origin: Why, what i' devil’s name, tailor, call’st thou this?
modern: What in the world do you call this, tailor!

origin: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.
modern: You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style.

origin: Marry, and did.
modern: Certainly, I did.

origin: But if you be remembered, I did not bid you mar it to the time.
modern: But if you remember, I didn’t tell you to parody the style.

origin: I’ll none of it.
modern: I won’t take it.

origin: Hence, make your best of it.
modern: Do whatever you want with it.

origin: I never saw a better-fashioned gown, More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable.
modern: I never saw a better-designed gown, more elegant and pleasing and well made.

origin: Why, true, he means to make a puppet of thee.
modern: Yes, that’s it!

origin: Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
modern: It’s a lie, you thread, you thimble, you measurement!

origin: Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter cricket thou!
modern: You flea, you louse, you winter cricket!

origin: Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?
modern: Disrespected in my own house by a spool of thread!

origin: I tell thee, I, that thou hast marred her gown.
modern: I tell you, you’ve ruined her gown.

origin: Your Worship is deceived.
modern: It’s not true.

origin: The gown is made Just as my master had direction.
modern: The gown was made just as my master was directed.

origin: Grumio gave order how it should be done.
modern: Grumio gave the order for how it should be done.

origin: I gave him no order.
modern: I gave him no order.

origin: I gave him the stuff.
modern: I gave him the material.

origin: But how did you desire it should be made?
modern: But how did you want it made?

origin: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.
modern: With a needle and thread.

origin: But did you not request to have it cut?
modern: But didn’t you expect us to cut the cloth?

origin: Face not me.
modern: Well, don’t face off with me.

origin: Thou hast braved many men; brave not me.
modern: You have bested many things, well don’t try and best me.

origin: I will neither be faced nor braved.
modern: I will not be faced or bested.

origin: I say unto thee, I bid thy master cutout the gown, but I did not bid him cut it to pieces.
modern: I tell you I requested that your master cut out the gown, but I didn’t ask him to cut it all to pieces.

origin: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.
modern: Why, here is the order to prove it.

origin: Read it.
modern: Read it.

origin: The note lies in ’s throat, if he say I said so.
modern: The note is a big fat liar if it says I said so.

origin: Dost thou love pictures?
modern: Do you like pictures?

origin: Thou hast a lady far more beautiful Than any woman in this waning age.
modern: You have a noble wife who is much more beautiful than any other woman in this declining age.

origin: And till the tears that she hath shed for thee Like envious floods o'errun her lovely face, She was the fairest creature in the world— And yet she is inferior to none.
modern: Before she began shedding tears all over her lovely face, she was the fairest creature in the world—and even now she has no equal.

origin: I confess the cape.
modern: I admit the cape.

origin: I confess two sleeves.
modern: I admit two sleeves.

origin: Ay, there’s the villany.
modern: Ah, there’s the problem.

origin: Error i' the bill, sir, error i' the bill!
modern: Error in the bill, sir, error in the bill!

origin: I commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed up again, and that I’ll prove upon thee, though thy little finger be armed in a thimble.
modern: I ordered that the sleeves be cut out and sewed up again, and I’ll prove it in combat even if your little finger is armed with your thimble.

origin: I am for thee straight.
modern: I am ready for you.

origin: Take thou the bill, give me thy mete- yard, and spare not me.
modern: You take the bill and I’ll take your yardstick.

origin: God-a-mercy, Grumio!
modern: God have mercy, Grumio!

origin: Then he shall have no odds.
modern: He won’t have a chance.

origin: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.
modern: Well, sir, the gown is not for me.

origin: You are i' the right, sir, ’tis for my mistress.
modern: You are right, it’s for my mistress.

origin: Go, take it up unto thy master’s use.
modern: Go, take it away and let your master make whatever use of it he can.

origin: Villain, not for thy life!
modern: Certainly not!

origin: Take up my mistress' gown for thy master’s use!
modern: Take off my mistress' gown for your master’s use!

origin: Why, sir, what’s your conceit in that?
modern: Why, what’s the problem?

origin: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for.
modern: Oh, sir, the problem goes far deeper than you realize.

origin: Take up my mistress' gown to his master’s use!
modern: Take up my mistress' gown for his master’s use!

origin: O, fie, fie, fie!
modern: Oh, that’s disgusting!

origin: Well, come, my Kate.
modern: Ah well, my Kate.

origin: What, is the jay more precious than the lark Because his feathers are more beautiful?
modern: I mean, is the jay more precious than the lark because his feather is more beautiful?

origin: Or is the adder better than the eel Because his painted skin contents the eye?
modern: Is the snake better than the eel because the pattern on his back pleases the eye?

origin: Oh, no, good Kate.
modern: Hardly, Kate.

origin: If thou account’st it shame, lay it on me, And therefore frolic!
modern: If you regard it as shameful, put the shame on me.

origin: We will hence forthwith To feast and sport us at thy father’s house.
modern: We’re off to eat and whoop it up at your father’s house.

origin: I dare assure you, sir, ’tis almost two, And ’twill be supper time ere you come there.
modern: I hate to say it, but it’s almost two and we won’t get there before suppertime.

origin: It shall be seven ere I go to horse.
modern: It shall be seven o'clock before I get on my horse.

origin: Look what I speak, or do, or think to do, You are still crossing it.
modern: Whatever I say, or think, or do, you’re continually contradicting it.

origin: Sirs, let ’t alone.
modern: Sirs, never mind.

origin: I will not go today, and ere I do It shall be what o'clock I say it is.
modern: We won’t go today—or any day until it’s clear that it shall be whatever time I say it is.

origin: Ay, what else?
modern: Yes, certainly.

origin: and but I be deceived, Signior Baptista may remember me, Near twenty years ago, in Genoa, Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
modern: Unless I am mistaken, Signior Baptista may remember me from the Pegasus in Genoa, where we both stayed twenty years ago.

origin: I warrant you.
modern: Of course I will.

origin: But, sir, here comes your boy.
modern: But, sir, here comes your servant.

origin: Tut, fear not me.
modern: Don’t worry about me.

origin: I told him that your father was at Venice, And that you looked for him this day in Padua.
modern: I told him that your father was in Venice, and that you expected him to arrive in Padua today.

origin: Here comes Baptista.
modern: He gives BIONDELLO  Here comes Baptista.

origin: Set your countenance, sir.
modern: Places, everyone!

origin: Signior Baptista, you are happily met.— Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.
modern: Signior Baptista, I’m glad to see you.—Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of.

origin: I pray you stand good father to me now.
modern: I hope you’ll be a good father to me now.

origin: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
modern: Give me Bianca for my inheritance.

origin: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say.
modern: Sir, pardon me for what I am about to say.

origin: Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
modern: I appreciate your frankness and your brevity.

origin: Right true it is your son Lucentio here Doth love my daughter and she loveth him, Or both dissemble deeply their affections.
modern: It’s true that your son Lucentio here loves my daughter, and she loves him—or else they’re putting on quite an act.

origin: Your son shall have my daughter with consent.
modern: Your son will have my consent to marry my daughter.

origin: Not in my house, Lucentio, for you know Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants.
modern: Not in my house, Lucentio.

origin: Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still, And happily we might be interrupted.
modern: My servants might overhear, and old Gremio is still hanging around, so we might be interrupted.

origin: I pray the gods she may, with all my heart!
modern: I hope with all my heart she will!

origin: Cambio.
modern: Cambio.

origin: What sayest thou, Biondello?
modern: What is it, Biondello?

origin: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
modern: You saw my master wink and laugh at you?

origin: Biondello, what of that?
modern: What about it?

origin: I pray thee, moralize them.
modern: Please, educate me.

origin: Then thus: Baptista is safe, talking with the deceiving father of a deceitful son.
modern: He’s talking with the bogus father about the bogus son.

origin: And what of him?
modern: And so—?

origin: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.
modern: You are to bring his daughter to the supper.

origin: And then?
modern: And then?

origin: The old priest at Saint Luke’s Church is at your command at all hours.
modern: The old priest at Saint Luke’s Church is at your command at all hours.

origin: And what of all this?
modern: And what of all this?

origin: I cannot tell, except they are busied about a counterfeit assurance.
modern: I don’t know, except they are busy with some phony guarantee.

origin: Take you assurance of her cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum.
modern: So go and put your stamp on the girl.

origin: To th' church take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient honest witnesses.
modern: Go to the church: take the priest, the clerk, and some reasonably honest witnesses.

origin: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
modern: If this isn’t what you’ve been hoping for, I have no more to say except that you ought to say goodbye to Bianca forever.

origin: I knew a wench married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit, and so may you, sir.
modern: I knew a girl who was married in an afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley to stuff a rabbit.

origin: And so adieu, sir.
modern: Farewell, sir.

origin: My master hath appointed me to go to Saint Luke’s to bid the priest be ready to come against you come with your appendix.
modern: My master has instructed me to go to Saint Luke’s to tell the priest to be ready in case you should show up with your better half.

origin: She will be pleased.
modern: She will be pleased.

origin: Then wherefore should I doubt?
modern: Then why am I worried?

origin: It shall go hard if “Cambio” go without her.
modern: It will be hard if “Cambio” loses her.

origin: Come on, i' God’s name, once more toward our father’s.
modern: Come, let’s continue on toward your father’s house.

origin: Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!
modern: Good Lord, how bright and splendid is the moon tonight!

origin: The moon?
modern: The moon?

origin: The sun!
modern: You mean the sun!

origin: It is not moonlight now.
modern: It is not nighttime now.

origin: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
modern: I say it’s the moon that shines so bright.

origin: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.
modern: I know it’s the sun that shines so bright.

origin: Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s myself, It shall be moon, or star, or what I list, Or e'er I journey to your father’s house.
modern: Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s me, it will be moon or star or whatever I want before I’ll travel to your father’s house.

origin: I say it is the moon.
modern: I say it’s the moon.

origin: I know it is the moon.
modern: I know it’s the moon.

origin: Nay, then you lie.
modern: Well, you’re a liar, then.

origin: It is the blessèd sun.
modern: It’s the blessed sun.

origin: Then God be blessed, it is the blessèd sun.
modern: Then God be praised, it  Petruchio, do whatever you like.

origin: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.
modern: You’ve won.

origin: Well, forward, forward!
modern: Well, onward, then.

origin: Thus the bowl should run, And not unluckily against the bias.
modern: That’s how things should be—straight and smooth.

origin: But, soft!
modern: But, hang on!

origin: Company is coming here.
modern: I hear someone coming.

origin: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet, Whither away, or where is thy abode?
modern: Young budding virgin, fair and pure and sweet, where are you off to?

origin: Happy the parents of so fair a child.
modern: Your parents are lucky to have such a lovely child.

origin: Will ’t please your Mightiness to wash your hands?
modern: Is  Would your Mightiness care to wash his hands?

origin: O, how we joy to see your wit restored!
modern: We’re overjoyed to see you sane again.

origin: O, that once more you knew but what you are!
modern: If only you had a clearer memory of who you are!

origin: These fifteen years you have been in a dream Or, when you waked, so waked as if you slept.
modern: These past fifteen years you have been living in a dream, and even when you were awake, it was as though you slept.

origin: These fifteen years!
modern: Fifteen years!

origin: By my fay, a goodly nap.
modern: That’s some nap.

origin: But did I never speak of all that time?
modern: But I never spoke the whole time?

origin: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
modern: Oh yes, you spoke, my lord, but total nonsense.

origin: Why, sir, you know no house nor no such maid, Nor no such men as you have reckoned up, As Stephen Sly and old John Naps of Greece, And Peter Turph and Henry Pimpernell, And twenty more such names and men as these, Which never were, nor no man ever saw.
modern: But sir, there is no such house, no such maid, and no such men as you have dreamed up, like a certain Stephen Sly and one old John Naps of Greece, a Peter Turph, one “Henry Pimpernell,” and twenty more men of this sort—who never actually existed.

origin: Why, how now, Kate!
modern: Why, dear me, Kate!

origin: I hope thou art not mad.
modern: I hope you haven’t lost your mind.

origin: This is a man—old, wrinkled, faded, withered— And not a maiden, as thou say’st he is.
modern: This is not a maiden, as you say, but an old man—wrinkled, faded, and withered.

origin: Fair sir, and you, my merry mistress, That with your strange encounter much amazed me, My name is called Vincentio, my dwelling Pisa, And bound I am to Padua, there to visit A son of mine which long I have not seen.
modern: Well, sir, and you, witty lady, who gave me quite a turn with your strange talk, my name is Vincentio, my hometown Pisa, and I am traveling to Padua to visit a son of mine whom I haven’t seen in a long while.

origin: What is his name?
modern: What is his name?

origin: Lucentio, gentle sir.
modern: Lucentio, sir.

origin: Happily met, the happier for thy son.
modern: A fortunate coincidence—more fortunate for your son.

origin: The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman, Thy son by this hath married.
modern: The sister of my wife, this lady here, is married to your son.

origin: Wonder not Nor be grieved.
modern: And there’s no need for wonder or worry.

origin: Let me embrace with old Vincentio, And wander we to see thy honest son, Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.
modern: Let me embrace the father of Lucentio, and then we’ll journey on to see your son, who will rejoice at your arrival.

origin: I do assure thee, father, so it is.
modern: I assure you, sir, it’s true.

origin: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
modern: Well, Petruchio, all this is very encouraging.

origin: Softly and swiftly, sir, for the priest is ready.
modern: The priest is already there.

origin: I fly, Biondello.
modern: We’re off, Biondello.

origin: Nay, faith, I’ll see the church a' your back, and then come back to my master’s as soon as I can.
modern: I’ll see them safely married first and then hurry back to my master’s.

origin: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while.
modern: I wonder why Cambio hasn’t shown up in all this time.

origin: Sir, here’s the door.
modern: Here is the door, sir.

origin: This is Lucentio’s house.
modern: This is Lucentio’s house.

origin: My father’s bears more toward the marketplace.
modern: My father-in-law lives closer to the marketplace.

origin: Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.
modern: That’s where I’m going now, so I’ll leave you here.

origin: You shall not choose but drink before you go.
modern: You must not go without having a drink first.

origin: They’re busy within.
modern: They’re pretty busy in there.

origin: You were best knock louder.
modern: You’d better knock louder.

origin: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?
modern: Is Signior Lucentio at home, sir?

origin: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two to make merry withal?
modern: What if a fellow were bringing him a couple of hundred pounds to toss around?

origin: Hope I may choose, sir.
modern: I believe I have some choice in the matter, sir.

origin: Come hither, you rogue!
modern: Come here, you wretch!

origin: What, have you forgot me?
modern: What, have you forgotten me?

origin: Forgot you!
modern: Forgotten you!

origin: No, sir.
modern: No, sir.

origin: I could not forget you, for I never saw you before in all my life.
modern: I could not forget you, since I never saw you before in my life.

origin: What, my old worshipful old master?
modern: My honorable, reverend master?

origin: Yes, marry, sir.
modern: Yes, of course.

origin: See where he looks out of the window.
modern: There he is at the window.

origin: Is ’t so, indeed.
modern: Is that so?

origin: Help, help, help!
modern: Help, help, help!

origin: Here’s a madman will murder me.
modern: This madman will murder me.

origin: Oh, I am undone, I am undone!
modern: How dare I?

origin: What, is the man lunatic?
modern: How dare    What, is the man crazy?

origin: Thy father!
modern: Your father!

origin: O villain!
modern: Why, you scoundrel!

origin: He is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
modern: Your father is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

origin: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir.
modern: You’re wrong, sir, very wrong.

origin: Pray, what do you think is his name?
modern: Why, what do you imagine his name to be?

origin: His name!
modern: His name!

origin: Lucentio!
modern: Lucentio!

origin: Oh, he hath murdered his master!
modern: Oh God, he’s murdered his master!

origin: O my son, my son!
modern: Oh, my son, my son!

origin: Tell me, thou villain, where is my son Lucentio?
modern: Tell me, you monster, where is my son Lucentio?

origin: Carry this mad knave to the jail.—Father Baptista, I charge you see that he be forthcoming.
modern: Take this mad wretch to jail.—Father-in-law Baptista, will you see that he’s available to appear in court?

origin: Carry me to the jail?
modern: Take me off to jail?

origin: He shall not go to prison.
modern: He mustn’t go to prison.

origin: Talk not, Signior Gremio.
modern: Be quiet, Signior Gremio.

origin: I say he shall go to prison.
modern: I say he shall go to prison.

origin: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in this business.
modern: Be careful, Signior Baptista, lest you be made the dupe in this business.

origin: I dare swear this is the right Vincentio.
modern: I could swear this is the real Vincentio.

origin: Nay, I dare not swear it.
modern: Well, no, not literally.

origin: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.
modern: No, I know that you’re Signior Lucentio.

origin: Away with the dotard!
modern: Away with the doddering fool!

origin: To the jail with him!
modern: Take him off to jail!

origin: O!
modern: We’re ruined!

origin: We are spoiled and yonder he is!
modern: There he is!

origin: Pardon, sweet father.
modern: Pardon, dear father.

origin: Lives my sweet son?
modern: Dear son, you’re alive!

origin: Pardon, dear father.
modern: Pardon us, dear father.

origin: How hast thou offended?
modern: What have you done?

origin: Where is Lucentio?
modern: Where is Lucentio?

origin: Here’s Lucentio, right son to the right Vincentio, That have by marriage made thy daughter mine While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.
modern: I have made your daughter mine by marriage while false impressions blinded your eyes.

origin: Here’s packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!
modern: We’ve all been duped.

origin: Where is that damnèd villain, Tranio, That faced and braved me in this matter so?
modern: Where is that damned wretch, Tranio, who defied me in such a disgraceful manner?

origin: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?
modern: Say, isn’t this the Latin master Cambio?

origin: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.
modern: Cambio is transformed into Lucentio.

origin: Love wrought these miracles.
modern: It was love that performed these miracles.

origin: Bianca’s love Made me exchange my state with Tranio, While he did bear my countenance in the town, And happily I have arrivèd at the last Unto the wishèd haven of my bliss.
modern: Bianca’s love made me trade places with Tranio while he masqueraded as me around town.

origin: What Tranio did, myself enforced him to.
modern: What Tranio did, he did at my command.

origin: Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.
modern: So pardon him, dear father, for my sake.

origin: I’ll slit the villain’s nose that would have sent me to the jail.
modern: No, I’ll slit the nose of the villain who would have sent me to jail.

origin: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?
modern: But sir, have you married my daughter without my consent?

origin: Fear not, Baptista, we will content you.
modern: Don’t worry, Baptista, you’ll be perfectly satisfied.

origin: Go to.
modern: You’ll see.

origin: My cake is dough, but I’ll in among the rest, Out of hope of all but my share of the feast.
modern: All I can hope for now is a share of the feast.

origin: Husband, let’s follow to see the end of this ado.
modern: Let’s follow them to see how this turns out.

origin: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
modern: First kiss me, Kate, and then we will.

origin: What, in the midst of the street?
modern: What, here in the middle of the street?

origin: What, art thou ashamed of me?
modern: Are you ashamed of me?

origin: No, sir, God forbid, but ashamed to kiss.
modern: But I’m ashamed to kiss, sir.

origin: Why, then let’s home again.
modern: All right then, back home we go.

origin: Nay, I will give thee a kiss.
modern: No, wait.

origin: Is not this well?
modern: I  Isn’t this good?

origin: Come, my sweet Kate.
modern: Come, my sweet Kate.

origin: Better once than never, for never too late.
modern: Better late than never—and it’s never too late to change.

origin: Now Lord be thanked for my good amends!
modern: Well, thank God I’m cured!

origin: Amen.
modern: Amen.

origin: I thank thee.
modern: I thank you all.

origin: Thou shalt not lose by it.
modern: You won’t regret this.

origin: How fares my noble lord?
modern: How is my noble lord?

origin: Marry, I fare well, For here is cheer enough.
modern: This is all quite pleasant.

origin: Where is my wife?
modern: Where is my wife?

origin: Here, noble lord.
modern: Here, noble lord.

origin: What is thy will with her?
modern: What is your wish with regard to her?

origin: Are you my wife and will not call me “husband”?
modern: You call yourself my wife, yet you don’t call me “husband”?

origin: My men should call me “lord.” I am your goodman.
modern: It’s my men who should call me “lord.” I’m your man, your fellow.

origin: My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine.
modern: My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, while I with equal affection welcome yours.

origin: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer.
modern: This last course here is for closing up the stomach after great feasting.

origin: Pray you, sit down, For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
modern: Now everyone be seated, as this is the part where we sit and chat as well as eat.

origin: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!
modern: All we do is sit and sit and eat and eat.

origin: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.
modern: I wish that were true for both our sakes!

origin: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.
modern: Hortensio

origin: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
modern: That’s very sensible, but you missed my sense: I meant Hortensio is afraid of you.

origin: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.
modern: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning.

origin: Roundly replied.
modern: A very candid reply.

origin: Mistress, how mean you that?
modern: What’s that supposed to mean?

origin: Thus I conceive by him.
modern: That’s what I conceive of him.

origin: Very well mended.
modern: Nice save!

origin: Kiss him for that, good widow.
modern: Kiss him for that, good widow.

origin: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round”— I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.
modern: He who is dizzy thinks the world is spinning”—please, tell me what you meant by that.

origin: Your husband being troubled with a shrew Measures my husband’s sorrow by his woe.
modern: Your husband, being saddled with a shrew, projects his own suffering onto my husband.

origin: And now you know my meaning.
modern: And now you know my meaning.

origin: A very mean meaning.
modern: A very nasty meaning.

origin: Right, I mean you.
modern: My meaning  And I

origin: To her, widow!
modern: You tell her, widow!

origin: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.
modern: I’ll bet you a hundred marks, my Kate puts her flat on her back.

origin: That’s my office.
modern: Well, that’s really my job.

origin: Spoke like an officer!
modern: Well said!

origin: Ha' to thee, lad!
modern: Here’s to you!

origin: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
modern: What do you think of these quick-witted folks, Gremio?

origin: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.
modern: They certainly do like to butt heads!

origin: Ay, but not frighted me.
modern: Yes, but not out of fear.

origin: Therefore I’ll sleep again.
modern: I’ll go back to sleep now.

origin: Nay, that you shall not.
modern: No, you shall not.

origin: Am I your bird?
modern: I’ll

origin: She hath prevented me.
modern: Well, she got away.

origin: Here, Signior Tranio, This bird you aimed at, though you hit her not.— Therefore a health to all that shot and missed.
modern: Signior Tranio, you also took aim at that bird, though you didn’t hit her.—So here’s a health to all who’ve shot and missed.

origin: A good swift simile, but something currish.
modern: A witty if a cynical reply.

origin: Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself.
modern: It’s good you hunted for yourself, sir.

origin: Tranio hits you now.
modern: Tranio got you that time.

origin: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
modern: I thank you for that quip, good Tranio.

origin: He has a little galled me, I confess.
modern: He’s made me a little sore, I’ll admit.

origin: And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maimed you two outright.
modern: But since the gibe glanced off me, ten to one it hit you both straight on.

origin: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
modern: Seriously, though, son Petruchio, I think you have the most thoroughgoing shrew of us all.

origin: Well, I say no.
modern: Well, I disagree.

origin: Content.
modern: Agreed.

origin: What’s the wager?
modern: What’s the bet?

origin: Twenty crowns.
modern: Twenty crowns.

origin: Twenty crowns?
modern: Twenty crowns?

origin: I’ll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.
modern: I’d wager twenty times as much on my wife.

origin: A hundred then.
modern: A hundred then.

origin: Content.
modern: Agreed.

origin: A match!
modern: Good!

origin: Tis done.
modern: It’s a bet.

origin: Who shall begin?
modern: Who should begin?

origin: That will I.
modern: I will.

origin: Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
modern: Biondello, go and tell your mistress to come to me.

origin: I go.
modern: Here I go.

origin: Son, I’ll be your half Bianca comes.
modern: Son, I’ll stake you half that Bianca comes.

origin: I’ll have no halves.
modern: I’ll have no halves.

origin: How!
modern: What!

origin: She’s busy, and she cannot come!” Is that an answer?
modern: She’s busy and cannot come!” Is that an answer?

origin: Ay, and a kind one too.
modern: Yes, and a nice one at that.

origin: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.
modern: Pray God your wife doesn’t send you a worse one.

origin: I hope better.
modern: I’m hoping for better.

origin: Now, where’s my wife?
modern: So, where’s my wife?

origin: She says you have some goodly jest in hand.
modern: She says she thinks this is a prank.

origin: She will not come.
modern: She will not come.

origin: She bids you come to her.
modern: She says that you should come to her.

origin: Worse and worse.
modern: Worse and worse!

origin: I know her answer.
modern: She  I can guess her answer.

origin: What?
modern: What?

origin: She will not.
modern: She will not.

origin: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!
modern: By all that’s holy, here comes Katherina!

origin: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?
modern: You sent for me, sir?

origin: Where is your sister, and Hortensio’s wife?
modern: Where are your sister and Hortensio’s wife?

origin: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.
modern: They sit chatting by the parlor fire.

origin: Go fetch them hither.
modern: Go bring them here.

origin: If they deny to come, Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands.
modern: If they refuse to come, get physical—use a whip if you have to, but get them out here to their husbands.

origin: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.
modern: This is a miracle, if you talk of miracles.

origin: And so it is.
modern: It is.

origin: I wonder what it bodes.
modern: I wonder what it means.

origin: Marry, peace it bodes, and love, and quiet life, And awful rule, and right supremacy, And, to be short, what not that’s sweet and happy?
modern: It means peace and love and a quiet life, supremacy based on reverence and profound respect, and—not to go on and on about it—everything that’s sweet and happy.

origin: Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
modern: May good fortune come to you, good Petruchio!

origin: The wager thou hast won, and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns, Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed as she had never been.
modern: You’ve won the wager, and I will add twenty thousand crowns to what they owe you.

origin: See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion.— Katherine, that cap of yours becomes you not.
modern: Look, here she comes, with your ungovernable wives in tow, like prisoners of her womanly persuasion.—Katherine, that cap of yours doesn’t look good on you.

origin: Off with that bauble, throw it underfoot.
modern: Take it off and throw it on the ground.

origin: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
modern: Lord, may I never see a day of trouble until the day I let someone treat me like that.

origin: Fie!
modern: For shame!

origin: What a foolish duty call you this?
modern: What kind of loyalty is this?

origin: I would your duty were as foolish too.
modern: I wish your loyalty were as foolish.

origin: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime.
modern: The wisdom of your loyalty, fair Bianca, has cost me a hundred crowns since dinner.

origin: The more fool you for laying on my duty.
modern: The more fool you for betting on my loyalty.

origin: We will have no telling.
modern: There will be no lecture.

origin: She shall not.
modern: She shall not.

origin: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.
modern: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.

origin: Fie, fie!
modern: Girls, girls!

origin: Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.
modern: This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord, your king, your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land.

origin: Such duty as the subject owes the prince, Even such a woman oweth to her husband.
modern: A woman owes her husband the same loyalty a subject owes his king.

origin: And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
modern: And when she is peevish and perverse, sullen, sour, and disobedient to his honest wishes, what is she but a loathsome, warlike rebel and an ungrateful traitor to her loving lord?

origin: I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway When they are bound to serve, love, and obey.
modern: I am ashamed that women are so foolish as to declare war when they should plead on their knees for peace, that they seek authority, supremacy, and power when they are under an obligation to serve, love, and obey.

origin: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?
modern: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unfit for toil and trouble in the world, if not so that our soft qualities and our hearts should agree with our external parts?

origin: Come, come, you froward and unable worms!
modern: Come, come, you weak, ungovernable worms!

origin: My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown.
modern: My spirit has been as proud as each of yours, my courage as great, and my reason perhaps even better suited to bandy words back and forth and exchange frown for frown.

origin: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
modern: But now I see our weapons are like straws, our strength like a straw’s weakness, and our weakness past comparison, so that we seem to be the thing we most are not.

origin: Come on and kiss me, Kate.
modern: Come on and kiss me, Kate.

origin: Tis a good hearing when children are toward.
modern: It’s nice to see children playing well together.

origin: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.
modern: But not so nice when women misbehave.

origin: Come, Kate, we’ll to bed.
modern: Come, Kate, let’s go to bed.

origin: We three are married, but you two are sped.
modern: We three are married, but you two are defeated.

origin: Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
modern: It’s amazing, if I may say so, that she let herself be tamed.

origin: Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed And slept above some fifteen year or more.
modern: Madam wife, they say I’ve been dreaming or asleep for more than fifteen years.

origin: Ay, and the time seems thirty unto me, Being all this time abandoned from your bed.
modern: Yes, and it seemed twice as long to me, having been kept from your bed that whole time.

origin: Tis much.—Servants, leave me and her alone.
modern: That’s too long.—Servants, leave her and me alone.

origin: Madam, undress you and come now to bed.
modern: Now, madam, undress and come to bed.

origin: Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you To pardon me yet for a night or two, Or if not so, until the sun be set.
modern: Thrice noble lord, I beg you to excuse me for another night or two—or at least until nightfall.

origin: For your physicians have expressly charged, In peril to incur your former malady, That I should yet absent me from your bed.
modern: Your doctors have expressly forbidden me to sleep with you, as there’s a risk that you might have a relapse.

origin: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
modern: I hope this explanation will stand as my excuse.

origin: Ay, it stands so that I may hardly tarry so long.
modern: I’m not sure I can wait that long.

origin: But I would be loath to fall into my dreams again.
modern: Still, I’d hate to see my former dreams return.

origin: Your Honor’s players, hearing your amendment, Are come to play a pleasant comedy, For so your doctors hold it very meet, Seeing too much sadness hath congealed your blood, And melancholy is the nurse of frenzy.
modern: So I  Your Honor’s actors, hearing of your recovery, have come to perform a pleasing comedy for you—and your doctors approve wholeheartedly.

origin: Therefore they thought it good you hear a play And frame your mind to mirth and merriment, Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.
modern: So they think it’s a good idea for you to watch a play and direct your thoughts toward laughter and merriment—two strong preventive medicines that foster long life.

origin: Let them play it.
modern: Okay, bring on the play.

origin: What, household stuff?
modern: What, like stuff from a house?

origin: It is a kind of history.
modern: No, it’s a story.

origin: Well, we’ll see ’t.
modern: Well, let’s watch it.

origin: We shall ne'er be younger.
modern: We’re not getting any younger.

origin: Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens, Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
modern: I was born in Pisa, famous for its serious citizens, like my father before me; my father, Vincentio, a successful, world-traveled merchant, was one of the

origin: I’ll pheeze you, in faith.
modern: I’ll fix you, I swear.

origin: A pair of stocks, you rogue!
modern: You thug!

origin: Y'are a baggage, the Slys are no rogues.
modern: Read your history!

origin: Therefore  You will not pay for the glasses you have burst?
modern: We You won’t pay for the glasses you smashed?

origin: No, not a denier.
modern: No, not a penny.

origin: Go by, Saint Jeronimy.
modern: Get out of my face.

origin: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
modern: Go play with yourself.

origin: I know my remedy.
modern: I know my rights.

origin: I’ll not budge an inch, boy.
modern: I’m not moving an inch, pal.

origin: Let him come, and kindly.
modern: Let them come—I don’t care.

origin: Gramercies, Tranio, well dost thou advise.
modern: That’s good advice.

origin: But stay awhile.
modern: Wait!

origin: What company is this?
modern: Who are all these people?

origin: Master, some show to welcome us to town.
modern: Maybe it’s a parade to welcome us to town, master.

origin: I' faith, sir, you shall never need to fear.
modern: Don’t worry, I couldn’t care less.

origin: But if it were, doubt not her care should be To comb your noddle with a three-legged stool And paint your face and use you like a fool.
modern: The only possible interest I could take in you would be to hit you on the head with a stool, paint your face with blood, and make a fool out of you.

origin: From all such devils, good Lord, deliver us!
modern: May the good Lord keep me safe from all women like her!

origin: And me too, good Lord!
modern: Me too, Lord!

origin: Maid’s mild behavior and sobriety.
modern: What a spoiled little brat.

origin: Sister, content you in my discontent.— Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe.
modern: Sister, be happy in my unhappiness.—Sir, I will humbly obey you.

origin: My books and instruments shall be my company, On them to look and practice by myself.
modern: I’ll take comfort in my books and music, reading and practicing my instruments.

origin: Hark, Tranio!
modern: Listen Tranio!

origin: Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?
modern: That’s  Signior Baptista, will you really be this cruel?

origin: Why will you mew her up, Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell And make her bear the penance of her tongue?
modern: Why are you locking her away because of this fiend from hell, Signor Baptista?

origin: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments, and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.
modern: And because I know how fond she is of music, playing her instruments, and poetry, I plan to hire live-in tutors for her.

origin: And so farewell.—Katherina, you may stay, For I have more to commune with Bianca.
modern: Katherina, you may stay.

origin: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
modern: I don’t think so!

origin: What, shall I be appointed hours as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?
modern: Am I to be dictated to, like a child?

origin: You may go to the devil’s dam!
modern: You can go straight to hell!

origin: Farewell.
modern: So long.

origin: Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both, that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca’s love, to labor and effect one thing specially.
modern: That is, if we ever want to return to being rivals for Bianca’s love.

origin: What’s that, I pray?
modern: And that would be—?

origin: Marry, sir, to get a husband for her sister.
modern: To find a husband for her sister.

origin: A husband?
modern: A husband?

origin: A devil!
modern: You mean a devil!

origin: I say a husband.
modern: I mean a husband.

origin: I say a devil.
modern: I say a devil.

origin: Think’st thou, Hortensio, though her father be very rich, any man is so very a fool to be married to hell?
modern: Do you really think there’s a man fool enough to marry into hell—however rich the father is?

origin: Tush, Gremio.
modern: Oh, I don’t know.

origin: Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.
modern: Guys who’d take her with all her faults, provided there were enough money involved.

origin: I cannot tell.
modern: I don’t know.

origin: How say you, Signior Gremio?
modern: What do you say, Signior Gremio?

origin: I am agreed, and would I had given him the best horse inv Padua to begin his wooing that would thoroughly woo her, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her!
modern: This imaginary suitor for Katherina—I’d buy him the best horse in Padua if he’d get here quickly, woo her, marry her, take her to bed, and rid the house of her.

origin: Come on.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?
modern: Sir, is it possible that a person could fall in love so suddenly?

origin: O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never thought it possible or likely.
modern: Oh, Tranio, until it happened to me, I never would have thought it possible.

origin: Affection is not rated from the heart.
modern: The heart won’t be reasoned with.

origin: If love have touched you, naught remains but so:   Gramercies, lad, go forward.
modern: If love has touched you, love has touched you—end of story.

origin: This contents.
modern: Yes, you’re right.

origin: The rest will comfort, for thy counsel’s sound.
modern: Please go on.

origin: Master, you looked so longly on the maid, Perhaps you marked not what’s the pith of all.
modern: I feel better already, and I know there’s more good advice where that came from.

origin: Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.
modern: Master, you were so focused on the girl herself, I wonder if you missed the main point here.

origin: Saw you no more?
modern: Oh no!

origin: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air.
modern: Tranio, I saw her coral-pink lips move and perfume the air with her breath.

origin: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel father’s he!
modern: Oh, Tranio, what a cruel father he is.

origin: But art thou not advised, he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
modern: Still, did you notice how ready he was to hire good tutors for her?

origin: Ay, marry, am I, sir; and now ’tis plotted!
modern: I did—and now I’ve got it!

origin: I have it, Tranio!
modern: Tranio, I think I’ve got it!

origin: Master, for my hand, Both our inventions meet and jump in one.
modern: I’ll bet we’re both thinking the same thing, master.

origin: Tell me thine first.
modern: Tell me your idea first.

origin: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That’s your device.
modern: You will pretend to be a schoolmaster and offer to teach the girl.

origin: It is.
modern: It is.

origin: May it be done?
modern: Do you think it would work?

origin: Not possible.
modern: No, not a chance.

origin: Tis hatched, and shall be so.
modern: Enough!

origin: When Biondello comes, he waits on thee, But I will charm him first to keep his tongue.
modern: It’s obvious:  Here comes Biondello.

origin: Where have I been?
modern: Where have you been, boy?

origin: Nay, how now, where are you?
modern: Where have  Come here, boy.

origin: Sirrah, come hither: ’tis no time to jest, And therefore frame your manners to the time.
modern: It’s no time for jokes: sober up.

origin: You understand me?
modern: Understand?

origin: Aye, sir.
modern: Of course, sir.

origin: And not a jot of “Tranio” in your mouth.
modern: And you’re not to utter a syllable of Tranio’s name.

origin: Would I were so too.
modern: Wish I could say the same.

origin: So could I, faith, boy, to have the next wish after, That Lucentio indeed had Baptista’s youngest daughter.
modern: I’d second your wish if it automatically meant that Lucentio could have Baptista’s youngest daughter.

origin: But, sirrah, not for my sake, but your master’s, I advise You use your manners discreetly in all kind of companies.
modern: This is for your master’s sake, not mine.

origin: When I am alone, why then I am Tranio; But in all places else, your master Lucentio.
modern: When we’re by ourselves you can call me “Tranio.” Everywhere else, address me as your master Lucentio.

origin: Tranio, let’s go.
modern: Tranio, let’s go.

origin: One thing more rests, that thyself execute, to make one among these wooers.
modern: One last thing, and this is up to you.

origin: If thou ask me why, sufficeth my reasons are both good and weighty.
modern: You’ll have to woo Bianca like the rest.

origin: My lord, you nod.
modern: Don’t ask why.

origin: You do not mind the play.
modern: No, no.

origin: A good matter, surely.
modern: Very impressive.

origin: Comes there any more of it?
modern: Is there any more, or is that it?

origin: Tis a very excellent piece of work, madam lady.
modern: And what an excellent piece of work it is, too, madam lady!

origin: Would ’twere done.
modern: I wish it were over.

origin: Huntsman, I charge thee, tender well my hounds.
modern: Huntsman, look after my hounds.

origin: Breathe Merriman, the poor cur is embossed, And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.
modern: Let Merriman catch his breath—the poor dog’s foaming at the mouth.

origin: Why, Belman is as good as he, my lord.
modern: I think Belman is just as good, my lord.

origin: Trust me, I take him for the better dog.
modern: I swear he’s the better dog.

origin: Thou art a fool.
modern: You’re a fool.

origin: If Echo were as fleet, I would esteem him worth a dozen such.
modern: If Echo were as fast, he would be worth a dozen like Belman.

origin: But sup them well and look unto them all.
modern: But give them all a good dinner and look after them well.

origin: Tomorrow I intend to hunt again.
modern: I’ll go hunting again tomorrow, I think.

origin: I will, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

origin: What’s here?
modern: What’s this?

origin: One dead, or drunk?
modern: A drunkard or a corpse?

origin: See, doth he breathe?
modern: Check and see if he’s breathing.

origin: He breathes, my lord.
modern: He is, my lord.

origin: Were he not warmed with ale, This were a bed but cold to sleep so soundly.
modern: But this would be too cold a place to sleep if he hadn’t warmed himself with ale.

origin: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!
modern: Alas, grim death, how vile and ugly your near-twin, sleep, is!

origin: Sirs, I will practice on this drunken man.
modern: What do you think?

origin: Verona, for a while I take my leave, To see my friends in Padua, but of all My best belovèd and approvèd friend, Hortensio.
modern: I’m off to visit my friends in Padua—particularly my best friend Hortensio.

origin: And I trow this is his house.
modern: And I think this is his house.

origin: Here, sirrah Grumio.
modern: Here, you there, Grumio.

origin: Knock, I say.
modern: Knock.

origin: Knock, sir?
modern: Knock, sir?

origin: Whom should I knock?
modern: Whom should I knock?

origin: Is there any man has rebused your Worship?
modern: Has anyone offended your Worship?

origin: Knock you here, sir?
modern: Moron!

origin: Villain, I say, knock me at this gate And rap me well, or I’ll knock your knave’s pate.
modern: I’m telling you to make a fist and pound.

origin: My master is grown quarrelsome.
modern: My master is being difficult.

origin: How now, what’s the matter?
modern: Say, what’s the trouble?

origin: My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio?
modern: If it isn’t my old friend Grumio—and my dear friend Petruchio!

origin: How do you all at Verona?
modern: How’s everyone in Verona?

origin: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?
modern: Hortensio, have you come to break up the fight?

origin: Nay, ’tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin.
modern: I don’t care what he told you in Latin.

origin: I bade the rascal knock upon your gate And could not get him for my heart to do it.
modern: I told him to knock at your gate and for the life of me could not get him to do it.

origin: Knock at the gate?
modern: Knock at the gate?

origin: O heavens!
modern: Oh, for Pete’s sake!

origin: Spake you not these words plain: “Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly”?
modern: Didn’t you clearly say “Knock,” “pound,” and “put your fists to work”?

origin: And come you now with “knocking at the gate”?
modern: Now you say it was “Knock at the gate”?

origin: Petruchio, patience.
modern: I’m warning you.

origin: I am Grumio’s pledge.
modern: Easy, Petruchio.

origin: Why, this' a heavy chance ’twixt him and you, Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.
modern: I’ll vouch for Grumio.

origin: And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?
modern: Now, my dear friend, what lucky wind blows you in from Verona?

origin: Such wind as scatters young men through the world To seek their fortunes farther than at home, Where small experience grows.
modern: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world, encouraging them to seek their fortunes some place other than home, where there’s little to be found in the way of experience.

origin: Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home, And so am come abroad to see the world.
modern: I have money in my purse and property at home, so I’m off to see the world.

origin: Thou’dst thank me but a little for my counsel; And yet I’ll promise thee she shall be rich, And very rich.
modern: I doubt you’d thank me in the end, but she’s rich, all right, very rich.

origin: But thou'rt too much my friend, And I’ll not wish thee to her.
modern: But you’re too good a friend for me to wish her on you.

origin: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.
modern: Hortensio, good friends like us can get by on a few words.

origin: I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough, and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
modern: I can help you find a wife who’s rich, young, beautiful, and reared in a manner fit for a gentlewoman.

origin: Her only fault, and that is faults enough, Is that she is intolerable curst, And shrewd and froward, so beyond all measure That, were my state far worser than it is, I would not wed her for a mine of gold.
modern: Her only flaw—and it’s a big one—is that she’s unbearable, a total witch, so much so that I wouldn’t think of marrying her myself, not even if I were in a worse fix than I am, not for a whole goldmine.

origin: Hortensio, peace.
modern: Hush, Hortensio.

origin: Thou know’st not gold’s effect.
modern: You don’t know what money can buy.

origin: Her father is Baptista Minola, An affable and courteous gentleman.
modern: Her father is Baptista Minola, a pleasant and courteous gentleman.

origin: Her name is Katherina Minola, Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.
modern: Her name is Katherina Minola, famous throughout Padua for her scolding tongue.

origin: I know her father, though I know not her, And he knew my deceasèd father well.
modern: I don’t know her, but I know her father and he knew mine well.

origin: I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her, And therefore let me be thus bold with you To give you over at this first encounter, Unless you will accompany me thither.
modern: I won’t sleep until I see her, Hortensio.

origin: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.
modern: Wait, Petruchio, I should go with you.

origin: He hath the jewel of my life in hold, His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca, And her withholds from me and other more, Suitors to her and rivals in my love, Supposing it a thing impossible, For those defects I have before rehearsed, That ever Katherina will be wooed.
modern: His youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca, is the jewel of my life, and he keeps her hidden away from me and other rivals for her hand.

origin: Katherine the curst!” A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
modern: Katherine the shrew!” That’s the worst thing you can call a young woman.

origin: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace, And offer me disguised in sober robes To old Baptista as a schoolmaster Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca, That so I may, by this device at least, Have leave and leisure to make love to her And, unsuspected, court her by herself.
modern: Now my friend Petruchio will help me out, presenting me to old Baptista as a schoolmaster for Bianca well-versed in music.

origin: Here’s no knavery!
modern: I’ll disguise myself in somber robes.

origin: Master, master, look about you.
modern: Oh,  Master, master, look!

origin: Who goes there, ha?
modern: Who are these people?

origin: Peace, Grumio.
modern: Hush, Grumio.

origin: It is the rival of my love.
modern: It is my rival for Bianca.

origin: Petruchio, stand by a while.
modern: Petruchio, let’s stand over here awhile.

origin: O this learning, what a thing it is!
modern: Oh, what an excellent thing this learning is!

origin: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.
modern: Good to see you, Signior Hortensio.

origin: Trow you whither I am going?
modern: Do you know where I’m going?

origin: To Baptista Minola.
modern: To Baptista Minola’s house.

origin: Tis well.
modern: That’s great.

origin: And I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress.
modern: And I have met a gentleman who promises to help me find a good music tutor to instruct our lady love.

origin: Gremio, ’tis now no time to vent our love.
modern: Gremio, this is no time to compete over how deeply we love Bianca.

origin: So said, so done, is well.
modern: That’s good, if he’ll really do it.

origin: Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
modern: Have you told him all her faults, Hortensio?

origin: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.
modern: I know she is a hateful, brawling scold.

origin: If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
modern: If that’s all, gentlemen, I see no problem.

origin: No?
modern: No?

origin: Say’st me so, friend?
modern: Tell me, friend.

origin: What countryman?
modern: Where are you from?

origin: My father dead, my fortune lives for me.
modern: My father’s dead, and his fortune is mine now.

origin: And I do hope good days and long to see.
modern: I hope to see good days—and many of them.

origin: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!
modern: Sir, such a life with such a wife is unlikely!

origin: But if you have a stomach, to ’t, i' God’s name: You shall have me assisting you in all.
modern: But if you have the stomach for it, you’ll have all the help from me you need.

origin: But will you woo this wildcat?
modern: Do you really mean to go after this wildcat?

origin: Why came I hither but to that intent?
modern: Why did I come here if not for that?

origin: Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds, Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?
