modern: I, who have survived storms at sea where the winds raged like wild animals?

origin: Have I not heard great ordnance in the field, And heaven’s artillery thunder in the skies?
modern: I, who have heard the rumble of guns in battle—and thunder in the sky (heaven’s version of artillery).

origin: Hortensio, hark.
modern: Listen, Hortensio.

origin: And so we will, provided that he win her.
modern: Absolutely—so long as he gets the girl.

origin: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.
modern: I wish I could be as certain of a good dinner.

origin: He that has the two fair daughters—is ’t he you mean?
modern: Is that the man you want?

origin: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.
modern: But not the woman who scolds, anyway, I hope.

origin: Sir, a word ere you go.
modern: Sir, a word before you go.

origin: Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
modern: Are you a suitor to the girl we speak of, yes or no?

origin: An if I be, sir, is it any offense?
modern: What if I am?

origin: No, if without more words you will get you hence.
modern: Not if you go away, there isn’t.

origin: For this reason, if you’ll know: That she’s the choice love of Signior Gremio.
modern: Because, if you must know, she’s been chosen by Signior Gremio.

origin: That she’s the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
modern: Because she’s been chosen by Signior Hortensio.

origin: Softly, my masters.
modern: Wait a minute, gentlemen.

origin: If you be gentlemen, Do me this right: hear me with patience.
modern: Be good enough to hear me out.

origin: Baptista is a noble gentleman, To whom my father is not all unknown, And were his daughter fairer than she is, She may more suitors have, and me for one.
modern: Baptista is a noble gentleman—one to whom my father is not completely unknown—and lovely as his daughter is, she is entitled to any number of suitors—myself among them.

origin: Believe me, lord, I think he cannot choose.
modern: I don’t think he’d have any choice, my lord.

origin: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.
modern: When he woke, he wouldn’t know where he was.

origin: Even as a flatt'ring dream or worthless fancy.
modern: It would be just like a nice daydream or fantasy.

origin: Then take him up and manage well the jest.
modern: Well, take him on up and we’ll try to pull it off.

origin: Carry him gently to my fairest chamber And hang it round with all my wanton pictures.
modern: Carry him to my best room—gently, so he doesn’t wake—and hang all my erotic paintings around him.

origin: Balm his foul head in warm distilled waters And burn sweet wood to make the lodging sweet.
modern: Bathe his filthy head with warm, scented water.

origin: My lord, I warrant you we will play our part As he shall think by our true diligence He is no less than what we say he is.
modern: Convince him that he has been out of his mind—and when he says he’s out of his mind  My lord, I promise we will play our parts so skillfully that he will believe everything we tell him.

origin: Fair Leda’s daughter had a thousand wooers; Then well one more may fair Bianca have.
modern: The beautiful Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors.

origin: This gentleman will out-talk us all.
modern: This fellow will out-talk us all.

origin: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
modern: Hortensio, what’s all this about?

origin: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules, And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
modern: Yes, leave that labor to great Hercules—it’s worse than the previous twelve put together.

origin: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.
modern: Sir, that’s well said and well thought out.

origin: O excellent motion!
modern: An excellent motion.

origin: Fellows, let’s be gone.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: The motion’s good indeed and be it so.— Petruchio, I shall be your
modern: I second that

origin: Good sister, wrong me not nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me.
modern: Dear sister, it’s unfair to me—and unfair to yourself—to turn me into a slave.

origin: That I disdain.
modern: That I won’t stand for.

origin: See thou dissemble not.
modern: And don’t lie.

origin: Minion, thou liest.
modern: You lying brat.

origin: Is ’t not Hortensio?
modern: It’s Hortensio, isn’t it?

origin: Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.
modern: Oh, I see.

origin: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.
modern: You’ll live in luxury with Gremio.

origin: Is it for him you do envy me so?
modern: Is it because of

origin: What, in my sight?—Bianca, get thee in.
modern: What, in my presence?

origin: What, will you not suffer me?
modern: You mean you don’t even want to hear my side?

origin: Talk not to me.
modern: Don’t talk to me.

origin: But who comes here?
modern: Now what?

origin: Good morrow, neighbor Baptista.
modern: Good morning, neighbor Baptista.

origin: Good morrow, neighbor Gremio.—God save you, gentlemen!
modern: Good morning, neighbor Gremio.

origin: And you, good sir.
modern: And to you, good sir.

origin: Pray, have you not a daughter Called Katherina, fair and virtuous?
modern: Tell me, don’t you have a virtuous and lovely daughter named Katherina?

origin: I have a daughter, sir, called Katherina.
modern: I have a daughter named Katherina, sir.

origin: You wrong me, Signior Gremio.
modern: Please, Signior Gremio.

origin: Give me leave.— I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard.
modern: Allow me to continue.—I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, who, hearing of your daughter’s beauty and wit, her friendly disposition and bashful modesty, her uncommon virtues and her mild behavior, have taken the liberty of presenting myself as a guest at your house in the hope of seeing for myself if what I’ve heard is true.

origin: You’re welcome, sir, and he for your good sake.
modern: You and he are both welcome, sir.

origin: But for my daughter Katherine, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.
modern: As for my daughter Katherine, this much I know: she’s not for you—more’s the pity.

origin: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.
modern: I see you don’t intend to part with her—or perhaps you don’t like my company.

origin: Mistake me not.
modern: Don’t misunderstand me, sir.

origin: I speak but as I find.
modern: I’m just stating the facts as I see them.

origin: Whence are you, sir?
modern: Where are you from?

origin: What may I call your name?
modern: What’s your name?

origin: Petruchio is my name, Antonio’s son, A man well known throughout all Italy.
modern: My name is Petruchio, son of Antonio, a man well known throughout Italy.

origin: I know him well.
modern: I know him well.

origin: You are welcome for his sake.
modern: You are welcome for his sake.

origin: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.
modern: You’re  Forgive me, Signior Gremio, but I’m anxious to get things moving.

origin: I doubt it not, sir, but you will curse your wooing.— Neighbor, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it.
modern: No doubt, but you may be going about it the wrong way—Neighbor, this gift is very gracious, I’m sure.

origin: To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar
modern: I myself, who am more indebted to you than anyone, have brought you this young scholar

origin: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.
modern: Many thanks, Signior Gremio.

origin: Welcome, good Cambio.
modern: Welcome, good Cambio.

origin: Lucentio is your name.
modern: Your name is Lucentio, you say.

origin: Of whence, I pray?
modern: Of what city, may I ask?

origin: A mighty man of Pisa.
modern: A man of great influence.

origin: By report I know him well.
modern: I know him well by reputation.

origin: You are very welcome, sir.
modern: You are very welcome here, sir.

origin: We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.
modern: Let’s take a little walk in the orchard before dinner.

origin: You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.
modern: You are all most welcome here; please make yourselves at home.

origin: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.
modern: Signior Baptista, I’m actually in a bit of a hurry.

origin: You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have bettered rather than decreased.
modern: You knew my father well; therefore, you know me, the sole heir to all his property and possessions, which I have added to rather than depleted.

origin: Then tell me, if I get your daughter’s love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife?
modern: So, tell me, assuming I win your daughter’s love, what dowry would she bring to the marriage?

origin: After my death, the one half of my lands, And, in possession, twenty thousand crowns.
modern: Twenty thousand crowns now, and half my lands after my death.

origin: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.
modern: Let’s have explicit contracts drawn up to ensure that both sides keep their promises.

origin: Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.
modern: That counts for everything.

origin: Why, that is nothing.
modern: Oh, that’s nothing, believe me, sir.

origin: For I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proud-minded; And where two raging fires meet together, They do consume the thing that feeds their fury.
modern: I’m as commanding as she is proud, and when two raging fires meet, they end up consuming the very thing that kindled them.

origin: So I to her and so she yields to me, For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
modern: I’m that great gust to her fire.

origin: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed.
modern: Well, good luck!

origin: But be thou armed for some unhappy words.
modern: But prepare yourself for some unpleasantness.

origin: Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds, That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.
modern: Mountains don’t tremble, however much the wind may blow!

origin: How now, my friend, why dost thou look so pale?
modern: Why so pale, my friend?

origin: What, will my daughter prove a good musician?
modern: Will my daughter be a good musician, do you think?

origin: I think she’ll sooner prove a soldier.
modern: I think she’ll be a better soldier.

origin: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute?
modern: You don’t think you can teach her?

origin: I’ll fume with them!” And with that word she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way,
modern: I’ll give you frets!” With that, she clobbers me with the lute so that my head goes right through,

origin: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench.
modern: I like this girl!

origin: I love her ten times more than e'er I did.
modern: Now I want her more than ever.

origin: Oh, how I long to have some chat with her!
modern: I can’t wait to meet her!

origin: I pray you do.
modern: Please do.

origin: I’ll attend her here And woo her with some spirit when she comes.
modern: I’ll wait for her here and when she comes I’ll take a novel approach with her.

origin: Say that she rail; why then I’ll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
modern: If she rants, I’ll tell her that she sings as sweetly as a nightingale.

origin: Say that she frown; I’ll say she looks as clear As morning roses newly washed with dew.
modern: If she glares, I’ll say her brow is as clear as roses newly washed with morning dew.

origin: Say she be mute and will not speak a word; Then I’ll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.
modern: If she is silent and won’t speak at all, I’ll praise her chattiness and say she speaks with piercing eloquence.

origin: If she do bid me pack, I’ll give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week.
modern: If she orders me to go, I’ll thank her warmly as if she’d just offered to put me up for a week.

origin: If she deny to wed, I’ll crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be marrièd.
modern: If she refuses my proposal, I’ll tell her how much I’m looking forward to the announcement and the wedding.

origin: Take him up gently, and to bed with him, And each one to his office when he wakes.
modern: Carry him gently to bed, and every man be ready at his post when he awakes.

origin: Sirrah, go see what trumpet ’tis that sounds.
modern: Go, lad, and find out what the trumpet’s sounding for.

origin: Belike some noble gentleman that means, Traveling some journey, to repose him here.
modern: It’s probably some noble gentleman stopping off in mid-journey, thinking to spend the night here.

origin: An’t please your Honor, players That offer service to your Lordship.
modern: Sir, it’s a troupe of actors who want to perform for your Lordship.

origin: Bid them come near.
modern: Have them come in.

origin: Now, fellows, you are welcome.
modern: You are welcome here, my friends.

origin: We thank your Honor.
modern: We thank your Honor.

origin: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
modern: Were you thinking of spending the night here?

origin: So please your Lordship to accept our duty.
modern: Yes, if that would be all right with your Lordship.

origin: With all my heart.
modern: By all means.

origin: This fellow I remember Since once he played a farmer’s eldest son.
modern: I remember this fellow—he once played the eldest son of a farmer.

origin: Twas where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.
modern: It was the play in which you wooed the gentlewoman so successfully.

origin: I have forgot your name, but sure that part Was aptly fitted and naturally performed.
modern: I have forgotten your name, but you were well cast in the role and played it convincingly.

origin: Good morrow, Kate—for that’s your name, I hear.
modern: Good morning, Kate, for I hear that’s what you’re called.

origin: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing.
modern: Is that what you’ve heard?

origin: Moved,” in good time.
modern: Driven?” Really?

origin: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.
modern: I had you figured for a piece of furniture.

origin: Why, what’s a moveable?
modern: What do you mean by “furniture”?

origin: A joint stool.
modern: A nice stool.

origin: Thou hast hit it.
modern: You’re right, actually.

origin: Come, sit on me.
modern: Come sit on me.

origin: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
modern: Asses are made for bearing, and so are you.

origin: Women are made to bear, and so are you.
modern: Women are made for

origin: No such jade as you, if me you mean.
modern: Not by the likes of you!

origin: Alas, good Kate, I will not burden thee, For knowing thee to be but young and light— Too light for such a swain as you to catch, And yet as heavy as my weight should be.
modern: I know how  Too light for a lout like you to catch—though no lighter than I should be.

origin: Should be”—should buzz!
modern: Should be?

origin: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.
modern: If I’m a wasp, look out for my stinger.

origin: My remedy is then to pluck it out.
modern: All I have to do is remove it.

origin: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies.
modern: True, if a fool such as yourself could find it.

origin: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting?
modern: Everyone knows where a wasp wears its stinger.

origin: In his tail.
modern: In its tail.

origin: In his tongue.
modern: No, in its tongue.

origin: Whose tongue?
modern: Whose tongue?

origin: Yours, if you talk of tales.
modern: Yours, if we’re talking about  I’m leaving.

origin: What, with my tongue in your tail?
modern: You’re leaving with my tongue in your tail?

origin: Nay, come again, Good Kate.
modern: No, come back, Kate.

origin: That I’ll try.
modern: We’ll see about that!

origin: I swear I’ll cuff you if you strike again.
modern: I swear I’ll smack you if you hit me again.

origin: So may you lose your arms.
modern: Not if you want to keep your arms!

origin: No cock of mine.
modern: It has no fighting spirit.

origin: Nay, come, Kate, come.
modern: Oh, come on now, Kate.

origin: You must not look so sour.
modern: Don’t look so sour.

origin: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.
modern: That’s my way, when I see a crab-apple.

origin: Why, here’s no crab, and therefore look not sour.
modern: There’s no crab-apple here, so don’t look sour.

origin: There is, there is.
modern: There is a crab-apple here.

origin: Then show it me.
modern: Show me.

origin: Had I a glass, I would.
modern: I would, if I had a mirror.

origin: What, you mean my face?
modern: What, you mean my face looks like a crab-apple?

origin: Well aimed of such a young one.
modern: You know, you’re right.

origin: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.
modern: I probably am too young for you.

origin: Yet you are withered.
modern: Maybe, but you’re wrinkled all the same.

origin: Tis with cares.
modern: Oh, that’s with worry.

origin: I care not.
modern: Well, that doesn’t worry me.

origin: Let me go.
modern: Let me go.

origin: No, not a whit.
modern: No, not a bit.

origin: I find you passing gentle.
modern: I find you quite gentle.

origin: Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen, And now I find report a very liar.
modern: I was told that you were violent, proud, and sullen.

origin: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.
modern: You haven’t got it in you to frown or look displeased or bite your lip as angry women do.

origin: But thou with mildness entertain’st thy wooers, With gentle conference, soft and affable.
modern: No, you entertain your suitors with mild and gentle conversation, quiet and pleasant.

origin: Why does the world report that Kate doth limp?
modern: Why does the world report that Kate is lame?

origin: O slanderous world!
modern: The world’s a liar.

origin: Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels.
modern: Kate is as straight and slender as a hazel-twig, her hair as brown as hazelnut shells, and she herself sweeter than the kernels.

origin: Oh, let me see thee walk!
modern: Take a few steps—I want to see you walk.

origin: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait?
modern: Did Diana ever beautify a grove as much as Kate beautifies this room with her queenly movements?

origin: A witty mother!
modern: It’s born of my  A witty mother!

origin: Witless else her son.
modern: Too bad about the son!

origin: Am I not wise?
modern: Am I not wise?

origin: For I am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.
modern: I’m the man who was born to tame you and change you from a wildcat Kate into a Kate as gentle and domestic as other household Kates.

origin: I should know that voice.
modern: I almost recognize that voice.

origin: It should be—But he is drowned, and these are devils.
modern: It’s—But he’s drowned, and these guys are devils.

origin: Oh, defend me!
modern: Oh, God help me!

origin: Four legs and two voices—a most delicate monster.
modern: Four legs and two voices—a very special monster.

origin: His forward voice now is to speak well of his friend.
modern: One voice speaks well and talks about his friend.

origin: His backward voice is to utter foul speeches and to detract.
modern: The other voice is harsh and abusive.

origin: If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague.
modern: If it takes all the wine in my bottle, I’ll cure him.

origin: Come.
modern: Come on.

origin: Stephano!
modern: CALIBAN  Stephano!

origin: Doth thy other mouth call me?
modern: Is your other mouth calling my name?

origin: Mercy, mercy!
modern: Mercy, mercy!

origin: This is a devil, and no monster.
modern: This isn’t a monster, it’s a devil.

origin: I will leave him.
modern: I’ll leave him alone.

origin: I have no long spoon.
modern: I have no interest in getting mixed up with the devil.

origin: Stephano!
modern: Stephano!

origin: If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me.
modern: If you’re Stephano, touch me and speak to me.

origin: For I am Trinculo—be not afeard—thy good friend Trinculo.
modern: I’m Trinculo—don’t be scared—your good friend Trinculo.

origin: If thou beest Trinculo, come forth.
modern: If you’re Trinculo, then come out.

origin: I’ll pull thee by the lesser legs.
modern: I’ll pull on these smaller legs.

origin: If any be Trinculo’s legs, these are they.
modern: If any legs here are Trinculo’s, these are.

origin: But art thou not drowned, Stephano?
modern: But aren’t you drowned, Stephano?

origin: I hope now thou art not drowned.
modern: I hope you’re not drowned.

origin: Is the storm overblown?
modern: Has the storm passed?

origin: I hid me under the dead mooncalf’s gaberdine for fear of the storm.
modern: I hid under this monster’s cloak to get out of the storm.

origin: And art thou living, Stephano?
modern: Are you really alive, Stephano?

origin: O Stephano, two Neapolitans ’scaped!
modern: Oh, Stephano, two men from Naples survived!

origin: Prithee, do not turn me about.
modern: Please stop turning me around.

origin: My stomach is not constant.
modern: My stomach’s a little upset.

origin: Swum ashore, man, like a duck.
modern: I swam ashore like a duck.

origin: I can swim like a duck, I’ll be sworn.
modern: I can swim like a duck, I swear.

origin: Here, kiss the book.
modern: Here,

origin: O Stephano, hast any more of this?
modern: Oh Stephano, do you have any more of that wine?

origin: The whole butt, man.
modern: I’ve got the whole barrel, man.

origin: Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
modern: You come from heaven, don’t you?

origin: Out o' th' moon, I do assure thee.
modern: No, from the moon, I’m telling you.

origin: I was the man i' the moon when time was.
modern: I used to be the man in the moon a long time ago.

origin: My mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
modern: My mistress showed me you in the moon and your dog and your bush.

origin: I afeard of him!
modern: I can’t believe I was scared of him!

origin: A very weak monster.
modern: A pretty pathetic monster.

origin: The man i' th' moon!
modern: The man in the moon!

origin: A most poor credulous monster.—Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!
modern: What a poor, gullible monster.—That was a nice big gulp, monster!

origin: By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster.
modern: What a lying, drunken monster.

origin: When ’s god’s asleep, he’ll rob his bottle.
modern: When his god falls asleep, the monster will snatch his wine bottle.

origin: Come on then.
modern: Come on, then.

origin: Down, and swear.
modern: Get down and swear it.

origin: I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster.
modern: I’m going to laugh myself to death over this silly monster.

origin: A most scurvy monster.
modern: A rotten, foolish monster.

origin: I could find in my heart to beat him—   But that the poor monster’s in drink.
modern: I could find it in my heart to beat him— Come on, kiss my feet.

origin: An abominable monster!
modern: An awful monster!

origin: I’ll show thee the best springs.
modern: I’ll show you where to get fresh water.

origin: I’ll pluck thee berries.
modern: I’ll pick berries for you.

origin: I’ll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
modern: I’ll fish for you and get you plenty of firewood.

origin: A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
modern: The tyrant I’m serving now can go to hell!

origin: A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard.
modern: What a silly monster, to think a poor drunk is wonderful.

origin: I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking.— Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.—Here, bear my bottle.—Fellow Trinculo, we’ll fill him by and by again.
modern: Show us the way without further delay.—Trinculo, since the king and all our comrades are drowned, we’re the heirs of this place.—Here, carry my wine bottle.—Trinculo, my buddy, we’ll get that bottle refilled soon enough.

origin: A howling monster, a drunken monster.
modern: A loud-mouthed, drunken monster.

origin: O brave monster!
modern: Good monster!

origin: Lead the way.
modern: Show us the way.

origin: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze, anything.
modern: Right now I’d give a thousand

origin: Some kinds of baseness Are nobly undergone.
modern: Some kinds of lowly activities are done for noble reasons.

origin: And most poor matters Point to rich ends.
modern: And you can do poor things that lead to rich results.

origin: This my mean task Would be as heavy to me as odious, but The mistress which I serve quickens what’s dead And makes my labors pleasures.
modern: This hard work would be boring and nasty to me, but I’m working for a mistress who makes me enjoy my labor.

origin: Oh, she is Ten times more gentle than her father’s crabbed, And he’s composed of harshness.
modern: Oh, she’s ten times nicer than her father is mean, and he’s the height of crabbiness.

origin: I must remove Some thousands of these logs and pile them up, Upon a sore injunction.
modern: I have thousands of logs to take away and pile up, on strict orders from him.

origin: My sweet mistress Weeps when she sees me work, and says such baseness Had never like executor.
modern: My sweet darling cries when she sees me work and tells me that such a wonderful man never performed such lowly tasks before.

origin: I forget, But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labors, Most busiest when I do it.
modern: These sweet thoughts relieve me and refresh me, especially when I’m slaving away busily.

origin: Alas now, pray you, Work not so hard.
modern: Now, please, I beg you, don’t work so hard.

origin: I would the lightning had Burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!
modern: I wish the lightning had burned up all those logs that you’ve been ordered to stack!

origin: Pray, set it down and rest you.
modern: Please put that log down and rest a while.

origin: When this burns, 'Twill weep for having wearied you.
modern: When this wood burns, it’ll weep for making you tired.

origin: My father Is hard at study.
modern: My father’s studying hard, so he won’t see you.

origin: Pray now, rest yourself.
modern: So please rest.

origin: He’s safe for these three hours.
modern: We’re safe from my father for at least three hours.

origin: O most dear mistress, The sun will set before I shall discharge What I must strive to do.
modern: Oh, my dear mistress, I won’t be able to finish this work until sunset at the earliest.

origin: If you’ll sit down, I’ll bear your logs the while.
modern: If you sit down, I’ll carry your logs a while.

origin: Pray, give me that.
modern: Please give me that.

origin: I’ll carry it to the pile.
modern: I’ll take it over to the pile.

origin: It would become me As well as it does you, and I should do it With much more ease, for my good will is to it And yours it is against.
modern: I’d be as right for the job as you are, and I’d do it more easily, since I’d have good will on my side.

origin: You look wearily.
modern: You look tired.

origin: I do beseech you— Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers— What is your name?
modern: I beg you to tell me your name so I can use it in my prayers.

origin: Miranda.—O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!
modern: Miranda.—Oh father, I’ve disobeyed you by telling him that!

origin: Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time
modern: I’ve looked at many ladies with pleasure, and been

origin: For several virtues Have I liked several women.
modern: But with you it’s different.

origin: But you, O you, So perfect and so peerless, are created Of every creature’s best.
modern: You’re perfect, without a rival in the world, made up of the best qualities of every creature.

origin: I do not know One of my sex, no woman’s face remember— Save, from my glass, mine own.
modern: I’ve never known any woman or seen a woman’s face—except my own in the mirror.

origin: Nor have I seen More that I may call men than you, good friend, And my dear father.
modern: And I’ve never met any men besides you and my father.

origin: I am in my condition A prince, Miranda—I do think, a king; I would, not so!—and would no more endure This wooden slavery than to suffer The flesh-fly blow my mouth.
modern: I’m a prince by birth, Miranda—maybe even a king now; though I wish I weren’t—and normally I wouldn’t put up with carrying these logs any more than I’d let flies breed in my mouth.

origin: Hear my soul speak.
modern: But I’ll tell you something from my soul.

origin: The very instant that I saw you did My heart fly to your service, there resides To make me slave to it, and for your sake Am I this patient log-man.
modern: The second I saw you, my heart rushed to serve you and be your slave, so here I am now, a patient log-man.

origin: Do you love me?
modern: Do you love me?

origin: O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound And crown what I profess with kind event
modern: Oh heaven, oh earth, witness what I’m about to say, and reward me if I tell the truth!

origin: If I speak true!
modern: If I’m lying, then

origin: I Beyond all limit of what else i' th' world Do love, prize, honor you.
modern: More than anything else in the world, I love you, value you, and honor you.

origin: I am a fool To weep at what I am glad of.
modern: Look at me crying—what a fool I am to cry at what makes me happy.

origin: Wherefore weep you?
modern: Why are you crying?

origin: At mine unworthiness, that dare not offer What I desire to give, and much less take What I shall die to want.
modern: I’m crying at how unworthy I am to give you what I want to give you and to take what I’m dying to have.

origin: But this is trifling, And all the more it seeks to hide itself The bigger bulk it shows.
modern: The more I try to hide what I’m feeling, the bigger it gets.

origin: I am your wife if you will marry me.
modern: I’ll be your wife if you’ll have me.

origin: If not, I’ll die your maid.
modern: Otherwise, I’ll die a virgin, devoted to you.

origin: To be your fellow You may deny me, but I’ll be your servant Whether you will or no.
modern: You can refuse to make me your spouse, but I’ll be your servant whether you want me to or not.

origin: My mistress, dearest, and I thus humble ever.
modern: You’ll be my wife, dearest, and I’ll serve you forever.

origin: My husband, then?
modern: Will you be my husband, then?

origin: A thousand thousand!
modern: A million goodbyes to you.

origin: I’ll to my book, For yet ere supper-time must I perform Much business appertaining.
modern: Now it’s time to get back to my studying, since I have a lot of serious business to take care of before dinner.

origin: Tell not me.
modern: Don’t tell me that.

origin: When the butt is out, we will drink water.
modern: When the barrel’s empty, we’ll drink water.

origin: Not a drop before.
modern: Not one drop sooner.

origin: Therefore bear up and board 'em.—Servant- monster, drink to me.
modern: Therefore, drink up.—Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.

origin: Servant-monster”?
modern: Servant monster”?

origin: The folly of this island.
modern: What a crazy island this is.

origin: They say there’s but five upon this isle.
modern: They say there are only five people on it.

origin: We are three of them.
modern: We’re three of them.

origin: If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
modern: If the other two are as loopy as we are, our country’s in bad shape.

origin: Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee.
modern: Drink when I order you, servant-monster.

origin: Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
modern: Your eyes look like they’ve sunk into your head.

origin: Where should they be set else?
modern: Where else should his eyes be, if not in his head?

origin: He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
modern: He’d be quite a monster if his eyes were in his tail.

origin: For my part, the sea cannot drown me.
modern: My man—monster is so drunk he can’t talk.

origin: He’s no standard.
modern: He’s not standing straight enough to hold a flag.

origin: We’ll not run, Monsieur Monster.
modern: We’re not going to run in our army, Monsieur Monster.

origin: Nor go neither.
modern: Or walk either.

origin: But you’ll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
modern: You’ll just lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing.

origin: Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.
modern: Monster sweetie, be a good monster and just speak once.

origin: How does thy honor?
modern: How is your Highness?

origin: Let me lick thy shoe.
modern: Let me lick your shoe.

origin: Lord,” quoth he?
modern: Lord,” he calls you?

origin: That a monster should be such a natural!
modern: What an idiot that monster is!

origin: Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head.
modern: Trinculo, speak politely.

origin: If you prove a mutineer, the next tree.
modern: If you mutiny against me, I’ll hang you from the next tree.

origin: I thank my noble lord.
modern: Thank you, my noble lord.

origin: Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
modern: Now would you please listen once again to the request I made to you earlier?

origin: I will stand, and so shall Trinculo.
modern: I’ll stand, and so will Trinculo.

origin: Thou liest.
modern: You lie.

origin: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in ’s tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
modern: Trinculo, if you interrupt him any more, I swear I’ll knock some teeth out of your head.

origin: Why, I said nothing.
modern: I didn’t say anything.

origin: Mum, then, and no more.
modern: Okay, just stay quiet.

origin: Proceed.
modern: Go on.

origin: I say, by sorcery he got this isle.
modern: I was telling you he used witchcraft to take this island.

origin: From me he got it.
modern: He stole it from me.

origin: If thy greatness will Revenge it on him—for I know thou darest, But this thing dare not— That’s most certain.
modern: If your highness is willing, take revenge on him for that—because I know you’re brave enough, I don’t dare to— That’s for sure.

origin: Thou shalt be lord of it and I’ll serve thee.
modern: You’ll be lord of the island then, and I’ll be your servant.

origin: How now shall this be compassed?
modern: And how would we go about doing that?

origin: Canst thou bring me to th' party?
modern: Can you bring me to him?

origin: Yea, yea, my lord.
modern: Yes, yes, my lord.

origin: I’ll yield him thee asleep, Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
modern: I’ll take you to where he sleeps, and you can pound a nail into his head.

origin: Thou liest.
modern: You lie.

origin: Thou canst not.
modern: You can’t do that.

origin: What a pied ninny’s this!—Thou scurvy patch!— I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows And take his bottle from him.
modern: What an idiot this guy is!—You’re a rotten piece of work!—I beg your highness, beat him up and take his wine bottle from him.

origin: When that’s gone, He shall drink naught but brine, for I’ll not show him Where the quick freshes are.
modern: When he loses that, he’ll be drinking salt water, since I’ll never tell him where the freshwater springs are.

origin: Trinculo, run into no further danger.
modern: Trinculo, watch out.

origin: Interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, I’ll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
modern: If you interrupt this monster with one more word, I’ll beat you like a piece of salted fish.

origin: Why, what did I?
modern: What did I do?

origin: I did nothing.
modern: I didn’t do anything.

origin: I’ll go farther off.
modern: I need to get away from you.

origin: Didst thou not say he lied?
modern: Didn’t you call him a liar?

origin: Thou liest.
modern: You lie.

origin: I did not give the lie.
modern: I didn’t accuse you of lying.

origin: Out o' your wits and hearing too?
modern: Are you out of your mind and deaf too?

origin: A pox o' your bottle!
modern: Damn your wine!

origin: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

origin: Now, forward with your tale.—Prithee, stand farther off.
modern: Now go ahead and tell me the rest of your story.—Please go stand farther away.

origin: Beat him enough.
modern: Beat him up.

origin: After a little time, I’ll beat him too.
modern: After a little while, I’ll beat him too.

origin: Why, as I told thee, ’tis a custom with him, I' th' afternoon to sleep.
modern: Just as I told you, he usually sleeps in the afternoon.

origin: There thou mayst brain him, Having first seized his books; or with a log Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake; Or cut his weasand with thy knife.
modern: At that time you can smash in his skull after seizing his books; or you can bash his skull with a log; or you can stab him in the belly; or cut his windpipe.

origin: Remember First to possess his books, for without them He’s but a sot, as I am, nor hath not One spirit to command.
modern: Just remember to grab his books first, since without them he’s just a poor fool like me, and can’t command a single spirit.

origin: They all do hate him As rootedly as I.
modern: All the spirits hate him as much as I do.

origin: Burn but his books.
modern: Be sure to burn his magic books.

origin: He has brave utensils—for so he calls them— Which when he has a house, he’ll deck withal.
modern: He has some wonderful home furnishings—that’s what he calls them—that he’ll use to decorate his house when he gets one.

origin: And that most deeply to consider is The beauty of his daughter.
modern: The most important thing for you to think about is how beautiful his daughter is.

origin: He himself Calls her a nonpareil.
modern: He says she has no equal.

origin: I never saw a woman, But only Sycorax my dam and she.
modern: I never saw a woman except her and Sycorax, my mother.

origin: But she as far surpasseth Sycorax As great’st does least.
modern: But Miranda is so much more beautiful, you can’t even compare the two.

origin: Is it so brave a lass?
modern: Is she really that wonderful?

origin: Ay, lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: Monster, I will kill this man.
modern: Monster, I’ll kill this man.

origin: His daughter and I will be king and queen—save our graces!—and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.—Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
modern: His daughter and I will be king and queen—God protect us!—and you and Trinculo will be our governors.—Do you like that idea, Trinculo?

origin: Excellent.
modern: Excellent.

origin: Give me thy hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: I am sorry I beat thee.
modern: I’m sorry I hit you.

origin: But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
modern: But try to control your speech.

origin: Within this half hour will he be asleep.
modern: In a half an hour he’ll be asleep.

origin: Wilt thou destroy him then?
modern: Will you kill him then?

origin: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
modern: Dear father, if you caused this terrible storm with your magic powers, please put an end to it.

origin: The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, But that the sea, mounting to th' welkin’s cheek, Dashes the fire out.
modern: The sky’s so dark it looks like it would rain down boiling hot tar if the sea weren’t swelling up to the sky to put its fire out.

origin: Oh, I have suffered With those that I saw suffer.
modern: Oh, I suffered along with all the men I watched suffer!

origin: A brave vessel Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her Dashed all to pieces.
modern: A fine ship, with some good people in it, I’m sure, smashed to pieces.

origin: Oh, the cry did knock Against my very heart!
modern: Their dying shouts broke my heart!

origin: Poor souls, they perished.
modern: The poor people died.

origin: Had I been any god of power, I would Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere It should the good ship so have swallowed and The fraughting souls within her.
modern: If I’d been a god I would’ve let the sea sink inside the earth before it had a chance to swallow up that ship and all the people it was carrying.

origin: Be collected.
modern: Calm down.

origin: No more amazement.
modern: There’s nothing to get upset about.

origin: Tell your piteous heart There’s no harm done.
modern: No harm was done.

origin: Oh, woe the day!
modern: Oh, what a horrible day!

origin: No harm.
modern: There was no harm, I’m telling you.

origin: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.
modern: It never occurred to me to imagine there was anything more to know.

origin: Ay, on mine honor.
modern: Yes, I swear.

origin: Thou makest me merry.
modern: You make me so happy.

origin: I am full of pleasure.
modern: I’m full of joy.

origin: Let us be jocund.
modern: Let’s be light-hearted.

origin: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason.— Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.
modern: I’ll do anything you ask, monster, anything reasonable.—Come on, Trinculo, let’s sing.

origin: That’s not the tune.
modern: That’s not the tune I had in mind.

origin: What is this same?
modern: What’s this song?

origin: O, forgive me my sins!
modern: Oh, forgive all my sins!

origin: Art thou afeard?
modern: Are you scared?

origin: No, monster, not I.
modern: No, monster, not me.

origin: Be not afeard.
modern: Don’t be scared.

origin: This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
modern: This’ll be a wonderful kingdom to live in, where they play music for free.

origin: When Prospero is destroyed.
modern: As soon as you kill Prospero.

origin: That shall be by and by.
modern: That’ll happen soon enough.

origin: I remember the story.
modern: I remember the plan.

origin: The sound is going away.
modern: The sound is going away.

origin: Let’s follow it, and after do our work.
modern: But let’s follow it, and then do our dirty work afterward.

origin: Lead, monster; we’ll follow.
modern: Lead us, monster; we’ll follow.

origin: I would I could see this taborer.
modern: I wish I could see this invisible drummer.

origin: He lays it on.
modern: He really plays well.

origin: Wilt come?
modern: Are you coming monster?

origin: My old bones ache.
modern: My old bones are tired.

origin: Here’s a maze trod indeed Through forthrights and meanders.
modern: We’re wandering in a maze.

origin: By your patience, I needs must rest me.
modern: If you don’t mind, I need to rest a bit.

origin: Old lord, I cannot blame thee, Who am myself attached with weariness To th' dulling of my spirits.
modern: I can’t blame you, old lord.

origin: Sit down and rest.
modern: Sit down and rest.

origin: He is drowned Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks Our frustrate search on land.
modern: We’re searching on land, but he’s lost in the sea.

origin: Well, let him go.
modern: We have to give up and let him go.

origin: What harmony is this?
modern: What’s that music?

origin: My good friends, hark!
modern: My friends, listen.

origin: Marvelous sweet music!
modern: What marvelous music!

origin: Give us kind keepers, heavens!
modern: Heaven help us!

origin: What were these?
modern: What were those things?

origin: Now I will believe That there are unicorns, that in Arabia There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix At this hour reigning there.
modern: Now I’ll believe that unicorns exist, and that there’s a tree in Arabia where the phoenix lives.

origin: Travelers ne'er did lie, Though fools at home condemn 'em.
modern: Travelers have never told lies, no matter what the fools at home accuse them of.

origin: If in Naples I should report this now, would they believe me?
modern: If I told them about this back in Naples, would they believe me?

origin: If I should say, I saw such islanders— For, certes, these are people of the island— Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet note, Their manners are more gentle-kind than of Our human generation you shall find Many—nay, almost any.
modern: I’d tell them that I saw natives like these—since they must be natives—who are graceful and well-mannered even if they’re monstrous to look at, kinder than most human beings you might find— kinder than almost any human.

origin: They vanished strangely.
modern: They vanished strangely.

origin: No matter, since They have left their viands behind, for we have stomachs.
modern: It’s all right, since they left their food behind, and we’re hungry.

origin: Will ’t please you taste of what is here?
modern: Would you like to taste the banquet?

origin: Not I.
modern: Not me.

origin: Faith, sir, you need not fear.
modern: I assure you, sir, there’s nothing to be afraid of.

origin: Brother, my lord the duke, Stand to and do as we.
modern: Brother, Duke, please have some food.

origin: Oh, it is monstrous, monstrous.
modern: Oh, it’s horrible, horrible.

origin: Methought the billows spoke and told me of it, The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder, That deep and dreadful organ pipe, pronounced The name of Prosper.
modern: I thought the clouds were talking to me, the winds were singing to me, and the thunder, like an awful organ pipe, roared Prospero’s name.

origin: It did bass my trespass.
modern: It sang about my crimes.

origin: Therefore my son i' th' ooze is bedded, and I’ll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded And with him there lie mudded.
modern: I’ll go join him there, going down deeper than any anchor ever sank, and lie with him dead in the mud.

origin: But one fiend at a time, I’ll fight their legions o'er.
modern: I’ll fight every one of these devils if I have to, one at a time.

origin: I’ll be thy second.
modern: I’ll back you up.

origin: All three of them are desperate.
modern: All three of them are crazy with despair.

origin: Their great guilt, Like poison given to work a great time after, Now 'gins to bite the spirits.
modern: Their guilt is finally starting to gnaw at them, like a slow-acting poison.

origin: I do beseech you That are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly And hinder them from what this ecstasy May now provoke them to.
modern: Those of you who are young and active, I beg you to follow them and keep them from doing the crazy things their guilt might push them to do.

origin: Follow, I pray you.
modern: Follow them, please.

origin: But If thou dost break her virgin knot before All sanctimonious ceremonies may With full and holy rite be ministered, No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall To make this contract grow, but barren hate, Sour-eyed disdain, and discord shall bestrew The union of your bed with weeds so loathly That you shall hate it both.
modern: But if you have sex with her before the marriage ceremony takes place, the heavens will not bless your relationship, but will overwhelm you with hate, contempt, and discord, and will poison your marriage bed so that you both grow to loathe it.

origin: Fairly spoke.
modern: You’ve said it well.

origin: Sit then and talk with her.
modern: So have a seat and talk to her.

origin: She is thine own.— What, Ariel!
modern: She’s yours.—Come, Ariel!

origin: My industrious servant, Ariel!
modern: My trusty servant, Ariel!

origin: What would my potent master?
modern: What does my powerful master wish for?

origin: Here I am.
modern: I’m here.

origin: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service Did worthily perform, and I must use you In such another trick.
modern: You and your fellow spirits did your last assignment well, and now I need your help again.

origin: Go bring the rabble, O'er whom I give thee power, here to this place.
modern: Go bring them all here; I give you power over them.

origin: It is my promise, And they expect it from me.
modern: I’ve promised them I would, and they’re expecting it.

origin: Presently?
modern: Right now?

origin: Ay, with a twink.
modern: Yes, right away.

origin: Before you can say “Come” and “Go,” And breathe twice and cry “So, so!” Each one, tripping on his toe,
modern: Before you can say “Come” and “Go,” And breathe twice, and shout “So, so!” Each one of your servants will rush here,

origin: Tis time I should inform thee farther.
modern: It’s time for you to know the whole story.

origin: Lend thy hand And pluck my magic garment from me.
modern: Give me a hand and help me off with this magic cloak.

origin: Not yet.”      The hour’s now come.
modern: Not yet.” Well, the time has come.

origin: Canst thou remember A time before we came unto this cell?
modern: Can you remember the time before you came to live in this shack?

origin: I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not Out three years old.
modern: I doubt it, since you weren’t even three at the time.

origin: Certainly, sir, I can.
modern: Sure I can, father.

origin: By what?
modern: What do you remember?

origin: By any other house or person?
modern: A house, a person?

origin: Of anything the image tell me that Hath kept with thy remembrance.
modern: Tell me anything you remember.

origin: Dearly my delicate Ariel.
modern: I love you dearly, Ariel.

origin: Do not approach Till thou dost hear me call.
modern: Don’t come near till you hear me call you.

origin: Well, I conceive.
modern: All right, I understand.

origin: I warrant you, sir, The white cold virgin snow upon my heart Abates the ardor of my liver.
modern: I assure you, sir, the tender love I feel in my heart is stronger than the sexual passions stirring down below.

origin: Well.— Now come, my Ariel!
modern: Good.—Now come, Ariel!

origin: Bring a corollary, Rather than want a spirit.
modern: Better to have an extra servant on hand than be understaffed.

origin: Appear and pertly!— No tongue.
modern: Appear before me now quickly— No talking.

origin: All eyes!
modern: Just watch!

origin: Be silent.
modern: Be quiet.

origin: Ceres, most bounteous lady, thy rich leas Of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats, and peas; Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep, And flat meads thatched with stover, them to keep; Thy banks with pionèd and twillèd brims,
modern: I have come to announce that Juno has asked you, Ceres, goddess of the fields and the earth, to leave your rich farms of wheat, rye, barley, oats, and peas, the hills where the

origin: Why hath thy queen Summoned me hither to this short-grassed green?
modern: Why has your queen, Juno, called me here to this grassy spot?

origin: A contract of true love to celebrate, And some donation freely to estate On the blessed lovers.
modern: To celebrate a marriage of true love, and give a gift to the lovers.

origin: Tell me, heavenly bow, If Venus or her son, as thou dost know, Do now attend the queen?
modern: Tell me, rainbow, do you know if either Venus, the goddess of love, or her son, Cupid, is accompanying Queen Juno?

origin: Since they did plot The means that dusky Dis my daughter got, Her and her blind boy’s scandaled company I have forsworn.
modern: Ever since Venus and her blind son plotted a way for the god of the underworld to steal my daughter away for half the year, I swore I’d never speak to them again.

origin: Of her society Be not afraid.
modern: Don’t be afraid of her company.

origin: I met her deity Cutting the clouds towards Paphos, and her son Dove-drawn with her.
modern: I met Venus as she was with her son on her way to her home on Paphos, in a carriage pulled by doves.

origin: Here thought they to have done Some wanton charm upon this man and maid, Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid Till Hymen’s torch be lighted—but in vain.
modern: They were planning to pull a mischievous trick on Ferdinand and Miranda, who have sworn not to sleep together till their wedding day.

origin: Mars’s hot minion is returned again.
modern: But their trick failed.

origin: Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, Swears he will shoot no more, but play with sparrows And be a boy right out.
modern: Venus went home again, and her little son broke all his arrows, swearing he’ll never shoot them again, but play with birds like other little boys.

origin: Highest queen of state, Great Juno, comes.
modern: Great Queen Juno is coming.

origin: I know her by her gait.
modern: I know her by her walk.

origin: How does my bounteous sister?
modern: How is my generous sister?

origin: Go with me To bless this twain that they may prosperous be, And honored in their issue.
modern: Come help me bless this couple, so they will be prosperous and have many children.

origin: This is a most majestic vision, and Harmonious charmingly.
modern: This is a majestic and harmonious vision.

origin: May I be bold To think these spirits?
modern: Are these spirits we see before us?

origin: Spirits, which by mine art I have from their confines called to enact My present fancies.
modern: Yes, they’re spirits that I’ve called out of their prisons to perform my whims.

origin: Let me live here ever.
modern: Let me live here forever.

origin: So rare a wondered father and a wife Makes this place paradise.
modern: Such a wonderful father-in-law and wife make this place a paradise.

origin: Sweet now, silence.
modern: Now be quiet.

origin: Juno and Ceres whisper seriously.
modern: Juno and Ceres are whispering about something serious.

origin: There’s something else to do.
modern: There’s something else to be done.

origin: Hush and be mute, Or else our spell is marred.
modern: Be silent, or else my magic spell will be broken.

origin: Come, temperate nymphs, and help to celebrate A contract of true love.
modern: Come, sweet nymphs, and help us celebrate the wedding of two true lovers.

origin: Be not too late.
modern: Don’t be late.

origin: You sunburnt sicklemen of August weary, Come hither from the furrow and be merry.
modern: Now, you tanned fieldworkers who are so tired of August’s labors, get out of the dirt and come rejoice with us here.

origin: Your rye-straw hats put on, And these fresh nymphs encounter every one In country footing.
modern: Put your straw hats on, have some fun, and dance with these young nymphs.

origin: The minute of their plot Is almost come.—Well done.
modern: The moment they planned to act is almost here.

origin: Never till this day Saw I him touched with anger so distempered.
modern: I’ve never seen him like this.

origin: We are such stuff As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep.
modern: We are all made of dreams, and our life stretches from sleep before birth to sleep after death.

origin: Sir, I am vexed.
modern: Sir, I’m upset.

origin: Bear with my weakness.
modern: Please put up with my weakness.

origin: My old brain is troubled.
modern: My old brain is troubled.

origin: Be not disturbed with my infirmity.
modern: Don’t be disturbed by my illness.

origin: If you be pleased, retire into my cell And there repose.
modern: If you like, you can rest a while in my room.

origin: A turn or two I’ll walk To still my beating mind.
modern: I’ll go for a short walk to calm down my feverish mind.

origin: We wish your peace.
modern: We hope you feel better and find some peace.

origin: Come with a thought.
modern: Come, Ariel—I summon you with a thought.

origin: I thank thee, Ariel.
modern: Thank you, Ariel.

origin: Come.
modern: Come.

origin: Thy thoughts I cleave to.
modern: I obey all your thoughts.

origin: What’s thy pleasure?
modern: What do you wish?

origin: Spirit, We must prepare to meet with Caliban.
modern: Spirit, we have to get ready to meet with Caliban.

origin: Ay, my commander.
modern: Yes, my master.

origin: When I presented Ceres, I thought to have told thee of it, but I feared Lest I might anger thee.
modern: When I was putting on the Ceres show, I thought of reminding you about Caliban, but I was afraid of upsetting you.

origin: Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
modern: Tell me again, where did you leave those lowlifes?

origin: I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking, So full of valor that they smote the air For breathing in their faces, beat the ground For kissing of their feet—yet always bending Towards their project.
modern: I told you, sir, they were totally drunk, so puffed up with courage that they were getting angry at the air for blowing in their faces, and beating the ground for touching their feet—yet even when drunk, they kept their plan firmly in mind.

origin: Then I beat my tabor, At which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears, Advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses As they smelt music.
modern: Then I beat my drum, at which point they pricked up their ears and opened their eyes, looking around for the source of my music.

origin: So I charmed their ears That, calflike, they my lowing followed through Toothed briers, sharp furzes, pricking gorse, and thorns, Which entered their frail shins.
modern: I enchanted them so thoroughly that they followed me through thorn bushes and prickly shrubs that tore up their shins.

origin: At last I left them I' th' filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell, There dancing up to th' chins, that the foul lake O'erstunk their feet.
modern: In the end I left them standing in the smelly pond behind your room, with the stinking water covering them up to their chins.

origin: This was well done, my bird.
modern: Good job, my little one.

origin: Thy shape invisible retain thou still.
modern: Stay invisible.

origin: The trumpery in my house, go bring it hither For stale to catch these thieves.
modern: Bring the fancy clothes out of my house, to use as bait to catch these thieves.

origin: I go, I go.
modern: I’m going, I’m going.

origin: A devil, a born devil on whose nature Nurture can never stick, on whom my pains, Humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost.
modern: He’s a devil, a born devil, who can never be trained.

origin: And as with age his body uglier grows, So his mind cankers.
modern: As his body grows uglier with age, his mind rots away as well.

origin: I will plague them all, Even to roaring.
modern: I’ll torment them all till they roar with pain.

origin: Come, hang them on this line.
modern: Here, hang them on this clothesline.

origin: Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a foot fall.
modern: Please walk softly, so not even a mole hears us approach.

origin: We now are near his cell.
modern: We’re near his room now.

origin: Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the jack with us.
modern: Hey monster, the spirit you’ve been talking about, the one you call harmless, has been playing tricks on us.

origin: Monster, I do smell all horse piss, at which my nose is in great indignation.
modern: Monster, I smell like horse piss, which is making my nose pretty upset.

origin: So is mine.—Do you hear, monster?
modern: Mine too.—Are you listening, monster?

origin: If I should take a displeasure against you, look you—  Thou wert but a lost monster.
modern: If I decide to get angry at you, just watch out— You’d be done for then, monster.

origin: Good my lord, give me thy favor still.
modern: My good lord, I still need you to like me.

origin: Be patient, for the prize I’ll bring thee to Shall hoodwink this mischance.
modern: Be patient, because the prize I’m leading you to will make you forget how smelly you are now.

origin: Therefore speak softly.
modern: So be quiet.

origin: All’s hushed as midnight yet.
modern: It’s as silent as a graveyard here.

origin: That’s more to me than my wetting.
modern: That upsets me much more than getting wet.

origin: Yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
modern: And you called the fairy creature harmless, monster.

origin: Prithee, my king, be quiet.
modern: Please, my king, be quiet.

origin: Seest thou here, This is the mouth o' th' cell.
modern: Look here, this is the entrance to his room.

origin: No noise, and enter.
modern: Be silent and go in.

origin: Do that good mischief which may make this island Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban, For aye thy foot-licker.
modern: Do the deed that will make this island yours forever, and will make me, Caliban, your worshipful foot-licker.

origin: Give me thy hand.
modern: Give me your hand.

origin: I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
modern: I’m starting to feel murderous urges.

origin: Let it alone, thou fool.
modern: Leave it alone, you fool.

origin: It is but trash.
modern: It’s worthless.

origin: Oh, ho, monster, we know what belongs to a frippery.—   Put off that gown, Trinculo.
modern: Oh, monster, we know secondhand clothes when we see them.— Take off that gown, Trinculo.

origin: By this hand, I’ll have that gown.
modern: I swear that gown’s for me.

origin: Thy grace shall have it.
modern: You can have it then, your highness.

origin: The dropsy drown this fool!
modern: To hell with this idiot!

origin: What do you mean To dote thus on such luggage?
modern: Why are you going crazy over these trashy clothes?

origin: Let’s alone, And do the murder first.
modern: Leave them alone, and do the murder first.

origin: If he awake, From toe to crown he’ll fill our skins with pinches, Make us strange stuff.
modern: If he wakes up before we kill him, he’ll never stop punishing us.

origin: Do, do.
modern: Thank you kindly.

origin: I thank thee for that jest.
modern: Thank you for that joke.

origin: Wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country.
modern: As king of this country I like to reward wit when I hear it.

origin: There’s another garment for ’t.
modern: Here’s another jacket to say thanks.

origin: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
modern: Come here, monster, put some glue on your fingers, and carry away the rest of these clothes for us.

origin: I will have none on ’t.
modern: I won’t have any of this.

origin: Monster, lay to your fingers.
modern: Monster, use your fingers.

origin: Help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I’ll turn you out of my kingdom.
modern: Help us carry these clothes to where my barrel of wine is hidden, or I’ll kick you out of my kingdom.

origin: Go to, carry this.
modern: Go on, take them.

origin: And this.
modern: Take these too.

origin: Ay, and this.
modern: Yes, and these.

origin: Hey, Mountain, hey!
modern: Hey, Mountain, hey!

origin: Silver.
modern: Silver.

origin: There it goes, Silver!
modern: There they go, Silver!

origin: Tis far off, And rather like a dream than an assurance That my remembrance warrants.
modern: My memory is hazy, more like a dream than a recollection.

origin: Had I not Four or five women once that tended me?
modern: Didn’t I use to have four or five women taking care of me?

origin: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda.
modern: Indeed you did, and more besides, Miranda.

origin: But how is it That this lives in thy mind?
modern: But how is it possible that you still remember this, through all the darkness of the past?

origin: If thou rememberest aught ere thou camest here, How thou camest here thou mayst.
modern: If you remember your life before you came here, you may also remember how you got here.

origin: But that I do not.
modern: No, that I don’t remember.

origin: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, Thy father was the Duke of Milan and A prince of power.
modern: Twelve years ago, Miranda, twelve years ago your father was the Duke of Milan, a powerful prince.

origin: Sir, are not you my father?
modern: Aren’t you my father?

origin: Thy mother was a piece of virtue and She said thou wast my daughter.
modern: Your mother was extremely virtuous, and she said you were my daughter.

origin: And thy father Was Duke of Milan, and thou his only heir And princess no worse issued.
modern: And your father was Duke of Milan, and you were his heir, a princess.

origin: Oh, the heavens!
modern: Good lord!

origin: What foul play had we that we came from thence?
modern: What evil things were done to us that we were driven here?

origin: Or blessè was ’t we did?
modern: Or was it a blessing that we came here?

origin: Both, both, my girl.
modern: Both, both, my girl.

origin: By foul play, as thou sayst, were we heaved thence, But blessedly holp hither.
modern: We were pushed out of power by evil deeds, as you call them.

origin: Fury, Fury!—There, Tyrant, there.
modern: Fury, Fury!—Get over there, Tyrant, there.

origin: Hark, hark!
modern: Listen, listen!

origin: Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints With dry convulsions, shorten up their sinews With agèd cramps, and more pinch-spotted make them Than pard or cat o' mountain.
modern: Ariel, go order my goblin servants to make these fellows' bones ache, give them muscle cramps all over, and give them more bruises than leopards have spots.

origin: Hark, they roar.
modern: Listen they’re howling.

origin: Let them be hunted soundly.
modern: Hunt them down.

origin: At this hour Lie at my mercy all mine enemies.
modern: Now all my enemies are at my mercy.

origin: Shortly shall all my labors end, and thou Shalt have the air at freedom.
modern: Soon all my work will be done, and you’ll be free.

origin: For a little Follow, and do me service.
modern: Just obey me a little bit longer.

origin: Now does my project gather to a head.
modern: My plans are almost at their climax.

origin: My charms crack not, my spirits obey, and time Goes upright with his carriage.
modern: My spells are working well, my spirits are obeying me, and everything is right on schedule.

origin: How’s the day?
modern: What time is it?

origin: On the sixth hour, at which time, my lord, You said our work should cease.
modern: It’s after six o'clock, my lord, when you said our work would be finished.

origin: I did say so When first I raised the tempest.
modern: That’s what I said when I first conjured the tempest.

origin: Say, my spirit, How fares the king and ’s followers?
modern: Tell me, spirit, how’s the king and his entourage?

origin: Confined together In the same fashion as you gave in charge, Just as you left them, all prisoners, sir, In the line grove which weather-fends your cell.
modern: All cooped up together, just as you ordered, all imprisoned in the grove of linden trees that protects your room from bad weather.

origin: They cannot budge till your release.
modern: They can’t move till you release them.

origin: The king, His brother, and yours, abide all three distracted, And the remainder mourning over them, Brimful of sorrow and dismay.
modern: The king, his brother, and your brother are all waiting there in a crazed state of mind, and the rest are grieving over them, sad and astonished.

origin: But chiefly Him that you termed, sir, “the good old Lord Gonzalo,” His tears run down his beard like winter’s drops From eaves of reeds.
modern: Good old lord Gonzalo,” as you call him, is saddest of all, with tears running down his beard.

origin: Your charm so strongly works 'em That if you now beheld them, your affections Would become tender.
modern: Your magic spell has such an effect on them that if you saw them now, you’d feel sorry for them.

origin: Dost thou think so, spirit?
modern: Do you think so, spirit?

origin: Mine would, sir, were I human.
modern: I’d feel sorry for them, if I were human.

origin: And mine shall.
modern: I will too.

origin: The rarer action is In virtue than in vengeance.
modern: It’s better to act virtuously rather than vengefully.

origin: Go release them, Ariel.
modern: Go release them, Ariel.

origin: My charms I’ll break, their senses I’ll restore, And they shall be themselves.
modern: I’ll break my spells and bring them back to their senses, and they’ll feel like themselves again.

origin: I’ll fetch them, sir.
modern: I’ll go get them, sir.

origin: With his own bolt;     the strong-based promontory Have I made shake, and by the spurs plucked up The pine and cedar; graves at my command Have waked their sleepers, oped, and let 'em forth By my so potent art.
modern: With his own lightning bolts; I’ve shaken up the sturdy cliffs and uprooted pines and cedars; I’ve opened up graves and awakened the corpses sleeping in them, letting them out with my powerful magic.

origin: But this rough magic I here abjure, and when I have required Some heavenly music, which even now I do, To work mine end upon their senses that This airy charm is for, I’ll break my staff, Bury it certain fathoms in the earth, And deeper than did ever plummet sound I’ll drown my book.
modern: But I surrender all this magic now, when I’ve summoned some heavenly music to cast a spell, as I’m doing now, I’ll break my staff and bury it far underground, and throw my book of magic spells deeper into the sea than any anchor ever sank.

origin: A solemn air and the best comforter To an unsettled fancy cure thy brains, Now useless, boiled within thy skull.—There stand, For you are spell-stopped.—   Mine eyes, ev'n sociable to the show of thine, Fall fellowly drops.
modern: Let this solemn melody comfort your fevered minds, which are now useless, seething inside your skulls.—All of you stand there in my spell.—

origin: Why, that’s my dainty Ariel.
modern: Why, that’s my dainty Ariel singing now.

origin: I shall miss thee, But yet thou shalt have freedom.—So, so, so.— To the king’s ship, invisible as thou art.
modern: I’ll miss you, Ariel, but you’ll be free.—Yes, you will, yes.—Go to the king’s ship in your invisible state.

origin: All torment, trouble, wonder, and amazement Inhabits here.
modern: This place is full of trouble, torments, and amazements.

origin: This must crave— An if this be at all—a most strange story.
modern: There must be a strange explanation for this—if it’s true.

origin: Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat Thou pardon me my wrongs.
modern: I surrender your dukedom and beg you to forgive me all my crimes.

origin: But how should Prospero Be living and be here?
modern: But how is it possible that Prospero’s alive and well and living on this island?

origin: Whether this be Or be not, I’ll not swear.
modern: I won’t bet on whether or not any of this is real.

origin: Welcome, my friends all.
modern: Welcome, my friends.

origin: The devil speaks in him.
modern: It’s the devil speaking through him.

origin: You the like loss?
modern: You suffered a loss like mine?

origin: As great to me as late.
modern: Yes, just as great and just as recent.

origin: And supportable To make the dear loss have I means much weaker Than you may call to comfort you, for I Have lost my daughter.
modern: And I have much less to comfort me than you do, since I’ve lost my daughter.

origin: A daughter?
modern: A daughter?

origin: O heavens, that they were living both in Naples, The king and queen there!
modern: Oh God, I wish the two of them were alive and living in Naples, as king and queen!

origin: That they were, I wish Myself were mudded in that oozy bed Where my son lies.—When did you lose your daughter?
modern: I’d give up my life and take my son’s place in the mud on the ocean floor if I could see them alive in Naples.—When did you lose your daughter?

origin: In this last tempest.
modern: In this recent storm.

origin: I perceive these lords At this encounter do so much admire That they devour their reason and scarce think Their eyes do offices of truth, their words Are natural breath.—But howsoev'r you have Been justled from your senses, know for certain That I am Prospero and that very duke Which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely Upon this shore where you were wracked, was landed, To be the lord on ’t.
modern: These lords seem so astonished that they’ve lost their use of reason and can hardly believe what they see with their own eyes.—But whatever the reason for your losing your senses, you can know for sure that I’m Prospero, that same duke who was kicked out of Milan and landed on this same island where you landed, and became the lord of it.

origin: No, my dearest love, I would not for the world.
modern: No, my dearest love, I wouldn’t cheat you for the whole world.

origin: If this prove A vision of the Island, one dear son Shall I twice lose.
modern: If this dream vision is typical of what this island conjures up, then I’ll lose my son twice.

origin: A most high miracle!
modern: A wonderful miracle!

origin: Now all the blessings Of a glad father, compass thee about.
modern: Receive all the blessings of a happy father.

origin: Arise, and say how thou camest here.
modern: Get up and tell me how you came here.

origin: Oh, wonder!
modern: How amazing!

origin: How many goodly creatures are there here!
modern: How many wonderful creatures there are here!

origin: How beauteous mankind is!
modern: Mankind is so beautiful!

origin: O brave new world, That has such people in ’t!
modern: Oh, what a wonderful new world, that has such people in it!

origin: Tis new to thee.
modern: It’s new to you.

origin: Sir, she is mortal.
modern: No, sir, she’s human.

origin: But by immortal providence, she’s mine.
modern: But by the grace of God, she’s mine.

origin: I chose her when I could not ask my father For his advice, nor thought I had one.
modern: I chose her for my wife when I thought I had no father to ask advice of.

origin: She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, Of whom so often I have heard renown But never saw before, of whom I have Received a second life.
modern: She’s the daughter of this famous Duke of Milan I heard so much about but never saw before.

origin: And second father This lady makes him to me.
modern: He’s given me a second life, and marrying her makes him a second father to me.

origin: I am hers.
modern: And I’m her father as well.

origin: But oh, how oddly will it sound that I Must ask my child forgiveness!
modern: But oh, how odd it is to have to ask for my child’s forgiveness!

origin: There, sir, stop.
modern: Stop right there, sir.

origin: Let us not burden our remembrances with A heaviness that’s gone.
modern: Let’s not get gloomy in our reminiscing, since there’s no reason for sadness anymore.

origin: Oh, my heart bleeds To think o' th' teen that I have turned you to, Which is from my remembrance!
modern: Oh, it breaks my heart to think how painful it must be for you to recall all this, things that I can’t remember.

origin: Please you, farther.
modern: But please tell me more.

origin: My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio— I pray thee, mark me (that a brother should Be so perfidious!
modern: My brother, your uncle Antonio—just listen to this (I still can’t believe a brother could be so disloyal!

origin: he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved and to him put The manage of my state, as at that time Through all the signories it was the first, And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel.
modern: My brother whom—aside from you—I loved more than anyone else in the world, I trusted to run my state, which at that time was the strongest in the land, and Prospero the number one duke, famous for my dignity and my education.

origin: Those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies.
modern: Since I was so drawn to studying things like logic, grammar, geometry, and astronomy, I let my control of the government slide a bit, being too wrapped up in my occult books.

origin: Thy false uncle— Dost thou attend me?
modern: Your disloyal uncle—are you paying attention?

origin: Sir, most heedfully.
modern: I’m hanging on every word.

origin: O, good sir, I do.
modern: Oh, yes I am, father.

origin: Look down, you gods, And on this couple drop a blessèd crown, For it is you that have chalked forth the way Which brought us hither.
modern: Dear gods, bless this couple, since you’re the ones who have shown us the path that led us here.

origin: I say amen, Gonzalo.
modern: Amen to that, Gonzalo.

origin: Was Milan thrust from Milan, that his issue Should become kings of Naples?
modern: Was the Duke of Milan kicked out of Milan so his children could become kings of Naples?

origin: O, rejoice Beyond a common joy, and set it down With gold on lasting pillars.
modern: Oh, this is cause for an extraordinary joy that should be engraved in gold on pillars to last forever.

origin: In one voyage Did Claribel her husband find at Tunis; And Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife Where he himself was lost; Prospero, his dukedom In a poor isle; and all of us, ourselves When no man was his own.
modern: On one and the same trip Claribel found a husband in Tunis, and Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife where he was shipwrecked; Prospero found his dukedom on a poor island; and all of us found ourselves when we lost control of ourselves.

origin: Be it so.
modern: So be it.

origin: Amen.
modern: Amen.

origin: Oh, look, sir, look, sir!
modern: Oh, look, sir, look, sir!

origin: Here is more of us.
modern: More of us are here.

origin: The best news is that we have safely found Our king and company.
modern: The best news of all is that we’ve located our king and our men.

origin: The next, our ship— Which, but three glasses since, we gave out split— Is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when We first put out to sea.
modern: The next bit of good news is that our ship—which we gave up for ruined only three hours ago—is as well-outfitted and seaworthy as it was when we first set sail.

origin: These are not natural events.
modern: These are unnatural events.

origin: On a trice, so please you, Even in a dream were we divided from them And were brought moping hither.
modern: In an instant we were separated from them, as if in a dream, and brought here in a daze.

origin: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod, And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of.
modern: This is a stranger business than men have ever set foot in before, and it’s not natural either.

origin: Some oracle Must rectify our knowledge.
modern: We need some oracle to tell us what’s going on.

origin: Sir, my liege, Do not infest your mind with beating on The strangeness of this business.
modern: Sir, my king, don’t waste your time mulling over how strange this business is.

origin: How fares my gracious sir?
modern: How is my lord?

origin: Coraggio, bully-monster,  If these be true spies which I wear in my head, here’s a goodly sight.
modern: If I can believe my eyes, this is a fine sight to see.

origin: O Setebos, these be brave spirits indeed!
modern: Oh Setebos, these are handsome spirits!

origin: How fine my master is!
modern: How wonderful my master is!

origin: I am afraid He will chastise me.
modern: I’m afraid he’ll punish me.

origin: Ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha!

origin: What things are these, my lord Antonio?
modern: What are these things we’re looking at, my lord Antonio?

origin: Will money buy 'em?
modern: Can you buy them with money?

origin: I shall be pinched to death.
modern: He’ll kill me with tortures.

origin: Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?
modern: Isn’t this Stephano, my drunken butler?

origin: He is drunk now.
modern: He’s definitely drunk now.

origin: Where had he wine?
modern: Where did he get wine?

origin: And Trinculo is reeling ripe.
modern: And Trinculo’s drunk.

origin: Why, how now, Stephano?
modern: How are you doing, Stephano?

origin: O, touch me not.
modern: Oh, don’t touch me.

origin: I am not Stephano, but a cramp.
modern: I’m not Stephano, I’m a walking cramp.

origin: You’d be king o' th' isle, sirrah?
modern: You wanted to be king of the island, sir?
