origin: I should have been a sore one then.
modern: I would’ve been a sore king then.

origin: He is as disproportioned in his manners As in his shape.— Take with you your companions.
modern: He’s as ugly in his manners as he is in appearance.— I will indeed.

origin: And I’ll be wise hereafter And seek for grace.
modern: And after this I’ll be good and hope you forgive me.

origin: What a thrice-double ass Was I, to take this drunkard for a god And worship this dull fool!
modern: What an idiot I was to think this drunkard was a god and to worship such a stupid fool!

origin: Go to, away.
modern: Go away, now.

origin: Or stole it, rather.
modern: Or stole it, rather.

origin: And in the morn I’ll bring you to your ship and so to Naples, Where I have hope to see the nuptial Of these our dear-belovèd solemnized, And thence retire me to my Milan, where Every third thought shall be my grave.
modern: And in the morning I’ll take you to your ship and we’ll sail to Naples, where I hope to see this loving couple married.

origin: I long To hear the story of your life, which must Take the ear strangely.
modern: I’m dying to hear your life story, which must be a strange tale.

origin: Now my charms are all o'erthrown, And what strength I have’s mine own, Which is most faint.
modern: Now my spells are all broken, And the only power I have is my own, Which is very weak.

origin: Let me not, Since I have my dukedom got And pardoned the deceiver, dwell In this bare island by your spell, But release me from my bands With the help of your good hands.
modern: Release me So I can return to my dukedom With your help.

origin: As you from crimes would pardoned be, Let your indulgence set me free.
modern: Just as you’d like to have your sins forgiven, Indulge me, forgive me, and set me free.

origin: I pray thee, mark me.
modern: Please listen to me carefully.

origin: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'erprized all popular rate, in my false brother Awaked an evil nature.
modern: As I neglected practical matters, being totally dedicated to solitude and to improving my mind with subjects more valuable than most people imagine, I was so shut away from the world that I unwittingly stirred up evil wishes in my disloyal brother.

origin: And my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in its contrary as great As my trust was, which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.
modern: My deep trust in him made him deeply untrustworthy, arousing in him a treachery as big as my trust was—my trust which had no limit, an infinite confidence.

origin: Hence his ambition growing— Dost thou hear?
modern: With his ambition growing like this—do you hear what I’m saying?

origin: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
modern: Of course I hear it.

origin: Me, poor man, my library Was dukedom large enough.
modern: My library was a large enough dukedom for me.

origin: Oh, the heavens!
modern: Good heavens!

origin: Mark his condition and the event.
modern: Think about that, and about what followed afterward.

origin: Then tell me If this might be a brother.
modern: Then tell me if Antonio can be called a brother.

origin: I should sin To think but nobly of my grandmother.
modern: It would be wrong for me to think poorly of my grandmother.

origin: The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother’s suit, Which was that he, in lieu o' th' premises Of homage and I know not how much tribute, Should presently extirpate me and mine Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan With all the honors on my brother.
modern: The king of Naples, my arch-enemy, listens to my brother’s request, which was that the king, in exchange for the respect and money paid to him, would get rid of me and make my brother Duke of Milan instead.

origin: Alack, for pity!
modern: How awful!

origin: I, not remembering how I cried out then, Will cry it o'er again.
modern: I can’t remember how I cried then, but I’ll cry all over again.

origin: It is a hint That wrings mine eyes to ’t.
modern: This story breaks my heart.

origin: Hear a little further And then I’ll bring thee to the present business Which now ’s upon ’s, without the which this story Were most impertinent.
modern: Just listen a little more, and I’ll bring you up to date about the present situation, which is the whole reason I’m telling you this story in the first place.

origin: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?
modern: Why didn’t they just kill us that night?

origin: Well demanded, wench.
modern: Good question, my girl.

origin: My tale provokes that question.
modern: My story does raise that question.

origin: Dear, they durst not, So dear the love my people bore me, nor set A mark so bloody on the business, but With colors fairer painted their foul ends.
modern: The answer, my dear, is that they didn’t dare, because the people of Milan loved me too much.

origin: Alack, what trouble Was I then to you!
modern: God, what a burden on you I must have been!

origin: Oh, a cherubim Thou wast that did preserve me.
modern: No, my dear, you were a little angel who kept me going.

origin: Thou didst smile Infusèd with a fortitude from heaven, When I have decked the sea with drops full salt, Under my burthen groaned; which raised in me An undergoing stomach to bear up Against what should ensue.
modern: You smiled with a strength you must have gotten from heaven, while I cried salty tears into the salty sea, and groaned at our situation.

origin: How came we ashore?
modern: How did we manage to get ashore?

origin: By providence divine.
modern: With God’s help.

origin: Some food we had and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, Out of his charity, who being then appointed Master of this design, did give us, with Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and necessaries, Which since have steaded much.
modern: We had a little food and fresh water that a nobleman from Naples, Gonzalo, had given us out of the kindness of his heart.

origin: So, of his gentleness, Knowing I loved my books, he furnished me From mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.
modern: Knowing how much I loved my books, he gave me some books from my library that I value more than my dukedom.

origin: Would I might But ever see that man!
modern: I wish I could see that man someday!

origin: Now I arise.
modern: Now I’ll stand up.

origin: Heavens thank you for ’t!
modern: May God thank you for it.

origin: And now, I pray you, sir— For still ’tis beating in my mind—your reason For raising this sea storm?
modern: But please, father—the question is still nagging at me—why did you conjure up this storm?

origin: Know thus far forth: By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune (Now my dear lady) hath mine enemies Brought to this shore.
modern: You should know this: much luck is on my side, and my enemies have happened to wreck their ship on this island.

origin: Here cease more questions.
modern: Now, no more questions.

origin: Tis a good dullness, And give it way.
modern: It’s a nice hazy feeling, so give in to it.

origin: I know thou canst not choose.
modern: I know you have no choice.

origin: Come away, servant, come.
modern: Come on, servant, come.

origin: I am ready now.
modern: I’m ready now.

origin: Approach, my Ariel, come.
modern: Come here, Ariel.

origin: All hail, great master!
modern: Humble greetings, great master!

origin: Grave sir, hail!
modern: Worthy sir, greetings!

origin: Hast thou, spirit, Performed to point the tempest that I bade thee?
modern: Spirit, did you carry out the storm just as I ordered?

origin: Sometime I’d divide, And burn in many places.
modern: Sometimes I appeared in many places at once.

origin: Jove’s lightning, the precursors O' th' dreadful thunderclaps, more momentary And sight-outrunning were not.
modern: I flashed about faster than lightning.

origin: My brave spirit!
modern: Good spirit!

origin: Boatswain!
modern: Boatswain!

origin: Here, master.
modern: I’m here, sir.

origin: What cheer?
modern: Hurry, hurry!

origin: Good, speak to th' mariners.
modern: Come on, men!

origin: Fall to ’t yarely, or we run ourselves aground.
modern: That’s the way to do it!

origin: Where’s the Master?
modern: Where’s the Master?

origin: Play the men.
modern: Make these men work.

origin: I pray now, keep below.
modern: Please stay below deck, sir.

origin: Where is the Master, Boatswain?
modern: Where’s the Master, Boatswain?

origin: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and played Some tricks of desperation.
modern: Everyone there got a little crazy and pulled some desperate stunts.

origin: All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me.
modern: Everyone except the sailors dove into the sea, leaving behind the ship that I had set on fire.

origin: The king’s son, Ferdinand, With hair up-staring—then, like reeds, not hair— Was the first man that leaped, cried, “Hell is empty And all the devils are here.”      Why, that’s my spirit!
modern: The king’s son, Ferdinand, with his hair standing straight up—it looked like reeds, not hair—was the first person to jump, shouting, “Hell is empty, and all the devils are here!” Good job!

origin: But was not this nigh shore?
modern: But was this near the shore?

origin: Close by, my master.
modern: Very near, my master.

origin: But are they, Ariel, safe?
modern: But are they all safe, Ariel?

origin: Not a hair perished.
modern: Nobody was hurt in the slightest.

origin: On their sustaining garments not a blemish, But fresher than before.
modern: Even their clothes are unstained, and look fresher than before the storm.

origin: And, as thou badest me, In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
modern: I’ve separated them into groups around the island, just as you ordered.

origin: The king’s son have I landed by himself, Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs In an odd angle of the isle, and sitting, His arms in this sad knot.
modern: I sent the king’s son off by himself to a faraway nook on the island, where he’s sitting now sighing, with his arms crossed like this.

origin: Of the king’s ship, The mariners, say how thou hast disposed, And all the rest o' th' fleet.
modern: Tell me what you did with the king’s ship, the sailors, and the other ships.

origin: The mariners all under hatches stowed, Who, with a charm joined to their suffered labor, I have left asleep.
modern: The sailors are all below deck, sleeping both from their labor and from a magic spell I cast over them.

origin: And for the rest o' th' fleet, Which I dispersed, they all have met again And are upon the Mediterranean float, Bound sadly home for Naples, Supposing that they saw the king’s ship wracked And his great person perish.
modern: As for the rest of the ships, I scattered them, and they’ve gathered again in the Mediterranean, sailing sadly home to Naples, believing that they witnessed the shipwreck and death of their great king.

origin: Ariel, thy charge Exactly is performed.
modern: Ariel, you’ve done your work exactly as I ordered.

origin: But there’s more work.
modern: But there’s more work to be done.

origin: What is the time o' th' day?
modern: What time is it?

origin: Past the mid season.
modern: Past noon.

origin: At least two glasses.
modern: At least two hours past.

origin: The time ’twixt six and now Must by us both be spent most preciously.
modern: We can’t waste time between now and six o'clock.

origin: Is there more toil?
modern: Is there more work to do?

origin: Since thou dost give me pains, Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet performed me.
modern: Since you’re giving me new assignments, let me remind you what you promised me but haven’t come through with yet.

origin: How now?
modern: What?

origin: Moody?
modern: You’re in a bad mood?

origin: What is ’t thou canst demand?
modern: What could you possibly ask for?

origin: My liberty.
modern: My freedom.

origin: Before the time be out?
modern: Before your sentence has been completed?

origin: No more!
modern: Don’t say anything else.

origin: I prithee, Remember I have done thee worthy service, Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served Without or grudge or grumblings.
modern: I beg you, remember the good work I’ve done for you, and how I’ve never lied to you, never made mistakes, and never grumbled in my work.

origin: Thou didst promise To bate me a full year.
modern: You promised to take a full year off my sentence.

origin: Dost thou forget From what a torment I did free thee?
modern: Have you forgotten the torture I freed you from?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Thou dost, and think’st it much to tread the ooze Of the salt deep, To run upon the sharp wind of the north, To do me business in the veins o' th' earth When it is baked with frost.
modern: You have forgotten, and you think it’s a burden when I ask you to walk through the ocean, or run on the north wind, or do business for me underground when the earth’s frozen solid.

origin: I do not, sir.
modern: No, I don’t, sir.

origin: Thou liest, malignant thing!
modern: You lie, you nasty, ungrateful thing!

origin: Hast thou forgot The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy Was grown into a hoop?
modern: Have you forgotten the horrid witch Sycorax, stooped over with old age and ill will?

origin: Hast thou forgot her?
modern: Have you forgotten her?

origin: No, sir.
modern: No, sir.

origin: Thou hast.
modern: You have.

origin: Where was she born?
modern: Where was she born?

origin: Speak.
modern: Speak.

origin: Tell me.
modern: Tell me.

origin: Sir, in Argier.
modern: In Algiers, sir.

origin: Oh, was she so?
modern: Oh, was she now?

origin: I must Once in a month recount what thou hast been, Which thou forget’st.
modern: I’ll have to tell the story again every month, since you seem to forget it.

origin: This damned witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Argier, Thou know’st, was banished.
modern: This damned witch Sycorax was kicked out of Algiers for various witching crimes too terrible for humans to hear about.

origin: For one thing she did They would not take her life.
modern: But for one reason they refused to execute her.

origin: Is not this true?
modern: Isn’t that true?

origin: Ay, sir.
modern: Yes, sir.

origin: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child And here was left by th' sailors.
modern: This sunken-eyed hag was brought here pregnant and left by the sailors.

origin: Thou, my slave, As thou report’st thyself, wast then her servant.
modern: You, my slave, were her servant at the time, as you admit yourself.

origin: And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate To act her earthy and abhorred commands, Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee, By help of her more potent ministers And in her most unmitigable rage, Into a cloven pine, within which rift Imprisoned thou didst painfully remain A dozen years; within which space she died And left thee there, where thou didst vent thy groans As fast as mill wheels strike.
modern: In a fit of rage she locked you up in a hollow pine tree, with the help of her powerful assistants, and left you there for twelve years.

origin: Dull thing, I say so.
modern: That’s right, you stupid thing.

origin: He, that Caliban Whom now I keep in service.
modern: Caliban, who now serves me.

origin: It was mine art, When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape The pine and let thee out.
modern: It was my magic that saved you when I arrived on the island and heard you, making the pine tree open and let you out.

origin: I thank thee, master.
modern: Thank you, master.

origin: If thou more murmur’st, I will rend an oak And peg thee in his knotty entrails till Thou hast howled away twelve winters.
modern: If you complain any more, I’ll split an oak tree and lock you up in it till you’ve howled for twelve years.

origin: Pardon, master.
modern: Please forgive me, master.

origin: I will be correspondent to command And do my spiriting gently.
modern: I’ll be obedient and do all my tasks without complaining.

origin: Do so, and after two days I will discharge thee.
modern: Do that, and I’ll set you free in two days.

origin: That’s my noble master!
modern: That’s noble of you, master.

origin: What shall I do?
modern: What shall I do for you?

origin: Say, what?
modern: Just tell me.

origin: What shall I do?
modern: What shall I do?

origin: Go make thyself like a nymph o' th' sea.
modern: Go disguise yourself as a sea nymph.

origin: Be subject To no sight but thine and mine, invisible To every eyeball else.
modern: Be invisible to everyone except yourself and me.

origin: Go take this shape And hither come in ’t.
modern: Take this garment, put it on, and then come back here.

origin: Go hence with diligence.
modern: Hurry, go!

origin: Shake it off.
modern: Shake off your sleepiness.

origin: Come on.
modern: Come on.

origin: We’ll visit Caliban, my slave who never Yields us kind answer.
modern: We’ll go visit Caliban, my slave who always talks to us so nastily.

origin: But as ’tis, We cannot miss him.
modern: But even so, we can’t do without him.

origin: He does make our fire, Fetch in our wood, and serves in offices That profit us.—What, ho!
modern: He builds our fires, gets our firewood, and does all kinds of useful things for us.—Hey!

origin: Slave!
modern: Caliban!

origin: Caliban!
modern: Pile of dirt!

origin: Speak.
modern: Say something.

origin: Come forth, I say!
modern: Come out, I order you.

origin: There’s other business for thee.
modern: There’s other work for you to do.

origin: Come, thou tortoise!
modern: Come on, you turtle!

origin: Fine apparition!
modern: What a fine sight!

origin: My quaint Ariel, Hark in thine ear.
modern: My dear clever Ariel, listen carefully.

origin: My lord it shall be done.
modern: My lord, I’ll do it right away.

origin: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed With raven’s feather from unwholesome fen Drop on you both!
modern: I hope you both get drenched with a dew as evil as what my mother used to collect with a crow’s feather from the poison swamps.

origin: A southwest blow on ye And blister you all o'er!
modern: May a hot southwest wind blow on you and cover you with blisters all over.

origin: For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps, Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up.
modern: I’ll give you cramps for saying that—horrible pains in your sides that will keep you from breathing.

origin: Urchins Shall, forth at vast of night that they may work, All exercise on thee.
modern: I’ll send goblins out at night to work their nasty deeds on you.

origin: Thou shalt be pinched As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging Than bees that made 'em.
modern: You’ll be pricked all over, and it’ll sting like bees.

origin: I must eat my dinner.
modern: I have to eat my dinner now.

origin: This island’s mine, by Sycorax my mother, Which thou takest from me.
modern: This island belongs to me because Sycorax, my mother, left it to me.

origin: Cursed be I that did so!
modern: I curse myself for doing that!

origin: Thou most lying slave, Whom stripes may move, not kindness!
modern: You liar, you respond better to the whip than to kindness!

origin: I have used thee, Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee In mine own cell till thou didst seek to violate The honor of my child.
modern: I took good care of you—piece of filth that you are—and let you stay in my own hut until you tried to rape my daughter.

origin: Oh ho, oh ho!
modern: Oh ho, oh ho!

origin: Would ’t had been done!
modern: I wish I had!

origin: Thou didst prevent me.
modern: You stopped me.

origin: Abhorrèd slave, Which any print of goodness wilt not take, Being capable of all ill!
modern: You horrid slave, you can’t be trained to be good, and you’re capable of anything evil!

origin: I pitied thee, Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour One thing or other.
modern: I pitied you, worked hard to teach you to speak, and taught you some new thing practically every hour.

origin: But thy vile race, Though thou didst learn, had that in ’t which good natures Could not abide to be with.
modern: But you had bad blood in you, no matter how much you learned, and good people couldn’t stand to be near you.

origin: Therefore wast thou Deservedly confined into this rock, Who hadst deserved more than a prison.
modern: So you got what you deserved, and were locked up in this cave, which is more fitting for the likes of you than a prison would be.

origin: You taught me language, and my profit on ’t Is I know how to curse.
modern: You taught me language, and all I can do with it is curse.

origin: The red plague rid you For learning me your language!
modern: Damn you for teaching me your language!

origin: No, pray thee.
modern: No, please.

origin: So, slave, hence!
modern: Go then, slave.

origin: The watchdogs bark.
modern: The watchdogs bark.

origin: Hark, hark!
modern: Listen, listen!

origin: I hear The strain of strutting chanticleer Cry “Cock-a-diddle-dow.” Where should this music be?
modern: Where’s that music coming from?

origin: I' th' air or th' earth?
modern: From the earth, or the air?

origin: It sounds no more, and sure, it waits upon Some god o' th' island.
modern: It’s stopped now—it must be played for some local god of the island.

origin: Sitting on a bank, Weeping again the king my father’s wrack, This music crept by me upon the waters, Allaying both their fury and my passion With its sweet air.
modern: As I sat on the shore crying over my father’s shipwreck, I heard the music creep over the wild waves, calming their fury and soothing my own grief with its sweet melodies.

origin: Thence I have followed it, Or it hath drawn me rather.
modern: I followed it here, or I should say it dragged me here.

origin: But ’tis gone.
modern: But now it’s stopped.

origin: No, it begins again.
modern: No, there it is again.

origin: Hark, now I hear them.
modern: Listen, I hear them.

origin: The ditty does remember my drowned father.
modern: This song’s about my dead father.

origin: I hear it now above me.
modern: I hear it now overhead.

origin: What is ’t?
modern: What is it?

origin: A spirit?
modern: A spirit?

origin: Lord, how it looks about!
modern: Lord, it’s glancing every which way!

origin: Believe me, sir, It carries a brave form.
modern: How handsome it is.

origin: But ’tis a spirit.
modern: It must be a spirit.

origin: No, wench!
modern: No, girl!

origin: It eats and sleeps and hath such senses As we have, such.
modern: It eats and sleeps and has the same five senses we do.

origin: He hath lost his fellows And strays about to find 'em.
modern: He’s lost his comrades and is wandering around looking for them.

origin: Do you not hear him?
modern: He’s busy, can’t you hear him giving orders?

origin: You mar our labor.
modern: You’re getting in the way of our work.

origin: Keep your cabins.
modern: Stay in your cabins.

origin: You do assist the storm.
modern: You’re helping the storm, not us.

origin: Nay, good, be patient.
modern: Don’t get wound up, my good man.

origin: Hence!
modern: Now get out of here!

origin: To cabin, silence!
modern: Go to your cabins and be quiet!

origin: Trouble us not.
modern: Don’t bother us up here.

origin: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
modern: Just remember who you’ve got on board with you, good man.

origin: None that I more love than myself.
modern: Nobody I care about more than myself.

origin: You are a councilor.
modern: You’re a king’s advisor.

origin: Use your authority.
modern: Go ahead, use your authority.

origin: If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap.—Cheerly, good hearts!—Out of our way, I say.
modern: If you can’t do it, be grateful you’ve lived this long and go wait to die in your cabin, if it comes to that.—Harder, men!—Now get out of our way, I’m telling you.

origin: I have great comfort from this fellow.
modern: I feel a lot better after talking to this guy.

origin: I might call him A thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.
modern: I could imagine he’s divine, since I never saw anything so noble-looking on earth before.

origin: No wonder, sir, But certainly a maid.
modern: I’m not marvelous, sir, but I’m certainly a maiden.

origin: My language!
modern: She speaks my language!

origin: Heavens, I am the best of them that speak this speech, Were I but where ’tis spoken.
modern: My God, I’m the highest-ranking person who speaks this language—if only we were back where it’s spoken.

origin: How?
modern: What’s that?

origin: The best?
modern: The highest-ranking?

origin: What wert thou if the King of Naples heard thee?
modern: What would the King of Naples do if he heard you say that?

origin: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.
modern: He would just see me for what I am, a person amazed to hear you talking about Naples.

origin: He does hear me, And that he does I weep.
modern: He does hear me, and that makes me cry.

origin: Myself am Naples, Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld The king my father wracked.
modern: I myself am the King of Naples, since I saw with my own eyes—these eyes that haven’t been dry since—my father killed in a shipwreck.

origin: Alack, for mercy!
modern: Ah, how pitiful!

origin: Yes, faith, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan And his brave son being twain.
modern: Yes, indeed, and all the King’s men, the Duke of Milan and his fine son too.

origin: Soft, sir!
modern: Hang on, sir!

origin: One word more.
modern: Just a moment.

origin: If the ill spirit have so fair a house, Good things will strive to dwell with ’t.
modern: If the devil had such a beautiful house as his body, then good things would fight to live in it.

origin: What, I say?
modern: What’s that?

origin: Come from thy ward, For I can here disarm thee with this stick And make thy weapon drop.
modern: Get out of that position, because I can disarm you with my magic wand and make your sword drop.

origin: Beseech you, father.
modern: Please, father, I beg you.

origin: Hence!
modern: Let go of me!

origin: Hang not on my garments.
modern: Don’t tug on my clothes.

origin: Sir, have pity, I’ll be his surety.
modern: Father, take pity on him.

origin: Silence!
modern: Quiet!

origin: One word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee.
modern: If you say one more word, I’ll punish you, maybe even hate you.

origin: What, An advocate for an imposter?
modern: You’re defending an impostor?

origin: Hush, Thou think’st there is no more such shapes as he, Having seen but him and Caliban.
modern: You think he’s special, since you’ve only ever seen him and Caliban.

origin: Foolish wench, To th' most of men this is a Caliban And they to him are angels.
modern: Foolish girl, in the eyes of most people this man’s a Caliban, and compared to him, they’re angels.

origin: My affections Are then most humble.
modern: Then my love is humble.

origin: I have no ambition To see a goodlier man.
modern: I don’t feel any urge to see a more handsome man than this one.

origin: So they are.
modern: That’s true, they are.

origin: My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
modern: My strength is all gone, as if in a dream.

origin: My father’s loss, the weakness which I feel, The wrack of all my friends, nor this man’s threats, To whom I am subdued, are but light to me, Might I but through my prison once a day Behold this maid.
modern: The death of my father, my physical weakness, the loss of all my friends, the threats of this man who’s taken me prisoner—all that would be easy for me to take, if only I could look through my prison windows once a day and see this girl.

origin: Space enough Have I in such a prison.
modern: A prison like that would give me enough liberty.

origin: Prithee, peace.
modern: Please say no more.

origin: A dollar.
modern: What a pain.

origin: Dolor comes to him, indeed.
modern: Pain, yes indeed.

origin: You have spoken truer than you purposed.
modern: You thought you were being funny, but you said the truth.

origin: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
modern: You’re taking it more seriously than I meant it.

origin: Well, I have done.
modern: Well, I’m nearly finished.

origin: But yet—   Which, of he or Adrian, for a good wager, first begins to crow?
modern: Which one will start yammering first, Gonzalo or Adrian?

origin: The old cock.
modern: The old guy.

origin: The cockerel.
modern: I pick the younger one.

origin: Done.
modern: You’re on.

origin: The wager?
modern: What’s the prize?

origin: A laughter.
modern: A good laugh.

origin: A match!
modern: It’s a deal!

origin: Though this island seem to be desert—
modern: Though this island may appear desolate—

origin: It must needs be of subtle, tender, and delicate temperance.
modern: The island must be mild, and have a temperate climate.

origin: Temperance was a delicate wench.
modern: I knew Temperance—she was a fine girl.

origin: Ay, and a subtle, as he most learnedly delivered.
modern: Yes, and she was mild too.

origin: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
modern: There’s always a breath of fresh air here.

origin: Or as ’twere perfumed by a fen.
modern: Stinking like a swamp.

origin: Here is everything advantageous to life.
modern: This island contains everything beneficial to life.

origin: True.
modern: True.

origin: Save means to live.
modern: Everything except something to live on.

origin: Of that there’s none, or little.
modern: There’s little or nothing of that.

origin: How lush and lusty the grass looks!
modern: Look how lush and healthy the grass is!

origin: How green!
modern: How green!

origin: The ground indeed is tawny.
modern: The ground is brown.

origin: With an eye of green in ’t.
modern: With a touch of green in it.

origin: He misses not much.
modern: He doesn’t miss a thing.

origin: No, he doth but mistake the truth totally.
modern: No, he just gets reality completely wrong.

origin: But the rarity of it is—which is indeed almost beyond credit—  As many vouched rarities are.
modern: But the really unbelievable thing is—and this is incredible— As most unbelievable things are.

origin: That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
modern: That our clothes were drenched with sea water, but they came out looking brand-new.

origin: Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
modern: Or stuff what he says into their pockets.

origin: Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king’s fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
modern: Seriously, I think our clothes are as fresh now as they were the day we put them on in Africa, when we attended the marriage of the king’s daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.

origin: Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
modern: It was a lovely wedding, and we’re doing really well on our trip home.

origin: Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
modern: Tunis has never had such a beautiful queen.

origin: Widow Dido” said you?
modern: Next thing you know, he’ll be saying “widower Aeneas.” “Widow Dido,” did you say?

origin: You make me study of that.
modern: I’m not sure about that.

origin: She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
modern: Dido was from Carthage, not Tunis.

origin: Carthage?
modern: Carthage?

origin: I assure you, Carthage.
modern: I’m telling you, it was Carthage.

origin: His word is more than the miraculous harp.
modern: Gonzalo is a miracle-worker.

origin: What impossible matter will he make easy next?
modern: What miracle will he work next?

origin: I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
modern: I think he’ll carry this island home in his pocket and give it to his son like an apple.

origin: And sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
modern: And then throw the seeds in the sea, to make more islands grow.

origin: Ay.
modern: Yes indeed.

origin: Why, in good time.
modern: Absolutely, yes indeed.

origin: Down with the topmast!
modern: Bring down that top sail!

origin: Yare, lower, lower!
modern: Fast!

origin: Bring her to try wi' th' main course.
modern: Let the ship sail close to the wind.

origin: A plague upon this howling!
modern: Damn those men shouting down there!

origin: They are louder than the weather or our office.
modern: They’re louder than the storm or us sailors.

origin: Yet again?
modern: Oh, not you again.

origin: What do you here?
modern: What do you want?

origin: Shall we give o'er and drown?
modern: Should we all give up and drown?

origin: Have you a mind to sink?
modern: Do you want to sink?

origin: I’ll warrant him for drowning though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
modern: Yes, I guarantee he won’t drown—even if this ship were as fragile as an eggshell and as leaky as a menstruating woman.

origin: Lay her a-hold, a-hold!
modern: Turn the ship to the wind!

origin: All lost!
modern: It’s no use!

origin: To prayers, to prayers, all lost!
modern: We’re done for!

origin: And the rarest that e'er came there.
modern: The most beautiful queen they ever had.

origin: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
modern: I beg your pardon, except for the widow Dido.

origin: Oh, widow Dido?
modern: Oh, except for the widow Dido?

origin: Ay, widow Dido.
modern: That’s right, except for the widow Dido.

origin: Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it?
modern: Isn’t my vest just as clean and fresh as the day I put it on?

origin: I mean, in a sort.
modern: In a way, I mean.

origin: That “sort” was well fished for.
modern: In a way” is the right way to go.

origin: When I wore it at your daughter’s marriage?
modern: I mean when I wore it at your daughter’s wedding.

origin: You cram these words into mine ears against The stomach of my sense.
modern: You keep cramming words into my ears that I don’t want to hear.

origin: Sir, he may live.
modern: Sir, he may still be alive.

origin: I not doubt He came alive to land.
modern: I have no doubt he got ashore alive.

origin: No, no, he’s gone.
modern: No, no, he’s dead.

origin: Prithee, peace.
modern: Please be quiet.

origin: You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise By all of us, and the fair soul herself Weighed between loathness and obedience, at Which end o' th' beam should bow.
modern: We all begged you not to go ahead with those marriage plans, and your lovely daughter struggled between disgust at marrying an African and the desire to obey you.

origin: We have lost your son, I fear, forever.
modern: Now I’m afraid we’ve lost your son forever.

origin: Milan and Naples have More widows in them of this business' making Than we bring men to comfort them.
modern: Our shipwreck has made more women widows in Milan and Naples than there are survivors to comfort them.

origin: The fault’s your own.
modern: And it’s all your fault.

origin: So is the dearest o' th' loss.
modern: And the greatest sorrow is mine too.

origin: My lord Sebastian, The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness And time to speak it in.
modern: My lord Sebastian, even though what you say is true, your way of saying it is tactless and comes at the wrong time.

origin: You rub the sore When you should bring the plaster.
modern: You’re rubbing salt in his wounds when you should be applying bandages.

origin: Very well.
modern: All right, I’ll stop.

origin: And most chirurgeonly.
modern: Like a good doctor.

origin: Foul weather?
modern: Bad times?

origin: Very foul.
modern: Yes, very bad.

origin: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord— He’d sow ’t with nettle seed.
modern: If I could colonize this island, my lord— He’d cultivate weeds on it.

origin: Or docks, or mallows.
modern: Or thorn-bushes.

origin: And were the king on ’t, what would I do?
modern: And if I were king of it, you know what I’d do?

origin: Scape being drunk for want of wine.
modern: He wouldn’t get drunk much, since there’s no wine here.

origin: For no kind of traffic Would I admit.
modern: I wouldn’t allow any commerce.

origin: No occupation.
modern: There’d be no work.

origin: No sovereignty—     Yet he would be king on ’t.
modern: There’d be no kingship— He wants to be king in a place with no kingship.

origin: All things in common nature should produce Without sweat or endeavor.
modern: Everything would be produced without labor, and would be shared by all.

origin: But nature should bring forth Of its own kind all foison, all abundance, To feed my innocent people.
modern: Nature would produce its harvests in abundance, to feed my innocent people.

origin: No marrying ’mong his subjects?
modern: There’d be no marriage?

origin: None, man.
modern: No.

origin: Prithee, no more.
modern: Oh, please be quiet.

origin: Thou dost talk nothing to me.
modern: You’re absolutely right, your highness.

origin: Twas you we laughed at.
modern: It’s you we were laughing at.

origin: What a blow was there given!
modern: Ouch, what a comeback!

origin: An it had not fallen flat-long.
modern: Too bad it fell flat.

origin: You are gentlemen of brave mettle.
modern: You’re brave gentlemen.

origin: You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
modern: You’d give the moon a shove if it got stuck five weeks in its orbit.

origin: We would so, and then go a-batfowling.
modern: That’s right, and then after we fixed the moon, we’d go bird-hunting.

origin: No, I warrant you.
modern: I’m not.

origin: Go sleep, and hear us.
modern: Go to sleep, and listen to us laughing.

origin: What, all so soon asleep?
modern: What, everybody falls asleep so fast?

origin: I wish mine eyes Would with themselves shut up my thoughts.
modern: I wish I could sleep too—it would stop me from thinking.

origin: Please you, sir, Do not omit the heavy offer of it.
modern: Come to think of it, I am feeling sleepy.

origin: It seldom visits sorrow.
modern: In that case you should sleep.

origin: We two, my lord, Will guard your person while you take your rest And watch your safety.
modern: The two of us will guard you while you sleep, my lord, and keep you safe.

origin: Thank you.
modern: Thank you.

origin: Wondrous heavy.
modern: I’m terribly sleepy.

origin: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!
modern: How strange that they all got so sleepy!

origin: It is the quality o' th' climate.
modern: There must be something in the air here.

origin: Why Doth it not then our eyelids sink?
modern: So why aren’t our eyelids heavy?

origin: I find not Myself disposed to sleep.
modern: I’m not sleepy at all.

origin: Nor I.
modern: Me neither.

origin: My spirits are nimble.
modern: I’m wide awake.

origin: They fell together all, as by consent.
modern: They all fell asleep together, as if they’d planned it.

origin: Th' occasion speaks thee, and My strong imagination sees a crown Dropping upon thy head.
modern: Opportunity’s knocking for you, and in my imagination I see a crown dropping onto your head.

origin: What, art thou waking?
modern: Are you dreaming or awake?

origin: Do you not hear me speak?
modern: Don’t you hear me speaking?

origin: I do, and surely It is a sleepy language, and thou speak’st Out of thy sleep.
modern: I do, and it sounds like you’re talking in your sleep.

origin: What is it thou didst say?
modern: What did you say?

origin: Thou dost snore distinctly.
modern: You’re snoring, but it sounds like you’re talking.

origin: There’s meaning in thy snores.
modern: There’s meaning in your snoring.

origin: I’ll teach you how to flow.
modern: I’ll show you how.

origin: Do so.
modern: You need to.

origin: Oh, If you but knew how you the purpose cherish Whiles thus you mock it!
modern: Oh, if you only knew how close to success you are, even while you make fun of what I’m telling you!

origin: How, in stripping it, You more invest it!
modern: The more you joke about it, the more clearly I feel how serious it is!

origin: Ebbing men indeed Most often do so near the bottom run By their own fear or sloth.
modern: Lazy people end up at the bottom, and you deserve to be at the top.

origin: Prithee, say on.
modern: Please, tell me more.

origin: I have no hope That he’s undrowned.
modern: Yes, I’m sure he’s dead.

origin: Oh, out of that “no hope” What great hope have you!
modern: I’ve got no hope that he survived.

origin: No hope that way is Another way so high a hope that even Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond, But doubt discovery there.
modern: But in that “no hope” there are great hopes for you!

origin: Will you grant with me That Ferdinand is drowned?
modern: Do you agree that Ferdinand must have drowned?

origin: He’s gone.
modern: He’s dead.

origin: Then, tell me, Who’s the next heir of Naples?
modern: So, in that case, tell me who’s next in line to inherit the kingdom of Naples?

origin: Claribel.
modern: Claribel, his daughter.

origin: Tis true, my brother’s daughter’s Queen of Tunis, So is she heir of Naples, ’twixt which regions There is some space.
modern: It’s true that my brother’s daughter is Queen of Tunis, and heir of Naples.

origin: I myself could make A chough of as deep chat.
modern: I could do it myself.

origin: Oh, that you bore The mind that I do, what a sleep were this For your advancement!
modern: Do you even get what I’m saying?

origin: Methinks I do.
modern: I think I do.

origin: And how does your content Tender your own good fortune?
modern: And does this prospect of good fortune make you happy?

origin: I remember You did supplant your brother Prospero.
modern: I remember you took the throne from your brother Prospero.

origin: My brother’s servants Were then my fellows.
modern: My brother’s servants used to be my equals.

origin: Now they are my men.
modern: Now they work for me.

origin: But, for your conscience?
modern: But what about your guilty conscience?

origin: Ay, sir.
modern: Yes.

origin: But I feel not This deity in my bosom.
modern: I don’t feel anything.

origin: Should not upbraid our course.
modern: As

origin: For all the rest, They’ll take suggestion as a cat laps milk.
modern: for the other men, we can make them believe anything we choose.

origin: They’ll tell the clock to any business that We say befits the hour.
modern: They’ll set their watches to whatever time we say.

origin: Thy case, dear friend, Shall be my precedent.
modern: You’ll be my role model.

origin: As thou got’st Milan, I’ll come by Naples.
modern: Just as you got Milan, I’ll get Naples.

origin: Draw thy sword.
modern: Take out your sword.

origin: One stroke Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest.
modern: With one cut you can be through paying money to Naples.

origin: And I the king shall love thee.
modern: And as king I’ll love you forever.

origin: Draw together.
modern: You take out your sword too.

origin: And when I rear my hand, do you the like, To fall it on Gonzalo.
modern: When I raise my hand, you do the same, and bring it down on Gonzalo’s head.

origin: O, but one word.
modern: Oh, but there’s one more thing to tell you.

origin: What, must our mouths be cold?
modern: What, we’re going to die?

origin: The king and prince at prayers.
modern: The king and the prince are praying.

origin: I’m out of patience.
modern: I’m out of patience.

origin: He’ll be hanged yet, though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him.
modern: This bigmouth jerk here—( He’ll still die by hanging, not drowning, even if every drop of water in the sea tries to swallow him.

origin: Let’s all sink wi' th' king.
modern: Let’s all sink with the king.

origin: Let’s take leave of him.
modern: Let’s say goodbye to him.

origin: Then let us both be sudden.
modern: Let’s act quickly.

origin: Why are you drawn?
modern: Why are your swords out?

origin: Wherefore this ghastly looking?
modern: Why do you look like that?

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s this all about?

origin: Whiles we stood here securing your repose, Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing Like bulls, or rather lions.
modern: While we were here guarding you as you slept, we heard a loud roar that sounded like bulls, or lions.

origin: Did ’t not wake you?
modern: Didn’t you hear it?

origin: It struck mine ear most terribly.
modern: We heard it very clearly.

origin: I heard nothing.
modern: I didn’t hear anything.

origin: Oh, ’twas a din to fright a monster’s ear, To make an earthquake!
modern: Oh, it was a monstrous roar, to make the earth tremble!

origin: Sure, it was the roar Of a whole herd of lions.
modern: I’m sure there was a herd of lions nearby.

origin: Heard you this, Gonzalo?
modern: Did you hear this, Gonzalo?

origin: Upon mine honor, sir, I heard a humming, And that a strange one too, which did awake me.
modern: It’s true I heard a humming sound, a strange one, which woke me up.

origin: I shaked you, sir, and cried.
modern: I shook you and shouted at you, sir.

origin: As mine eyes opened, I saw their weapons drawn.
modern: When I opened my eyes, I saw their swords out.

origin: There was a noise, That’s verily.
modern: There was a noise, that’s certainly true.

origin: Let’s draw our weapons.
modern: Let’s draw our own swords too.

origin: Heavens keep him from these beasts!
modern: I hope those lions stay far away from him.

origin: For he is, sure, i' th' island.
modern: I’m sure he’s somewhere on the island.

origin: Lead away.
modern: Get us out of here.

origin: His spirits hear me And yet I needs must curse.
modern: His spirits are listening to me, but I can’t help cursing him anyway.

origin: But they’ll nor pinch, Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' th' mire, Nor lead me like a firebrand in the dark Out of my way, unless he bid 'em.
modern: They won’t pinch me, frighten me, push me in the mud, or mislead me unless he tells them to.

origin: Sometime am I All wound with adders who with cloven tongues Do hiss me into madness.
modern: Sometimes snakes wrap around me, hissing at me with their forked tongues till I go crazy.

origin: Lo, now, lo!
modern: Hey, look over there!

origin: Perchance he will not mind me.
modern: Maybe he won’t see me.

origin: Here’s neither bush nor shrub to bear off any weather at all.
modern: There are no bushes or shrubs to protect me from the weather here.

origin: And another storm brewing, I hear it sing i' th' wind.
modern: And there’s another storm brewing—I can hear it in the way the wind whistles.

origin: Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor.
modern: That huge black cloud over there looks like a filthy liquor jug that’s about to pour out its contents.

origin: A strange fish!
modern: A strange fish.

origin: Were I in England now, as once I was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver.
modern: If I were in England now, like I was once, and I had even a painted picture of this fish, every fool there would give me a piece of silver to look at it.

origin: There would this monster make a man.
modern: In England this strange monster would be just like a man.

origin: Any strange beast there makes a man.
modern: Any strange beast there can be considered a man.

origin: When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian.
modern: The men there won’t give a penny to a lame beggar, but they’ll pay ten cents to look at a freak show exhibit.

origin: Legged like a man and his fins like arms!
modern: This guy has legs like a man but fins for arms!

origin: Warm, o' my troth.
modern: And he’s still warm, by God.

origin: I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
modern: I guess this is not a fish, but a native who got struck by lightning just now.

origin: Alas, the storm is come again!
modern: Oh, here comes the storm again.

origin: My best way is to creep under his gaberdine.
modern: The best thing to do is crawl under his cloak.

origin: There is no other shelter hereabouts.
modern: There’s no other shelter around here.

origin: Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.
modern: In emergencies you meet the strangest folks.

origin: I will here shroud till the dregs of the storm be past.
modern: I’ll just stay here till the storm passes.

origin: This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man’s funeral.
modern: This is a rotten song to sing at a man’s funeral.

origin: Well, here’s my comfort.
modern: At least I’ve got some booze to comfort me.

origin: Do not torment me.
modern: Don’t hurt me.

origin: Oh!
modern: Oh!

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s going on?

origin: Have we devils here?
modern: Do we have devils on the island?

origin: Do you put tricks upon ’s with savages and men of Ind, ha?
modern: Are you playing tricks on me by showing me savages and uncivilized men from the Indies, ha?

origin: I have not ’scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs.
modern: I didn’t survive a shipwreck so I could be scared of your four legs now.

origin: The spirit torments me.
modern: The spirit is torturing me.

origin: Oh!
modern: Oh!

origin: This is some monster of the isle with four legs who hath got, as I take it, an ague.
modern: This is some monster of the island, with four legs, who seems to me to have some kind of ache.

origin: Where the devil should he learn our language?
modern: How the hell does he know our language?

origin: I will give him some relief if it be but for that.
modern: I’ll help out, if only because he speaks the same language as me.

origin: If I can recover him and keep him tame and get to Naples with him, he’s a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat’s leather.
modern: If I can cure him from his fever and tame him, and get him back to Naples, he’d make a great present for any emperor.

origin: Do not torment me, prithee.
modern: Don’t hurt me, please.

origin: I’ll bring my wood home faster.
modern: I promise I’ll carry the wood faster.

origin: He’s in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest.
modern: He’s having a fit and talking nonsense.

origin: He shall taste of my bottle.
modern: I’ll give him some liquor.

origin: If he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit.
modern: If he’s never drunk it before, it’ll help soothe his fever.

origin: If I can recover him and keep him tame, I will not take too much for him.
modern: If I can tame him, I’ll charge as much as I can get for him.

origin: He shall pay for him that hath him, and that soundly.
modern: He’ll bring a lot of money to the person who owns him, that’s for sure.

origin: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
modern: Now, you lie there on the path.

origin: Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion.
modern: She said if she were interested in someone, it would be someone who looked like me.

origin: Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her.
modern: Besides, she treats me more respectfully than the other servants.

origin: What should I think on ’t?
modern: What’s the obvious conclusion from that?

origin: To be Count Malvolio!
modern: Just think, I could be Count Malvolio!

origin: The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.
modern: Lady Strachy married her wardrobe manager.

origin: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him.
modern: I’d send seven of my servants to go get him.

origin: I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my—some rich jewel.
modern: While I waited, I’d frown impatiently, and perhaps wind my watch, or play with my—with some expensive piece of jewelry I happen to be wearing.

origin: Lips, do not move; No man must know.”
modern: I can’t let my lips say his name; “No man must know.”

origin: No man must know.” What follows?
modern: No man must know.” What comes after that?

origin: No man must know.” If this should be thee, Malvolio?
modern: No man must know.” What if this someone were you, Malvolio?

origin: I may command where I adore, But silence, like a Lucrece knife, With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore; M.O.A.I.
modern: But silence, like a knife, cuts open my heart With strokes that draw no blood.

origin: doth sway my life.” Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.
modern: rules my life.” Hmm, let me see, let me see, let me see.

origin: I may command where I adore.” Why, she may command me.
modern: I may command the one I love.” Well, she commands me.

origin: Why, this is evident to any formal capacity.
modern: Why, anyone can see what this means.

origin: There is no obstruction in this.
modern: There’s no ambiguity here.

origin: If I could make that resemble something in me—Softly!
modern: If only I could somehow relate them to me!

origin: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain, And though that nature with a beauteous wall Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee I will believe thou hast a mind that suits With this thy fair and outward character.
modern: You seem to be a good person, captain, and although people who look beautiful are often corrupt inside, I believe that you have a beautiful mind to go with your good looks and manners.

origin: I prithee—and I’ll pay thee bounteously— Conceal me what I am, and be my aid For such disguise as haply shall become The form of my intent.
modern: Please—and I’ll pay you plenty for this—help me conceal my identity, and find me the right disguise so I can look the way I want.

origin: I’ll serve this duke.
modern: I want to be this Duke’s servant.

origin: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.
modern: You’ll introduce me to him as a eunuch.

origin: It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing And speak to him in many sorts of music That will allow me very worth his service.
modern: You won’t be wasting your time, because I really can sing and talk to him about many different kinds of music, so he’ll be happy to have me in his service.

origin: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.
modern: You can be a eunuch, but I’ll be mute.

origin: When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.
modern: I swear on my life I won’t tell your secret.

origin: I thank thee.
modern: Thank you.

origin: Lead me on.
modern: Show me the way.

origin: M”—Malvolio.
modern: M”—Malvolio.

origin: M”—why, that begins my name.
modern: M”—why, that’s the first letter in my name.

origin: M.O.A.I.” This simulation is not as the former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name.
modern: But if I shake it up a little it’ll work, because every one of those letters is in my name.

origin: Soft, here follows prose.
modern: But wait, there’s some prose after her poem.

origin: If this fall into thy hand, revolve.
modern: If this letter falls into your hands, think carefully about what it says.

origin: In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness.
modern: By my birth I rank above you, but don’t be afraid of my greatness.

origin: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
modern: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.

origin: Thy Fates open their hands.
modern: Your fate awaits you.

origin: Let thy blood and spirit embrace them.
modern: Accept it in body and spirit.

origin: And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh.
modern: To get used to the life you’ll most likely be leading soon, get rid of your low-class trappings.

origin: I say, remember.
modern: Go ahead.

origin: Farewell.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: She that would alter services with thee,  The Fortunate Unhappy”  Daylight and champaign discovers not more.
modern: Signed, she who would be your servant,     The Fortunate Unhappy.” This is as clear as sunlight in an open field.

origin: This is open.
modern: I’ll do it.

origin: I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point- devise the very man.
modern: I’ll be vain and proud, I’ll read up on politics, I’ll insult Sir Toby, I’ll get rid of my lower-class friends, and I’ll be the perfect man for her.

origin: I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me, for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
modern: I know I’m not fooling myself, or letting myself get carried away by my imagination, because every clue points to the fact that Lady Olivia loves me.

origin: She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking.
modern: She did compliment me on my yellow stockings recently, and she said she liked how the crisscross laces looked on my legs.

origin: I thank my stars I am happy.
modern: Oh, I thank my lucky stars, I’m so happy.

origin: I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on.
modern: For her I’ll be strange and condescending, and I’ll put on my yellow stockings and crisscross laces right away.

origin: Jove and my stars be praised!
modern: Thank God and my horoscope!

origin: Here is yet a postscript.
modern: Here’s a postscript!.

origin: Thou canst not choose but know who I am.
modern: You must have figured out who I am.

origin: If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling.
modern: If you love me, let me know by smiling at me.

origin: Thy smiles become thee well.
modern: You’re so attractive when you smile.

origin: Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.”
modern: Please smile whenever you’re near me, my dearest darling.”

origin: Jove, I thank thee!
modern: Dear God, thank you!

origin: I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
modern: I’ll do everything she wants me to do.

origin: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.
modern: I wouldn’t have missed this even for a pension of thousands of pounds, to be paid by the shah of Persia.

origin: I could marry this wench for this device.
modern: I could marry that Maria for thinking this up.

origin: So could I too.
modern: So could I.

origin: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.
modern: And I wouldn’t ask for any dowry except for her to play another trick like this one.

origin: Nor I neither.
modern: Neither would I.

origin: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
modern: Here she comes, the brilliant fool-catcher.

origin: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?
modern: May I kiss your feet?

origin: Or o' mine either?
modern: And I too?

origin: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bondslave?
modern: Shall I be your slave?

origin: I' faith, or I either?
modern: Me too.

origin: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.
modern: You’ve made him so delusional he’ll go crazy when he learns the truth.

origin: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?
modern: Did it really work?

origin: Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
modern: Like medicine for a sick man.

origin: If you will see it, follow me.
modern: If you want to watch, follow me.

origin: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!
modern: I’d follow you to the gates of Hell, you sneaky little devil!

origin: I’ll make one too.
modern: I’ll come too.

origin: Save thee, friend, and thy music.
modern: God bless you, my friend, and your music too.

origin: Dost thou live by thy tabour?
modern: Do you make your living by playing that drum?

origin: No, sir, I live by the church.
modern: No, sir, I live by the church.

origin: Art thou a churchman?
modern: Oh, you’re a clergyman?

origin: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.
modern: You could just as easily say that a king sleeps near a beggar if the beggar lives near him, or that the church is supported by your drum because it “stands by” your drum.

origin: You have said, sir.
modern: You’re right, sir.

origin: How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!
modern: What a wonderful time to be alive!

origin: Nay, that’s certain.
modern: That’s true.

origin: I would therefore my sister had no name, sir.
modern: That’s why I wish my sister didn’t have a name, sir.

origin: Why, man?
modern: Why, man?

origin: Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton.
modern: Well, her name’s a word, and if you fooled around with it you might make her into a whore.

origin: Thy reason, man?
modern: Why do you say that?

origin: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.
modern: Honestly, sir, I’d need to use words to explain why, and since words are so unreliable and false, I’d rather avoid using them in a serious discussion.

origin: I warrant thou art a merry fellow and carest for nothing.
modern: I bet you’re a happy fellow who doesn’t care about anything.

origin: Not so, sir, I do care for something.
modern: You’re wrong, sir, I do care about something.

origin: But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you.
modern: But I’ll admit I don’t care for you.

origin: If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
modern: If that means I don’t care about anything, you should disappear right now, since you’re nothing.

origin: Art not thou the Lady Olivia’s fool?
modern: Aren’t you Lady Olivia’s fool?

origin: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly.
modern: No, sir.

origin: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino’s.
modern: I saw you at Count Orsino’s recently.

origin: It shines everywhere.
modern: I’m everywhere.

origin: I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress: I think I saw your wisdom there.
modern: I think I saw you there, you wise man.

origin: Hold, there’s expenses for thee.
modern: Wait, here’s a coin for you.

origin: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!
modern: Next time God sends out a shipment of hair, I hope he gives you a beard!

origin: to fool) Is thy lady within?
modern: Oh, I know.

origin: Yes, being kept together and put to use.
modern: Yes, if you kept them together and invested them.

origin: My lady is within, sir.
modern: My lady Olivia’s inside, sir.

origin: I will construe to them whence you come.
modern: I’ll tell them where you come from, though I don’t know who you are or what you want.

origin: Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say “element,” but the word is overworn.
modern: I’d say I was “out of my element,” but that phrase is overused, so I’ll say I’m “out of my air.”

origin: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
modern: This guy’s wise enough to play the fool, and only clever people can do that.

origin: This is a practise As full of labor as a wise man’s art, For folly that he wisely shows is fit.
modern: And he doesn’t let go of his target when a distraction appears.

origin: Save you, gentleman.
modern: Hello, sir.

origin: And you, sir.
modern: Hello to you too, sir.

origin: I am bound to your niece, sir.
modern: I’m headed for your niece, sir.

origin: I mean, she is the list of my voyage.
modern: She’s the reason I’m here.

origin: Taste your legs, sir.
modern: Taste your legs, sir.

origin: Put them to motion.
modern: Please go inside.

origin: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.
modern: I mean please go into the house, sir.

origin: I will answer you with gait and entrance.
modern: I will.

origin: But we are prevented.
modern: But now we don’t have to!

origin: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!
modern: Oh, beautiful and accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!

origin: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.
modern: My message is not for anyone else to hear, my lady.

origin: em all three all ready.
modern: It’s only for your willing and receptive ear.

origin: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.
modern: Close the garden door and leave me alone to hear his message.

origin: Give me your hand, sir.
modern: Give me your hand, sir.

origin: My duty, madam, and most humble service.
modern: I give you my obedience and my humble service, madam.

origin: What is your name?
modern: What’s your name?

origin: Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.
modern: Cesario is my name—your servant’s name—fair princess.

origin: My servant, sir!
modern: My servant!

origin: Twas never merry world Since lowly feigning was call’d compliment.
modern: The world’s gone downhill since fake humility started passing for compliments.

origin: For him, I think not on him.
modern: As for him, I never think about him.

origin: For his thoughts, Would they were blanks, rather than fill’d with me.
modern: As for his thoughts, I wish he’d think about nothing at all rather than think about me all the time.

origin: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalf.
modern: Madam, I’ve come here to try to make you like him.

origin: O, by your leave, I pray you, I bade you never speak again of him.
modern: Oh, please, I’m begging you, don’t mention him again.

origin: Dear lady— Give me leave, beseech you.
modern: My dear lady— Please let me say something, I’m begging you.

origin: I did send, After the last enchantment you did here, A ring in chase of you.
modern: After you cast your magic spell on me last time, I sent you a ring.

origin: What might you think?
modern: What else could you possibly think of me?

origin: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus?
modern: What’s wrong with my niece?

origin: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights.
modern: For God’s sake, Sir Toby, you’ve got to come home earlier at night.

origin: Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
modern: My lady Olivia, your niece, disapproves of your late-night partying.

origin: Why, let her except, before excepted.
modern: Well, she can get used to it.

origin: I’ll confine myself no finer than I am.
modern: Keep myself?

origin: These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.
modern: They’re good enough to drink in, and so are these boots.

origin: An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
modern: If they aren’t, they can go hang themselves by their own laces!

origin: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
modern: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

origin: Ay, he.
modern: Yes, that’s the one.

origin: He’s as tall a man as any ’s in Illyria.
modern: He’s as

origin: Have you not set mine honor at the stake, And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts That tyrannous heart can think?
modern: Haven’t you totally dismissed my honor and integrity in your anger?

origin: To one of your receiving Enough is shown.
modern: For someone as intelligent as you the situation must be clear enough.

origin: So, let me hear you speak.
modern: So let me hear what you have to say.

origin: I pity you.
modern: I feel sorry for you.

origin: That’s a degree to love.
modern: That’s a step in the direction of love.

origin: No, not a grize.
modern: No, not at all.

origin: If one should be a prey, how much the better To fall before the lion than the wolf!
modern: It’s much better to be destroyed by a noble enemy than by a cruel and heartless one.

origin: There lies your way, due west.
modern: I wish you all the best.

origin: Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
modern: You do Stay, Please, tell me what you think of me.

origin: That you do think you are not what you are.
modern: I think you’re denying what you really are.

origin: If I think so, I think the same of you.
modern: If that’s true, I think the same thing about you.

origin: I would you were as I would have you be!
modern: I wish you were what I wanted you to be!

origin: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
modern: Would it be better if I were that, instead of what I am?

origin: I wish it might, for now I am your fool.
modern: I wish I were something better, because right now I’m a big fool.

origin: And so adieu, good madam.
modern: So goodbye, my lady.

origin: No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.
modern: No, I won’t stay a second longer.

origin: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
modern: Why are you leaving, my angry friend?

origin: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
modern: Yes, you have to tell us why, Sir Andrew.

origin: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon me.
modern: Well, because I saw your niece Olivia treat the count’s messenger better than she’s ever treated me.

origin: I saw ’t i' the orchard.
modern: I saw it in the orchard.

origin: Did she see thee the while, old boy?
modern: Did she see you there the whole time, old boy?

origin: Tell me that.
modern: Tell me that.

origin: As plain as I see you now.
modern: Yes, she saw me quite clearly.

origin: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.
modern: Well, that proves she’s in love with you.

origin: Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
modern: Are you trying to make fun of me?

origin: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.
modern: No, I’ll prove it with airtight evidence and logical argument.

origin: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.
modern: And you can’t deny evidence and argument—They’ve been around since Noah’s ark.

origin: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
modern: She flirted with the messenger boy to exasperate you, fire up your passions, and make you angry and jealous.

origin: You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
modern: You should have run up to her, unleashed a few excellent quips invented on the spot, and rendered the young man speechless.

origin: This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked.
modern: That’s what she was expecting, and you let her down.

origin: An ’t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate.
modern: I’ll have to do something courageous then, because I hate intrigue.

origin: I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.
modern: I’d rather be a heretic than a schemer with fancy plots.

origin: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor.
modern: Well then, improve your situation with a show of courage.

origin: Challenge me the count’s youth to fight with him.
modern: Challenge the count’s young servant to a fight.

origin: Hurt him in eleven places.
modern: Hurt him in eleven different places.

origin: My niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s commendation with woman than report of valor.
modern: My niece Olivia will notice, and let me tell you, no matchmaker in the world can get you a woman faster than a reputation for courage.

origin: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.
modern: It’s really the only way, Sir Andrew.

origin: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
modern: Will either of you give him the message that I’m challenging him to a duel?

origin: Go, write it in a martial hand.
modern: Go ahead and write it down.

origin: Be curst and brief.
modern: Be pointed and brief.

origin: It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.
modern: It doesn’t need to be witty as long as it’s eloquent and imaginative.

origin: Go.
modern: Go on.

origin: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.
modern: This precious little guy is putty in your hands, Sir Toby.

origin: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.
modern: His letter’s going to be hilarious.

origin: We shall have a rare letter from him: but you’ll not deliver ’t?
modern: But you’re not going to deliver it, are you?

origin: Never trust me, then.
modern: Never trust me again if I don’t.

origin: And by all means stir on the youth to an answer.
modern: And by all means see if you can get the young man to answer it.

origin: I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.
modern: I don’t think a team of oxen could get them close enough to fight.

origin: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.
modern: Here comes my little bird.

origin: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.
modern: Listen, if you want a good laugh—and I mean a side-splitting one—then follow me.

origin: He’s in yellow stockings.
modern: He’s wearing yellow stockings.

origin: And cross-gartered?
modern: With crisscrossed laces?

origin: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.
modern: Oh, he looks like a pathetic Sunday school teacher.

origin: He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.
modern: He smiles so much his face has more lines in it than a map of the East Indies.

origin: You have not seen such a thing as ’tis.
modern: You’ve never seen anything like it.

origin: I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.
modern: I can hardly keep myself from throwing things at him.

origin: I know my lady will strike him.
modern: I know that my lady’s going to end up hitting him.

origin: If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
modern: And when she does, he’ll imagine she’s flirting with him.

origin: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
modern: Come on, take us to him.

origin: I could not stay behind you.
modern: I couldn’t stay behind after you left.

origin: My kind Antonio, I can no other answer make but thanks, And thanks, and ever thanks.
modern: My friend Antonio, all I can say is thank you.

origin: What’s to do?
modern: Anyway, what should we do?

origin: Shall we go see the relics of this town?
modern: Should we go see the sights in the town?

origin: Belike you slew great number of his people?
modern: You probably killed a lot of his men?

origin: It might have since been answered in repaying What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake, Most of our city did.
modern: The whole quarrel might have been resolved since then when we repaid what we stole from them—which most of our city did, for the sake of friendly trade relations.

origin: Only myself stood out; For which, if I be lapsèd in this place, I shall pay dear.
modern: I was the only one who refused to give back what I stole.

origin: Do not then walk too open.
modern: Then don’t make yourself too conspicuous.

origin: It doth not fit me.
modern: You’re right.

origin: Hold, sir, here’s my purse.
modern: Hang on a minute, here’s some money for you.

origin: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy You have desire to purchase, and your store, I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
modern: Maybe you’ll see some little trinket you want to buy.

origin: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you For an hour.
modern: I’ll hold on to your money and leave you for an hour.

origin: To the Elephant.
modern: We’ll meet at the Elephant.

origin: I do remember.
modern: I remember.

origin: I have sent after him.
modern: I’ve sent for him.

origin: He says he’ll come.
modern: He says he’ll come.

origin: For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrow’d.
modern: It’s easier to buy young people than to beg or borrow them.

origin: I speak too loud.— Where’s Malvolio?
modern: Oh, I’m talking too loud.—Where’s Malvolio?

origin: He is sad and civil And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
modern: He’s very serious, which is right for someone in mourning like me.

origin: Where is Malvolio?
modern: Where is Malvolio?

origin: He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner.
modern: He’s coming, madam; but he’s acting very strangely.

origin: He is sure possessed, madam.
modern: He must be possessed by the devil.

origin: Why, what’s the matter?
modern: Why, what’s the matter with him?

origin: Does he rave?
modern: Is he talking nonsense?

origin: No, madam, he does nothing but smile.
modern: No, he just smiles.

origin: Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.
modern: You should have a guard nearby if he comes in here, because he’s clearly disturbed.

origin: Go call him hither.
modern: Ask him in here.

origin: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.
modern: I’m as crazy as he is, if sad craziness and happy craziness are equivalent.

origin: How now, Malvolio?
modern: What’s going on, Malvolio?

origin: Sweet lady, ho, ho.
modern: Hello, sweet lady.

origin: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
modern: Why, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.

origin: He’s a very fool and a prodigal.
modern: He’s a fool and a spendthrift.

origin: Fie, that you’ll say so!
modern: You shouldn’t talk about him like that!

origin: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors that say so of him.
modern: Anyone who says that is a lying piece of garbage.

origin: Who are they?
modern: Who said that?

origin: They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in your company.
modern: The same people who say he gets drunk with you every night.

origin: With drinking healths to my niece.
modern: We only drink toasts to my niece.

origin: I’ll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.
modern: I’ll drink to her as long as there’s a hole in my throat and booze in Illyria.

origin: He’s a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like a parish top.
modern: Anyone who refuses to drink to my niece until his brain spins around like a merry-go-round is scum.

origin: Sir Toby Belch!
modern: Sir Toby Belch!

origin: How now, Sir Toby Belch!
modern: How are you, Sir Toby Belch?

origin: Sweet Sir Andrew!
modern: Sweet Sir Andrew!

origin: Smilest thou?
modern: You’re smiling?

origin: I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.
modern: I sent for you about a sad occasion.

origin: Sad, lady!
modern: Sad, my lady!

origin: I could be sad.
modern: I could be sad if I wanted to be.

origin: This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but what of that?
modern: These crisscrossing laces do cut off the circulation in my legs a bit, but who cares?

origin: If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, “Please one, and please all.”  Why, how dost thou, man?
modern: As the sonnet says, “If you please one special person, you please everyone who matters.” Why, what’s going on?

origin: What is the matter with thee?
modern: What’s the matter with you?

origin: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs.
modern: My legs may be yellow, but I don’t feel blue.

origin: It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed.
modern: It was addressed to him, and orders must be obeyed.

origin: I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.
modern: I think we know whose fancy handwriting that was.

origin: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?
