modern: Don’t you think you should go to bed, Malvolio?

origin: To bed?
modern: To bed!

origin: How do you, Malvolio?
modern: How are you feeling, Malvolio?

origin: At your request!
modern: You’re asking me!

origin: Yes, nightingales answer daws!
modern: Noble people don’t answer to peasants!

origin: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?
modern: Why are you acting so brazen toward my lady?

origin: Be not afraid of greatness.” 'Twas well writ.
modern: Don’t be afraid of greatness.” That was well written.

origin: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
modern: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

origin: Some are born great—”
modern: Some are born great—”

origin: Ha?
modern: What?

origin: Some achieve greatness—” What sayest thou?
modern: Some achieve greatness—” What are you saying?

origin: And some have greatness thrust upon them.” Heaven restore thee!
modern: And some have greatness thrust upon them.” Heaven help you!

origin: Remember who commended thy yellow stockings—” Thy yellow stockings?
modern: Remember who liked your yellow stockings—” Your yellow stockings?

origin: And wished to see thee cross-gartered.” Cross-gartered?
modern: And wanted to see you with laces crisscrossed over your legs.” Crisscrossed?

origin: Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so—” Am I made?
modern: Go ahead.

origin: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino’s is returned.
modern: Madam, Count Orsino’s young messenger has returned.

origin: I’ll come to him.
modern: I’ll go to him.

origin: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to.
modern: Maria, take care of this poor fellow here.

origin: Where’s my cousin Toby?
modern: Where’s my cousin Toby?

origin: Let some of my people have a special care of him.
modern: Have some of my servants take care of Malvolio.

origin: I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.
modern: I’d give half my dowry to keep anything bad from happening to him.

origin: Oh, ho!
modern: Oh ho!

origin: Do you come near me now?
modern: Look at me now!

origin: This concurs directly with the letter.
modern: This is just what the letter said.

origin: Cast thy humble slough,” says she.
modern: Get rid of your low-class trapping,” she said.

origin: I have limed her, but it is Jove’s doing, and Jove make me thankful!
modern: I’ve got her now, but I’ve got God to thank for it!

origin: And when she went away now, “Let this fellow be looked to.” “Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” nor after my degree, but “fellow.” Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance—what can be said?
modern: And when she left just now, she said “Take care of this poor fellow here.” Fellow!” Not “Malvolio,” not anything referring to my low station in life, but “fellow.” Everything’s going perfectly.

origin: Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes.
modern: Nothing can come between me and the fulfillment of all my hopes.

origin: Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
modern: Well, God is responsible for that, not me, and he deserves thanks.

origin: If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I’ll speak to him.
modern: I don’t care if all the devils in hell crammed together to possess him, I still want to speak to him.

origin: Here he is, here he is.
modern: Here he is, here he is.

origin: How is’t with you, sir?
modern: How are you, sir?

origin: Go off, I discard you.
modern: Go away.

origin: Let me enjoy my private.
modern: Let me enjoy my privacy.

origin: Go off.
modern: Go away.

origin: Aha!
modern: Ah-ha!

origin: Does she so?
modern: Does she?

origin: Do you know what you say?
modern: Do you even know what you’re talking about?

origin: Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning if I live.
modern: Sure thing, we’ll do it tomorrow morning.

origin: My lady would not lose him for more than I’ll say.
modern: My lady would never want to lose him.

origin: How now, mistress?
modern: What are you saying, mistress?

origin: O Lord!
modern: Oh, Lord!

origin: No way but gentleness, gently, gently.
modern: Gentleness is the only way to go—gently, gently.

origin: The fiend is rough and will not be roughly used.
modern: The devil inside him is rough, but we can’t treat it roughly.

origin: Sir!
modern: Sir!

origin: Ay, Biddy, come with me.—What, man!
modern: Yes, dear little chick, come along with me.—Shut up, man!

origin: Tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan.
modern: You’re serious enough to know not to play games with Satan.

origin: Hang him, foul collier!
modern: Damn that dirty black coalminer of a devil!

origin: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.
modern: Get him to say his prayers, Sir Toby, get him to pray.

origin: My prayers, minx?
modern: My prayers, you hussy?

origin: Go, hang yourselves all!
modern: Go hang yourselves, all of you!

origin: You are idle, shallow things.
modern: You’re all lazy and shallow.

origin: I am not of your element.
modern: I’m not like you.

origin: You shall know more hereafter.
modern: You’ll know more about it later.

origin: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is it possible?

origin: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
modern: If this were a play, I’d complain it was unrealistic.

origin: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.
modern: He’s really taken this prank to heart.

origin: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.
modern: No, follow him now, before he divulges the prank and ruins everything.

origin: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
modern: Wow, we’re really going to drive him crazy.

origin: The house will be the quieter.
modern: The house will be so much quieter.

origin: Come, we’ll have him in a dark room and bound.
modern: Come on, let’s put him in a dark room and tie him up.

origin: My niece is already in the belief that he’s mad.
modern: My niece already thinks he’s insane.

origin: More matter for a May morning.
modern: Here’s more insanity for us.

origin: Is ’t so saucy?
modern: Is it that aggressive?

origin: Ay, is ’t, I warrant him.
modern: Yes, it is, I think.

origin: Do but read.
modern: Just read it.

origin: Give me.
modern: Give it to me.

origin: A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.
modern: That’s a good thing to put in—it keeps you from getting in trouble with the law.

origin: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.
modern: Nice and short and full of good sense—or should I say nonsense?

origin: Good.
modern: Good.

origin: Still you keep o' the windy side of the law.
modern: You still haven’t said anything incriminating.

origin: Good.
modern: Good.

origin: Andrew Aguecheek”
modern: Andrew Aguecheek”

origin: If this letter move him not, his legs cannot.
modern: If this letter doesn’t make him fight, I don’t know what will.

origin: I’ll give ’t him.
modern: I’ll give it to him.

origin: You may have very fit occasion for ’t.
modern: You might have a great opportunity to give it to him right now.

origin: He is now in some commerce with my lady and will by and by depart.
modern: He’s conducting some business with my lady, and sooner or later he’ll leave.

origin: Go, Sir Andrew.
modern: Go, Sir Andrew.

origin: Scout me for him at the corner the orchard like a bum-baily.
modern: Look out for him in the corner of the orchard as if you were a sheriff’s deputy.

origin: Away!
modern: Now go!

origin: Nay, let me alone for swearing.
modern: Don’t worry about me not swearing enough.

origin: His employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less.
modern: The fact that he serves as a go-between for his lord and my niece Olivia confirms this.

origin: Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth.
modern: So this letter, which is so incredibly stupid and ignorant, isn’t going to scare him at all.

origin: He will find it comes from a clodpole.
modern: He’ll just think an idiot wrote it.

origin: But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek a notable report of valor, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity.
modern: But I’ll deliver Sir Andrew’s challenge by word of mouth, describing Sir Andrew as courageous in battle and convincing the young gentleman that Sir Andrew is furious, impetuous, and a skilled fighter (he’ll believe me because he’s young).

origin: This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.
modern: This will make them both so afraid that they’ll kill each other just by looking at each other.

origin: Here he comes with your niece.
modern: Here comes the messenger with your niece.

origin: Give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.
modern: Leave them alone until he sets off home, and then follow him.

origin: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.
modern: Meanwhile, I’ll think of some horrible way to phrase the challenge.

origin: With the same 'havior that your passion bears Goes on my master’s grief.
modern: My lord acts just as crazy with love as you do.

origin: Here, wear this jewel for me.
modern: Here, take this piece of jewelry.

origin: Tis my picture.
modern: There’s a picture of me inside.

origin: Refuse it not.
modern: Don’t refuse it.

origin: It hath no tongue to vex you.
modern: It won’t annoy you like me, because it doesn’t have a voice.

origin: And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
modern: And I beg you, please come here again tomorrow.

origin: What shall you ask of me that I’ll deny, That honor, saved, may upon asking give?
modern: What could you possibly ask of me that I wouldn’t give you, as long as it didn’t damage my honor and self-respect?

origin: Nothing but this: your true love for my master.
modern: Nothing, except your true love for my lord.

origin: How with mine honor may I give him that Which I have given to you?
modern: How could I honorably give him what I’ve already given you?

origin: I will acquit you.
modern: I’ll give it back to you.

origin: Well, come again tomorrow.
modern: Just come again tomorrow.

origin: Fare thee well.
modern: Good-bye.

origin: A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
modern: A devil like you could lead me to hell.

origin: Gentleman, God save thee.
modern: Hello, sir.

origin: And you, sir.
modern: Hello to you.

origin: That defense thou hast, betake thee to ’t.
modern: You’d better think up a way to defend yourself.

origin: Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end.
modern: I don’t know what you’ve done to upset him, but someone has challenged you to a duel.

origin: Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skillful and deadly.
modern: Draw your sword and get on your toes, because your assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

origin: You mistake, sir.
modern: There must be some mistake, sir.

origin: I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me.
modern: I’m sure nobody would have any reason to fight with me.

origin: My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offense done to any man.
modern: I can’t remember anything I’ve ever done to offend anyone.

origin: You’ll find it otherwise, I assure you.
modern: You’re wrong about that, I assure you.

origin: I pray you, sir, what is he?
modern: But who is this person, sir?

origin: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl.
modern: He’s a knight.

origin: Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre.
modern: He’s killed three people, and he’s so furious right now that the only thing that will satisfy him is seeing you die.

origin: Hob, nob, is his word.
modern: Fight to the death” is his motto.

origin: And you too, sir.
modern: Hello, sir.

origin: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.
modern: Chat her up, Sir Andrew.

origin: What’s that?
modern: What?

origin: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
modern: My dear Miss Chat-her-up, I look forward to getting to know you better.

origin: My name is Mary, sir.
modern: My name is Mary, sir.

origin: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.
modern: I was telling you to go after her, woo her, confront her.

origin: Is that the meaning of “accost”?
modern: Is that really what you meant?

origin: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
modern: If you let her go this easily, Sir Andrew, you don’t deserve to ever use your sword again.

origin: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again.
modern: If you leave like this, my dear, I won’t ever use my sword again.

origin: Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
modern: Do you think you’ve got a couple of fools on your hands here?

origin: Sir, I have not you by the hand.
modern: I’m not holding your hand, sir.

origin: I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady.
modern: I’ll go back inside and ask the lady for some kind of escort.

origin: I am no fighter.
modern: I’m not a fighter.

origin: I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor.
modern: I’ve heard of men who pick fights with other people on purpose, just to see how brave they are.

origin: Belike this is a man of that quirk.
modern: This man is probably like that.

origin: Sir, no.
modern: No, sir.

origin: His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury.
modern: He’s furious because you insulted him, and he has a right to satisfaction.

origin: Therefore get you on and give him his desire.
modern: So go out there and give him what he wants.

origin: Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him.
modern: You can’t go back into the house unless you want to fight with me—and if you’re willing to do that, you might as well just go and fight with him.

origin: This is as uncivil as strange.
modern: This is as rude as it is strange.

origin: I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offense to him is.
modern: Please, do me this one favor: find out what I’ve done to offend this knight.

origin: It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
modern: It must be something I did accidentally.

origin: I will do so.
modern: I will do so.

origin: Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
modern: Mr. Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I come back.

origin: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?
modern: Excuse me, sir, do you know anything about this?

origin: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
modern: What kind of man is he?

origin: He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria.
modern: He really is the most skillful, bloodthirsty, and dangerous opponent you can find in Illyria.

origin: Will you walk towards him?
modern: Do you want to go see him?

origin: I will make your peace with him if I can.
modern: I’ll try to calm him down for you if I can.

origin: I shall be much bound to you for ’t.
modern: I’d be very grateful to you if you did.

origin: Why, man, he’s a very devil.
modern: Wow, he’s a real devil.

origin: I have not seen such a firago.
modern: I’ve never seen such a monster.

origin: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable.
modern: I had a round with him, and his sword thrust is so deadly that you can’t even duck out of the way.

origin: And on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hit the ground they step on.
modern: And when he strikes back at you, he’ll hit you as sure as you’re standing there.

origin: They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
modern: They say he used to fence for the shah of Persia.

origin: Pox on ’t!
modern: That’s it!

origin: I’ll not meddle with him.
modern: I won’t mess with him.

origin: Ay, but he will not now be pacified.
modern: Yes, but now there’s no way to calm him down.

origin: Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.
modern: Fabian can hardly control him over there.

origin: Plague on ’t, an I thought he had been valiant and so cunning in fence, I’d have seen him damned ere I’d have challenged him.
modern: Darn it, if I’d guessed he was so brave and such a good swordsman, I never would have challenged him.

origin: Let him let the matter slip, and I’ll give him my horse, gray Capilet.
modern: I’ll give him my gray horse Capilet if he forgets the whole thing.

origin: I’ll make the motion.
modern: I’ll give it a try.

origin: Stand here, make a good show on ’t.
modern: Stay right here and try to look good.

origin: This shall end without the perdition of souls.
modern: This may end without anyone getting killed.

origin: I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
modern: He’s just as terrified of Sir Andrew.

origin: He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
modern: He’s pale and hyperventilating, as if a bear were chasing him.

origin: Come, Sir Andrew, there’s no remedy.
modern: Come on, Sir Andrew, there’s nothing you can do about it.

origin: The gentleman will, for his honor’s sake, have one bout with you.
modern: The gentleman insists on fighting a round with you, for the sake of his honor.

origin: He cannot by the duello avoid it.
modern: The rules of dueling say he has to.

origin: But he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you.
modern: But as a gentleman and a soldier he’s promised me he won’t hurt you.

origin: Come on, to ’t.
modern: Come on, get ready.

origin: Pray God, he keep his oath!
modern: I hope to God he keeps his promise!

origin: I do assure you, ’tis against my will.
modern: I swear to you, I don’t want to be doing this.

origin: Put up your sword.
modern: Put your sword away.

origin: If this young gentleman Have done offence, I take the fault on me.
modern: If this young gentleman has offended you, I’ll take the blame for it.

origin: If you offend him, I for him defy you.
modern: If you’ve offended him, I’ll fight you.

origin: You, sir?
modern: You, sir?

origin: Why, what are you?
modern: Who are you?

origin: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more Than you have heard him brag to you he will.
modern: In fact, I’d do even more to him than what you’ve heard him promise to do.

origin: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
modern: If you’re someone who gets into fights, I’ll fight with you.

origin: O good Sir Toby, hold!
modern: Oh, Sir Toby, stop!

origin: Here come the officers.
modern: The police are here.

origin: Marry, will I, sir.
modern: I certainly will, sir.

origin: And for that I promised you, I’ll be as good as my word.
modern: And as for what I promised to you, I’m as good as my word.

origin: He will bear you easily and reins well.
modern: You can ride him easily, and he responds well when you pull the reins.

origin: This is the man.
modern: This is the man.

origin: Do thy office.
modern: Do your job.

origin: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.
modern: Antonio, you’re under arrest on the orders of Count Orsino.

origin: You do mistake me, sir.
modern: You must be mistaking me for someone else, sir.

origin: No, sir, no jot.
modern: No, sir, not at all.

origin: I know your favor well, Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.— Take him away.
modern: I recognize your face perfectly, even without a sailor’s cap on your head.—Take him away.

origin: He knows I know him well.
modern: He knows I recognize him.

origin: I must obey.
modern: I have to obey.

origin: You stand amazed, But be of comfort.
modern: Don’t worry about me.

origin: Come, sir, away.
modern: Come on, sir, let’s go.

origin: What money, sir?
modern: What money, sir?

origin: I’ll make division of my present with you.
modern: Take this.

origin: Hold, there’s half my coffer.
modern: It’s half of all my money.

origin: Will you deny me now?
modern: Are you really going to pretend you don’t know me now?

origin: I hate ingratitude more in a man Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption Inhabits our frail blood—    O heavens themselves!
modern: I hate an ungrateful man more than I hate lying, vanity, babbling, drunkenness, or any other vice that we feeble human beings are susceptible to.— Oh, my God!

origin: Come, sir, I pray you, go.
modern: Come on, sir, please.

origin: Let me speak a little.
modern: Let’s go.

origin: Away!
modern: Let’s go!

origin: But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!
modern: But oh, what a deceiver he turned out to be!

origin: None can be called deformed but the unkind.
modern: Only really cruel people can be called deformed.

origin: Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
modern: Virtue is beauty, but someone beautiful and wicked is like an empty box decorated by the devil.

origin: The man grows mad.
modern: The man’s going crazy.

origin: Away with him.
modern: Take him away.

origin: Lead me on.
modern: Take me.

origin: Methinks his words do from such passion fly, That he believes himself.
modern: I don’t believe it.

origin: So do not I.
modern: Yet I wish I could.

origin: Prove true, imagination, oh, prove true, That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!
modern: Oh, please be true, please let it be that this man has mistaken me for you, my dear brother!

origin: Come hither, knight.
modern: Come here, Sir Andrew.

origin: Come hither, Fabian.
modern: You too, Fabian.

origin: We’ll whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.
modern: We’ve got some words of wisdom to mull over.

origin: He named Sebastian.
modern: He called me Sebastian.

origin: Still in this fashion, color, ornament, For him I imitate.
modern: with the same accessories.

origin: Oh, if it prove, Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love!
modern: Oh, if it turns out to be true that he survived, then that storm was kind, and the ocean was full of love!

origin: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare.
modern: He’s a very dishonest, puny boy, and more cowardly than a rabbit.

origin: His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity and denying him.
modern: He abandoned his friend here in an emergency, and even pretended he didn’t know him.

origin: And for his cowardship, ask Fabian.
modern: As for his cowardliness, ask Fabian.

origin: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.
modern: He’s a coward, a total coward.

origin: Slid, I’ll after him again and beat him.
modern: By God, I’ll go after him again and beat him up.

origin: An I do not— Come, let’s see the event.
modern: I swear I will— Come on, let’s go see what happens.

origin: I dare lay any money ’twill be nothing yet.
modern: I’ll bet anything you like that nothing will happen, once again.

origin: Let me be clear of thee.
modern: Leave me alone.

origin: Well held out, i' faith.
modern: Good for you, holding out on me like this!

origin: No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her, nor your name is not Master Cesario, nor this is not my nose neither.
modern: No, I don’t know you, and my lady didn’t send me to get you, and I’m not supposed to tell you to come speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this is not my nose, either.

origin: Nothing that is so is so.
modern: Nothing is what it is.

origin: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else.
modern: Oh please, go somewhere else to blab your nonsense.

origin: Thou know’st not me.
modern: You don’t know me.

origin: Vent my folly?
modern: Blab my nonsense?

origin: He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool.
modern: He must’ve heard that phrase describing some great man and now he’s using it on a jester.

origin: Vent my folly!
modern: Blab my nonsense!

origin: I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney.
modern: What an idiotic place this world is.

origin: I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell me what I shall vent to my lady.
modern: Now please stop being so strange and tell me what exactly I should blab to my lady.

origin: Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?
modern: Should I blab to her that you’re coming?

origin: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me.
modern: Please, fool, go away.

origin: There’s money for thee.
modern: Here’s money for you.

origin: By my troth, thou hast an open hand.
modern: Well, well.

origin: These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years' purchase.
modern: Wise men who give fools money might get a good reputation—if they keep up regular payments for fourteen years.

origin: Hold, sir, or I’ll throw your dagger o'er the house.
modern: Stop right now or I’ll throw your dagger over the roof.

origin: Nay, let him alone.
modern: No, leave him alone.

origin: I’ll go another way to work with him.
modern: I’ll get back at him another way.

origin: I’ll have an action of battery against him if there be any law in Illyria.
modern: I’ll sue him for assault and battery, if there’s any justice in Illyria.

origin: Though I struck him first, yet it’s no matter for that.
modern: It doesn’t matter that I hit him first.

origin: Come, sir, I will not let you go.
modern: No, sir, I won’t let you go.

origin: Come, my young soldier, put up your iron.
modern: Come on, put your sword away, my little soldier.

origin: You are well fleshed.
modern: You’re awfully eager to fight.

origin: Come on.
modern: Come on.

origin: I will be free from thee.
modern: I’ll get free of you.

origin: What wouldst thou now?
modern: What are you going to do now?

origin: If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
modern: If you insist on trying my patience any further, then take out your sword right now.

origin: What, what?
modern: What?

origin: Nay, then I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.
modern: Because then I’d have to shed an ounce or two of your impudent blood.

origin: Hold, Toby!
modern: Stop, Sir Toby!

origin: On thy life I charge thee, hold!
modern: I order you to stop!

origin: Madam!
modern: Madam!

origin: Will it be ever thus?
modern: Are you always going to be like this?

origin: Out of my sight!— Be not offended, dear Cesario.— Rudesby, be gone!
modern: Get out of my sight!—Dear Cesario, please don’t be offended.—Get out of here, you barbarian!

origin: Thou shalt not choose but go.
modern: You have to come with me.

origin: Do not deny.
modern: Please don’t say no.

origin: Beshrew his soul for me!
modern: Damn that Toby!

origin: He started one poor heart of mine in thee.
modern: He made my heart leap for you.

origin: Wherefore, sweetheart?
modern: Why, sweetheart?

origin: Why, I think so.
modern: Your hand is  Well, I hope so.

origin: I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry.
modern: I’m not such an idiot that I can’t keep my hands dry.

origin: But what’s your jest?
modern: But I don’t get it—what’s the joke?

origin: A dry jest, sir.
modern: Just a bit of my dry humor, sir.

origin: Are you full of them?
modern: Are you always so funny?

origin: Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
modern: But oops, when I let go of your hand, I let go of the biggest joke of all.

origin: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary.
modern: Sir, you need a drink.

origin: When did I see thee so put down?
modern: When has anyone ever put you down like that.

origin: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down.
modern: Never.

origin: Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.
modern: Sometimes I think I’m no smarter than average.

origin: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
modern: If this is a dream, let me keep on sleeping!

origin: Nay, come, I prithee.
modern: Come with me, please.

origin: Would thou’dst be ruled by me!
modern: I wish you’d do what I ask!

origin: Madam, I will.
modern: Madam, I will.

origin: Oh, say so, and so be!
modern: Oh, say it, and mean it!

origin: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard.
modern: No, I’m telling you, put on this robe and beard.

origin: Make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate.
modern: Make him think you’re Sir Topas the priest.

origin: Do it quickly.
modern: Be quick.

origin: I’ll call Sir Toby the whilst.
modern: Meanwhile, I’ll get Sir Toby.

origin: The competitors enter.
modern: Here come the conspirators.

origin: Jove bless thee, master Parson.
modern: God bless you, Mr.

origin: Bonos dies, Sir Toby.
modern: Priest.

origin: To him, Sir Topas.
modern: Go to him, Sir Topas.

origin: The knave counterfeits well.
modern: The fool’s a good actor.

origin: A good knave.
modern: A good fool.

origin: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady— Out, hyperbolical fiend!
modern: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, please go find my lady Olivia— Get out, demon!

origin: How vexest thou this man!
modern: Why are you bothering this poor man!

origin: Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
modern: Can’t you talk about anything besides ladies?

origin: Fie, thou dishonest Satan!
modern: You should be ashamed of yourself, Satan, you liar!

origin: I call thee by the most modest terms, for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy.
modern: I’m being gentle with you, because I’m one of those good-hearted people who are polite to the devil himself.

origin: Sayest thou that house is dark?
modern: You call this house dark?

origin: As hell, Sir Topas.
modern: Dark as hell, Sir Topas.

origin: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony.
modern: But it has bay windows that are as transparent as stone walls, and the upper windows facing south-north are as clear as coal.

origin: And yet complainest thou of obstruction?
modern: But you’re still complaining of darkness and a bad view?

origin: I am not mad, Sir Topas.
modern: I’m not insane, Sir Topas.

origin: I say to you this house is dark.
modern: I’m telling you, this house is dark.

origin: Madman, thou errest.
modern: You’re wrong, you madman.

origin: I say, there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.
modern: There’s no darkness except ignorance, and you’re more ignorant than the Egyptians during the plague of fog.

origin: I say, this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell.
modern: I tell you, this house is as dark as ignorance.

origin: I am no more mad than you are.
modern: I’m no more insane than you are, and I’ll prove it.

origin: Make the trial of it in any constant question.
modern: Ask me any commonsense question.

origin: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?
modern: What was the philosopher Pythagoras’s belief about wild birds?

origin: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
modern: That our grandmother’s soul could end up inhabiting a bird.

origin: What thinkest thou of his opinion?
modern: What do you think of his belief?

origin: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.
modern: I respect the soul very much, so I disagree with his belief.

origin: Fare thee well.
modern: Well then, goodbye.

origin: Remain thou still in darkness.
modern: Stay in the dark.

origin: Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam.
modern: I’ll only admit that you’re sane when you agree with Pythagoras and hesitate to kill a bird because it might contain your grandmother’s soul.

origin: Fare thee well.
modern: Goodbye.

origin: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!
modern: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

origin: My most exquisite Sir Topas!
modern: The brilliant Sir Topas!

origin: Nay, I am for all waters.
modern: I can do anything!

origin: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.
modern: You could’ve done this without your beard and gown.

origin: He sees thee not.
modern: He couldn’t see you.

origin: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou findest him.
modern: Now talk to him in your own voice, and tell me how he is.

origin: I would we were well rid of this knavery.
modern: I wish this trick would be over.

origin: If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offense with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot.
modern: I’m in so much trouble with my niece that it wouldn’t be safe to let this prank go to its conclusion.

origin: Come by and by to my chamber.
modern: Come to my room later on.

origin: Fool!
modern: Fool!

origin: Fool!
modern: Fool!

origin: Fool, I say!
modern: Fool, I say!

origin: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper.
modern: Good fool, good jester, I’ll make it worth your while if you get me a candle, and a pen, ink and paper.

origin: As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for ’t.
modern: You have my word as a gentleman that I’ll always be grateful to you.

origin: Master Malvolio?
modern: Master Malvolio?

origin: Ay, good fool.
modern: Yes, good fool.

origin: But as well?
modern: As sane as me?

origin: Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.
modern: Then you really are insane, if you’re no saner than a fool.

origin: Sir Topas!
modern: Sir Topas!

origin: Fool, fool, fool, I say!
modern: Fool, fool, hey, fool!

origin: Alas, sir, be patient.
modern: Please, sir, be quiet.

origin: What say you sir?
modern: What do you want to say, sir?

origin: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper.
modern: Be a nice fool and help me find a candle and some paper.

origin: I tell thee, I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.
modern: I tell you, I’m as sane as any man in Illyria.

origin: Well-a-day that you were, sir.
modern: If only you were, sir.

origin: By this hand, I am.
modern: I swear I am.

origin: Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady.
modern: Get me some ink, paper, and a candle.

origin: It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.
modern: You’ll get a bigger reward than you ever got delivering a letter before.

origin: I will help you to ’t.
modern: I’ll help you.

origin: But tell me true, are you not mad indeed?
modern: But tell me honestly, are you sure you’re not insane?

origin: Or do you but counterfeit?
modern: Or are you just pretending?

origin: Believe me, I am not.
modern: Believe me, I’m not.

origin: I tell thee true.
modern: I’m telling the truth.

origin: Nay, I’ll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains.
modern: I’ll never believe a madman until I can see his brains.

origin: I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.
modern: But I’ll get you a candle and paper and ink.

origin: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree.
modern: Fool, I’ll repay you for this favor.

origin: I prithee, be gone.
modern: Please, hurry.

origin: This is the air, that is the glorious sun.
modern: This is the air, that’s the glorious sun.

origin: Where’s Antonio, then?
modern: Where’s Antonio, then?

origin: I could not find him at the Elephant.
modern: I didn’t find him at the Elephant.

origin: Yet there he was, and there I found this credit, That he did range the town to seek me out.
modern: But he’d been there before me, and they told me he’d gone out looking for me.

origin: His counsel now might do me golden service.
modern: I could really use his advice right now.

origin: There’s something in ’t That is deceivable.
modern: There’s something going on that’s not what it seems.

origin: But here the lady comes.
modern: But here she comes.

origin: I’ll follow this good man, and go with you; And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.
modern: I’ll follow the priest and go with you; and after I’ve sworn to be faithful, I’ll be faithful forever.

origin: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine That they may fairly note this act of mine.
modern: Then lead the way, father.

origin: Now, as thou lovest me, let me see his letter.
modern: If you’re my friend, you’ll let me see his letter.

origin: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.
modern: Dear Mr. Fabian, do me another favor first.

origin: Anything.
modern: Anything.

origin: Do not desire to see this letter.
modern: Don’t ask to see this letter.

origin: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?
modern: My friends, are you all Lady Olivia’s servants?

origin: Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.
modern: Yes, sir, we’re part of her entourage.

origin: I know thee well.
modern: I know you.

origin: How dost thou, my good fellow?
modern: How are you, my friend?

origin: Truly, sir, the better for my foes and the worse for my friends.
modern: I’m better off because of my enemies, and worse off because of my friends.

origin: The better for thy friends.
modern: You’re better off because of your friends.

origin: No, sir, the worse.
modern: No, sir, worse off.

origin: How can that be?
modern: How can that be?

origin: I’ll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
modern: By the way, I’m going home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

origin: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
modern: What does  You’d have a great hairstyle if you had.

origin: Why, would that have mended my hair?
modern: Why, would that have fixed my hair?

origin: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
modern: Oh, no question—it won’t style itself.

origin: But it becomes me well enough, does ’t not?
modern: But my hair looks good anyway, doesn’t it?

origin: Excellent.
modern: It looks great.

origin: It hangs like flax on a distaff.
modern: It hangs like an old worn-out mop.

origin: Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
modern: Listen, I’m going home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

origin: The count himself here hard by woos her.
modern: That duke who lives nearby is courting her.

origin: I have heard her swear ’t.
modern: I’ve heard her say that.

origin: Tut, there’s life in ’t, man.
modern: So cheer up, there’s still hope for you, man.

origin: Marry, sir, they praise me and make an ass of me, now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass.
modern: Well, my friends praise me and make me look like an idiot, while my enemies tell me straightforwardly that I am an idiot.

origin: So that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused.
modern: My enemies help me understand myself better, which is an advantage, and my friends help me lie about myself, which is a disadvantage.

origin: So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then the worse for my friends and the better for my foes.
modern: So if four negatives make two affirmatives, I’m worse off because of my friends and better off because of my foes.

origin: Why, this is excellent.
modern: That’s excellent.

origin: By my troth, sir, no—though it please you to be one of my friends.
modern: Don’t say that—unless you want to be one of my friends.

origin: Thou shalt not be the worse for me: there’s gold.
modern: That’s a nice hand you dealt me.

origin: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.
modern: But if it’s not double-dealing, sir, I wish you’d deal me another.

origin: O, you give me ill counsel.
modern: Oh, you’re a naughty one, encouraging double-dealing.

origin: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a double-dealer.
modern: Well, I’ll commit the sin of double-dealing, and deal you a second coin.

origin: There’s another.
modern: Here it is.

origin: Primo, secundo, tertio is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all.
modern: And maybe a third?

origin: The triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure, or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind—one, two, three.
modern: The three-beat rhythm is a good for dancing, and the church bells chime—one, two, three.

origin: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw.
modern: You can’t get any more money out of me right now.

origin: If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.
modern: If you tell your lady I’m here to speak with her, and bring her out with you when you come back, you might make me more generous.

origin: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again.
modern: Well then, sing a lullaby to your generosity: it’ll nap until I come back.

origin: I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness.
modern: But don’t think I’m doing this because I’m greedy.

origin: But, as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.
modern: I’ll be back soon to wake up your generosity.

origin: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.
modern: Here comes the man who rescued me, sir.

origin: That face of his I do remember well.
modern: I remember his face well.

origin: Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmeared As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war.
modern: Though the last time I saw him it was black from the smoke of war.

origin: A baubling vessel was he captain of, For shallow draught and bulk unprizable, With which such scathful grapple did he make With the most noble bottom of our fleet, That very envy and the tongue of loss Cried fame and honor on him.—What’s the matter?
modern: He was the captain of a flimsy boat that was practically worthless because it was so small.

origin: Orsino, this is that Antonio That took the  And this is he that did the  When your young nephew Titus lost his leg.
modern: Orsino, this is the same Antonio who took the

origin: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side, But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.
modern: But then he said strange things to me.

origin: I know not what ’twas but distraction.
modern: I don’t know what else it could be.

origin: Notable pirate!
modern: But you’re a famous pirate!

origin: Orsino, noble sir, Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me.
modern: Orsino, sir, please don’t call me those names.

origin: Antonio never yet was thief or pirate, Though, I confess, on base and ground enough, Orsino’s enemy.
modern: I was never a thief or a pirate, though I admit I was your enemy for good reasons.

origin: That most ingrateful boy there by your side From the rude sea’s enraged and foamy mouth Did I redeem.
modern: I rescued that ungrateful boy next to you from drowning.

origin: A wreck past hope he was.
modern: He was a wreck, almost past hope.

origin: His life I gave him and did thereto add My love, without retention or restraint, All his in dedication.
modern: I saved his life and gave him my love, without reservation.

origin: How can this be?
modern: How is that possible?

origin: Here comes the Countess.
modern: Ah, the countess is coming!

origin: Now heaven walks on earth.
modern: An angel is walking on earth.

origin: What would my lord, but that he may not have, Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
modern: What can I give you that you want, my lord, except the one thing you can’t have?

origin: Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.
modern: Cesario, you missed your appointment with me.

origin: Madam?
modern: Madam?

origin: Gracious Olivia— What do you say, Cesario?—Good my lord— My lord would speak.
modern: Dearest Olivia— What do you have to say for yourself, Cesario?—My lord, please— My lord wants to speak.

origin: My duty hushes me.
modern: It’s my duty to be quiet.

origin: Still so cruel?
modern: Are you still so cruel?

origin: Still so constant, lord.
modern: I am still so faithful, my lord.

origin: What, to perverseness?
modern: What, faithful to being mean and nasty?

origin: You, uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out That e'er devotion tendered—what shall I do?
modern: I breathed from my soul the most faithful offerings to your ungrateful altars that any devoted person has ever offered—what more am I supposed to do?

origin: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.
modern: You can do whatever you want as long as it’s socially appropriate.

origin: Come, boy, with me.
modern: Come with me, boy.

origin: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.
modern: And I would die a thousand deaths cheerfully, if it made your life easier.

origin: Where goes Cesario?
modern: Where’s Cesario going?

origin: Ay me, detested!
modern: That’s the truth.

origin: Who does beguile you?
modern: Who tricked you?

origin: Who does do you wrong?
modern: Who treated you badly?

origin: Hast thou forgot thyself?
modern: Have you completely forgotten?

origin: Is it so long?— Call forth the holy father.
modern: Has it been so long?

origin: Come, away!
modern: Call the priest.

origin: Whither, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.
modern: Go where, my lord?—Cesario, my husband, stay here.

origin: Husband?
modern: Husband?

origin: Ay, husband.
modern: Yes, husband.

origin: Can he that deny?
modern: Can he deny it?

origin: Her husband, sirrah?
modern: Are you her husband, boy?

origin: No, my lord, not I. Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear That makes thee strangle thy propriety.
modern: No, my lord, not me.

origin: Fear not, Cesario.
modern: But don’t be afraid, Cesario.

origin: Be that thou know’st thou art, and then thou art As great as that thou fear’st.
modern: Be the person you know you are, and you’ll be as powerful as this person you fear.

origin: O, welcome, father!
modern: Oh, hello, father!

origin: Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence, Here to unfold (though lately we intended To keep in darkness what occasion now Reveals before ’tis ripe) what thou dost know Hath newly passed between this youth and me.
modern: Father, could I please ask you to tell these people what happened between me and this young man?

origin: My lord, I do protest—    O, do not swear!
modern: My lord, I swear to you— Oh, don’t swear!

origin: Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
modern: Keep a little bit of honesty, even if you’re afraid.

origin: For the love of God, a surgeon!
modern: For the love of God, call a doctor!

origin: Send one presently to Sir Toby.
modern: Sir Toby needs help right away.

origin: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

origin: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too.
modern: He cut my head and gave Sir Toby a bloody head, too.

origin: For the love of God, your help!
modern: For the love of God, help us!

origin: I had rather than forty pound I were at home.
modern: I’d give forty pounds to be safe at home right now.

origin: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?
modern: Who did this, Sir Andrew?

origin: The Count’s gentleman, one Cesario.
modern: The count’s messenger, Cesario.

origin: We took him for a coward, but he’s the very devil incardinate.
modern: We thought he was a coward, but he fights like a devil.

origin: My gentleman, Cesario?
modern: My Cesario?

origin: Od’s lifelings, here he is!—You broke my head for nothing, and that that I did, I was set on to do ’t by Sir Toby.
modern: Anything I did to you, I did it because Sir Toby made me.

origin: Why do you speak to me?
modern: Why are you talking like this?

origin: I never hurt you.
modern: I never hurt you.

origin: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me.
modern: If a bloody head counts as a hurt, then you hurt me.

origin: I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb.
modern: Apparently you think there’s nothing unusual about a bloody head.

origin: Here comes Sir Toby halting.
modern: Here comes Sir Toby, limping.

origin: You shall hear more.
modern: He’ll tell you more of the story.

origin: But if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.
modern: If he hadn’t been drunk, he would’ve really roughed you up.

origin: How now, gentleman?
modern: Hello, sir!

origin: How is ’t with you?
modern: How are you?

origin: That’s all one: has hurt me, and there’s the end on ’t.
modern: It doesn’t matter how I am: he hurt me, and that’s that.

origin: FOOL Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone.
modern: Oh, he’s drunk, Sir Toby, for a whole hour now.

origin: His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.
modern: His eyes started glazing over around eight in the morning.

origin: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin.
modern: Then he’s no good.

origin: I hate a drunken rogue.
modern: I hate no-good drunks.

origin: Away with him!
modern: Take him away!

origin: Who hath made this havoc with them?
modern: Who did this to him?

origin: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
modern: I’ll help you, Sir Toby.

origin: Will you help?—An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull!
modern: Will you help me?—What an ass and a fool, a gullible no-good idiot!

origin: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to.
modern: Get him to bed and make sure his wounds are treated.

origin: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.
modern: But please forgive me, darling, for the sake of the vows we made to each other so recently.

origin: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons!
modern: One face, one voice, one way of dressing, but two people!

origin: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
modern: Antonio, oh my dear Antonio!

origin: How have the hours racked and tortured me Since I have lost thee!
modern: I’ve been so tortured since I lost track of you!

origin: Sebastian are you?
modern: Are you Sebastian?

origin: Fear’st thou that, Antonio?
modern: Do you have any doubts, Antonio?

origin: How have you made division of yourself?
modern: How did you divide yourself in two?

origin: An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin Than these two creatures.
modern: These two people are as identical as two halves of an apple.

origin: Which is Sebastian?
modern: Which one is Sebastian?

origin: Most wonderful!
modern: How unbelievable!

origin: Sebastian was my father; Such a Sebastian was my brother too, So went he suited to his watery tomb.
modern: Sebastian was my father’s name, and my brother was named Sebastian too.

origin: A spirit I am indeed, But am in that dimension grossly clad Which from the womb I did participate.
modern: I am a spirit, yes, since I have a soul.

origin: Were you a woman, as the rest goes even, I should my tears let fall upon your cheek And say “Thrice-welcome, drownèd Viola!” My father had a mole upon his brow.
modern: If you were a woman, I’d hug you now and cry, and say “Welcome back, drowned Viola!” My father had a mole on his forehead.

origin: And so had mine.
modern: Mine did too.

origin: And died that day when Viola from her birth Had numbered thirteen years.
modern: He died on Viola’s thirteenth birthday.

origin: I’ll stay a month longer.
modern: All right, I’ll stay another month.

origin: I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world.
modern: Ah, I’m an odd kind of guy.

origin: I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
modern: Sometimes all I want to do is see plays and go out dancing.

origin: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?
modern: Are you good at those kinds of things?

origin: Wherefore are these things hid?
modern: Why do you hide these things?

origin: Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em?
modern: Why do you keep these talents behind a curtain?

origin: Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture?
modern: Are they likely to get dusty?

origin: Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto?
modern: Why don’t you go off to church dancing one way, and come home dancing another way?

origin: I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
modern: I wouldn’t even pee without dancing a waltz.

origin: What dost thou mean?
modern: What are you thinking?

origin: Is it a world to hide virtues in?
modern: Is this the kind of world where we hide our accomplishments?

origin: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.
modern: Look how shapely your legs are.

origin: Ay, ’tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock.
modern: That’s true.

origin: What shall we do else?
modern: Why not?

origin: Were we not born under Taurus?
modern: Weren’t we both born under Taurus?

origin: Oh, that record is lively in my soul!
modern: Oh, I remember that very clearly!

origin: He finished indeed his mortal act That day that made my sister thirteen years.
modern: It’s true, he died on the day my sister turned thirteen.

origin: Give me thy hand, And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.
modern: Give me your hand and let me see you dressed in woman’s clothing.

origin: The captain that did bring me first on shore Hath my maid’s garments.
modern: The captain who brought me to shore has my women’s clothes.

origin: He, upon some action, Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit, A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
modern: For some reason he’s in prison now on some legal technicality, on Malvolio’s orders.

origin: He shall enlarge him.
modern: He’ll release him.

origin: A most extracting frenzy of mine own From my remembrance clearly banished his.
modern: I was so crazy myself that I forgot all about him.

origin: Truly, madam, he holds Beelzebub at the staves' end as well as a man in his case may do.
modern: Well, he keeps the devil away as well as a man can in his situation.

origin: Has here writ a letter to you.
modern: He’s written you a letter.

origin: I should have given ’t you today morning, but as a madman’s epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.
modern: I would’ve given it to you this morning, but a madman’s letters aren’t Gospel, so it doesn’t matter much if I’m a bit late.

origin: Open ’t, and read it.
modern: Open it and read it.

origin: Look then to be well edified when the fool delivers the madman.
modern: There’s a lot to learn when a fool recites the words of a madman.

origin: How now?
modern: Why are you talking like that?

origin: Art thou mad?
modern: Are you insane?

origin: No, madam, I do but read madness.
modern: No, madam, I’m just reading an insane letter.

origin: An your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow  Prithee, read i' thy right wits.
modern: If you want things done in the right way, you’ll have to let me read a crazy letter in a crazy voice.

origin: So I do, madonna.
modern: No, please, read it like a sane person.

origin: But to read his right wits is to read thus.
modern: I will, my lady, but a sane person reading this would make it sound crazy.

origin: Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.
modern: So listen up, princess.

origin: By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it.
modern: I swear to God, madam, you’ve wronged me, and I’ll tell the whole world.

origin: Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your Ladyship.
modern: You’ve shut me up in a dark room and given your drunken cousin authority over me, but I’m as sane as you are.

origin: Think of me as you please.
modern: I don’t care what you think of me.

origin: I leave my duty a little unthought of and speak out of my injury.
modern: I’m going to forget my duties to you a little bit and complain about the injuries you’ve caused me.

origin: The madly used Malvolio.”  Did he write this?
modern: Signed,    The poorly treated Malvolio.” Did he write this?

origin: Ay, madam.
modern: Yes, madam.

origin: This savors not much of distraction.
modern: Set him free.

origin: See him delivered, Fabian; bring him hither.
modern: Fabian, bring him here.

origin: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
modern: I accept that offer happily, madam.

origin: Is this the madman?
modern: Is this the madman?

origin: Ay, my lord, this same.
modern: Yes, my lord.

origin: How now, Malvolio!
modern: How are you, Malvolio?

origin: Madam, you have done me wrong, Notorious wrong.
modern: Madam, you’ve treated me badly, very badly.

origin: Have I, Malvolio?
modern: I did, Malvolio?

origin: No.
modern: No.

origin: Tell me why.
modern: Tell me why you did it.

origin: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing, Though, I confess, much like the character.
modern: I’m sorry, Malvolio, but this isn’t my writing, though I admit it looks like mine.

origin: But out of question, ’tis Maria’s hand.
modern: It’s definitely Maria’s handwriting.

origin: And now I do bethink me, it was she First told me thou wast mad, then camest in smiling, And in such forms which here were presupposed Upon thee in the letter.
modern: Now that I think about it, Maria was the one who first told me you were insane.

origin: Prithee, be content.
modern: I promise.

origin: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was one, sir, in this interlude, one Sir Topas, sir, but that’s all one.
modern: Well, you know, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.” Anyway, I was part of the trick, sir.

origin: He hath been most notoriously abused.
modern: He really was tricked horribly.

origin: Pursue him and entreat him to a peace.
modern: Go after him and try to calm him down a little.

origin: He hath not told us of the captain yet.
modern: He still hasn’t told us about the captain.

origin: Cesario, come, For so you shall be, while you are a man.
modern: Cesario, come here.

origin: Taurus!
modern: Taurus!

origin: That’s sides and heart.
modern: That governs the torso and heart, doesn’t it?

origin: No, sir, it is legs and thighs.
modern: No, the legs and thighs.

origin: Let me see the caper.
modern: Let me see you dance.

origin: He hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.
modern: He’s only known you for three days, but he’s already treating you like a close friend.

origin: No, believe me.
modern: No, not at all.

origin: I thank you.
modern: Thanks for telling me.

origin: Here comes the count.
modern: Here comes the Duke now.

origin: Who saw Cesario, ho?
modern: Has anyone seen Cesario?

origin: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds, Rather than make unprofited return.
modern: Be loud and obnoxious.

origin: I think not so, my lord.
modern: I don’t think so, my lord.

origin: Dear lad, believe it.
modern: My boy, it’s true.

origin: For they shall yet belie thy happy years That say thou art a man.
modern: Anyone who says you’re a man must not notice how young you are.

origin: I know thy constellation is right apt For this affair.
modern: I know you’re the right person for this job.

origin: I’ll do my best To woo your lady— Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.
modern: I’ll do my best to make this lady love you.

origin: Give me excess of it that, surfeiting, The appetite may sicken, and so die.
modern: Give me too much of it, so I’ll get sick of it and stop loving.

origin: Oh, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound, That breathes upon a bank of violets, Stealing and giving odor.
modern: Oh, it sounded like a sweet breeze blowing gently over a bank of violets, taking their scent with it.

origin: Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
modern: It doesn’t sound as sweet as it did before.

origin: So full of shapes is fancy That it alone is high fantastical.
modern: Love is so vivid and fantastical that nothing compares to it.

origin: Will you go hunt, my lord?
modern: Do you want to go hunting, my lord?

origin: What, Curio?
modern: Hunting what, Curio?

origin: My lady will hang thee for thy absence.
modern: Lady Olivia will have you executed for not showing up.

origin: Let her hang me.
modern: So let her execute me.

origin: Make that good.
modern: How do you know?

origin: He shall see none to fear.
modern: Well, he’ll be dead, so he won’t see anything.

origin: A good lenten answer.
modern: That’s a lame answer.

origin: I can tell thee where that saying was born, of “I fear no colors.”  Where, good Mistress Mary?
modern: Where, good Miss Mary?

origin: In the wars.
modern: From soldiers.

origin: Well, God give them wisdom that have it.
modern: Well, we all have our special gifts.

origin: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.
modern: But still, she’s going to kill you for being gone so long.

origin: You are resolute, then?
modern: You’ve made up your mind, then?

origin: Well, go thy way.
modern: Well, go along now.

origin: If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve’s flesh as any in Illyria.
modern: You’d be the funniest person in Illyria… if Sir Toby ever stopped drinking.

origin: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that.
modern: Shut up, you troublemaker, no more of that.

origin: Here comes my lady.
modern: Here comes my lady.

origin: Take the fool away.
modern: Get that fool out of here.

origin: Do you not hear, fellows?
modern: Didn’t you hear her, guys?

origin: Take away the lady.
modern: Get the lady out of here.

origin: Go to, you’re a dry fool.
modern: Oh, go away, you’re a boring fool.

origin: I’ll no more of you.
modern: I don’t want to have anything to do with you anymore.

origin: Besides, you grow dishonest.
modern: Besides, you’ve gotten unreliable.

origin: If he cannot, let the botcher mend him.
modern: If he cannot, let the tailor mend him.

origin: Anything that’s mended is but patched.
modern: Anything that’s mended is only patched up.

origin: Virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue.
modern: A good person who does something wrong is only patched up with sin.

origin: If that this simple syllogism will serve, so.
modern: If this logic works, that’s great.

origin: If it will not, what remedy?
modern: If not, what can you do about it?

origin: Sir, I bade them take away you.
modern: I told them to take  Oh, what a big mistake!

origin: Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.
modern: Please let me prove you’re a fool.

origin: Can you do it?
modern: Can you do that?

origin: Dexterously, good madonna.
modern: Easily, madam.

origin: I must catechise you for it, madonna.
modern: I’ll have to ask you some questions, madam.

origin: Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
modern: Please answer, my good little student.

origin: Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide your proof.
modern: I’m listening to you only because I’ve got nothing better to do.

origin: Good madonna, why mournest thou?
modern: My dear madam, why are you in mourning?

origin: Good fool, for my brother’s death.
modern: My dear fool, because my brother died.

origin: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.
modern: I think his soul’s in hell, my lady.

origin: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.
modern: I know his soul’s in heaven, fool.

origin: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven.
modern: Then you’re a fool for being sad that your brother’s soul is in heaven.

origin: Take away the fool, gentlemen.
modern: Take away this fool, gentlemen.

origin: What think you of this fool, Malvolio?
modern: What do you think of this fool, Malvolio?

origin: Doth he not mend?
modern: Isn’t he getting funnier?

origin: Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death shake him.
modern: Yes, and he’ll keep getting funnier till he dies.

origin: Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.
modern: Old age always makes people act funny—even wise people, but fools more than anybody.

origin: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!
modern: I hope you go senile soon, sir, so you can become a more foolish fool!

origin: Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.
modern: Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I’m not smart, but he wouldn’t bet two cents that you’re not a fool.

origin: How say you to that, Malvolio?
modern: What do you say to that, Malvolio?

origin: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal.
modern: I’m surprised you enjoy the company of this stupid troublemaker.

origin: I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that
modern: The other day I saw him defeated in a

origin: I protest I take these wise men that crow so at these set kind of fools no better than the fools' zanies.
modern: I swear, anyone smart who laughs at these courts jesters is nothing but a jester’s apprentice.

origin: Oh, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite.
modern: Malvolio, your vanity is damaging your good taste.

origin: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speakest well of fools!
modern: You speak so highly of fools!

origin: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.
modern: Madam, there’s a young gentleman at the gate who really wants to speak to you.

origin: From the Count Orsino, is it?
modern: Was he sent by Count Orsino?

origin: I know not, madam.
modern: I don’t know, madam.

origin: Tis a fair young man, and well attended.
modern: He’s a good-looking young man, and there are a lot of people with him.

origin: Who of my people hold him in delay?
modern: Who’s talking to him now?

origin: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.
modern: Sir Toby, madam, your relative.

origin: He speaks nothing but madman.
modern: He talks nothing but nonsense.

origin: If it be a suit from the count, I am sick, or not at home.
modern: If he’s got a message from the count, tell him I’m sick, or not home.

origin: What is he at the gate, cousin?
modern: Who’s that at the gate, uncle?

origin: A gentleman.
modern: A gentleman.

origin: A gentleman?
modern: A gentleman?

origin: What gentleman?
modern: What gentleman?

origin: Good Sir Toby!
modern: There’s some gentleman out there.— Good Sir Toby!

origin: Lechery!
modern: Nonsense.

origin: I defy lechery.
modern: I defy brain-death!

origin: There’s one at the gate.
modern: I told you, someone’s at the gate.

origin: Ay, marry, what is he?
modern: Yes, but who is he?

origin: Let him be the devil, an he will, I care not.
modern: Let him be the devil if he wants to, I don’t care.

origin: Give me faith, say I.
modern: God will protect me.

origin: What’s a drunken man like, fool?
modern: Tell me what a drunk is like, fool.

origin: Like a drowned man, a fool and a madman.
modern: He’s a fool, a madman, and a drowned man.

origin: One draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.
modern: The first drink makes him a fool, the second makes him crazy, and the third drowns him.

origin: Go look after him.
modern: Go take care of him.

origin: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you.
modern: Madam, that young man out there says he’s got to speak to you.

origin: I told him you were sick.
modern: I told him you were sick.

origin: He takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you.
modern: He claimed he knew that, and that’s why he’s come to speak with you.

origin: I told him you were asleep.
modern: I told him you were asleep.

origin: He seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you.
modern: He claimed to know that already too, and said that’s the reason he’s come to speak with you.

origin: What is to be said to him, lady?
modern: What can I say to him, lady?

origin: He’s fortified against any denial.
modern: He’s got an answer for everything.

origin: Tell him he shall not speak with me.
modern: Tell him he’s not going to speak with me.

origin: What manner of man?
modern: Just a man, like any other.

origin: Of very ill manner.
modern: But what’s he like?

origin: He’ll speak with you, will you or no.
modern: He insists he’ll speak with you whether you want him to or not.

origin: Of what personage and years is he?
modern: How old is he?

origin: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy, as a squash is before ’tis a peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple.
modern: Not old enough to be a man, but not young enough to be a boy.

origin: Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.
modern: He’s somewhere between boy and man.

origin: He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly.
modern: He’s very handsome and speaks well, but he’s very young.

origin: One would think his mother’s milk were scarce out of him.
modern: He looks like he just recently stopped breastfeeding.

origin: Let him approach.
modern: Show him in.

origin: Call in my gentlewoman.
modern: Call in my maid.

origin: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
modern: Maria, our lady wants you.

origin: Give me my veil.
modern: Give me my veil.

origin: Come, throw it o'er my face.
modern: Come, put it over my face.

origin: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?
modern: Which one of you is the lady of the house?

origin: Speak to me.
modern: You can speak to me.

origin: I shall answer for her.
modern: I represent her.

origin: Your will?
modern: What do you want?

origin: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her.
modern: What stunning, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty—but please, tell me if you’re the lady of the house, because I’ve never seen her.

origin: I would be loath to cast away my speech, for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it.
modern: I’d hate to waste my speech on the wrong person, because It’s very well written and I spent a lot of time and energy memorizing it.

origin: Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn.
modern: Beautiful ladies, please don’t treat me badly.

origin: I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.
modern: I’m very sensitive, and even the smallest bit of rudeness hurts my feelings.

origin: Whence came you, sir?
modern: Where do you come from, sir?

origin: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part.
modern: I’m sorry, but I memorized what I’m supposed to say here today, and that question isn’t part of the speech I learned.

origin: Good gentle one, give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.
modern: Please, my lady, just confirm that you’re the lady of the house so I can get on with my speech.

origin: Are you a comedian?
modern: Are you an actor?

origin: No, my profound heart.
modern: No, madam.

origin: And yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play.
modern: But I swear I’m not the person I’m playing.

origin: Are you the lady of the house?
modern: Are you the lady of the house?

origin: If I do not usurp myself, I am.
modern: I am, unless I somehow stole this role.

origin: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve.
modern: If you’re the lady of the house, then it’s true you’re stealing your role, because what’s yours to give away is not yours to keep for yourself.

origin: But this is from my commission.
modern: But that’s not part of what I’m supposed to say.

origin: I will on with my speech in your praise and then show you the heart of my message.
modern: I’ll go on with my speech praising you, and then I’ll get to the point.

origin: Come to what is important in ’t.
modern: Get to the point now.

origin: I forgive you the praise.
modern: I’ll let you get away with skipping the praise.

origin: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis poetical.
modern: That’s too bad, because I spent a long time memorizing it, and it’s poetic.

origin: It is the more like to be feigned.
modern: That means it’s more likely to be fake.

origin: I pray you, keep it in.
modern: Please, keep it to yourself.

origin: If you be not mad, be gone.
modern: If you’re just insane, then get out of here.

origin: Will you hoist sail, sir?
modern: Ready to set sail, sir?

origin: Here lies your way.
modern: The door’s right here.

origin: Tell me your mind.
modern: Tell me what you want.

origin: Speak your office.
modern: Tell me what it’s about.

origin: It alone concerns your ear.
modern: It’s about you.

origin: I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage.
modern: I’m not bringing any declarations of war or demands for cash.

origin: He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour.

origin: What’s she?

modern: You know, he got me in trouble with the lady of the house once when I arranged a bear-baiting here.

origin: To anger him, we’ll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue.
modern: We’ll have another bear-baiting just to make him angry, and we’ll mock him till he’s black and blue.

origin: Shall we not, Sir Andrew?
modern: Won’t we, Sir Andrew?

origin: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.
modern: If we don’t, it’ll be the biggest disappointment of our lives.

origin: Here comes the little villain.
modern: Here comes the little villain herself.

origin: How now, my metal of India?
modern: How are you, my golden girl?

origin: Get you all three into the boxtree.
modern: Hide behind the boxwood hedge, all three of you.

origin: Malvolio’s coming down this walk.
modern: Malvolio’s coming down the path.

origin: He has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour.
modern: He’s been over there practicing how to act for the past half hour.

origin: Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.
modern: This letter’s going to turn him into a starry-eyed idiot.
